site_title: Modern twists on local favourites at Baba Chews
summary: Baba Chews Bar and Eatery has introduced a new menu featuring modern twists on local favorites. The restaurant now offers dishes such as ikan laksa satay, pork belly with turmeric, and Nonya yakitori. New items also include pita pockets with flavors like Szechuan lamb leg and chilli crab. SPH subscribers can enjoy 15% off their total bill in October, with the first 20 subscribers receiving a $50 nett return voucher.

site_title: More than pride riding on derby
summary: Arsenal and Tottenham Hotspur, two top contenders for the English Premier League title, face off in the highly anticipated north London derby. Arsenal, currently top of the table, is seeking to prove its title credentials, while Spurs aim to capitalize on their recent form after snatching a top-four finish last season. The match is the first in the league for both teams to be top of the table since 2007, with Arsenal looking to subdue striker Harry Kane, who has scored a record 13 league goals in 15 north London derbies.

site_title: Global health architecture needs revamp ahead of future pandemics: Indonesia health minister
summary: Indonesian Health Minister Budi Gunadi Sadikin emphasized the need for a global health architecture overhaul ahead of future pandemics. He highlighted the importance of standardized protocols, a single genome sequencing network, and essential services during lockdowns. Sadikin also discussed Indonesia's healthcare reform plan, which includes increasing primary healthcare, hospital facilities, and human resources. However, the country faces significant challenges, including a shortage of doctors, with only 12,000 produced annually over the past decade, and a need for trust and credibility from philanthropic organizations.

site_title: Euro zone inflation at double-digit record piles pressure on ECB
summary: The euro zone has reached a double-digit inflation rate of 10% in September, surpassing economists' median forecast of 9.7%. This marks the fifth consecutive month of inflation exceeding expectations, driven by energy and food prices. The European Central Bank (ECB) faces pressure to continue raising interest rates aggressively to combat inflation, with investors pricing in a possible second consecutive 75 basis-point increase. Officials warn of the risk of a persistent upward shift in inflation expectations and a potential recession, particularly with Russia's gas supply disruptions and winter approaching.

site_title: askST: Will property cooling measures affect August BTO applicants?
summary: Singapore's new property cooling measures, introduced on Sept 30, will take effect from November BTO launches. The measures include a 15-month wait for private home owners selling their homes to buy HDB resale flats, and a tightened 85% loan-to-value limit for HDB loans. However, successful applicants in August and earlier BTO launches will not be affected, and those who sold their private properties before the measures were announced will still be able to buy HDB flats after a 15-month wait. The wait-out period will not apply to seniors and their spouses moving to smaller resale flats.

site_title: Sporting Life: Chess reminds us sport is full of crooked moves
summary: World chess champion Magnus Carlsen has accused fellow Grandmaster Hans Niemann of cheating. The accusation comes after Carlsen's loss to Niemann in a tournament. This isn't the first time Niemann has faced cheating allegations, with a 2019 incident involving a hidden earpiece. The incident has sparked debate over the integrity of chess tournaments, with Carlsen calling for stricter measures to prevent cheating.

site_title: Football: Neymar forced onto back foot over Bolsonaro backing
summary: Brazilian footballer Neymar faced criticism after endorsing far-right President Jair Bolsonaro on social media, just days before a polarized election. Neymar posted a TikTok video of himself dancing to a pro-Bolsonaro campaign song, sparking outrage among many users. Bolsonaro quickly retweeted Neymar's endorsement, with former Brazilian striker Walter Casagrande calling Neymar's support "incoherent" and "lacking social awareness." Neymar responded on Twitter, saying those who attack differing opinions are hypocritical. The controversy has sparked debate about Neymar's social awareness and his endorsement of a polarizing figure.

site_title: CNA wins best news website at global contest
summary: Mediacorp's CNA has won the Best News Website or Mobile Service award at the Digital Media Awards Worldwide 2022, beating regional winners from Africa, Asia, Europe, Latin America, North America, and South Asia. This marks the first time a South-east Asian news network has won the award, following previous recipients such as The Washington Post and The Guardian. CNA's revamped website and app, launched in August 2021, were recognized for their design, content, and user experience, technical implementation, and value to readers.

site_title: Construction on Riviera station on Cross Island Line’s Punggol extension to start in early 2023
summary: Construction on the Riviera station on the Cross Island Line's Punggol extension is set to start in early 2023, with a $1.1 billion contract awarded to a joint venture between Japan's Taisei Corporation and China State Construction Engineering Corporation. Passenger service is targeted to begin in 2032, with safety measures and ground improvement works to be implemented before construction commences. The 4.3km-long tunnel will feature two tracks and is expected to improve connectivity for over 40,000 households in the eastern, north-eastern, and western corridors.

site_title: Weakened pound spurs uptick in interest here in travel, property buying in the UK
summary: The British pound has weakened to an all-time low of US$1.0327, sparking an uptick in interest from Singaporeans to buy property in the UK and travel there. With a 15% increase in searches for flights to the UK, more Singaporeans are exploring better exchange rates. Property agent Doris Tan notes it's a buyer's market, while travel booking website Expedia sees increased interest in UK destinations. However, experts caution against making big-ticket purchases due to increased taxes and rising interest rates, advising those to consider the long-term benefits and potential losses.

site_title: Sea's Shopee faces boycott calls in Philippines over brand ambassador
summary: Shopee, an e-commerce business from Singapore's Sea Limited, faces boycott calls in the Philippines after naming actress and singer Toni Gonzaga as its brand ambassador, a staunch supporter of President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. The move sparked widespread backlash on social media, with over 340,000 tweets and top trends of #ByeShopee and #BoycottShopee. The backlash comes as Shopee struggles with ballooning losses and declining shares, down 76% this year. Gonzaga defended her appointment, saying she was chosen for her "mass appeal," but the move has raised concerns about the company's ties to the Marcos administration.

site_title: GIC seeks Japan property deals as yen falls and tourists return
summary: Singapore's GIC seeks Japan property deals amid falling yen and tourist surge. The sovereign wealth fund is evaluating hotels, resorts, and traditional inns in key cities like Tokyo and Okinawa. GIC recently closed a deal to buy properties from Japanese conglomerate Seibu Holdings for low single-digit billions of dollars. The fund is attracted to Japan's low financing costs and sees an increase in attractiveness due to its rising inbound tourism. With an estimated $690 billion in assets, GIC is one of the world's largest sovereign wealth funds and aims to do more Japan real estate investments.

site_title: 'Where do I live for 15 months?': Extended wait-out period for HDB resale flat leaves some frustrated
summary: The Singapore government has introduced a 15-month wait-out period for buyers of non-subsidized HDB resale flats, effectively banning them from buying a new flat if they sell their private properties within six months of purchasing the HDB flat. This move aims to slow the flow of "hot money" from private property owners to HDB properties, but has left some buyers frustrated, claiming the policy is unfair to those with genuine needs to downgrade. The move is part of a broader set of cooling measures announced by the government, including stricter loan criteria and reduced loan-to-value limits.

site_title: Capgemini moves Asia-Pacific HQ to Singapore from Hong Kong
summary: Capgemini has officially opened its Asia-Pacific headquarters in Singapore, relocating from Hong Kong. The French multinational will run key functions from a new 1,244 square meter office in the Marina Bay Financial Centre area. The company aims to accelerate its growth in Singapore, exploring options for expansion through acquisitions and organic growth. Singapore is a key growth pillar for Capgemini, with financial services, public sector, and industries like consumer goods and retail. Revenue in the Asia-Pacific region rose 41.5% year-over-year, driven by growth areas in digital transformation, customer relationship management, and sustainability.

site_title: US stocks end lower, adding to week's losses
summary: US stocks ended lower on Friday, adding to the week's losses, amid worries over inflation and the Russia-Ukraine conflict. A slightly slower inflation rate in August still exceeded expectations, leading to a hike in interest rates. The S&P 500 fell 1.5% for the day and nearly 3% for the week. Russian President Vladimir Putin annexed four parts of Ukraine, while a shelling attack killed 30 people in Ukraine's Zaporizhzhia region. Individual companies such as Nike, Carnival, Norwegian, and Royal Caribbean plummeted due to lower profits and higher operating costs.

site_title: Watch out, cheats: ACS (Independent) exploring the use of artificial intelligence to invigilate exams
summary: Singapore's Anglo-Chinese School (Independent) is exploring the use of artificial intelligence (AI) to invigilate exams, aiming to detect irregular behavior and reduce manpower needed. The school launched a tender to develop and operate an AI system that analyzes student actions, such as frequent head movements or hand movements. The system, built on closed-circuit television (CCTV) cameras, has already been used in school-based exams with a 30% manpower savings. The Ministry of Education has given its approval for the trial, which will provide insights on the effectiveness of cameras and AI for invigilation.

site_title: Bean curd maker fined $4,200 for failing to keep premises clean
summary: A Singaporean bean curd maker, Hensin Food, was fined $4,200 for failing to maintain clean premises, resulting in a widespread cockroach infestation. The company was suspended and recalled its product, tau kwa, after an inspection by the Singapore Food Agency in January. The agency emphasized the importance of joint responsibility in food safety and urged food operators to ensure proper hygiene and training. The incident highlights the need for strict enforcement of food safety regulations, with offenders facing fines of up to $10,000 or jail terms of up to 12 months.

site_title: Singapore property stocks steady after roll-out of cooling measures
summary: Singapore property stocks remained steady after the roll-out of cooling measures, with City Developments closing 1 cent lower at $7.60. Market experts attributed the muted reaction to the limited and mild nature of the measures. Despite this, some stocks even experienced a relief rally during the trading session, indicating a cautious optimism among investors. The measures were seen as insufficient to significantly impact the market.

site_title: Man slashed passer-by with razor blade after hearing voices calling him a transvestite
summary: A 33-year-old Singaporean man, Mohd S. Muhibullah Said Abdullah, pleaded guilty to three counts of voluntarily causing hurt for slashing a stranger, John Ryan Baguistan Jimenez, with a razor blade after hearing voices calling him a "transvestite". Muhibullah, who worked as a packer, became agitated after hearing voices and attacked Jimenez with the blade on March 14, 2022. He suffered an 8.5cm laceration on his neck and was taken to hospital. Muhibullah is set to return to court on October 14 for sentencing and may face a mandatory treatment order for his mental condition.

site_title: Golf: PGA Tour accuses LIV Golf of interfering with its contracts
summary: The US PGA Tour has filed a countersuit against LIV Golf, accusing the Saudi-backed circuit of interfering with its contracts by luring players away with astronomical sums of money. The Tour claims LIV has "falsely informed" players they can break their contracts to play in LIV events, and that LIV offered significant sums to breach the agreements. The countersuit seeks damages for lost profits, reputational harm, and other costs. LIV has maintained its confidence in the legal battle, stating it will "right these wrongs" in court.

site_title: S'pore property stocks steady after roll-out of latest restrictions
summary: Singapore property stocks remained stable after the release of the latest property cooling measures, with some even experiencing a relief rally. City Developments, a key indicator of the property sector's performance, closed at $7.60, down just one cent on a low trading volume of 3.4 million shares. This muted response suggests that investors are adapting to the new restrictions, and the sector is expected to continue its steady performance despite the measures.

site_title: SCDF rescues worker stuck on gondola at Teck Whye HDB block
summary: A male worker was stuck on a gondola between the 8th and 9th storeys of a Teck Whye HDB block in Singapore for at least 40 minutes before being rescued by the SCDF. The SCDF's elite Disaster Assistance and Rescue Team (Dart) responded and used a lowering system to secure the worker, who had no visible injuries. The worker refused hospital treatment and was left at the scene. The incident occurred on Friday, with the SCDF assessing the gondola's stability and condition of the worker before the rescue.

site_title: Downgraders' 15-month wait will moderate demand for HDB resale flats: Desmond Lee
summary: Singapore's 15-month wait-out period for private property owners to buy non-subsidized HDB resale flats aims to moderate demand and keep prices affordable, especially for first-time buyers. The measure, part of a new round of cooling measures, restricts resale flat purchases to 15 months after selling a private property. Exceptions include seniors and those with genuine housing needs. The aim is to prevent overborrowing in the market, which has shown signs of overheating, and protect home buyers from future difficulties in servicing loans.

site_title: S'poreans will not miss out on opportunities in top management: Tan See Leng
summary: Singaporean Manpower Minister Tan See Leng has reassured that the One Pass scheme, which brings in global talent, will not pass Singaporeans over for opportunities in top management. Instead, it will create more opportunities for locals to work alongside experts and progress in their careers. The government supports businesses in growing the local talent pool through leadership development schemes, and takes fair consideration seriously to prevent discriminatory practices. Local employment has continued to grow, and unemployment rates have recovered to pre-Covid-19 levels.

site_title: Formula 1: Fitness, courage, luck - Singapore night race winner will need all three
summary: The Singapore Grand Prix has been described as an "oven" due to its intense heat, with drivers needing to be physically and mentally fit to compete. Ferrari's Carlos Sainz and McLaren's Daniel Ricciardo showcased their endurance with their training sessions. Championship leader Max Verstappen is favored to win, but teammate Charles Leclerc faces an almost impossible task to catch up in the world title standings. Red Bull is also expected to claim the constructors' championship, ending Mercedes' record eight-year run.

site_title: Downgraders' 15-month wait will moderate demand for resale flats: Desmond Lee
summary: Singapore's 15-month wait-out period for private property owners to buy non-subsidized HDB resale flats will moderate demand, keeping prices affordable for first-time buyers. The measure aims to curb overborrowing in the market, which has shown signs of overheating. The wait-out period will apply to most private property owners, except those aged 55 and above or those with genuine housing needs. The government will review the measure if demand remains high, and the measures are expected to help moderate prices and meet strong demand in the market.

site_title: Team culture helps Merc cope: Allison
summary: Mercedes team principal Toto Wolff and chief technical officer James Allison emphasized the importance of team culture and values in coping with the team's struggles in the 2022 Formula One season. Despite not winning a race, the team's strong culture of integrity, loyalty, and humility helped them stay productive and optimistic for the future. Allison attributed this to the team's collective efforts, saying "it's the small things done by hundreds of people" that created a sense of unity and purpose. The team is now focusing on getting the car competitive and championship-ready again.

site_title: Football: Lion City Sailors and Dortmund to play at Jalan Besar on Nov 24, tickets from $13
summary: German football club Borussia Dortmund will play an exhibition match with Singapore Premier League side Lion City Sailors on November 24 at the 6,000-seater Jalan Besar Stadium. Tickets are priced from $13 for youth and senior citizens and $25 for adults. The match aims to bring fans closer to the players, with public training sessions and meet-and-greets planned. Despite some Dortmund players missing the World Cup, fans may still have opportunities to meet up-and-coming players like Salih Ozcan and Youssoufa Moukoko.

site_title: Larger HDB resale flats to bear brunt of new cooling measures
summary: Singapore is introducing new cooling measures for HDB resale flats, which will likely drive up rents and impact private home owners. The measures aim to curb overleveraging in the property market amid rising interest rates and a deteriorating economic outlook. This move is seen as a necessary step to prevent market overheating in both the public and private housing markets.

site_title: China's factory activity struggles for a rebound
summary: China's factory activity showed a slight rebound in September, with the manufacturing purchasing managers' index rising to 50.1 from 49.4 in August. However, services slowed, with the non-manufacturing gauge falling to 50.6. The country's economic recovery is being challenged by ongoing lockdowns, a property market downturn, and a severe Covid-19 outbreak, which has shaved 1.1 percentage points from China's GDP growth in the third quarter. The consensus estimate for 2022 growth is 3.4%, with deflationary pressure from the property market risk of further economic strain.

site_title: Capgemini moves Asia-Pacific HQ to Singapore from HK
summary: Capgemini has relocated its Asia-Pacific headquarters from Hong Kong to Singapore, marking a significant move for the French-based business consultancy. The new office, located in the Marina Bay Financial Centre, will oversee the company's regional operations, including its South-east Asia business. CEO Olaf Pietschner stated that the company aims to accelerate growth in Singapore through organic expansion and potential acquisitions. The region has seen a 41.5% year-on-year increase in revenue, driven by growth areas in digital transformation, customer relationship management, and sustainability.

site_title: Green-conscious firms get higher investor interest, attract more talent, say Milken summit speakers
summary: Razer CEO Tan Min-Liang stated that the company aims to switch to fully recycled materials by 2030, citing cost benefits such as cheaper packaging and lower freight costs. This aligns with the growing trend of investors seeking ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) conscious companies. Younger investors are driving interest in sustainable firms, with GIC's head of sustainability noting that companies with good sustainability practices can offer better risk-adjusted returns in the long term. This trend is attracting more talent to green-conscious firms, including Razer, which has helped conserve over 1.2 million trees through its conservation initiative.

site_title: Football: Arteta faces Jesus balancing act over Arsenal star's bookings
summary: Arsenal manager Mikel Arteta faces a balancing act as he tries to let Gabriel Jesus play his natural game while preventing the striker from accumulating more yellow cards that could lead to suspensions. Jesus has already been shown four yellow cards in the Premier League this term, and a fifth would result in a one-match ban. Arteta acknowledges Jesus's fiery temperament but wants to avoid disciplinary issues, having seen it impact the team in previous matches, including a 3-0 loss to Tottenham last season. The team will look to hold their temper better in Saturday's north London derby against Tottenham.

site_title: Global stocks have further to fall despite recent sell-off: Temasek CIO
summary: Global stock markets have more room to decline due to investors yet to price in the odds of an economic downturn and its impact on corporate earnings, according to Temasek's CIO Rohit Sipahimalani. The expected decline, led by the US market, suggests the investment company will be cautious through the next several months. Current valuations do not reflect the risks of a downturn over the next 12-18 months, prompting Temasek to adopt a cautious investment approach, with a focus on long-term trends, companies with pricing power, and large domestic markets amid geopolitical tensions.

site_title: Health screenings, activity classes to keep gig workers healthy, fit
summary: The Health Promotion Board (HPB) is expanding its health initiative for gig workers, which includes quarterly health screenings, health coaching sessions, and mental wellness workshops, to another 7,000 workers by 2024. The initiative, launched in 2019, has already seen 13,000 workers, mostly taxi and private-hire car drivers, participate. Senior Minister of State for Health Janil Puthucheary noted that 70% of gig workers are aged above 40, increasing their risk of chronic conditions. The HPB aims to reach more gig workers through partnerships with platforms and unions.

site_title: Sentek charged with acquiring $81m in gas oil linked to Shell heist
summary: Sentek Marine & Trading, a Singapore-based bunkering firm, has been charged with acquiring over US$56 million in marine gas oil linked to a Shell heist. The firm, one of Singapore's largest marine fuel suppliers, faces 42 charges under the Corruption, Drug Trafficking and Other Serious Crimes Act. Sentek founder Pai Keng Pheng, 59, also faces 43 charges in connection with the case, which includes bribery and obstructing justice. Sentek has denied the charges and plans to claim trial, with its cases set to resume in court on November 11.

site_title: New curbs will indirectly cool private residential market: Expert
summary: Singapore has introduced new property curbs targeting the public housing market, nine months after similar curbs were imposed on private residential prices. The move aims to cool the market, following a 12.7% increase in Housing Board resale prices in 2021 and a further 5.3% rise in the first half of 2022. The curbs are indirect, as they focus on public housing rather than private prices, but are expected to indirectly impact the private market, which has seen hot money flow into public housing. This is the second round of curbs in 2022.

site_title: Potter 'itching to play' after 23 days
summary: Chelsea manager Graham Potter is set to take charge of his first Premier League match after a 23-day wait, as the team travels to Crystal Palace on Saturday. Potter is eager to play, saying "the boys are ready" despite the team's struggles, which include a 7th-place finish with just 10 points from six matches. Chelsea will look to end their losing streak against Palace, who have lost only once in their last six matches but have struggled at home in the Premier League, leaking goals in all three games at Selhurst Park this season.

site_title: New BMW dealer eyeing 2,500 sales within first 2 years
summary: A new BMW dealer, Eurokars, is set to open its showroom in Singapore on October 1. Motor entrepreneur Karsono Kwee aims to capture at least half of the BMW sales previously held by Sime Darby within the first two years, expecting around 2,500 sales.

site_title: Asian shares head for worst month since Covid-19 pandemic started
summary: Asian shares are headed for the worst month since the Covid-19 pandemic began, with Japan's Nikkei 225 and South Korea's Kospi experiencing significant losses. Despite Chinese factory activity data beating expectations, MSCI's Asia-Pacific shares index is set to record a 12.5% drop for September, the largest since 2020. Rising interest rates, slowing growth, and a strong dollar have intensified, according to Goldman Sachs, and traders remain wary of central bank intervention, particularly from China and Japan.

site_title: Nov 24 date for fans to see, touch Dortmund players
summary: Borussia Dortmund will host an exhibition match against Singapore's Lion City Sailors on November 24 at the Jalan Besar Stadium. The game will be part of the mid-season World Cup break and will feature public training sessions and opportunities for fans to meet and greet players. Tickets are priced from $13 for youth and senior citizens and $25 for adults, with the aim of bringing fans closer to players. The game was chosen for its compact seating arrangement, allowing fans to be near the pitch, and was seen as a way to generate a lively atmosphere.

site_title: Fans out in force as S'pore F1 kicks off
summary: Formula One fans flocked to the Marina Bay Street Circuit in Singapore for the first practice session of the Singapore Airlines Singapore Grand Prix, with attendance potentially reaching its highest level since the event's inception in 2008. Fans from the region and abroad, including a Filipino couple who waited nearly two years to attend, were seen cheering on their favorite drivers, with some even climbing the fence to get a better view. The event marks a return to normality after the pandemic, with fans expecting the return of the night race to boost tourism and local economy.

site_title: 35%-40% jump in Covid-19 cases week on week in last few days: MOH
summary: Singapore has seen a 35-40% week-on-week increase in Covid-19 cases, driven primarily by the Omicron variant BA.2.75, which accounts for about a quarter of daily infections. The country reported 3,715 new cases on Friday, a 58.6% jump from the previous week. Despite higher numbers, there is no evidence of more severe disease or significant impact on the healthcare system. The Ministry of Health urges those who haven't received their booster shots to get them, and advises the public to exercise personal and social responsibility, including wearing masks in crowded places and staying home if unwell.

site_title: Global health architecture needs revamp, says Indonesian minister
summary: Indonesian Health Minister Budi Gunadi Sadikin emphasized the need for a global health architecture overhaul, citing the COVID-19 pandemic as a major global health crisis. He called for standardized protocols, a single genome sequencing network, and improved resource allocation. The minister also highlighted Indonesia's healthcare reform plan, which includes increasing primary healthcare, hospital facilities, and human resources. However, he noted significant barriers, including a shortage of 150,000 doctors in a country that produces only 12,000 per year. The government is working to improve trust with philanthropists, but earning trust is a long-term process.

site_title: HDB ballot results for August BTO exercise delayed due to high number of applicants
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) has delayed the release of ballot results for the August Build-To-Order (BTO) sales exercise due to a high number of applicants, exceeding 34,000. The results were initially expected in September but will now be announced around mid-October. The delay is to verify applicants' eligibility and conduct computer balloting. HDB has also clarified that successful applicants will not be subject to the latest cooling measures, which aim to moderate demand for HDB resale flats. The loan amount for successful applicants will remain at up to 85% of the BTO flat price.

site_title: More wet weather, thundery showers expected in first half of October
summary: Singapore can expect wet weather with thundery showers in the first half of October, according to the Meteorological Service Singapore. Showers are expected to occur between morning and early afternoon, with daily temperatures ranging from 24-33°C. The rainy south-west monsoon is currently affecting the island, and strong winds in the Strait of Malacca may cause additional thundery showers in the second week of October, leading to above-average rainfall. This follows above-average rainfall in many parts of the island in September, with the lowest daily minimum temperature recorded at 21.6°C on September 25.

site_title: Lin makes late eagle to take lead at Texas event
summary: China's Lin Xiyu shot a six-under 65 in the opening round of the Volunteers of America Classic, taking the lead by one shot after eagling the par-five 17th hole. Lin, 26, is seeking her first LPGA win, having finished in the top 10 in September. Lizette Salas and Atthaya Thitikul trail Lin by one shot, with Salas setting the early pace with a bogey-free 66. The Thai players, Thitikul and Moriya Jutanugarn, are tied for fourth with Lexi Thompson and others.

site_title: Lower household electricity bills in Q4 with first tariff fall in over a year
summary: Singapore households will experience slightly lower electricity bills starting October 1, with the electricity tariff decreasing by 1.4% to 29.74 cents per kilowatt hour. This is the first decrease in over a year, attributed to lower fuel costs. The gas tariff for households will also decrease by 0.36 cents per kWh. However, experts warn that the respite may be short-lived due to ongoing global energy market volatility and the looming European embargo on Russian oil, which could drive oil prices up further.

site_title: S'poreans will not miss out on senior roles amid schemes to draw global talent: Minister
summary: Singapore Minister for Manpower Tan See Leng has addressed concerns that the new Overseas Networks and Expertise (One) Pass will lead to Singaporeans being passed over for senior roles. Tan stated that the pass aims to bring in global talent, creating more opportunities for Singaporeans. The government supports businesses in growing the local talent pool through leadership development schemes, and the Ministry of Manpower will take action against discriminatory employers. Unemployment rates have recovered to pre-Covid-19 levels, and local employment continues to grow every year since 2020.

site_title: SPH subscribers get 10% discount on The Sound Of Music musical
summary: The Sound of Music musical is set to open in Singapore in November, marking the first international musical to perform since the pandemic. Directed by Tony Award winner Jack O'Brien and choreographed by Danny Mefford, the show tells the true story of Maria's impact on the von Trapp family. SPH subscribers can purchase discounted tickets (10% off) for shows between Dec 10-18. Additionally, attendees of the Dec 10 shows will have the chance to take a photo with the cast, capped at 50 pictures per show.

site_title: 950,000 HDB households to receive third tranche of GST vouchers, rebates in Oct
summary: About 950,000 Singaporean households living in Housing Board flats will receive their third quarterly GST vouchers and S&CC rebates in October. The U-Save vouchers will range from $110 to $190, while S&CC rebates will be half or one month's worth, identical to July payouts. This is the third payout of the financial year, with a final tranche in January 2023. The rebates aim to help lower-to middle-income households defray GST and living expenses, with a total of $720 million disbursed this year.

site_title: Beijing allows 23 cities to lower rates for first-home mortgages
summary: China's central government has allowed 23 cities to lower mortgage rates for primary residence purchases, effective until the end of the year. The move is expected to provide limited relief for the country's struggling housing market. New home prices in top 70 cities dropped 0.29% in August from July and 2.1% from 2021. Analysts, including Pantheon Macroeconomics' Craig Botham, are skeptical about the rate cut's effectiveness, citing a lack of confidence in the market and weak economic conditions. Existing rules for second-home loans remain unchanged.

site_title: Lee vows to show her maternal instincts
summary: Angela Lee, One Championship's atomweight world champion, is set to face Xiong Jingnan for the strawweight title at One Fight Night 2. Lee, a new mother, believes her maternal instincts give her an edge in the cage and is determined to "go through hell" to protect her daughter. The five-round bout will headline the event, which will be broadcast on Amazon Prime in the US. Lee's opponent, Xiong, is seeking her sixth title defense, while Lee aims to become One's first female MMA double champion.

site_title: Green-conscious firms get higher investor interest, attract more talent: Summit speakers
summary: Razer, a gaming technology company, has seen increased investor interest and attracted more talent due to its green-conscious initiatives. The company has helped conserve over 1.2 million trees through its "Razer Green Fund" and aims to switch to recycled materials by 2030. Investors, including those from GIC, are prioritizing environmental, social, and governance (ESG) issues, seeking companies that both perform well and do good. This shift is expected to lead to better risk-adjusted returns in the long term, as companies with strong sustainability practices can attract and retain talent, and manage labor costs.

site_title: Sports World
summary: World No. 2 tennis player Casper Ruud secured a spot at the ATP Finals, reaching the quarter-finals of the Korea Open. He lost to Yoshihito Nishioka in the next round. Meanwhile, China will host its first international badminton tournament since 2019, the World Tour Finals, from December 14-18 in Guangzhou. India will also host its first MotoGP race in 2023 at the Buddh International Circuit in Uttar Pradesh, aiming to expand the sport in the country's large population of 1.4 billion.

site_title: STI breaks 5-day losing streak amid mixed showing in region
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) broke its 5-day losing streak, rising 0.5% to 3,130.24, amid a mixed Asian market performance. Despite concerns over interest rates, US economic health, and the Ukraine war, optimism and gains from local banks UOL, DBS, OCBC, and UOB offset losses. Regional markets were mixed, with Japan's Nikkei 225 down 1.8% and South Korea's Kospi shedding 0.7%, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng and Indonesia's Jakarta Composite indices rose 0.3% and 0.1% respectively.

site_title: Next six weeks before Qatar very important: Klopp
summary: Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp emphasizes the importance of the next six weeks before the Qatar World Cup, citing fixture congestions and player welfare. Despite struggling in the English Premier League with just two wins in six games, Klopp hopes to collect points against fourth-placed Brighton & Hove Albion, who are seeking a new manager after Graham Potter left for Chelsea. The match will be Klopp's first test against Brighton under new manager Roberto de Zerbi, who is known for his attacking style.

site_title: Calls in Philippines to boycott Shopee over new brand ambassador
summary: Philippine consumers are calling for a boycott of Shopee after the e-commerce platform named actress and singer Toni Gonzaga, a supporter of President Ferdinand Marcos Jr, as its brand ambassador. The hashtag #ByeShopee trended on Twitter, with users expressing outrage over the move. Some defended the choice, citing Gonzaga's "mass appeal", but others urged shoppers to switch to rival platform Lazada. The backlash comes as Shopee faces financial struggles, including ballooning losses and a 76% decline in shares this year.

site_title: Singapore eyes role as regional centre for philanthropy: Wong
summary: Singapore aims to become a regional centre for philanthropy, with Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong encouraging family offices, businesses, and individuals to contribute to impactful solutions. The government is reviewing tax incentive schemes to support donors and is working with agencies to identify suitable causes. Wong noted that while Singapore has a growing base of successful entrepreneurs, it lacks a strong tradition of philanthropic giving. He advocates for a combination of private giving and government support to build a stronger social compact and mitigate income and wealth gaps.

site_title: New alliance raises over $300m for philanthropic partnerships
summary: A new alliance has raised over $300 million for philanthropic partnerships to address global issues such as climate change, peace, and education. The alliance, which includes major contributors like the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation and Li Ka Shing Foundation, aims to provide a coordinated approach to delivering impactful outcomes. The partnership will focus on four major priorities: the planet, peace, people, and progress, and is expected to launch in the next 9-12 months with a governance framework to support member interests.

site_title: New BMW dealer aims to sell 2,500 cars within two years
summary: Karsono Kwee, a 74-year-old motor entrepreneur, aims to sell 2,500 BMW cars within two years as Singapore's second BMW dealer. He expects to capture at least half of the sales previously made by Sime Darby, a current BMW dealer in Singapore. The goal is set for the first two years of Eurokars' operation, which began on Saturday with the pre-opening launch of its showroom at 11 Leng Kee Road.

site_title: Optus to pay for new passports for those affected by data hack
summary: Optus, a Singtel-owned telco, will pay for replacing passports of Australians affected by a major cyber attack that compromised 9.8 million customers' personal data. The Australian government has demanded Optus cover the cost, estimated to be around A$661 million. The breach exposed passport numbers of around 3 million people, with replacement passports costing A$193 each. An operation has been launched to protect 10,000 people whose data may have been shared online, with police working to identify and protect those individuals.

site_title: Blow to Dettori's 7th Arc bid
summary: Frankie Dettori's bid for a record-extending seventh Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe suffered a setback, as defending champion Torquator Tasso was given a tough draw from Gate 18. Stay Foolish, a Japanese contender, drew the widest stall, while Aga Khan's Vadeni secured a favorable draw from stall 2. Favorites Alpinista and Luxembourg also received favorable draws, but doubts remain about Vadeni's ability to complete the grueling trip. The Arc is set to take place on Sunday at Longchamp.

site_title: Rwanda's path to progress similar to the one taken by Singapore: President Paul Kagame
summary: Rwandan President Paul Kagame compared his country's development to Singapore's, citing the importance of investing in people, prudent policy choices, and innovative methods. Rwanda has achieved significant economic growth and progress since the 1994 genocide, transforming from a nation on the brink of collapse to a stable and prosperous one. Kagame attributed the country's success to innovation, inclusive governance, and prioritizing technology, and highlighted partnerships with foreign institutions, including Singapore. The two leaders discussed regional and global issues, including the Ukraine war, and pledged to deepen their ties in areas of mutual interest.

site_title: Football: Women's rights group calls on Fifa to kick Iran out of World Cup
summary: A women's rights group, Open Stadiums, has called on FIFA to expel Iran from the World Cup Finals in Qatar due to the country's treatment of women, specifically the denial of female fans' access to games. Despite pressure from FIFA, Iranian authorities continue to restrict female fans' entry to matches, citing security concerns. The group cites FIFA's statutes on human rights and non-discrimination, which breach Iran's actions. The call comes amidst protests in Iran against the death of a young woman in police custody, with at least 83 people killed in nearly two weeks of demonstrations.

site_title: Chess: Federation to form panel to look into cheating allegations
summary: The International Chess Federation (Fide) has formed a three-person panel to investigate allegations of cheating by American Grandmaster Hans Niemann, who was accused by World Chess Champion Magnus Carlsen of cheating in a September match. Niemann had previously been banned from chess.com for online cheating in his youth, but denies wrongdoing in over-the-board games. The panel will examine Carlsen's claims and Niemann's statements regarding online cheating, aiming to ensure a fair ruling and protect the rights of both parties.

site_title: The marina bay oven: Red Bull bursting budget 'idle talk'
summary: The 2022 Singapore Grand Prix has been described as an "oven" due to the intense heat, with cockpit temperatures reaching 60 degrees Celsius. Despite the challenging conditions, all 20 drivers completed Friday's practice sessions unscathed, with Lewis Hamilton setting the fastest time. Max Verstappen, the championship leader, is in a strong position to win the title, with Charles Leclerc trailing by 116 points. Red Bull is expected to claim the constructors' championship, ending Mercedes' eight-year record. The race will be a test of drivers' mental and physical endurance, with the track featuring 23 corners and 308.706km of racing.

site_title: Next 24 hours
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Today's sports schedule includes football matches between Tampines and Geylang, and Tanjong Pagar and Young Lions. English Premier League games feature Arsenal vs Tottenham, Liverpool vs Brighton, and West Ham vs Wolves. Spanish Primera Liga matches include Getafe vs Valladolid and Sevilla vs Atletico. Other sports events include golf's Alfred Dunhill Links C'ship, mixed martial arts' One Championship and UFC Fight Night, motorcycling's Thailand Grand Prix, and tennis' ATP and WTA tournaments. Check local TV listings for specific channels and times.

site_title: Weak pound drives up interest in UK travel, property purchases
summary: The UK's historic weakening of the pound against the US dollar has led to an increase in interest from Singaporeans in buying property and traveling to the UK. Realtor Doris Tan says the pound's weakness is a buying opportunity for Singaporeans, with some having already profited from long-term investments. Meanwhile, Expedia Group reports a 15% rise in searches for UK flights, with London remaining a popular destination. However, experts caution against making large purchases, citing increased interest rates and other taxes that may not offset the benefits of a weaker pound.

site_title: Tennis: Djokovic advances to Tel Aviv semi-finals
summary: Novak Djokovic advanced to the Tel Aviv semi-finals with a 7-6 (7/5), 6-3 victory over Vasek Pospisil. The top-seeded Serb maintains his perfect record in their six meetings and will face 104th-ranked Russian Roman Safiullin in the next match. Djokovic, playing his first singles tournament since Wimbledon, praised Pospisil's fight and expressed his desire to play the Astana Open and Paris Masters tournaments.

site_title: 35% to 40% increase in Covid-19 cases week-on-week in last few days: MOH
summary: Singapore has seen a 35% to 40% increase in Covid-19 cases week-on-week, driven primarily by the Omicron variant BA.2.75, which accounts for about a quarter of all daily infections. The increase translates to 900 to 1,000 more cases daily, with higher numbers expected over the next few weeks. Despite this, there's no evidence of increased disease severity associated with BA.2.75, and the healthcare system remains unaffected. MOH urges the public to exercise personal and social responsibility, including wearing masks and staying home if unwell.

site_title: Pinheiro out 2 months for Mr Malek ride
summary: Singapore Turf Club stewards handed Brazilian jockey Bernardo Pinheiro a two-month suspension for failing to ride Mr Malek with sufficient vigour in the home straight of a Class 1 race on September 24. Pinheiro's suspension begins on October 3 and ends on December 2. In another inquiry, apprentice jockey Akmazani Mazuki was let off the hook for his handling of Amazing Breeze in a Class 3 race.

site_title: More gig workers can go for regular health screenings and more with extended initiative
summary: The Health Promotion Board (HPB) is extending its health initiative for self-employed workers, including gig sector workers, to reach 20,000 more participants by 2024. The initiative, launched in 2019, includes quarterly health screenings, health coaching sessions, and mental wellness workshops, as well as weekly physical activity classes. The HPB aims to support mature workers, who are at higher risk of developing chronic conditions due to their age and sedentary work. The initiative has already seen 13,000 participants, mostly from taxi and delivery companies, and will be expanded to reach self-employed workers from various professions and industries.

site_title: Conman admits to cheating 10 people of nearly $85,000
summary: A Singaporean conman, Thong Meng Fie, 46, pleaded guilty to 8 counts of cheating and admitted to deceiving 10 people, totaling $84,598. He posed as a lawyer and law firm owner, hiring staff and taking payments from victims, despite being previously jailed multiple times for similar offenses. Thong used the money to cover expenses and made no restitution to some victims, with only $1,600 returned so far. He will be sentenced on November 7.

site_title: Football: Nagelsmann 'not responsible for everything' amid Bayern's league struggles
summary: Bayern Munich head coach Julian Nagelsmann has denied stepping down amid the team's poor start to the Bundesliga campaign. Nagelsmann attributed the struggles to the entire squad's responsibility, saying he's not solely to blame. Bayern have won the last 10 German crowns but sit fifth, five points off the lead. Nagelsmann expressed his desire to win the league and go further in the Champions League, stating he wouldn't back down from his responsibility despite criticism. He will lead the team against Bayer Leverkusen on Friday.

site_title: Pressure grows on ECB as euro zone inflation hits double digits for 1st time
summary: The euro zone has experienced its first-ever double-digit inflation, with consumer prices rising 10% from September 2021. This has intensified pressure on the European Central Bank (ECB) to continue raising interest rates aggressively. The inflation rate exceeds the median forecast of 9.7% and marks the fifth consecutive month that prices have exceeded expectations. ECB officials are expected to keep raising interest rates, with a possible 75 basis-point hike at the next decision on October 27, to combat inflation and prevent a persistent upward shift in inflation expectations.

site_title: Liv confident despite PGA's countersuit
summary: The US PGA Tour has filed a countersuit against LIV Golf, claiming the Saudi-backed circuit interfered with contracts the Tour had with its players, and LIV had "falsely informed" them to breach their contracts. LIV Golf maintains its strategy is not anti-competitive, despite the PGA Tour's claims that it offered "astronomical sums" to lure players away. The PGA Tour seeks damages, lost profits, and other costs, while LIV remains confident in its position, stating the courts will "right these wrongs".

site_title: Shining under right set-up
summary: Kristijan Krajcek, a 29-year-old Croatian winger, credits Singapore's Premier League for sustaining his passion for football. Growing up in a small village in Croatia, Krajcek struggled to make a living as a professional footballer due to the country's lack of government protection for players. He eventually found success in Singapore, where he earns five times more than he did in Croatia and has improved his skills under Hougang United coach Clement Teo. Krajcek aims to help the team finish in the top half of the league and potentially win the Singapore Cup.

site_title: Vettel's Singapore secret recipe: Nasi goreng
summary: Sebastian Vettel, the "Lion of Singapore," is set to compete in his final Formula One Grand Prix, the Singapore Grand Prix, with Aston Martin. Vettel has a strong record at the track, with five wins, but the team's struggles in 2022 have put his podium finish in jeopardy. Despite this, Vettel remains confident, citing the track's challenge and his car's strengths in slower-speed corners. He attributes his past successes to a secret recipe of eating nasi goreng on Saturday night, which he claims has contributed to his victories in 2019 and 2015.

site_title: CNA wins Best News Website at Wan-Ifra Digital Media Awards Worldwide 2022
summary: CNA, a Singapore-based news network, won the Best News Website award at the Wan-Ifra Digital Media Awards Worldwide 2022, becoming the first South-east Asian news network to receive the honor. The revamped website and app, launched in August 2021, were recognized for their design, content, and user experience. CNA beat gold award winners from five other regions to clinch the global award, which marks a significant achievement for the network. This win follows other international awards, including the Channel of the Year award in 2020.

site_title: Winter's Destiny is worth following
summary: Greyville in South Africa hosted eight horse racing events, with various horses showing promising form. Notable horses to follow include Winter's Destiny, who was narrowly beaten last time and is expected to improve from a better draw, and Straight Up, who has been dropping in the handicap and is primed for a bold bid in the 1,700m event. Geronto and Venturous are also expected to perform well, with the latter having won two smart races on the Poly.

site_title: Rwanda President shares his country's formula for success
summary: Rwandan President Paul Kagame attributes his country's success to following Singapore's example by investing in its people, adopting innovative methods, and making prudent policy choices. Since the 1994 genocide, Rwanda has made significant strides in economic growth, safety, and order, with a strong focus on technology and inclusive governance. The country is now working on a vaccine and medicine manufacturing hub, with a German pharmaceutical company launching its first mRNA vaccine facility in Kigali next year.

site_title: Straight favours Master Eight
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

In Saturday's Hong Kong (Sha Tin) form analysis, Master Eight is favored to win the National Day Cup. Straight favorites in each of the 10 races include This Is Charisma in Race 1, Big Me in Race 2, One Voice in Race 3, Gracylove in Race 4, President's Choice in Race 5, Midori Beauty in Race 6, Harmony And Rich in Race 7, Sakewin in Race 8, Money Catcher in Race 9, and Tempest Express in Race 10. Trainers David Hall and Zac Purton have strong performances with horses like Gracylove and Master Eight.

site_title: Motor sports: India to host MotoGP for first time in 2023, say organisers
summary: India will host its first MotoGP race in 2023 at the Buddh International Circuit in Uttar Pradesh, marking a significant milestone for the sport. The track, which previously hosted Formula One, is expected to attract a large audience given India's massive population of 1.4 billion people and over 200 million motorcycle owners. Organizers see the event as a key market expansion opportunity and a source of foreign investment for the state. The event is set to be a major success, with local authorities expressing pride and excitement for the global event.

site_title: Chess reminds us sport is full of crooked moves
summary: The 1968 Olympics marked a turning point in sports anti-doping efforts. Swedish pentathlete Hans-Gunnar Liljenwall became the first athlete to be disqualified for failing a drug test. Liljenwall ingested a banned stimulant to calm his nerves before his shooting segment. This incident highlights the lengths athletes will go to gain an edge, but also serves as a reminder that fair play is essential in sports. The incident paved the way for increased anti-doping measures, demonstrating the need for strict regulations to maintain the integrity of athletic competitions.

site_title: Must-reads
summary: National Development Minister Desmond Lee announced a 15-month wait-out period to moderate demand for resale HDB flats, keeping them affordable. Thailand's Constitutional Court ruled that Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha can remain in office without exceeding the eight-year term limit. South Korea and Hong Kong eased Covid-19 restrictions, while Australia scrapped the five-day home quarantine period for infected people. Singapore reported a 35-40% increase in Covid-19 cases over the past few days, and seven Singaporean designers won the Red Dot Award for design concept.

site_title: Undertaker charged with evading $427,000 in taxes
summary: Roland Tay Hai Choon, a 75-year-old Singaporean undertaker, was charged with evading $427,000 in taxes and failing to register his business for Goods and Services Tax (GST). Tay allegedly understated his income by over $2.2 million for three years and failed to pay an additional $427,427 in taxes. He is out on $80,000 bail and will face charges of making a false statement in a tax return and GST non-registration. If convicted, Tay can be jailed for up to three years and fined up to $10,000.

site_title: Football: Newcastle swoop in for Australia striker Kuol
summary: Newcastle United has agreed to sign 18-year-old Australian striker Garang Kuol from Central Coast Mariners in January 2023. Kuol, who scored four A-League goals in eight appearances last season, will join Eddie Howe's side. Financial details of the transfer were not disclosed. Kuol made his debut for Australia in a 2-0 win against New Zealand and is increasingly likely to be included in the World Cup squad in Qatar.

site_title: Apple loses $172b in market cap as Big Tech feels selling pressure
summary: Apple shares plummeted 4.9% after a rare analyst downgrade from Bank of America, erasing $120 billion from its market capitalization. The iPhone maker's market value fell 20% in 2022, amidst a broader tech sell-off driven by recession fears and weakening consumer demand. The downgrade cited slowing demand for Apple's services and products, with analysts warning of negative estimate revisions and valuation risks in the near term. The sell-off was part of a broader market downturn, with the Nasdaq 100 falling 2.9% and other tech giants like Amazon and Alphabet also experiencing significant losses.

site_title: Covid-19 antibody treatment no longer recommended as it is not effective against Omicron variants
summary: The National Centre for Infectious Diseases (NCID) no longer recommends the use of casirivimab-imdevimab due to its poor activity against Omicron variants. The treatment, which was authorized in Singapore last year, was advised against by the World Health Organisation (WHO) in September. Alternative treatments such as antiviral drugs like Paxlovid or Lagevrio are now recommended, and NCID will review its recommendations as new data emerges. The number of daily Covid-19 cases in Singapore has increased by 35-40% over the past few days due to the BA.2.75 variant.

site_title: High number of applicants, so ballot results for Aug BTO exercise delayed
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) has delayed the release of ballot results for the August Build-To-Order (BTO) sales exercise due to a high number of applicants, exceeding 34,000. The results were initially expected in September but will now be announced in mid-October. HDB attributed the delay to verifying applicants' eligibility and conducting computer balloting. The delay does not affect successful applicants who wish to take out an HDB housing loan, as the loan amount will remain at up to 85% of the flat price.

site_title: Football: New Chelsea boss Potter calm despite sweeping overhaul
summary: Chelsea's new manager Graham Potter remains calm amidst a sweeping overhaul at the club, following the £250 million takeover by Todd Boehly's consortium. The former Brighton boss acknowledges the challenges, but emphasizes the importance of adapting to change and focusing on the next match. Despite a disappointing start to the season, Potter prioritizes qualifying for the Champions League, a goal he believes is crucial for a club of Chelsea's stature, over securing a top-four league finish. The new manager aims to improve the team through clear strategy and collaboration.

site_title: Cash-rich private property downgraders, en bloc sellers targeted in new property curbs
summary: Singapore has introduced new property curbs targeting cash-rich private property downgraders and en bloc sellers, aiming to curb a surge in public housing prices. The measures come after a 12.7% increase in Housing Board resale prices in 2021 and a further 5.3% rise in the first half of 2022. The curbs aim to encourage more prudent borrowing and address hot money inflows into the public housing market, which has been fueled by private property downgraders and pandemic-related disruptions. The new curbs aim to maintain a balance between supply and demand in the public housing market.

site_title: Formula 1: Vettel hopes his secret nasi goreng can still work its magic in S'pore
summary: Sebastian Vettel, a four-time Formula 1 world champion, is set to retire at the end of 2022, but hopes to still achieve success in the Singapore Grand Prix. Vettel has a strong record at the track, with five wins, but his current team, Aston Martin, is struggling. The team has made upgrades to their car, which Vettel believes will improve their performance. Vettel's secret to past success, eating nasi goreng on Saturday night, remains a mystery. Despite his team's struggles, Vettel is confident in his abilities and trusts his car to perform well.

site_title: Some downgraders left frustrated by wait-out period
summary: Singapore's government has introduced a 15-month wait-out period for current and former private property owners who wish to buy a non-subsidized HDB resale flat. This measure aims to slow down the flow of "hot money" from private property owners who want to cash out and downgrade to an HDB property. The move has left some downgraders frustrated, including those who genuinely need to downgrade due to financial difficulties, and may force them to abandon their plans or appeal to HDB for a waiver.

site_title: Company Briefs :  Barclays BlackRock Hyundai
summary: British lender Barclays agreed to pay US$361 million to US regulators for "staggering" failures in selling structured products, exceeding a US$20.8 billion limit by 75%. BlackRock is launching a new metaverse ETF, while Hyundai is considering building its first US electric-vehicle plant earlier than scheduled, potentially around October 2024, amid disputes over a new US clean energy law.

site_title: Football: Criticism of England boss Southgate 'harsh', says Lampard
summary: England football manager Gareth Southgate has faced criticism for his "cautious" approach, with some labeling it harsh. Everton manager Frank Lampard has come to Southgate's defense, stating that the criticism is "some parts harsh" and urging fans to support the team before the World Cup. Lampard believes Southgate's tactics are effective and comparable to successful teams in the past, and hopes fans will rally behind him and the team in the lead-up to the World Cup. England will begin their Group B campaign against Iran on November 21.

site_title: Football: Klopp backs Alexander-Arnold after England snub
summary: Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp has defended Trent Alexander-Arnold after being snubbed by England manager Gareth Southgate for the recent Nations League matches. Klopp believes Alexander-Arnold is a world-class player and would sign him for any team, citing his exceptional skills. Alexander-Arnold was an unused substitute for England, who lost 1-0 in Italy and 3-3 against Germany, with Southgate reportedly concerned about his defensive deficiencies. Alexander-Arnold's hopes of making the World Cup squad now hang in the balance.

site_title: 950,000 S'porean households to receive third tranche of GST vouchers in October
summary: About 950,000 Singaporean households, mostly living in Housing Board flats, will receive their third quarterly GST voucher and service and conservancy rebates in October. The rebates, part of the permanent GST Voucher scheme, range from $110 to $190 for utility bills and ½ to 1 month for S&CC expenses. This is the third payout of the year, with the final tranche to be disbursed in January 2023. The total disbursement for the year is $720 million, providing continued support to lower-to-middle-income households.

site_title: Formula 1: Chastening season for eight-time world champions Mercedes, says chief technical officer
summary: Mercedes, the eight-time Formula One constructors' champions, has experienced a chastening season, struggling to maintain a top-three finish. Despite efforts to improve, the team is seeking to avoid making the same mistakes and is focusing on creating a competitive and championship-ready car. Mercedes' chief technical officer James Allison credits the team's culture and values, including openness and a no-blame environment, for helping the team cope with the difficulties. The team is optimistic for the future, with CEO Toto Wolff emphasizing the importance of work-life balance and self-care in maintaining a high level of performance.

site_title: S'pore-based Asia Innovations Group plans US listing via $3.6b Spac merger
summary: Asia Innovations Group, a Singapore-based mobile app developer, plans to go public through a merger with Magnum Opus Acquisition, a blank-cheque firm valued at US$2.5 billion. The deal is expected to close in Q1 2023 and will raise an estimated US$350 million in cash, supporting the growth of its live-streaming app Uplive and e-commerce platform Hekka. The company also aims to raise up to US$150 million from an additional capital raising.

site_title: Lower household electricity bills in Q4 as tariff falls for first time in over a year
summary: The electricity tariff in Singapore will decrease by 1.4% from 30.17 cents to 29.74 cents per kilowatt hour (kWh) from Oct 1 to Dec 31, marking the first decrease in over a year. This translates to a $1.55 decrease in the average monthly electricity bill for a family living in a HDB four-room flat. The decrease is attributed to lower fuel costs, with global oil prices falling from over $100 to around $88 per barrel. However, the respite may be short-lived due to ongoing global energy market volatility.

site_title: Singtel's Optus to pay for new Australian passports for those affected by giant data hack
summary: Optus, a subsidiary of Singtel, will pay to replace passports of Australians affected by a major cyber attack that compromised the personal information of 9.8 million customers. The breach exposed identity documents like passports, driving licenses, and Medicare cards of 3 million Australians, with passports being the most expensive to replace, costing A$193 each. The cost to Optus could be up to A$661 million, while the company's parent company, Singtel, may face a bill of over US$400 million. Australian authorities are working to protect the personal information of 10,000 people whose data may have been shared online.

site_title: Woman accused of killing husband certified to be of unsound mind
summary: A 57-year-old Chinese woman, Wang Shuzhen, has been certified by the Institute of Mental Health to be of unsound mind and incapable of defending herself in court. As a result, the High Court ordered a stay of proceedings against her for the 2019 killing of her 63-year-old husband, Teh Hock Pine. Wang faces a charge of culpable homicide and will be detained in Changi Prison pending further orders from the Law Minister. The court cited Wang's schizophrenia diagnosis and recent reports indicating she has delusional beliefs, leading to her discharge from her lawyer.

site_title: Larger HDB resale flats to bear brunt of new property cooling measures; may drive up rents
summary: Singapore's new property cooling measures are primarily aimed at curbing overleveraging in the market, particularly in larger HDB resale flats, which have seen a 12.7% price increase in 2021. The measures are a response to growing signs of overheating in both HDB and private home markets, driven by rising interest rates and an economic downturn. Larger flats, bought by private home downgraders, are expected to bear the brunt of the measures, potentially driving up rents. The cooling measures are seen as a necessary step to prevent market bubbles.

site_title: Singapore aims to be regional centre for philanthropy: DPM Wong
summary: Singapore aims to become a regional centre for philanthropy, with Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong encouraging family offices, businesses, and individuals to contribute to impactful solutions. The government is reviewing tax incentive schemes and working with donors to identify suitable causes and monitor impact. Wong notes that Singapore lacks a long-standing tradition of philanthropy but sees potential for growth, particularly among successful entrepreneurs and family offices. He advocates for a combination of private giving and government support to build a stronger social compact and reduce income gaps.

site_title: Hong Kong's abrupt quarantine end triggers new crisis for hotels
summary: Hong Kong's abrupt end of its mandatory hotel quarantine rule has left the city's former quarantine hotels with empty rooms, with over 1,500 bookings cancelled in just a few days. The Ovolo Group and Landmark Mandarin Oriental reported few bookings, while the government offers a subsidy to hotels that remain unoccupied for 30 days. The city's hotels are now facing a new crisis, with outbound travel surging and inbound flights increasing, but still a fraction of pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: New alliance raises over $300m to drive philanthropic partnerships in Asia
summary: A new alliance has raised over $300 million to drive philanthropic partnerships in Asia, focusing on issues related to the planet, peace, people, and progress. The alliance, led by Temasek Trust, brings together founding core members such as the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, Li Ka Shing Foundation, and Tanoto Foundation, with other partners committing between $1 million and $10 million each. The alliance aims to provide a coordinated approach to delivering impactful outcomes through a governance framework and strategic partnerships, with four major priorities including addressing climate change, promoting peace, improving education and healthcare, and achieving just and inclusive progress.

site_title: MMA: Angela Lee ready to 'go through hell' as she targets second One C'ship belt
summary: Angela Lee, One Championship's atomweight world champion, is set to face Xiong Jingnan for the strawweight title in a highly anticipated MMA bout. Lee aims to become the first female double champion and "go through hell" to protect her title and her daughter. The event, One Fight Night 2, will be broadcast on Amazon Prime and marks the second major event in the US for One Championship. Lee has been training with a maternal instinct, while Xiong seeks to maintain her dominance with six title defenses.

site_title: Football: For Croatia's Kristijan Krajcek, the grass is greener in Hougang
summary: Croatian footballer Kristijan Krajcek credits the Singapore Premier League for sustaining his passion for the sport, despite facing financial struggles in his home country. Krajcek, who plays for Hougang United, had to take bank loans to support his family while playing in Croatia, where the government did not protect professional footballers. He found better opportunities in Singapore, where he earns five times more than he did in Croatia and receives timely payments. Krajcek praises the Hougang United coaching staff and the team's organization, and aims to help the club win the Singapore Cup.

site_title: SMRT bus hits 74-year-old pedestrian in Sengkang, driver arrested
summary: A 74-year-old pedestrian was hit by an SMRT bus in Sengkang, Singapore, on Thursday night. The pedestrian was conscious when taken to hospital. The bus driver, 68, was arrested for careless driving causing grievous hurt and suspended from duties. The incident occurred when the bus made a right turn at the Compassvale Road and Compassvale Drive junction. The pedestrian received medical attention and the company's care team is offering assistance. Investigations into the incident are ongoing.

site_title: Global stocks have further to fall despite recent sell-offs: Temasek CIO
summary: Global stock markets have more room to decline due to investors not yet pricing in the odds of an economic downturn and its impact on company earnings, according to Temasek's chief investment officer Rohit Sipahimalani. The expected decline, led by the US market, is driven by inflation remaining higher for a longer period. As a result, Temasek will be cautious in its investments, but expects to turn aggressive once risks are priced in, focusing on companies with pricing power and large domestic markets. A recession in the US is expected, but it's likely to be mild due to households and companies' financial resilience.

site_title: China allows some cities to lower first-home mortgage rates
summary: China's central government has allowed 23 out of 70 largest cities to lower mortgage rates for primary residence purchases, effective until the end of the year. The move aims to ease the country's struggling housing market, but analysts say it may only provide limited help. Existing rules for second-home mortgage loans remain unchanged, and new home prices in China's top 70 cities dropped 0.29% in August. The policy change is seen as a response to the more than year-long slump in the housing market, which has weighed on employment and income due to falling prices and failing developers.

site_title: Formula 1: 2022 S'pore race signals return to normality, say happy fans
summary: Formula 1 fans are celebrating the return of the Singapore Grand Prix, with thousands of fans attending the event after a two-year hiatus due to the pandemic. Many fans, including a couple who had never attended a live grand prix before, have traveled from overseas to experience the event. The return of the night race is seen as a sign of normality, and fans are excited to meet drivers and enjoy the community aspect of the sport. Local fans are also optimistic about the economic benefits of the event, which is expected to attract tourists and boost the local economy.

site_title: 312 people being investigated for suspected involvement in scams worth over $15.7m
summary: Singapore's police are investigating 312 people for their suspected involvement in over $15.7 million scams, including internet love, loan, and phishing scams. The suspects, aged 17-68, were rounded up in a two-week operation between Sept 16 and 29. The total number of scam cases reported in the first half of 2022 was 14,349, with losses totaling $346.5 million, nearly double the amount lost in 2021. Those found guilty can face up to 10 years in jail and fines ranging from $125,000 to $500,000.

site_title: SoftBank cuts about 150 staff globally: Source
summary: SoftBank Group is cutting around 150 staff globally, affecting 3% of workers, mainly in investment teams and back-office departments. The move follows huge losses on tech bets, with the Vision Fund unit recording a record $50 billion loss in the six months to June. CEO Masayoshi Son pledged to cut costs after the loss, stating that "no sacred areas" would be spared. The cuts will primarily affect SoftBank's Vision Fund unit and SoftBank Group International, with plans to scale back investing activity and focus on existing portfolios.

site_title: China factory activity continues to struggle on Covid-19 curbs, property woes
summary: China's factory activity continued to struggle in September, with the official manufacturing purchasing managers' index rising to 50.1 from 49.4 in August. The non-manufacturing gauge, which measures services and construction, fell to 50.6. The country's economic recovery was challenged by lockdowns, zero-Covid-19 policies, and a severe property market downturn. Chinese stocks edged higher, but the country's mobility restrictions are estimated to have shaved 1.1 percentage points from GDP growth in the third quarter. The consensus estimate for 2022 growth remains at 3.4%.

site_title: Woman accused of killing husband in Ang Mo Kio 'of unsound mind', case put on hold
summary: A 57-year-old Chinese woman, Wang Shuzhen, has had her case put on hold after being certified by the Institute of Mental Health (IMH) as of unsound mind and incapable of defending herself in court. Wang faces a charge of culpable homicide for allegedly killing her 63-year-old husband, Mr Teh Hock Pine, in 2019. The High Court ordered a stay of proceedings and directed the case to be reported to the Law Minister, who may order Wang to be detained in a psychiatric institution or a safe custody place.

site_title: Asia shares head for worst month since Covid-19 pandemic started
summary: Asian shares are on track for the worst month since the Covid-19 pandemic, with Japan's Nikkei down 1.8%, Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index 0.35%, and the Shanghai Composite 0.3% lower. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index is set to record a 12.5% drop, its largest since March 2020. Rising interest rates, slowing growth, and a strong dollar have intensified market concerns, with the US dollar up 2.9% for the month. Geopolitical tensions, including Russia's annexation of Ukrainian regions, and concerns about a global recession also weigh on markets.

site_title: 7 great spots to catch Singapore F1 action, including some that don't require tickets
summary: The Singapore F1 night race offers various viewing spots for fans, including those with walkabout tickets and public areas. Key spots include the Pit Grandstand, Turn 1 Grandstand, and Padang Grandstand for those with walkabout tickets, while public areas like the Marina Square roof garden and Link bridge between Millenia Walk and Marina Square provide alternative views. These spots offer stunning views of the Marina Bay Street Circuit, which is lit by over 1,600 custom-made floodlights.

site_title: Must-reads
summary: Key events include tightened maximum loan amounts for home buyers to avoid servicing difficulties, a potential cost of $1.1 billion for Singtel to rectify the Optus data breach, Russia's formal annexation of four Ukrainian regions, and Singapore's increased fines for smoking in public areas. Sats is poised to become a global supply chain leader, while the Singapore Government engages residents to improve their living environment.

site_title: Apple's ugly day wipes out $172 billion, spills over Big Tech
summary: Apple shares dropped 4.9% after Bank of America cut its rating to "neutral" from "buy", citing weaker consumer demand for its devices. The sell-off erased $120 billion from Apple's market capitalization, wiping out $172 billion in market value. The Nasdaq 100 fell 2.9%, with few gainers, as investors dumped stocks amid interest rate hikes and recession fears. Apple's market value has fallen 20% in 2022, with demand for its services already slowing and product demand expected to follow.

site_title: Facebook parent Meta to cut headcount for first time, slash budgets across teams
summary: Meta, the parent company of Facebook, is cutting headcount for the first time and slashing budgets across teams, citing economic uncertainty and slowing advertising revenue growth. CEO Mark Zuckerberg announced the move during a Q&A session with employees, stating the company will freeze hiring and restructure teams to reduce expenses. Meta is expected to be smaller in 2023 than it was this year, with a focus on realigning priorities and managing headcount changes. The move follows similar actions by Twitter and Google, and comes as the company faces mounting competition for users' attention.

site_title: Golf: China's Lin Xiyu takes early lead at The Ascendant LPGA event with late eagle
summary: Lin Xiyu of China leads The Ascendant LPGA event after one round with a six-under 65, one shot ahead of Lizette Salas and Thailand's Atthaya Thitikul on 66. Lin eagled the par-five 17th hole, her first of the tournament, after previously having two top-10 finishes this month. Atthaya, coming off a win last week, is also in contention for the lead, while defending champion Ko Jin-young withdrew due to a wrist injury.

site_title: S'pore inks agreements with US and UK to make flights greener
summary: Singapore has signed agreements with the US and UK to make flights more environmentally friendly. The agreements, signed at the ICAO assembly in Montreal, include a memorandum of cooperation on research and trial of biofuel aviation fuels with the US, and a memorandum of understanding with the UK to include environment protection as a new area of collaboration. The agreements aim to reduce carbon emissions from flights, with Singapore and the US planning to study the commercial viability of a green lane between the two countries.

site_title: Postcards from work trips, getting caught in the rain: What politicians are up to this week
summary: Singaporean MPs are keeping busy with work trips abroad, with recent photos and videos showing them attending international events and meetings. Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan attended the United Nations General Assembly, while Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen visited Australia for Exercise Wallaby and Exercise Trident. Other MPs, including Manpower Minister Tan See Leng and Transport Minister S. Iswaran, are also abroad, with some sharing their experiences on social media. Meanwhile, politicians are also finding time to unwind, with some enjoying runs in the rain and others watching TV shows on streaming services.

site_title: Little India eateries reeling from Delhi's wheat export ban
summary: Restaurants and retailers in Singapore's Little India are struggling due to India's wheat export ban, which has led to a supply crunch.
