Eateries reliant on wheat flour for popular items like chapati flatbreads are either raising prices or dropping wheat flour-based dishes from their menus. The ban has resulted in a significant increase in the cost of wheat flour, with prices doubling or more in some cases. Many restaurants are reluctant to raise prices, with some owners saying they cannot pass the increased cost to customers.

site_title: South Korea slashes chip production for first time in over 4 years
summary: South Korea's semiconductor production declined 1.7% in August from the previous year, marking the first fall in over four years, according to Statistics Korea. This drop coincides with rising chip inventories and factory shipments also falling 20.4% for the second consecutive month. The decline suggests a slowdown in global demand, particularly in the electronics sector, which has been a major driver of economic growth. This trend is echoed by weak forecasts from US chipmaker Micron Technology and South Korea's Samsung Electronics, which warned of a gloomy outlook for the second half of the year.

site_title: American who allegedly made false bomb threat on SIA flight charged
summary: A 37-year-old American man, La Andy Hien Duc, has been charged for allegedly making a false bomb threat on a Singapore Airlines flight. Duc claimed there was a bomb on the plane, grabbed a passenger's luggage, and assaulted a cabin crew member. He was remanded at the Institute of Mental Health for psychiatric observation. The incident caused a four-hour delay in disembarkation and was later verified as false. Duc faces charges under the Tokyo Convention Act 1971 and may receive up to $5,000 in fines or three years in jail for causing alarm and voluntarily causing hurt.

site_title: GIC seeks Japan property deals as yen falls and tourists return
summary: Singapore's GIC is seeking property deals and corporate partners in Japan as the yen falls and tourists return. The fund is interested in hotels, resorts, and traditional inns, as well as residential and logistics projects. A recent deal to buy properties from Seibu Holdings valued at low single-digit billions of dollars demonstrates its interest. GIC sees Japan's property market as attractive due to low financing costs and a levered yield compared to Japanese yen bonds, despite the risk of currency fluctuations. The fund aims to increase its Japanese investments, which currently account for about 7% of its portfolio.

site_title: Football: Neymar backs Bolsonaro in Brazil vote
summary: Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro received a celebrity endorsement from football superstar Neymar, who posted a TikTok video dancing to a pro-Bolsonaro campaign song. The video, posted three days before the election, showed Neymar flashing Bolsonaro's candidate number 22. Neymar had previously stayed out of the election, but visited Bolsonaro at his charitable foundation, the Neymar Jr Institute. Bolsonaro's re-election bid is against leftist ex-president Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, who leads in opinion polls. The endorsement is seen as a significant boost to Bolsonaro's campaign.

site_title: US stocks back in the red as Apple slumps
summary: US stocks plummeted, with the S&P 500 falling 2.1% to its lowest close since November 2020. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 1.5% and the Nasdaq Composite Index tumbled 2.8%. Apple slumped nearly 5% after a downgrade by Bank of America, while Facebook parent Meta and Tesla also fell. The decline was fueled by concerns over inflation and market volatility, particularly in Britain, where Prime Minister Liz Truss's tax cut policy has rattled markets. Investors fear a "contagion" effect, contradicting central banks' efforts to counter inflation.

site_title: Undertaker Roland Tay charged with tax evasion, failing to register business for GST
summary: Roland Tay, 75, a local undertaker, was charged with tax evasion and failing to register his business for GST. He allegedly understated his income by $2.2 million and failed to pay $427,427 in taxes. Tay also failed to register his company for GST, resulting in $286,963 in unaccounted tax. He faces up to 3 years in jail, fines, and a penalty three times the undercharged tax. Tay, known for arranging free funerals for victims and the poor, was bailed for $80,000 and his case is set for Oct 18.

site_title: Genting aims to upend Macau casino landscape in bidding war
summary: Genting Malaysia, a Malaysian Chinese billionaire-led group, is emerging as a strong contender to unseat Macau casino operators in a licensing bid. The company, which has casinos globally, is seen as a disruptor to Macau's gaming landscape due to its non-gaming track record and investments in China. Genting's chances are bolstered by its ability to offer a diverse range of attractions and its multiple non-gaming investments in China. The bid could send tremors through the industry, with analysts warning of "far too much disruption" if any of the six incumbent operators lose their licence.

site_title: S'pore, Australia reaffirm close defence ties
summary: Singapore and Australia reaffirmed their close defence ties during a meeting between Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen and Prime Minister Anthony Albanese in Canberra. They discussed enhancing cooperation under the Comprehensive Strategic Partnership, including joint development of training areas in Queensland, Australia. The 2020 Treaty on Military Training and Training Area Development will increase capacity and offer more sophisticated training opportunities for both armed forces. Dr Ng also laid a wreath at the Australian War Memorial to honor Australian soldiers who fought for Singapore during World War II.

site_title: Kovan site for private assisted-living facility launched for sale
summary: A 60-year leasehold site in Kovan has been launched for sale by public tender to house a private assisted-living facility. The site, located within the Rosyth estate, will yield self-contained units with an average size of 32 sq m, offering seniors access to services such as healthcare, social programs, and care services. The facility is expected to accommodate 300-400 seniors and will provide a long-term residential accommodation with a focus on independence and social bonding. The sale comes after the successful pilot launch of Community Care Apartments in Bukit Batok and Queenstown.

site_title: New model lets patients get hospital care at home
summary: Singapore is launching a new care model, Mobile Inpatient Care @ Home (MIC@Home), allowing selected patients to recover at home with 24/7 access to medical teams through teleconsultations and home visits. Up to 2,000 patients can be treated at home over the next two years, with plans to expand to more hospitals. The program aims to increase patient comfort, reduce hospital-acquired infections, and improve manpower efficiency, while also easing the hospital bed crunch. Similar care models in other countries have shown equivalent clinical outcomes and improved patient recovery.

site_title: CJ reduces sentence for man who sexually violated minor, overrules past incorrect cases
summary: Chief Justice Sundaresh Menon reduced the sentence of a 30-year-old man who sexually violated a 13-year-old girl to 3½ years' jail with no caning. The decision overruled past cases where similar offenders received low sentences, following the 2017 Pram Nair precedent that sets a framework of 7-10 years' imprisonment and 4 strokes of the cane. Menon noted the initial sentence was not excessive but applied the ruling prospectively to future cases, ensuring consistency in sentencing.

site_title: Book details unique challenges faced by female drug offenders
summary: A new book, A Woman's Journey Home: Stories Of Hope And Empowerment, shares the stories of 16 female drug offenders, including Salimah Sukar and Chris Wong, who struggled with addiction and faced unique challenges. The book highlights the pressures of running households and paying expenses, as well as the risk of abuse and trauma. Minister of State Muhammad Faishal Ibrahim emphasized the need for rehabilitation programs specifically addressing the issues that lead to female drug use, such as managing unhelpful relationships and coping in roles as mothers and partners.

site_title: 2 men jailed a year each for helping couple flee S'pore
summary: Two Malaysian men, Mohamed Alias and Mohamad Fazli Abdul Rahman, were sentenced to one year in jail each for helping a couple, Pi Jiapeng and Pansuk Siriwipa, flee Singapore in a $32 million luxury goods scam. The men, who worked for the same logistics company, were paid RM16,000 (S$5,000) for their role in smuggling the couple out of the country on July 4. Pi and Pansuk, who allegedly failed to deliver goods worth $32 million, were later arrested in Malaysia and charged in a Singapore court.

site_title: Colombian state firm to invest $69b to expand oil, gas production: CEO
summary: Colombia's state-owned energy company, Ecopetrol, plans to invest around $48 billion over the next eight years to expand oil and gas production, aiming to reach 850,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day. The company is currently producing around 700,000 barrels per day and is seeking to increase this to 730,000 by the middle of the decade. Ecopetrol's CEO, Felipe Bayon, discussed plans with investors, including the Singapore sovereign wealth fund GIC, and addressed concerns about the impact of Colombia's new government on the company's operations and growth plans.

site_title: S'pore, UK to work together to build capacity in region
summary: Singapore and the UK signed a memorandum of understanding to promote capacity-building in Southeast Asia and the region, underlining their cooperation in international development and sharing best practices in sustainable development. The agreement was signed by Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan and British Foreign Secretary James Cleverly during his first working visit to Singapore. The UK aims to invest in green infrastructure, support climate resilience, and enhance cooperation in areas such as the digital economy and clean energy. The partnership is seen as a significant step in deepening the UK's engagement in the region, particularly through the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN).

site_title: SIA bomb threat case example of harms of drugs: Shanmugam
summary: Singapore's Minister for Law and Home Affairs K. Shanmugam highlighted the harms of drugs, citing a recent bomb threat case where a 37-year-old man suspected of consuming controlled drugs was arrested. The incident, which also involved assaulting a cabin crew member, is just one example of how drugs can cause harm not only to abusers but also those around them. Shanmugam emphasized the need for a balanced approach, including rehabilitation and reintegration programs, and criticized the decriminalization of drug use in other countries, citing Thailand's reported cases of cannabis-related harm.

site_title: Tennis: Djokovic makes winning return to ATP action in Tel Aviv
summary: Novak Djokovic, ranked 7th in the world, made a successful return to singles tennis with a 6-0, 6-3 win over 115th-ranked Pablo Andujar in the Tel Aviv quarter-finals. Djokovic, who last played in Israel 16 years ago, dominated the match in 86 minutes, firing 30 winners and breaking Andujar four times. He will face 149th-ranked Vasek Pospisil in the quarter-finals, with a 5-0 career record against the Canadian. Djokovic's victory comes after a 10-week absence from singles tennis since winning Wimbledon.

site_title: With mega deal, Sats on path to becoming global supply chain leader
summary: Singapore Airlines (Sats) is on the path to becoming a global supply chain leader following a mega deal with WFS. In the past two years, cargo accounted for 40% of global airline revenue. SIA's cargo capacity increased despite a significant decline in passenger numbers, with some flights having seats removed to accommodate cargo. The deal with WFS delivers both size and connectivity, positioning Sats for growth in the global supply chain industry.

site_title: Sats shares fall 21% following news of Worldwide Flight Services deal
summary: Shares of Sats plummeted 21% to a two-year low after the company announced a $1.64 billion deal to acquire Paris-based Worldwide Flight Services, covering 50% of global air cargo volume. The deal, funded by a rights issue and internal cash, raised concerns among investors, with some analysts citing a post-cyclical peak in cargo and near-term earnings headwinds. Despite this, market insiders remain optimistic about the company's long-term prospects.

site_title: Up to $1k fine from Oct for smoking in parks, beaches
summary: Singapore has banned smoking in all public parks, beaches, and water areas, with fines of up to $1,000 for violators. The ban, which started on July 1, was initially given a three-month grace period before verbal advisories were issued to smokers. Now, those caught smoking in these areas may face fines or composition fines. Designated smoking areas have been provided in 12 regional parks, and "no smoking by law" signs have been installed at new smoke-free locations, totaling over 49,000 premises.

site_title: US does not seek economic decoupling from China, says envoy
summary: US Ambassador to China Nicholas Burns stated that the US does not seek economic decoupling from China, despite competing with the country in technology and reiterating US commitments to global trade and investment agreements. The US and China have a $650 billion two-way annual trade, with 11,000 American companies invested in China. Burns expressed concerns over China's economic policies, national security, and aggressive actions towards Taiwan, warning Beijing that the US will not agree to a change in policy.

site_title: Opportunities for family offices to back innovative firms: DPM Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong said Singapore offers opportunities for family offices to support innovative companies, contribute to sustainable finance, and philanthropy. The city-state is home to one of the world's fastest-growing start-up communities and a high concentration of Asian-focused private equity and venture capital firms. Wong encouraged family offices to invest in and mentor promising entrepreneurs, and highlighted Singapore's potential as a launch pad for sustainable finance initiatives, particularly in the Asia region.

site_title: Company briefs: First Reit
summary: First Reit secured a 1.7 billion yen loan from Japan's Shinsei Bank to fund nursing home acquisitions, with the remaining financing provided by Singapore-dollar debt. Porsche made its Frankfurt stock exchange debut, raising over €76 billion in valuation despite global market turmoil. SoftBank Group began laying off 20% of its Vision Fund workforce, with at least 100 employees expected to be affected.

site_title: Energy crisis highlights need for chip sector to go green: Summit
summary: The Singapore Semiconductor Industry Association (SSIA) Summit highlighted the need for the semiconductor industry to transition to greener practices due to the energy crisis. Industry leaders, including Minister of State for Trade and Industry Alvin Tan, emphasized the importance of sustainability in the sector. With information and computing technology projected to consume 20% of global energy demand by 2030, the industry must adopt cleaner energy and refine manufacturing processes to reduce its carbon footprint. The Government will support the sector's sustainability goals, and companies are encouraged to expose employees to sustainability training to integrate green practices into their products.

site_title: HSA authorises Pfizer vaccine for kids aged six months to four years
summary: Singapore's Health Sciences Authority (HSA) has authorised Pfizer's Comirnaty Covid-19 vaccine for children aged six months to four years, with a three-dose regimen of 3mcg doses. The vaccine's benefits outweigh the risks, according to the HSA. The vaccination regimen will consist of three doses, with the first two doses given three weeks apart and the third dose given at least eight weeks after the second dose. The vaccine's effectiveness remains high, with over 80% protection against Covid-19-related hospitalisations for children aged five to 11 years old.

site_title: Local bourse ends flat with regional markets mostly in the red
summary: Local bourse ended flat, with regional markets mostly in the red, amid US economy uncertainty. The Straits Times Index shed 0.04% to close at 3,115.08. Japan's Nikkei 225 gained 1%, while Australian shares rose 1.4% driven by commodities companies. Keppel Corp was the biggest gainer, rising 2.5%. Sats plummeted 20.7% after announcing its acquisition of Worldwide Flight Services. Analysts warn of more pain ahead, citing potential significant misses to the downside for the S&P 500 this quarter.

site_title: New POSB home loan package offers rate similar to that of HDB loan
summary: DBS Bank launched two new home loan packages, one targeting Housing Board flat owners. The POSB HDB home loan offers an interest rate of 2.6% per year, similar to the HDB loan rate, and allows borrowers to earn higher interest on their savings with DBS Multiplier and POSB Save As You Earn accounts. The package also provides a cash bonus of $500. The DBS HomeSaver scheme offers similar benefits, aiming to help customers make the most of their savings amidst rising interest rates and market volatility.

site_title: S'pore can gain from US crypto regulatory woes: Industry exec
summary: Singapore's digital asset sector may benefit from the US's crypto regulatory woes, according to industry executive Diogo Monica. Monica, co-founder of American cryptocurrency bank Anchorage Digital, expects US regulatory troubles to push domestic and international players to set up headquarters outside the US, potentially creating opportunities for Singapore to attract these businesses.

site_title: Some racegoers pay a premium to make weekend one to remember
summary: US entrepreneur Rembrandt Flores is splurging on a week-long trip to Singapore for the Singapore Grand Prix, estimated to cost upwards of $30,000. His itinerary includes a Paddock Club package, meals at top restaurants, a private yacht trip, and F1 after-parties. Flores' spending on his Grand Prix experience is broken down to $44,373, including a VIP ticket for a cryptocurrency conference and a seven-day stay at a five-star hotel. The event is expected to attract a record-breaking 550,000 international visitors, generating over $1.5 billion in tourism receipts for Singapore.

site_title: Shell heist: Ex-surveyor jailed for taking over $123k in bribes
summary: A former surveyor, Muhammad Ali Muhammad Nor, was sentenced to 18 months' imprisonment for accepting bribes totaling $123,243.10 to conceal the misappropriation of gas oil at Shell Pulau Bukom. He aided 15 incidents worth over $10 million, which went undetected in 2016 and 2017. The bribes were accepted in exchange for turning a blind eye to the crime, allowing gas oil worth $10 million to be misappropriated.

site_title: Views divided on penalty
summary: Sport Singapore suspended support for swimmers Joseph Schooling, Amanda Lim, and Teong Tzen Wei for a month after admitting to consuming illicit drugs. The decision has drawn mixed reactions, with some praising the second chance and others feeling it was too lenient for a serious offense that broke both sporting and law regulations.

site_title: Optus probing massive hack
summary: Optus, an Australian telecommunications operator, is investigating a massive hack that allegedly exposed customer information, including names, dates of birth, phone numbers, and email addresses. The company immediately shut down the attack and is working with the Australian Cyber Security Centre to mitigate risks. Notable data that may have been compromised includes addresses and ID document numbers for a subset of customers. Payment details and account passwords remain secure. Authorities, including the Australian Federal Police and regulators, have been notified, and Optus has notified customers.

site_title: Innovation, collaboration can help world weather crisis: Tharman
summary: Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam emphasizes the need for innovation and international collaboration to weather the current economic crisis. He states that there are no quick fixes and that economic conditions will worsen before improving. Tharman notes that both public and private sectors must work together to drive economic transition and address climate change. He highlights the potential for Asian countries, particularly India and Southeast Asia, to emerge as a positive force, but warns that a stronger US dollar and recession in advanced economies pose significant challenges.

site_title: Cost of Optus' data breach risks eroding Singtel's profits
summary: Optus, a subsidiary of Singtel, revealed a data breach affecting 9.8 million Australian customers, exposing personal info of 2.8 million, including passports and driver's licenses. The breach's cost risks eroding Singtel's annual profit by more than a quarter. Estimated costs range from US$420 million to US$560 million, including compensation, legal bills, and security measures. The Australian government plans to tighten cyber-security legislation, while Optus faces potential class action lawsuits and increased security spending. The breach has sparked concerns about large-scale identity fraud.

site_title: Britain's financial crisis: Why the central bank acted
summary: Britain's central bank, the Bank of England (BOE), intervened in the financial markets by buying government bonds to stabilize the market and prevent panic selling. The move came after the new Prime Minister Liz Truss's tax and spending plans triggered a slump in bond prices, threatening to hurt the pension industry, raise recession risks, and increase inflation. The BOE aims to reverse the "dysfunction" in the bond market, specifically addressing problems facing pension funds, and investors are now expecting higher interest rates to combat inflation, with some predicting a rate of almost 6% by May.

site_title: 'The protagonist of the new F1'
summary: Formula One (F1) CEO Stefano Domenicali stated that Singapore remains a crucial part of the circuit, despite its expansion into the Middle East and North America. A decade ago, F1 visited 10 countries in East and South-east Asia, but currently only three (China, Singapore, and Japan) remain on the schedule. The addition of Las Vegas in 2023 will see the US host three grands prix, while the Middle East will stage four races.

site_title: McIlroy sees truce but Monahan plays hardball
summary: Rory McIlroy believes a truce is possible for men's professional golf, citing the need for unity after an "ugly year" marked by conflicts between the PGA Tour, European Tour, and LIV Golf. However, PGA Tour commissioner Jay Monahan disagrees, stating that the tours are on different paths and won't co-exist. The dispute escalated with LIV Golf filing an antitrust lawsuit and the PGA Tour responding with a countersuit. A trial is scheduled for January 2024, with LIV Golf also reportedly planning to secure broadcast rights with Fox through an unusual agreement.

site_title: Stricter property loan limits to moderate market demand
summary: Singapore has implemented stricter property loan limits to moderate market demand. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has raised the medium-term interest rate floor used to compute the Total Debt Servicing Ratio (TDSR) and Mortgage Servicing Ratio (MSR) by 0.5 percentage point, starting from September 30. For HDB loans, a 3% interest rate floor has been introduced, and the Loan-to-Value (LTV) limit has been lowered to 80% from 85%. Additionally, a 15-month wait-out period has been imposed on private property owners to buy non-subsidized HDB resale flats, effective immediately.

site_title: S. Korea seeks to freeze $93m of Bitcoin linked to Terra founder
summary: South Korean authorities have asked cryptocurrency exchanges to freeze approximately $93 million in Bitcoin linked to Do Kwon, founder of Terraform Labs behind the collapsed digital coins TerraUSD and Luna. Terraform Labs rejected charges, claiming the case has become "highly politicized" and accusing prosecutors of unfairness. Kwon, 31, is believed to be evading authorities, but claims to be in contact with government agencies and remains involved in Terraform Labs management. The freeze is related to a Bitcoin reserve connected to Kwon, amid controversy over a digital token transfer.

site_title: Chadwick wants to change perceptions
summary: Jamie Chadwick, 24-year-old Formula 1 driver, reflects on her early karting days, where she was one of few female drivers. Chadwick, who competes for Jenner Racing in the all-women W Series, expressed concerns about the environment, stating she was "blissfully unaware" of the scarcity of women drivers at the time.

site_title: China's warning on speculation sparks first renminbi gain in 9 days
summary: China's onshore renminbi advanced 0.1% for the first time in nine sessions after the central bank issued a verbal warning against currency speculation, halting an eight-session slide of around 3%. The People's Bank of China set the fix at a stronger-than-expected level for the 26th straight session. Despite this, the currency remains weak, having fallen about 4% against the greenback this month, and is on track for the worst annual loss since 1994. The PBOC is under pressure to balance boosting the economy with avoiding renminbi weakness.

site_title: Not the end of the world for Hamilton
summary: Lewis Hamilton, the seven-time F1 world champion, expressed his confidence ahead of the 2022 Singapore Grand Prix, despite acknowledging the challenging night race circuit. Despite struggling with his car this season, Hamilton is focused on getting a win and securing second place for Mercedes in the constructors' championship. He remains upbeat, viewing adversity as an opportunity to gain strength, and is also exploring business opportunities and personal passions outside of racing, including music and football.

site_title: Gimmeafirst en route to back-to-back success
summary: Key South African horse racing events are analyzed for Saturday's form analysis, focusing on upcoming races. The races include 16 events, with several horses expected to perform well, including Gimmeafirst, William Robertson, and Definitely Maybe. Each race is analyzed, highlighting potential winners, horses with improving form, and those to watch. The analysis provides a comprehensive overview of the upcoming events, helping readers make informed decisions about their bets.

site_title: Grand plans ahead for in-form Duric
summary: Singapore champion jockey Vlad Duric is looking to stay in the Kranji racing circuit after a successful comeback. With 22 wins from 73 rides, he has silenced doubters and secured a one-month licence extension to the end of the season. Duric plans to leave Singapore in four weeks, moving to a new home in Europe with his family, and has applied for next season's licence. He will ride Grand Koonta in the Lion City Cup, aiming to pad up his current haul and prove his staying power.

site_title: Albon 'excited' after quick recovery
summary: Alex Albon, a 26-year-old Thai-British Formula One driver for Williams, has made a swift recovery from appendicitis and is ready to return to action for the Singapore Grand Prix. Albon, who was replaced at the Italian Grand Prix, expressed excitement to get back behind the wheel, despite acknowledging the physical challenge of the night race. He has done everything possible to prepare for the event, which is close to home for him in Thailand. Albon is currently 19th in the drivers' standings with six races remaining.

site_title: Leclerc looking forward to Sunday... and Monday
summary: Charles Leclerc, the Ferrari driver, is eager to win the Singapore Grand Prix despite trailing Max Verstappen by 116 points in the drivers' championship. Leclerc, who is seeking his first victory since the Austrian Grand Prix in July, is optimistic about his chances with upgraded car components. He faces a challenging 61-lap, 23-turn street circuit under nighttime conditions. A win would help him close the gap with Verstappen, but it would also delay the Red Bull driver's championship coronation. Leclerc hopes to celebrate with his friends and girlfriend in the city on Monday.

site_title: German title race 'must be tighter'
summary: German Football League boss Donata Hopfen says the Bundesliga needs a closer title race to attract international fans, citing Bayern Munich's dominance as a reason for the league's lagging global TV revenue. The league's total spend was €484 million in the recent transfer window, behind La Liga and Serie A. Hopfen believes more competition would make the league easier to market globally and expressed solidarity with the current system, which prioritizes unity among German clubs.

site_title: Injuries 'up 20%' in Europe's Big Five leagues
summary: Injuries across Europe's Big Five leagues increased by 20% last season, costing clubs £500 million. The Premier League had the highest injury cost at nearly £185 million, followed by the German Bundesliga and La Liga. French champions Paris Saint-Germain had the highest individual injury cost at £34.2 million. The study attributes the rise to fixture congestion and intense playing styles, particularly in English and German clubs, as well as the impact of the World Cup on match schedules and player welfare.

site_title: Stern warning from Lord Justice
summary: Lord Justice, an 8-year-old New Zealand-bred gelding, has impressed trainer David Kok with a winning trial for a Class 3 assignment. Ridden by apprentice jockey Jerlyn Seow, Lord Justice scored 60.74 seconds in a 1,000m Polytrack trial, beating Winning Spirit by 3/4 lengths. This marks a significant turnaround from his last trial, where he finished eighth. Kok is hopeful of making it four wins in a row for the horse, which will run in the Class 3 race on October 8.

site_title: Schooling 'disappointed' by SportSG's sanctions
summary: Former Olympic champion Joseph Schooling expressed disappointment over Sport Singapore's sanctions, which include suspension of support and withdrawal of training assistance grants for him and fellow national swimmers Amanda Lim and Teong Tzen Wei, for consuming cannabis. The trio will face a month of restricted access to sports facilities and services. Schooling accepted the consequences of his actions, while Lim and Teong apologized for the distress caused and vowed to continue their training and strive to achieve their goals.

site_title: ST Sports Talk Podcast: F1 CEO Stefano Domenicali on Singapore GP's status, sport's growth and sustainability
summary: F1 CEO Stefano Domenicali discusses the Singapore Grand Prix's status on the F1 calendar and its importance in the sport's global strategy. He addresses rumors of preferential treatment for certain teams and highlights the push for sustainability by 2030. The Singapore GP is considered a key event in Asia, with Domenicali stating it remains a vital part of F1's global strategy. The conversation also touches on potential future expansions and the sport's growth in the region.

site_title: Football: Tottenham's Conte mum on injuries but says they could decide title race
summary: Tottenham Hotspur manager Antonio Conte expressed concerns about the team's injury situation ahead of their match against Arsenal, citing a grueling schedule that may impact the Premier League title race. Key players such as goalkeeper Hugo Lloris, winger Dejan Kulusevski, and defender Ben Davies are expected to be sidelined, while Conte acknowledged Arsenal's strong start under manager Mikel Arteta. A victory for Spurs at the Emirates Stadium could potentially change the standings, with the match serving as a crucial test for both teams.

site_title: This counsellor pursued a Masters to better support the emotional needs of children with special needs
summary: A Singaporean counsellor, Ms Chan Peilin, is working to support children with special needs and their families through her role at Think Psychological Services. Pursuing a Master of Guidance and Counselling (MGC) at James Cook University has given her the confidence and skills to address the emotional needs of her clients, including those with autism and other conditions. The program's flexible and interactive approach has enabled her to develop a holistic approach to counselling, equipping her to better support her clients and their families.

site_title: Next 24 hours
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

The next 24 hours feature various sports events. In football, Bilbao vs Almeria will be played tomorrow at 2:55am, while Getafe vs Valladolid and Sevilla vs Atletico will be played at 10:10pm and 12:25am respectively on Sunday. In golf, Day 2 of the Alfred Dunhill Links C'ship and The Ascendant LPGA will take place tomorrow at 7pm and 12:30am respectively. Additionally, MotoGP Thailand Grand Prix practice sessions will be held tomorrow, and F1 S'pore Grand Prix practice sessions will be held today at 5:55pm and 8:55pm. Various tennis and table tennis events will also be held throughout the day.

site_title: Tennis: Ruud qualifies for ATP Finals after reaching Seoul quarters
summary: Casper Ruud secured a spot at the ATP Finals for the second consecutive year after reaching the Korea Open quarter-finals. The Norwegian defeated Nicolas Jarry 6-2, 3-6, 6-3 in Seoul. Ruud, the world number two, is aiming to finish in the top three in the ranking and will face Yoshihito Nishioka for a semi-final spot. Alcaraz and Rafael Nadal have already qualified for the event, set to take place from Nov 13-20.

site_title: MMA: Singapore's Tiffany Teo eyes Angela Lee's belt after winning her first atomweight bout
summary: Singaporean MMA fighter Tiffany Teo won her first atomweight bout, submitting Ritu Phogat with a rear naked choke in the first round. The victory marked an impressive outing for Teo, who dropped down a weight class to compete. Teo has set her sights on Angela Lee, the current atomweight world champion, and earned a $50,000 bonus for the win. One Championship also announced a multi-year partnership with beIN Media Group to broadcast its events in the Middle East and North Africa.

site_title: Sports World: Teo in dominant win over Phogat at home
summary: Singapore mixed martial arts fighter Tiffany Teo dominated her opponent Ritu Phogat, submitting her by rear naked choke in the first round of their atomweight bout at the One Championship event. Denmark's World Cup kits, designed as a protest against Qatar's human rights record, have been toned down to minimize visibility. Italy's Serie A will feature its first female referee, Maria Sole Ferrieri Caputi, in a match on Sunday. The US women's basketball team, led by Alyssa Thomas, defeated Serbia 88-55 and set up a semi-final match against Canada.

site_title: American who allegedly made false bomb threat on SIA flight charged
summary: An American passenger, La Andy Hien Duc, 37, has been charged with causing alarm and voluntarily causing hurt after allegedly making a false bomb threat on a Singapore Airlines flight from San Francisco to Singapore. Duc claimed there was a bomb in a hand-carry bag, leading to a security response and a delay in disembarkation. He was arrested, remanded at a psychiatric hospital for observation, and tested positive for controlled drugs. The police will prosecute him under Singapore laws, which can carry a maximum jail term of three years and a fine of up to $5,000.

site_title: New cooling measures: Tighter housing loans, 15-month wait for private home owners to buy HDB flats
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore, Ministry of National Development, and Housing Development Board have implemented cooling measures to tighten housing loans and moderate demand in the property market. Key measures include a 0.5 percentage point increase in the medium-term interest rate floor for private loans, a 3% interest rate floor for HDB loan eligibility, a lowered loan-to-value limit from 85% to 80%, and a 15-month wait-out period for current and former private property owners to buy non-subsidized HDB flats. These measures aim to ensure home buyers borrow within their means and maintain affordability in the market.

site_title: Managing tyres really tricky: Pirelli
summary: Pirelli's motor sports director Mario Isola highlighted the unique challenges of the Singapore Grand Prix, citing the twisty 5.063km circuit and 23 low-speed corners as key factors. The new 18-inch tyres will require drivers to balance traction and prevent understeer, while the hot temperature and humidity, combined with the aggressive asphalt, will also play a role. Pirelli is pleased with the performance of the new tyres, which have led to more action on the track and less overheating, and is working towards a ban on tyre-warming blankets starting from 2024 to support Formula One's sustainability push.

site_title: Golf: Patrick Reed drops defamation lawsuit, files bigger one
summary: Patrick Reed dropped his $750 million defamation lawsuit against the Golf Channel and Brandel Chamblee in Texas, only to refile a larger one in Florida federal court. The new suit adds Golf Channel employees and parent companies as defendants, alleging they conspired to defame Reed since he was 23. Reed claims he lost sponsorships and seeks $750 million in damages for actual and compensatory damages, including intentional malice and reckless disregard for the truth. The defamation allegations stem from Chamblee's repeated accusations of cheating and defection from the PGA Tour to LIV Golf.

site_title: Lui saddles milestone 800th HK win
summary: Francis Lui has achieved a milestone 800th win in Hong Kong, joining an elite group of trainers. Lui, 63, reached the milestone with Vincent Ho and Seaweed Fortune at Happy Valley on Wednesday night. He is now among trainers Tony Cruz, John Size, and Ricky Yiu, who have also posted at least 800 victories. Lui's achievement comes after a dominant night, with Ho winning a treble and Lui securing a double with Ho aboard Gallant Waking. Lui has been a trainer since 1996/97 and his first Group 1 win came in 2017.

site_title: New POSB home loan package offers rate similar to that of HDB loan
summary: DBS Bank launched a new home loan package for HDB flat owners, offering an interest rate of 2.6% per annum, similar to the HDB loan rate. The package is available to those earning less than $2,500/month and to homeowners who have taken up two or more HDB mortgages. Borrowers with DBS Multiplier and POSB Save As You Earn accounts can earn higher interest and receive a $500 cash bonus. The move aims to help customers plan for their financial needs amidst rising interest rates and market volatility.

site_title: Formula One: Steps taken to bridge gap for women in motor sports, says W Series champion Chadwick
summary: Formula One champion Jamie Chadwick highlighted the W Series as a key step towards increasing women's participation in motor sports. Chadwick, 24, who races for Jenner Racing, said she was "blissfully unaware" of the lack of female drivers when she started karting at 11. She believes the W Series provides a platform for women to gain experience and progress in the sport, while also giving younger drivers a chance to develop their skills.

site_title: Football: Arsenal's Smith Rowe sidelined until December after groin surgery
summary: Arsenal midfielder Emile Smith Rowe underwent surgery on a groin injury and will not return to training until at least December. The 22-year-old had limited game time this season, making only four substitute appearances. Smith Rowe's surgery took place in London and his rehabilitation program has begun, with the goal of returning to full training in December. He is expected to miss seven rounds of Premier League matches, including the World Cup break in November and December, and will sit out Arsenal's Europa League and League Cup commitments during the period.

site_title: Free car-sharing, beautiful trains: 70 in LTA focus group session discuss public transport
summary: About 70 people participated in a focus group session at LTA's headquarters to share their views on Singapore's public transport system. Participants discussed shortcomings, including lack of cycling paths, bus arrival unpredictability, and night bus removal, as well as praised sheltered pathways and MRT map readability. Proposed ideas included more shower facilities, improved MRT trains with more art and greenery, and a transport fund for students. Senior Minister of State Chee Hong Tat attended to listen to their views, emphasizing the need for trade-offs and balancing costs while considering different ideas.

site_title: FairPrice donates $40,000 to Sinda to help needy students ahead of Deepavali
summary: FairPrice donated $40,000 to the Singapore Indian Development Association (Sinda) to support needy students ahead of Deepavali. This is double the amount donated in 2021. Additionally, five Sinda beneficiary families received $100 worth of FairPrice vouchers. The donation aims to help families affected by inflation, with one beneficiary, Valli Krishnasamy, stating that the vouchers were helpful in purchasing essential items, including chicken and diapers, for her family of four.

site_title: Singapore and Australia reaffirm close defence ties
summary: Singapore and Australia reaffirmed their close defence ties during a meeting between Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen and Prime Minister Anthony Albanese in Australia. The two countries acknowledged their long-standing bilateral defence relationship and discussed enhancing cooperation under the Comprehensive Strategic Partnership. They emphasized the importance of joint training areas, such as Shoalwater Bay, to increase capacity and training opportunities. The meeting also included a wreath-laying ceremony at the Australian War Memorial and meetings with other Australian officials. The partnership aims to strengthen cooperation between the two nations' armed forces.

site_title: Motor racing: Verstappen rates himself a 'long shot' to clinch F1 title in Singapore
summary: Max Verstappen, the current F1 world champion, has downplayed his chances of retaining the title by stating he is a "long shot" to win the Singapore Grand Prix. Despite being mathematically possible, Verstappen believes he needs a lot of luck to secure the championship. He will need to win the race and rely on his closest rivals, including Sergio Perez and Charles Leclerc, to falter in order to secure the title. Verstappen is focused on enjoying the weekend and winning the race, rather than worrying about the championship outcome.

site_title: Formula One: Leclerc impatient to win again, but ready for challenge of S'pore race
summary: Formula One driver Charles Leclerc is eager to win again after a seven-month drought, but faces a challenging task in the Singapore Grand Prix. Leclerc's last victory was at the Austrian Grand Prix in July, and he trails Max Verstappen by 116 points in the championship. Despite his pole position in 2019, Leclerc has struggled to secure a win, finishing second in the last three Grands Prix. Leclerc is optimistic about his chances, citing upgrades to his car and a focus on preparation, but acknowledges the long and challenging nature of the Singapore circuit.

site_title: S’pore, UK to work together to build capacity in region
summary: Singapore and the UK have signed a memorandum of understanding to promote capacity-building in Southeast Asia and the region. The agreement, signed on September 29, 2022, aims to enhance international development cooperation through the sharing of best practices in sustainable development. The partnership also includes plans to invest in green infrastructure and support climate resilience in the region. British Foreign Secretary James Cleverly launched the British International Investment Office in Singapore, which will focus on green infrastructure and a green economic transition. The partnership is seen as a significant step in deepening UK engagement in the region.

site_title: Over $44,000 for a week in S'pore to see F1? No sweat: Racegoers splurge for a weekend to remember
summary: American entrepreneur Rembrandt Flores is spending over $30,000 on a week-long trip to Singapore for the Singapore Grand Prix, including a VIP ticket, 7-day stay at a 5-star hotel, and a private yacht trip. He is also attending the Asia Crypto Week conference. His spending includes a $9,898 package at the Paddock Club, a meal at a Michelin-starred restaurant, and F1 after-parties. The event is expected to attract big spenders and corporate clients, generating significant revenue for the city.

site_title: S'pore think-tank studying benefits of floating nuclear power plants for S-E Asia
summary: A Singapore-based think-tank, the Centre for Strategic Energy and Resources (CSER), is studying the benefits of floating nuclear power plants for Southeast Asia. The centre, launched in 2018, focuses on small modular reactors and advanced nuclear power technologies. Following the global energy crisis and Russia's invasion of Ukraine, CSER aims to help countries achieve their energy transition and carbon neutrality goals. Denmark's Ambassador to Singapore has expressed support for the centre, highlighting the need for cleaner energy and sustainable systems, particularly in the region.

site_title: Family offices can support innovation, sustainable finance, philanthropy in S'pore: DPM Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong said family offices in Singapore can support innovation, sustainable finance, and philanthropy. The city-state is home to a fast-growing start-up community and a high concentration of private equity and venture capital firms focused on the region. Family offices can invest in innovative companies, mentor entrepreneurs, and contribute to sustainable finance initiatives. Singapore is also a good launch pad for family offices to support the global net-zero agenda, particularly in areas like blended finance for climate transition projects. The government is reviewing tax incentives to encourage family offices to give more to local charities.

site_title: Sembawang flat fire: Neighbours rushed to help evacuate family from burning unit
summary: A fire broke out at a 7th-floor flat in Block 340A Sembawang Close in Singapore, forcing the evacuation of around 100 residents. Neighbors, including construction manager Mr Xu Ming Lin and 22-year-old Mr Damien Lim, helped evacuate the family from the burning unit. Three children were taken to hospital for smoke inhalation. The cause of the fire is under investigation, with initial reports suggesting it started from the electrical switches in the flat. Donations have been made for the affected family, including household items.

site_title: New book details unique challenges faced by female drug offenders
summary: A new book, "A Woman's Journey Home: Stories Of Hope And Empowerment," highlights the unique challenges faced by female drug offenders in Singapore. The book features stories of 16 women, including Ms. Salimah Sukar and Ms. Chris Wong, who struggled with addiction and were incarcerated multiple times. Experts say female offenders often face abuse, neglect, and trauma, and struggle for financial independence. The book aims to provide a deeper understanding of their struggles and promote rehabilitation programs, such as the country's first all-women halfway house, Rise Above Halfway House.

site_title: Motor racing: New tyres and unique Singapore circuit will 'challenge' F1 drivers, says Pirelli's Isola
summary: Pirelli's motorsports director Mario Isola says the new 18-inch tyres and unique Marina Bay Street Circuit in Singapore will "challenge" F1 drivers, requiring them to balance traction and prevent understeer. Isola notes the hot temperature and humidity, as well as the circuit's aggressive asphalt, will also play a role. The new tyres have proven successful in increasing track action and reducing overheating, leading to Pirelli's push for a blanket ban, set to be implemented in 2024.

site_title: Swimming: Views divided on SportSG's sanctions on errant swimmers over drug use
summary: Sport Singapore has suspended support to national swimmers Joseph Schooling, Amanda Lim, and Teong Tzen Wei for a month after they admitted consuming controlled drugs while representing Singapore overseas. The decision has sparked mixed reactions, with some praising Sport Singapore for giving the athletes a second chance, while others feel it is too lenient for an offence that broke both sporting and law regulations. The athletes' actions have raised concerns about the integrity of Singapore's sports programs.

site_title: Formula One: Lewis Hamilton seeks 1st win of the season, hopes for positive weekend in Singapore
summary: Lewis Hamilton, a seven-time Formula One world champion, is seeking his first win of the season at the Singapore Airlines Singapore Grand Prix. Despite struggling with his Mercedes car this year, Hamilton is optimistic about the weekend and has praised the circuit, calling it one of the hardest and longest tracks. He is also focused on securing second place in the constructors' championship for Mercedes, with six remaining races. Off the track, Hamilton is balancing his racing career with other passions, including learning to play the piano and exploring business opportunities, as he prepares for eventual retirement.

site_title: Convenient tap-and-go commutes: More Singaporeans using contactless payment for transport
summary: Contactless payment methods are increasingly popular among Singaporean commuters, driven by convenience and ease of use. A 2021 Visa Urban Mobility study found that 51% of respondents preferred contactless payments due to their speed and convenience, while 48% valued not needing to top up stored-value travel cards. The survey also revealed that 65% of respondents still prefer stored-value travel cards, but 25% use contactless or mobile contactless cards more frequently for bus and train trips. Visa is working with the Land Transport Authority to make public transport more seamless and convenient, with over one billion tap-to-ride transactions processed globally in a single year.

site_title: Global energy crisis highlights need for semiconductor sector to be more sustainable
summary: The global energy crisis highlights the need for the semiconductor industry to become more sustainable, with the sector projected to consume up to 20% of global energy demand by 2030. The Singapore Semiconductor Industry Association (SSIA) Summit emphasized the importance of green transformation, with government support and industry strategies to be shared in October. Industry leaders propose adopting cleaner energy, refining manufacturing processes, and exposing employees to sustainability training to cut down on carbon emissions and drive progress in sustainability reporting.

site_title: NTU scientists map key part of human DNA associated with ageing and cancer
summary: Scientists from Nanyang Technological University (NTU) have mapped the molecular structure of telomeres, the protective caps at the ends of human chromosomes. Contrary to textbook depictions, telomeres are formed in columns and a spring structure, leaving a part of the DNA exposed and vulnerable to damage. This discovery paves the way for a deeper understanding of longevity and the development of better anti-cancer drugs, which could target telomeres and potentially overcome limitations of existing treatments. The research was published in the journal Nature after eight years of work.

site_title: Motor racing: Singapore race has been 'protagonist of the new F1', says F1 CEO Domenicali
summary: F1 CEO Stefano Domenicali stated that the Singapore Grand Prix remains a "protagonist of the new F1" despite the series' expansion into the Middle East and North America. The circuit has seen a decline in its original 2013 lineup, with only Singapore, Japan, and Malaysia remaining part of the 2023 schedule. A new stop in Las Vegas in 2023 will feature three US Grands Prix, while the Middle East will host four events.

site_title: Basketball: Curry says teams 'reloading' to dethrone Warriors as NBA champs
summary: Stephen Curry says NBA teams are "reloading" to dethrone the Golden State Warriors as champions, urging his teammates to "embrace" the target on their backs. Curry, aiming for his fifth championship, believes defending a title is the hardest thing in the sport. The Warriors will play their first pre-season game in Japan against the Washington Wizards, with Curry promising to "put on a great show" for the Japanese fans. Curry is looking forward to the new season, which he considers his "happy place," and is eager to get into the routine of the season.

site_title: Repeat offender gets five years' jail for counterfeiting $100 notes
summary: Muhammad Farhan Farus, 28, was sentenced to five years' jail for counterfeiting $100 notes in Singapore. He worked with an accomplice, Mahadi Ab Latif, to print and cut counterfeit notes between June and July 2021, with the intention of buying contraband cigarettes. The duo was caught when Farhan used the fake notes to purchase items, and 185 pieces of counterfeit notes were seized from a warehouse. Farhan's previous offense resulted in a three-year jail sentence, but he was deemed a repeat offender due to his involvement in the same scheme.

site_title: PropertyBT Podcast: Are Singapore's office buildings a good bet?
summary: Singapore's office market remains optimistic despite weaker economic growth and the rise of remote working. Leasing activity and investment sales for Grade A office buildings in the Central Business District are strong. Experts, including Nicholas Mak, Catherine He, and Leonard Tay, discuss the challenges and opportunities facing the market, including the impact of economic weakness and remote working on office demand. While some predict a shift towards more flexible and adaptable office spaces, others believe that high-quality office buildings will remain in demand, particularly among businesses and talent.

site_title: S'pore to gain from US crypto regulatory woes, says digital asset bank
summary: Singapore's digital asset sector is expected to benefit from the US's uncertain crypto regulation, according to Diogo Monica, co-founder of American cryptocurrency bank Anchorage Digital. As the US struggles with regulatory woes, some companies may relocate their headquarters offshore, creating opportunities for Singapore to attract digital asset businesses. Monica noted that the uncertainty in the US could prompt many domestic and international players to set up operations outside of the US, potentially benefiting Singapore's growing crypto industry.

site_title: Motor racing: Hamilton vows maximum attack to the end of the F1 season
summary: Lewis Hamilton has vowed to launch a maximum attack on the remaining six Formula One races to help Mercedes overtake Ferrari and claim second place in the constructors' standings. The seven-time world champion is determined to end a winning drought and secure a podium finish for the team, with Singapore considered a promising track for their high-downforce circuit. With six rounds remaining, Hamilton believes Mercedes have the opportunity to gain strength through adversity and win a race, despite Nico Rosberg expressing skepticism about their chances without luck.

site_title: Football: Covid vaccinations not compulsory for World Cup fans
summary: Qatar authorities announced that COVID-19 vaccinations will not be mandatory for World Cup fans, but all visitors over six will need to produce negative COVID-19 tests before flights to Qatar. The 29-day tournament, starting on November 20, will require fans to wear masks in public transport and those testing positive will be required to isolate. If cases surge, players, referees, and officials may be forced to stay in a secure "bio-bubble" for the event's safe operation.

site_title: Caltex first to raise petrol prices days after cuts by pump operators
summary: Caltex raised its petrol pump prices by 5 cents a litre, just days after an industry-wide reduction. The price increase brings Caltex petrols to the priciest, with its 92-octane fuel now at $2.76. The move follows declining raw material and wholesale prices, with Brent crude oil trading at US$89.32 a barrel. None of the other four pump operators have followed Caltex's price increase, which may be due to subdued demand for fuel and energy.

site_title: Golf: LIV denies report of TV buy agreement with FOX, countersued by PGA Tour
summary: LIV Golf has denied a report it plans to secure broadcast rights with FOX in an unusual airtime purchase agreement, instead stating it is in active discussions with several companies. The Saudi-backed circuit is facing a countersuit from the PGA Tour, which claims LIV Golf is competing unfairly by luring players with millions of dollars to defect from their contracts. The PGA Tour alleges LIV Golf is "orchestrated efforts to induce tour members to breach their contracts" and that its allegations are "baseless and entirely without legal merit."

site_title: Badminton: Loh Kean Yew named Grab brand ambassador
summary: Badminton ace Loh Kean Yew, 25, has been named Grab Singapore's first brand ambassador. The partnership was launched with a video showcasing Loh experiencing life as a GrabFood delivery rider. Loh, the Republic's first badminton world champion in 2021, expressed his excitement to work with a brand that reflects his values. The partnership will include various campaigns, including an Instagram augmented reality filter game and contest tie-in, and promotions on the GrabFood app, highlighting Loh's authenticity and work ethic as a national athlete.

site_title: Singapore signs agreements with US, UK to make flights greener
summary: Singapore signed two memoranda of cooperation with the US and UK to promote environmentally friendly aviation. The agreements focus on researching and using biofuel alternatives, encouraging sustainable flights, and establishing a green lane between the two countries. The US agreement also includes a green lane concept, while the UK agreement updates the Open Skies Agreement to prioritize environment protection. The move aims to reduce carbon emissions and aligns with Singapore's commitment to cleaner aviation, following similar agreements with New Zealand and the completion of the world's largest sustainable aviation fuel production capacity in 2023.

site_title: Tennis: Laver backs Kyrgios for success after run to Wimbledon final
summary: Australian tennis great Rod Laver backs Nick Kyrgios for future success after his Wimbledon final appearance. Laver attributes Kyrgios' defeat to Novak Djokovic to a lack of belief, not talent. Kyrgios has shown significant improvement in the second half of 2022, climbing back into the top 20 rankings. Laver believes Kyrgios realized his capabilities and now has the confidence to compete at the highest level, predicting a different player will emerge in next year's Wimbledon tournament.

site_title: Delivery rider killed in Choa Chu Kang accident not a workplace fatality; 3 people arrested
summary: A 28-year-old delivery rider died in a car accident in Choa Chu Kang on Tuesday night after being hit by a vehicle. The incident involved a power-assisted bicycle and a car, and paramedics were alerted at 11:25pm. The rider was taken to hospital and died, contrary to initial reports suggesting it was a workplace fatality. Three people, aged 32-36, were arrested for careless driving causing death and drink driving. Police investigations are ongoing, and a Facebook video shows the rider motionless on the ground after the accident.

site_title: Swimming: Joseph Schooling disappointed with SportSG sanctions but 'accepts the consequences'
summary: Former Olympic champion Joseph Schooling expressed disappointment over Sport Singapore's sanctions, accepting the consequences of consuming cannabis during the SEA Games in May. Schooling, 27, and fellow national swimmers Amanda Lim and Teong Tzen Wei were suspended from training assistance grants and access to sports facilities for a month. The trio, who were under Sport Singapore's High Performance Scheme, had all tested negative for drugs in their urine tests. Schooling will continue training on his own and thanked those who stood by him, while Lim vowed to achieve her goals and make Singapore proud again.

site_title: Basketball: LeBron James headlines ownership group with Major League Pickleball
summary: LeBron James' firm LRMR Ventures leads a new ownership group buying a team in Major League Pickleball (MLP). The group, also featuring Draymond Green and Kevin Love, aims to expand the league to 16 teams from 12. MLP founder Steve Kuhn believes the investment will help reach 40 million pickleball players by 2030. Pickleball, a fast-paced paddle sport with similarities to tennis, has become the fastest-growing sport in the US. The ownership group plans to build a championship team, citing the sport's fun and competitive community as key motivators.

site_title: Man fined $17,500 for flying into Singapore with 200kg of meat in luggage
summary: A Chinese national, Wang Liansheng, 68, was fined $17,500 for importing over 200kg of frozen meat products into Singapore without a permit. The meat, including rabbit and mutton, was seized and destroyed. Additionally, a Singaporean, Tan Kay Huat, 74, was fined $2,000 for illegally importing 55kg of fresh vegetables from Malaysia. Both cases highlight the importance of adhering to Singapore's food safety regulations, which include obtaining permits and declaring all food imports. Offenders face fines and imprisonment for violating these regulations.

site_title: SIA passenger who allegedly made bomb threat an example of drug harms: Shanmugam
summary: Singapore's Minister for Law and Home Affairs K. Shanmugam cited a recent bomb threat incident and a 2019 case of a man who died from LSD as examples of the harms caused by drugs. He emphasized that Singapore's drug policies are based on "science, evidence and common sense." Shanmugam noted that decriminalizing drug use in other countries has led to negative consequences, such as increased harm to non-users. He advocated for rehabilitation and reintegration programs, as well as family support and community involvement, to address drug addiction.

site_title: Maid gets jail for stealing jewellery worth over $16,200 and cash from employer
summary: A Singaporean migrant domestic worker, Ria Dwi Astuti, was sentenced to six months and two weeks in jail for stealing $16,207 worth of gold jewellery and £900 from her employer, Ms Gindo Kaur, between January and February 2022. Ria had been granted free access to the employer's household to carry out tasks, and she sold the stolen items to a male acquaintance. She pleaded guilty and apologized to her employer, but did not make restitution. The court noted that Ria had abused the trust placed in her as a domestic helper, resulting in significant losses.

site_title: $32m luxury goods scam: 2 men get 1 year in jail for helping couple flee S'pore
summary: Two Malaysian men, Mohamed Alias and Mohamad Fazli Abdul Rahman, were sentenced to one year in jail for helping a Singaporean couple, Pi Jiapeng and Pansuk Siriwipa, flee the country illegally. The pair, accused of a $32 million luxury goods scam, had been smuggled out of Singapore on July 4 by Alias, a lorry driver, and Fazli, who had received a payment of RM16,000 for his role. The couple was later arrested and charged with cheating and leaving Singapore illegally.

site_title: China warning on speculation sparks first renminbi gain in nine days
summary: China's onshore renminbi advanced 0.1% on September 29, halting an 8-session slide of around 3%, after the People's Bank of China issued a verbal warning against currency speculation. The central bank set the fix at a stronger-than-expected level for the 26th straight session. The move came as traders stuck to bearish bets on the renminbi amid a surging US dollar and local economic challenges. The onshore renminbi has fallen 4% against the greenback this month, with the offshore unit reaching a record low.

site_title: Chief Justice cuts sentence for man who sexually violated minor, overrules past incorrect cases
summary: Chief Justice Sundaresh Menon reduced the sentence of a 30-year-old man convicted of having sex with a 13-year-old girl to 3½ years' jail with no caning, after finding the initial sentence of six years' jail and three strokes of the cane to be not manifestly excessive. The decision comes after Menon overruled past cases where similar offenders received very low sentences, citing a need to apply the correct sentencing framework set out in the 2017 Pram Nair case. The framework recommends a minimum of seven to 10 years' imprisonment and four strokes of the cane for similar offenses.

site_title: Football: Grealish says his best is yet to come at Manchester City
summary: Manchester City playmaker Jack Grealish says his best is yet to come as he continues his recovery from a groin injury. Grealish has scored only one goal this season, but is confident he'll see improvement once he's fully fit. He's not worried about his numbers, focusing on training to be the best of his ability. Grealish believes it takes time to adapt to Pep Guardiola's system and is eager to perform better in his second season with the team.

site_title: Those caught smoking at public parks and beaches can be fined from Oct 1
summary: Singapore will fine individuals up to $1,000 for smoking at public parks and beaches starting October 1. The ban, which prohibits smoking in over 49,000 premises, was first implemented in July 2022 with verbal advisories. Following the end of the advisory period, those caught smoking in prohibited areas may face a composition fine of $200 or a fine of up to $1,000. Designated smoking areas have been provided in 12 regional parks and signs have been installed to remind smokers of the ban.

site_title: Football: Spain's Hermoso backs teammates in dispute with federation
summary: Spanish football star Jennifer Hermoso has publicly backed her teammates in their dispute with the Spanish Football Federation over working conditions in the national women's team. Hermoso, who is the team's all-time leading goalscorer, expressed her support for the players, who are unhappy with the management of injuries, locker room atmosphere, team selections, and training sessions. She acknowledged the need for communication and player input, but also accepted that the coach's decisions should not be dictated by the players. Hermoso's statement came after the federation made the players' complaints public.

site_title: Motor racing: Albon ready to get back on track in Singapore
summary: Williams Formula One driver Alex Albon is ready to return to racing after missing the Italian Grand Prix due to appendicitis. He spent a night in hospital intensive care and is feeling good, despite a different preparation schedule. Albon is excited to compete in the Singapore Grand Prix, a physically demanding circuit, and is looking forward to hitting the track on Friday. He replaces Nyck de Vries, who finished 9th in his debut at Monza, and is motivated by the opportunity to compete in the closest race to his home in Thailand.

site_title: Site for pilot private assisted-living development for seniors launched for tender
summary: A 60-year leasehold site in Kovan, Singapore, has been launched for sale by public tender to develop a pilot private assisted-living facility for seniors. The site, located within the Rosyth estate, is expected to yield self-contained units with en-suite bathrooms, averaging 32 sq m. The facility will provide long-term residential accommodation, with seniors aged 65 and above offered leases covering them till at least 95 years old. The development aims to offer seniors a living environment that enables independence and social bonding, with services including care, social activities, and community spaces.

site_title: Court rules handler liable for dogs' attack on smaller dog
summary: A Singapore district court ruled a dog handler liable for damages after two larger dogs attacked a smaller Japanese spitz on November 1, 2020, outside the handler's Upper Thomson home. The smaller dog, Shiro, and its owner, Dr. Joanne Lim, were bitten and received medical treatment. The court found the handler responsible for the incident, which occurred when the larger dogs bolted off their leash.

site_title: Britain told to relook tax-cut plans
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has publicly criticized Britain's new economic strategy, citing a recent slide in bond markets that forced the Bank of England to promise a "significant" response. Economists say rock-bottom investor confidence will only recover if the plan is scrapped, indicating the IMF is urging Britain to re-examine its tax-cut plans.

site_title: Shell heist: 18 months' jail for ex-surveyor who took bribes to ignore gas oil misappropriation
summary: A Singaporean ex-surveyor, Muhammad Ali Muhammad Nor, has been sentenced to 18 months' jail for accepting bribes totaling $123,243.10 in exchange for ignoring the misappropriation of gas oil at Shell Pulau Bukom, resulting in 15 undetected incidents worth over $10 million. The offense occurred in 2016 and 2017 while Ali worked for Intertek Testing Services, and he pleaded guilty to a graft charge.

site_title: Vesak Day revised to fall on June 2 next year; Singapore to have 7 long weekends in 2023
summary: Singapore's Vesak Day has been revised to fall on June 2, 2023, a Friday, after the Singapore Buddhist Federation verified the date with Chinese almanacs following public feedback. The change results in seven long weekends in 2023, up from the previously announced six. The revised date was made to prevent similar errors in the future, with the federation promising to conduct additional checks and verifications.

site_title: Sats shares tumble 21% after $1.64b deal to buy world's biggest air cargo handler
summary: Sats shares plummet 21% to a two-year low after the company's $1.64 billion deal to acquire Worldwide Flight Services, the world's largest air cargo handler, resumed trading. The deal will cover 50% of global air cargo volume. The company's shares sank 80 cents, or 20.7%, to $3.07. Despite some analysts downgrading their target prices, others remain optimistic about the company's longer-term prospects.

site_title: Formula One revs up business for F&B outlets around the circuit
summary: Business is booming for food and beverage (F&B) outlets in Singapore as Formula One revs up for the Singapore Grand Prix. Restaurants such as Lavo Singapore, Altro Zafferano, and Skai are fully booked for all three days of the event, with some venues offering exclusive corporate buyouts. F&B operators attribute the surge in bookings to pent-up demand created by the COVID-19 pandemic, with many events and experiences being cancelled during that time. The event is expected to drive significant business for F&B outlets, both those with and without track views.

site_title: America does not seek economic decoupling from China, says US ambassador in Beijing Nicholas Burns
summary: US Ambassador to Beijing Nicholas Burns stated that the US does not seek economic decoupling from China, despite competing in technology and reminding China of its commitments to multilateral agreements. The US and China have a $650 billion annual trade, with 11,000 American companies invested in China. Burns expressed concerns about Chinese investment in the US and China's aggressive policy towards Taiwan, citing recent military drills after US Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit. The ambassador urged nations to be concerned about China's actions threatening global trade through the Taiwan Strait.

site_title: NTU student took upskirt video of woman in toilet and then waited to apologise to her
summary: A 22-year-old NTU student, Zhou Zhiwen, pleaded guilty to filming an upskirt video of a woman in a campus toilet on February 5, 2021. Zhou, who deleted the video and waited to apologize to the victim, claimed he was feeling stressed and emotional. The incident was discovered when the victim noticed a shadow and found a phone, prompting her to shout and Zhou to flee. An Institute of Mental Health report found Zhou suffered from early psychotic symptoms at the time of the offense, contributing to his behavior.

site_title: Colombia's state oil firm to invest up to $69b to expand production of oil and gas: CEO
summary: Colombia's state-owned oil company, Ecopetrol, plans to invest around $48 billion over the next eight years to expand oil and gas production. CEO Felipe Bayon aims to increase daily production to 850,000 barrels of oil equivalent, up from current levels of 700,000. The company sells over half of its crude to Asia, with plans to increase this volume. Ecopetrol is also establishing its first overseas trading office in Singapore, representing a significant step in building relationships with existing clients and developing new markets.

site_title: US increasingly worried about UK turmoil, working with IMF
summary: The US is increasingly concerned about the UK's economic turmoil, triggered by Prime Minister Liz Truss's tax-cutting programme, which has led to historic plunges in British government bonds and the pound. The Biden administration is working with the IMF to apply pressure on the UK government to dial back its policies, citing concerns over market volatility and potential spillovers to the broader economy. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen and Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo have expressed skepticism about the UK's approach, calling it "misguided" and arguing it won't combat inflation or promote long-term economic growth.

site_title: Hong Kong's worst trading debut in 2022 sends EV-maker down 42%
summary: Hong Kong's worst trading debut in 2022 saw an electric-vehicle maker, Zhejiang Leapmotor Technology, plummet 42% to HK$25.05 after raising about US$800 million. The company's IPO was the steepest first-day decline by a listing larger than US$250 million in Hong Kong. China Vanke's property management unit, Onewo, also fell 7.9% to HK$45.45 after raising about US$739 million. Analysts attribute the poor performance to weak investor sentiment and high IPO prices.

site_title: With mega deal, Sats on path to becoming global supply chain leader
summary: SATS Ltd, a Singapore-based company, has secured a mega deal that puts it on track to become a global supply chain leader. The company has a prominent presence in East Asia and has seen a significant increase in cargo revenue during the pandemic, accounting for 40% of global airline revenue. By removing seats to accommodate cargo, some flights were able to maintain full bellyholds, highlighting the company's adaptability and growth potential. The mega deal is expected to further solidify SATS' position in the global supply chain industry.

site_title: South Korea seeks to freeze $93m of Bitcoin linked to Terra founder Do Kwon
summary: South Korea has sought to freeze $93 million of Bitcoin linked to Terra founder Do Kwon, with Interpol assistance, amid ongoing investigations into the collapse of two digital coins, TerraUSD and Luna. Terraform Labs, the company behind the coins, rejected South Korean charges and accused prosecutors of unfairness. The company claims Kwon is actively involved in management and has denied transferring digital tokens. A court warrant for Kwon's arrest was issued last month, with officials suggesting he is evading the probe. The freeze request includes 3,313 bitcoins worth approximately $65 million.

site_title: Some patients can now be hospitalised at home and be cared for via teleconsultations, home visits
summary: Singapore is launching a trial program, MIC@Home, to allow up to 2,000 patients to recover at home with mobile medical teams and teleconsultations. The program, which began in April 2022, aims to increase patient comfort, reduce hospital-acquired infections, and improve manpower efficiency. Patients receive similar clinical care to hospital patients, including intravenous medication and blood tests, and can be transferred to a hospital if their condition deteriorates. The program, which is being piloted by National University Health System, Singapore General Hospital, and Yishun Health Medical Home, has shown promising results in earlier trials.

site_title: Innovation, collaboration can get global economy out of today's crisis: Tharman
summary: Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam of Singapore emphasizes the need for innovation and international collaboration to help the global economy recover from the current crisis. He notes that there are no quick fixes and economic conditions will worsen before improving. Tharman warns of a global recession and its impact on countries using the US dollar, but highlights the potential for Asian countries, particularly India and Southeast Asia, to weather the crisis better. He advocates for public and private sector collaboration to drive economic transition and address climate change.

site_title: Football: Denmark's Qatar World Cup kit to be toned down
summary: Denmark's national football team will wear a "toned-down" kit at the World Cup in protest against Qatar's human rights record, according to sportswear maker Hummel. The kit, designed by Hummel, features a red main strip, a white second strip, and a black-and-grey third strip symbolizing "mourning". Qatar's World Cup organisers responded, denying claims of thousands of lives lost during construction and highlighting "significant reforms" to protect workers. The dispute sparked a fierce reaction from Qatar, urging Denmark's football federation to intervene and accurately convey the outcome of their communication with the Supreme Committee.

site_title: Australia's massive data breach risks eroding Singtel's profits
summary: Australia's Optus, a subsidiary of Singtel, disclosed a massive data breach exposing the personal information of 9.8 million customers, or over one-third of the population. The breach, which includes sensitive documents like passports and driver's licenses, risks eroding Singtel's profits by up to a quarter of its annual profit, estimated to be between $420 million and $560 million. The Australian government plans to tighten cyber-security legislation, and Optus is expected to spend on security measures and training.

site_title: Football: Injuries 'up 20 per cent' in Europe's top leagues
summary: Injuries across Europe's top five leagues rose 20% in the 2021/22 season, with England's Premier League having the highest injury cost of nearly £185 million. Insurance brokers Howden found clubs paid a record-high £513 million for injuries. The congested calendar, including the World Cup, has sparked concerns over player workloads. The Premier League, La Liga, and French club Paris Saint-Germain had the highest injury costs, with French club PSG paying £34 million. The World Players' Union is urging FIFA to implement minimum rest periods and mid-season breaks to reduce injuries.
