site_title: Traffic victims' medical costs paid through govt schemes: not all can be reclaimed from insurers, says court
summary: A court decision has raised questions about whether vehicle insurers should reimburse government subsidies and schemes used by accident victims to fund medical treatment. An 81-year-old victim claimed $57,000 in medical expenses from a defendant, despite paying less than $500 out-of-pocket, with the remaining costs covered by public schemes. The case is now going on appeal to the High Court, potentially clarifying whether insurers should reimburse these government subsidies.

site_title: Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine approved for children aged 6 months to 4 years
summary: The Health Sciences Authority (HSA) in Singapore has approved the Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine, Comirnaty, for children aged 6 months to 4 years. The vaccine's benefits are deemed to outweigh the risks, with a recommended three-dose primary series. Clinical data shows the vaccine provides a similar immune response in young children as in adults, with estimated efficacy of 73% against Covid-19-related hospitalizations. Adverse events are mild to moderate and commonly reported, but no serious cases of myocarditis were reported in the clinical study. Vaccinations will be available next month for the two-dose Moderna/Spikevax vaccine and by the end of the year for the three-dose Pfizer-BioNTech/Comirnaty vaccine.

site_title: Fuel supplier Sentek Marine charged with acquiring over $80m in gas oil linked to Shell Bukom heist
summary: Sentek Marine & Trading, a Singapore-based marine fuel supplier, has been charged with acquiring over $80 million in marine gas oil linked to Shell's Bukom heist. The firm faces 42 charges under the Corruption, Drug Trafficking and Other Serious Crimes Act. Sentek denies all charges and intends to claim trial. The company allegedly received the stolen gas oil between 2014 and 2018 despite knowing it was the result of criminal activity. Sentek founder Pai Keng Pheng, 59, also faces 83 charges related to the scandal.

site_title: S'pore, Laos ink MOUs to deepen cooperation in emerging areas
summary: Singapore and Laos signed four memorandums of understanding (MOUs) to deepen cooperation in emerging areas such as energy, digital technology, sustainability, and environmental protection. The agreements include renewable energy deployment, regional power grids, and cross-border electricity trade. The move aims to enhance regional cooperation and decarbonize the energy sector, while creating jobs and economic growth. The two countries also agreed to strengthen people-to-people ties, including human resource development, business, and tourism links.

site_title: US stocks rally after Bank of England intervention
summary: US stocks rallied after the Bank of England's intervention in the British bond market, reassuring investors. The Bank of England temporarily bought long-dated British government bonds to restore orderly market conditions, pressuring Treasury bond yields. This led to a reversal of a spike in bond yields and a reversal of the recent slump in US stocks, which had pushed major indexes to their lowest level of 2022. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index all gained, with individual stocks like Biogen and Netflix also seeing significant increases.

site_title: UK financial crisis: Why Bank of England stepped in and what's next
summary: The Bank of England intervened in the UK financial crisis by buying bonds on September 28, aiming to reduce market chaos triggered by new Prime Minister Liz Truss's tax and spending plans. The move seeks to address problems in the pension industry and prevent panic selling. The crisis has led to a surge in government bond yields, threatening the housing market and recession risks. The pound plummeted, adding to inflation pressure, and interest rates are expected to rise to almost 6% by May. The government's tax cut plan remains unchanged, and investors are calling for a reversal of the plan to regain confidence.

site_title: Crypto world on edge after string of hacks with $3.2 billion stolen from DeFi projects
summary: Hackers have stolen over $3.2 billion from DeFi (decentralized finance) projects this year, with $2.2 billion of that lost in the past six months alone. The thefts, which have targeted platforms such as Beanstalk and Nomad, are attributed to flaws in the smart contracts that power DeFi, allowing hackers to exploit vulnerabilities and orchestrate attacks on the digital infrastructure. The breaches have shaken faith in DeFi, prompting start-ups to explore preventive measures and security and auditing companies to see a surge in business.

site_title: Drive to cut Singaporeans' sodium intake by 15%
summary: Singapore aims to reduce its residents' sodium intake by 15% over the next five years through a national strategy. The Health Promotion Board will promote the use of lower-sodium salt substitutes, sauces, and seasonings, working with retailers to make these alternatives more affordable. The goal is to lower daily sodium intake from 3,600mg to 3,100mg, aligning with the World Health Organisation's recommended daily intake. The strategy includes a public education campaign and the introduction of lower-sodium salt products, starting with a $2.50 400g packet at supermarkets FairPrice and Sheng Siong.

site_title: Laotian leader calls on PM Lee
summary: Laotian Prime Minister Phankham Viphavanh met with Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, signing four memorandums of understanding on energy, sustainability, and environmental protection. The meeting was followed by a lunch at the Istana, where both leaders also witnessed the ceremonial welcome of Mr Phankham by President Halimah Yacob.

site_title: Tips on securing and thriving in an overseas posting
summary: Singapore is a talent hub, ideal for sending experienced executives abroad to secure top regional and global roles. This strategy allows Singaporeans to gain international exposure and hone their skills, while also attracting top foreign talents to drive the country's competitive advantage. By leveraging its strategic location, Singapore can capitalize on its expats to make their mark globally and stay ahead of competitors.

site_title: Legal hotshot relocates to Singapore after 25 years in UK
summary: Singapore is attracting top legal talent with the relocation of London-based King's Counsel (KC) Ng Jern-Fei, who has spent 25 years in the UK. Ng, admitted to the Singapore Bar in September, has previously chaired the Singapore Academy of Law's Foreign Lawyers Chapter, providing support to Singapore lawyers pursuing English Bar careers. His move is seen as a sign of the Republic's growing appeal to international legal experts, highlighting the country's growing reputation as a hub for legal professionals.

site_title: Handler found liable for bigger dogs' attack on spitz
summary: A district court found a dog handler liable for damages in a case where his two larger dogs attacked a smaller Japanese spitz, causing injury to its owner, Dr. Joanne Lim, on November 1, 2020. The handler was found liable for not taking sufficient precautions to control his dogs in a public place, resulting in the attack. The incident highlights the importance of dog owners taking necessary precautions when walking dogs in public areas.

site_title: Traffic injuries: Courts may clarify on insurers reimbursing subsidies
summary: Courts may clarify whether vehicle insurers should reimburse government subsidies used to fund medical treatment for accident victims. An 81-year-old victim claimed $57,000 in medical expenses, with the victim paying less than $500 out-of-pocket, and receiving the rest from public schemes. The case is now going on appeal to the High Court after earlier decision grounds were released in September. The outcome could impact how insurers reimburse subsidies for accident victims' medical expenses.

site_title: Wage growth inevitable but cannot outstrip productivity: DPM Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong warned that Singapore's wage growth cannot outstrip productivity, or the country will lose its global competitiveness. He emphasized the need for the National Wages Council to ensure fair, inclusive, and sustainable growth, citing the council's role in matching wage increases with productivity growth over the past decade. Wong also highlighted the need to address income inequality and reduce wage gaps, and encouraged employers, workers, and the government to work together to achieve this goal.

site_title: Calm on board plane despite escort of fighter jets
summary: A Singapore Airlines flight SQ33 was delayed and escorted by fighter jets after a bomb hoax was reported. Passengers remained calm despite the incident, and the cabin crew managed the situation well. The plane made three loops over the South China Sea before landing at Changi Airport, where authorities boarded the plane and arrested a passenger suspected of making the threat. The delay lasted over three hours, but no one felt unsafe during the ordeal. The plane ultimately landed safely, and the passengers were able to complete their journey.

site_title: Nearly 150 caterers have already switched to low-sodium salt
summary: Nearly 150 catering companies in Singapore have switched to low-sodium salt and sauces ahead of a Health Promotion Board (HPB) campaign to reduce sodium consumption. The switch, initiated in 2021, has shown that customers did not notice a change in taste and was a "pleasant experience" for caterers. Studies have linked excessive sodium intake to high blood pressure and related health issues. HPB aims to increase the market share of low-sodium salt from 2% to at least 50% through grants and incentives, as part of efforts to address rising hypertension in Singapore.

site_title: Shell technician received up to $2.3m for role in gas oil misappropriation
summary: A Shell process technician, Cai Zhi Zhong, pleaded guilty to misappropriating gas oil worth over US$93 million from 2014 to 2018, with gains estimated between US$1.3 million and US$1.6 million. Cai used the money to purchase luxury items, including a condominium and Audi A3 car, and watches worth up to $73,500 each. He faces sentencing on October 20 for multiple offences, including criminal breach of trust and dealing with the benefits of criminal activities.

site_title: More to sustainability than action on climate change, says MAS chief
summary: Singapore's MAS chief Ravi Menon emphasizes that sustainability extends beyond climate change, focusing on policies ensuring economic stability and promoting sustainable work environments. He warns policymakers about the dangers of supply and demand imbalance, which can lead to inflation. Menon stresses the need for central banks to slow down the economy to achieve medium-term macroeconomic sustainability, citing labor shortages and changes in work preferences as contributing factors. He advocates for sustainable work environments that balance productivity and work-life balance.

site_title: Legal hotshot relocates to S'pore to focus on Asia after 25 years in UK
summary: Singapore is attracting top legal talent with the relocation of London-based King's Counsel Ng Jern-Fei, who spent 25 years in the UK. Ng, a Malaysian-born legal expert, has been admitted to the Singapore Bar and will split his time between Singapore, China, and London. He will contribute to Asia's growth as a global hub for international commercial dispute resolution. Ng's relocation coincides with Singapore's increasing diversity and sophistication in the arbitration ecosystem, and his expertise will add depth and diversity to the country's legal practitioners.

site_title: Jail, cane for drug abuser whose car hit pedestrian during police chase
summary: A 36-year-old man, Vaswani Richard Prakash, was sentenced to over 9 years in jail for driving a car that hit a pedestrian during a police chase in Toa Payoh. He led police on a high-speed chase through nine red lights, reaching speeds of 120kmh, while serving a remission order for drug abuse and driving without a license. The pedestrian suffered multiple injuries, including a fractured ankle. Vaswani was also fined $3,000, ordered to receive 12 strokes of the cane, and disqualified from obtaining driving licenses for 8 years.

site_title: Retirees, housewives less satisfied with taxis, private-hire cars in 2022
summary: Singapore residents, including retirees, housewives, and the unemployed, are less satisfied with using taxis and private-hire cars compared to 2021, with scores decreasing by 5.8% to 72.1 points. Public buses and MRT maintained their 2021 levels of customer satisfaction. Non-working commuters gave lower scores, particularly on value perception and ease of getting a ride. The Institute of Service Excellence attributes the decrease to fewer vehicles on the road and higher fees. The study suggests transport operators should prepare for rising demand as more people return to the workplace.

site_title: Must-reads
summary: Singapore is urging citizens to cut their salt intake by 15% over the next five years to combat excessive consumption. The Health Promotion Board plans to promote lower-sodium alternatives and make them more affordable. Meanwhile, a 37-year-old foreign national was arrested for allegedly making a bomb threat on a Singapore Airlines flight, which was escorted by fighter jets after landing safely. In Vietnam, Typhoon Noru made landfall, causing power outages and damage, with over 500,000 households affected.

site_title: Motorist who defamed workshop on Facebook ordered to pay over $51k
summary: A Singaporean motorist, Jerry Tang Mun Wah, has been ordered to pay over $51,000 in damages and costs for defamation after publishing a post on Facebook claiming a workshop, On Site Car Accessories.SG, was seeking to charge him a fee for checking a car battery under warranty. The High Court found the post defamatory, rejecting Tang's defenses of justification and fair comment. Justice Kwek ordered Tang to pay $20,000 in damages, $24,000 in legal costs, and over $7,000 in disbursements, and also required him to remove the post and publish a written apology on three Facebook groups.

site_title: Passenger on SIA flight arrested after allegedly making bomb threat
summary: A 37-year-old foreign national was arrested on board a Singapore Airlines flight after allegedly making a bomb threat on a flight from San Francisco to Singapore. The threat was made at 2:40am, and the plane was escorted by two Republic of Singapore Air Force fighter jets before landing. The threat was later verified to be false, and the passenger was arrested for suspected consumption of controlled drugs. The incident is under investigation, and the passenger faces potential fines or jail time under anti-terror laws.

site_title: Sun Xueling stresses need to stay vigilant against terrorism
summary: Singapore's Minister of State for Home Affairs, Sun Xueling, stressed the need for vigilance against terrorism as the country continues to be a target. A false alarm on a Downtown Line train in August 2021, which turned out to be an umbrella, highlights the importance of staying vigilant. SBS Transit, which implemented a security enhancement program called Threat-Oriented Person Screening Integrated System (Topsis), was recognized for its efforts in enhancing security. The government encourages active participation from businesses and the community in a whole-of-society approach to counter terrorism.

site_title: Sats to pay $1.64b in cash for world's largest air cargo handler WFS
summary: Sats has agreed to buy Worldwide Flight Services (WFS), the world's largest air cargo handler, for approximately $1.64 billion in cash. The acquisition will elevate Sats to a global leader in aviation services, covering over 50% of global air cargo volume. The combined network will operate in key airports worldwide, enhancing service quality, digitalization, and supply chain visibility. The deal is expected to be immediately financially accretive, with a 78% increase in earnings per share and over 200% revenue growth on a pro forma basis.

site_title: Expect warmer days, chillier nights due to climate change
summary: Singapore is investing in research and development to tackle the effects of climate change, including warmer days and chillier nights, as well as extreme weather events. The country's National Environment Agency (NEA) is strengthening its weather forecasting capabilities and conducting a third national climate change study, which will provide localised climate projections until 2100. The study also includes data on land subsidence, with Singapore sinking at an average rate of 1.4mm per year, which could amplify the impact of sea-level rise.

site_title: Dengue cases declining after early spike ahead of peak season
summary: Singapore has seen a decline in dengue cases after an early spike ahead of the peak season, with the weekly number of reported cases falling from 1,568 in May to under 600 in September. The National Environment Agency (NEA) attributes the decline to collective efforts of stakeholders and the community, as well as the implementation of Wolbachia technology to control the Aedes aegypti mosquito population. Dengue cases reported as of September 24 total 27,761, with households accounting for 63% of all dengue cluster areas.

site_title: US fines 16 financial firms $2.6b over discussing deals, trades on personal apps
summary: US regulators fined 16 financial firms, including Barclays, Bank of America, and Goldman Sachs, a combined $1.8 billion for discussing deals and trades on personal devices and apps. The firms' staff, including senior and junior investment bankers, communicated via text messages and WhatsApp from 2018 to 2021, violating federal rules that require preserving business communications. The institutions cooperated with the investigation and have implemented improvements to their compliance policies. The case marks a landmark moment for the Securities and Exchange Commission and Commodity Futures Trading Commission, emphasizing the importance of record-keeping requirements.

site_title: 'Fastest Car Not Enough'
summary: There is no article content provided to summarize.

site_title: Anti-scam app ScamShield now available for Android users
summary: ScamShield, an anti-scam app, is now available for Android users. Developed by the National Crime Prevention Council (NCPC) and Open Government Products, the app blocks calls and SMSes from verified scam-related numbers. The Android version, launched on September 1, has almost identical features to the iOS version, but only notifies users of scam messages instead of diverting them to a junk folder. Since its iOS launch in November 2020, the app has been downloaded over 315,000 times and blocked over 29,000 phone numbers suspected of being used for scam calls.

site_title: Serene Centre in Bukit Timah up for sale at $120 million
summary: The Serene Centre, a 30-unit mixed-use development in Bukit Timah, is up for sale at a reserve price of $120 million. The freehold property, built in the 1980s, comprises retail, food, and beverage units, apartments, and carpark facilities. Located near the Botanic Gardens MRT interchange station, it is eligible for purchase by foreigners and has a high potential for rental income and redevelopment. A tender for the property will close on November 14, while a collective sale tender for Sultan Plaza is expected to close on October 26 at a reserve price of $325 million.

site_title: Diversified customer base
summary: Worldwide Flight Services, the world's largest air cargo logistics provider, was founded in 1984. With 32,300 employees serving 300 customers at 164 airports in 18 countries, the company boasts a diversified customer base including major airlines and logistics players. Despite a negative book value of €829 million, Worldwide Flight Services reported €232 million in Ebitda and €66 million in net profit before tax in the 12 months ended March 31. The company is backed by Cerberus Capital Management, which acquired it in 2018 for €1.2 billion.

site_title: Digital IDs on blockchain could help with crypto compliance
summary: Digital identity stored on blockchain could simplify crypto compliance. Experts believe that investors creating a digital identity on the blockchain could streamline the process of applying for online wallets. This, in turn, would enable companies to verify identities more efficiently. According to David Shin of Klaytn Foundation, having this information stored on the blockchain reduces the time spent on creating digital wallet accounts. This technology has the potential to enhance crypto compliance and user experience.

site_title: Quality and standards certs give SMEs an edge over rivals
summary: A recent Enterprise Singapore survey found that 70% of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) gained better access to exports and global opportunities after adopting quality and standards certifications. The certifications, such as Singapore Standard (SS) 668, have helped companies improve their quality control processes, attract new business, and establish trust with customers. This is particularly evident in Jurong Cold Store, which has seen an increase in exports to countries like Chile and Norway after implementing the certification program.

site_title: Next 48 hours
summary: Upcoming sports events include the Alfred Dunhill Links Championship golf tournament, the Ascendant LPGA golf tournament, and the Tel Aviv Open tennis tournament, all scheduled to take place over the next 48 hours. Other events include the Korea Open, the Parma Ladies Open, and the Thailand Grand Prix, as well as the F1 S'pore Grand Prix and the World Team Championships in table tennis.

site_title: Study finds more S'pore investors keen on sustainable investments
summary: A Standard Chartered Bank survey found 37% of Singapore investors expect to hold 15% or more sustainable assets in their portfolios within 2-3 years, up from 24%. Despite this, low adoption rates indicate untapped opportunities for sustainable investments. The survey highlights climate change and carbon emissions as top ESG priorities, with perceived low returns or higher risk being the primary barrier for investors. The bank suggests addressing these concerns with professional advice and education to increase interest and adoption of sustainable investments.

site_title: Singapore ranks 4th in global digital competitiveness, top in Asia
summary: Singapore has moved up one spot to rank fourth globally in the IMD World Digital Competitiveness Ranking, driven by improvements in tertiary education, research and development, and regulatory frameworks. The country ranked first in the "technology" factor and retained its top spot in the "regulatory framework" sub-factor. South Korea moved up four places to rank eighth, while Hong Kong dropped from second to ninth place. The World Competitiveness Centre noted that all regions are "far from being fully prepared to combat sophisticated cyber attacks".

site_title: Deflation looms for China amid Covid-19, property crisis: Survey
summary: China faces increasing deflation risks due to the ongoing property crisis and Covid-19 restrictions, according to a private survey by China Beige Book International. Companies reported the weakest growth in sale prices since 2020, despite rising wages and input costs. The property industry is the main driver of deflationary pressure, with home prices slumping for the 12th straight month. The survey also highlights a slowdown in the manufacturing industry and declining corporate borrowing activity, pointing to a "new era of much slower growth" for China.

site_title: Renminbi weakest against US dollar since 2008 crisis
summary: The onshore renminbi has fallen to its weakest level against the US dollar since the 2008 global financial crisis, weakening 0.2% to 7.1955 per dollar. China's support for the currency appears to be easing, with the People's Bank of China setting a daily reference rate that was 444 pips stronger than expected. The renminbi has fallen 4% against the dollar this month, with analysts attributing the decline to the diverging monetary policies between China and the US.

site_title: Company briefs: Pantera Capital
summary: Pantera Capital plans to raise $1.25 billion for its second blockchain fund, despite market fluctuations, aiming to close the fund by May. Founder Dan Morehead aims to provide liquidity for investors who are giving up on digital assets. Meanwhile, JPMorgan Chase's UK digital lender has attracted 1 million customers and processed 92 million transactions since its launch in 2021, holding £10 billion of deposits. Sun Venture is considering a deal to buy the remaining shares of PSGourmet, a Singapore-based restaurant chain, valued at approximately $300 million.

site_title: Changing of guards ceremony at Istana resuming after two years
summary: The Istana will resume its changing of guards ceremony after a two-year hiatus due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The ceremony, which has been held monthly since 1960, will resume on Sunday at 6pm. The event marks the handing over of responsibility to another platoon of 20 guards, selected from the SAF Military Police Command, who will perform sentry duty on a monthly basis. The ceremony will be held at the Istana main gate, featuring a march-in by the incoming guards, a silent precision drill, and a 30-minute event.

site_title: Sports World: Ex-Blues star Mikel hangs up boots at 35
summary: Former Chelsea midfielder John Obi Mikel, 35, announced his retirement from football after a decorated career spanning over a decade. Mikel, who won the Champions League in 2012, accumulated 372 appearances and multiple titles with Chelsea. Meanwhile, Iran drew 1-1 with Senegal in a friendly match, and Dutch cyclist Mathieu van der Poel was fined A$1,500 for assaulting two girls who interrupted his sleep.

site_title: Nets coach now says all's good with Durant
summary: Brooklyn Nets head coach Steve Nash has downplayed the tension between himself and Kevin Durant, stating that there is "no bad blood" heading into the 2022-23 NBA season. Durant had requested a trade in June but ultimately stayed with the Nets, with Nash and general manager Sean Marks keeping their jobs. Nash believes the situation was "overblown" and that Durant has moved on, while Durant has spoken about his decision to remain unvaccinated, which led to him declining a contract extension with the Nets.

site_title: Kipchoge to give out medals but Farah is injured
summary: Eliud Kipchoge will participate in the London Mini Marathon, handing out medals to participants, after breaking his world record in Berlin last weekend. Kipchoge, a four-time London winner, will not compete in the full marathon due to a scheduling conflict with the Berlin course. Britain's Mo Farah has withdrawn from the full marathon with a hip injury, despite treatment. The London Marathon will return to its April date in 2023, increasing Kipchoge's chances of competing. Kipchoge's participation is seen as a potential inspiration for Farah, who may consider deferring retirement.

site_title: Regional markets awash in red ink after Wall Street's overnight fall
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.6% to 3,116.31, with 430 losers outweighing 171 gainers, as regional markets mirrored Wall Street's decline. The S&P 500 hit its lowest level in nearly 2 years, amid a risk-averse global environment. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index plummeted 3.4%, while South Korea's Kospi and Japan's Nikkei 225 also fell. Only Emperador and Venture Corporation were in the black among STI stocks, with Emperador gaining 1% and Venture edging up 0.1%.

site_title: Chinese workers lacking in skills for transition to favoured 'hard tech' jobs
summary: China's tech giants, such as Alibaba and Tencent, are shifting their focus to "hard tech" industries like electric vehicles, biopharmaceuticals, and AI, but a skills mismatch is hindering the transition. Despite a 382% increase in job postings in these emerging industries, many workers lack the necessary skills to pivot into these sectors. This has contributed to high unemployment rates, particularly among 16-24 year olds, and may slow advancements in these industries. Experts predict it may take 3-5 years for the skills gap to ease, but state-funded initiatives could eventually fill the gap.

site_title: Roger will never forget Nadal's 'incredible effort'
summary: Roger Federer, the 20-time Grand Slam champion, has retired from competitive tennis after a 24-year career. He partnered with Rafael Nadal in a farewell doubles match at the Laver Cup, where Team Europe lost to Team World. The emotional goodbye marked the end of the "Golden Age" of men's tennis, with Federer, Nadal, and Novak Djokovic forming a long-running rivalry. Federer expressed gratitude to Nadal for his support and described the farewell as "incredible" and "beautiful."

site_title: From a watcher to an F1 driver
summary: Chinese karting sensation Zhou Guanyu, now a Formula One driver, reminisced about his past as a spectator at the 2008 Singapore Grand Prix. At 9 years old, he was one of the 100,000 fans cheering under the night lights at the Marina Bay Street Circuit, dreaming of making it to the top of motor sports. Zhou has now taken his career to the next level, racing for Alfa Romeo.

site_title: Djokovic wants swansong like Federer's
summary: Novak Djokovic wants to retire with his biggest rivals by his side, mirroring Roger Federer's emotional farewell. Djokovic expressed his desire for Federer, Rafael Nadal, and Andy Murray to be present during his final tennis match. The 35-year-old Djokovic, who is one Grand Slam title behind Nadal's record, felt no issues with his wrist after a recent injury. He praised the rivalry between himself and Nadal, which has spanned 59 matches. Djokovic hopes to continue playing with Nadal in the future, keeping the rivalry "exciting for us and for tennis fans."

site_title: Paddlers to play in Covid-secure Chengdu bubble
summary: China is hosting the table tennis world team championships in a Covid-secure "closed loop" bubble in Chengdu, following a roller-coaster ride of lockdowns and an earthquake. Nearly 1,300 people, including over 250 international players, will be encased in the bubble. The event, which started on Friday, is the first major international sports event in China since the Beijing Winter Games. The tournament will be played for 10 days, with strict zero-Covid policies in place, including daily PCR tests and no spectators. China is the defending champion in both men's and women's events.

site_title: Grand Koonta muscles up for Sunday's main event
summary: Grand Koonta, a 7-time grass track winner, is set to challenge King Arthur in Sunday's main event. Grand Koonta, trained by James Peters and ridden by Vlad Duric, ran a faultless gallop on Wednesday, covering 600m in 39.8 seconds. The Kranji Stakes A trip of 1,200m is a distance Grand Koonta is well-suited for, and Peters' decision to let Duric take a more cautious approach suggests he believes Grand Koonta has the credentials to inflict damage on King Arthur.

site_title: Enjoy Messi while we can, Scaloni tells fans
summary: Argentina coach Lionel Scaloni has urged fans to "enjoy" Lionel Messi while he can, comparing his eventual retirement to tennis great Roger Federer's. Messi, 35, could play his last World Cup in Qatar, and Scaloni believes football generates a stronger bond than other sports. Argentina won 3-0 against Jamaica, with Messi scoring his 90th international goal and cementing his team's 35-game unbeaten streak. The team, led by Messi, is emerging as a World Cup favourite, facing Saudi Arabia, Mexico, and Poland in Group C.

site_title: Winning is antidote to sadness: Enrique
summary: Spain's late goal, scored by Alvaro Morata in the 88th minute, sent the team into the Nations League semi-finals, boosting their morale ahead of the World Cup. Coach Luis Enrique likened winning to a "wonderful sport" that cures sadness, after Spain finished top of League A Group 2. The 1-0 victory over Portugal marked Spain's first win in five matches, with the team making wholesale changes to their starting lineup. Spain will join Italy, Croatia, and the Netherlands in the Nations League semi-finals.

site_title: Golden Brown looks all set for first win
summary: Golden Brown, a three-year-old trained by Tim Fitzsimmons, is poised for his first win after a convincing 11/4-length victory at Kranji trials on Tuesday. The gelding, who finished second on his debut, demonstrated impressive speed and skill, tracking the lead and making a decisive move 200m out. His win follows two successful trials, and experts predict he will continue to improve. Meanwhile, Ima and Champagne Finale, both from separate trials, are worth watching in upcoming races, with Ima showing potential as a sprinter despite a short trip.

site_title: Formula One: Win in Singapore will push Verstappen closer to a masterpiece year
summary: Max Verstappen is seeking a win in the Singapore Grand Prix, which would push him closer to a "masterpiece year" in Formula One. Verstappen has a solid record in Singapore, with podium finishes in 2018 and 2019.

site_title: Women's side seek Thai payback
summary: The Singapore women's table tennis team will compete in Group 4 at the World Team Table Tennis Championships, seeking revenge against Thailand after losing to them in the SEA Games final. The team, led by coach Jing Junhong, will face South Korea, Luxembourg, and Iran, with top-ranked China also competing in the group. Without top player Feng Tianwei, the team will rely on debutantes and Commonwealth Games double gold medallist Zeng Jian. The men's team, ranked 28th, will face a tough Group 7 with Chinese Taipei, Croatia, and Belgium, with coach Gao Ning aiming to challenge the top teams.

site_title: Richarlison racially abused in Brazil's win over Tunisia
summary: Brazil's national team was involved in a racist incident during a friendly match against Tunisia in Paris, where Richarlison was targeted with a banana thrown by the crowd. The Brazilian Football Association (CBF) condemned the act, calling it "yet another episode of racism in football." The team's captain, Thiago Silva, expressed disappointment and frustration, stating that the mentality needs to change. The incident comes after recent instances of racism in football, including Vinicius Jr being racially abused by Atletico Madrid fans.

site_title: Teong Tzen Wei third swimmer to admit to drug use
summary: Teong Tzen Wei, a Commonwealth Games silver medallist, has admitted to consuming a controlled drug overseas, becoming the third swimmer to do so, after Joseph Schooling and Amanda Lim. Sport Singapore (SportSG) has suspended support for the three athletes for one month, withdrawn scholarship benefits for Teong, and issued letters of warning. The athletes have expressed remorse and pledged not to abuse controlled drugs again. The Central Narcotics Bureau (CNB) had investigated the trio but found negative results in their urine tests.

site_title: Lim's lightning out till end of the season
summary: Lim's Lightning, the 2021 Singapore Gold Cup champion, will not defend his title due to a leg injury sustained just before the Lion City Cup. The seven-year-old's trainer, Daniel Meagher, has decided to give him a break, considering the injury a "mild" setback. Lim's Lightning will not compete in the Queen Elizabeth II Cup or Singapore Gold Cup, but his stablemate, Lim's Kosciuszko, will be nominated for the Hong Kong Sprint, with a potential comeback planned for the Singapore Gold Cup day.

site_title: Golf: McIlroy calls for unity in men's golf after 'ugly year'
summary: Rory McIlroy calls for unity in men's golf, criticizing the LIV series' impact on the sport. The LIV series, backed by Saudi Arabia, has caused turmoil since its June debut, luring top players away from the US PGA Tour. McIlroy, the world No. 2, believes a way out of the impasse is possible, suggesting that the current heightened rhetoric needs to "cool off." He expressed confidence that professional golf can become "cohesive again," referencing past successes, including his win at the Tour Championship and FedEx Cup play-off series.

site_title: Nanofilm unit forms joint venture to develop coating solutions for EV batteries
summary: A joint venture, Sichuan Apex Technologies (ApexTech), has been formed between Nanofilm Vacuum Coating (Shanghai), Shenzhen Everwin Precision Technology, and Shanghai Hongshi Enterprise Management to develop coating solutions for electric vehicle batteries and energy storage applications in China. The venture aims to replace electroplating with proprietary coating solutions, targeting initial production in 2023 and industrial-scale mass production in 2024. The market for advanced batteries in China is projected to reach $156 billion by 2030, with electric vehicle penetration expected to reach 42% by then.

site_title: Mickelson 'focused on moving forward'
summary: Phil Mickelson, along with three other golfers, dropped out of a lawsuit against the PGA Tour over its decision to suspend players competing on the LIV Golf circuit. The lawsuit, filed in August, claimed the PGA Tour was an "entrenched monopolist" and sought damages. Mickelson stated he is "focused on moving forward" and "extremely happy" with LIV Golf, which has made changes to its purses and implemented an earnings assurance program. The trial is set to begin in January 2024.

site_title: Swimmer Teong Tzen Wei apologises to family, fraternity after latest drugs bombshell
summary: Singaporean swimmer Teong Tzen Wei, the country's top-performer in 2022, has confessed to drug consumption and apologized to his family, fraternity, and the Singapore Swimming Association. This marks the third swimmer implicated in the scandal, following other national athletes. Teong expressed regret for his actions and vowed to come back stronger, while the SSA has taken a zero-tolerance stance on controlled drugs but emphasized the importance of not ostracizing the swimmers. The incident has sparked shockwaves through the swimming community, but many are supporting Teong's apology and willingness to reflect and improve.

site_title: Keppel subsidiary bags $4 billion repeat contract from Petrobras to build vessel
summary: Keppel Shipyard, a subsidiary of Keppel Corporation, has secured a $4 billion contract from Petrobras to build a floating production, storage and offloading (FPSO) vessel, P-83. The contract is a repeat order for Petrobras, and the vessel will have a production capacity of 225,000 barrels of oil per day and a storage capacity of two million barrels of oil. The contract is scheduled for delivery in the first half of 2027 and will add approximately $3.8 billion to Keppel O&M's orderbook, bringing the unit's net orderbook to $11.8 billion.

site_title: Fitness the main goal, not records
summary: Los Angeles Lakers star LeBron James prioritized staying injury-free over breaking Kareem Abdul-Jabbar's all-time scoring record as he prepares for his 20th season in the NBA. James, 37, aims to lead the Lakers back to the playoffs after a dismal 2021-2022 season, with maintaining fitness being his main focus. He entered the 2022-2023 season 1,325 points behind Abdul-Jabbar's record, but doesn't obsess about surpassing it, instead focusing on being available on the floor. James expressed his commitment to the franchise and new coach Darvin Ham, who he praised for his transparency and leadership.

site_title: Man fined $3,000 for drunken threat to kill cop and trying to remove his mask
summary: A 34-year-old Singaporean man, Sim Hui Chun, was fined $3,000 for drunkenly threatening to kill a police officer and trying to remove his mask after a dispute at a restaurant in 2021. Sim, who had been intoxicated after a drinking session, insulted and threatened Sergeant Yan Lufeng, prompting other patrons to intervene. The incident was captured by Sgt Yan's body-worn camera. Sim pleaded guilty to charges under the Protection from Harassment Act and was sentenced to nine days in jail in default if the fine is not paid.

site_title: Ideal Angel has the wings to carry her to victory
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

South Africa's Friday form analysis is highlighted, focusing on key contenders for each of the eight races. Ideal Angel is considered a top contender in Race 4, while Admirals Chance and Goom Goom are expected to perform well in their respective races. AspiringtoReign and Homer Fidget are also favored to win in Races 3 and 3, respectively. Variety Breeze and Savannah Winter are expected to run well in Race 6, while Global Drummer and PleaseMeetYou are top contenders in Races 7 and 7, respectively. The analysis provides insights into the strengths and weaknesses of each horse.

site_title: A young race fan in 2008, Zhou Guanyu returns to S'pore GP in an Alfa Romeo
summary: Zhou Guanyu, a young Singaporean racing fan in 2008, returned to the Marina Bay Street Circuit for the Singapore Grand Prix in 2022, 14 years after his first visit. At 9 years old, he attended the inaugural Formula One Singapore Grand Prix and dreamed of becoming a professional motor sports driver. Now, 14 years later, Zhou Guanyu, a Formula One driver, signed autographs at Puma's flagship store in Singapore, marking his full-circle return to the event that sparked his passion for racing.

site_title: 3 children taken to hospital after fire in Sembawang flat
summary: A fire broke out at a Housing Board flat in Sembawang, Singapore, on Wednesday, affecting a bedroom and the living room. Three children were taken to hospital for smoke inhalation, while two others refused medical attention. The fire was extinguished in 15 minutes, and around 100 residents from the seventh to 15th floors were evacuated as a precaution. The cause of the fire is under investigation, but no one was seriously hurt. The family of the affected unit received temporary assistance from grassroots leaders and the HDB, with the children receiving observation for possible inhalation injuries.

site_title: Organisations' support essential in keeping Singapore safe and terrorism at bay: Sun Xueling
summary: Singapore's Minister of State for Home Affairs, Sun Xueling, emphasizes the importance of organizations' support in keeping the country safe from terrorism. A false alarm on a Downtown Line train in 2021, where a technician correctly identified a non-threatening object, is highlighted as an example of vigilant behavior. The government's Threat-Oriented Person Screening Integrated System (Topsis) program has been successful in enhancing security, and 137 organizations won awards for their efforts. Sun Xueling praises the role of the Safety and Security Watch Group in a whole-of-society effort to combat terrorism, with over 1,600 members and 196 clusters nationwide.

site_title: Golf: LIV series set to pay for US television coverage, says report
summary: LIV Golf, a Saudi-funded golf circuit, is reportedly close to sealing a deal with Fox Sports to pay for US television coverage. This would break the typical convention of sports business, where broadcasters pay sporting bodies for rights. The move is seen as a failure to attract serious commercial interest in LIV, despite its high purses and unique format. The circuit's funding by Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund has raised concerns about "sportswashing" the country's human rights record, with multiple broadcasters passing on the opportunity to broadcast LIV events.

site_title: Table tennis: Revenge on S'pore's mind in rematch with Thailand at World C'ships
summary: Singapore's women's table tennis team will compete in the World Team Table Tennis Championships after being drawn into Group 4 alongside South Korea, Thailand, Luxembourg, and Iran. Without top player Feng Tianwei, the team will be led by Commonwealth Games double gold medallist Zeng Jian and debutants Wong Xin Ru, Goi Rui Xuan, Zhang Wanling, and Zhou Jingyi. The team aims to avenge their SEA Games final loss to Thailand and mature as a team to compete against top favorites China.

site_title: Anti-scam app ScamShield now available for Android users
summary: Singapore's anti-scam app ScamShield is now available for Android users, following its release for iOS in November 2020. The app, developed by the National Crime Prevention Council (NCPC) and Open Government Products, blocks calls from blacklisted numbers and identifies scam SMSes. The Android version, launched on September 1, has similar features to the iOS version, but with limited functionality due to Android's limitations. Since its iOS release, the app has been downloaded by over 315,000 users and resulted in over 5.8 million reported scam messages, with over 29,000 blocked phone numbers.

site_title: Digital identities on blockchain could help with compliance in crypto, say players
summary: Digital identities stored on blockchain could simplify compliance in cryptocurrency, say market observers. Investors can create a digital identity on blockchain, streamlining online wallet applications. Companies can also verify identities more efficiently, reducing account creation time. This technology could aid in the crypto downturn, which is expected to last at least six more months, according to market predictions.

site_title: Malay Heritage Centre invites everyone to join in its two-week long closure party
summary: The Malay Heritage Centre (MHC) in Singapore is hosting a two-week long "ClosingFest" celebration ahead of its two-year closure, starting October 14. The festival will feature over 100 performers, including 30 from Malaysia and Indonesia, showcasing Malay song and dance. The event will include traditional music, modern dance styles, and tribute concerts to notable Malay figures such as Saloma. The festival aims to celebrate Malay traditions and heritage, with the MHC promising to maintain its legacy and presence in Kampong Glam through travelling exhibitions and decentralised events.

site_title: False bomb threat on SIA plane: Passengers said aircraft circled in the air for about 40 minutes
summary: A Singapore Airlines flight SQ33 experienced a 40-minute delay after a bomb hoax was reported by a passenger on board. The Airbus A350-941 aircraft, carrying 209 passengers and 17 crew, made three loops over the South China Sea before being escorted by two Republic of Singapore Air Force F-16 jets. Authorities later confirmed there was no bomb, and the passenger was arrested for suspected consumption of controlled drugs after allegedly claiming a bomb in a hand-carry bag and assaulting a cabin crew member. The plane landed safely at Changi Airport at 9:20am local time.

site_title: Serene Centre launched for sale via tender at $120 million
summary: Serene Centre, a prime mixed-use development in Singapore, is being launched for sale via tender at a reserve price of $120 million. The freehold four-storey building, built in the 1980s, comprises 30 retail/F&B units, 10 apartment units, and carpark facilities. Located near the Botanic Gardens MRT interchange station, the site is zoned for commercial/residential use and eligible for purchase by foreigners. The tender will close on November 14, with the site offering immediate rental income and potential for redevelopment into serviced apartments or a hotel.

site_title: Pacific Express has found a winnable race
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Thursday's form analysis at Turffontein's S.A. Races, with Pacific Express considered the winnable horse in the 1,700m R4, despite racing in new surroundings. African Torrent and King of Rome are expected to feature in the 1,700m R3. Karangetang is highly thought of in the 1,000m R5, while Southern Song, Ballroom Bliss, and Terra Time are the top contenders in the 2,000m R7. MIRREN is in form and could complete a hat-trick in the 2,000m R8. Other notable horses include STROKE OF MERCY, INNER SENSE, and TRUST THE FIRE, with various horses looking to improve their performances.

site_title: About 150 caterers have switched to low-sodium salt, ahead of push to cut S'poreans' sodium intake
summary: About 150 Singaporean caterers have switched to low-sodium salt and sauces ahead of a Health Promotion Board campaign to reduce sodium intake. The switch was made possible by low-sodium substitutes, such as potassium chloride, which taste the same as regular salt but contain less sodium. Studies show that excessive sodium intake leads to high blood pressure and cardiovascular disease. The Health Promotion Board aims to increase the use of low-sodium alternatives, currently making up only 2% of the market, to reduce sodium consumption and address hypertension cases in Singapore.

site_title: Sats calls for trading halt pending announcement
summary: Sats, a Singapore-based in-flight caterer and ground handler, requested a trading halt pending an announcement. The company is in discussions to acquire Worldwide Flight Services, an air cargo handler, with potential terms ranging from US$3 billion. No definitive terms or documentation have been agreed upon. The announcement may address the US$3 billion valuation reported by Bloomberg.

site_title: Wage growth inevitable, but cannot outstrip productivity: Lawrence Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong warned that Singapore risks losing global competitiveness if wages rise too quickly, potentially leading to a destabilizing wage-price spiral. Despite a tight labor market, wage increases must align with productivity growth to maintain competitiveness. The National Wages Council (NWC) plays a crucial role in ensuring fair and inclusive growth, and its recommendations have helped keep wages in tandem with productivity over the past 10 years. To sustain wage growth, the government has implemented support measures, including a $1.5 billion package, and the NWC will focus on skills upgrading and productivity improvements across all sectors.

site_title: Warmer days, chillier nights: Expect more serious extreme weather in Singapore
summary: Singapore is experiencing more extreme weather events due to climate change, with warmer days and chillier nights becoming more frequent. The country is investing in research and development to better forecast and prepare for long-term impacts. The National Environment Agency has released a climate study, the third national climate change study (V3), which will provide localised climate projections until 2100. This study will also account for land subsidence, which is sinking at an average rate of 1.4mm per year, amplifying sea-level rise impacts.

site_title: Stop Scams Podcast: Even elderly are targeted by cryptocurrency scammers
summary: A special-edition podcast series by The Straits Times discusses cryptocurrency scams in Singapore, where nearly $1 billion has been lost by victims since 2016. Experts, including Fiona Choong, vice-president of compliance at Coinhako, share common scams, precautions, and measures to take to avoid falling victim. The series highlights the evolving nature of cryptocurrency scams, including non-fungible tokens and Web 3.0 products, and provides tips for protecting oneself against scams, including fear, greed, and loneliness being exploited by scammers.

site_title: Singapore and Laos deepen cooperation in energy, environment and digital domains
summary: Singapore and Laos signed four memoranda of understanding (MOUs) on September 28, 2022, to deepen cooperation in energy, digital, sustainability, and environmental protection. The MOUs cover renewable energy deployment, regional power grids, and grid interconnections, as well as environmental management and protection. The agreements aim to enhance cross-border electricity trading, promote green growth, and create jobs and economic growth. The partnership also includes human resource development, business and tourism links, and people-to-people exchanges. The MOUs mark the 50th anniversary of diplomatic relations between the two countries in 2024.

site_title: Sats to buy world's largest air cargo handler WFS for $1.64 billion
summary: Sats has agreed to buy Worldwide Flight Services (WFS), the world's largest air cargo handler, for $1.64 billion. The deal will be financed with a $1.7 billion equity fund-raising and internal cash resources. The acquisition positions Sats as the largest cargo handler globally, covering 50% of global air cargo volume. The combined network will enable seamless support across regions, simplifying and strengthening operations for customers. The deal is expected to be immediately financially accretive, with a 78% increase in earnings per share and over 200% increase in revenue on a pro forma basis.

site_title: Table tennis: China to replicate Olympic 'bubble' for World Team Championships
summary: China will host the World Team Table Tennis Championships in a Covid-secure "closed loop" from September 30, replicating its Olympic bubble from the Beijing Winter Games. Nearly 1,300 people, including players, coaches, and officials, will be encased in the bubble. The event, which was postponed due to the Omicron variant and a lockdown in Chengdu, will feature defending champions China and top players from around the world, with no public spectators allowed. The tournament is considered a "complex and important" event in table tennis history.

site_title: Jail, caning for drug abuser who rammed into pedestrian during high-speed police chase
summary: A 36-year-old man, Vaswani Richard Prakash, was sentenced to over 9 years in jail for drug abuse, causing grievous hurt while driving in a dangerous manner, and driving while under disqualification. He led a high-speed police chase through Toa Payoh in February 2021, hitting a pedestrian who suffered multiple injuries, including a fractured ankle. Vaswani was also fined $3,000, ordered to receive 12 strokes of the cane, and disqualified from obtaining driving licences for 8 years.

site_title: Third swimmer Teong Tzen Wei implicated in Joseph Schooling, Amanda Lim drug use case
summary: Three Singaporean swimmers, Teong Tzen Wei, Joseph Schooling, and Amanda Lim, have admitted to consuming controlled drugs while representing Team Singapore. The athletes, including Olympic champion Schooling and Commonwealth Games silver medallist Teong, were issued letters of warning and had their support suspended for one month. Sport Singapore has taken disciplinary action, citing breaches of athlete agreements and the code of conduct expected of national athletes. The swimmers apologized for their actions and vowed to cooperate with the disciplinary process, which may result in further penalties, including the withdrawal of their scholarship benefits and prize money.

site_title: Students, housewives and retirees are less satisfied with taxis and private-hire cars: Study
summary: Satisfaction among students, housewives, retirees, and the unemployed with taxis and private-hire cars in Singapore decreased by 5.8% in 2022 compared to 2021, falling to 72.1 points. This decline was attributed to smaller vehicle numbers and higher fees. In contrast, public buses and MRT maintained their customer satisfaction scores at 2021 levels. The study, which surveyed 2,350 residents, found that non-working commuters were more dissatisfied with the ease of getting a ride and waiting for a ride, while employed respondents were more satisfied with the value for using taxis and private-hire cars.

site_title: Bank of England intervenes in UK bond market to stem historic rout
summary: The Bank of England intervened in the UK bond market to stem a historic rout, pledging to buy around £65 billion of long-dated gilts after the new government's tax cut plans triggered the biggest sell-off in decades. The central bank cited potential risks to financial stability and delayed its plan to sell down its £838 billion of government bond holdings. Long-dated bond yields surged after the announcement, and the pound whipsawed during the session, jumping as high as US$1.09165 and falling as low as US$1.05390. The BoE's intervention was seen as a temporary measure to restore orderly market conditions.

site_title: S'poreans consuming too much salt: HPB calls for switch to lower-sodium alternatives
summary: Singapore's Health Promotion Board (HPB) aims to reduce the country's sodium intake by 15% over the next five years, with plans to replace regular salt with lower-sodium alternatives. The average Singaporean consumes 3,600mg of sodium daily, exceeding the World Health Organisation's recommended daily limit of 2,000mg. To achieve the goal, HPB will work with retailers to make lower-sodium alternatives more affordable, increase the variety of lower-sodium sauces and seasonings, and launch a nationwide sodium-reduction campaign. The campaign will focus on replacing regular salt with lower-sodium alternatives, such as potassium chloride-based salt substitutes.

site_title: Football: Messi scores twice again to mark century of wins with Argentina
summary: Lionel Messi scored twice to help Argentina secure a 3-0 win over Jamaica in a World Cup warm-up friendly. The victory marked Messi's 100th international win and cemented Argentina's 35-game unbeaten streak, just two shy of Italy's world record. Messi's goals came in the 86th and 90th minutes, with his second also coming from a free-kick. The win was a dominant performance from Lionel Scaloni's Argentina, who are emerging as a top contender for the World Cup in Qatar.

site_title: Sustainable work conditions as important as sustainable growth: MAS chief
summary: MAS chief Ravi Menon emphasizes the importance of sustainable work conditions alongside sustainable growth, citing climate change as a key concern. He notes that a tight labor market and imbalance in labor markets contribute to inflation, and suggests promoting sustainable work environments where staff can be productive and have time for family and friends. Menon warns that central banks must slow down economic growth to achieve medium-term macroeconomic sustainability, as a rapidly growing economy can lead to inflation and curb job creation.

site_title: 70% of S'pore SMEs had better access to global opportunities after adopting quality standards: Survey
summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) have seen a 70% increase in access to global opportunities after adopting quality standards, according to a survey by Enterprise Singapore. The adoption of standards such as the Singapore Standard (SS) 668 has enabled companies like Jurong Cold Store to enter new markets and attract overseas clients. The survey also found that 90% of SMEs that adopted quality and standards infrastructure gained a competitive edge, differentiating their products and services from competitors.

site_title: NBA: LeBron prioritising fitness, not records, in 20th season
summary: Los Angeles Lakers star LeBron James prioritizes staying injury-free over breaking Kareem Abdul-Jabbar's all-time scoring record in his 20th season in the NBA. James played 56 games last season and aims to maintain fitness to lead the Lakers back to the playoffs. Despite being 1,325 points behind Abdul-Jabbar, James doesn't obsess over the record, focusing on being available on the floor. He is committed to the Lakers and new coach Darvin Ham, and the team begins their season on October 18 against the Golden State Warriors.

site_title: Tennis: Like Federer's farewell, Djokovic wants biggest rivals at his swansong
summary: Novak Djokovic has expressed his desire to have his biggest rivals, including Rafael Nadal and Andy Murray, by his side when he retires from tennis. This sentiment was echoed by Roger Federer's emotional farewell, where he was joined by his main rivals. Djokovic, one Grand Slam title behind Nadal's record of 22, feels no issues with his wrist after a recent injury and remains committed to competing against Nadal. Djokovic and Nadal have a long-standing rivalry with 59 matches between them, and Djokovic hopes to continue playing against his rival in the future.

site_title: Swimming: 5 things to know about South-east Asia's fastest man Teong Tzen Wei
summary: Singaporean swimmer Teong Tzen Wei has admitted to consuming cannabis while on Team Singapore duty, prompting a warning and suspension of support from Sport Singapore. The 24-year-old, an Olympic champion and SEA Games gold medalist, broke multiple records in the 50m freestyle and butterfly events before dropping out of university to focus on swimming. He is one of only three Singaporean swimmers to earn a Commonwealth Games medal, winning silver in 2022. Teong's admission comes after he was previously known as the "laziest man alive" by his coach, but he has since changed his mentality after winning his first SEA Games medal in 2017.

site_title: Man ordered to pay more than $51k for defaming car workshop on Facebook
summary: A Singaporean motorist, Jerry Tang Mun Wah, has been ordered to pay over $51,000 in damages and costs for defamation after publishing a post claiming a car workshop, On Site Car Accessories.SG, was seeking to charge him for checking a car battery under warranty. The High Court found the post defamatory and rejected his defenses, ordering him to pay $20,000 in damages, $24,000 in legal costs, and $7,000 in disbursements. Justice Kwek also found Tang was "reckless about the truthfulness" of the post and ordered him to remove the statements and publish an apology.

site_title: Shell heist: Man received up to $2.3m for role in crime, used monies to buy car, condo
summary: A process technician at Shell, Cai Zhi Zhong, 39, pleaded guilty to multiple offenses including criminal breach of trust and dealing with the benefits of criminal activities. He received between $1.3 million and $1.6 million (S$2.3 million) for his role in misappropriating over $93 million worth of gas oil from the company between 2014 and 2018. He used the monies to buy a condominium unit, an Audi A3 car, and luxury watches. Cai faces a possible 15-year jail term and is expected to be sentenced on October 20.

site_title: Dengue cases in S'pore declining after early spike ahead of peak season: NEA
summary: Dengue cases in Singapore have been declining after an early spike ahead of the peak season, with the weekly number of reported cases dropping from a high of 1,568 in May to under 600 in September. The number of active dengue clusters has also decreased by 62% from a high of 422 in June. As of September 24, 27,761 dengue cases have been reported, with 144 active clusters remaining. The National Environment Agency (NEA) attributes the decline to collective efforts and community engagement, but urges continued vigilance to sustain dengue prevention measures.

site_title: Australian retail sales keep defying gravity with August jump
summary: Australian retail sales rose 0.6% in August to a record A$34.9 billion, defying expectations and inflation. This marks a 19.2% increase from August last year, driven by food-related industries and household goods. The resilience in sales may reassure the Reserve Bank of Australia to continue raising interest rates without tipping the economy towards recession. Despite a strong July, spending on clothing fell back, while petrol prices have fallen, boosting consumer confidence.

site_title: Deflation looms in China amid property crisis and Covid-19 curbs: Survey
summary: China faces increasing risks of deflation amid an ongoing property crisis and continued Covid-19 restrictions. Home prices slumped for the 12th straight month in August, and companies reported the weakest growth in sale prices since 2020. The bulk of the deflationary pressure comes from the property industry, while retail and services saw price acceleration in the third quarter. China's consumer price index rose 2.5% in August, but core inflation was unchanged at 0.8%. The survey warns of "a new era of much slower growth" for China, pointing to the need for policies to stimulate consumption.

site_title: 13kg of drugs worth $790,000 seized in two operations; five arrested
summary: Singapore's Central Narcotics Bureau (CNB) seized 13kg of illicit drugs, including cannabis, Ice, heroin, ketamine, and LSD, in two operations, arresting five suspects. The estimated street value of the seized drugs is $790,000. The drugs are sufficient to feed around 1,800 users for a week. Five suspects were arrested, including three Singaporeans and two foreigners, in separate operations. Investigations are ongoing.

site_title: Apple ditches iPhone production increase after demand falters
summary: Apple is reducing its iPhone production plans due to lower-than-expected demand. The company had initially projected a 7% increase in orders, but suppliers are now being told to scale back production by up to 6 million units in the second half of the year. Apple will instead aim to produce 90 million handsets, in line with its original forecast. The decline in demand is attributed to an economic slump in China and global recession fears, with the smartphone market expected to shrink 6.5% this year.

site_title: Football: Spain pip Portugal to Nations League Finals, as Czechs go down
summary: Spain secured a 1-0 win over Portugal, with Alvaro Morata scoring in the 88th minute to secure a spot in the UEFA Nations League finals. The Czech Republic were relegated after losing to Switzerland, while Scotland clinched promotion to League A after a 0-0 draw against Ukraine. The Republic of Ireland finished third in Group B1 with a stoppage-time penalty from Robbie Brady, and Serbia took top spot in Group B with a 2-0 victory over Norway.

site_title: Wall Street ends mixed following days of losses
summary: Wall Street closed mixed on Tuesday, with the S&P 500 hitting a new low for the year. The US markets have experienced five consecutive days of declines amid soaring inflation and interest rate increases. Despite a jump in the consumer confidence index to 108.0 in September, orders for big-ticket goods slipped in August, and new home sales rose unexpectedly. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.4%, while the Nasdaq Composite Index climbed 0.3%. The mixed results reflect ongoing concerns about recession and the impact of monetary policy decisions worldwide.

site_title: Singapore 4th in global digital competitiveness, top in Asia
summary: Singapore has moved up one spot to fourth place globally in the IMD World Digital Competitiveness Ranking, behind Denmark, the US, and Sweden. The country retained its top spot in the "technology" factor and "regulatory framework" sub-factor, driven by improvements in tertiary education, R&D, and regulatory frameworks. Singapore ranked 10th in the "future readiness" factor, with perceptions on immigration policies improving this year. South Korea rose to eighth place, while Hong Kong dropped to ninth place, marking one of the largest drops in the ranking.

site_title: Workers' Party invites youth to submit and debate alternative policies in competition
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) Youth Wing is launching the WP Policy Challenge 2022, a competition inviting Singaporean youth aged 40 and below to submit alternative policy ideas. The contest, open until October 9, will see 10 finalists presenting their speeches to WP MPs, with a public audience vote determining the winner. The top three will receive cash prizes, while all participants are encouraged to apply for longer-term collaboration with the party. The competition aims to provide a platform for youth to engage with politics and policymaking, demystifying the workings of Parliament.

site_title: House sales collapse as UK lenders withdraw mortgage offers
summary: UK house sales are collapsing as lenders withdraw mortgage offers amid concerns of a potential interest rate hike by the Bank of England to support the pound. Nearly 300 mortgage deals have been pulled in 24 hours, with smaller lenders such as Kensington and Accord Mortgages withdrawing products. Major firms like HSBC and Nationwide Building Society have also increased rates or withdrawn offers. Analysts predict house prices could fall 10-15% due to the expected interest rate hike, leaving hopeful buyers in an uncertain position.

site_title: Crypto billionaire Bankman-Fried eyeing bid for bankrupt Celsius' assets
summary: Crypto billionaire Sam Bankman-Fried is considering bidding for the assets of bankrupt Celsius Network, following his $1.4 billion acquisition of Voyager Digital. Celsius, which filed for bankruptcy in July, owns Bitcoin mining operations and a crypto custody business. FTX is also raising a $1 billion funding round, and Bankman-Fried's crypto companies, FTX and Alameda Research, may consider bidding for Celsius' assets. Celsius' token surged 9.9% before retreating, and the company's CEO resigned on Tuesday as creditors consider restructuring or liquidation options.

site_title: World Bank cuts growth forecast for China to 2.8%
summary: The World Bank has cut its 2022 growth forecast for China to 2.8%, the lowest among international institutions, due to the country's slowdown. This will drag overall growth in the East Asia and Pacific region down to 3.2% from 7.2% in 2021. The slowdown is attributed to the global economic slowdown, interest rate hikes, and measures to control inflation, which will impact the region's exports and debt servicing burdens.

site_title: Inflation in UK shops hits record high as pound tumbles
summary: UK shop prices hit a record high of 5.7% in September, driven by soaring food bills that rose 10.6%, the highest increase since the index began in 2005. The British Retail Consortium attributed the surge to the weak pound, rising energy bills, and global commodity prices. Non-food items, such as gardening and home products, also saw higher prices, with inflation accelerating to 3.3%. The pound's record low is expected to further dampen consumer sentiment, with 76% of consumers anticipating being "moderately or severely affected" by the cost-of-living crisis.

site_title: Fighter jets escort SIA plane to Changi Airport, man arrested for allegedly making bomb threat
summary: A 37-year-old foreign national was arrested for allegedly making a bomb threat on board Singapore Airlines Flight SQ33 from San Francisco to Singapore, which landed at Changi Airport early Wednesday morning. The plane was escorted by two RSAF fighter jets before landing, and the threat was later verified to be false. The passenger allegedly claimed there was a bomb in a hand-carry bag and assaulted the crew. He was arrested for suspected consumption of controlled drugs and is facing charges under anti-terror rules.

site_title: Jail for man who scalded sleeping wife, hurt two strangers in separate incidents
summary: A 34-year-old man, Philip Ong Guo Xiong, was sentenced to 11 months and 2 weeks in jail for voluntarily causing hurt to his wife and two strangers. He scalded his wife on May 28 after a dispute over a term, and also punched her in the eye and caused other injuries. Additionally, he breached a personal protection order and was involved in two other incidents, including throwing a traffic cone at a woman and kicking another stranger. Ong apologized in court and plans to continue treatment for his behavior.

site_title: China lacks the right workers to boost transition to 'Hard Tech'
summary: China's transition to "Hard Tech" industries, such as electric vehicles and biopharmaceuticals, is hindered by a skills mismatch in the workforce. Despite a surge in job postings in these emerging industries, many workers laid off from the tech sector lack the necessary skills to pivot. Only 7% of those leaving the internet sector moved into AI, 5.2% into electric vehicles, and 2% into biomedicine. Experts predict it will take 3-5 years for the bottlenecks to ease, but the Chinese government's push for state-led economic transitions may eventually address the talent shortage.

site_title: Renminbi falls to weakest since 2008 on signs China is easing support for currency
summary: The renminbi has fallen to its weakest level since 2008, with a 0.2% drop to 7.1955 per dollar, amid speculation that China is easing support for the currency. This marks the currency's worst annual loss since 1994 and follows a 4% decline against the dollar this month. China's central bank set a daily reference rate that was 444 pips stronger than expected, indicating a possible shift in support for the currency. The move is seen as a sign that Beijing may be allowing market forces to drive the yuan, but could still deploy other tools to prop it up.

site_title: Poly student allegedly committed voyeurism in female toilet on campus
summary: A 26-year-old Singapore Polytechnic student, Muhammad Danial Nordin, has been accused of committing voyeurism and trespassing in a female toilet on campus. He allegedly placed a mobile phone under a cubicle door with its camera pointing at a woman on February 23. Danial, who was charged with one count each of criminal trespass and voyeurism, is expected to admit to his offences in October. He was immediately placed on a one-year suspension and provided counselling support to the victim. The school has vowed to take disciplinary action against any student found guilty of such behaviour.

site_title: Football: Banana thrown at Richarlison as Brazil thrash Tunisia
summary: Brazil thrashed Tunisia 5-1 in a friendly match in Paris, with Richarlison being targeted by a banana thrown from the crowd. The incident occurred after Richarlison scored the second Brazilian goal. The Brazilian football confederation condemned the act, stating it will not tolerate racism. Brazil captain Thiago Silva expressed disappointment, saying people's mentality needs to change. The win marks Brazil's 15th match unbeaten run, ahead of their World Cup Group G opener against Serbia on November 24.

site_title: US fines 16 Wall Street firms $2.6b for talking deals, trades on personal apps
summary: US regulators fined 16 Wall Street firms, including Barclays, Bank of America, and Citigroup, a combined $1.8 billion for discussing deals and trades on personal devices and apps. The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) and Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) investigated staff using personal apps like WhatsApp and Signal to evade oversight. The institutions failed to preserve business communications, violating federal rules, and cooperated with the investigation. They have begun implementing improvements to their compliance policies and procedures, marking a landmark case for the SEC and CFTC.

site_title: Must-reads
summary: Singapore's population grew 3.4% in June, reaching 5.64 million, reversing two years of decline. In international news, Italy's far-right party won a general election, prompting EU alarm. The World Bank reduced China's growth forecast to 2.8% in its October update. Meanwhile, a bilateral exercise between Singapore and Australia took place, and chess star Magnus Carlsen accused fellow Grandmaster Hans Niemann of cheating. Additionally, a gynaecologist emphasized the importance of normalizing conversations about menstrual pain to encourage women to seek help for endometriosis.

site_title: Dog deaths: Trainer loses appeal against disqualification order
summary: A dog trainer, Sabrina Sim Xin Huey, has lost her appeal against a disqualification order. She was fined $8,000 and sentenced to six months' disqualification after leaving two French bulldogs in the car boot, resulting in their deaths from heat stress. The High Court judge dismissed her appeal, stating that her negligence led to a grave outcome and that the disqualification order aims to protect other animals and their owners. The court rejected her argument that the disqualification was excessive, noting that her actions were not limited to intentional acts.

site_title: More help for SMEs going digital and workers aiming to hone skills
summary: Singapore has launched two new schemes, Rise for Business and Rise 2.0, to support small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and workers in digitalising their businesses and upskilling. The schemes, run by Boston Consulting Group and supported by SkillsFuture Singapore, offer up to 90% subsidy for courses and digital hackathons. The programmes aim to improve productivity, optimise operations, and lower costs by adopting technology such as artificial intelligence. The education minister emphasized the importance of business transformation and workforce transformation going hand-in-hand, with 70% of Rise 1.0 participants landing jobs.

site_title: Accused in Clementi knife attack pleads guilty
summary: Soo Cheow Wee, 50, pleaded guilty to two counts of criminal intimidation and one count each of voluntarily causing hurt to a public servant and using a knife to assault a man in a February knife attack in Clementi. He consumed diazepam and cough syrup without a prescription before the rampage. Soo was shot in the left arm by police and arrested after a stand-off. He had a previous incident in 2019 where he claimed people wanted to kill him and attacked an auxiliary police officer. Soo will be sentenced on October 26.

site_title: Nationwide study to get clearer gauge of youth mental health
summary: A nationwide study in Singapore aims to gauge the prevalence and personal and social factors associated with key mental health conditions among young people aged 15-35. The study, led by the Institute of Mental Health, will examine anxiety, depression, insomnia, and other conditions, as well as psychological distress and social support systems. Approximately 2,600 young people will be interviewed between October 2022 and June 2023, with results expected by end-2024, providing a clearer picture of when to intervene and design mental health promotion measures.

site_title: Coinhako, Luno expand services amid current crypto downturn
summary: Two Singapore-based cryptocurrency exchanges, Coinhako and Luno, are expanding their services amid the current crypto downturn. Coinhako has launched a new institutional market service, allowing high-net-worth individuals and family offices to access the crypto market through its exchange. This move aims to attract more sophisticated investors during a challenging market period. The expansion is a strategic move to maintain market presence and potentially capitalize on the downturn.

site_title: Singapore Army and RSAF link drones for the first time to give soldiers more intel
summary: Singapore's Army and Republic of Singapore Air Force (RSAF) have successfully linked drones for the first time, enabling soldiers on the ground to receive more intel on enemy locations. The Veloce 15 (V-15) and Heron 1 UAVs are being used in conjunction with a new Mobile Imagery Intelligence Dissemination System (Mids), which allows for the sharing of information captured by the Heron 1 to army operators. This collaboration aims to enhance battlefield awareness, improve chances of survival, and enable more effective "last-mile" reconnaissance and surveillance. The RSAF is currently trialing the Mids system at Exercise Wallaby.

site_title: Company briefs: Keppel New Energy Walmart Volkswagen
summary: Keppel New Energy partners with Mitsubishi Heavy Industries and DNV to explore an ammonia-fired gas turbine on Jurong Island in Singapore.
