summary: France striker Kylian Mbappe has said his refusal to participate in sponsor activities with the French Football Federation was a "collective move" to support his teammates. The move came after media reported that Mbappe did not want to endorse certain brands, including fast food chains and betting companies, under contract with the national team. Mbappe stated that his actions would not change his gameplay or personal life, but rather aim to help his teammates achieve their goals. The French Football Federation will review its agreement on players' image rights following the controversy.

site_title: Formula One: Latifi to leave Williams at end of 2022 season
summary: Canadian driver Nicholas Latifi will leave Williams at the end of the 2022 Formula One season. Latifi, 27, has failed to score a point in 16 races this year, with a career total of seven points from 55 starts. Williams has confirmed Thai driver Alexander Albon for 2023 and beyond. Latifi's departure opens up a seat in the driver market, with several contenders, including Nyck de Vries, Daniel Ricciardo, and Mick Schumacher, potentially taking his place.

site_title: International panel unveils plans to make Changi air hub greener
summary: Singapore's Changi Airport is set to become greener with an international panel's 15 recommendations to reduce its carbon footprint. The proposals include replacing existing vehicles with cleaner alternatives, such as electric or hydrogen-powered vehicles, and maximizing solar power use by installing panels on untapped open spaces. The airport will also explore alternative cooling methods, such as district cooling, and consider securing imported low-carbon electricity. The Government will study the proposals and incorporate them into a blueprint outlining Singapore's 2030 and 2050 goals for a greener air hub.

site_title: Football: Former Brazilian star Kaka to make marathon debut in Berlin
summary: Former Brazilian football star Kaka will make his marathon debut in Berlin on Sunday. Kaka's father had a 45-day hospital stay due to Covid-19, inspiring him to run the marathon. Kaka, a 2002 World Cup winner, aims to complete the 26.2 miles in under 4 hours. He will be joined by his father and brother, who will walk the course as part of a "family experience." Kaka values the opportunity to run alongside professionals and hopes to set a personal best time.

site_title: Borrowing costs surge, sterling tumbles after Britain's new economic plan
summary: The British pound plummeted 1.8% against the US dollar, reaching its lowest value since 1985, after Finance Minister Kwasi Kwarteng unveiled a £45 billion tax cut package aimed at boosting growth. Bond yields surged, with the 5-year gilt yield increasing by half a percentage point, the largest one-day rise since 1991. The FTSE 100 dropped 1.3%, while shares in homebuilders rose after changes to property stamp duty. The Bank of England's interest rate hike to 2.25% disappointed traders, and economists warn of a policy tug-of-war that could lead to a bumpy ride for the economy.

site_title: Police and SCDF say officers responded correctly in incident of woman who jumped from Eunos flat
summary: Singapore police and SCDF officers responded correctly in an incident where a woman jumped from a 5th-floor unit at 36 Eunos Crescent. Officers tried to dissuade her from jumping, but she was not receptive. The woman jumped off the ledge at 6:54pm, and SCDF personnel were already on the scene. The agencies stated that their officers acted appropriately and in accordance with procedures, and two members of the public attempted to engage the woman prior to police arrival. The woman was taken to hospital conscious.

site_title: Football: Liverpool's van Dijk admits to poor form at start of season
summary: Liverpool captain Virgil van Dijk admitted to a poor start to the season, attributing it to the intense spotlight of his leadership role. He acknowledged making mistakes and feeling the pressure, but expressed satisfaction with how he handled the dip in form. Van Dijk credited a convincing performance for the Netherlands against Poland as a turning point, and expressed hope that Liverpool can turn their season around, despite being nine points off the pace in the Premier League. He emphasized the importance of teamwork and focus in achieving success.

site_title: Tennis: Tsitsipas shrugs off fiery Laver Cup protest to give Europe 2-0 lead
summary: Stefanos Tsitsipas gave Team Europe a 2-0 lead in the Laver Cup with a 6-2, 6-1 win over Diego Schwartzman, shrugging off a dramatic on-court protest where a spectator set his arm ablaze. Tsitsipas overpowered Schwartzman with 17 winners, leading Team Europe to a strong start in the team competition. Earlier, Casper Ruud edged out Jack Sock 6-4, 5-7, 10-7, putting Team Europe 1-0 up. The Laver Cup continues with Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal set to team up in doubles for the final match.

site_title: UOB and DBS ceasing fixed-rate home loans for now, interest rates under review
summary: Singaporean banks UOB and DBS are temporarily halting fixed-rate home loans while reviewing interest rates following the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hike. The banks will not completely remove fixed-rate loans and will review packages to ensure competitiveness. DBS removed its fixed-rate packages from its website, while UOB's packages are set to expire on October 5. Local banks have cheaper costs of funds due to their larger deposits, allowing them to offer fixed-rate packages at a margin.

site_title: Duo climbed to top of shophouse to escape CNB raid in Geylang, leaving behind drugs and samurai swords
summary: Two people, a 36-year-old Singaporean man and a 38-year-old permanent resident, were arrested after attempting to escape a CNB raid on a shophouse in Geylang by climbing onto the rooftop. They left behind drugs, including 12g of crystal methamphetamine and samurai swords. The raid was part of a five-day islandwide operation that resulted in the arrest of 71 people and the seizure of $26,000 worth of drugs. Both suspects are believed to be drug users, and their actions pose a risk to themselves and others in the community.

site_title: Don't spy on employees to ensure they're working, Microsoft says
summary: Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella warns against "productivity paranoia" and workplace surveillance, citing a disconnect between managers and employees. A survey of 20,000 people in 11 countries found 85% of managers worry employees are not productive, while 87% of workers feel productive. Microsoft's Viva employee experience software aims to bridge this gap without resorting to surveillance. The company has adjusted its features to prevent employee monitoring, and job listings for in-person roles have increased, suggesting a shift towards pre-pandemic work arrangements.

site_title: Man who killed his mother, grandmother after taking drug to be confined indefinitely
summary: A 25-year-old man, Gabriel Lien Goh, was acquitted of two charges of culpable homicide due to his mental incapacity after fatally stabbing his 56-year-old mother and 90-year-old grandmother in 2019. The High Court found Goh to be under the influence of LSD when he committed the crimes, which occurred after he took two tabs of the hallucinogen. He will be confined indefinitely at the Complex Medical Centre in Changi Prison.

site_title: Healthier SG plan: Healthcare clusters working to support GPs in providing preventive care
summary: Singapore's healthcare clusters are working to support GPs in delivering preventive care under the Healthier SG plan, which aims to have people take charge of their health. The clusters are strengthening relationships with GPs, community partners, and government agencies to provide preventive care and care coordination. The Ministry of Health has submitted a White Paper on Healthier SG to Parliament, with plans to launch the program in the second half of 2023 for those aged 60 and above. The clusters will work to gather feedback from GPs on support needs and develop integrated community care teams to deliver care in the community.

site_title: Biomed start-up Hummingbird Bioscience opens new facility to boost its R&D work
summary: Singapore-based biomedical start-up Hummingbird Bioscience has launched a new 40,000 sq ft facility to expand its research and development capabilities. The facility features state-of-the-art laboratories and will hire more research scientists and clinical pharmacology managers. The company, specializing in cancer treatment, has secured US$125 million in funding and currently has two drugs undergoing clinical trials, including HMBD-001 and HMBD-002. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat praised the company's growth, noting that biomedical sciences are a key pillar in Singapore's manufacturing economy and employing over 25,000 workers.

site_title: Tennis: Djokovic has no regrets about missing Majors due to unvaccinated status
summary: Novak Djokovic, a 35-year-old Serbian tennis player, missed two Grand Slam tournaments due to his unvaccinated status against the novel coronavirus. Djokovic won the Australian Open and Wimbledon titles in 2021 but was deported from Australia before defending his Melbourne Park crown. He also was unable to travel to New York for the US Open. Djokovic expressed no regrets about his decision, stating he accepted the consequences and is waiting to see if his travel ban can be waived to allow him to participate in future Grand Slams.

site_title: China to offer Europe a lifeline this winter with more diesel exports
summary: China is set to release a significant amount of diesel onto the global market, with refiners receiving up to 15 million tonnes of oil product quotas for the rest of the year. This move is expected to provide relief to a tight market facing winter demand, particularly in Europe, where supplies have been severely disrupted by the Ukraine war. Diesel exports from China are expected to reach pre-pandemic levels, with most of the new export quotas allocated to diesel, used as heating fuel and power generation.

site_title: Basketball: Boston Celtics suspend coach Ime Udoka for entire NBA season
summary: The Boston Celtics have suspended head coach Ime Udoka for the entire 2022-23 NBA season due to "violations of team policies." The team did not specify the nature of the policy violations, which reportedly involved a consensual relationship between Udoka and a female member of the Celtics staff. Assistant coach Joe Mazzulla will take over as interim coach, and a decision on Udoka's future with the team will be made at a later date.

site_title: Malaysia says ringgit moves to stay market determined
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, announced that the ringgit's movements will be market-determined, ensuring orderly financial conditions amid global market turbulence. The decline in the ringgit, fueled by the US dollar's strength, has reached a 24-year low. The bank prioritizes sustaining economic growth and strengthening domestic fundamentals through structural reforms, rather than resorting to capital controls. This comes as other Asian currencies, including Indonesia and the Philippines, have also raised borrowing costs to combat pressures.

site_title: DBS opens up digital exchange for accredited wealth investors to trade crypto
summary: DBS Bank has launched a digital exchange for accredited wealth investors in Singapore to trade cryptocurrencies, including Bitcoin, Bitcoin Cash, Ether, and Ripple. The DBS Digital Exchange (DDEx) will allow 100,000 wealth clients to trade at their convenience, with a minimum investment of US$500 (S$710). This move enables DBS clients to trade cryptocurrencies on the platform, expanding their investment options.

site_title: Football: Hassan Sunny set to earn 100th cap in match against India
summary: Singapore national team goalkeeper Hassan Sunny is set to earn his 100th cap in an international friendly against India in Vietnam. The 38-year-old, who has had a long and unlikely football career, will become the second local custodian and 15th Lion to reach this milestone. Hassan's journey to 100 caps has been marked by setbacks, including being on the bench for four years and injured for two years, but he remains committed to playing until he's 40 and hopes to be a role model for future generations of local footballers.

site_title: Motor racing: Chadwick still aiming to reach F1 in next five years
summary: Jamie Chadwick, a 24-year-old British racing driver, remains determined to reach Formula One within the next five years. Despite Formula One's boss Stefano Domenicali doubting the possibility, Chadwick is exploring options in the US and Europe. She recently tested an Indy Lights car with Andretti Autosport, stating that a year in America could put her in a good position for another step up. Chadwick aims to achieve success in feeder series to reach Formula One, citing the support of those who believe in her abilities.

site_title: S'pore's biggest motor association embroiled in election irregularities
summary: A dispute has erupted at the Singapore Vehicle Traders Association (SVTA) over the eligibility of its former president, Mr Neo Tiam Ting, to run for presidency. Mr Neo was disqualified from the election, but is now challenging the decision. The election, scheduled for Friday, has been delayed and is now set to be heard in the High Court. The SVTA, with 370 members, has 370 members among parallel importers and used car traders, and the outcome of the election could have significant implications for the association. The case is ongoing.

site_title: Strong property market, Singapore's reopening fuel higher land betterment charge rates
summary: Singapore's land betterment charge (LBC) rates have been raised for residential, commercial, and industrial use for six months, with non-landed residential use seeing a 12.9% increase, the largest since 2018. The rate hikes are attributed to a strong property market and high bids for state-owned land and collective sale sites. The increases are also linked to rising rents in the commercial, residential, and industrial markets, as well as the reopening of borders and return-to-office arrangements. The rate changes are expected to boost investor confidence in the Singapore property market.

site_title: Ex-mosque executive chairman and Public Service Medal recipient charged with corruption
summary: Abdul Rahim Mawasi, a former executive chairman of two mosques in Singapore, has been charged with corruption. He allegedly accepted gratification in the form of shares from Mohd Mustaqim Kam in exchange for advising a company on mosque work prices. Mawasi, 55, and Mustaqim, 64, face up to five years in jail and fines of up to $100,000 if convicted. The charges stem from alleged corruption in 2019, with both men set to return to court on October 21.

site_title: Football: Tottenham manager Conte the 'perfect' man to help club shed 'Spursy' tag
summary: Former Tottenham Hotspur player Teddy Sheringham believes manager Antonio Conte is the "perfect" man to help the club shed its "Spursy" tag, characterized by consistently missing out on success despite being close. Conte, who has won five domestic league titles, was instrumental in Tottenham's Champions League qualification in 2021 and has strengthened the team through significant transfers. Sheringham, who scored 124 goals for Spurs, thinks Conte's defensive prowess and ability to instill resilience in the team are key to winning the club's first silverware in over a decade.

site_title: Electric car-sharing firm BlueSG to add up to 500 Opel Corsa-e cars to its fleet
summary: BlueSG, an electric car-sharing firm, plans to add up to 500 Opel Corsa-e cars to its fleet in a deal estimated to cost around $80 million. This expansion, set to occur over several months, marks the first time BlueSG is introducing a new model, replacing its existing French BlueCars. The Opel Corsa-e cars are more modern and better equipped than the previous model, following Goldbell's acquisition of BlueSG from Bollore Group in 2021.

site_title: Planning a trip to Japan, Taiwan: Do I need to wear a mask there? Is a Covid-19 test required?
summary: Japan will allow individual travelers to enter from October 11, reinstating visa waivers and lifting daily arrival caps. Taiwan will scrap its mandatory Covid-19 quarantine for arrivals from October 13, easing other restrictions. To enter Japan, all travelers must have a valid Covid-19 vaccination certificate and may need to take a pre-departure test if not fully vaccinated. Masks are recommended in indoor spaces and public transport in Japan, while Taiwan mandates mask-wearing in public and encourages social distancing.

site_title: Central bank rate hikes are far from over despite mounting risks of recession
summary: Central banks worldwide continued to raise interest rates to combat inflation, with some surprising moves, despite mounting risks of recession. The US Federal Reserve increased rates by 75 basis points, while Sweden's Riksbank surprised with a 100-basis point hike. Other countries, including Indonesia and Vietnam, also raised rates, while Turkey cut them. Economists warn that higher rates could slow economic growth, and some central banks may need to be more aggressive in their tightening of monetary policy.

site_title: Biography of Sim Kee Boon, The Businessman Bureaucrat, launched
summary: Singaporean businessman and bureaucrat Sim Kee Boon's biography, "Sim Kee Boon: The Businessman Bureaucrat," was launched on September 23, 2022. Written by Leanne Sim, the eldest of five granddaughters, and co-author Low Shi Ping, the book documents Sim Kee Boon's life, from his graduation in 1953 to his death in 2007. The biography highlights his contributions to Singapore's development, including his role in building Changi Airport and transforming Keppel Corp into a leading conglomerate. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong wrote the book's foreword, praising Sim Kee Boon's humility, sense of mission, and leadership qualities. The book is available for $30 at bookshops.

site_title: OxPay did not declare $77k paid for wrongful dismissal as amount 'not material'
summary: OxPay Financial, a Singapore-based payment services company, has clarified that it did not disclose a tribunal's order to pay former CEO Anthony Koh and CFO Madeline Sam $77,000 for wrongful dismissal as the claim amount was deemed "not material" to the group. The company stated that the amount, 1.5% of its free cash on hand, was not a cash flow problem and was fully settled. OxPay has concluded all legal proceedings, with shares closing 1.5% higher.

site_title: Singapore overtakes Hong Kong as Asia's top financial centre; 3rd in world
summary: Singapore has surpassed Hong Kong to become Asia's top financial centre, ranking third globally, according to a new report. The move comes as Hong Kong struggles to revive its role due to strict Covid-19 restrictions and an exodus of talent. In contrast, Singapore is expecting over 4 million visitors in 2022, with high-profile events like the Milken Institute Asia Summit and Singapore Grand Prix boosting its profile. The report also shows that Chinese cities Shanghai, Beijing, and Shenzhen maintained spots in the top 10, despite Covid-19 mitigation measures.

site_title: Nasdaq increases scrutiny of small-cap IPOs after wild swings
summary: Nasdaq is increasing scrutiny of small-cap IPOs after a series of wild price swings, particularly among companies from China and Hong Kong. The exchange is reviewing companies across industries and countries, with some putting their IPO plans on hold. Recent examples include AMTD Digital, which soared 32,000% before falling 97%, and Addentax Group, experiencing massive share moves on trading debuts. The move adds uncertainty to ongoing IPOs, including those from Hongli Group, Lichen China, and Alopexx, with the US Securities and Exchange Commission also investigating unusual price movements.

site_title: S'pore core inflation near 14-year high of 5.1% in August on more costly food, services
summary: Singapore's core inflation reached a near 14-year high of 5.1% in August, driven by higher food and services costs. The country's headline CPI also hit 7.5%, matching its 14-year high in June 2008. Economists expect core inflation to remain elevated for longer, with some predicting a breach of the full-year forecast. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and Ministry of Trade and Industry have signaled a cautious tone, warning of potential monetary policy tightening to combat inflation.

site_title: Global stocks slump to 2-year low as rate hikes reality bites; Singapore index down 1.1%
summary: Global stock markets plummeted to a 2-year low on Friday, with the MSCI world stocks index touching its lowest since mid-2020. The slump was triggered by the prospect of US interest rates rising further and faster than expected, rattling investors. The US dollar surged to a 20-year high, causing currency markets to become volatile, while bond markets also experienced significant losses. The US Federal Reserve's outlook for persistently high US rates until 2023 has led to a sell-off, with many indexes down 1-2% or more, including the Singapore Straits Times Index and Australia's S&P/ASX 200 Index.

site_title: Small states must participate actively to strengthen the multilateral system: PM Lee
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of small states participating actively in the multilateral system to strengthen their security and survival. In a video message to the Forum of Small States, Lee stressed that small states must work together on specific interests such as sustainable development, climate change, and cyber security. He highlighted the need for small states to have a voice in the UN and its key bodies, and called for increased cooperation to advance collective interests.

site_title: Lawyer Lim Tean handed 2 more charges, including criminal breach of trust
summary: Lawyer and opposition politician Lim Tean has been handed two more charges, including refusing to answer a public servant's questions and a second count of criminal breach of trust as an attorney. He was earlier charged with multiple offenses, including stalking and acting as an advocate without a valid practising certificate. Lim is accused of misappropriating $5,500 and $30,000 in cash settlement monies, and faces up to 20 years in jail and a fine if convicted.

site_title: Japan intervenes to prop up yen for first time in 24 years
summary: Japan intervened to prop up the value of the yen for the first time in 24 years, seeking to stop its slide against the US dollar amid concerns over the country's economy. The yen has lost over 20% of its value against the dollar in the past year, making imports more expensive and pressuring the economy. The government's dollar-selling operation followed the Fed's interest rate hike and a low interest rate policy by the Bank of Japan, which aims to keep inflation in check.

site_title: Being 14 years late and World Alzheimer's Day: What politicians are up to this week
summary: Singaporean politicians marked World Alzheimer's Day by raising awareness of dementia, with Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat highlighting the importance of maintaining an active lifestyle and supporting caregivers. Meanwhile, Speaker of Parliament Tan Chuan-Jin revealed he had forgotten to collect his Master's degree from 14 years ago, and opposition politician Goh Meng Seng shared his views on alternative Covid-19 treatments, sparking criticism. Other MPs returned from overseas trips and indulged in local food, with some even ordering meals on their flights home.

site_title: It's every nation for itself as US dollar batters global currencies
summary: The US dollar is experiencing a surge against global currencies, the most in decades, driven by hawkish Federal Reserve policy and investors seeking a safe-haven asset. Japan, Chile, and Singapore have taken steps to bolster their currencies, while China is defending its own currency. The lack of global coordination to address the issue is evident, with the US Treasury not participating in Japan's intervention. This "every man for himself" scenario is expected to continue, with policymakers facing challenges in mitigating the damage to their economies and managing inflation.

site_title: Golf: US team take 4-1 lead over Internationals at Presidents Cup
summary: The US team took a 4-1 lead over the International team at the Presidents Cup on the first day of competition at Quail Hollow Club in Charlotte. The Americans won five alternate-shot matches, with notable victories by pairings featuring Patrick Cantlay and Xander Schauffele, and Jordan Spieth and Justin Thomas. The Internationals made a late surge in the fourth match, led by a comeback by Kim Si-woo and Cam Davis, but ultimately fell short. The US team improved to 11-1-1 in Presidents Cup history.

site_title: GIC buys majority stake in Mediterranean luxury resorts group as travel recovers
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC has acquired a majority stake in Sani/Ikos Group (SIG), a Mediterranean luxury resorts operator, in a €2.3 billion deal. The investment values SIG at €2.3 billion, with the deal expected to be completed in the fourth quarter. As travel recovers in Europe, SIG has seen a 52% increase in bookings in 2022 compared to 2021. The partnership aims to deliver on SIG's €900 million investment plan, create jobs, and expand its presence in Greece, Spain, and Portugal.

site_title: The search is on for Singapore's Best Employers 2023
summary: The Singapore's Best Employers 2023 survey, conducted by Statista in partnership with The Straits Times, aims to assess the attractiveness of organizations in Singapore. The survey will evaluate firms with at least 200 employees based on employee recommendations and satisfaction. Tech giants Google and Apple topped the list in 2021 and 2022, respectively. The Economic Development Board placed second, while The Lego Group, Apple, and fintech firm Wise rounded out the top five. The survey results will be released in April 2023, providing insights into employee satisfaction and influencing hiring practices and working environments.

site_title: US stocks fall again on recession fears
summary: US stocks fell on Thursday, with the Nasdaq Composite Index leading the decline at 1.4% to 11,066.81, while the Dow Jones shed 0.4% to 30,076.68. The downturn was fueled by growing recession fears and central banks' interest rate hikes, including the Bank of England's second consecutive half-point rate increase. Global equities are expected to be severely impacted, with the European, Swiss, and Norwegian central banks also raising rates.

site_title: Football: Dutch outclass Poland to close on Nations League finals
summary: The Netherlands secured a 2-0 win over Poland in the Nations League, moving within one point of winning their group. Cody Gakpo scored in the 13th minute and Steven Bergwijn added a second in the 60th minute, with the Dutch dominating possession and pressuring Poland. A missed penalty by Arkadiusz Milik was the closest Poland came to scoring. The win puts the Netherlands in a strong position to qualify for the Nations League finals, with a draw against Belgium on Sunday securing their spot.

site_title: Football: Croatia beat Denmark 2-1 to top Nations League group
summary: Croatia topped UEFA Nations League A Group 1 with a 2-1 win over Denmark. Lovro Majer scored the winning goal two minutes after Christian Eriksen's equalizer. Croatia's Mateo Kovacic and Borna Sosa scored in the first half, with Eriksen's late equalizer. The victory gives Croatia 10 points from five games, one ahead of Denmark in the bid for a Nations League semi-final spot.

site_title: Pump prices fall for second time in a week
summary: Pump prices in Singapore have fallen for the second time in a week, with Esso, Caltex, and Shell lowering rates on Friday morning, followed by Sinopec in the afternoon. The price cuts, averaging 6 cents a litre, come after a slide in oil prices due to recessionary fears and rising inflation. Esso still has the lowest posted price for petrol, with its 92-octane grade at $2.71 a litre, while Sinopec's 95-octane is at $2.16 a litre with selected cards.

site_title: Golf: US poised for Presidents Cup foursomes blowout
summary: The US Team dominated the opening foursomes matches of the Presidents Cup, leading the Internationals in all five matches. The US squad, featuring top 15 players, quickly seized control, with Patrick Cantlay and Xander Schauffele leading the charge against Australian Adam Scott and Japan's Hideki Matsuyama. The Internationals struggled, trailing in all four matches, and the US now holds a significant lead in the competition. The US has a 11-1-1 record in the Presidents Cup and has never lost on home soil.

site_title: Football: Deadly de Bruyne leads Belgium to Nations League win over Wales
summary: Belgium midfielder Kevin De Bruyne scored and set up a goal as they beat Wales 2-1 in their Nations League A Group 4 match. De Bruyne's goal, assisted by Michy Batshuayi, gave Belgium a 2-0 lead at halftime, but Wales halved the deficit in the second period through Kieffer Moore's goal. Belgium holds second place with 10 points and must win by three goals to overtake the Netherlands, while Wales is at risk of relegation with one point. The win sets Belgium up for their next match against the Netherlands.

site_title: 3 new Young Scientist badges launched as Science Centre programme turns 40
summary: The Science Centre Singapore marks its 40th anniversary with the launch of three new Young Scientist badges: Marie Curie, Margaret Fountaine, and Young Fabricator. The badges, which span multiple subjects, aim to introduce science to students in a relatable way. Over 1 million badges have been awarded since 1982, with students from diverse backgrounds and special needs participating. Education Minister Chan Chun Sing emphasizes the importance of STEM education in tackling future challenges, and the new badges are expected to bring back nostalgic memories for many Singaporeans.

site_title: Tennis: Angry Medvedev mocks fans in Metz during loss to Wawrinka
summary: Daniil Medvedev mocked a section of French fans who booed him after throwing his racket during a loss to Stan Wawrinka in the Moselle Open in Metz. Medvedev, the top seed, lost his composure after going down 2-0 in the deciding set and sent his racket flying. He responded by giving the crowd two thumbs down and mocking their jeering, leading to a heated exchange. The incident occurred during a three-set defeat by Wawrinka, who advanced to the quarter-finals. Medvedev later downplayed the incident, praising Wawrinka as a great opponent and a nice person.

site_title: 50 volunteers offer translation help for special needs people
summary: A group of 50 volunteers has come together to provide translation assistance to individuals with special needs, particularly those on the autism spectrum, who struggle to access English-language resources. Cai Suling, a full-time caregiver for her two autistic daughters, often relies on Google Translate, highlighting the need for this support. The volunteers aim to bridge the language gap and provide equal access to resources, improving the lives of individuals with autism.

site_title: Foodcourt ordered closed for 2 weeks over infestation
summary: Northpoint City's Malaysia Chiak foodcourt in Singapore was ordered closed for two weeks due to infestation. The Singapore Food Agency (SFA) imposed a $800 fine and six demerit points on the foodcourt for failing to keep the premises free from infestation over the past 12 months. The foodcourt will use the temporary closure to refurbish and improve its layout for cleaning and upkeeping. Malaysia Chiak will also retrain its food handlers on food safety and hygiene, and increase pest control inspections. The closure is part of the foodcourt's efforts to prevent future infestations.

site_title: 10-minute test to find out if one has immunity
summary: Scientists in Singapore have developed a 10-minute rapid blood test that can determine if a person has immunity against Covid-19 and its variants. The test, which uses a paper-based assay, detects neutralizing antibodies and has up to 93% accuracy. It can be easily adapted for new variants and does not require specialized equipment, making it accessible for widespread use. The test's development may pave the way for personalized vaccination strategies, where individuals receive boosters only when necessary, depending on their antibody levels and immune response. Further development is underway for regulatory approvals.

site_title: Football: Mbappe, Giroud shine as France beat Austria in Nations League
summary: France secured a 2-0 home victory over Austria in the Nations League, thanks to goals from Kylian Mbappe and Olivier Giroud. Mbappe broke the deadlock with a cool finish after beating five defenders, and Giroud sealed the win with a header in the 65th minute. The victory lifted France to third in Group 1 with five points from four games. However, the win came at a cost, with defender Jules Kounde and goalkeeper Mike Maignan sustaining injuries that may keep them out of action for several games.

site_title: TikTok to bar fund raising by politicians, political parties
summary: TikTok is banning politicians and political parties from raising funds and making money on the platform, starting over the next few weeks globally. The changes aim to prevent misinformation and polarization by restricting advertising features and monetization options. This move is expected to strengthen TikTok's enforcement of its existing ban on political advertising and misinformation. The platform aims to promote a positive environment that brings people together rather than divides them. The restrictions may impact opposition parties, particularly those with smaller audiences, and could change the way they rally and engage supporters.

site_title: Life sentence for man who stabbed roommate to death
summary: A 51-year-old Myanmar national, Naing Lin, was sentenced to life imprisonment for fatally stabbing his roommate, Myo Kyaw Thu, 49, in their Bedok Reservoir flat in April 2021. Naing Lin, who was intoxicated at the time, attacked the victim after an argument over spending habits. He left the victim bleeding on the floor and contacted mutual friends to call the police, eventually surrendering himself the next morning. The court ruled that the life sentence was justified, citing Naing Lin's remorse and lack of viciousness in the crime.

site_title: The future of work: 3 big ideas from tech giant's conference
summary: Tech giant Salesforce's conference emphasized the importance of sustainability, empathy, and digital headquarters in the future of work. The pandemic disruptions highlighted the need for virtual centers that support spontaneous interactions and information sharing, while maintaining in-person collaboration. These digital headquarters would enable staff to work together more effectively online, and companies are encouraged to develop such systems to stay competitive.

site_title: NTU team finds hair-raising way to help greens grow
summary: A team from Nanyang Technological University (NTU) has discovered a sustainable way to grow greens using keratin extracted from human hair, typically discarded from local salons. The keratin is mixed with cellulose fibers to create substrates that support plant growth. The NTU team found that crop yields from these substrates are comparable to commercially available ones. The biodegradable materials can also become a source of nutrients for plants when they degrade, and the team is currently conducting large-scale field tests to optimize the composition of the substrates.

site_title: TikTok series Finding Juliana looks at drug abuse, addiction up close
summary: A new TikTok series, Finding Juliana, explores the complexities of drug abuse and addiction through a personal lens, focusing on young people navigating identities and relationships. The series, part of the National Council Against Drug Abuse's two-year campaign What's Your Fix?, aims to spark conversations on the realities of drug use and promote advocacy for a drug-free society. The campaign's goal is to encourage clear choices against apathy and permissiveness, and to support those vulnerable to addiction. The series and campaign materials will be released starting October 2, with a live event on October 15.

site_title: Excess deaths during pandemic and how S'pore fared, compared with other countries
summary: Singapore reported 2,490 excess deaths due to Covid-19 between January 2020 and June 2022, with 1,403 official Covid-19 deaths. The country's World Health Organisation-estimated excess mortality rate is 26 per 100,000 for 2021, among the lowest globally. Vaccination rates influenced the figure, with unvaccinated individuals disproportionately affected. Singapore's excess death rate per million residents is comparable to countries like Malaysia and Japan, but higher than in the US or Britain. China's excess death rate is lower despite a small number of confirmed Covid-19 deaths, potentially due to underreporting or side effects of its zero-Covid-19 strategy.

site_title: Nudging nations on goals at COP27 won't be easy: Grace Fu
summary: Singapore's Minister for Sustainability and the Environment, Grace Fu, expressed concerns that the country's influence on nations to commit to greening goals at COP27 may be hindered by the US-China conflict and the energy crisis in Europe. Despite this, Singapore remains committed to its net-zero carbon emissions goal by 2050 and will continue to deliver on its promises. The minister emphasized the importance of finding ways to minimize environmental impacts, such as changing personal habits and implementing Extended Producer Responsibility schemes, to lower and minimize environmental costs.

site_title: Tennis: US great Sampras pays tribute to departing Federer
summary: Pete Sampras, a 14-time Grand Slam champion, paid tribute to Roger Federer in a social media video ahead of Federer's farewell appearance at the Laver Cup in London. Sampras recalled their 2001 Wimbledon match, where Federer defeated him at 19. Sampras praised Federer's dedication, fluid game, and dominance in the sport, calling him "truly a special player." Federer is retiring after a career spanning 20 Grand Slam titles and years as world number one. Sampras expressed that Federer will be missed in the game.

site_title: Swiss National Bank ends Europe's sub-zero rate era with 75 basis point hike
summary: The Swiss National Bank (SNB) raised interest rates by 75 basis points, marking the end of Europe's sub-zero rate era. This move takes Switzerland's policy rate to 0.5%, above zero for the first time in almost eight years. The decision follows recent rate hikes in the euro region and aims to contain inflation, currently above 3%. The SNB has now matched the European Central Bank's 1.25 percentage point of tightening since July, and policymakers are willing to intervene in currency markets if needed.

site_title: 4 insecurities the world will have to face in coming years
summary: Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam warned of four global insecurities facing the world in coming years, including an end to the era of low inflation and interest rates, deteriorating global commons due to climate change, loss of biodiversity, and water crisis, a potential rollback in developing countries, and geopolitical insecurity fueled by the Ukraine war and the China-US relationship. These insecurities are interconnected and pose significant challenges, requiring a new strategic relationship between the US and China to address common interests and prevent conflict.

site_title: Company Briefs: Onewo
summary: Onewo, a property management unit of China Vanke, plans to price its Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO) near the mid-point of its marketed range, potentially at HK$49.35 per share. GIC has acquired a majority stake in Mediterranean luxury beach resort Sani/Ikos Group for €2.3 billion (S$3.2 billion). Cromwell European Reit's manager clarified that proposed Dutch tax changes will not affect the Reit's distributable income, as it is not subject to the new tax regime.

site_title: Scammers scared boy into faking hostage scene to prey on mum
summary: A 16-year-old Chinese national, studying in Singapore, was tricked into staging a hostage situation by scammers posing as Chinese authorities. The scammers demanded $200,000 in ransom to free him, claiming his mother was involved in money laundering and he was accused of smuggling contraband cigarettes. Fortunately, his mother refused to pay the ransom, and he was safely located by the police. The incident highlights the risks of China official impersonation scams, with 476 reported cases in Singapore between January and August 2022, resulting in losses of at least $57.3 million.

site_title: All eyes on MAS after hawkish Fed rate hike deals blow to Sing$
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), is under scrutiny after the Federal Reserve's hawkish interest rate hike, which has raised fears of a significant economic growth decline. Analysts predict MAS will continue to tighten monetary policy, but some doubt the aggressiveness of the move. The Singdollar has retreated to a 29-month low against the US dollar, while Singapore stocks ended flat. Analysts weigh the impact on Singapore's export-dependent economy, with some predicting a hard landing in the US and stagflationary European Union may affect loans growth over the longer term.

site_title: What US rate hike means for S'pore investors, businesses
summary: The US Federal Reserve raised its benchmark interest rate to 3% to 3.25% in a 14-year high, aiming to combat surging inflation. This move led to a plunge in stock and bond prices and a rally in the US dollar. The 75 basis point increase is the largest in 14 years, marking a significant shift in monetary policy to curb inflation.

site_title: Daiwa House Logistics Trust plans $47m purchase in Japan
summary: Daiwa House Logistics Trust (DHLT) plans to acquire a portfolio of logistics facilities and freehold land in Japan for $47 million. The portfolio, valued at 4.68 billion yen, represents an 11.8% discount to its average appraised value. The acquisition aims to broaden DHLT's earnings base and diversify its portfolio across Japan, mitigating concentration risk and potential impacts from earthquakes. The trust expects the acquisition to lift its distribution per unit by 1.3% on a pro-forma basis.

site_title: HK very likely to end the year in recession, warns finance chief
summary: Hong Kong is likely to end the year in recession due to spiraling interest rates and strict Covid-19 controls, warned Finance Chief Paul Chan. The city's economy is struggling, with two consecutive quarters of negative growth, and interest rates are being raised at a historic pace. The government is considering easing travel curbs, but business leaders warn that pandemic controls and Beijing's crackdown on dissent are deterring talent and isolating the city.

site_title: Smaller nations stress support for multilateralism, sovereign equality
summary: A group of 30 small and medium-sized countries, including Singapore, Brunei, and Vietnam, expressed strong support for a multilateral system, with the United Nations at its core. They emphasized sovereign equality and the peaceful settlement of disputes, as well as the need for resilient supply chains and fair trading systems. The Global Governance Group (3G) called for expanded vaccine production globally, underpinned by the World Trade Organisation (WTO), to ensure unimpeded cross-border flows of essential goods. The meeting also discussed the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on global supply chains and rising protectionism.

site_title: Safety timeout extended for firms in high-risk sectors
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) has extended the safety timeout deadline for companies in high-risk sectors from Sept 15 to Sept 30. This affects industries such as construction, manufacturing, and transport, which are required to review their safety procedures as part of enhanced workplace safety requirements. The extension comes amid a rise in work-related deaths and injuries, with 37 fatalities so far in 2022. Companies must complete safety timeout activities by Sept 30 to avoid debarment action, and MOM will conduct compliance checks to ensure safety measures are in place.

site_title: Must-reads
summary: Asian stocks plummeted as the Federal Reserve raised interest rates by 0.75 percentage points, signaling further monetary tightening to combat inflation. The US dollar surged to a 20-year high, prompting investors to pull out of Asian equities and shift to US dollar-denominated assets. Meanwhile, Malaysian fugitive "Fat Leonard" was arrested in Venezuela after fleeing house arrest in California, and Parti Pribumi Bersatu Malaysia faces challenges ahead of upcoming elections. Taiwan is establishing a backup satellite Internet network to ensure command systems remain operational in the event of an attack.

site_title: Singtel's Optus warns cyber attack may have exposed customer data
summary: Singtel's Australian subsidiary Optus is investigating a possible cyber attack that may have exposed customer data, including names, dates of birth, phone numbers, and email addresses, for millions of customers. The attack was shut down immediately, but Optus is working with authorities to mitigate risks and notify affected customers. Payment details and account passwords remain secure. The company is offering expert monitoring services to those with heightened risk and urging customers to be vigilant for suspicious activity. Optus CEO Kelly Bayer Rosmarin described the incident as "devastating" and apologized to customers.

site_title: New quick test for immunity against virus
summary: Scientists at the Singapore-MIT Alliance for Research and Technology and Nanyang Technological University have developed a new rapid blood test that can determine immunity against Covid-19 and its variants in 10 minutes. The test, which requires only a finger prick, boasts up to 93% accuracy and can be easily adapted for new variants. This is a significant improvement over current laboratory testing, which can take 24-72 hours, offering a faster and more convenient way to assess immunity.

site_title: Asia markets slump as Fed rate hike fuels fears of global slowdown
summary: Asian stock markets slumped as the US Federal Reserve raised its key interest rate by 75 basis points for the third consecutive time, signaling more aggressive hikes to combat inflation. The US dollar reached a 20-year high, fueling concerns of a global slowdown and prompting investors to pull out of emerging markets. Despite this, Singapore's local stock market has seen institutional fund inflows, driven by its strong currency and proactive inflation management, which is expected to benefit from trade and capital flows resulting from the relocation of global supply chains to South-east Asia.

site_title: Room to be optimistic amid global fragility, says Tharman
summary: Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam of Singapore expressed optimism despite global fragility, urging the country to boost its social compact and develop deeper intrinsic capabilities. The world faces complex insecurities including geopolitics, climate change, and social polarisation, leading to a loss of optimism globally. However, Singapore has a strong foundation, including a multicultural society and a well-known system of governance, which can be strengthened to address these challenges. Tharman proposed developing capabilities such as depth of expertise, cultural breadth, and civic discourse to ensure Singapore's resilience and value as a global partner.

site_title: Bank of Japan keeps ultra low rates, remains global outlier
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its ultra-low interest rates, defying global trends and further weakening the yen, which touched a 24-year low. The decision came after the US Federal Reserve raised rates by 75 basis points. BOJ governor Haruhiko Kuroda signaled that policy normalization is not imminent, and the bank will continue to buy bonds to defend its yield cap of 0.25%. The yen's slide and BOJ's stance are expected to remain under pressure, with little change in policy expected before Kuroda's term ends in April.

site_title: Credit Suisse weighs splitting investment bank into three
summary: Credit Suisse Group is considering splitting its investment bank into three parts, including a "bad bank" to hold high-risk assets and a spun-off advisory business. The bank aims to prevent a damaging capital raise by selling profitable units, such as its securitised products business. The proposal, announced by CEO Ulrich Korner, follows a comprehensive strategy review led by Chairman Axel Lehmann, who has been tasked with addressing the bank's recent scandals and financial struggles, including a record trading loss and lawsuits. A decision is expected in the third-quarter earnings announcement.

site_title: Goldman slashes China's 2023 growth forecast
summary: Goldman Sachs has slashed China's 2023 economic growth forecast to 4.5% from a previous projection of 5.3%, citing the country's likely adherence to stringent zero-Covid-19 policies. The forecast also predicts a 3% expansion in 2022. Goldman expects China to reopen in the second quarter of 2023, after ensuring higher vaccination rates, manufacturing of effective Covid-19 pills, and other conditions are met. The economists warn that a full reopening will likely be followed by a surge in infections, reduced mobility, and supply chain disruptions, curbing economic activity.

site_title: Crypto shake-out engulfs top ranks as CEOs start stepping down
summary: Crypto industry leaders are stepping down as the sector faces a slump, wiping off $2 trillion from market value. Notable CEOs, including Jesse Powell of Kraken, Michael Moro of Genesis, and Michael Saylor of MicroStrategy, are relinquishing top positions. Regulators are re-evaluating the industry, leading to a shift towards more experienced executives with regulatory knowledge. Industry experts expect further changes as companies restructure and adapt to the changing landscape.

site_title: Sports World : United report loss of $185m in 2021-22
summary: Manchester United reported a net loss of £115.5 million (S$184.8 million) for the 2021-22 season, despite revenues rising to £583 million. The club also saw a 22% increase in debt and a 19% rise in wages. Football director John Murtough stated that a similar transfer window activity is not anticipated for the future.

site_title: Partnering Rafa in London is 'fitting' finale for Federer
summary: Roger Federer is set to retire from tennis with a fitting finale in London, where he won eight Wimbledon singles titles. He had initially considered announcing his retirement before the US Open but waited until Serena Williams' announcement allowed him to do so. Federer will play one final tournament, the Laver Cup, alongside Rafael Nadal in a doubles match on Friday, saying he will go out "happy" but not satisfied, on his own terms. The 41-year-old has been rehabilitating from a knee injury and acknowledged nervousness about his performance.

site_title: Digital Core Reit eyes data centres in US, Germany to grow presence
summary: Digital Core Reit, a Singapore-listed data centre real estate investment trust, plans to acquire two data centres in Frankfurt and Dallas, aiming to establish a presence in top-tier global markets. The proposed deal could be distribution per unit (DPU) accretive by up to 3.1% and is valued at approximately US$700 million. The acquisition could be funded through equity or debt, with a preferred scenario being a US$700 million deal. The deal is expected to be completed by the end of November or early December, pending approval from unit holders.

site_title: U-19s have 'room for improvement'
summary: The national Under-19 football team returned from the Under-20 Asian Cup qualification campaign in Tajikistan, finishing third in Group I behind hosts and Lebanon, but ahead of Cambodia. Despite showing signs of improvement, the team reverted to familiar weaknesses, including lapses in concentration and fatigue. Head coach Fadzuhasny Juraimi expressed satisfaction with the players' fighting spirit but noted a need for improvement in adapting to competitive club-level matches and maintaining physical condition. The team's best performers aim to bounce back from the defeat, with goalkeeper Aizil Yazid citing the experience as a valuable lesson in mental and physical toughness.

site_title: Germany wary of Hungary's 'enormous power'
summary: Germany faces Hungary in the Nations League on Friday, aware of their opponents' quality after a 1-1 draw in Budapest. Germany will be missing four first-team players, including captain Manuel Neuer and forward Marco Reus. Coach Hansi Flick is hopeful striker Timo Werner can capitalize on his opportunities, while new defender Armel Bella-Kotchap's inclusion has raised eyebrows. Germany is sitting second in their group and must prepare for an aggressive and organized Hungary team.

site_title: Indonesia raises key rate more than forecast to stabilise rupiah
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, raised the seven-day reverse repurchase rate by 50 basis points to 4.25% to combat inflation and stabilize the rupiah. This move exceeds expectations, as economists predicted a 25 basis point increase. The rate hike aims to shield the rupiah from pressure on emerging market currencies, following a 75 basis point hike by the US Federal Reserve. The central bank aims to control inflation, which is expected to reach 7% in coming months, and stabilize the rupiah in line with fundamentals.

site_title: STI ends slightly up amid regional gloom sparked by Fed rate hike
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.04% to 3,263.07, defying regional gloom sparked by the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hike. Regional bourses fell, with Shenzhen down 0.8%, Shanghai Composite 0.3%, and Hong Kong's Hang Seng 1.6%. Asset manager Aberdeen expects a Fed-induced recession, with the probability of a hard landing increasing. The top decliner, Sats, fell 5.1%, while Yangzijiang Shipbuilding rose 6.8%.

site_title: Diallo on bail but denies assault
summary: Aminata Diallo, a former Paris Saint-Germain women's player, was released on probation after being arrested on suspicion of orchestrating a brutal attack on teammate Kheira Hamraoui. The attack, which occurred in November, left Hamraoui with injuries requiring hospitalization and stitches. Diallo has denied any involvement, but investigators suspect the motive was professional rivalry as she competed with Hamraoui for a midfield starting spot. Four other men allegedly involved in the attack have been charged with aggravated violence.

site_title: BOE delivers half-point increase amid growing pressure for larger hikes
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) raised interest rates by half a point to 2.25% in its second consecutive hike, aiming to curb inflation. The decision was backed by five MPC members, including Governor Andrew Bailey, amid growing pressure from global peers. The BOE lowered its inflation forecast from over 13% to less than 11% and suggested a recession may be averted by new Prime Minister Liz Truss's energy relief plan. The committee vowed to respond to persistent price pressures and may consider a larger hike later this year.

site_title: Sarver caves in to public outcry
summary: Robert Sarver, owner of the Phoenix Suns and Phoenix Mercury, has announced plans to sell the two basketball teams amid public pressure following a National Basketball Association (NBA) investigation into his workplace misconduct. The investigation found Sarver engaged in over a decade of mistreatment, including using racial slurs and making sexual remarks. He had previously been fined $10 million and suspended for a year, but said the punishment was not enough in the "unforgiving climate." The NBA and the ownership group of the teams have welcomed the decision, citing the need for a change.

site_title: Big plans for California Spangle
summary: Trainer Tony Cruz is optimistic about California Spangle's upcoming campaign, following a successful double in Wednesday's Happy Valley races. California Spangle, a BMW Hong Kong Derby runner-up and Hong Kong Classic Cup winner, is set to compete in the Group 3 Celebration Cup Handicap on September 25. Cruz is pleased with his horse's condition and expects him to dictate the pace, with a potential path to the Group 1 Longines Hong Kong Sprint or Mile on December 11.

site_title: Next 48 hours
summary: Key sports events for the next 48 hours include Italy vs England in the Uefa Nations League and the French Open's Day 2 in golf. The ATP Tour features the Metz Open's Q-finals, San Diego Open's Q-finals, and Laver Cup's Day 1 and Day 2 in tennis. The LPGA Tour includes the Arkansas Championship's Day 1 and Day 2. Rugby Championship matches will be held between New Zealand and Australia, and South Africa and Argentina. S-finals will take place in the Pan Pacific Open and Korea Open.

site_title: Alvarez's One stint fizzles out
summary: Former UFC champion Eddie Alvarez's stint in One Championship ended when he announced he was no longer contracted to the Singapore-based organization. Alvarez, 38, had signed in 2018 but failed to deliver, with only one win and two losses in four years. He parted ways amicably and expressed gratitude to One Championship's CEO Chatri Sityodtong. Alvarez is now a free agent, considering a potential comeback to the US-based Bellator or other promotions, before retiring for good.

site_title: Hosts to be lenient over minor offences
summary: Qatar's World Cup authorities plan to be lenient on foreign fans committing minor offenses such as public drunkenness, with authorities unlikely to arrest those breaking laws that are mild elsewhere. The approach reflects Qatar's delicate balance between respecting Islamic traditions and accommodating visiting fans. Public drunkenness can still incur a prison sentence, but minor infractions like wearing revealing clothes or public displays of affection may not result in arrest. The approach is intended to increase leniency, but may upset conservatives within the country.

site_title: Why young families and savvy investors are keen on this District 10 property
summary: A freehold condominium in District 10, Perfect Ten, has attracted young families and savvy investors due to its prime location, proximity to reputable schools, and luxurious fittings. The development, comprising twin towers of 24 storeys each, offers units ranging from 753 sq ft to 1,281 sq ft, with high ceilings and unobstructed views of the Bukit Timah Nature Reserve. Prices for units range from $2.08 million to $4.4 million. With its unique design, premium finishes, and convenient location, Perfect Ten is considered a sound investment opportunity.

site_title: S'pore's rising costs of running business outpace Hong Kong's
summary: Singapore's rising business costs are outpacing those in Hong Kong, despite the latter's economic struggles. Inflation soared to 14-year highs, with expenses including talent hiring, office space, and utilities increasing faster in Singapore. New business formation in Singapore reached a 17-month high in August, while Hong Kong's new local businesses remained steady but declined from a peak in 2017. Singapore's office rents are still lower than Hong Kong's, but the gap is narrowing. Labor tightness and pay increases also favor Singapore, with a historic high in job vacancies to unemployed and civil servant pay rises expected to outpace Hong Kong's.

site_title: Criticism of Southgate is 'very harsh'
summary: England manager Gareth Southgate faced "very harsh" criticism after the team's disappointing results in the summer, but winger Jack Grealish has defended his boss, saying he's underrated despite leading the team to the Euro 2020 final and World Cup semi-finals. Grealish believes the criticism is unfair, particularly given the team's success in major tournaments. Meanwhile, Wales captain Gareth Bale is on a "good path" to full fitness ahead of the World Cup, with Scotland gaining a measure of revenge over Ukraine with a 3-0 win in their Nations League match.

site_title: Ailing Osaka out in Tokyo
summary: Naomi Osaka withdrew from the Pan Pacific Open in Tokyo due to stomach pain, just hours before her second-round match against Beatriz Haddad Maia. The 24-year-old Japanese, a four-time Grand Slam winner, cited her "body won't let her compete" after a poor run of form in Tokyo. This comes after Osaka's first-round match was cut short due to Daria Saville's injury, and she has plummeted to 48th in the world rankings this year. Osaka's withdrawal is the latest blow to the tournament, which has seen several top seeds eliminated.

site_title: Golf: Truce with LIV series 'off the table', says PGA boss Monahan
summary: US PGA Tour commissioner Jay Monahan says a truce with LIV Golf Series is "off the table" as the sport's civil war deepens. The PGA has made changes for the 2022-23 season to keep top talent, and Monahan believes the tour has more assets at its disposal to prevent players from leaving for LIV Golf. Several LIV Golf players are set to go to trial in 2024 on anti-trust lawsuit charges, and Monahan's reluctance to talk about a deal with LIV Golf has fueled speculation about the future of golf.

site_title: Start your day with a promising Hunting Trip
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

The article provides form analysis for Saturday's South African racing events. Promising horses include Hunting Trip, Miss Greenlight, and Sir William, who are expected to perform well. Global Forests and Guy Alexander are among the top contenders in the 2,000m event. Other notable horses include Sugar Mountain, Somerset Maugham, and The Future is Bright, who are part of a strong Justin Snaith quartet. The article also highlights well-bred newcomers and horses with the potential for improvement, making it a promising day for racing fans. Key results are expected in several events across the track.

site_title: Injury relapse for Tiger roar
summary: Tiger Roar, a leading contender for Saturday's $100,000 Class 1 race, has been scratched due to a recurring knee injury. The 2021 Champion Three-Year-Old suffered a similar issue 10 months ago, requiring surgery to repair a fractured bone. Trainer Michael Clements is optimistic that Tiger Roar can recover and return to racing, citing the horse's good health and training prep. Clements will now focus on other horses, including Prosperous Return, who has performed well in recent starts, as potential flagbearers for the Class 1 contest and upcoming feature races.

site_title: 19 cycling disciplines for 2027 world meet
summary: The International Cycling Union (UCI) has chosen Haute-Savoie, France, as the host for the 2027 World Cycling Championships, which will feature 19 disciplines. This will be the second "super" event, following the 2023 enlarged event in Glasgow, Scotland. The 2027 championships will include road, track, BMX, trials, mountain biking, para-cycling, and other disciplines, and will take place in a natural setting where French cycling legend Bernard Hinault won the 1980 world title. The event is set to increase participation and opportunities for grand tour specialists and climbers to become world champions.

site_title: Swimming on right path
summary: New Singapore Swimming Association (SSA) National Training Centre (NTC) head coach Brad Dingey aims to achieve "repeatable and reliable" success, following his two-year term starting Sept 1. Dingey, a Canadian with 20+ years of coaching experience, seeks to replicate past success and develop world-class swimmers, including those for the 2028 Los Angeles Olympics. Dingey will work with assistant coaches Gustavo Schirru and Alex Mordvincev to improve the NTC's performance, and has committed to open communication with clubs and stakeholders to achieve shared success.

site_title: Bank of England raises rates by a half-point as push begins for bigger moves
summary: The Bank of England raised interest rates by a half-point to 2.25% in its second consecutive hike to combat inflation, backed by five of the nine-member Monetary Policy Committee. The move aims to bring inflation down from over 13% to less than 11% and may set the stage for a bigger hike later this year. The decision also came after new Prime Minister Liz Truss's energy relief plan, which is expected to be unveiled on Friday, and tax cuts that could support demand and impact inflation.

site_title: Brace for super impact
summary: Super Impact, a New Zealand-bred bay gelding, is poised to notch his first Kranji success in Saturday's $70,000 Class 3 event. His impressive third-place finish in the Group 1 Singapore Derby and recent impressive trials suggest he's top-class material. With jockey Jake Bayliss, Super Impact has shown exceptional form, including a recent gallop where he demonstrated his speed and endurance. His main threats are trainers Tim Fitzsimmons' Boomba and In All His Glory, who are also recent winners. Super Impact's versatility in wet conditions adds to his chances of success.

site_title: Rainbow armbands latest issue Fifa must tackle
summary: A group of European football federations, including England, Germany, and France, plan to have their captains wear rainbow armbands with a One Love symbol during international matches and at the 2022 World Cup in Qatar. The move is part of an anti-discrimination campaign, with the Dutch football federation leading the effort. The armbands have not been approved by FIFA, which has strict rules on team attire, but the move aims to send a clear message against discrimination. The decision comes as Qatar faces pressure from fans, human rights groups, and others to address its laws against homosexuality and treatment of foreign laborers.

site_title: EPL fans to get ban for invasions, smoke bombs
summary: The English Premier League has unanimously agreed to impose automatic one-year bans on supporters who engage in anti-social and criminal behavior at stadiums, including pitch invasions and use of smoke bombs. This policy, effective immediately, aims to curb violent fan behavior and will also apply to accompanying parents or guardians. The leagues and the Football Association will report offenders to the police, potentially leading to permanent criminal records and prison sentences. The move follows a series of incidents, including a headbutting incident that resulted in a 24-week jail sentence and a 10-year football banning order.

site_title: Chinese clan volunteers to translate resources for Mandarin-speaking caregiver community
summary: A Chinese clan in Singapore has volunteered to translate resources for the Mandarin-speaking caregiver community, particularly those caring for children on the autism spectrum. SG Enable and CaringSG selected the resources to be translated. This initiative aims to improve access to autism-related information for caregivers who may struggle with English language barriers.

site_title: Tennis: Raducanu surges into Korea Open quarter-finals after overcoming Wickmayer
summary: Emma Raducanu advanced to the quarter-finals of the Korea Open, defeating 396th-ranked Yanina Wickmayer in straight sets, 6-3, 7-5. The 19-year-old Briton, seeded sixth, overcame a sluggish start and a late wobble to secure the win. Raducanu will face third seed Magda Linette of Poland next, following her loss to Wickmayer being her first win in the tournament.

site_title: The future of work: Here are three big ideas from Salesforce's Dreamforce conference
summary: Salesforce's Dreamforce conference in San Francisco discussed the concept of a "digital headquarters" to facilitate better online collaboration among staff. This virtual center would include systems for spontaneous interactions and information sharing, while in-person collaboration would remain essential. The idea aims to address the disruptions caused by the pandemic, enabling companies to work more effectively together online.

site_title: Singdollar hit by hawkish Fed; analysts eye MAS' next move
summary: Singapore stocks ended flat, down a quarter of a percent, amid the Federal Reserve's hawkish interest rate hike signal. The Singapore dollar retreated to a 29-month low against the US dollar. Analysts expect the Monetary Authority of Singapore to make another interest rate tightening move in October, but some now question the aggressiveness of the move.

site_title: Smaller nations stress support for multilateralism, principle of sovereign equality
summary: A group of 30 small and medium-sized countries, including Singapore, Brunei, Malaysia, the Philippines, and Vietnam, emphasized their support for a rules-based multilateral system with the United Nations at its core. They stressed sovereign equality and the peaceful settlement of disputes, as well as the need for resilient supply chains and an open trading system. The Global Governance Group (3G) also discussed the COVID-19 pandemic, vaccine access, and global pandemic prevention, calling for continued efforts to strengthen global cooperation and pandemic response.

site_title: Football: Wales forward Bale on 'good path' to be fully fit for World Cup
summary: Wales forward Gareth Bale is on a "good path" to full fitness ahead of the World Cup in Qatar, despite not completing a full game since joining Los Angeles FC in June. Bale has made only two starts in 11 appearances, scoring twice, and expects his fitness to be much improved by the World Cup's start date of November 20. He is targeting to play 90 minutes in as many games as possible, having struggled with injury in his previous seasons.

site_title: Ex-ship management company director pleads guilty to 5 corruption charges
summary: Ananthakrishnan Nanda, 51, a former director of Aoxing Ship Management Singapore, pleaded guilty to five corruption charges and two under the Corruption, Drug Trafficking and Other Serious Crimes Act. He agreed to pay 10% of Marine Care Singapore's revenue to Sakura Ship Management in exchange for advancing Marine Care's business interests with Aoxing. This arrangement resulted in over $9,400 being transferred to Master Manning Services & Logistics. Nanda faces up to five years in jail and/or a fine of up to $100,000 for each corruption charge.

site_title: Probation for man who sexually assaulted two underage girls when he was 16
summary: A 22-year-old man in Singapore has been ordered to undergo 21 months of probation after pleading guilty to multiple counts of sexually penetrating a minor. He committed the crimes when he was 16, including having unprotected sex with a 13-year-old girl and her 15-year-old girlfriend. The offender must stay indoors from midnight to 6am daily and perform 60 hours of community service. His parents were bonded for $5,000 to ensure his good behavior. The victims' identities are protected due to a gag order.

site_title: Golf: Swedish golf federation cuts ties with Stenson over LIV series
summary: The Swedish Golf Federation has cut ties with golfer Henrik Stenson, citing his involvement with LIV Golf, a Saudi-backed circuit that has faced criticism over human rights concerns. Stenson was sacked as Europe's Ryder Cup captain in July after joining LIV Golf. The federation believes Stenson can no longer serve as a role model for Swedish junior golfers due to his association with the LIV circuit. The decision was made after discussions began when Stenson announced his LIV Golf membership, and it is not limited to 2023.

site_title: Cycling: $220 registration fee for amateur races at Tour de France Singapore event draws mixed reaction
summary: The Tour de France Prudential Singapore Criterium has sparked a mixed reaction among the local cycling community regarding its $220 registration fee for amateur races. The event, featuring 32 professional riders, including 2022 Tour de France winner Jonas Vingegaard, will take place on October 29-30. While some, like 42-year-old teacher Lukman Nurhakim Noordin, find the price reasonable, others, like a local cycling enthusiast, consider it too steep, especially during economic uncertainty. Registration for community rides is also available.

site_title: Jail for man who paid $500 for an impostor to take his basic theory test
summary: A 52-year-old Singaporean man, Goh Ah Hock, was sentenced to two months' jail for engaging in a conspiracy to cheat by personation. He paid $500 to an agent to impersonate him for the basic theory test, which he needed to convert his Malaysian driving license to a Singaporean one. The impersonator, Chinese national Zhang Zhongliang, was caught after a suspicious tester noticed discrepancies. Goh's lack of confidence in passing the test posed a hazard to other road users, prompting the court to impose a deterrent sentence.

site_title: S'pore has room to be optimistic amid global fragility, says Tharman
summary: Singapore can remain optimistic despite global fragility, Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam said. The world is entering an era of complex insecurities, including geopolitics, energy and food, climate change, and pandemics. However, Singapore has bases for optimism due to its strong social compact, social mobility, and intrinsic capabilities. To maintain optimism, Singapore needs to invest in social mobility, develop deeper capabilities in its people, and cultivate a culture of civic discourse. The country must also address four global insecurities: stagflation, the deterioration of the global commons, debt distress in developing countries, and geopolitical insecurity.

site_title: Tennis: Osaka withdraws from Pan Pacific Open with abdominal pain
summary: Naomi Osaka withdrew from the Pan Pacific Open in Tokyo due to abdominal pain, citing that her body won't let her compete. The 24-year-old Japanese tennis player, a four-time Grand Slam winner, was set to face Beatriz Haddad Maia in the second round. Osaka, struggling with a poor run of form, admitted to having gone through "more down than up" this year, with her ranking plummeting to 48. This marks the latest setback for the tournament, which has seen several top seeds and players eliminated in the early rounds.

site_title: Jail for man involved in case where travel agency staff gave bribes to increase sales
summary: A 60-year-old operations manager, Tan Han Ser, was sentenced to five weeks' jail for conspiring with a colleague to give bribes to See Chun Keat in exchange for buying air tickets for a maritime industry company. The bribes, totaling over $7,000, included cash and travel insurance worth $5,571. Tan and See committed the offence in 2018 and 2019, while Bong Fung Sen, also involved, received a separate sentence. The bribes were part of a scheme to increase sales and commissions for the travel agency, Majestic Travel.

site_title: Tennis: Federer pairs up with Nadal for farewell match at Laver Cup
summary: Roger Federer will team up with Rafael Nadal for the final match of his career at the Laver Cup, a doubles match against Frances Tiafoe and Jack Sock. Federer, 41, has been struggling with a knee problem and will not play singles, while Nadal is looking forward to an "unforgettable" match with his long-time rival. The match is part of the three-day event, which also features Novak Djokovic and Andy Murray on Team Europe, and Taylor Fritz and Felix Auger-Aliassime on Team World. Federer announced his retirement after the event.

site_title: S'pore-listed data centre operator Digital Core Reit aims to acquire 2 data centres in US, Germany
summary: Digital Core Reit, a Singapore-listed data centre operator, plans to acquire two data centers in Frankfurt and Dallas. The proposed deal is valued at approximately US$757 million and could be distribution per unit (DPU) accretive by up to 3.1% if successful. The Reit has two possible scenarios: a larger deal with a total acquisition cost of US$700 million, which would be preferable, or a smaller deal with a total acquisition cost of US$654 million, funded by debt. The acquisition is expected to be completed by the end of November or early December, pending approval by unit holders.

site_title: Football: Manchester United report £115.5m loss for 2021-22 season
summary: Manchester United announced a net loss of £115.5 million for the 2021-22 season, despite revenues rising to £583 million due to easing coronavirus restrictions. The club's net debt increased to £514.9 million, primarily due to a 22% rise in debt and a 19% increase in wages. The loss was attributed to a fall in the pound, increased US dollar borrowings, and a £24.7 million compensation package for former manager Ole Gunnar Solskjaer. The club's new manager Erik ten Hag has strengthened the squad, but the failure to qualify for the Champions League will impact finances this season.

site_title: Football: Former skipper Noble to return to West Ham as sporting director
summary: Former West Ham captain Mark Noble will return to the club as their new sporting director, beginning in January. Noble, 35, spent 18 years at the club, including 24 years in the academy and first team. He will work closely with manager David Moyes and the current board to support the team, which is currently in the relegation zone. Noble expressed his happiness and eagerness to start, citing his deep knowledge and understanding of the club. Moyes welcomed Noble's return, praising his asset and strength as a player and captain.

site_title: Malaysia Chiak! at Northpoint City closed for 2 weeks due to infestation
summary: Malaysia Chiak! at Northpoint City in Singapore has been suspended for two weeks due to infestation. The foodcourt was fined a total of $800 and received six demerit points for failing to keep the premises free from infestation in the last 12 months. The restaurant plans to use the temporary closure to refurbish and improve its layout to facilitate cleaning and upkeeping. It will also retrain its food handlers on food safety and hygiene to prevent similar incidents. The Singapore Food Agency (SFA) imposed the suspension after the restaurant accumulated 12 demerit points over 12 months.

site_title: Formula One: Tsunoda to stay at AlphaTauri for a third season in 2023
summary: Japanese driver Yuki Tsunoda will remain with AlphaTauri for a third season in 2023. Currently 16th in the championship with 11 points from 16 races, Tsunoda expressed his commitment to the team, citing his improved performance and the team's support. Team boss Franz Tost praised Tsunoda's progress, stating he needs at least three years to fully adapt to F1. Meanwhile, teammate Pierre Gasly's future remains uncertain, with Renault's Alpine and Red Bull in talks, but a suitable replacement for Gasly has yet to be found.

site_title: Swimming: SSA appoints Canadian Brad Dingey as new NTC head coach
summary: Singapore Swimming Association (SSA) has appointed Canadian Brad Dingey as the new head coach of the National Training Centre (NTC), effective September 1.
