Dingey, with over 20 years of coaching experience, aims to build "repeatable and reliable" success. He will support assistant coaches Gustavo Schirru and Alex Mordvincev, with a focus on developing world-class talents and replicating success at major meets, including the 2028 Los Angeles Olympics. Dingey's appointment is seen as a critical link in the athlete pathway, with SSA committed to supporting the national swimming team towards the Olympic Games in 2024 and 2028.

site_title: TikTok series Finding Juliana looks at drug abuse, addiction up close
summary: A new TikTok series, Finding Juliana, explores the complexities of drug abuse and addiction through a personal lens, sparking conversations on the realities of drug use. The series, part of a two-year anti-drug campaign, aims to promote advocacy for a drug-free society, especially among youth. According to 2021 statistics, young people make up the majority of first-time drug abusers, and the campaign will engage young people through active discussions and activities on its microsite and TikTok account. The series will culminate in a live event and a documentary series featuring real-life individuals who inspired the series.

site_title: Daiwa House Logistics Trust proposes $46m maiden acquisition in Japan
summary: Daiwa House Logistics Trust (DHLT) proposes acquiring a Japanese portfolio of logistics facilities and freehold land for $46 million, representing an 11.8% discount to the properties' average appraised value. The acquisition aims to broaden DHLT's earnings base, diversify its portfolio, and mitigate concentration risk. The deal is expected to lift DPU by 1.3% and enhance the quality of the existing portfolio.

site_title: Man who stabbed roommate in Bedok flat and left him bleeding overnight gets life term for murder
summary: A 51-year-old Myanmar national, Naing Lin, was sentenced to life imprisonment for fatally stabbing his roommate, Myo Kyaw Thu, 49, in their Bedok Reservoir flat on April 2, 2021. Naing Lin had stabbed his roommate five times during an argument and left him bleeding overnight before returning the next day to surrender to the police. Prosecutors did not object to the life sentence, citing the lack of viciousness and disregard for human life in the crime. The court agreed, ruling that the death penalty was not warranted in this case.

site_title: What the US Fed's latest big rate hike means for Singapore
summary: The US Federal Reserve raised its benchmark interest rate to 3-3.25% in a 75-basis-point hike, the highest level in 14 years, to combat surging inflation. This move is expected to make loans more expensive, affecting stock and bond prices in Singapore. The US dollar rallied as a result, while the US stock market plummeted. The rate hike is aimed at crushing inflation, but its impact on the global economy, particularly Singapore, remains to be seen.

site_title: Swiss National Bank ends Europe’s subzero rate era with 75 basis-point hike
summary: The Swiss National Bank (SNB) raised interest rates by 75 basis points, ending Europe's subzero rate era, to 0.5% for the first time in almost eight years. This move is in line with recent euro region tightening actions. The decision aims to contain inflation above 3% and is the SNB's most aggressive tightening action in two decades. The Swiss franc tumbled 1.6% against the euro, while the Bank of Japan remains the only central bank with subzero policy.

site_title: Asia stocks slump on global slowdown fears after Fed signals more rate hikes ahead
summary: Asian stocks slumped on Thursday amid global slowdown fears, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng plummeting 2.6% after the US Federal Reserve raised interest rates by 75 basis points for the third straight time. The Fed chairman vowed to continue fighting inflation, despite risks of unemployment and growth slowing. Other regional markets, including Japan, Taiwan, and South Korea, also fell. Singapore's Straits Times Index closed up 0.04% despite concerns of a slowdown in Asia, with some analysts predicting further interest rate hikes and potential fund outflows.

site_title: Singtel's Optus in Australia hit by cyber attack, customer data leaked
summary: Optus, a subsidiary of Singtel in Australia, has been hit by a cyber attack that exposed customer data, including names, dates of birth, phone numbers, and email addresses. The attack also compromised addresses and identification document numbers for a subset of customers. Optus has assured customers that payment details and account passwords were not compromised, and services remain unaffected. The company is working with the Australian Cyber Security Centre and authorities to mitigate risks and offer expert monitoring services to affected customers, with CEO Kelly Bayer Rosmarin describing the incident as "devastating".

site_title: Singapore's rising costs of running a business outpace Hong Kong's
summary: Singapore's business costs are rising faster than Hong Kong's, driven by higher talent and office space costs. Despite Singapore's faster reopening, the city-state's inflation rate remains under control. Office rents in Singapore's central business area accelerated for a third quarter, narrowing the gap with Hong Kong's. The faster pace of new business formation in Singapore, however, suggests that the trend may not be a short-term anomaly. Structural factors such as geopolitical rivalry and supply chain diversification will likely play a significant role in shaping the decision-making process for companies considering a relocation.

site_title: Scam victim told to fake hostage situation, smear ketchup on himself to scare mum
summary: A 16-year-old Chinese national was tricked into staging a hostage situation in Singapore to scare his mother after being accused of smuggling contraband cigarettes and spreading Covid-19 rumors. He was instructed to fake his own kidnapping, smear ketchup on himself, and record a video to demand a ransom from his mother. Fortunately, the police intervened, and the mother refused to pay the ransom. The incident is part of a larger trend of China official impersonation scams, with at least $57.3 million in losses reported in Singapore from January to August 2022.

site_title: Football: Grealish tells critics to lay off England boss Southgate
summary: England manager Gareth Southgate faced "very harsh" criticism after the team's disappointing results in the summer, but Manchester City and England winger Jack Grealish has come to his defense. Grealish believes the criticism was unfair, citing England's successful performances in the Euro 2020 final and the 2018 World Cup semi-finals. He acknowledges that as an English player, he faces public scrutiny, especially given his high-profile transfer and success with Manchester City. Grealish suggests that criticism is just part of being a high-profile player and encourages others to "embrace it."

site_title: 'Very high chance' Hong Kong will end year in recession, warns finance chief
summary: Hong Kong is likely to end the year in recession, with Finance Chief Paul Chan warning of a "very high chance" of negative GDP growth due to spiralling interest rates and strict Covid-19 controls. The city's monetary policy is tied to the US Federal Reserve, which has raised interest rates to curb inflation. Hong Kong has already recorded two consecutive quarters of negative growth and is facing a net outflow of over 200,000 people in the last two years. The government is considering easing travel curbs, but experts warn of a decline in talent retention and a potential 20% slide in property prices.

site_title: Football: 'Room for improvement', says coach after S'pore's mixed display in U-20 Asian Cup qualifiers
summary: Singapore's Under-19 football team finished third in the Under-20 Asian Cup qualification campaign in Tajikistan, behind the hosts and Lebanon. Despite a goalless draw against Tajikistan and a 1-1 draw with Cambodia, the team struggled with fatigue and lapses in concentration in their third match against Lebanon, resulting in a 6-1 loss. Head coach Fadzuhasny Juraimi acknowledged the team's progress but emphasized the need for improvement, particularly in adapting to the high-intensity format of the tournament.

site_title: Indonesia raises key rate more than expected as rupiah weakens
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, raised the seven-day reverse repurchase rate by 50 basis points to 4.25% in an effort to stem inflation and stabilize the rupiah. This is the largest interest rate hike since 2018, exceeding economists' expectations of a 25 basis-point move. The move aims to shield the rupiah amid global economic pressures, following the US Federal Reserve's 75 basis-point hike. Bank Indonesia governor Perry Warjiyo stated the bank will target a consumer price index within 2-4% by 2023 and stabilize the rupiah according to fundamentals.

site_title: Tennis: Federer one of the greatest athletes of any sport, says Djokovic
summary: Roger Federer, a 41-year-old Swiss tennis great, will compete in his final match at the Laver Cup this week. Novak Djokovic hailed Federer as one of the greatest athletes of all time, praising his effortless playing style and lasting legacy in tennis. The two have a long history of rivalry, but Djokovic expressed respect for Federer's career and their relationship. Federer will team up with Rafael Nadal for the doubles match on Friday, a unique opportunity for the tennis world to celebrate his retirement.

site_title: Rapid blood test by MIT’s Smart and NTU can determine if person has immunity against Covid-19, variants
summary: Scientists at the Singapore-MIT Alliance for Research and Technology (Smart) and Nanyang Technological University (NTU) have developed a rapid blood test that can determine if a person has immunity against Covid-19 and its variants in just 10 minutes. The test, which uses a paper-based assay, has up to 93% accuracy and can be easily adapted for new variants. The findings could pave the way for personalized vaccination strategies and address vaccine hesitancy, with the test kit expected to be available for public use once regulatory approvals and manufacturing standards are met.

site_title: Goldman slashes China's 2023 growth forecast with Covid-zero strategy likely to stay
summary: Goldman Sachs has slashed China's 2023 economic growth forecast to 4.5% due to the country's likely continued adherence to its Covid-zero strategy. China is unlikely to begin reopening before the second quarter of 2023, with authorities prioritizing higher vaccination rates, manufacturing of Covid-19 pills, and other conditions. This prediction is in line with steady downgrades of forecasts due to repeated lockdowns, a persistent property crisis, and slowing exports. Goldman warns that any easing of restrictions could lead to a surge in infections, reduced mobility, and supply chain disruptions.

site_title: MMA: After 1 win in 4 years, Eddie Alvarez leaves One Championship 'amicably'
summary: Former UFC champion Eddie Alvarez leaves One Championship after a four-year stint with little fanfare, announcing he parted ways amicably with the organization. Alvarez, 38, had a disappointing run in One, winning only once in four years, and is now a free agent, considering a potential return to combat sports. Meanwhile, Raul Rosas Jr., 18, makes history by becoming the youngest fighter signed to a UFC contract, aiming to surpass Jon Jones as the organization's youngest world champion.

site_title: Bank of Japan keeps ultra low rates, remains global outlier despite sliding yen
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its ultra-low interest rates, setting itself as the last major monetary authority with a negative policy rate, despite a global wave of policy tightening and a slide in the yen to a 24-year low. The decision came after the Federal Reserve's rate hike and follows the BOJ's governor Haruhiko Kuroda's repeated signals that policy normalization is not imminent. The yen continues to fall, and the BOJ will likely need to buy more bonds to defend its yield cap of 0.25%.

site_title: Hong Kong finance chief says no sharp risk to property prices after Fed rate hike
summary: Hong Kong's finance chief, Paul Chan, stated that there is no sharp risk to the city's real estate market despite a 75 basis point interest rate hike by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, its highest since 2008. Home prices have dropped 6% in the first eight months, but Chan believes the market is not at risk due to various factors such as employment and repayment capabilities. However, Bloomberg analysts warn that housing could become the least affordable in 24 years, with mortgage repayments reaching 60.1% of household income, unless home prices decline further.

site_title: COP27 conversations not expected to be easy amid geopolitical tensions: Grace Fu
summary: Singapore remains committed to its goal of achieving net-zero carbon emissions by 2050, despite geopolitical tensions at COP27 potentially hindering global climate progress. Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu acknowledged the challenges posed by the US-China conflict and the energy crisis in Europe, but emphasized the importance of delivering on promises. She also highlighted the need for individual actions, such as changing personal habits and using environmentally friendly products, to minimize environmental impact.

site_title: NBA: Phoenix Suns owner Robert Sarver plans to sell team amid abuse scandal
summary: Phoenix Suns owner Robert Sarver plans to sell the team amid an NBA investigation finding he mistreated team employees for years, including using racial slurs, making sexual remarks, and belittling employees. Sarver was fined $10 million and suspended for a year after the investigation, but faced mounting public pressure to sell. The NBA and the Suns' ownership group say the sale is in the best interest for the community. Sarver's decision comes after criticism from NBA players and the league's commissioner, Adam Silver, who defended the fine and suspension as fair punishment.

site_title: US interest rates hit 14-year high in inflation battle; Fed chief Powell vows to 'keep at it'
summary: The US Federal Reserve raised interest rates by 3/4 of a percentage point for the third consecutive time, bringing the benchmark rate to a range of 3.00% to 3.25%, in a bid to combat inflation. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell vowed to continue the fight, warning of a "painful" correction in the housing market and potential recession. The Fed projects its policy rate will rise to 4.25% to 4.50% by the end of the year, and unemployment is expected to rise to 4.4% in 2023, above the threshold associated with past recessions.

site_title: Credit Suisse planning to split investment bank in three: Report
summary: Credit Suisse is planning to split its investment bank into three parts: an advisory business, a "bad bank" to hold high-risk assets, and the rest of the business. The move aims to prevent a damaging capital raise and is part of a broader strategy review led by CEO Ulrich Korner. The bank is also cutting around 5,000 jobs as part of a cost-reduction drive. The split is an attempt to address the bank's recent scandals, including a corporate spying scandal and a record trading loss, and to bolster its capital after a string of losses.

site_title: Asia stocks tumble, US dollar soars as Fed steps up inflation battle
summary: The US dollar surged to a 20-year high of 111.65, while major Asian stocks tumbled as the Federal Reserve raised interest rates sharply by 75 basis points, exceeding market expectations. The Fed now projects a funds rate of 4.4% this year, indicating an extended period of restrictive monetary policy. The US dollar index also hit a 20-year high, sending the Australian, New Zealand, and Canadian dollars to fresh multi-year lows, while the euro sank to a 20-year low.

site_title: Football: Rainbow armbands are new flashpoint for Fifa and Qatar World Cup
summary: A group of European football federations, including England, Germany, and France, plan to have their captains wear rainbow armbands with a "One Love" design during international matches and the 2022 World Cup in Qatar, as part of an anti-discrimination campaign. The move comes as Qatar faces pressure over its laws against homosexuality and treatment of foreign laborers. FIFA has not yet approved the armbands, but the move aims to send a clear message against discrimination, with captains Harry Kane and Manuel Neuer expressing support for the gesture.

site_title: Golf: Veterans Scott, Matsuyama lead Internationals against US
summary: Former Masters champions Adam Scott and Hideki Matsuyama will lead the International team against the US in the Presidents Cup's opening foursome. Scott, playing in his 10th Presidents Cup, and Matsuyama, in his fifth, will face US pair Patrick Cantlay and Xander Schauffele, who have a 4-0-0 record in foursomes. The match is seen as a crucial test for the International team, with captain Trevor Immelman relying on Scott and Matsuyama for a steady start.

site_title: Bitcoin, Ether drop as Fed warning of rate hike pain hits crypto
summary: Cryptocurrencies, particularly Bitcoin and Ether, plummeted as the Federal Reserve announced another interest rate hike, warning of economic pain and further tightening. Bitcoin fell 4% and Ether shed 7.2%, nearing levels last seen in 2020. The Fed's aggressive policy tightening is expected to continue, posing a significant threat to crypto markets, which have already suffered a $2 trillion decline from 2021's record high. Experts warn of potential failures and blood in the streets, with only a few "rich champions" emerging in the meantime.

site_title: With latest rate hike, US Fed signals willingness to accept recession to crush inflation
summary: The US Federal Reserve raised interest rates by 75 basis points, signaling a willingness to accept a recession to combat inflation. Fed officials now forecast a further 1.25 percentage points of tightening before year-end, with median unemployment projections reaching 4.4% next year. Chairman Jerome Powell acknowledged the need for a "painful slowdown" to curb price pressures, and officials cut growth projections, raised their unemployment outlook, and downgraded their inflation forecasts, indicating a growing risk of recession.

site_title: Football: Scotland beat Ukraine to boost Nations League push
summary: Scotland secured a 3-0 win over Ukraine in a Nations League match, boosting their bid for promotion. The victory, at Hampden Park in Glasgow, was a revenge win for Scotland after losing to Ukraine in a World Cup play-off in June. Lyndon Dykes scored a brace, including two headers, while John McGinn also found the net. The win moves Scotland to the top of Group B1 and sets them up for a final group match against the Republic of Ireland on Saturday.

site_title: Woman who stabbed herself during stand-off with cops charged
summary: A 53-year-old woman, Juliana Abdul Kadir, has been charged with possession of two weapons after a stand-off with police outside St Hilda's Secondary School in Tampines. She stabbed herself in the abdomen during the incident, prompting police to taser her to prevent further harm. Juliana will be remanded for psychiatric observation and her case has been adjourned to October 12. She faces up to three years in jail and at least six strokes of the cane for possession of the knife and penknife blade.

site_title: Businesses and residents welcome new transport option
summary: Residents and businesses near the Cross Island Line's phase two, set to open in 2032, welcome a new transport option. However, concerns arise over station locations and construction-related traffic. Mark Yeow, a West Coast resident, expresses relief at the six new stations along the 15km stretch, citing a lack of public transport connectivity near his home in Clementi. The new line aims to alleviate traffic issues in the area.

site_title: Sats in talks to buy air cargo firm
summary: Sats, a Singapore-listed catering and gateway services provider, is in talks to acquire Worldwide Flight Services, an air cargo handler. The potential purchase has sparked discussions around financing. This acquisition would expand Sats' services to include air cargo handling, further diversifying its offerings. The outcome of these talks is yet to be determined, but a deal could provide Sats with increased revenue streams and market presence.

site_title: 4% interest floor rate extended
summary: The 4% interest floor rate for Central Provident Fund (CPF) Special, MediSave, and Retirement Account monies has been extended until December 31, 2023, announced the Housing Board and CPF Board. This rate was previously set for interest earned until December 31, 2022. The extension provides a stable interest rate for CPF account holders until the end of 2023, offering financial stability and predictability.

site_title: Benefits for residents when they enrol in Healthier SG programme
summary: Singapore's Healthier SG programme aims to prevent chronic diseases by providing residents aged 60 and above with a dedicated family physician for health consultations and goal setting. The programme will be extended to those aged 40-59 in the following two years. Residents can expect personalized health plans, free consultations, and subsidized health screenings and vaccinations. They will also have the option to switch doctors up to four times in the first two years, with one change allowed per year thereafter. The programme also encourages healthy lifestyles through incentives such as Health Points and enhanced rewards for physical activity and diet adherence.

site_title: Residents aged 60 and above can enrol in Healthier SG in 2023
summary: Singapore's Healthier SG Programme will begin in the second half of 2023, targeting residents aged 60 and above. The programme aims to shift focus from "sick care" to preventive care, with eligible residents invited to enroll in a primary care clinic of their choice. Doctors will develop a health plan, including lifestyle adjustments and screenings, with the goal of empowering residents to stay on the path to better health. Community partners will help manage residents' health, and MOH will introduce incentives such as comparable drug prices and waived co-payments for screenings and vaccinations.

site_title: Crypto shake-out engulfs top management as CEOs start stepping down
summary: Crypto CEOs are stepping down amid industry shakeout, with Kraken's Jesse Powell, Genesis' Michael Moro, and Bitcoin evangelist Michael Saylor relinquishing top positions. The departures follow a slump that shaved $2 trillion from cryptocurrencies' market value and landed some bosses in bankruptcy court. Insiders are taking over at firms like MicroStrategy and Alameda, and regulators are re-evaluating the industry's leadership. The shakeout sets the stage for a changing of the guard in the roughly decade-old industry, with many prominent leaders being replaced by those with different skills.

site_title: How to read the US Federal Reserve's projections like a pro
summary: The US Federal Reserve raised borrowing costs by three-quarters of a percentage point, taking their official interest rate to a range of 3% to 3.25%, marking the third straight jumbo increase. Fed officials project interest rates to reach 4.4% by the end of the year and 4.6% by the end of 2023, with rates expected to begin coming down in 2024. The Fed aims to control inflation, which is running at more than three times their official target, by slowing spending, business investment, and the job market.

site_title: Asia LNG prices stabilise as China buys more Russian supply
summary: China's increased purchases of Russian liquefied natural gas (LNG) have stabilised Asia's LNG prices, which had been volatile due to global market uncertainty. China bought 671,105 tonnes of Russian LNG in August, a two-year high, and its imports from Russia rose 36.7% from the same period in 2021. This reduced competition for other buyers, keeping global prices capped. Experts expect China to expand its purchases over the next few months, and global market conditions remain uncertain and volatile, with demand and supply factors contributing to elevated prices.

site_title: Medical group says undiluted vaccine was given by relief doctor
summary: A relief doctor at the ProHealth Medical Group @ Hougang clinic, who started work only two weeks earlier, mistakenly administered a full vial of undiluted Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine to two adults. Each vial contains five doses. The clinic has stopped engaging the doctor's services and is cooperating with the investigation. One patient was hospitalized due to symptoms, and the clinic is providing necessary support and assistance to affected patients. The company has apologized for the incident and prioritizes patient safety and well-being. The matter is still under investigation by authorities.

site_title: Landmarks lit in purple and yellow to mark World Alzheimer's Day
summary: Five iconic landmarks in Singapore, including the Esplanade and Marina Bay Sands, were illuminated in purple and yellow to commemorate World Alzheimer's Day. The campaign, organized by Dementia Singapore, aims to raise public awareness about dementia and Alzheimer's disease. Various community events and activities were held throughout September to support those affected by dementia and their caregivers, including a $1 million donation by Keppel Care Foundation and a walkathon at Bishan-Ang Mo Kio Park. The events aim to show solidarity and provide resources for those impacted by dementia.

site_title: Cross Island Line set to transform more areas into vibrant hubs
summary: The second stage of the MRT Cross Island Line (CRL) in Singapore is set to transform the Turf City and Jurong Lake District into vibrant hubs. The six-station, 15km stretch will improve connectivity for residents and commuters in the west, as well as attract new residents. This follows the successful transformation of areas connected to earlier MRT lines, which previously remained sleepy towns. The completion of the CRL is expected to boost the local economy and enhance the quality of life for residents in the region.

site_title: Clean, honest govt a key factor in Singapore's progress: President
summary: Singapore's strong stance against corruption and trust in the government have been key factors in the country's progress, according to President Halimah Yacob. The city-state has been recognized as one of the least corrupt countries in the world, ranking fourth globally this year. The Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) has played a crucial role in maintaining this status, with President Halimah emphasizing the bureau's independence and commitment to investigating corruption without fear or influence. A new history book documents Singapore's anti-corruption journey and CPIB's contributions, highlighting the importance of a clean and honest government in the country's success.

site_title: S'pore stresses need for cross-border tie-ups to fight cyber scams
summary: Singapore reports a 53% increase in cyber scams in 2021, with 24,000 cases, resulting in losses of over $1.3 million. Minister of State for Home Affairs Muhammad Faishal Ibrahim emphasizes the need for cross-border cooperation to combat cybercrime, citing a successful joint operation with the Royal Malaysia Police that arrested 13 people from regional scam syndicates. The issue is part of broader concerns, including terrorism and illicit drugs, where digital platforms have facilitated communication and radicalization. Regional cooperation is crucial to addressing these threats, according to Faishal.

site_title: COE prices for cars down, new high for motorcycle premium
summary: The Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premium for motorcycles reached a new record of $11,589 in the latest tender exercise, breaking the previous record of $11,400 set in March 2022. In contrast, car COE prices decreased, with those for cars with engines up to 1,600cc and below 130bhp dropping 2.3% to $84,000. The commercial vehicle COE premium also rose 3.1% to $67,001. The high COE prices are expected to impact businesses and individuals, particularly those in the food delivery services.

site_title: 4% CPF interest floor rate extended to end-2023
summary: The 4% interest floor rate for Special, MediSave, and Retirement Account (SMRA) monies has been extended until Dec 31, 2023. This rate ensures fair and reasonable returns for CPF members, pegged to market instruments of comparable risk and duration. SMRA rates will continue to be reviewed, and members will earn the higher of the floor or pegged rate. Meanwhile, Ordinary Account (OA) interest rates remain unchanged at 2.5% per annum until Dec 31, 2022, with extra interest paid to members aged 55 and above, earning up to 6% per annum on retirement balances.

site_title: Full-time NSmen to get free access to over 75,000 online courses
summary: The Singapore government has launched the SkillsFuture@NS Learning eXperience Platform, offering full-time national servicemen (NSF) free access to over 75,000 online courses starting Nov 1. The platform, a tie-up between the Defence Ministry and NTUC LearningHub, includes courses in 135 categories such as programming, management, and digital photography, with some courses leading to credit exemptions at institutes of higher learning. The initiative aims to support NSF's transition to school or the workplace, with career and education fairs to be held four times a year.

site_title: 12 years' jail for man who fatally stabbed ex-girlfriend
summary: A 37-year-old Chinese national, Zheng Xianfeng, was sentenced to 12 years' jail for fatally stabbing his ex-girlfriend, Ms Tham Mee Yoke, 34, in February 2021 near her home in Jurong East, Singapore. The charge was reduced from murder to culpable homicide after Zheng was deemed to be suffering from major depressive disorder. Zheng had a history of violence, including a previous assault, and had attempted to reconcile with Ms Tham before the fatal attack.

site_title: Tiong Bahru Market surroundings to be pedestrian-friendly
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has made permanent changes to improve the walking experience around Tiong Bahru Market, including pedestrianizing a 60m stretch of Eng Hoon Street and widening the footpath in Seng Poh Road. Ramps will be built for barrier-free access. Other improvements include new loading and unloading bays and relocating the taxi stand. The changes aim to enhance the area's walkability, with residents praising the reduced traffic and increased safety. However, some businesses have seen a decline in customers due to the loss of parking spaces.

site_title: CPIB reviewing how to better recruit officers and retain veterans
summary: The Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) is reviewing its officer recruitment and retention strategies, considering aligning its retirement age with that of public service and strengthening professional development. The bureau is also leveraging technology to enhance its capabilities, launching a new platform called Command to better manage and evaluate corruption complaints. The platform uses natural language processing and machine-learning to assign a corruption risk score to complaints and provide data-led recommendations. Additionally, CPIB has launched a 472-page book documenting its anti-corruption journey and notable cases.

site_title: Sats confirms talks to buy world's largest air cargo handler
summary: Sats, a Singapore-listed catering and gateway services provider, confirmed talks to acquire Worldwide Flight Services, the world's largest air cargo handler, for a potential US$3 billion. The acquisition, if agreed, would add to the rising demand for logistics services as global travel resumes. Trading in Sats shares was halted pending an announcement, and the company's president, Kerry Mok, stated the company aims to capitalize on growth opportunities and broaden revenue streams.

site_title: Patients, doctors support pairing plan but some GPs have concerns
summary: Singapore is set to launch the Healthier SG programme in 2023, pairing patients with family physicians to provide holistic care and prevent illnesses. The programme aims to improve health outcomes, but some general practitioners (GPs) have concerns about the funding model, which may not account for variable fees tied to patient compliance with tests and procedures. GPs worry about the impact on their profit margins and ability to participate in the programme, but overall, they support the initiative, which they believe will lead to better patient-doctor relationships and health outcomes.

site_title: Counter-terrorism facility to boost regional cooperation
summary: Singapore has launched a counter-terrorism facility to enhance regional cooperation and share intelligence among South-East Asian nations. The facility, set up by the Ministry of Defence, aims to provide early warning against terrorism and synergise counter-terrorism efforts using collective intelligence and data. The threat of terrorism remains high and fluid, with Dr Ng Eng Hen stating that the facility's location in Changi will close the gap in regional intelligence and pre-empt terror attacks. The facility has produced timely intelligence products and assisted the region in the collective effort against terrorism.

site_title: Company Briefs : Voyager Digital JD Sports Fashion SGX
summary: Voyager Digital: Binance and FTX have submitted leading bids for assets of bankrupt crypto lender Voyager Digital, with Binance's bid at US$50 million and FTX's at slightly lower. JD Sports Fashion has agreed to pay former boss Peter Cowgill at least £5.5 million as part of an exit deal. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has launched its foreign exchange electronic communication network, SGX CurrencyNode, offering anonymous access to over-the-counter FX liquidity.

site_title: Australian RBA's equity wiped out by billions in bond losses
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) reported a net equity loss of A$12.4 billion due to mark-to-market valuation losses on pandemic-era bond holdings valued at A$44.9 billion. The losses, which eclipsed underlying earnings, were largely offset by the bank's ability to create money. The RBA's liabilities are guaranteed by the government, allowing it to continue operating normally. The bank expects to retain profits to rebuild its capital position and may not pay dividends for several years, eliminating the need for a government cash injection.

site_title: Global investors cut exposure to China on rising risks
summary: Global investors are rotating away from China due to rising risks, with many firms reassessing the country's rapidly changing environment. Despite long-term growth convictions, investors are paring their holdings in China's economy, which faces earnings pressure, regulatory scrutiny, and difficulties in going public overseas. Investors are seeking opportunities in other regions, including India, where they see a "buoyant" market driven by a supportive government, good investment policy, and realigned supply chains. This shift is not a retreat from Asia, with Singapore and India benefiting from the changes.

site_title: S'pore ranked most financially inclusive market in new survey
summary: Singapore has been ranked the most financially inclusive market in a new survey, ahead of the US, Sweden, Hong Kong, Britain, and Japan. The Global Financial Inclusion Index, compiled by Principal Financial Group and the Centre for Economics and Business Research, found that Singapore excelled in areas such as corporate tax system simplicity, online connectivity, and education levels. However, it scored lower on government-provided financial education and deposit insurance regulations. The survey highlights the need for continued improvement in these areas to maintain Singapore's status as a global financial hub.

site_title: S'pore students set off to take part in global competition that tests 60 skills
summary: Singapore's 29-member team is set to participate in the WorldSkills competition in Shanghai, which involves over 1,000 young people from 56 countries in 60 skill areas. The competition, initially cancelled due to Covid-19, will take place over 12 weeks. Education Minister Chan Chun Sing encouraged the participants to focus on personal growth and perseverance, emphasizing that surpassing oneself is more important than winning. Singapore's team, comprising representatives from five polytechnics, will compete in areas such as cyber security, fashion technology, and cloud computing.

site_title: Nasdaq in first big crypto push to draw institutional clients
summary: Nasdaq is launching a new group dedicated to digital assets, offering custody services for Bitcoin and Ether to institutional investors. The move is part of the exchange's effort to capitalize on increasing appetite for digital currencies among big-money investors. Nasdaq has hired Ira Auerbach, former head of prime broker services at Gemini, to lead the new unit. The company aims to build trust and brand in the market, with plans to develop other solutions such as execution and liquidity services. Nasdaq's cautious approach to the space has given way to embracing regulation, with a focus on building internally and hiring externally.

site_title: S. Korea's early exports edge up amid weakening global demand
summary: South Korea's early trade data showed exports growing 1.8% in the first 20 days of September, driven by a 3.4% increase in semiconductor sales. However, headline exports declined 8.7%, with a 14% drop in shipments to China. The slowdown in exports is attributed to weakening global demand due to the Russia-Ukraine war, Covid-19 outbreaks, and central bank policy tightening. Trade deficits widened to $4.1 billion, with Finance Minister Choo Kyung-ho warning of ongoing risks to exports, including cooling chip demand and volatility in energy prices.

site_title: Plunge in Europe's investments in China amid virus curbs, slowdown
summary: European corporate investment in China has plummeted, with greenfield investments from the EU and UK falling to $2 billion in the first half of the year, down from $4.8 billion in the same period last year. The decline is attributed to stringent "zero Covid-19" policies, lockdowns, and geopolitical tensions. A handful of German manufacturers, such as Volkswagen, continue to invest, but many others are reassessing their presence in China, with companies preferring other markets like South-east Asia and India.

site_title: Flying or release of unauthorised aerial objects banned during F1
summary: The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) has announced a temporary aerial ban over select areas in Singapore during the Formula One Singapore Airlines Singapore Grand Prix from September 29 to October 3. The ban, which will be in effect from 2.30pm to 10.30pm on September 29 and from 3pm to 12.30am on October 3, aims to ensure safety during helicopter aerial filming. Those found guilty of violating the ban can face fines up to $100,000 or jail terms of up to five years.

site_title: Qatar will be 'opening doors for all'
summary: Qatar's ruler, Sheikh Tamim Hamad al-Thani, has reassured the UN General Assembly that all fans attending the World Cup will be welcomed "without discrimination" this year. Despite homosexuality being illegal in the Gulf state, officials have battled to ease fears raised by LGBTQ activists. The Emir stated that Qatar's people will "open our doors for all" to enjoy the tournament, and FIFA has confirmed that LGBTQ rainbow flags will be allowed around stadiums. However, officials have emphasized that fans should respect local cultural norms, particularly regarding public displays of affection.

site_title: Despite struggles, cyclists' overseas stints 'invaluable'
summary: Singapore's overseas-based cyclists, such as national cyclist Chelsie Tan and Goh Choon Huat, face challenges competing with professional teams in Europe. Despite these struggles, the experience is considered invaluable, providing exposure to top athletes and training structures. The Singapore Cycling Federation's president, Hing Siong Chen, believes these stints help riders and coaches learn what it takes to compete at the world level, with lessons that can't be replicated in Singapore. This experience will aid the country's ambition to register a UCI men's continental team in the future.

site_title: Asia growth forecasts dim as Ukraine war, China lockdowns bite
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) cut its 2022 growth forecast for developing Asia to 4.3% due to global headwinds from the Ukraine war, China's Covid-19 lockdowns, and efforts to combat inflation. The region's growth is expected to be lower than previously forecast, with China's growth reduced to 3.3%. The ADB also raised its inflation forecast to 4.5% due to rising food and energy prices. The bank warned that "risks loom large" for the region's outlook, urging governments to remain vigilant.

site_title: Wall Street weakness, Fed rate hike weigh on regional stocks
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.2% on Wednesday, following regional weakness led by Wall Street's decline and a likely US interest rate hike. The Straits Times Index (STI) lost 5.15 points to 3,261.79, with losers outnumbering gainers 300 to 182. Other regional bourses, including Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index and Japan's Nikkei 225, also declined. The declines followed US indexes falling 1% overnight, and may be influenced by the size and rhetoric of the September US rate hike, which could give insight into the central bank's assessment of inflation risks.

site_title: Fed 'stopped believing' in comeback
summary: Roger Federer, a 41-year-old Swiss tennis icon, has expressed his desire to remain connected to the sport despite announcing his imminent retirement. Federer cited a persistent knee problem as the reason for his decision, stating he "stopped believing" in a comeback. He plans to participate in the Laver Cup, his final ATP event, and acknowledges a tough past three years, but is "happy to have taken the step" in announcing his retirement. Federer aims to stay connected to the sport without completely distancing himself from it.

site_title: Tencent's $3.2 billion buyback spree fails to stem stock rout
summary: Tencent Holdings' $3.2 billion buyback effort is failing to boost investor sentiment, with shares falling 60% from their 2021 peak. Despite spending nearly $2.3 billion on share repurchases, Tencent reported its first revenue decline in the second quarter due to China's economic slowdown and regulatory uncertainties. Major shareholder Prosus has sold 5.1 million shares, reducing its stake to 27.99%. Tencent is planning to divest more of its portfolio to fund buybacks and seek new growth drivers, adding uncertainty to China's tech sector.

site_title: Harvard report highlights rampant greenwashing online by major companies
summary: A Harvard report, commissioned by Greenpeace Netherlands, has exposed widespread greenwashing by major European companies on social media. Analyzing 2,300 posts by 22 fossil fuel companies, carmakers, and airlines, the report found that only 1 in 5 "green" car ads actually sell a product, while the rest promote the brand as green. Companies use tactics such as sports sponsorships, charity donations, and tokenistic diversity to distract from their core businesses and reduce their environmental impact. The report concludes that this "greenwashing" effort must be addressed with stricter regulations.

site_title: Time running out for England
summary: England manager Gareth Southgate is under pressure to restore his team's form ahead of the World Cup, having lost their last four games, including a humiliating 4-0 loss to Hungary. Several regular starters, including Manchester United players Harry Maguire and Luke Shaw, have seen their form dip, and players like Jadon Sancho and Marcus Rashford have been dropped. Southgate has called up injured players and recalled Eric Dier, hoping that Raheem Sterling and Harry Kane can provide firepower in attack and young midfielders can bring energy to the team.

site_title: Green S'pore well beaten
summary: Singapore's national football team, the Lions, suffered a 4-0 defeat against Vietnam in an international friendly match. The experimental side, featuring seven players with fewer than 15 caps, struggled to keep up with Vietnam's high-quality play. Despite a strong start, the Lions' loose defending and individual brilliance from Vietnam's players ultimately led to the defeat. Coach Takayuki Nishigaya expressed disappointment but acknowledged the opportunities provided to younger players, stating that the team needs to maintain concentration levels and minimize mistakes. The Lions will look to bounce back against India on Saturday.

site_title: Belgium new boy Debast starstruck by de Bruyne
summary: Belgium centre-back Zeno Debast has been called up to the national team for the first time, playing in the Nations League against Wales and the Netherlands. Debast, 18, has been starstruck by Manchester City's Kevin de Bruyne, saying he's adapting to playing alongside him. The young defender also praised teammate Jan Vertonghen for his guidance. Romelu Lukaku and Jeremy Doku will miss the matches due to injury, and Belgium will open their World Cup campaign against Canada on November 23.

site_title: Swiss 'go hard and finish hard'
summary: The Swiss cycling team, led by Stefan Bissegger and Marlen Reusser, won the time trial mixed relay at the Road World Championships with a time of 33min 47.17sec. Italy came second, 2.92sec behind, while Australia finished third. The Dutch team, including Olympic champion Annemiek van Vleuten, suffered a disastrous day after Van Vleuten crashed heavily during the event, finishing fifth. The Swiss team's strategy of "going hard and finishing hard" paid off, securing their victory in the inaugural world championship discipline since 2019.

site_title: LIV-PGA rivalry spicier than Presidents Cup
summary: The PGA Tour and LIV Golf are engaging in a bitter feud, with some players expressing interest in a hypothetical matchup between the two tours. However, it's unlikely that the rivalry will translate to a competitive golfing event, as the PGA Tour has nothing to gain from it. LIV Golf players have been labeled "sell-outs" for joining the circuit, which critics claim amounts to "sportswashing" by Saudi Arabia. The feud continues, with the two sides disagreeing over world ranking points and LIV Golf's eligibility for the rankings.

site_title: Be patient and and just wait for the Ideal Time
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

Key predictions include Divine Design to win the first race, Bavarian Jet to dominate the second, and Mansooriya to finish ahead of rivals in the third. Other notable predictions include Hilarity to win the fourth, Zatara Magic to show promise in the fifth, and Ideal Time to complete a hat-trick in the eighth. The article also highlights potential dark horses, such as Pinnacle in the sixth and Bold Strike in the eighth, and warns about unreliable types like Tamil Tiger and Rose of Bayeux.

site_title: Stable queue-up for Donna Logan's trio
summary: Donna Logan's trio dominated the final trial at Kranji, with Charminton winning by three parts of a length in 60.71 seconds. Legacy Fortune, ridden by Manoel Nunes, came in second, while Implement finished third. Charminton, ridden by Yusoff Fadzli, showed impressive form, with two wins and two seconds in four starts. Nunes, back from injury, also showed promise, and Legacy Fortune is expected to be a strong contender in upcoming races.

site_title: Glitzy Las Vegas set to take F1 'to the next level'
summary: Formula One has provisionally added a Las Vegas Grand Prix to its 2023 schedule, taking the total number of races to 24. The event, set for November 18, will be a floodlit race held on a 6.12km track along the Las Vegas Strip. Las Vegas joins Miami as the third US-based F1 event, with the US Grand Prix in Austin, Texas, also on the schedule. The circuit is still awaiting official approval from the International Automobile Federation.

site_title: Sports World: Ronaldo, 37, eyeing spot at Euro 2024
summary: Cristiano Ronaldo, 37, is aiming to participate in Euro 2024, saying his football journey is "not over yet" after being awarded top national team goalscorer of all time. South Africa plans to bid for the 2027 Women's World Cup, facing competition from other top bidders. The 2023 Ashes cricket series between England and Australia will begin on June 16, 2023, with the series concluding at The Oval on July 27.

site_title: Katak is out of cups, but yard is not KO-ed
summary: Trainer Ricardo Le Grange's horse Katak will not compete in the remaining season due to a fetlock injury sustained during a recent gallop. Despite this, Le Grange has two strong contenders for the upcoming Queen Elizabeth II Cup and Singapore Gold Cup: Senor Don and Hongkong Great. Senor Don, a six-year-old chestnut with a proven track record, will run on Saturday, while Hongkong Great will not compete in the same race but is expected to do well in a future event.

site_title: Exiled Russia omitted from Euro 2024 qualifying draw
summary: Russia will not participate in the Euro 2024 qualifying draw due to its suspension from international competitions following the invasion of Ukraine. The country's national team and clubs were banned by Uefa in February 2022, and the ban was later upheld by the Court of Arbitration for Sport. The 2024 European Championship will be hosted by Germany, with the qualifying draw taking place on October 9. Poland captain Robert Lewandowski has pledged to wear a Ukrainian armband at the World Cup to show solidarity with the war-torn country.

site_title: Football: Deschamps crossing fingers as injuries pile up ahead of France's matches
summary: France coach Didier Deschamps is dealing with a number of injury-related absences ahead of the World Cup, with over a dozen players missing for Nations League matches. Missing players include midfielder Paul Pogba, striker Karim Benzema, and defender Theo Hernandez. Deschamps attributes the injuries to the crowded schedule, saying it's a contact sport and intense matches put strain on the body. France faces an uphill task to stay in League A of the Nations League, currently bottom of Group 1 with two points from four matches.

site_title: Two-in-one jab for Covid-19 and flu could be available in late 2023: Moderna
summary: Moderna is developing a two-in-one jab for Covid-19 and flu, with phase one trials currently underway, and plans to have it available in late 2023. The mRNA platform allows for quick production and adaptation to new diseases, enabling the company to pivot and develop new vaccines rapidly. Moderna's Spikevax bivalent Covid-19 vaccine has received conditional authorisation in several countries, targeting two coronavirus variants, and is expected to arrive in Singapore at the end of September.

site_title: Cross Island Line phase 2: Excitement about new rail option but concerns linger over details, impact
summary: Singapore's Cross Island Line (CRL) phase 2 is set to provide greater public transport access to areas in the west, including West Coast and Clementi, with six new stations expected to open in 2032. The 15km rail stretch will include interchanges with existing lines, improving connectivity between eastern, western, and north-eastern parts of the city-state. However, concerns have been raised about the impact on traffic, construction-related disruptions, and potential gentrification, with some residents worried about increased rent and property prices.

site_title: Expect some loud cheers for Whispers Of War
summary: Thursday's S.A. (Turffontein) form analysis reveals promising horses for the day's races. Whispers Of War is expected to win in his new yard, while Don't Tell Ash, Regina Bellissima, and Treaty are contenders in the first race. Pyromaniac and Brenden James are favored in the second, while Var Park and Pendragon are strong contenders in the third. Brazilian Storm and Strange Magic are expected to perform well in the fourth, with Whispers Of War also a strong contender in the fifth. Bon Vivant and Quantum King are favored in the sixth, and Big Eyed Girl and Insatiable are expected to win in the seventh and eighth races, respectively.

site_title: Graft buster CPIB reviewing how to better recruit and retain talent
summary: The Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) is reviewing its scheme of service to better recruit and retain officers, considering measures such as aligning the retirement age with the public service and strengthening professional development. The agency is also leveraging technology with a new platform, Command, to manage and evaluate corruption complaints, assigning a corruption risk score to each complaint. The platform aims to provide faster resolution to complaints and better decision-making. Additionally, CPIB launched a 472-page history book, Scrupulous, Thorough, Fearless – The CPIB Story, documenting Singapore's anti-corruption journey and high-profile cases.

site_title: US stocks tumble after latest big Fed rate hike
summary: US stocks plummeted 1.7% on Wednesday after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates by 0.75 percentage points, its third consecutive hike, to combat inflation. The move, seen as more "hawkish" than expected, signals a prolonged monetary tightening cycle. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell to 30,183.78, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index declined 1.7% and 1.8% respectively. The Fed now expects higher interest rates through 2024, causing market volatility.

site_title: US Fed raises interest rates by 75 basis points, Powell signals more pain to come
summary: The US Federal Reserve raised interest rates by 75 basis points for the third consecutive time, with Chairman Jerome Powell signaling that officials will continue to take aggressive action to combat inflation. The benchmark federal funds rate was set at 3% to 3.25%, the highest level in 14 years. Powell predicted rates would reach 4.4% by the end of the year and 4.6% in 2023, and hinted at a possible fourth-straight 75 basis-point hike in November.

site_title: Track faults hit Bukit Panjang LRT, North-South Line
summary: A track fault on the Bukit Panjang LRT in Singapore caused service to run in only one direction on Wednesday evening. The fault, which occurred on the same day as a separate track fault on the North-South Line, was reportedly unrelated. Free regular bus services were activated between Yishun and Toa Payoh stations, but train services were restored by 7am. The track faults are part of an ongoing renewal of the line, with an interim arrangement in place until 2024.

site_title: Football: Neuer, Goretzka to miss Germans' Nations League games after positive Covid-19 tests
summary: Germany goalkeeper Manuel Neuer and midfielder Leon Goretzka will miss their Nations League matches against Hungary and England due to positive Covid-19 tests. Neuer and Goretzka will leave the team hotel, and Oliver Baumann will replace Neuer in goal. The German Football Association will make additional call-ups to fill the vacant spots. The team is preparing for the World Cup in Qatar, which starts in November, and the matches against Hungary and England are part of their Nations League preparations.

site_title: NSFs to get free unlimited access to 75,000 online courses to help prepare them for work or further studies
summary: The Singapore government has launched the SkillsFuture@NS Learning eXperience Platform, offering full-time national servicemen (NSFs) free unlimited access to over 75,000 online courses. The platform, a result of a tie-up between the Defence Ministry and Ministry of Home Affairs, aims to prepare NSFs for work or further studies. The platform will be available for two years, and courses include programming, management, and photography, with some leading to credit exemptions for polytechnics and universities.

site_title: Asian 'explosion' can ignite Internationals: Immelman
summary: A record five Asian players, including 2021 Masters champion Hideki Matsuyama, will join an event-high four South Koreans in the Internationals line-up at the Presidents Cup against the US team. The team's captain, Trevor Immelman, attributes the large Asian contingent to the rise of Asian golf, citing grassroots efforts and team bonding. Rookies Im Sung-jae and Kim Joo-hyung see this week as a potential milestone for Asian golf, with the potential to inspire others back home. The team hopes to pull off a shocking upset against the US team with 11 of the world's top 18 players.

site_title: Transnational cooperation vital in fighting borderless cyber scams: Faishal Ibrahim
summary: Singapore's Minister of State for Home Affairs and National Development Muhammad Faishal Ibrahim emphasized the need for transnational cooperation in combating borderless cyber scams, citing a 53% increase in reported cases in 2021 to over 24,000. Associate Professor Faishal highlighted the challenges of asset recovery and the importance of swift cross-border collaboration. He also raised concerns about terrorism and illicit drug trafficking in the region, citing the need for regional cooperation and counter-ideology efforts to prevent radical extremism and the potential risks of liberalizing cannabis policies.

site_title: Zheng, Zhang upset top seeds in Tokyo
summary: China celebrated a double triumph at the Pan Pacific Open in Tokyo, as 19-year-old Zheng Qinwen and 33-year-old Zhang Shuai stunned top seeds Paula Badosa and Caroline Garcia, respectively, in the round of 16. Zheng defeated world No. 4 Badosa 6-3, 6-2, while Zhang outlasted world No. 10 Garcia 4-6, 7-6 (7-5), 7-6 (7-5). The victories marked a significant upset, with both players advancing to the quarter-finals.

site_title: Edwards fined for homophobic language
summary: The NBA fined Minnesota Timberwolves guard Anthony Edwards $40,000 for using homophobic language in an Instagram video. Edwards apologized on Twitter, calling his remarks "immature, hurtful, and disrespectful." Hall of Famer Kareem Abdul-Jabbar criticized the apology, stating that Edwards should perform community service with LGBTQ+ organizations to show his support. The Timberwolves' president of basketball operations expressed disappointment, and the league has typically fined players for using profane or homophobic language, with some teams celebrating Pride nights to promote inclusivity.

site_title: Football: Lions thumped 4-0 by Vietnam in international friendly
summary: Singapore's national football team suffered a 4-0 defeat to Vietnam in an international friendly match. The inexperienced team, fielded by coach Takayuki Nishigaya, struggled with loose defending and individual brilliance from Vietnam's players. Vietnam's coach Park Hang-seo's side dominated the match, with four goals scored in the second half. Despite the loss, Nishigaya expressed optimism about the team's younger players, citing the importance of giving them international experience. The Lions will look to bounce back against India on Saturday.

site_title: S'pore ranked most financially inclusive market but needs to buck up in some areas: Survey
summary: Singapore ranked as the most financially inclusive market globally, according to a survey conducted by Principal Financial Group and the Centre for Economics and Business Research. The country scored highly in areas such as online connectivity and education levels, but received lower scores on government-provided financial education and regulations championing consumers. Despite this, Singapore's corporate tax system and fintech development were praised. The survey's findings highlight the country's efforts to boost financial inclusion as it seeks to grow its status as a global financial hub in Asia.

site_title: Prosecutors seek 3-year jail term for Laporte
summary: French prosecutors are seeking a 3-year prison sentence for Bernard Laporte, a former France rugby coach, for corruption and influence peddling. Laporte is accused of awarding a shirt sponsor contract to a close friend, Mohed Altrad, in exchange for €180,000. Prosecutors also claim he intervened in a disciplinary commission to reduce a fine against Altrad's company. Laporte's defence says the charges are "trumped up". The trial is nearing its close, with Laporte and Altrad potentially facing a 2-year ban from French rugby.

site_title: Relief doctor who gave undiluted Covid-19 vaccine at Hougang clinic was two weeks into job
summary: A relief doctor at the Prohealth Medical Group @ Hougang clinic in Singapore administered two full vials of undiluted Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine to two adults in September 2022, two weeks after starting work. The incident occurred on September 15 and prompted the clinic to stop engaging the doctor's services, while the clinic itself has been suspended from the National Vaccination Programme. The patients involved have received necessary support and assistance, and the clinic will cooperate fully with ongoing investigations. The clinic has apologized for the incident and assures patients of their utmost care.

site_title: Cycling: Partnership with pro teams helps cyclists, coaches develop, says SCF chief
summary: Singapore's cycling chief, Dr Hing Siong Chen, believes the country's overseas-based cyclists, such as Chelsie Tan and Goh Choon Huat, gain valuable experience competing at the world level. Despite struggling to make a mark with professional teams, Tan and others return to Singapore with valuable exposure to top athletes and training structures. Dr Hing notes that these experiences are invaluable for developing the country's cycling program, including its ambition to register a UCI men's continental team by 2023.

site_title: TikTok to ban politicians from raising funds, selling merchandise on its platform
summary: TikTok has announced plans to ban politicians from raising funds and selling merchandise on its platform, effective in a few weeks globally. This move aims to prevent misinformation and polarization, strengthening the platform's existing ban on political advertising. The changes will limit politicians' ability to give or receive money through TikTok's monetization features and spend money promoting content. Experts say this may impact opposition parties, but also promote a more positive environment on the platform, giving users fairer access to content.

site_title: Iconic landmarks in S'pore lit in purple and yellow to mark World Alzheimer's Day
summary: Singapore's five iconic landmarks - The Esplanade, Singapore Flyer, Marina Bay Sands, National Stadium, and National Gallery Singapore - were illuminated in purple and yellow on September 21, 2022, to mark World Alzheimer's Day. The light-up was a show of solidarity to raise awareness for dementia and Alzheimer's disease, and to support those impacted by it. The campaign was organized by Dementia Singapore, with various community bodies also holding activities throughout September to bring attention to the condition and support caregivers.

site_title: Football: Ballon d'Or adds Socrates award for players who tackle social issues
summary: The Ballon d'Or organisers are adding a humanitarian prize, named after Brazilian midfielder Socrates, to this year's ceremony. The Socrates Prize will recognize players who tackle social issues, such as social integration, environmental protection, and aid to disadvantaged groups. The prize will be awarded by a jury that includes Socrates' brother, Rai, and representatives of France Football and Peace and Sport. The ceremony will be held in Paris on October 17, with the first winner to be announced. This move aims to highlight the power of sports to transform society and promote a more just world.

site_title: Patients, doctors support Healthier SG pairing plan but some GPs have concerns
summary: Singapore's Healthier SG programme aims to pair residents with family physicians to manage their health holistically and prevent illnesses. Patients and doctors generally support the initiative, citing benefits such as better patient-doctor relationships and more effective disease prevention. However, some general practitioners (GPs) have expressed concerns over the proposed funding model, which ties payment to patient compliance with recommended tests and procedures. GPs worry that the reduced profit margin from medication sales will impact their ability to participate, prompting calls for a revised funding model to ensure their buy-in.

site_title: Tennis: China's Zheng Qinwen reaches Tokyo q-finals after defeating top seed Badosa
summary: Chinese tennis player Zheng Qinwen defeated top seed Paula Badosa 6-3, 6-2 in the Tokyo q-finals, advancing to the next round. The 19-year-old Zheng, ranked 36th, overcame a tough opponent and said her win was "not a surprise" as she believed she had the level to compete. Zheng will face either Elise Mertens or Claire Liu in the quarter-finals, while Badosa was eliminated after losing to Zhang Shuai in the previous round.

site_title: LTA to make area around Tiong Bahru Market more pedestrian-friendly
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) plans to make permanent changes to improve the walking experience around Tiong Bahru Market in Singapore. The changes include pedestrianising a 60m stretch of Eng Hoon Street, widening the footpath along Seng Poh Road, and building ramps for barrier-free access. Other improvements include new loading and unloading bays and moving the taxi stand closer to the market entrance. The LTA expects to begin works in October, following a successful six-month trial that saw a reduction in traffic congestion and an increase in pedestrian usage.

site_title: Man who drove van along a park connector pavement for 1.2km gets jail
summary: A Singaporean van driver, Muhammad Ibrahim Abdullah, was sentenced to 6 days' jail for driving in a rash manner, endangering human life, after falling asleep at the wheel and running a red light. He drove 1.2km on a park connector pavement before waking up to a passer-by, who alerted the police. Ibrahim had pleaded guilty and was also disqualified from holding driving licenses for 15 months. No pedestrians were injured, but the incident was deemed fortunate to have had no casualties.

site_title: Science Centre's flagship Young Scientist Badge programme turns 40: Over 1m badges awarded to pupils
summary: The Science Centre Singapore's flagship Young Scientist Badge programme is celebrating its 40th anniversary, having awarded over 1 million badges to primary school pupils since 1982. Three new badges, Marie Curie, Margaret Fountaine, and Young Fabricator, have been launched, introducing science to students in a real and relatable way, promoting initiative and creativity through hands-on learning. The programme aims to provide novel solutions to challenges, with STEM education critical for Singapore's younger generation.

site_title: Jail for man who took upskirt video of teen while they were with their friends
summary: A 21-year-old man in Singapore was sentenced to 18 weeks in jail for taking upskirt videos of 54 women, including a 19-year-old teen, while they were with friends at MRT stations. The offender pleaded guilty to three voyeurism charges after his phone was searched and videos of other victims were found. The crimes occurred between January 2021 and July 2021. The offender, who did not have a lawyer, claimed he was attempting to change his behavior and take on leadership roles.

site_title: Cheaper drugs at GPs under Healthier SG 'one resident, one doctor' scheme to be launched in 2023
summary: Singapore's Healthier SG Programme aims to launch in 2023 with one family physician and one health plan for each resident aged 60 and above, offering cheaper drugs for chronic diseases at general practitioner clinics. The programme, which focuses on preventive care, will provide a holistic approach to health management, including diet adjustments, exercise regimens, and regular health screenings. Residents will be able to join free programmes to keep fit, and drug prices at participating GP clinics will be made comparable with those at polyclinics through enhanced subsidies and price limits.

site_title: Hair used to make new material that helps grow vegetables through hydroponics
summary: Researchers from Nanyang Technological University in Singapore have developed a new material using keratin extracted from human hair to support hydroponic vegetable growth. The keratin-based substrate was found to be comparable in yield to commercially available ones. The material is biodegradable, can absorb and retain large quantities of water, and can become a source of nutrients for plants when it degrades. The team plans to conduct large-scale field tests with local urban farms and is working to reduce production costs. The research aims to provide a sustainable and eco-friendly alternative to traditional hydroponic substrates.

site_title: Clean, honest government has been vital to S'pore's progress: President Halimah
summary: Singapore's strong stance against corruption has been a key factor in the country's progress, according to President Halimah Yacob. A clean and honest government has been a major competitive advantage, allowing businesses to flourish and citizens to have equal opportunities. The country's low-corruption status was recognized globally, with Singapore ranking fourth out of 180 countries in Transparency International's list of least corrupt nations. President Halimah emphasized the importance of maintaining trust in the system, citing the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) as a crucial institution in protecting the integrity of the public service.

site_title: askST: How will being paired with a GP under the Healthier SG programme benefit me?
summary: Singapore's Healthier SG programme, set to launch in 2023, will pair residents aged 60 and above with a dedicated family physician under the Healthier SG programme, shifting the country's healthcare model towards prevention. Residents will receive a free initial consultation, and a personalized health plan will be created. The programme will offer subsidised health screenings, vaccinations, and remote check-ups. Care protocols will be developed for managing chronic conditions, and residents can switch doctors up to four times in the first two years. The programme aims to prevent or delay the onset of chronic diseases and ill health, with incentives such as health points for physical activity and diet adherence.

site_title: Football: Qatar planning for World Cup fans to avoid prosecution for minor offences: Sources
summary: Qatar plans to show leniency towards minor offenses, such as public drunkenness, for World Cup fans, allowing them to avoid prosecution. However, fans committing more serious offenses, like using flares or being involved in fights, can expect fines and cancellation of their permit to enter Qatar and access stadiums. The approach aims to balance respecting local traditions with accommodating visiting fans, but has raised concerns among some diplomats and Western officials.

site_title: Football: Pilot in crash that killed Argentinian Sala said plane was 'dodgy': BBC
summary: A pilot flying a plane that crashed in the English Channel, killing Argentinian footballer Emiliano Sala in 2019, had previously complained about the aircraft being "dodgy". The pilot, David Ibbotson, described the plane as having a faulty exhaust system and a non-working brake pedal. An inquest ruled that Sala inhaled toxic levels of carbon monoxide from the faulty exhaust system, leading to his death. The pilot's concerns were ignored, and he was sentenced to 18 months in prison for hiring an unqualified pilot and carrying a passenger without authorization.

site_title: Football: Brentford's Mbeumo among those hoping to shine after switching national teams
summary: Bryan Mbeumo, a Brentford forward, is among several African footballers hoping to impress by switching national teams for the 2022 World Cup. Five African qualifiers, including Cameroon, Ghana, Morocco, Senegal, and Tunisia, play two warm-up matches each. Players like Tariq Lamptey and Inaki Williams are taking advantage of a FIFA rule to represent their African birth countries. The African teams face tough opponents, including Brazil and Chile, in the lead-up to the World Cup, which starts on November 20.

site_title: Health Check Podcast: Take charge of your health with Healthier SG
summary: Singapore's government is launching "Healthier SG", a national preventive care strategy aiming to shift focus from sick care to preventive care. The plan, set to launch in mid-2023, will provide capitation funding and encourage family doctors to enroll in the system. The strategy includes free health screenings and vaccinations, digital tools, and incentives to promote healthier living. The goal is to help Singapore's rapidly ageing population stay healthy longer, with initial focus on those aged 60 and above, followed by those aged 40-59 in the next two years.

site_title: Football: Hiddink says Australia are fit and ready to fight as World Cup looms
summary: Legendary coach Guus Hiddink has expressed confidence in Australia's readiness for the World Cup, describing the team as "fresh" and "fit" after working alongside coach Graham Arnold. Hiddink, who led Australia to the last 16 in 2006, has been helping out in Arnold's absence, urging the team to play "football in an attacking way." The two coaches will face New Zealand in a friendly match in Brisbane on Thursday, before the team's final home game against New Zealand on Sunday.

site_title: Woman who stabbed herself outside school charged with possession of 2 weapons
summary: A 53-year-old woman, Juliana Abdul Kadir, was charged with possession of two weapons, a 21cm-long knife and a 13cm penknife blade, outside St Hilda's Secondary School in Tampines on September 19. She had a stand-off with police, stabbed herself in the abdomen, and threatened to harm herself. Juliana was tasered and taken to hospital, where she is currently undergoing psychiatric observation. Her case has been adjourned to October 12, with potential jail time and caning for possession of weapons.

site_title: Football: KFC France distances itself from executive's comments on Mbappe's sponsorship stance
summary: KFC France has distanced itself from comments by senior executive Alain Beral, who suggested the company may take legal action over Kylian Mbappe's refusal to participate in sponsorship commitments. Beral's comments, made after Mbappe skipped a team photo shoot and sponsor activities, were later clarified as personal opinions not reflecting the company's views. KFC France reiterated its support for the French Football Federation and confidence in finding solutions for all partners and players, including Mbappe, whose supporters are among the company's first in France.

site_title: Netball: Jamaica draft 54-year-old for Test match against New Zealand
summary: Jamaica's netball team, the "Sunshine Girls," has drafted a 54-year-old local nurse, Carla Borrego, and a recent mother, Romelda Aiken-George, to play against New Zealand due to visa delays. Five players were unable to arrive in New Zealand, leaving the team short-handed. The team's head coach, Connie Francis, issued an SOS to former players, including two Australia-based veterans, to fill the gaps. The unusual team composition has drawn criticism from netball officials, who expect a financial hit from the revamped scheduling. Jamaica's team will play without reserves in the two-match series.

site_title: Asia LNG prices stabilise as China expands imports of cheap Russian supply
summary: China's imports of Russian LNG reached 671,105 tonnes in August, close to a two-year high, stabilizing Asia's LNG prices due to the country's preference for cheap Russian supply over global market prices. China's indifference to Western sanctions has allowed it to take advantage of Moscow's desperation to sell energy exports at discounted prices, keeping global prices capped. Experts expect China to expand its purchases of Russian LNG, with prices estimated to remain elevated due to high demand and a hungry Europe.

site_title: Germany nationalises gas giant Uniper to avert winter energy collapse
summary: Germany nationalizes Uniper, its largest gas importer, to prevent a winter energy collapse. The government will invest €8 billion and take control of the company, which has accumulated €8.5 billion in gas-related losses due to Russia's supply cut-off. The move aims to secure energy supply for companies, municipalities, and consumers, as temperatures are expected to fall heading into winter. The nationalization package, including loans, is estimated to cost the government around €30 billion.

site_title: Cross Island Line poised to transform existing and new estates such as Jurong, Turf City into vibrant hubs
summary: The second stage of Singapore's MRT Cross Island Line (CRL) is set to transform the west into vibrant hubs. The 15km stretch will feature six stations in areas like Clementi, West Coast, and King Albert Park. This follows the successful completion of the first 12-station 29km stage announced three years ago. The new development is expected to bring cheer to residents and future movers in the region, enhancing connectivity and accessibility.

site_title: Golf: It's LIV players' fault that they don't get world ranking points: Thomas
summary: Golfers from LIV Golf, a breakaway tour backed by Saudi Arabia, are fighting for world ranking points after sending a letter to the Official World Golf Ranking (OWGR) organization. However, top-ranked players like Cameron Smith and Dustin Johnson are plummeting down the rankings, making it harder to qualify for major championships. Justin Thomas disagrees with LIV players, saying they should have known the risks of not receiving world ranking points and taking the decision to join the breakaway tour. The OWGR has not yet agreed to include LIV in the rankings system.

site_title: 12 years' jail for man who fatally stabbed ex-girlfriend in Jurong East
summary: A 37-year-old Chinese national, Zheng Xianfeng, was sentenced to 12 years' jail for fatally stabbing his ex-girlfriend, Ms Tham Mee Yoke, 34, in Jurong East in 2021. Zheng pleaded guilty to culpable homicide after a violent altercation, leaving Ms Tham with 29 stab and slash wounds and three rib fractures. The court reduced the original murder charge due to Zheng's major depressive disorder, but he was still found guilty of a serious offence.

site_title: Sats said to be in talks to buy Worldwide Flight Services
summary: Sats, a Singapore-listed catering and gateway services provider, is in talks to acquire air cargo handler Worldwide Flight Services. The potential buy is valued at around US$3 billion, with financing options being explored. Worldwide Flight Services, owned by private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management, operates in over 160 major airports worldwide. The acquisition, pending agreement, could be announced in the coming weeks. This deal would follow recent acquisitions in the logistics sector, driven by rising demand for services as global travel resumes.
