site_title: COE prices for car categories down in latest tender; premium for motorcycles hits new high of $11,589
summary: Singapore's latest COE tender results show a mixed picture, with commercial vehicle COE prices up and motorcycle COE premiums hitting a new record of $11,589. Car COE categories for smaller vehicles and fully electric vehicles saw a decrease in premiums, with prices down 2.3% and 4.4% respectively. Commercial vehicle COE premiums rose 3.1% and open category COEs decreased by 5.4%. The high COE prices are expected to impact businesses and individuals, with motorcycle buyers opting for longer loan contracts and car dealers advertising lower prices to attract buyers.

site_title: Lawyer charged over hit-and-run accident that injured biker
summary: A 49-year-old lawyer, Gregory John Fong Mun Yung, was charged with causing grievous hurt and failing to stop after a hit-and-run accident involving a motorcyclist on June 13, 2021. The 42-year-old rider suffered serious injuries. Fong allegedly drove away from the scene without rendering assistance. He faces charges of causing grievous hurt while driving dangerously and failing to stop after an accident, with potential jail sentences ranging from one to 10 years and fines up to $2,000. The case has been adjourned to October 12.

site_title: Singapore remains committed to the UN's open, inclusive and rules-based ideals: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong reaffirmed the country's commitment to the UN's open, inclusive, and rules-based ideals, 57 years after Singapore's membership. The 77th session of the UN General Assembly kicked off, with leaders from over 150 countries attending in-person meetings for the first time in three years. Amid global challenges like climate change and rising tensions, PM Lee emphasized the importance of institutions like the UN, providing a platform for countries to build a stable international environment. Singapore will continue to support the UN and engage in bilateral meetings and other events.

site_title: Aerial activity restrictions imposed during F1 Singapore Grand Prix: CAAS
summary: The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) has imposed aerial activity restrictions during the Formula One Singapore Airlines Singapore Grand Prix from Sept 29 to Oct 3 to ensure the safety of helicopters conducting aerial filming. Temporary restricted areas include Marina Bay, Central Business district, and other areas, extending from ground level to 4,000 ft above mean sea level. The ban will be in effect from 2.30pm to 10.30pm from Sept 29 to Oct 3, with violators facing fines up to $50,000 or imprisonment for up to five years.

site_title: Lian Beng declines disclosing family members' pay, citing poaching fears
summary: Lian Beng Group has declined a Singapore Exchange (SGX) request to disclose the remuneration of five employees deemed family members of a director or substantial shareholder. The company cited concerns that disclosure could lead to "inappropriate peer comparison" and provide an advantage to competitors. SGX is increasing its push for remuneration transparency, with only 35% of companies disclosing director pay and 18% disclosing CEO pay in dollar value. Lian Beng's shares traded flat at 54 cents following the request.

site_title: South Korea early exports edge higher amid weakening global demand
summary: South Korea's early trade data shows exports growing 1.8% on average in the first 20 days of September, with headline exports dropping 8.7% led by a 14% decline in shipments to China. Semiconductor sales increased 3.4%. The slowdown in exports is attributed to weakening global demand due to Russia's war on Ukraine, Covid-19 outbreaks in China, and central bank policy tightening. Trade deficits remain a concern, with a US$4.1 billion deficit so far this month, and risks to exports persist due to cooling chip demand and volatile energy prices.

site_title: European interest in China investments falling sharply
summary: European corporate investment in China has sharply declined, with only a handful of multinationals remaining, according to new reports. The real estate market is slumping, consumer spending is drying up due to lockdowns, and American investment is faltering due to geopolitical tensions. European investment in greenfield projects has dropped to just under $2 billion in the first half of the year, with only a few German manufacturers like Volkswagen continuing to invest. The European Chamber of Commerce in China has expressed frustration with China's strict travel policies and recommends easing restrictions to revive foreign investment.

site_title: Australian central bank's equity wiped out by billions in bond losses
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has taken a mark-to-market valuation loss of A$44.9 billion on its bond holdings, eclipsing underlying earnings of A$8.2 billion. The losses were incurred during the pandemic-era A$300 billion emergency stimulus program. Despite the losses, the RBA remains solvent due to its ability to create money, and its liabilities are guaranteed by the government. The central bank expects to retain future profits to rebuild its capital position and will not require a cash injection from the government.

site_title: Oil jumps after Putin orders partial mobilisation in Ukraine
summary: Oil prices surged after Russian President Vladimir Putin ordered a partial mobilization in Ukraine, potentially escalating the conflict and disrupting energy supplies. Crude oil jumped 2.6% to $86.12 a barrel and Brent crude rose 2.54% to $92.92. The move could lead to further supply disruptions, supporting oil prices. The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates, which could impact oil demand, while a tough European winter may lead to gas-to-oil switching, maintaining strong oil demand in the medium term.

site_title: Global investors cut exposure to China on rising risks
summary: Global investors are reducing their exposure to China due to rising risks, despite long-term growth convictions. The country's economic pillars face earnings pressure, regulatory scrutiny, and difficulties going public overseas. Investors are diversifying to other regions, such as India, and firms are adjusting their portfolios accordingly. Despite this, the region's growth is expected to continue, with India experiencing a "buoyant" market and Singapore benefiting from the shift. The rotation away from China highlights the opportunities in other Asian economies.

site_title: Safety time-out deadline for firms in high-risk sectors extended to Sept 30: MOM
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) in Singapore has extended the safety time-out deadline for companies in high-risk sectors from Sept 15 to Sept 30. This is due to feedback from industries that require more time to review and comply with the mandatory safety procedures. The affected sectors include construction, manufacturing, and transportation industries, among others. Companies must complete the safety time-out activities before the new deadline, or face compliance checks and potential debarment actions. This comes amid a rise in work-related deaths and injuries, with 37 fatalities reported in 2022.

site_title: Asia stocks fall, bond yields rise as markets brace for aggressive Fed rate hike
summary: Asia stocks fell, with Japan's Nikkei down 1.26%, Australia's benchmark share index 1.35% lower, and South Korea's Kospi 0.9% off. Bond yields rose globally, with the US two-year Treasury yield hitting a 15-year high at 3.992%. Markets expect an 81% chance of a 75-basis-point Fed rate hike, with the US dollar index edging higher. Crude oil prices declined, falling 26 cents to $90.36 a barrel, amid concerns of growth curbing demand.

site_title: 4% interest floor rate on CPF Special, MediSave and Retirement accounts extended to end-2023
summary: The Singapore Government has extended the 4% interest floor rate on CPF Special, MediSave, and Retirement accounts until December 31, 2023. The rates were pegged to market instruments of comparable risk and duration to ensure fair returns. Members below 55 years old will continue to earn interest rates of up to 3.5% per annum, while those aged 55 and above will earn up to 6% per annum. The extension aims to help CPF members grow their savings consistently.

site_title: Football: Qatar emir says no 'discrimination' in bid to ease World Cup doubts
summary: Qatar's emir, Sheikh Tamim Hamad al-Thani, assured the UN General Assembly that all World Cup fans will be welcomed "without discrimination" in a bid to ease concerns from LGBTQ activists. Despite homosexuality being illegal in the Gulf state, Qatar aims to provide a welcoming atmosphere for fans from all walks of life. FIFA has reaffirmed that LGBTQ rainbow flags will be allowed around stadiums, and the organizing committee emphasizes respecting local cultural norms while welcoming everyone. The emir's statement comes as Qatar prepares to host the World Cup starting on November 20.

site_title: Counter-terrorism facility opens in S'pore to boost regional cooperation, info sharing
summary: Singapore has opened a counter-terrorism facility to enhance regional cooperation and information sharing among South-east Asian countries. The Counter-Terrorism Information Facility, established by the Ministry of Defence, allows countries to share intelligence and provide early warnings against terrorism. Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen said the threat of terrorism remains high and fluid, and the facility's location in Changi is crucial for synergizing counter-terrorism efforts. The facility has produced timely intelligence products and assisted the region in the collective effort against terrorism. Its establishment aims to close the gap in regional intelligence and pre-empt terror attacks.

site_title: Checks in place to verify fund-raiser when permit for such activities by charities scrapped
summary: Singapore charities no longer require a police permit to raise funds in public from 2023. To verify a charity's legitimacy, donors can use clear identification such as an official letter or contact information, or check the Commissioner of Charities' (COC) SMS and hotline verification services. Charities must disclose details of their fund-raising campaigns on the Charity Portal. The move aims to reduce administrative burden and make fund-raising easier, while ensuring donors can give safely. The COC will provide more details by the end of the year.

site_title: Tencent's $3.2 billion buyback spree fails to stem stock rout
summary: Tencent Holdings, China's largest company by market capitalization, has spent nearly $1 billion in repurchasing shares over the past month, but its efforts to stem the decline of its stock price have failed. Tencent's shares are down over 60% from their peak in January 2021, with the company reporting its first-ever revenue decline in the second quarter. Major shareholder Prosus has sold over 5 million shares, reducing its ownership to 27.9%. Tencent is planning to divest more of its equity portfolio to fund buybacks and seek new growth drivers, adding to uncertainties in China's tech sphere.

site_title: Rugby: Prosecutors seek jail time for French federation boss Bernard Laporte in graft trial
summary: Prosecutors in France are seeking a three-year prison sentence for Bernard Laporte, the former France rugby coach, in a graft trial. Laporte is accused of favoritism in awarding a shirt sponsor contract to a close friend, Mohed Altrad, and intervening with a disciplinary commission to reduce a fine against Altrad's company. Laporte and Altrad's friendship and business links are at the heart of the case, which dates back to 2017. The trial concludes on Thursday, with Laporte facing a possible two-year ban from French rugby.

site_title: Tennis: Roger Federer says he wants to remain involved in the game after retirement
summary: Roger Federer, a 20-time Grand Slam winner, wants to remain involved in tennis after retirement, despite announcing his imminent exit last week. The 41-year-old cited knee problems as the reason for his decision, stating he was "relieved" and "happy" to have had the career he did. Federer acknowledged he was "on thin ice" for the last year, but couldn't continue playing due to his knee issues. He expressed gratitude to those who helped him throughout his career and plans to stay connected to the sport, although no specific future plans have been announced.

site_title: ADB cuts Singapore, Asia growth forecasts as China lockdowns bite
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) cut its 2022 growth forecast for developing Asia to 4.3%, citing crippling Covid-19 lockdowns in China, conflict in Ukraine, and efforts to combat inflation. Singapore's growth forecast was also lowered to 3.7% from 4.3%, while China's forecast was reduced to 3.3% due to its zero-Covid-19 strategy. The ADB warned of "global headwinds" to the region's recovery and urged governments to remain vigilant, citing risks of a significant downturn in the world economy and financial instability.

site_title: Safeguards in place when fund-raiser permits are scrapped
summary: Singapore to scrap police permits for charities to raise funds in public from 2023. Charities will need to disclose details of their fund-raising campaigns on the Charity Portal and carry clear identification, such as an official letter from the charity. The move aims to reduce administrative burden and increase transparency, with safeguards in place to protect donors. Charities must verify the legitimacy of their fund-raising activities through SMS and hotline services.

site_title: S'pore Customs raids largest complex of car importers, dealerships
summary: Singapore Customs raided Carros Centre, a 2.3 million sq ft complex housing multiple car importers and dealerships, on September 2. The raid was part of an inspection at a licensed warehouse facility at 60 Jalan Lam Huat in the Sungei Kadut area. The exact reasons for the raid are not specified, but it has sparked discussion in the motor industry.

site_title: 'Rampant' greenwashing by major companies on social media: Harvard report
summary: A Harvard report found that major companies, including carmakers, fossil fuel producers, and airlines, engage in widespread "greenwashing" on social media. Two-thirds of their posts presented a "green innovation" image, while one in five "green" car ads promoted a product for sale, and one in five posts by oil companies focused on social causes to divert attention from their core businesses. The report highlights tokenistic use of minorities and nature imagery to create a misleading perception of sustainability.

site_title: Woman with schizophrenia acquitted of murdering daughter, 8
summary: A 36-year-old woman with schizophrenia was acquitted of murdering her 8-year-old daughter, who was stabbed 76 times after the woman heard voices telling her the girl was an evil spirit. The woman was found to be of unsound mind at the time of the killing and will be confined indefinitely. The court ruled that the woman's schizophrenia had gone untreated for several years, causing her to experience a distorted state of mind. The woman will be subject to regular reviews on her mental state before possible discharge.

site_title: Binance, FTX make top bids for bankrupt crypto lender Voyager: Report
summary: Binance and FTX have made top bids for assets of bankrupt crypto lender Voyager Digital, with Binance's offer at around US$50 million, slightly higher than FTX's. Both exchanges have been relatively unaffected by the crypto winter, unlike companies like Coinbase and BlockFi. Voyager, a crypto lender that boomed during the pandemic, filed for bankruptcy after struggling with market downturns. FTX had previously proposed a bailout but was rejected by Voyager, which is now considering Binance's bid.

site_title: Singapore looking at how future gas plants can affect net-zero target
summary: Singapore's Energy Market Authority (EMA) is studying how future gas plants could impact the country's net-zero emissions target by 2050. As 23% of the nation's power generation capacity, set to reach the end of its lifespan in the next 5 years, will be replaced, EMA aims to understand the potential emissions intensity of new natural gas technologies. The industry regulator emphasizes the need for a phased approach to decarbonize the power sector, with strategies including intensifying research in cleaner energy sources and improving gas-fired power generation efficiency.

site_title: Football: Poland skipper Lewandowski will wear Ukraine captain's armband in Qatar
summary: Poland captain Robert Lewandowski will wear the Ukrainian captain's armband at the World Cup in Qatar. The symbolic armband was presented to him by Ukraine coach Andriy Shevchenko, who expressed the country's resilience in the face of war. Lewandowski expressed his honor in carrying the armband, while Shevchenko stated that the gesture is a message to the world, showing Ukraine's determination to never give up. Poland will face Argentina, Saudi Arabia, and Mexico in Group C.

site_title: Must-reads
summary: The Cross Island MRT Line phase two alignment has been announced, with six new stations from Turf City to Jurong Lake District, set to begin construction in 2023 and open by 2032. UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres urged wealthy nations to tax fossil fuel firms to compensate for climate damage. A stage 4 lung cancer patient, Elden Yee, has climbed Mount Kinabalu, inspiring his doctor to form a stair-climbing group for lung cancer patients. Digital banking services are now considered the baseline for banks, according to DBS Bank.

site_title: Two given full vials of undiluted Covid-19 vaccine at Hougang clinic
summary: A hospitalised patient in Singapore received a full vial of undiluted Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine at a Hougang clinic, prompting a serious investigation by the Ministry of Health. The patient, one of two individuals given the vaccine, experienced a headache and increased heart rate and has since been discharged. The clinic and doctor involved have been suspended from the National Vaccination Programme until further notice. This incident follows previous cases of incorrect vaccine dosages being administered, including a 2021 incident at the Singapore National Eye Centre and another at Bukit Merah Polyclinic.

site_title: Integrated depot slated to be ready in 2025; structural works 75% done
summary: Singapore's largest train and bus depot, the East Coast Integrated Depot, is 75% complete with structural works expected to be finished by 2025. The facility will house 220 trains from three MRT lines and provide parking for 760 buses, saving 44ha of land equivalent to 60 football fields. The four-in-one setup optimizes natural lighting and ventilation and features green features like solar panels. The depot's innovative design allows for shared foundations, columns, and facilities, freeing up land for housing and commercial uses, according to Transport Minister S. Iswaran.

site_title: Cleaning up after death
summary: Trauma cleaner Mr Rahman Razali, 40, cleans up remains of decomposed bodies, often dealing with seniors who die alone. He recalls a case where he had to hack away contaminated flooring in a condominium unit after a middle-aged man died without being discovered for three months. Rahman, who owns DDQ Services, deals with 80% of cases involving the elderly, who are increasingly living alone due to the ageing population. His team of four, including his 18-year-old daughter, dignify the space, clean, and dispose of contaminated belongings, charging between $2,000 and $4,000 per assignment.

site_title: US stocks end with steep declines
summary: US stocks experienced steep declines on Tuesday as the Federal Reserve opened its two-day policy meeting, with Fed officials vowing to raise interest rates to combat soaring inflation. A possible three-quarter-point interest rate hike was widely expected, with some speculating about a one-percentage-point move. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index all dropped, with the Dow falling 1%, the S&P 500 losing 1.1%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index sinking 1%.

site_title: DBS' net-zero plan wins praise but faces challenges
summary: DBS, a regional bank, has set a clear goal to reach net-zero financed emissions by 2050, becoming the first bank to do so. The bank aims to reduce carbon emissions from major polluting industries it lends to, and will work with clients to drive low-carbon investments and reduce fossil fuel reliance. This move is seen as a major step towards tackling climate change, but faces challenges in achieving its ambitious target.

site_title: Diesel prices down by 11-12 cents, petrol cheaper by 6-19 cents
summary: Fuel pump prices in Singapore have decreased, with diesel prices falling 11-12 cents to $2.76-$2.77 per litre and petrol prices falling 6-19 cents to $2.77-$2.81 per litre. The adjustments follow a decline in oil and wholesale fuel prices amid global recession fears. Petrol prices are now at their lowest since February, with the exception of premium-grade 98-octane, which remains 19 cents higher than the regular 98-octane.

site_title: Canned, bottled drinks may cost 10 to 20 cents more in recycling scheme
summary: Singapore to introduce a 10-20 cent deposit on canned and bottled drinks, with consumers able to redeem the deposit by returning empty containers to designated recycling points. Over 400 return points will be set up nationwide, including supermarkets and community centers. The goal is to increase recycling rates of beverage containers to 80% and follows a similar model used in Germany, where the recycling rate stands at 98%. The deposit will be refunded in cash or digitally, and producers and retailers will be charged a fee for each drink manufactured or imported.

site_title: Firms that help staff grow can retain talent better: Panel
summary: Companies that invest in internal growth opportunities for their staff tend to retain talent for over five years, compared to an average of under three years for those that struggle. A 2022 LinkedIn report found 40% of companies are considering skills over traditional credentials when hiring. Industry leaders such as Sir James Dyson and Singtel's Yuen Kuan Moon emphasized the importance of continuous learning and adaptability in the modern workforce. To retain talent, companies must provide a sense of purpose and growth opportunities, as traditional jobs evolve and new ones emerge.

site_title: 4th agricultural revolution needed to cut greenhouse gas emissions: Nobel laureate
summary: Nobel laureate Steven Chu emphasizes the need for a fourth agricultural revolution to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, citing the sector's significant contribution to global emissions. The previous agricultural revolutions, which focused on domestication and fertilizers, have unintended consequences such as fertilizer runoff and methane emissions from cow burps. Chu proposes solutions like microbes that can reduce fertilizer use and modifying cattle feed to reduce methane emissions. He also advocates for carbon capture technologies to mitigate emissions from various industries, crucial to achieving the 1.5°C temperature goal set by the 2015 Paris Agreement.

site_title: 2 industrial units, condo carpark spaces to make way for building of CRL
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has announced plans to acquire two industrial units and 18 condo carpark spaces at Casa Esperanza in Bukit Timah Road to build the second phase of Singapore's Cross Island Line (CRL). The underground space will be handed over in early 2024, and the affected land owners will receive compensation based on market value. The construction of the 15km CRL phase two is expected to start in 2023 and open by 2032, benefiting 40,000 households within 800m of the six stations.

site_title: Police reports made against luxury bag reseller; woman arrested
summary: A 33-year-old woman has been arrested for allegedly collecting money for luxury bags from WestCloset, a Singapore-based reseller. At least five police reports have been made against the company for allegedly failing to deliver second-hand luxury bags. The victims paid between $18,000 to $29,900 for the bags but never received them. WestCloset's website has been taken down, and its physical outlet is rarely opened. The company's excuses for not delivering the bags included financial issues and the boss being hospitalized. The police are investigating the case.

site_title: Teenage girl charged over allegedly pouring boiling water on youth with special needs
summary: A 19-year-old man with special needs was repeatedly assaulted in a hotel room from January 17 to 25, with one of his tormentors, a 17-year-old girl, charged with pouring boiling water on him. She faces one count of voluntarily causing hurt to the man by using a heated substance. The girl allegedly committed the offence with 21-year-old Muhammad Shahfakhry Mohamad Faizal, who is accused of multiple offences, including burning the victim with a lighter and slashing his hands and legs with a razor blade.

site_title: S-E Asian coastal cities sinking the fastest globally: NTU-led study
summary: South-east Asian coastal cities are sinking at a rate of 16.2mm per year, the fastest globally, according to a recent study led by Nanyang Technological University. The study found that excessive groundwater extraction and high-rise buildings in weak foundations contribute to land subsidence. Coupled with sea-level rise and climate change, this could lead to more frequent and intense flooding, disrupting businesses, damaging property, and affecting livelihoods. The study highlights the need for governments to build coastal defences and tackle the root cause of land subsidence, such as groundwater extraction, to mitigate the impacts of sea-level rise.

site_title: 4th agricultural revolution needed to cut greenhouse gas: Nobel laureate
summary: Nobel laureate Steven Chu emphasizes the need for a 4th agricultural revolution to cut greenhouse gas emissions, equivalent to the world's electricity generation, which are largely due to the sector. Chu proposes sustainable methods to boost crop yields without fertilizers or insecticides, such as using microbes to reduce nitrogen usage. Solutions, like modifying cattle feed or vaccinating them, can also mitigate methane emissions. Chu advocates for carbon capture technologies to mitigate emissions from various industries, crucial to achieving the 1.5°C temperature goal and mitigating climate change.

site_title: Malaysia investigating hiker from S'pore who went missing in forest
summary: A 33-year-old Singaporean man, Jason Ren Jie, went missing during a hike in Malaysia's Hutan Panti Forest Reserve in Johor. He was found with minor cuts on his body by members of the public on Sunday. Authorities are investigating Ren Jie for entering the forest reserve without permission, a punishable offense that can result in fines up to RM10,000 or imprisonment for up to three years. The case will be handled in Johor, and Ren Jie will be released once the case is settled, according to the Johor State Forestry Department.

site_title: Buy now, pay later schemes: How to avoid falling into debt
summary: A code of conduct for buy now, pay later (BNPL) providers is set to be released by the end of 2022. As BNPL schemes gain popularity, concerns over consumer debt are growing. Experts advise subscribers to carefully read the fine print, pay on time, and be disciplined to avoid falling into debt. The new code aims to address these concerns and provide a framework for BNPL providers to operate responsibly.

site_title: Boss fined $100k after worker fixing motor is electrocuted
summary: A Singaporean employer, Lee Ee Ten, was fined $100,000 for failing to conduct a proper risk assessment and implement safe work procedures, resulting in the electrocution death of an electrician, Mr. Tong Baorong, in 2019. The incident occurred while the worker was replacing a motor on a roller shutter, and he fell off a ladder and died after coming into contact with live electrical apparatus. The Ministry of Manpower found Lee's employer duties to be inadequate, highlighting a need for improved workplace safety measures.

site_title: Cross Island Line phase 2 to open by 2032 with six MRT stations
summary: Singapore's Cross Island Line phase 2, comprising six MRT stations, is set to open by 2032, benefiting 40,000 households. The 15km stretch will include interchanges with the Downtown Line and East-West Line, and will provide greater public transport access to western areas. Construction works are expected to begin in 2023, with three private land plots to be acquired for the project. The phase will improve connectivity between eastern, western, and north-eastern parts of Singapore, offering shorter and more direct journeys, as well as increased resilience for commuters.

site_title: First scientist to hold US Cabinet position
summary: Professor Steven Chu became the first scientist to hold a US Cabinet position as US energy secretary from 2009 to 2013. He was a Nobel Prize winner in Physics in 1997 for his work on cooling atoms using laser light, which improved atomic clock accuracy. Chu previously directed the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory and helped launch Bio-X at Stanford University. As energy secretary, he assisted in stopping the Deepwater Horizon oil spill in 2010 under President Barack Obama, serving the longest tenure in the position.

site_title: Company briefs: American Express Beyond Meat Ford
summary: American Express plans to hire 1,500 tech employees by the end of the year, despite economic concerns. The company has already added 3,600 tech staff in 2022. Meanwhile, Beyond Meat's COO Doug Ramsey was arrested on charges of terroristic threatening and third-degree battery after allegedly attacking a Subaru driver. Ford Motor reported that inflation is pushing supplier costs $1 billion higher than expected, leading to a preliminary adjusted Ebit estimate of $1.4 billion to $1.7 billion in the current quarter.

site_title: 1 in 2 has experienced discrimination at workplace: Survey
summary: One in two people in Singapore have experienced workplace discrimination, with cases involving race, age, and gender being the most common. A survey by Aware and Milieu Insight found that 54% of those who felt discriminated at work did not report it, and 28% who did report it quit their jobs. The survey highlights the need for comprehensive anti-discrimination legislation, including protections for LGBTQ+ individuals, people with disabilities, and those with disabilities. The findings also suggest that companies need further guidance and incentives to tackle workplace discrimination effectively.

site_title: Asian markets lifted by last-hour dip-buying on Wall Street
summary: Asian markets ended higher on Tuesday, boosted by a late rally on Wall Street that reversed earlier declines. Key gauges, including the Kospi, Shanghai Composite, and Nikkei 225, rose 0.2-0.5% in the day. The STI index in Singapore also gained 0.3% as Australian shares recorded their best day in nearly two weeks. Despite concerns over the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hike, market strategist Yeap Jun Rong suggests that near-term relief may be possible before further Fed comments.

site_title: Energy shipping costs soar as Europe's supply push leads to shortage of vessels
summary: Europe's scramble for energy supplies due to the Ukraine conflict has led to a shortage of vessels, causing shipping costs to surge. LNG freight rates are at elevated levels, threatening to surpass last year's winter peak, while shipping costs for oil and petrochemical feedstock have more than doubled. The shortage affects Asian economies that rely on US energy imports, particularly if the weather turns extremely cold this winter. Shipowners are booking vessels for shorter periods, and energy majors are refusing to release LNG ships, leading to a tight market and higher costs.

site_title: Book documenting 38 community-led healthy living initiatives launched
summary: A book titled Caring Communities was launched in Singapore, featuring 38 community-led healthy living initiatives that have benefited over 10,000 residents since 2011. The book documents initiatives such as brisk-walking groups and community food distribution programs, which have improved residents' mental and physical health. Health Minister Ong Ye Kung emphasized the importance of community support in building a sustainable healthcare environment. The initiatives were led by Yishun Health's population health and community transformation team, with residents taking ownership and growing the projects over time.

site_title: Europe's energy crisis plans seen as short-term solution only
summary: Europe's plans to cap energy bills and tax energy firms are seen as short-term solutions to the global energy crisis, according to Aramco's head Amin Nasser. The crisis, driven by under-investment in hydrocarbons, is not resolved even if the conflict in Ukraine stops, Nasser said. Aramco is investing to raise oil capacity, but globally, investments are "too little, too late, too short-term." Nasser calls for a more viable energy transition plan, not a change in climate goals, to address the crisis and prevent future shortages.

site_title: Tycoon's wild $4.2b gamble on 'China's LVMH' crashes
summary: Shandong Ruyi Group, a Chinese textile maker, embarked on a $4.2 billion acquisition spree six years ago with the goal of becoming China's LVMH. However, the company's strategy has since unraveled, with lenders taking over key businesses and Ruyi facing disputes with creditors. The company is now trying to offload assets, joining other Chinese conglomerates in reversing their global deal sprees. Despite initial success, Ruyi's luxury brands have struggled due to deflated demand for formal wear, leading to financial struggles and potential bankruptcy proceedings.

site_title: Japan's inflation hits 8-year high, staying above BOJ target
summary: Japan's inflation surged to an 8-year high of 2.8% in August, exceeding the Bank of Japan's 2% target. The central bank is unlikely to change its monetary policy despite the acceleration, as governor Haruhiko Kuroda aims to keep interest rates low until solid wage gains support inflation. Analysts expect the US Federal Reserve to raise interest rates this week, further differing from the BOJ's stance. The yen has fallen to 24-year lows, making energy and food imports more expensive for Japan, but wage gains remain elusive.

site_title: DBS: Digital banking now the baseline for all lenders
summary: DBS Bank, a pioneer in digital banking, has set a new standard for lenders in Singapore, emphasizing the importance of leveraging data and technology to create value-added services. The company's Singapore country head, Mr. Shee Tse Koon, notes that DBS had anticipated the shift to digital banking, suggesting a proactive approach. This shift is driven by customers' rising expectations, prompting incumbent banks to invest in innovative solutions to meet these needs. As digital banking continues to grow, banks must adapt to remain competitive.

site_title: Luxury homes snapped up as 'hard currency' in China
summary: Wealthy buyers in China's Shenzhen city are snapping up luxury homes as a safe haven in the country's slowing property market. 604 units in a luxury development have been pre-sold for up to 162,000 yuan (S$32,500) per sq m, valued at up to US$9.8 million. Despite a 48% decline in property sales by floor area, demand for luxury properties remains strong, with average prices rising 11% year-over-year for properties valued at 10 million yuan and above.

site_title: Singapore 'Fort Knox' sold to Chinese crypto billionaire
summary: Chinese crypto billionaire Wu Jihan's firm, Bitdeer Technologies Holding, has purchased Le Freeport, a maximum security vault in Singapore, for $40 million. The vault, dubbed Asia's Fort Knox, was built at a cost of $100 million and was previously owned by Swiss art dealer Yves Bouvier. The purchase represents a significant discount, with Wu's firm acquiring the vault in July. Wu, who has long-term residency in Singapore, is considered influential in cryptocurrency markets and has a history of investing in cloud-mining services. The sale is expected to support the facility's expansion and improvement.

site_title: Double time trial delight for Britain
summary: British cyclists Joshua Tarling and Zoe Backstedt won the men's and women's junior time trials at the Road World Championships in Wollongong, Australia. Tarling secured the gold by 19 seconds, while Backstedt took the bronze medal. The wins mark a promising start to Britain's cycling future, with Tarling signing a three-year deal with Ineos Grenadiers. Tarling and Backstedt will compete in the junior road race on Friday and Saturday, respectively.

site_title: Push to help firms go green via workshops, expert consultationssp
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) and sovereign wealth fund GIC have launched an initiative to help businesses adopt energy-efficient solutions and go green. Through workshops and one-to-one consultations, companies will gain hands-on experience implementing eco-solutions. The initiative aims to attract and retain talent, as well as secure capital from investors conscious about environmental, social, and governance issues. The program, called Map, has already helped 600 companies since its inception and is expected to benefit over 500 participants from 300 companies in its third run.

site_title: Boomba and in All His Glory dazzle
summary: Trainer Tim Fitzsimmons has a strong chance of consolidating his top spot in the leaderboard with his two top horses, In All His Glory and Boomba, set to dominate Saturday's Class 3 thriller. Both horses are in excellent form, with In All His Glory winning his last start and Boomba showing impressive speed in a 600m training session. They will face competition from Super Impact, Tiger Roar, and Relentless, but Fitzsimmons' horses are considered the favorites to win.

site_title: Lithium resumes huge gains to add pressure on carmakers
summary: Lithium prices have surged to a new peak in China, reaching 500,500 yuan (S$100,600) a tonne, after briefly cooling in response to industry pressure. The price increase threatens to squeeze carmakers and battery manufacturers, eroding profits and prompting suppliers to raise their rates. Supply is lagging behind rising forecasts for vehicle demand, with the China Passenger Car Association projecting a record six million EV sales in 2022. Global suppliers expect the lithium rally to continue, indicating a potential supply deficit through at least 2030.

site_title: China's August coal imports from Russia soar amid heatwave
summary: China's coal imports from Russia surged in August to 8.54 million tonnes, the highest in at least five years, amid a heatwave that drove up demand. The increase was 57% higher than in the same period in 2021. Despite being cheaper than domestic coal, Russian thermal coal prices rose due to increased demand from China and India. China also imported more Indonesian coal, 35% higher than in July, but less than in 2021. Power utilities expect to increase imports in October to replenish stocks ahead of the heating season.

site_title: Buy now, pay later schemes: How to avoid exceeding your budget and falling into debt
summary: Singapore to release a code of conduct for buy now, pay later (BNPL) providers by the end of 2022, amid growing concerns over consumer indebtedness. The move aims to regulate the industry and prevent excessive borrowing. BNPL providers, such as those offering 0% instalment plans for big-ticket items like electronics and furniture, will be subject to the new code. The release follows the industry's increasing popularity and rising concerns about debt. The code is expected to address issues related to affordability and responsible lending practices.

site_title: S. Korean prosecutors ask Interpol for help in arresting Terra co-founder
summary: South Korean prosecutors have asked Interpol for help in arresting Terra co-founder Do Kwon, wanted for allegedly breaking capital markets law and facing charges related to the collapse of the $60 billion Terra cryptocurrency project. Do Kwon, who is believed to be in Singapore, denies being on the run and claims to be cooperating with officials. An arrest warrant was issued in South Korea after "circumstantial evidence" suggested his escape, and officials could cancel his passport to force his return. Interpol is expected to issue a red notice to assist in his arrest, which could take about a week.

site_title: A hell of a ride: Pereira
summary: Joshua Pereira, 24, has joined Vietnam's world No. 159 Lions squad for an AFF Championship "audition" after years of injury and uncertainty. The defender, known for his versatility and calmness, hopes to secure a spot in the national team. Pereira has had a tumultuous football journey, including multiple injuries and disciplinary issues, but has impressed with his performances in the Singapore Premier League. With just three months left to prepare for the AFF Championship, Pereira aims to nail down his spot and potentially play in regional leagues.

site_title: 'Ironman' Im adds firepower to Internationals
summary: South Korea's golfer Im Sung-jae, a two-time PGA Tour winner, will be part of the International Team at the Presidents Cup in Charlotte, North Carolina. In 2019, Im was a captain's pick by Ernie Els and impressed with 3.5 points in the International Team's 16-14 loss to the US at Royal Melbourne.

site_title: Dutch testing for 'penalty killer'
summary: The Netherlands is testing its goalkeepers in a penalty shoot-out training session ahead of the World Cup in Qatar later this year. Coach Louis van Gaal has called up four goalkeepers, including Jasper Cillessen, Mark Flekken, Andries Noppert, and Remko Pasveer, for the upcoming Nations League matches. Van Gaal aims to find the best penalty killer and is also testing a second set of goalkeepers, Justin Bijlow and Kjell Scherpen, for this purpose. The Dutch coach has expressed his desire to have four goalkeepers in his 26-man World Cup squad, pending FIFA's clarification on the issue.

site_title: Count Marsh is good enough to score again
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article:

South African horse racing form analysis is provided for Wednesday's Greyville races. The analysis highlights promising horses in various races, including Count Marsh, who is expected to score again in Race 8 after winning last time. Other notable horses include Johnny's Hope, Poltical Party, Aerial View, and Winter Melody, who are favored to win their respective races. The analysis also provides insights into the strengths and weaknesses of each horse, taking into account factors such as surface preference, distance, and form trends.

site_title: Osaka 'really scared' by Saville's knee injury
summary: Naomi Osaka's successful return to the Pan Pacific Open in Tokyo was marred by her opponent Daria Saville's knee injury, which forced her retirement 9 minutes into their match. Osaka expressed concern for Saville, saying she felt "really scared" after seeing her in pain. The match will continue with Osaka facing fifth seed Beatriz Haddad Maia next. Osaka is aiming to break her slump after a poor run, which includes not winning a title since 2021 and being hampered by injuries.

site_title: Carlsen quits again in Niemann rematch
summary: Norwegian world chess champion Magnus Carlsen withdrew from a game against American Hans Niemann in the Julius Baer Generation Cup online tournament, citing a lack of trust due to Niemann's past online cheating. This is the second time Carlsen has withdrawn from a match against Niemann, following a similar incident at the Sinquefield Cup in the US. The move has reignited the controversy, with some grandmasters defending Carlsen's decision and others expressing understanding of his frustration. The incident highlights the ongoing issue of cheating in online chess.

site_title: Rugby C'ship race down to the wire
summary: The Rugby Championship is nearing its conclusion, with New Zealand and South Africa tied at 14 points each. The two teams face off in the final round of fixtures, with the winner potentially being decided by a tiebreaker. If the Springboks and All Blacks both win, the first tiebreaker would be points difference through the series, with New Zealand holding a +41 advantage. The winner will be determined by subsequent tiebreakers, including points difference in matches between the two teams, and finally, the number of tries scored in the series.

site_title: Final warmups ahead of Qatar
summary: European national teams are set to face intense final warm-ups ahead of the World Cup, with the Nations League group stage fixtures and friendly matches providing a last chance to fine-tune preparations before the tournament starts on November 20. Reigning champions France, seeking to defend their title, face Austria and Denmark, while England, seeking to avoid relegation, play Italy and Germany. Other teams, including Brazil, Spain, and Portugal, also have crucial matches, with Wales set to return to the World Cup stage for the first time since 1958.

site_title: Tan gets another year in Europe
summary: Chelsie Tan, the first Singaporean to secure a professional contract in Europe, has secured another year with Team BikeExchange-Jayco after a poor season in the International Cycling Union (UCI) Women's World Tour. Despite being dropped early in her European debut and struggling in several races, Tan bounced back in the US, where she participated in eight races and reaffirmed her potential. A contract extension for the 2023 season is a testament to her resilience and motivation, with team officials believing she still has untapped potential.

site_title: Next 48 hours
summary: Key events and conclusions in the next 48 hours include ATP Tour tennis tournaments, particularly the Metz Open and San Diego Open, as well as the WTA Tour's Pan Pacific Open and Korea Open. Football fans can catch the UEFA Nations League Group A4 match between Belgium and Wales, while golf enthusiasts can watch the DP World Tour French Open. The tournaments will air on various channels, including Singtel TV and StarHub, with schedules available on their websites and TV guides.

site_title: No national c'ships in SCSM irks some runners
summary: The Standard Chartered Singapore Marathon (SCSM) will return in December after a two-year hiatus, but without the National Championships and a significant prize purse drop. Top marathoner Soh Rui Yong expressed disappointment, calling it "sad times for local distance running." The prize purse has decreased by 80% from $244,000 in 2019 to $70,000. Local runners are concerned about the lack of recognition and pride in competing in Singapore's only two marathons. Discussions are underway between the Singapore Athletics and SCSM organisers to address the issue.

site_title: Sports World: MLS to investigate alleged racial abuse
summary: Major League Soccer (MLS) has announced an investigation into alleged racial abuse during a game between DC United and Inter Miami. DC United forward Taxi Fountas was accused of using a racial slur towards Inter Miami defender Damion Lowe, but Fountas has denied the allegations. The investigation will begin promptly. Meanwhile, the NBA is expected to reduce the minimum draft age from 19 to 18 by 2024, allowing high school players to enter the draft. The International Cricket Council has also made permanent a ban on using saliva to polish cricket balls, effective immediately.

site_title: LIV CEO Norman to meet U.S. Lawmakers
summary: LIV Golf CEO Greg Norman will meet US lawmakers on Capitol Hill to discuss the company's business model and dispute with the PGA Tour. The meeting comes amid a federal antitrust lawsuit accusing the PGA Tour of improperly suspending members for their involvement in LIV. Critics say LIV is an attempt by Saudi Arabia to "sportswash" its image, while supporters argue the tour is reimagining the game. Norman has stated he is not interested in a truce with the PGA Tour, calling their efforts to destroy LIV "not true."

site_title: Alonso is Aston Martin's 'perfect candidate'
summary: Aston Martin team boss Mike Krack believes Fernando Alonso is the "perfect candidate" to help the team take the next step in Formula One. Alonso, a two-time world champion, will replace Sebastian Vettel in 2023 with his unique combination of speed, hunger, and experience. However, Krack warns that if the car is not fast enough, it may be challenging for Alonso to win. Despite this, Krack is confident that Alonso's presence will be crucial in helping Aston Martin make progress, having previously managed champion Sebastian Vettel.

site_title: Prime minister to call the shots in race 2
summary: Hong Kong's Happy Valley racing analysis focuses on key contenders for Wednesday's races. In Race 2, Prime Minister is expected to continue trainer Ricky Yiu's hot run, with 4 Fa Fa and 5 Sunny Star also in contention. Other notable performances are predicted for California Forest in Race 3 and Smart Cousin in Race 4. Island Surprise is closing in on a first win in Race 5, while My Ecstatic is a straightforward customer in Race 6. The races also feature notable trainers Ricky Yiu and Richard Gibson, with jockeys Joao Moreira and Zac Purton playing significant roles.

site_title: We will ensure the war is not a paradise for cheats: Wada
summary: Wada president Witold Banka stated the agency is monitoring Russia's testing operations despite the country's invasion of Ukraine, which has complicated doping compliance. The existing two-year ban from international sport expires at the end of 2022, and Wada is keeping an open line of communication with the Russian Anti-Doping Agency (Rusada) to ensure compliance. Banka emphasized that Wada will not allow Russia to become a "paradise for cheats" and is closely monitoring the investigation into figure skater Kamila Valieva's positive test. A decision on Rusada's reinstatement is expected at the end of the year.

site_title: Savea boost but headaches for All Blacks
summary: New Zealand's back row is uncertain ahead of the Rugby Championship Test against Australia at Eden Park, with Ardie Savea ready to replace Hoskins Sotutu. Sam Cane and David Havili may miss the match due to concussion protocols, and Shannon Frizell needs to pass a fitness test. If Cane is ruled out, Savea is in line to take over the All Blacks' captaincy. The match will decide the Rugby Championship title, with New Zealand seeking back-to-back titles.

site_title: Football: Russia banned from Euro 2024 qualifying draw
summary: Russia has been banned from participating in the Euro 2024 qualifying draw due to the country's invasion of Ukraine, following a Uefa Executive Committee decision in February 2022. The ban, confirmed by the Court of Arbitration for Sport, also affects Russian clubs. Russia had initially qualified for the European qualifying play-offs but will not be included in the draw, set for October 9 in Frankfurt. The ban also applies to the upcoming World Cup in Qatar and the Russian women's team was replaced by Portugal in the European Championship.

site_title: More than WFH: Staggered hours keep home-grown bakery chain staff happy and productive
summary: A home-grown bakery chain in Singapore, Polar Puffs & Cakes, has been offering flexible working arrangements since 2013, including staggered hours, to keep staff happy and productive. The company's staggered hours policy allows employees to choose from five start-and-end times, improving work-life harmony and productivity. With over 90% of employees being women, the policy caters to those who are main caregivers for elderly parents and children. Polar's flexible work arrangements have also enabled it to attract and retain young staff, with low turnover rates, and have been recognized as one of Singapore's top 20 firms in 2022 in terms of working conditions.

site_title: Athletics: National C'ships dropped from StanChart Marathon; prize money dips from $300k to $70k
summary: The Standard Chartered Singapore Marathon (SCSM) is set to return to its full physical format in December, but it will no longer feature the National Championships or the associated prize purse, which has dropped by 80% from $244,000 to $70,000. This move has disappointed local runners, including top national marathoner Soh Rui Yong, who feel that the event has lost its prestige. The SCSM organizers, Ironman Group, attribute the changes to the absence of elite racing categories due to the pandemic recovery, but have promised to increase the prize pool in a progressive manner.

images.alt_text: Standard Chartered Singapore Marathon

site_title: Football: Spain PM condemns Atletico over Vinicius racism incident
summary: Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez condemned Atletico Madrid for not addressing racist chants against Real Madrid's Vinicius Junior during their match. The chants, including "You are a monkey, Vinicius, you are a monkey," were met with missiles and lighters. Atletico Madrid released a statement condemning the abuse and vowing to find and ban the perpetrators. La Liga reported the incident to the Spanish Football Federation's disciplinary committee. Sanchez called on football clubs to take a strong stance against such behavior, saying it's unacceptable and needs to be condemned.

site_title: Nasdaq makes first big crypto push to lure institutional clients
summary: Nasdaq, the second-largest stock exchange, is making its first major push into the crypto market by launching a new group dedicated to digital assets. The group will offer custody services for Bitcoin and Ether to institutional investors, with Nasdaq hiring former Gemini executive Ira Auerbach to head the unit. The move is part of Nasdaq's efforts to diversify revenue sources beyond the exchange business. While it has no immediate plans to launch a crypto exchange, Nasdaq will evaluate opportunities based on the regulatory environment and competitive landscape.

site_title: Rugby: All four teams can still win southern hemisphere championship
summary: The Rugby Championship is entering its final round, with New Zealand and South Africa currently tied for first place with 14 points each. Australia and Argentina trail behind with 10 and 9 points, respectively. If both New Zealand and South Africa win, the winner will be determined by a try-scoring bonus point, with New Zealand holding a 41-point lead over South Africa. The competition rules state that if the scores are still tied, the winner will be determined by head-to-head record, points difference, and then tries scored in the series.

site_title: Formula One: Glitzy Las Vegas set to 'take F1 race weekends to the next level'
summary: Formula One has provisionally added a Las Vegas night race to the 2023 schedule, taking the total number of races to a record 24. The event, set to be held on November 18, will feature a 6.12km track along the Las Vegas Strip and is expected to attract 170,000 fans. The addition comes after Miami joined the schedule this season, and the Las Vegas Grand Prix is expected to "take F1 race weekends to the next level," according to F1's chief executive Stefano Domenicali.

site_title: Chess: World champion Magnus Carlsen quits rematch with Hans Niemann amid cheating allegations
summary: Norwegian world chess champion Magnus Carlsen withdrew from a game against American Hans Niemann in an online tournament, amid ongoing cheating allegations. This is the second time Carlsen has withdrawn from a match against Niemann, following a week-long absence from the Sinquefield Cup in the US. Carlsen's gesture is seen as a protest against Niemann, who has admitted to cheating in online games in the past. The controversy has reignited debate about trust and fair play in chess, with many experts expressing understanding for Carlsen's frustration but also cautioning against jumping to conclusions.

site_title: Golf: LIV series players push for retroactive world ranking points
summary: The LIV Golf Series players, including 48 participants from the Chicago Invitational, have submitted an open letter to world rankings board chairman Peter Dawson, requesting retroactive world ranking points. The players argue that the 54-hole, shotgun start events should be recognized alongside other world tours, citing comparable competition levels and major wins. The move comes as LIV Golf chairman Greg Norman visits US lawmakers to discuss the circuit's fight with the US PGA Tour, amidst ongoing anti-trust lawsuit and concerns over Saudi financial support.

site_title: Firms that help employees grow can better retain talent, says panellist at SIM forum
summary: Companies that provide internal growth opportunities are more likely to retain talent for over five years, according to LinkedIn's 2022 report. The platform's research shows that 40% of companies now consider skills over traditional credentials when hiring. Panelists, including Dyson's John Churchill and LinkedIn's Feon Ang, emphasized the importance of learning places and employee growth in retaining talent. Experts also highlighted the need for continuous learning, adaptability, and a sense of purpose in the evolving workforce.

site_title: Singapore students to take part in global competition that tests over 60 skills
summary: Singapore is sending a 29-member team to the WorldSkills 2022 Special Edition competition, taking place in 15 host countries, to compete in over 60 skill areas. The team, representing the country's five polytechnics, will participate in areas like cyber security, fashion technology, and cloud computing. Education Minister Chan Chun Sing encouraged the participants to focus on self-improvement and having fun, while former student Lim Hui Fang is set to compete in beauty therapy skills in Finland. The competition aims to help young participants develop skills and shift their passion into a professional career.

site_title: SG Extra Podcast: What Formula One's return means for fans, businesses and Singapore's economy
summary: The Singapore Grand Prix Formula One race is set to return this year, with 25 events timed around the event, boosting the country's MICE industry after a two-year pandemic hiatus. The return of the race is expected to have a positive impact on fans, businesses, and the economy, with many events and activities planned around the event. The episode discusses the potential benefits and challenges of the F1's return to Singapore.

site_title: Aramco CEO says Europe's energy crisis plans only a short-term solution
summary: Aramco CEO Amin Nasser stated that Europe's energy crisis plans, including capping energy bills and taxing companies, are short-term solutions that do not address the root cause of the problem - under-investment in hydrocarbons. He emphasized that the global energy crisis is driven by insufficient investments in hydrocarbons, despite alternatives not being readily available. Nasser warned that the crisis would persist even if the conflict in Ukraine stopped, and called for a more viable energy transition plan to unite the world.

site_title: Football: Nations League games offer last chance to prepare for World Cup
summary: National teams face a crucial week of preparation ahead of the World Cup, as they compete in the Nations League group stage. The European season's interruption due to the World Cup has left teams with limited time to fine-tune their preparations, with many players returning from injuries just in time. France and England, among others, are under pressure to avoid relegation, while Spain and Portugal will meet in a Nations League match that could decide their World Cup advancement. The week's events will be crucial in shaping the teams' World Cup campaigns.

site_title: New initiative to help businesses go green via workshops, consultations with experts
summary: A new initiative by the Singapore Business Federation (SBF) aims to help businesses go green through workshops, consultations with experts, and technology demonstrations. The Map initiative, in partnership with GIC, offers companies a pathway to reduce carbon emissions and adopt energy-efficient solutions. Experts emphasize that companies with good sustainability practices can attract talent, capital, and differentiate themselves from competitors. The program has already helped 600 companies and is expected to benefit 500 participants from 300 companies in its third run.

site_title: Two months' jail for man who furnished forged court document showing boss' fines had been paid
summary: A 42-year-old Singaporean, Chua Chee Siang, was sentenced to two months' jail for furnishing a forged court document to support his false claim that fines against his employer's charges had been paid. Chua, who was employed by A-Tec Motorz, created a document with the State Courts' logo to deceive his employer, Heng Cheng Hock, about the payment of $300 in fines. Chua was found guilty of using a forged document and showed no remorse, prompting the prosecution to request a longer sentence.

site_title: 2 people given undiluted Covid-19 vaccine at Hougang clinic, 1 discharged after hospitalisation
summary: Two adults received undiluted Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine at a clinic in Hougang, Singapore, on September 15. One of them was hospitalized with a headache and increased heart rate, but has since been discharged. The clinic and doctor involved have been suspended from the National Vaccination Programme until further notice. The incident is being thoroughly investigated by the Ministry of Health. This is the latest in a series of incidents involving incorrect vaccine dosages, including a previous mistake at the Singapore National Eye Centre and a polyclinic error involving 117 patients.

site_title: New book documents Yishun and Sembawang residents' community-based approach to healthy living
summary: A new book titled "Caring Communities" documents 38 healthy living community-led initiatives in Yishun and Sembawang, benefiting over 10,000 residents since 2011. The initiatives, facilitated by Yishun Health's population health team, focus on mental and physical well-being. Health Minister Ong Ye Kung emphasized the importance of community support in building a sustainable healthcare environment. Residents, such as Jeremy Wong, who started a brisk-walking group, have seen positive outcomes from these community-led projects, showcasing the effectiveness of community-based approaches to healthy living.

site_title: Tennis: Osaka 'really scared' after Saville retires with knee injury
summary: Tennis star Naomi Osaka expressed concern for her opponent Daria Saville after she retired from their match at the Pan Pacific Open in Tokyo due to a left knee injury. Saville, who was leading 1-0, 30-30, received treatment and walked off the court on her own. Osaka, who is seeking to break out of a slump, will face fifth seed Beatriz Haddad Maia in the next round. The tournament marks Osaka's successful return to Japan, but she is still hampered by injury, including achilles, back, and abdominal issues.

site_title: Woman who brandished knife, stabbed herself during police stand-off in Tampines to be charged
summary: A 53-year-old woman in Singapore brandished a knife and stabbed herself during a police stand-off outside a secondary school in Tampines. She was surrounded by 10 police officers and used the knife to threaten herself before being subdued and arrested. Two knives were seized from her. She will be charged with possession of offensive weapons in a public place, a jail term of up to three years, and caning of not less than six strokes. The woman will also face investigation by the Central Narcotics Bureau for suspected drug-related offences.

site_title: Football: French federation to review image rights agreement
summary: The French Football Federation announced it will review its agreement on players' image rights after striker Kylian Mbappe refused to participate in sponsor activities due to his opposition to endorsing certain brands under contract with the national team. Mbappe stated he will not take part in a team photo and sponsor activities. The federation held discussions with team executives and players, with coach Didier Deschamps already without several key players due to injuries. France faces the risk of dropping to the second tier of the competition.

site_title: 1 in 2 people experienced discrimination at work: Aware-Milieu survey
summary: One in two people in Singapore have experienced workplace discrimination, with cases involving race, age, and gender being the most common. A survey by Aware and Milieu Insight found that people with disabilities, LGBTQ individuals, and women are more likely to experience discrimination. Many respondents who felt discriminated at work did not report it, with 54% not reporting any incidents. Those who did report discrimination often faced adverse career impacts, with 28% quitting their jobs. The survey's findings support the need for anti-discrimination legislation, which should include a comprehensive range of protected characteristics.

site_title: Golf: Greg Norman going before US lawmakers to defend LIV Series
summary: LIV Golf CEO Greg Norman is set to meet US lawmakers on Capitol Hill to discuss the Saudi-backed circuit's ongoing dispute with the PGA Tour. The meeting aims to improve LIV's public image amid criticism over its use of Saudi financing and accusations of "sportswashing." Norman has accused the PGA Tour of trying to destroy LIV, while the tour has accused LIV of improperly suspending members for their involvement. The dispute has also drawn attention from lawmakers, with some criticizing the PGA Tour for accepting Saudi funding.

site_title: South-east Asian coastal cities sinking fastest, could worsen impacts of sea level rise: Study
summary: A recent study by a team led by Nanyang Technological University (NTU) found that South-east Asian coastal cities are sinking at the fastest rate globally, with median sinking speeds of 16.2mm per year. Cities such as Ho Chi Minh City (16.2mm/year) and Jakarta (4.4mm/year) are experiencing rapid land subsidence due to excessive groundwater extraction. This can exacerbate the impacts of sea-level rise, leading to more frequent and intense flooding. The study highlights the need for governments to build coastal defences and tackle the root cause of land subsidence, such as groundwater extraction, to mitigate the effects of climate change.

site_title: Top Glove sinks into the red with $16.3m loss as orders slow, costs pile up
summary: Top Glove Corporation, a leading manufacturer of disposable rubber gloves, reported a net loss of RM52.6 million (S$16.3 million) for the fourth quarter of 2022, down 52.3% from the same period last year. The company's revenue fell to RM990.1 million, a 52.3% decrease from the previous year. Cost pressures, including a 60% hike in natural gas tariff and a 25% increase in the Malaysian minimum wage, contributed to the decline. The company attributed the slowdown to an adjustment period in the industry due to oversupply and excess stockpiling.

site_title: Cross Island Line phase 2 to open by 2032 with 6 MRT stations, from Turf City to Jurong Lake District
summary: Singapore's Cross Island MRT line phase 2, spanning 15km from Turf City to Jurong Lake District, is set to open by 2032 with six new stations, including interchanges with the Downtown Line and East-West Line. The line will provide greater public transport access to western areas and improve connectivity between eastern, western, and north-eastern parts of the city. Construction is expected to begin in 2023, and the project will benefit 40,000 households.

site_title: Luxury bag reseller fails to deliver paid branded items including Hermes bags; police reports made
summary: At least five police reports have been made against luxury bag reseller WestCloset, alleging the company collected money for second-hand luxury bags but failed to deliver. A 33-year-old woman was arrested after lodging a police report in August, and more victims intend to file reports. WestCloset, registered under an Indonesian woman's name, has a physical store and online presence, but its website has been taken down. The company's excuses for not delivering goods include financial issues and the boss being hospitalized.

site_title: Doping: Wada still monitoring Russia ahead of expiration of ban - Banka
summary: The World Anti-Doping Agency (Wada) continues to monitor Russia's anti-doping operations, despite the country's invasion of Ukraine and the expiration of its two-year ban from international sports at the end of 2022. Wada president Witold Banka said there is an open line of communication with Russia's anti-doping agency, Rusada, to ensure compliance with doping regulations. The agency is closely monitoring Rusada's investigation into figure skater Kamila Valieva's positive test and will make a decision on her case after the hearing. A decision on Russia's reinstatement to the international sports system is expected in the coming months.

site_title: Football: After a career blighted by injuries, Pereira aims to soar with Lions
summary: Singapore's national football team, the Lions, has named a 23-man squad for upcoming friendlies against Vietnam and India. Among the new faces is 24-year-old Joshua Pereira, a midfielder from Geylang International, who aims to prove himself for the national team after a career plagued by injuries. Pereira has impressed in the Singapore Premier League and is technically gifted, but has faced setbacks, including a broken leg and punctured lung. The Lions' coach, Takayuki Nishigaya, sees Pereira's versatility and calmness in possession as valuable assets for the team, and hopes the upcoming friendlies will provide a boost ahead of the Asean Football Federation Championship.

site_title: Singapore 'Fort Knox' sold to Chinese crypto billionaire Wu Jihan
summary: Chinese crypto billionaire Wu Jihan has purchased Le Freeport, a maximum-security vault in Singapore dubbed Asia's Fort Knox, for $40 million. The facility, which costs $100 million to build, was previously owned by Swiss art dealer Yves Bouvier. Wu, who has long-term residency in Singapore, acquired the vault from Bouvier's shareholders, including DBS Group Holdings, and has expressed commitment to supporting the facility and expanding its services.

site_title: askST: What is excess death and what is Covid-19's true toll on the world?
summary: Singapore reported 2,490 excess deaths due to Covid-19 between January 2020 and June 2022, exceeding its official death toll of 1,403. This figure is among the lowest globally, with an estimated 26 excess deaths per 100,000 in 2021. Vaccination disparities were significant, with 28% of excess deaths among unvaccinated individuals. Comparing countries, Singapore's excess deaths per million residents (600-700) are lower than in the US or Britain, but similar to China's 470 per million, suggesting potential underreporting of actual Covid-19 deaths.

site_title: Football: After missing Euros, Ward-Prowse targets World Cup place
summary: England midfielder James Ward-Prowse is using the disappointment of missing the Euros as motivation to win a place in the World Cup squad. Ward-Prowse was excluded from the final cut for the tournament, but has been included in Gareth Southgate's squad for upcoming Nations League games. The 27-year-old aims to perform well and secure a spot in the World Cup squad, which will be named before the tournament in Qatar. Meanwhile, Jordan Henderson has been added to the England squad after recovering from a hamstring injury, replacing Manchester City midfielder Kalvin Phillips.

site_title: S’pore’s largest train and bus depot to open in 2025, structural works 75% complete
summary: Singapore's largest train and bus depot, the East Coast Integrated Depot, is 75% complete with structural works. Scheduled to open in 2025, the facility will house 220 trains from three MRT lines and 760 buses. The four-in-one setup, located on a 44ha plot, saves land equivalent to 60 football fields and features green features such as solar panels and optimized natural lighting. The depot's design allows for independent train depots while sharing facilities and systems, and its completion will free up land for housing and other uses.

site_title: Jail for investment scammer who cheated 4 victims of more than $1.1 million
summary: A Singaporean investment scammer, Hong Ban Joo, 51, was sentenced to 6 years and 2 months in jail for cheating 4 victims of $1,128,000. Hong, an introducing broker for NoaFX, used dummy accounts to deceive victims, collecting $660,000 and $350,000 from them. He used the funds to pay creditors and provided false returns to the victims. Hong also managed to return $351,080 to 3 of the victims. He intends to appeal against his sentence.

site_title: Condo parking spaces, 2 industrial units to make way for Cross Island Line phase 2
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) will acquire 18 carpark spaces at freehold condominium Casa Esperanza in Bukit Timah Road and two industrial units in Pandan Loop to build the second phase of Singapore's Cross Island Line (CRL). The underground space will be handed over to LTA in early 2024, and affected land owners will receive compensation based on market value. The CRL phase 2, expected to open by 2032, will comprise six stations serving Bukit Timah, Clementi, and West Coast, and will benefit 40,000 households.

site_title: S’pore could charge 10 to 20 cents more per canned or bottled drink under proposed recycling scheme
summary: Singapore may charge 10 to 20 cents extra per canned or bottled drink by mid-2024 under a proposed recycling scheme. Consumers can return empty bottles and cans for a refund, with over 400 return points planned across the island. The goal is to increase recycling rates to 80% and cut packaging waste. The deposit amount and refund methods are subject to public feedback, which ends on October 14.

site_title: Digital banking now baseline, future growth lies in how cleverly banks use data: DBS
summary: DBS Bank in Singapore reports that 90% of its banking services can now be done online, including mortgage repayments and refinancing. This shift to digital banking has prompted incumbent banks to prioritize customer needs and invest in innovative solutions. DBS Bank's Singapore country head, Shee Tse Koon, notes that the bank had anticipated the shift to digital banking, highlighting the bank's preparedness for the industry's evolution. The bank's focus on data-driven solutions is seen as key to future growth.

site_title: Vessel shortage makes soaring shipping costs a new energy threat
summary: Shipping costs are surging due to a vessel shortage, particularly for liquefied natural gas (LNG) and other energy supplies, as Europe scrambles for alternatives to Russian energy amid the Ukraine conflict. LNG freight rates are at elevated levels, threatening to surpass last year's winter peak, and are impacting Asian economies that rely on US energy imports. Shipowners are booking vessels for winter earlier, and energy majors are holding onto ships, leading to a tight market and higher costs, with some ships burning extra fuel to stay afloat.

site_title: Cycling: Undaunted by 'scary' first race, Chelsie Tan earns one-year contract extension with pro outfit
summary: Singaporean cyclist Chelsie Tan secured a one-year contract extension with Team BikeExchange-Jayco after her professional debut in Europe. Despite being dropped in her first European outing, Tan persevered, racing in 13 events and finishing only once. The cyclist credited her experience in the US and support from her team and loved ones for helping her regain confidence and believe in her abilities. With a renewed focus, Tan plans to continue racing in the International Cycling Union (UCI) Women's World Tour and is expected to make significant improvements in her second season.

site_title: Girl charged with assault after allegedly pouring boiling water on man with special needs
summary: A 19-year-old man with special needs was allegedly assaulted repeatedly in a hotel room by four individuals, including a 17-year-old girl who poured boiling water on him. The girl, charged with voluntarily causing hurt, has her case adjourned to Oct 11. The man was also allegedly subjected to other forms of torture, including being burned with a lighter, punched, and kicked. He suffered facial fractures and was taken to hospital for treatment. The girl and three others, including 21-year-old Muhammad Shahfakhry Mohamad Faizal, face charges related to the assault.

site_title: Japan's inflation hits 31-year high, creating headaches for BOJ
summary: Japan's inflation has reached a 31-year high, with consumer prices excluding fresh food and energy rising 1.6% in August. The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is expected to maintain its monetary stimulus despite the surge in inflation, as central bank governor Haruhiko Kuroda aims to keep interest rates low until wage gains make inflation more sustainable. Analysts predict the BOJ's policy will remain unchanged, despite growing pressure to justify its ongoing stimulus, with the US Federal Reserve set to raise interest rates this week.

site_title: Terra founder Do Kwon at risk of Interpol red notice as net tightens
summary: South Korean prosecutors have requested Interpol's assistance in arresting Do Kwon, founder of the Terra cryptocurrency project, which collapsed and wiped out $60 billion in value. Kwon faces charges for allegedly breaking capital markets laws. He has denied being on the run and claims to be in "full cooperation" with officials. An arrest warrant has been issued, and Kwon's passport could be revoked, potentially requiring him to return to Seoul within 14 days. Interpol may issue a red notice to facilitate his arrest.

site_title: Worker electrocuted, fell off ladder and died: Employer fined $100k
summary: A Singaporean electrician, Lee Ee Ten, was fined $100,000 for failing to conduct a proper risk assessment and implement safe work procedures, leading to the death of her worker, Tong Baorong, who was electrocuted and fell off a ladder in 2019. Lee pleaded guilty to the charge under the Workplace Safety and Health Act and faces a three-month jail term if she fails to pay the fine. The incident highlights the need for improved workplace safety measures in Singapore, with the Ministry of Manpower launching a code of practice to enhance workplace safety culture.

site_title: Ether's outlook darkens in charts capturing hangover after Merge
summary: Ether's price has dropped below the second standard deviation of a regression channel drawn from its June lows, signaling a potential retreat to the third standard deviation, around US$1,250. The token has fallen 63% this year, and the recent sell-off is bringing technical patterns into play that hint at more downside risk. The price of Ether has breached a zone of support at around US$1,340, raising the risk of further falls. Options data from Deribit suggests that levels of US$1,000 and US$2,000 define a trading range for Ether, with a maximum pain point implied at around US$1,600.
