site_title: Geely-backed smart car firm Ecarx said to seek Hong Kong listing after US Spac deal
summary: Ecarx Holdings, a smart car technology company backed by Chinese billionaire Li Shufu and Zhejiang Geely Holding Group, is exploring a Hong Kong listing after a planned US listing via a merger with a blank-cheque company. The firm has not decided whether to raise funds via the Hong Kong listing, but a listing outside the US could help hedge potential delisting risks. Ecarx is aiming to complete the merger by the end of this year or early next year, pending US regulatory approvals. The move comes as many US-listed Chinese companies are trading in Hong Kong due to ongoing disputes over audit documents.

site_title: China's August coal imports from Russia, Indonesia soar as heatwave spurs power use
summary: China's coal imports from Russia surged in August, reaching 8.54 million tonnes, the highest in at least five years, as extreme heat sparked power demand. Imports from Russia rose 57% from the same period in 2021, driven by Europe's suspension of purchases due to the Ukraine conflict. China also increased imports from Indonesia, 35% more than July, as utilities sought to meet demand and improve efficiency. Power utilities are expected to increase imports in October to replenish stocks ahead of the heating season, but renminbi depreciation may dent demand.

site_title: Nobel laureate defies attacks, death threats to continue fight to end child exploitation
summary: Nobel laureate Kailash Satyarthi continues his fight to end child exploitation despite death threats and attacks. Since starting the Bachpan Bachao Andolan movement in 1980, Satyarthi has rescued over 120,000 children from exploitation, with his efforts leading to the enactment of a law to prohibit child labor in India and the adoption of an International Labour Organisation convention. Satyarthi, who was awarded the 2014 Nobel Peace Prize, remains determined to save children from exploitation, citing incidents that sparked his zeal for the cause, including witnessing a child working outside school and his friend dropping out due to poverty.

site_title: Gojek to impose $3 minimum waiting fee from Sept 26
summary: Gojek will impose a $3 minimum waiting fee on passengers starting Sept 26, with an additional $3 charged for every 5 minutes the driver waits thereafter, capped at $9. The waiting time fee applies to GoCar, GoCar XL, and GoCar Premium services, but not GoTaxi. The platform also reduces its 5-minute cancellation grace period to 4 minutes, with a $4 fee for cancellations made within 4 minutes of the pickup time.

site_title: Tycoon's wild $4.2 billion gamble on 'China's LVMH' crashes
summary: Shandong Ruyi Group, a Chinese textile maker, has seen its $4.2 billion gamble on becoming China's LVMH collapse. Chairman Qiu Yafu has been negotiating with creditors in a hotel room, struggling to hold on to assets acquired from French fashion brands and heritage British tailors. The company is losing control of key businesses and facing disputes with creditors, including Carlyle Group. Ruyi's strategy to bring European luxury goods to China's booming market has unraveled, with brands struggling due to deflated demand for formalwear. Creditors are seeking to offload assets, and the company's future is uncertain.

site_title: Beyond Meat COO arrested for biting man's nose after US college football game
summary: Beyond Meat's COO Doug Ramsey, 53, was arrested on charges of terroristic threatening and third-degree battery after an altercation following a college football game in Fayetteville, Arkansas. Ramsey allegedly bit a man's nose, ripped flesh on the tip, and threatened to kill him after a car incident. He was released on $11,085 bond. This incident comes as the plant-based protein company faces recent setbacks, including slashing its revenue outlook and cutting 4% of its workforce. Ramsey's arrest is the latest blow to the company, which has seen its shares decline 74% this year.

site_title: Woman with schizophrenia who killed 8-year-old daughter acquitted, to be confined indefinitely
summary: A 36-year-old woman with schizophrenia was found not guilty of murdering her 8-year-old daughter due to mental incapacity. The woman, who had untreated schizophrenia, was ordered to be confined indefinitely after hearing voices telling her to kill her daughter. The court found that the woman's psychosis caused her to be out of touch with reality, leading her to commit the crime. The woman will undergo regular reviews on her mental state before possible discharge, and her case will be reported to the Law Minister.

site_title: Call to S'poreans to take part in building climate-resilient nation
summary: Singaporeans are urged to participate in a national conversation to build a climate-resilient nation, with Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu launching the "Steward pillar" of the Forward Singapore exercise. The conversation will involve individuals, schools, and organizations, with a focus on sustainable economic growth, reducing carbon emissions, and mitigating the effects of climate change. Discussions will center on trade-offs, carbon tax increases, and ensuring no one is left behind in the transition to a more sustainable future. The goal is to create a liveable planet for future generations.

site_title: S'pore hiker who went missing in Malaysian forest reserve under investigation for illegal hiking
summary: A 33-year-old Singaporean hiker, Mr Jason Ren Jie, went missing in a Malaysian forest reserve and was later found with minor cuts. He is under investigation for entering the forest reserve without permission or permit. The Malaysian authorities have handed the case to the forestry department for further investigation, and the Singapore Consulate-General has provided consular assistance to his family. The case may result in fines or imprisonment, with penalties ranging from RM10,000 to three years. The incident is not expected to affect the relationship between Johor and Singapore.

site_title: Workplace safety code for bosses to be gazetted
summary: Singapore is set to gazette a workplace safety code of practice for companies, outlining their duties on safety and health. The code aims to improve workplace safety culture, including measures such as internal reporting systems and demanding effective safety standards from suppliers. The move comes after a spate of workplace fatalities in 2022, with 37 deaths to date, and will give courts the power to consider compliance with the code in cases of non-compliance. The code applies to all industries and prioritizes mental wellbeing, with companies that fail to comply facing potential consequences.

site_title: Chinese buyers snap up luxury homes as 'hard currency' in soft property market
summary: Chinese luxury property sales are bucking the trend of the slowing property market, with wealthy buyers seeking a safe haven. In Shenzhen, 604 luxury units have been presold for up to $9.8 million each, with prices rising 11% in the first half of the year. Despite a 48% decline in property sales by floor area, demand for luxury homes remains high, with buyers viewing them as "hard currency" in a weak market. Authorities' efforts to cut excessive debt have led to a liquidity crunch, but luxury buyers are undeterred.

site_title: Ford to spend $1.4 billion more in Q3 because of supply chain problems
summary: Ford Motor expects to spend $1.4 billion more in the third quarter due to supply chain problems, primarily caused by a computer chip shortage. The company now anticipates 40,000 to 45,000 vehicles to be left incomplete, with high-margin trucks and SUVs being a significant portion. This is higher than the previous estimate of 53,000 vehicles. Despite this, Ford remains confident in its full-year adjusted earnings forecast of $11.5 billion to $12.5 billion, relying on strong performance in the final quarter to meet the goal.

site_title: Rare serious reactions with Novavax vaccine: HSA
summary: The Health Sciences Authority (HSA) in Singapore reported 28 adverse effects from 18,073 doses of the Novavax Covid-19 vaccine, with five being serious. Four cases were anaphylaxis and one was a serious allergic reaction, occurring in individuals with previous allergies or adverse reactions to other Covid-19 vaccines. All patients recovered. The HSA emphasized that the risk of myocarditis is low, with no local reports, and advised avoiding strenuous physical activity for two weeks after vaccination. The incidence of adverse reactions remains low, with most being reported from mRNA vaccines.

site_title: Keep Jurong Bird Park and Jurong Hill as recreational green space: Heritage advocates
summary: Heritage advocates in Singapore are urging to keep Jurong Bird Park and the adjacent Jurong Hill as recreational green spaces, despite the park's planned closure in January. The area holds historical significance in Singapore's early industrialization program and features iconic structures. Advocates aim to preserve these aspects, prioritizing green spaces over the park's relocation to Mandai.

site_title: President Halimah meets Malaysia's King in London
summary: President Halimah Yacob met with Malaysia's King, Sultan Abdullah Ahmad Shah, in London during the state funeral of Queen Elizabeth II. The two leaders discussed their countries' longstanding relationship and cooperation, with Halimah looking forward to hosting the King for a state visit in Singapore next month. The visit was initially scheduled to begin on Monday but was postponed due to the King's visit to London. The King is now scheduled to visit Singapore from October 25.

site_title: Jail, caning for groomsman who sexually assaulted bride
summary: A 42-year-old groomsman was sentenced to 7 years' jail and 6 strokes of the cane for sexually assaulting the bride at her wedding reception in 2016. The offender, a friend of the groom, molested the woman in her bridal suite after serving drinks at the wedding dinner, deceiving her into thinking he was her husband. The bride initially thought the person touching her was her husband, but soon realized it was someone else. The couple has since divorced.

site_title: Must-reads
summary: A new code of practice for workplace safety was launched in Singapore, providing actionable guidance for company leaders to build a strong safety culture. The code was fast-tracked after a spike in workplace deaths and will be gazetted in October. Meanwhile, Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's support is in free fall due to public discontent over a state funeral for former leader Shinzo Abe and handling of economic issues. Singapore Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu emphasized the need for a national conversation on climate change and its trade-offs.

site_title: Cop dead with gunshot wound at MBS, no foul play suspected
summary: A 29-year-old Singapore Police Force officer was found dead with a gunshot wound at Marina Bay Sands on Monday morning. The officer, who had joined the SPF in 2014, reportedly fired two shots in the air before turning his gun onto himself. No foul play is suspected, and the police classify the case as an unnatural death. Investigations are ongoing, with the SPF stating that officers are trained to identify signs of distress and have access to internal and external resources for support. No other injuries were reported.

site_title: Designer of lion head so focused that he 'ate and slept with the lion'
summary: Michael Lee, a senior art director, designed Singapore's iconic lion head symbol in 1986 after months of meticulous work, including eating and sleeping with a lion. His minimalist design, featuring a bold red lion head, was chosen from over 260 submissions and represents the country's ideals of democracy, peace, and progress. The symbol, now recognized as a national icon, will be featured on various items, including bank notes and driving licenses, and its use is expected to be more flexible under new legislation passed by Parliament.

site_title: New Year's Eve countdown fireworks to return to Marina Bay
summary: Singapore's Marina Bay will host the return of New Year's Eve countdown fireworks, titled "Star Island," after a two-year hiatus due to the pandemic. The event, organized by the Urban Redevelopment Authority, will feature a multi-sensory experience with state-of-the-art technologies and will kick off on Dec 1 with various activities. The fireworks display will be put up by Avex Asia, the company behind the 2020 multi-sensory show featuring 500 drones. Vaccination-differentiated safe management measures may be in place for the event.

site_title: He defies attacks, death threats in fight to end child exploitation
summary: A man who was enslaved for 17 years at a brick kiln in India's Punjab state has bravely come forward to expose the exploitation. He and his wife were tricked into slavery and forced to work without pay. After escaping, he sought help from Nobel laureate Kailash Satyarthi, who has been fighting to end child exploitation. The man's story aims to save his daughter from a similar fate, highlighting the ongoing issue of child labor and human trafficking in India. His courage is seen as a crucial step in raising awareness and sparking change.

site_title: Zaqy witnesses joint exercise by SAF, US Army in Oklahoma
summary: Senior Minister of State for Defence Zaqy Mohamad witnessed a combined live-firing exercise by the Singapore Armed Forces (SAF) and the US Army in Oklahoma. The Exercise Daring Warrior, the ninth edition, began on August 28 and involved approximately 180 personnel from both forces. Zaqy expressed confidence in the SAF's operational capabilities, highlighting the importance of overseas training opportunities for the military. The exercise deepened cooperation between the two armies and allowed the SAF to benchmark itself against the US counterpart, strengthening defence relations between Singapore and the US.

site_title: ST video series shows how S'pore tackles waste problem
summary: Singapore aims to reduce daily waste sent to its only landfill on Semakau Island by 20% by 2026 and 30% by 2030, potentially extending its lifespan to 2035. The country's domestic recycling rate was 13% in 2020-2021 and 17-22% from 2017-2019, largely due to contamination from food and liquid waste. A six-part video series, "Our Better Nature," explores the issue and proposes solutions to improve recycling efforts, with the goal of increasing the recycling rate and prolonging the landfill's lifespan.

site_title: How the four national symbols came about, and guidelines on their use
summary: Singapore has formally recognized four new national symbols: the lion head, public seal, national flower Vanda Miss Joaquim, and national pledge. The lion head was introduced in 1986 as an alternative to the national flag, while the public seal represents the Republic of Singapore and is affixed to state documents. The national flower, Vanda Miss Joaquim, was chosen in 1981 for its resilience and year-round blooming quality. The national pledge, which was drafted in 1966, promotes national pride and exists in four languages. These symbols will be used alongside the state flag, state crest, and National Anthem.

site_title: Our Better Nature video series: Tackling Singapore's waste problem
summary: Singapore's only landfill on Semakau Island is filling up at an alarming rate, prompting plans to reduce daily waste sent to the landfill by 20% by 2026 and 30% by 2030. The country aims to prolong the landfill's lifespan beyond its original "use by" date of 2045. Recycling efforts have been hindered by contamination, with a domestic recycling rate of just 13% in 2020 and 2021. A new video series, "Our Better Nature," aims to address the issue and explore ways to improve waste management in Singapore.

site_title: Credit Suisse trust admits failure to flag rogue transfers from client's account
summary: A Credit Suisse trust has admitted to failing to notify its billionaire client, Bidzina Ivanishvili, of unauthorized transfers from his account. The admission comes during a trial in Singapore, where Ivanishvili is suing the trust for $800 million in damages. The trust's shift in strategy may limit its potential liability, as it previously argued it was not responsible for investment decisions. The move could impact a separate case in Bermuda, where Ivanishvili won a $607 million judgment against Credit Suisse Life, which is appealing the decision.

site_title: State flags at S'pore govt buildings flown at half-mast as mark of respect
summary: Singapore's state flags were flown at half-mast as a mark of respect for Queen Elizabeth II's state funeral in London. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong expressed condolences to King Charles III and the British people, praising the Queen's sense of duty and contributions to the UK, Commonwealth, and world. President Halimah Yacob attended the funeral, alongside officials from the Istana and MFA, as the world bid farewell to the Queen, a symbol of hope and stability.

site_title: Iran ready to slash oil prices to counter Russian flow to China
summary: Iran is prepared to lower oil prices to counter Russia's rise as China's top supplier, following EU rejection. Russia has become China's primary crude oil source, while Iran seeks to defend its market share. Industry sources indicate that Iran will cut prices of its sanctioned crude stored in Singapore waters. This move aims to maintain its influence in the Chinese market, which has been a significant loss due to EU sanctions.

site_title: 'Buy now, pay later' growing more popular with consumers
summary: The "buy now, pay later" (BNPL) option is gaining popularity, with consumers able to borrow money for short periods to pay for purchases. Industry players say they have safeguards in place to limit risk of overspending, such as suspending accounts when users fail to meet payment deadlines. Despite concerns, BNPL transactions in Singapore rose to $440 million last year, accounting for less than 1% of all credit and debit card payments. A global survey found that 18% of Singaporeans aged 18-64 have used BNPL schemes, and 36% are likely to use them in the future.

site_title: Terra co-founder may be trying to escape probe, prosecutors say
summary: South Korean prosecutors believe Terra co-founder Do Kwon may be trying to evade redress over the $60 billion cryptocurrency collapse. He has denied being on the run despite moving from South Korea to Singapore, where he is no longer located. An arrest warrant has been issued, and officials are seeking his cooperation in multiple jurisdictions. Do Kwon faces charges in South Korea, and his passport could be revoked, requiring him to return to Seoul within 14 days. Regulatory scrutiny of stablecoins is intensifying, and the collapse has triggered probes in the US and other countries.

site_title: Company Briefs: Volkswagen Oyo Hotels Sun Life
summary: Volkswagen is set to raise up to €9.4 billion from the IPO of its sports-car maker Porsche, valuing the company at €70-€75 billion. European markets have been largely shut to IPOs due to the energy crisis and rising interest rates. Oyo Hotels, an Indian start-up, is reviving plans for a stock market debut, targeting an IPO in early 2023. Sun Life Singapore has signed an MOU with the Community Chest to support charities and philanthropic giving, committing $500,000 over five years.

site_title: Some Singapore staff affected in Shopee's latest job cuts
summary: Shopee, the e-commerce arm of Sea, has announced its latest round of job cuts, affecting a low single-digit percentage of staff in Singapore and other regional markets. The affected employees will receive "appropriate compensation packages" in line with market norms. The cuts come as part of the company's ongoing cost-cutting measures to achieve self-sufficiency, amid a challenging global environment and declining technology stocks. Shopee's parent company has also trimmed staff at its gaming arm Garena and research unit Sea Labs in recent months.

site_title: Criticism of S'pore death penalty overstated: Shanmugam
summary: Singapore's Home Affairs and Law Minister K. Shanmugam has defended the country's death penalty, stating that international criticism is overstated and a survey shows it's a strong deterrent for would-be traffickers. He cited a survey indicating 80% of Singaporeans agree with the death penalty, and 83% outside Singapore see it as effective in deterring crime. Shanmugam also highlighted the Netherlands' description as a "narco state" and Sweden's gang violence issues, suggesting that the EU has its own problems with crime.

site_title: Business-class airfares soaring beyond firms' budgets
summary: Business-class airfares have soared beyond companies' budgets, with a return flight from New York to Sydney costing over $20,000, nearly double pre-pandemic prices. Airlines struggle to reactivate fleets and staff to meet growing demand, contributing to limited seat availability and higher fares. Business-class airfares are expected to rise 45% this year and 6.2% in 2023, while corporate travel remains on shaky ground due to virus-related lockdowns and the shift to video calls. Airlines risk losing corporate travel revenue if they don't attract back business customers, who previously fueled their profitability.

site_title: More Chinese stop paying mortgages amid building standstill
summary: Chinese home buyers are increasing their threat to stop mortgage payments amid stalled construction projects, following a two-month protest that began in late June. The boycott, which has already affected 342 projects, has been fueled by a lack of progress at work sites and no clear guidance from local authorities. Regulators have offered loan payment holidays and pledged to expedite construction, but home buyers remain skeptical, with some planning to halt payments if construction doesn't resume after a six-month moratorium. The mortgage boycott has added to concerns about a prolonged slump in China's property market.

site_title: Markets in Asia fall on fears of another outsized Fed rate hike
summary: Stock markets in Asia fell on Monday due to concerns over another outsized US Federal Reserve rate hike, with losses outweighing gains 295 to 188 in Singapore's broader market. Key bourses in Asia, including Malaysia, Hong Kong, and China, also closed in the red, with the Straits Times Index down 0.4% and the Shanghai Composite Index down 0.35%. Market strategist Charu Chanana warned of volatility ahead, citing a potential Bank of England rate increase and market holidays commemorating Queen Elizabeth II.

site_title: China Vanke unit seeks up to $1.1b in HK IPO with Temasek among investors
summary: A Hong Kong IPO by Onewo, the property management unit of China Vanke, is set to raise up to HK$6.2 billion (S$1.11 billion). The firm is offering 116.7 million shares at HK$47.10 to HK$52.70 each. Singapore's Temasek and China Chengtong Holdings Group are among the six cornerstone investors agreeing to purchase up to US$280 million worth of shares. The IPO aims to provide a guide on China's developer assets and follows a series of billion-dollar listings in Hong Kong. Proceeds will help boost China Vanke's cash coverage of short-term debt.

site_title: Next 48 hours
summary: The article provides schedules for tennis tournaments over the next two days. The ATP Tour events include the Metz Open and San Diego Open, while the WTA Tour features the Pan Pacific Open. Viewing details are provided for each tournament on various channels, including Singtel TV and StarHub. The schedules cover Day 2 and Day 3 of the events, with start times varying across channels.

site_title: In Channel crosser's feat lies a lesson in pushing limits
summary: Li Ling Yung-Hryniewiecki, 37, attempted to cross the English Channel solo, facing challenges such as salt water corrosion and exhaustion. Despite doubts and fatigue, she refused to give up. Her determination is seen as a lesson in pushing limits, as she navigates the physically and mentally demanding feat. Yung-Hryniewiecki's refusal to stop is a testament to her resolve and perseverance, making her a remarkable figure in the world of long-distance swimming.

site_title: De Zerbi to replace Potter at Brighton
summary: Brighton & Hove Albion has appointed Roberto de Zerbi as their new manager on a four-year contract, replacing Graham Potter who left for Chelsea. De Zerbi, 43, has experience in Serie A and Ukraine, guiding Sassuolo to eighth-placed finishes and Shakhtar Donetsk to the Ukrainian Super Cup. Brighton chairman Tony Bloom praised de Zerbi's playing style, saying it will suit the existing squad. De Zerbi takes over as the team prepares to face Liverpool on October 1.

site_title: Oxley Garden up for collective sale again at $200m minimum price
summary: Oxley Garden, a 1960s freehold residential site in District 9, Singapore, has been relaunched for collective sale by tender at a minimum price of $200 million, unchanged from its earlier attempt. Over 80% of owners have consented to the sale at this price. The site, comprising 46 walk-up apartments, has a total land area of 58,207 sq ft and can accommodate a GFA of up to 93,770 sq ft. The tender closes on November 1.

site_title: IPO epicentre shifts east to China as US market weakens
summary: The global IPO market has shifted east to China, with stock listings in Asia raising a record $104 billion this year, accounting for 68% of global volume. In contrast, US IPOs have seen a significant decline, with 14% of global volume, due to market volatility and rising interest rates. Chinese IPOs, particularly on mainland exchanges and in Hong Kong, have driven the shift, with six of the 10 largest listings globally this year coming from Chinese companies. US market conditions have become unfavorable, forcing highly anticipated listings to be pushed back or scrapped.

site_title: Sports World
summary: A French Ligue 1 match between Nice and Angers ended in controversy when Nice defender Jean-Clair Todibo was red-carded in just 9 seconds for tripping an opponent. The game continued with Angers winning 1-0. Meanwhile, Bayern Munich received backing from CEO Oliver Kahn after a poor run, and the Las Vegas Aces won the WNBA Championship with a 78-71 victory over the Connecticut Sun.

site_title: Europe gas futures fall as nations act to ease crisis
summary: European natural gas futures plummeted to their lowest level in almost two months, dropping 8.3% on Monday as nations implement measures to combat the energy crisis. Germany, Britain, and others plan to spend billions to reduce reliance on Russian imports, rescue local energy companies, and cap prices. The European Commission's proposals include raising €140 billion from energy companies and implementing mandatory curbs on peak power demand. Other countries, such as France and Britain, are also developing plans to support households and businesses, but the effectiveness of these measures will be tested ahead of the heating season's start.

site_title: Osaka wants to emerge from slump at Pan Pacific
summary: Naomi Osaka, the 24-year-old Japanese tennis player, admitted that 2022 has been a difficult year, stating it was "more down than up." Osaka has plummeted to 48th in the women's tennis world rankings after a slump that has seen her crash out of her last three tournaments. She is seeking to break out of her slump at the Pan Pacific Open in Tokyo, where she is the reigning champion. Osaka faces stiff competition from top players like Caroline Garcia and Elena Rybakina, and is focused on rebuilding her confidence and being at peace with herself.

site_title: Economists see recession in euro area as highly likely
summary: Economists predict a highly likely euro area recession, with 80% chance of two straight quarters of contraction in the next 12 months. Germany, the largest economy, is expected to shrink as early as this quarter due to energy rationing concerns and record-high inflation rates. The European Central Bank (ECB) is predicted to pause rate hikes but lift interest rates higher, with a 75 basis-point increase expected at the October policy meeting. Inflation is forecast to peak at 9.6% in the final quarter, far exceeding the ECB's 2% target until 2024.

site_title: Racial abuse of Vinicius mars Real's derby win
summary: Atletico Madrid supporters were filmed racially abusing Real Madrid's Brazilian forward Vinicius Junior outside their stadium ahead of a Madrid derby match. The incident involved hundreds of fans singing "Vinicius, you are a monkey" and making monkey noises. La Liga has filed a written complaint with the Anti-Violence Commission, and financial penalties against Atletico are likely. Vinicius and Real Madrid have condemned the abuse, with Vinicius stating he won't stop celebrating his cultural heritage. The incident follows criticism of Atletico's head of the Spanish Football Agents Association for his comments on Vinicius' celebrations.

site_title: First victory as new world no. 1
summary: Spain secured its first Davis Cup quarter-final spot as Carlos Alcaraz defeated South Korea's Kwon Soon-woo, sending the team to face Croatia. Matteo Berrettini helped Italy secure a top spot in their group with a victory over Sweden. Spain's win marks its sixth title in the tournament. Andy Murray played a dead rubber for Britain, defeating Kazakhstan's Dmitry Popko, but his team's losses to the US and Netherlands mean they will miss the quarter-finals. The knockout rounds will be played in Malaga from November 22 to 27.

site_title: Song saving himself
summary: Song Ui-young, a 28-year-old midfielder for the Lion City Sailors, has withdrawn from the Singapore national team due to a niggling ankle injury. The decision came despite the team's medical team clearing him to play, as he prioritized self-preservation to avoid further injury. Song's absence is a setback for the team ahead of two friendlies in Vietnam and the upcoming AFF Championship. His club, the Sailors, are supportive of his decision, and the team will now focus on the matches at hand.

site_title: Premier League talking points
summary: Tottenham Hotspur manager Antonio Conte believes his squad is closer to winning silverware after leaving star player Son Heung-min on the bench until the 59th minute of a 6-2 win against Leicester City. Conte stated his goal is to bring the team to a "superior level" and not just maintain mediocrity. Meanwhile, Aston Villa secured a 1-0 win over Southampton, with manager Steven Gerrard embracing the team's "ugly" performance. Arsenal continued their strong start to the season with a 3-0 win over Brentford, but Brentford boss Thomas Frank questioned the Gunners' title credentials.

site_title: Lee dedicates win to grandpa, her No. 1 fan
summary: Former world amateur No. 1 Andrea Lee won her first career LPGA Tour title at the Portland Classic with a 72-hole score of 19-under 269. Lee, 24, fired a six-under 66 in the final round to beat Ecuador's Daniela Darquea by one stroke. The victory marks Lee's first win since losing her LPGA Tour playing rights last year, and she dedicated it to her grandfather, who died in November 2021, calling him her "No. 1 fan."

site_title: Injured stewart, Beasley on the mend
summary: Australian jockeys Ronnie Stewart and Danny Beasley are recovering from injuries sustained while riding in Kranji. Stewart has a wrist injury and is expected to be out for at least two to three weeks, while Beasley has a mouth injury and may ride again this Saturday. Both jockeys aim to return to the saddle quickly, with Stewart hoping to ride again by October 15.

site_title: Singdollar may become rare global winner on further MAS tightening
summary: The Singapore dollar is expected to remain a rare winner against the US dollar if the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) tightens its exchange rate policy in October, according to several banks. Goldman Sachs, Citigroup, and MUFG Bank are bullish on the currency, citing an expectation of policy tightening to combat rising core inflation. The MAS is forecast to extend its policy tightening for the fourth time this year, potentially leading to a 1% gain for the local currency against the US dollar by year-end. However, a policy change is not guaranteed, and the currency could fall to 1.42 if MAS decides to keep its policy unchanged.

site_title: Nike's latest shirt dubbed 'grocery store bagger'
summary: US tennis player Frances Tiafoe's Nike shirt at the US Open has sparked attention, with many calling it the "grocery store bagger" due to its unusual design. The shirt, worn by Tiafoe and two other players, features a maroon color with neon orange accents and a horizontal neckline. While the design was polarizing, Nike's history of outfitting athletes in unconventional attire has been a hallmark of the company's approach, as seen in past examples such as Andre Agassi's denim shorts and Rafael Nadal's white clam-diggers. This approach challenges convention and grabs attention.

site_title: Spain win fourth title in six outings
summary: Spain won their fourth Eurobasket title in six outings, defeating France 88-76 in the final at the Mercedes-Benz Arena in Berlin. Spain dominated from start to finish, led by Juancho Hernangomez's 27 points, and held off a late French comeback. The Spanish team, featuring eight debutants, continued to prove their dominance in European basketball. France's Rudy Gobert and Evan Fournier led their team, but ultimately fell short. Spain's Willy Hernangomez was named the tournament's Most Valuable Player.

site_title: I'd die for coach Deschamps: Pavard
summary: French defender Benjamin Pavard expressed his loyalty to coach Didier Deschamps, saying he would "die for him on the pitch." This statement comes amid uncertainty and crisis surrounding the French national team, including reports of inappropriate behavior by president Noel Le Graet and allegations of cover-ups. Coach Deschamps responded to the reports, calling them "lies, absurdities" that create a "climate not the most calm and serene." France is struggling, having lost four consecutive matches, and will be without talisman Paul Pogba for the current international break due to knee surgery.

site_title: Smith wants verdict on ranking points
summary: Cameron Smith, winner of LIV Golf's Chicago event, is seeking a decision on whether he and other competitors will receive world ranking points. LIV Golf applied for recognition in July, but its file remains under review. Smith, who earned exemption into the four Majors for at least the next five years, believes a resolution is needed soon to determine his eligibility. The decision could impact his ability to compete in Majors, as organizers have not changed their qualifying rules.

site_title: Hakim gets 2 months
summary: Reigning champion apprentice jockey Hakim Kamaruddin was suspended for two months after being found guilty of failing to ride to the satisfaction of stewards in a Polytrack 1,600m Maiden event on September 10. The stewards cited two instances of Hakim's handling of his mount Engine Start, including failing to improve position and obstructing a clear run. The suspension, effective from September 18 to November 17, was based on Hakim's disciplinary record and personal circumstances, with an option for appeal.

site_title: Australia cry foul over ref's decision
summary: Australia has expressed concerns over a refereeing decision in a Rugby Championship Test against New Zealand, criticizing French referee Mathieu Raynal for a time-wasting penalty that led to a 39-37 All Blacks victory. The decision, deemed "clear cut" by All Blacks coach Ian Foster, saw Australia lose the Bledisloe Cup for a 20th consecutive year. Rugby Australia has urged World Rugby to take concerns about officiating seriously, as the sport continues to be dominated by officials and stop-start games. The incident has sparked calls for change, with coaches and pundits criticizing the use of the Television Match Official.

site_title: Saturday's Singapore Stipendiary Stewards' report highlights
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article:

Racing results from Singapore's Stipendiary Stewards' report are highlighted. Bionics and Hurricane secured wins in Races 1 and 2, respectively. However, several horses were penalized for unsportsmanlike behavior, including Free Fallin', who returned lame off-fore, and Lucky Charm, who failed to find the line. The stewards also advised jockey Krisna Thangamani to place his mounts under significant pressure. Other notable performances included Ninesixthreethree's win in Race 8 and the improved performance of Hurricane. The report highlights various incidents and issues in the racing community.

site_title: Powerlifting: Never too busy for a world-record feat, Farhanna keeps raising the bar
summary: National powerlifter Farhanna Farid rewrote her Under-52kg deadlift world record at the SEA Cup, lifting 201kg. Despite being busy with her job, coaching, and home renovation, Farhanna prioritized her training and achieved the feat. She was named the event's best female lifter and expressed her surreal feeling about breaking the record. Farhanna credits her hard work, discipline, and commitment to growing the sport as key factors in her success, with her next goal being a medal at the world championships.

site_title: Football: Van Gaal goes in search of 'penalty killer' for World Cup
summary: Dutch coach Louis van Gaal is focusing on finding a reliable penalty shooter ahead of the World Cup in Qatar, where the Netherlands play in Group A. Van Gaal has called up four goalkeepers for the upcoming Nations League matches and will test them in a special penalty shootout training session. He aims to identify the best penalty killer, a strategy that worked for him at the 2014 World Cup, and is considering including four goalkeepers in his 26-man squad for the tournament.

site_title: Hurricane too powerful
summary: Hurricane, a 4-year-old Shamexpress gelding, made a commanding comeback in his second start with a 33 1/4-length win in the $20,000 Open Maiden race at Kranji. Partnered by Simon Kok, the horse overcame a disappointing debut to storm to the front and outrun rivals. Trainer Tim Fitzsimmons attributed the difference to removing blinkers, which he believes showcased the horse's class. Hurricane's win mirrors his impressive barrier trials, and Kok is optimistic about the horse's potential for further growth.

site_title: Triple Time worth the wait in the last event
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The article provides form analysis for seven horse races in South Africa, including predictions for the winners and potential contenders. Triple Time is expected to dominate the finish in Race 7 after making impressive improvements. Other notable horses include Pegasus Peak, Selukwe, and Rosalie Runs, who are likely to make a strong impact. Candice Bass-Robinson's runners are expected to dominate the finish in Race 4, while the improving three-year-old colts King Mo and Red Impact are likely to feature prominently in Race 5. The article provides insights into the potential winners and contenders for each race.

site_title: Farhanna keeps raising the bar
summary: National powerlifter Farhanna Farid rewrote her Under-52kg dead lift world record at the South-east Asian (SEA) Cup, lifting 201kg. Despite managing her training, job, and coaching responsibilities, Farhanna achieved the feat, which she attributes to her hard work and discipline. She was named the event's best female lifter and expressed her surreal feeling about breaking the record, which represents Singapore's prowess on the world level. Farhanna plans to continue breaking records and competing in the world championships, where she aims to secure a medal.

site_title: Singapore Customs raids largest complex of car importers and dealerships
summary: Singapore Customs conducted a raid on Carros Centre, a 2.3 million sq ft complex housing multiple car importers and dealerships, on September 2. The raid targeted a licensed warehouse facility at 60 Jalan Lam Huat, where Customs officers inspected the premises. The move has sparked discussion in the motor industry, with Carros Centre being described as Singapore's largest vehicle complex. The raid's purpose and findings have not been publicly disclosed by Customs.

site_title: Wall Street ends higher after choppy trading ahead of Fed
summary: Wall Street closed higher on Monday after a choppy trading session, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq logging their worst weekly percentage drop since June. Investors await the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike at its policy meeting this week, with Fed funds futures showing a 15% chance of a 100 basis point increase. The Fed's actions are driving market sentiment, with inflation data and economic projections to be released on Wednesday expected to further influence the market.

site_title: Woman brandishing knife outside Tampines school stabs herself after stand-off with police
summary: A 53-year-old woman wielding a knife outside St Hilda's Secondary School in Tampines, Singapore, was arrested after a stand-off with police. The woman, who stabbed herself in the abdomen, was tasered and taken to hospital in stable condition. She was later arrested for possession of an offensive weapon, suspected drug-related offenses, and mental health issues. At least 10 police officers were involved in the incident, and investigations are ongoing.

site_title: Death penalty for drugs: International pressure overstated, says Shanmugam
summary: Singapore's Home Affairs and Law Minister K. Shanmugam has disputed international criticism of the country's death penalty for drugs, stating that the criticism is overstated. He cited a survey that shows the death penalty is a strong deterrent for traffickers and saves lives. Shanmugam also pointed out that many Western countries, such as the Netherlands and Sweden, have issues with drug-related violence and crime, but do not publicly discuss them. He emphasized that Singapore's tough stance on narcotics is intended to prevent the country from becoming like Western Europe or South-east Asia.

site_title: Football: Atletico fans filmed chanting racist abuse at Real's Vinicius
summary: Atletico Madrid supporters were filmed racially abusing Real Madrid's Vinicius Junior outside the Metropolitano Stadium ahead of the Madrid derby. Hundreds of fans could be heard chanting "Vinicius, you are a monkey" in a video published on social media. La Liga has denounced the incident and is filing a written complaint with the Anti-Violence Commission, with potential financial penalties for Atletico. Vinicius and Real have both released statements condemning the racist abuse, with the player stating he won't stop celebrating his cultural heritage.

site_title: 'Wild finish' helps Homa retain Fortinet title
summary: Max Homa won the PGA Tour's Fortinet Championship for a second straight year, securing a one-shot victory over Danny Willett with a birdie at the 72nd hole. Homa finished with a 16-under 272 total after a four-under 68 on Sunday. Willett, who took a one-shot lead at the 14th, missed a 31/2-foot birdie putt at the 18th, securing his third DP World Tour title since 2016. Taylor Montgomery finished third with an eight-under 64, and Justin Lower and An Byeong-hun shared fourth with a one-over 73.

site_title: Ex-teacher pleads guilty to anonymously harassing school principal, lecturer
summary: A 46-year-old former teacher pleaded guilty to two harassment charges for sending anonymous text messages, letters, and e-mails to a school principal and a female lecturer between 2018 and 2021. The offender, unhappy with the principal's management style, blamed him for a student's death and sent threatening letters, including some with Shakespearean quotes and death threats. The principal and lecturer received distressing messages, leading to increased security measures and changes in their daily lives. The offender faces sentencing on October 5.

site_title: Lithium resumes insane gains to add pressure on automakers
summary: The price of lithium carbonate, a key material for electric vehicle batteries, has surged to a new record of 500,500 yuan (S$100,584) a tonne in China, tripling in the past year and more than 1,150% higher than a pandemic low. This increase is putting pressure on automakers, with some suppliers hiking their rates and manufacturers reassessing prices. Supply is lagging behind rising forecasts for vehicle demand, and commodities producers are struggling to bring new projects online, leading to concerns over the sector's future.

site_title: Yanlord unit's consortium wins Lentor Central residential site tender for $481 million
summary: Yanlord Land Group's indirect subsidiary, UED Alpha, won the Lentor Central residential site tender with a bid price of $481 million, or $1,108 per sq ft per plot ratio. The development will feature about 470 units on a 144,714 sq ft site. The winning bid surpassed CapitaLand Development's $1,069 psf ppr and GuocoLand's $1,038 psf ppr. The parties plan to build a residential development within the Lentor Hills estate, with a maximum permissible gross floor area of about 434,140 sq ft.

site_title: Football: Late pullout from Lions squad necessary to feel '100 per cent', says Song Ui-young
summary: Singapore footballer Song Ui-young has withdrawn from the national team's friendlies in Vietnam due to a niggling ankle injury, despite having received medical clearance to play. The 28-year-old player cited the need for self-preservation and ensuring he feels "100 per cent" before returning to action. The move has raised eyebrows, with coach Takayuki Nishigaya praising Song's decision and expressing confidence in the two replacements. Song has made 12 appearances for the Lions, scoring three goals, and is eager to focus on his club team, Lion City Sailors, ahead of the Asean Football Federation Championship.

site_title: 'Buy now, pay later' getting popular: Providers in S'pore say safeguards in place to curb overspending
summary: Singapore's "buy now, pay later" option is gaining popularity, with consumers using it to make purchases that exceed their budgets. BNPL providers claim to have safeguards in place to curb overspending, but concerns remain about users getting mired in debt. The service allows users to borrow for short periods to pay for purchases at physical stores or online, with some users utilizing it for items they wouldn't otherwise afford. The trend raises concerns about overspending and debt accumulation among consumers.

site_title: President Halimah meets Malaysia's king in London
summary: President Halimah Yacob met Malaysia's King, Sultan Abdullah Ahmad Shah, in London for a 45-minute meeting during Queen Elizabeth II's state funeral. The meeting focused on strengthening the bilateral relationship between Singapore and Malaysia. Halimah expressed her look forward to hosting Sultan Abdullah for a state visit to Singapore next month. The King will visit Singapore from October 25 for a three-day trip, marking the first visit since the initial schedule was postponed.

site_title: Rugby: Wounded Australia write to World Rugby over refereeing concerns
summary: Rugby Australia has written to World Rugby, expressing concerns about refereeing after a contentious time-wasting decision in the Rugby Championship Test against New Zealand. French referee Mathieu Raynal penalized Australian fly half Bernard Foley, leading to a try by Jordie Barrett and a 39-37 All Blacks victory. The incident sparked criticism from coaches and pundits, with Rugby Australia urging World Rugby to address officiating issues. The issue is part of a broader debate about the impact of referees and the Television Match Official on the flow of the game, with some calling for changes to improve safety and fan experience.

site_title: Green Pulse Podcast: What’s at stake for South-east Asia at COP27 climate conference
summary: The COP27 climate change conference, set to take place in Egypt, is crucial for South-east Asia as it addresses extreme weather events and climate change impacts. Senior WWF Singapore advisor Sandeep Rai discusses three key topics: adapting to climate change, funding for adaptation, and loss and damage despite efforts. The conference aims to avoid the harshest climate change impacts, with South-east Asia expected to be heavily affected, and delegates from almost 200 nations will gather to work out solutions.

site_title: Green transformation means more than just profit for these companies
summary: Singapore companies are taking bold steps towards a more sustainable future, with environmental services company Chye Thiam Maintenance and luxury hotel brand W Singapore leading the way. CTM has implemented materials recovery facilities, e-waste recycling, and electric lorries, reducing waste and incineration costs. W Singapore has introduced sustainable practices such as a small eco-garden, food waste compactors, and energy-efficient lighting, saving 39% of electricity and 8,000 cubic meters of water annually. Both companies believe that sustainability is a collective effort and aim to inspire others to adopt eco-friendly practices, with CTM giving talks on its green practices and W Singapore's initiatives aligning with national efforts to advance sustainable development and achieve carbon neutrality by 2030.

site_title: Man fined $2k for scratching car parked in his favourite spot in NUS
summary: A crane operator, Pang Kok Wai, was fined $2,000 for scratching a car parked in his favourite spot at the National University of Singapore (NUS) on March 9, 2022. Pang, 48, pleaded guilty to committing mischief after damaging the car, which had a $428 repair bill. The incident occurred eight days after Pang had scratched another car in the same space. Pang's stress at the time, including a hospitalised father and work issues, was taken into consideration during his sentencing.

site_title: In Channel crosser's feat lies a lesson in limits
summary: Li Ling Yung-Hryniewiecki, the first Singaporean woman to swim the English Channel, faced numerous challenges during her 11-hour journey, including saltwater corrosion, tidal changes, and exhaustion. Despite these obstacles, she refused to give up, drawing inspiration from her determination. Yung-Hryniewiecki's feat serves as a lesson in pushing beyond perceived limits and persevering in the face of adversity, inspiring others to adopt a similar mindset. Her remarkable achievement showcases her resilience and unwavering commitment to her goal.

site_title: Football: Injured Phillips could return for World Cup but may need surgery: Guardiola
summary: Manchester City midfielder Kalvin Phillips, who has struggled with injuries since joining the club, is sidelined due to a recurring shoulder problem. The 26-year-old has seen limited competitive action and will miss England's Nations League games. City manager Pep Guardiola believes Phillips could return in time for the World Cup, but there is a possibility he may need surgery to resolve the issue, with the doctor advising a longer recovery period.

site_title: Man jailed four months for submitting falsified payslips to Citibank to get a loan
summary: A 28-year-old man, Noah Loo Yu Hong, was sentenced to four months in jail for submitting falsified payslips to Citibank to obtain a $12,920 loan. Loo had worked with a friend, Eugene Yap Siang, to forge payslips stating he earned $6,350 a month, despite being unemployed. The scheme, which involved six others, resulted in Citibank approving 20 loan applications with falsified income documents. Loo has since made restitution, paying Citibank $12,920, along with finance charges.

site_title: BT Mark To Market Podcast: What’s next for Frasers Hospitality Trust?
summary: Senior Correspondent Ben Paul discusses the proposed privatization of Frasers Hospitality Trust (FHT) and its potential rejection by minority holders. The proposed move aimed to address FHT's poor performance, but minority investors voted against it, citing flaws in the trust's overall strategy. FHT may need a broad reconstitution of its portfolio to recover.

site_title: Asia-Pacific agencies meet to share ideas on prison management after 2-year hiatus
summary: The Asian and Pacific Conference of Correctional Administrators, hosted by Singapore, resumed after a two-year hiatus due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Officials from 21 countries attended the five-day virtual conference to discuss prison management and share information on topics such as emergency response and offender rehabilitation. The theme "forging new frontiers in corrections" aims to improve prison practices through data sharing and collaboration. Second Minister Josephine Teo emphasized the importance of technology and data in rehabilitation programs, and highlighted the new Employment Preparation Scheme, which allows offenders to undergo skills training and education before release.

site_title: Lion head crest designer so obsessed that he 'ate and slept with the lion'
summary: Singapore's iconic lion head crest, designed by Michael Lee in 1986, has been formally recognized as a national symbol by Parliament. The minimalist design, which features a bold red lion head, was chosen for its graphic power and connection to the city's history. Lee, who ate and slept with the lion during his design process, believes the symbol represents the nation's ideals of democracy, peace, and progress. The design has been used on various national symbols, including bank notes and driving licenses, and Lee feels a sense of satisfaction seeing it used across the island.

site_title: Shorter grace period and new $3 waiting fee for Gojek from Sept 26
summary: Gojek will implement a shorter 4-minute grace period for passengers to reach the pickup point before a $3 waiting fee is applied, starting Sept 26. A total fee of $9 is capped for waiting. The fee applies to GoCar, GoCar XL, and GoCar Premium services, but not GoTaxi. Drivers will receive the fees, which will be charged to passengers. Passengers can request reviews if they believe they are wrongly charged, and Gojek will immediately match a new driver if a trip is cancelled.

site_title: Iran ready to slash oil prices to counter Russia's growing sales to China
summary: Iran is preparing to cut the prices of its sanctioned crude oil to around $5 to $7 per barrel to defend its market share in China, where Russia has emerged as the top crude oil supplier. Iran has around 90 million barrels of crude stored on ships in international waters, and offering discounts is seen as a sign that it has given up hope of being relieved of US sanctions. The move comes as negotiations to revive the 2015 nuclear deal have fallen through, and demand from China has been affected by its zero Covid-19 strategy.

site_title: BT Money Hacks Podcast: Certain collectibles may beat inflation
summary: A recent podcast by The Business Times discusses whether collectibles can serve as a hedge against inflation. According to Nannette Hechler-Fayd’herbe, chief investment officer at Credit Suisse, certain collectibles may perform well in high-inflation regimes. However, not all collectibles respond equally to inflation, with some categories being more resilient than others. The key takeaway is that investing in collectibles for passion or profit is crucial, and categorizing them by their inflation response can help investors make informed decisions.

site_title: Football: Arteta's decision to bring on 15-year-old based on 'gut feeling'
summary: Arsenal manager Mikel Arteta made the historic decision to bring on 15-year-old Ethan Nwaneri as a substitute in a 3-0 win against Brentford, becoming the youngest player in English Premier League history. Nwaneri, 15 years and 181 days old, replaced Fabio Vieira in the second minute of stoppage time, breaking Liverpool's record set by Harvey Elliott in 2019. Arteta attributed the decision to a "gut feeling" and emphasized the club's commitment to developing talent, stating Nwaneri has a "talent that has to be developed in the next two or three years."

site_title: Sea plans to fire 3% of Shopee Indonesia staff as regional job cuts begin
summary: Sea Limited, a Singapore-based company, plans to fire 3% of Shopee Indonesia staff as part of a regional job cut to curb losses and win back investors. The layoffs, affecting approximately 2,000 employees, will be notified on Monday. The move is part of a broader effort to optimize operating efficiency and achieve self-sufficiency across the business. The company has lost significant market value since October due to concerns about its financial prospects in a rising interest rate environment.

site_title: Football: Bayern CEO Kahn backs coach Nagelsmann despite poor league form
summary: Bayern Munich CEO Oliver Kahn has expressed dissatisfaction with the team's poor league form, but remains confident in head coach Julian Nagelsmann. Bayern, currently fifth in the Bundesliga, has not won in four games and has not scored in a league match in 87 matches. Despite this, Kahn urges the team to respond with an attacking performance against Bayer Leverkusen on September 30, stating that Nagelsmann is "totally convinced" of his abilities and that the team must fully attack to turn their season around.

site_title: More than 18,000 Novavax Covid-19 shots given, with rare serious reactions: HSA
summary: The Health Sciences Authority (HSA) in Singapore reported 28 adverse effects from 18,073 doses of Novavax Covid-19 vaccine, with 5 serious cases of anaphylaxis and allergic reactions. These reactions occurred in individuals with previous allergic reactions or medical histories. The patients have recovered, and HSA advises avoiding strenuous physical activity for two weeks after vaccination to mitigate potential risks. The incidence of adverse reactions remains low, with 0.12% of mRNA vaccine reports and 0.007% of mRNA vaccine serious reactions.

site_title: Some Singapore staff affected in Shopee's latest job cuts
summary: Shopee, the e-commerce arm of Sea, has announced its latest round of job cuts affecting employees in Singapore and other regional markets. The layoffs include staff in human resources, regional operations, marketing, and product and engineering. Affected employees will receive "appropriate compensation packages" in line with market norms. This move is part of Sea's ongoing cost-cutting efforts, following earlier staff cuts in its ShopeeFood and ShopeePay teams, Garena, and research and development unit.

site_title: Police officer believed to have fired 2 shots in the air before shooting himself in Bayfront Ave
summary: A 29-year-old police officer from the Central Police Division in Singapore was found with a gunshot wound at Bayfront Avenue and died from his injuries. Preliminary investigations indicate no foul play, and the officer was believed to have fired two shots in the air before turning his gun onto himself. The police officer had joined the SPF in 2014 and was trained to identify signs of distress, but the cause of his death remains unknown. Investigations are ongoing, and the police have offered helpline numbers for those seeking support.

site_title: Tennis: Emotional Murray hopes to play in Davis Cup again
summary: Britain's Andy Murray expressed mixed emotions after potentially playing his last Davis Cup match, defeating Kazakhstan's Dmitry Popko 6-4, 6-3 in a dead rubber match. Murray, 35, led Britain to their first Davis Cup title in 79 years in 2015 but has struggled to regain top form since hip surgery. Despite feeling emotional, Murray hopes to be selected again, citing the competition for places in the team and uncertainty over his doubles role as obstacles. He remains optimistic, stating that if selected, he will definitely be involved.

site_title: New Year’s Eve countdown fireworks return to Marina Bay after a two-year break due to Covid-19
summary: Singapore's Marina Bay is set to host New Year's Eve fireworks after a two-year hiatus due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The Marina Bay Singapore Countdown 2023 will kick off on Dec 1 with various activities, culminating in the countdown on Dec 31. Avex Asia will display the fireworks, titled Star Island, which will feature a multi-sensory experience. The event will include a carnival, shows, and a food fiesta, with nightly light projection shows and free performances. Vaccination-differentiated safe management measures may be in place, with details to be announced later.

site_title: Europe gas drops as nations ramp up measures to ease crisis
summary: European natural gas futures plummeted to their lowest level in almost two months as nations intensify efforts to combat the energy crisis ahead of the heating season. Benchmark prices dropped 8.3% on Monday, with countries like Germany, Britain, and France implementing measures to reduce reliance on Russian imports, cap prices, and rescue local energy companies. The European Commission's proposals aim to raise €140 billion from energy companies' earnings and include mandatory curbs on peak power demand. The effectiveness of these measures will be tested as the heating season approaches.

site_title: Tennis: Struggling Osaka aiming to break slump as Pan Pacific Open returns
summary: Naomi Osaka, the 24-year-old Japanese tennis player, is set to compete in the Pan Pacific Open, seeking to break her slump. After plummeting to 48th in the world rankings, Osaka has struggled with injuries and poor form, including first-round defeats at the French and US Opens. She aims to rebuild her confidence and move forward, drawing inspiration from tennis legend Serena Williams, who retired after the US Open. Osaka begins her campaign against Daria Saville in the first round, hoping to regain her form and challenge the top contenders, including Caroline Garcia and Elena Rybakina.

site_title: Motorcyclists can't use Causeway to JB from Tuesday 11pm overnight due to works, have to go by Tuas
summary: Motorcyclists in Singapore will be restricted from crossing the Causeway at Woodlands Checkpoint from Tuesday 11pm to 4am due to signage replacement works at the Malaysia's Bangunan Sultan Iskandar CIQ Complex. Motorcyclists departing Singapore are advised to use Tuas Checkpoint instead. The restriction aims to minimize disruptions to daily land border crossings, which average over 300,000 people daily.

site_title: Terra founder Do Kwon may be trying to escape probes, prosecutors say
summary: South Korean prosecutors suspect Terra founder Do Kwon is trying to evade arrest for alleged breaches of capital-markets law. Kwon moved from South Korea to Singapore, where his Terraform Labs project collapsed, but his location is unclear. He denies being on the run, despite prosecutors citing "circumstantial evidence of escape" and an arrest warrant being issued. Kwon faces charges in South Korea and Singapore, and his passport could be revoked, potentially forcing him to return to Seoul within 14 days.

site_title: State flags at govt buildings at half-mast on Monday as mark of respect for Queen Elizabeth: PM Lee
summary: Singapore flew state flags at half-mast on Monday as a mark of respect for Queen Elizabeth II, who died at 96 at Balmoral Castle in Scotland on September 8. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong expressed condolences to King Charles III and the royal family, and President Halimah Yacob will attend the Queen's state funeral in London. Hundreds of thousands of people from around the world attended the Queen's lying-in-state and a reception at Buckingham Palace, with leaders including US President Joe Biden and French President Emmanuel Macron in attendance.

site_title: Euro area recession now looks almost inevitable to economists
summary: The euro area recession is now considered almost inevitable, with 80% of economists predicting two straight quarters of contraction in the next 12 months. Energy shortages, fueled by Russia's reduced gas shipments, are expected to cause economic activity to slump. Inflation is forecast to peak at 9.6% by year-end, significantly exceeding the European Central Bank's 2% target. The ECB is expected to pause its rate-hiking cycle but lift interest rates higher, with a possible 75 basis-point increase at the October policy meeting.

site_title: Golf: 'Ironman' Im capable of putting in the steel in Internationals' quest for victory
summary: South Korean golfer Im Sung-jae, known for his exceptional ball-striking and birdie-making skills, will be a key player for the International Team at the upcoming Presidents Cup. A two-time PGA Tour winner, Im has earned his spot on the team through merit and has proven his ability to perform under pressure. He is expected to team up with various partners and help the underdog International Team dethrone the powerful US team at Quail Hollow. Im aims to make a significant contribution to the team's quest for victory, which would be a historic moment for Asian golf.

site_title: Oxley Garden tries for collective sale again at unchanged $200m minimum price
summary: Oxley Garden, a 58,207 sq ft freehold residential site in District 9, Singapore, has been relaunched for collective sale at an unchanged minimum price of $200 million. Over 80% of owners have consented to the sale, and the site can accommodate a total GFA of up to 93,770 sq ft. The site is zoned "residential" and has a gross plot ratio of 1.4645, allowing for a 10% bonus GFA. The tender closes on November 1, 2022, with JLL and Brilliance Capital handling the sale.

site_title: Keep Jurong Bird Park and Jurong Hill as recreational green space, say heritage advocates
summary: Heritage advocates in Singapore are urging the authorities to retain the Jurong Bird Park and the adjacent Jurong Hill as a recreational green space, despite the park's planned relocation to Mandai. The bird park, set to vacate in January, is home to 3,500 birds and 130 staff. The area's significance extends beyond the bird park, with Jurong Hill holding a role in Singapore's early industrialisation programme. Advocates call for the preservation of iconic built features in the area, rather than announcing plans for its development.

site_title: Weekly Money FM Podcasts: The 'quiet quitting' phenomenon that is trending
summary: The "quiet quitting" phenomenon, where employees are choosing not to go above and beyond at work, is trending in South-east Asia. Experts attribute this shift to a new stage of evolution in the region, driven by changing workforce values and expectations. Key factors include burnout, work-life balance, and financial pressures. The trend is seen as a response to the pressures of modern work, with employees seeking more sustainable and fulfilling careers. As a result, some employers are re-evaluating their strategies to retain talent and create a more balanced work environment.

site_title: Building climate-resilient S'pore: National conversation involving individuals, all sectors launched
summary: Singapore launches a national conversation to build climate-resilient infrastructure, involving individuals, educational institutions, and organizations. Minister for Sustainability Grace Fu emphasizes the need for collective action to address climate change, citing potential extreme weather events, rising sea levels, and urban heat threats. The conversation will focus on sustainable economic growth, distribution of resources, and minimizing costs for future generations. Efforts include implementing a carbon tax, upskilling workers, and transforming industries to be more sustainable.

site_title: Golf: Australia's Cameron Smith wins his first LIV title in Chicago, bags US$4 million
summary: Cameron Smith of Australia won his first LIV Golf title at the Chicago Invitational, defeating Dustin Johnson and Peter Uihlein by three strokes. Smith, a reigning British Open champion, fired a 3-under 69 to finish at 13-under 203. The victory marked his first win since joining LIV Golf, which has attracted several high-profile PGA Tour defections. Smith's win comes with a $4 million prize, adding to his $25 million purse. The victory sends a message to critics of his decision to join the Saudi-backed series.

site_title: Crypto drops on pre-Fed jitters, Ether falls to 2-month low
summary: Cryptocurrencies, particularly Ether, plummeted on Monday due to pre-Fed jitters and the expected interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve. Ether fell 3.3% to a two-month low, trading at $1,350, while Bitcoin retreated below $19,500. The Ethereum Merge upgrade, aimed at reducing energy usage, is being undone by the inflationary environment, with investors bracing for volatility. Other tokens, such as XRP and Polkadot, also suffered significant losses, with XRP shedding 9.6% in a court case with the SEC.

site_title: STB to study new cruise and ferry infrastructure to meet growth in demand
summary: Singapore's cruise industry is expected to return to pre-pandemic levels by 2024. The Singapore Tourism Board (STB) has announced plans to study new cruise and ferry infrastructure to meet growing demand. The board has called a tender for a team of consultants, including experts in architecture and engineering, to conduct a survey. The study aims to ensure Singapore is prepared to capture the growing demand in the medium to long term.

site_title: Prices of diesel fall by 11-12 cents, petrol down by 6-19 cents
summary: Singapore's fuel pump prices fell over the weekend, with diesel prices dropping 11-12 cents per liter to $2.76-$2.77, and petrol prices falling 6-19 cents per liter. The latest adjustments follow a slide in oil and wholesale fuel prices due to global recession fears. Petrol prices are now at their lowest since February, with 92-octane petrol at $2.77 and 95-octane at $2.82.

site_title: Golf: Andrea Lee captures LPGA Tour's Portland Classic with final-round charge
summary: Andrea Lee won the Portland Classic with a 19-under 269 after firing a six-under 66 in the final round. Lee, a 24-year-old American, overcame a strong charge from Daniela Darquea to capture her first LPGA Tour title. Lee had previously lost her playing rights but battled back to reclaim her spot with top play and sponsor exemptions. She dedicated the victory to her late grandfather, who had always believed in her.

site_title: Man who allegedly assaulted stranger with penknife charged in court
summary: A 50-year-old man, Chia Chiew Boon, has been charged with using a penknife to assault 31-year-old Mr. Noel Yeo, leaving him with serious injuries to his chest and abdomen. The incident occurred at around 4am on Sunday outside Golden Mile Complex in Singapore. Chia was arrested and a penknife was seized. He will be remanded at the Institute of Mental Health for psychiatric observation and his case has been adjourned to October 3. The charges carry a maximum sentence of life imprisonment or up to 15 years with a fine and caning, but Chia's age prevents caning.

site_title: Bride sexually assaulted on wedding night, groomsman gets jail, caning
summary: A 42-year-old groomsman was sentenced to 7 years' jail and 6 strokes of the cane for sexually assaulting the bride on her wedding night in Singapore. The incident occurred in 2016 after the wedding dinner, when the groom's friend, who had been drinking, molested the bride in her bridal suite. The victim initially thought the person touching her was her husband, but realized it was not him after a confrontation. The couple has since divorced, and the offender plans to appeal against his conviction and sentence.

site_title: Singapore dollar may become rare global winner as MAS tightens
summary: The Singapore dollar is predicted to remain a rare global winner as the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is expected to tighten its exchange rate policy again next month to combat core inflation, which hit a 14-year high in July. Goldman Sachs, Citigroup, and MUFG Bank are bullish on the currency, with MUFG forecasting a 1.38 Singapore dollar to US dollar ratio by year-end. However, there is a risk that the MAS may keep its policy unchanged, potentially leading to a decline in the currency to 1.42 US dollars.

site_title: China Vanke's unit seeks up to $1.1b in Hong Kong IPO with Temasek among investors
summary: China Vanke's property management unit, Onewo, plans to raise up to HK$6.2 billion (S$1.1 billion) through a Hong Kong IPO, attracting investors including Singapore's Temasek. The IPO would provide a guide to ranking assets tied to China's developers, who have been under pressure due to Covid-19 lockdowns and cash-strapped home sales. Onewo offers residential services and tech solutions, and the listing joins other billion-dollar offerings in Hong Kong this year, amid a drought of large listings in the first half of the year. The IPO is expected to price shares on Thursday, Sept 29.

site_title: Business class for $28,000 means staff fly economy or not at all
summary: Business class flights have become unaffordable for companies due to soaring prices, with some routes costing over US$20,000 (S$28,000) for a return ticket. The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a tight travel market, with airlines struggling to reactivate fleets and bring back staff, resulting in limited flight capacity and seat availability. As a result, corporate travel is on shaky ground, and companies are opting for economy class or canceling trips altogether. Experts predict a 45% increase in business class airfares in 2022 and 6.2% next year, with some airlines charging over US$10,000 for premium return flights.

site_title: Workplace safety code of practice for bosses to be gazetted in October amid spike in deaths
summary: Singapore is set to gazette a workplace safety code of practice in October, aiming to improve the country's workplace safety culture. The code includes measures such as setting up internal reporting systems and demanding effective safety standards from suppliers. The move comes after 37 workplace fatalities this year, with the government seeking to prioritize safety despite Covid-19 challenges. The code applies to all industries and will be considered in court cases if companies commit offenses under the Workplace Safety and Health Act.

site_title: China's mortgage boycott quietly regroups as construction idles
summary: China's mortgage boycott, sparked by stalled construction on properties, has quietly regrouped with more home buyers threatening to halt mortgage payments. Despite authorities' assurances and efforts to revive the economy, no clear guidance has been given, and many projects remain idle. The boycott has expanded to 342 projects, with 2.3 trillion yuan ($464 billion) worth of loans at stake, and Beijing has set up a bailout fund to restore confidence. Home buyers warn they will stop all payments if construction does not resume, putting pressure on the government ahead of the Communist Party congress next month.

site_title: Pasir Ris Park carpark and nearby green plot to make way for public housing
summary: A 2.9ha parcel in Pasir Ris Park, including a carpark, will be converted into public housing, according to an approved amendment to the 2019 masterplan. The site is located next to a rail construction site for the East-West Line. Another 1.7ha plot adjacent to the park will also be developed for public housing, as assigned by the Urban Redevelopment Authority. The changes aim to increase housing supply in the area.

site_title: Insects can't adapt to drastic temperature changes, may be wiped out by climate change: Study
summary: A new study suggests that insects may be unable to adapt to drastic temperature changes, potentially leading to their extinction due to climate change. The research, led by the University of Bristol, found that insects can only tolerate small temperature shifts, making them vulnerable to extreme heat or cold. As a result, many insects may need to migrate to suitable climates or change their behaviors to survive. The study also highlights the importance of further research on climate resilience in under-represented insect species.

site_title: Singapore should aim for zero road death, says safety champion
summary: Singapore Road Safety Council chairman Bernard Tay advocates for the country to aim for zero road deaths, inspired by Vision Zero initiatives in countries such as Sweden, Canada, and the US. Tay considers this goal worthy, despite its potential difficulty.

site_title: Invest Talk Podcast: Thinking about retirement? Tips for CPF Life plans, spending and investing
summary: DBS' Lorna Tan, head of Financial Planning Literacy, shares retirement planning tips on the Invest Talk Podcast. Key considerations for retirement planning include deciding between different CPF Life plans and saving, spending, and shopping wisely. Tan advises listeners to consider their financial goals, risk tolerance, and time horizon when choosing a plan. She also provides guidance on how to save more, spend less, and make informed investment decisions. The episode aims to provide listeners with practical advice to manage their hard-earned money effectively.

site_title: Insects' inability to adapt to climate change may wipe them out: Study
summary: A new study suggests that insects may face extinction due to their inability to adapt to climate change. Researchers found that insects can only tolerate marginal temperature changes, making them vulnerable to drastic heating or cooling. For every 1°C shift in temperature, insects can adjust their survival range by only 0.092°C when rising and 0.147°C when cooling. This means many insects may need to migrate or change behaviors to survive, highlighting the need for further research on their responses to climate change.

site_title: Nearly a quarter of S'pore's power generation capacity due for replacement in next 5 years: EMA
summary: Singapore's power sector is facing a significant replacement challenge, with nearly a quarter of its generation capacity due for replacement within the next five years. The Energy Market Authority (EMA) is studying the impact of new gas plants entering the system before 2030 on its net zero emissions target by 2050. The sector contributes 40% of the country's carbon emissions, and replacing natural gas generators with low-carbon alternatives could affect the nation's plans to reduce emissions to 65 million tonnes by 2030.

site_title: Singapore should aim for zero road death, says safety champion
summary: Singapore should aim for zero road deaths, according to safety champion Mr. Bernard Tay, chairman of the Singapore Road Safety Council. Although Singapore has a low mortality rate of two deaths per 100,000 residents, it is not impossible to achieve zero road deaths. Tay advocates for adopting the "Vision Zero" initiative, which was started in Sweden in the 1990s and has been adopted by countries such as Canada and the US. This goal aims to eliminate all road fatalities through a combination of measures, including improved infrastructure, enforcement, and public awareness.

site_title: Golf: Late birdie lifts Max Homa to 2nd straight PGA Tour title at Silverado
summary: Max Homa won the PGA Tour's Fortinet Championship for a second straight year, defeating Danny Willett by one shot at the Silverado Resort in Napa, California. Homa fired a four-under 68 in the final round, his 16-under total of 272 securing the victory.
