Willett missed a 31/2-foot birdie putt at the 18th, which would have given him the win, instead settling for a three-under 69. Taylor Montgomery finished third with an eight-under 64. Homa's victory silenced critics suggesting he was only on the US Presidents Cup team due to LIV Golf defections.

site_title: Singapore couple build free bomb-resistant homes for Ukrainians
summary: A Singaporean couple, Rudy Taslim and Lam Bao Yan, are building bomb-resistant emergency homes for Ukrainian citizens affected by the war with Russia. Since the war started in February, they have built 200 homes with local partners, with plans to build 500 more by winter. The homes are designed to be cost-effective and use local-sourced materials, and are provided to those in need for free. The couple aims to provide holistic support, including medical care and counseling, to those they help, and encourages others to imagine what love and support look like in action.

site_title: Zaqy in US to see joint exercise by SAF and US Army, highlights importance of overseas training
summary: Senior Minister of State for Defence Zaqy Mohamad witnessed a combined live-firing exercise between the Singapore Armed Forces (SAF) and the US Army at Fort Sill in Oklahoma. The exercise, Exercise Daring Warrior, began on August 28 and involves approximately 180 personnel from both forces. Zaqy expressed confidence in the SAF's operational capabilities and highlighted the importance of overseas training opportunities, stating that they allow the SAF to conduct realistic and complex training that cannot be replicated in Singapore. The exercise is the ninth edition of the program, showcasing the strong defence relations between Singapore and the US.

site_title: Repealing Section 377A: What Parliament will have to do
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced plans to repeal Section 377A of the Penal Code, which criminalizes same-sex relationships between men. The repeal will allow Parliament to define the institution of marriage, eliminating the risk of the definition being challenged in court. The move aims to address long-standing concerns and promote inclusivity, although the exact timeline and implementation details have not been disclosed.

site_title: Help kids from lower-income homes read more
summary: A study by the National Institute of Education found that teenagers from lower-income families have fewer books at home and less home reading support, with 4 in 10 students on the Financial Assistance Scheme owning 10 books or fewer. In contrast, 3 in 10 non-FAS students own 50 books or more. The survey also revealed that students from lower-income families are less likely to enjoy reading, with 2 in 10 FAS students saying they enjoy reading compared to 10 in 10 non-FAS students.

site_title: New field guide to dragonflies and damselflies in S'pore
summary: A new field guide to dragonflies and damselflies in Singapore has been launched, identifying 136 species found in the country. The guide, titled "A Photographic Field Guide To The Dragonflies And Damselflies Of Singapore," features colorful photos of each species and notes on identifying characteristics. Ecologist Robin Ngiam hopes that the guide will encourage Singaporeans to appreciate the insect world and promote dragonfly watching as a way to experience nature. The guide is available for $69.30 and can be found at Kinokuniya.

site_title: New field guide on S'pore's dragonflies and damselflies records beauty of 136 species
summary: A new field guide on Singapore's dragonflies and damselflies has been released, featuring 136 species recorded in the country. The guide, titled "A Photographic Field Guide To The Dragonflies And Damselflies Of Singapore," was launched by ecologist Robin Ngiam and freelance writer Marcus Ng. The guide aims to promote a greater appreciation for the insect world and encourage wetlands conservation. It includes colourful photos and notes on identifying characteristics, making it accessible to both experienced enthusiasts and newcomers.

site_title: Teens from lower-income families need more support for reading
summary: A study by the National Institute of Education in Singapore found that teenagers from lower-income families are less likely to read and own books. Four in 10 students on the Financial Assistance Scheme (FAS) own 10 books or fewer, compared to two in 10 non-FAS students. The study also revealed that these students receive less home reading support and fewer enjoy reading. The findings highlight the need for more support for reading among teenagers from lower-income families.

site_title: Carpark at Pasir Ris Park, nearby green plot to make way for public flats
summary: A carpark at Pasir Ris Park is being converted into public housing as part of a 2.9ha parcel, with an adjacent 1.7ha plot also earmarked for the same purpose. The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) approved the amendment to its 2019 masterplan, reducing the need for greenery clearance in the carpark area. The development is expected to provide public housing units, but no specific details on the number of units or timeline have been announced.

site_title: S'pore firms impacted by tensions
summary: Singapore companies are most affected by US-China tensions in South-east Asia, with supply chain disruptions being the primary concern. A survey reveals local businesses are diversifying supply chains and entering new markets to mitigate risks. To survive, companies must demonstrate alignment with Singapore's neutrality amidst geopolitical turbulence.

site_title: Little Mighty Warriors garnering support to help those with dwarfism
summary: A local support group, Little Mighty Warriors, is helping families of children with achondroplasia, a genetic disorder causing dwarfism, by providing advice and resources. Founded by Joshua Khoo, a 30-year-old photographer with the condition, the group has 19 members, including children and teenagers. The organization aims to address health concerns, insurance issues, and bullying faced by those with achondroplasia. Little Mighty Warriors has also appealed for support for the drug Voxzogo, which can increase height and alleviate medical issues, but is currently not available in Singapore.

site_title: Chasing speed demons all in a day's work for female TP officer
summary: Sergeant Joey Png, a 34-year-old female Traffic Police officer, patrols the roads on a black BMW RT 1250, intimidating motorists with her imposing figure despite weighing only 53kg. As a member of the Special Operations Team, she tackles speeding, illegal racing, and VIP escorts. In the last two months, the Traffic Police dealt with 22,447 speeding-related violations, with 231 accidents related to speeding. Sgt Png passed the TP's circuit training in one try and is one of 12 female outriders in the force. Her calm demeanor helps de-escalate interactions with violators.

site_title: ST Explains: How is a law repealed and the Constitution amended?
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced the repeal of Section 377A of the Penal Code, which criminalizes sex between men. The government will also amend the Constitution to allow Parliament to define the institution of marriage. The repeal and constitutional amendment are part of a broader effort to modernize the country's laws, following months of public discussion. The process of repealing a law typically involves parliamentary approval and public consultation, while amending the Constitution requires a two-thirds majority in Parliament and ratification by at least two-thirds of the total number of elected members.

site_title: Positive steps to take when one feels trapped in a job
summary: A person feeling trapped in their job can address concerns by breaking down pros and cons of their role, re-evaluating their needs and aspirations, and working towards new goals. Experts suggest seeking input from family, friends, and coworkers, as well as speaking with supervisors or human resources. They emphasize the importance of taking small steps in the right direction and not comparing oneself to others. Ultimately, getting unstuck from a stagnant job is in the individual's control, and making progress is key to changing one's situation.

site_title: MOE to pilot computer game teaching moral lessons to upper primary pupils
summary: The Singapore Education Ministry (MOE) plans to pilot a computer game teaching moral lessons to upper primary pupils, starting next year. The game, developed for Primary 4 to 6 pupils, will simulate real social situations and ask pupils to respond to scenarios, with teachers leading discussions to reinforce learning. The game's data will help teachers understand pupils' responses and facilitate targeted interventions. MOE aims to promote empathy, care, respect, and moral reasoning skills in pupils, but Associate Professor Jason Tan notes that home support is crucial for long-lasting moral development.

site_title: askST Jobs: What can you do if you are unhappy and feel trapped in your current job role?
summary: Individuals feeling trapped in their current job role can take steps to address their concerns. Experts suggest breaking down the issue by listing pros and cons of the current job, re-evaluating needs and aspirations, and working towards new goals. Speaking with supervisors, HR, or colleagues can also be helpful in finding solutions. It's essential to remember that unhappiness at work can negatively impact performance and that getting unstuck is within one's control, according to career experts. By taking proactive steps, individuals can begin to break free from feelings of being trapped and find a more fulfilling career path.

site_title: Markets brace themselves for another big Fed rate hike
summary: The New York market experienced a sharp decline last Tuesday due to unexpectedly hot August inflation numbers, marking its worst single-day collapse since June 2020. This comes amidst fresh worries about the global economy following FedEx's profit warning last week. The Fed rate hike is expected to be another significant factor in the market's volatility, with investors bracing themselves for potential economic impacts.

site_title: Covid-19 main contributor here to excess deaths during pandemic
summary: Singapore's analysis found that 1,087 people, or 40% of the 2,490 excess deaths during the pandemic, died of other illnesses within 90 days of becoming infected with Covid-19. These deaths were aggravated by Covid-19, which worsened underlying medical conditions. Vaccination status played a role, with 28% of excess deaths involving unvaccinated individuals, despite only 5% of the eligible population being unvaccinated. The Ministry of Health attributed the low excess mortality to Singapore's pandemic response and high vaccine coverage, with an estimated 26 deaths per 100,000 population.

site_title: Must-reads
summary: A recent analysis found that over 1,000 excess deaths in Singapore were indirectly caused by Covid-19, with the virus exacerbating existing illnesses. In Japan, powerful storms caused widespread flooding and power outages, with nearly 200,000 homes left without power. Meanwhile, a study in Singapore revealed that teens from lower-income families are less likely to have access to books and reading support, leading to concerns about adult literacy. Additionally, Singaporeans are opening more savings accounts as interest rates rise to combat inflation.

site_title: S'pore couple build homes for Ukrainians affected by war
summary: A Singaporean couple, Rudy Taslim and Lam Bao Yan, are working to build bomb-resistant emergency homes for Ukrainians affected by the war. Since the war started in February, they have built 200 homes with local partners in the region, aiming to reach 500 by November. The modular homes, designed with cost-effectiveness in mind, are made from locally sourced materials and provide basic amenities. The couple, who have visited Ukraine twice, provide holistic support, including medical care and counseling, to the people they help, and their efforts aim to demonstrate "love and support" in action.

site_title: Amid geopolitical tensions, Singapore firms take no sides
summary: Singapore firms remain neutral amid geopolitical tensions, with many dependent on both the US and Chinese economies. Following US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan in August, tensions in the region increased, prompting some start-ups to review their capital sources and businesses to reassess markets and supply chains. Many Singapore companies, including those in the Association of Small and Medium Enterprises, do business with China, highlighting the country's reliance on the Chinese economy. This neutrality is a strategic move to mitigate potential risks.

site_title: Self-help groups like CDAC still play a vital role: PM Lee
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of ethnic-based self-help groups like the Chinese Development Assistance Council (CDAC) in providing tailored support to low-income families. These groups, which include Mendaki and the Singapore Indian Development Association, offer customized programs that address specific needs without raising racial or religious sensitivities. With funding from the Government and community donations, CDAC benefits over 18,000 households and will continue to support social mobility as Singapore's economy develops.

site_title: Still relevant in Singapore
summary: Singapore's ethnic-based self-help groups, such as the Chinese Development Assistance Council and Singapore Indian Development Association, remain relevant in the country's multiracial society, according to Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. These groups offer customized programs, additional aid to needy families, and issue-sensitive support, allowing them to address community needs without raising racial or religious tensions. They also facilitate philanthropic efforts among the well-off to support their own communities, making them a valuable resource in Singapore's diverse society.

site_title: MOE to pilot teaching moral lessons via computer game
summary: MOE plans to pilot a computer game teaching moral lessons to upper primary school pupils, aged 9-11, through virtual scenarios and tasks. The game, developed by the Ministry of Education, will be used alongside current lessons and resources, allowing teachers to lead discussions and reinforce social and emotional competencies. The game aims to simulate real social situations, such as helping a new classmate, and help pupils develop empathy and moral reasoning skills. The pilot is expected to begin next year, with the goal of improving character and citizenship education.

site_title: Top S'pore executives give their takes on impact of geopolitics in business world
summary: Singaporean business leaders are reviewing their sources of capital and supply chains due to recent geopolitical events. Industry players, including Dr. Lei Hsien-Hsien, Mr. Tan Zhiyong, Ms. Dora Hoan, and Mr. Joseph Gan, spoke about the impact of geopolitics on the business world. They cited the need to adapt to changing global circumstances and diversify their operations to mitigate risks. The review of sources and supply chains is a response to heightened tensions and uncertainty in the global market, highlighting the growing importance of resilience and adaptability in business.

site_title: Citibank S'pore launches digital-only offering to woo customers
summary: Citibank Singapore has launched Citi Plus, a digital-only wealth offering that lets customers earn interest of up to 2.8% per year. The account pays interest in five categories: spending, investing, insurance, mortgage, and savings, with bonus interest ranging from 0.1% to 0.8% per year. The bank aims to capture younger customers with a low barrier to entry, expecting them to use all categories to earn interest. This is part of a trend by local banks to raise interest rates on savings accounts, with other banks such as UOB, OCBC, and DBS also increasing rates.

site_title: Strategies for building an inflation-fighting portfolio
summary: Inflation remains a concern for consumers and investors, despite early signs of peaking. Stagflation risks have affected bond and equity markets, creating a double whammy for investors. The possibility of inflation remaining high for some time poses a challenge, making it difficult to build an effective inflation-fighting portfolio. Investors must consider strategies to mitigate inflation risks, despite the uncertainty of its future trajectory.

site_title: Next 48 hours
summary: No article content provided.

site_title: Strategies for building an inflation-fighting portfolio
summary: Inflation remains a concern, with early signs suggesting it may peak but potentially persist for some time. This poses a challenge for consumers and investors alike. The stagflation risks have negatively impacted bond and equity markets, creating difficulties for investors.

site_title: STB to look into boosting cruise, ferry infrastructure with demand set to surge
summary: The Singapore Tourism Board (STB) plans to study the need for new cruise and ferry infrastructure in Singapore to meet growing demand for cruises. A tender was called on September 6 for a team of consultants to conduct the survey, which will include experts in architecture, engineering, and other specialists. The study aims to ensure the country is ready to capture the surge in cruise demand in the medium to long term.

site_title: Banks see surge in savings account openings as interest rates rise
summary: US interest rates rising to tame inflation. In response, Singapore banks are seeing a surge in savings account openings as locals save more money. DBS Bank raised interest rates on its flagship savings account from 3% to 3.5% for balances between $50,000 and $100,000. Other lenders are also increasing interest rates, prompting Singaporeans to squirrel away more money in the bank.

site_title: Markets brace themselves for another big Fed rate hike
summary: The US market experienced a sharp decline last Tuesday, with the New York market suffering its worst single-day collapse since June 2020, following the release of unexpectedly hot August inflation numbers. This event has raised concerns about the Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates, potentially leading to an extended period of heightened volatility across risk assets. Investors are bracing themselves for another potential rate hike, which could impact market stability.

site_title: Top executives give their takes on impact of geopolitics in business world
summary: Top executives from Singapore firms have expressed concerns over the impact of recent geopolitical events on their businesses. Companies are reviewing their sources of capital and supply chains due to uncertainty and potential disruptions. Industry players share their perspectives on the effects of geopolitics on the business world, highlighting the need for adaptability and resilience. The review of capital and supply chains aims to mitigate potential risks and ensure long-term sustainability. This shift reflects the growing influence of geopolitics on business operations and the need for companies to navigate complex global landscapes.

site_title: Surge in savings account openings at banks as rates rise
summary: Singaporeans are increasing their savings by opening new accounts at banks and depositing more money after local lenders raised interest rates. DBS Bank recently raised the yield on its DBS Multiplier account from 3% to 3.5% for balances between $50,000 and $100,000, prompting a surge in new savings account openings. This trend is expected to continue as more banks follow suit with interest rate increases, allowing customers to earn higher returns on their deposits.

site_title: Murray wants last hurrah with Federer
summary: Andy Murray hopes to share a court with retiring Roger Federer at the Laver Cup in London, possibly in doubles. Federer announced his retirement due to injury issues, with Murray expressing it's a "sad, sad day" for the sport. The two will team up with Rafael Nadal and Novak Djokovic for Team Europe, which has won all four previous Laver Cup editions. Federer's participation is uncertain, but his coach believes he's aiming to play at the tournament, potentially in singles or doubles.

site_title: Amid geopolitical tensions, Singapore firms take no sides
summary: Singapore firms remain neutral amidst geopolitical tensions, with many dependent on a strong US and Chinese economy. Following US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taiwan, tensions rose, prompting businesses to reassess capital sources, markets, and supply chains, according to Association of Small and Medium Enterprises President Kurt Wee. The situation was deemed "alarming" by Wee, highlighting the impact on start-ups and small businesses in Singapore.

site_title: 84% of Lentor Modern condo sold on launch weekend
summary: Lentor Modern, a 99-year leasehold integrated private residential project, sold 508 units (84% of 605 units) during its launch over the weekend, with prices ranging from $1.07 million to $3.33 million. Despite higher home loan rates and an uncertain economic environment, demand from HDB upgraders and new families remains strong, with 92% of buyers being Singaporeans. The project's success is attributed to its convenience, lifestyle concept, and limited supply of new private residential launches.

site_title: PayPal to end sponsorship of Suns if team owner Sarver stays
summary: PayPal is ending its sponsorship deal with the Phoenix Suns if owner Robert Sarver stays, following an NBA investigation that found him using racist slurs and harassing female employees. The league suspended Sarver for a year and ordered a $10 million fine. PayPal's CEO, Dan Schulman, stated that Sarver's conduct is "unacceptable and in conflict with our values," and will not renew the deal when it expires. The decision comes after a similar call from civil rights leader Al Sharpton, who urged PayPal to cut ties with Sarver's businesses.

site_title: Entertainer back in the spotlight
summary: Entertainer, a six-year-old Zoustar, has regained form with his eighth win in a $70,000 Class 3 race. Trainer Donna Logan attributed his success to using common sense and pulling him back from his usual pace. The win follows a close second in his previous outing, and Entertainer has now pushed closer to the $300,000 mark in prize money. Logan's apprentice jockey Yusoff Fadzli also had a successful outing, maintaining his lead in the juniors' log.

site_title: SA Rugby blasts media on failed drug-test claims
summary: South African Rugby has accused the media of "distracting and destabilizing" the national team ahead of their Rugby Championship match against Argentina. The allegations, made by a South African website, claim that Springbok players have failed drug tests, but SA Rugby denies any evidence of adverse analytical findings. The team's coach, Jacques Nienaber, described the allegations as "strategically planned" and stated that the team has not had a positive test this year. SA Rugby has also sought a legal interdict to stop the publication of the story.

site_title: Gunners back on their perch
summary: Arsenal returned to the top of the Premier League with a 3-0 win over Brentford, thanks to goals from William Saliba and Gabriel Jesus. 15-year-old Ethan Nwaneri became the youngest player in EPL history, making his debut as a substitute in the 88th minute. The victory puts Arsenal on 18 points from seven league matches, ahead of Manchester City and Tottenham Hotspur. Manager Mikel Arteta praised Nwaneri's talent, saying he "deserves it" and will be kept with the team.

site_title: Auger-Aliassime wins again to take Canada into q-finals
summary: Felix Auger-Aliassime secured Canada's spot in the Davis Cup quarter-finals with a 6-3, 6-4 win over Serbia's Miomir Kecmanovic. The victory came after Laslo Djere gave Serbia an initial lead, but Auger-Aliassime's clinical display levelled the tie. Serbia ultimately won the group-stage tie 2-1. With the win, Canada advances to the knockout stages, while Spain also remains in contention for a spot. The quarter-finals will take place in Malaga from November 22-27.

site_title: Same approach works for Smith
summary: World No. 3 golfer Cameron Smith claimed the lead at the LIV Golf Invitational Chicago, firing a 4-under 68 to move to 10-under 134. Smith's unchanged mentality and consistent gameplay have contributed to his success, as he attributed his form to "keeping everything the same" and "still doing the work at home." Peter Uihlein vaulted 18 spots up the leaderboard to move into solo third, while Phil Mickelson called on the PGA Tour to work with LIV for the good of the sport.

site_title: MacIntyre wins Italian Open after play-off
summary: Robert MacIntyre won the Italian Open in a play-off against Matthew Fitzpatrick, claiming his second DP World Tour victory. MacIntyre shot a 29 on the front nine and took a two-shot lead, but Fitzpatrick overtook him on the 16th. MacIntyre regained the lead at the clubhouse and ultimately won the title with a birdie on the first play-off hole. The victory marked a significant moment for MacIntyre, who hopes to be selected for the 2023 Ryder Cup at Marco Simone Golf and Country Club.

site_title: Tour card in hand, Lower hunts for first victory
summary: Justin Lower seized the outright lead at the Fortinet Championship with a three-under 69, capped by a birdie on the final hole. Lower, aiming for his first PGA Tour title, moved to 13-under 203, one stroke ahead of second-round leaders Max Homa and Danny Willett. An Byeong-hun trailed in third at 204. Lower's steady round, despite a "nervy" bogey on the first hole, puts him in position to challenge for his first victory, a month after securing his tour card.

site_title: Huge win 'more than I can ever dream of'
summary: Norwegian cyclist Tobias Foss won the men's time trial at the road cycling world championships in Wollongong, Australia, with a time of 40min 2.78sec. Foss, 25, stunned the field, including favored riders Stefan Kung and Remco Evenepoel, to claim his first global title. In the women's event, Ellen van Dijk retained her title, clocking 44:28.60, and is now the second most successful rider in women's world championships history.

site_title: All-rounder David among world's best, says Cummins
summary: Australia's Twenty20 World Cup squad includes 26-year-old all-rounder Tim David, who is considered an "X-factor" by pace spearhead Pat Cummins. David, a Singapore-born Australian, has impressed in the Pakistan Super League and is set to make his debut in Australian colours during the three-match series in India. Cummins praised David's batting skills, saying he's been "right up there with the best in the world" and is looking forward to seeing him perform. The series starts on Tuesday in Mohali, with Australia missing all-rounders Mitchell Marsh and Marcus Stoinis due to injuries.

site_title: Everton finally win, thanks to Maupay's strike
summary: Everton secured their first win of the season with a 1-0 victory over West Ham United at Goodison Park. Neal Maupay scored his maiden goal for the Toffees in the 53rd minute, ending a 12-game drought in the Premier League. The win lifts Everton to 13th in the standings, while West Ham remains third from bottom with just one victory from seven games. Maupay's goal was his first for his new club, and his manager Frank Lampard praised his signing as a proven Premier League scorer.

site_title: Lifters' hefty returns
summary: National powerlifter Farhanna Farid broke her own dead lift world record with a 201kg lift at the South-east Asian (SEA) Cup, eclipsing her previous record of 200.5kg. The 29-year-old's achievement comes just three months after setting her first world mark. Five others, including Shirley Chu, Nigel Ng, Patricia Lynn Meyer, Saudi Tan, and Yunie Yang, also set Asian records in their respective events. Singapore's 48-strong contingent won 26 gold, seven silver, and nine bronze medals, with Farhanna crowned best female lifter and Clinton Lee named best male athlete.

site_title: Sports World: S'pore lose 6-1 in U-20 Asian Cup qualifier
summary: Singapore lost 6-1 to Lebanon in a U-20 Asian Cup qualifier, failing to qualify for the tournament. Meanwhile, in other sports news, American Cory Sandhagen won a UFC bout by TKO, Elena Rybakina reached the final of a WTA tournament, Borussia Dortmund took the top spot in the Bundesliga with a 1-0 win over Schalke, Monza secured their first-ever Serie A win, and Bayern Munich suffered their first defeat of the season at Augsburg.

site_title: Cheika rues poor 1st half as Boks win
summary: South Africa dominated the first half of their 36-20 win over Argentina in the Rugby Championship, but Argentina made a strong comeback in the second half. Coach Michael Cheika criticized his team's poor discipline and high penalty count in the first half, but vowed to keep faith with the players. The Springboks' execution in attack was key to their win, according to captain Siya Kolisi. South Africa remains joint top with New Zealand, with one round of matches left, while Argentina remains five points behind in fourth place.

site_title: High-tech devices make chess cheats hard to spot
summary: The methods of cheating in chess have evolved significantly, with high-tech devices making it harder to detect. Cheating methods include surreptitious meetings, bone conduction spectacles, and other sophisticated methods. The issue gained attention after top player Magnus Carlsen lost to 19-year-old Hans Niemann in the Sinquefield Cup, highlighting the need for improved detection and prevention of cheating in competitive chess. The incident has sparked a renewed focus on ensuring fair play in the game.

site_title: Football is crazy, says Spurs' Son after hat-trick
summary: Tottenham Hotspur forward Son Heung-min scored a hat-trick in a 6-2 Premier League win over Leicester City, ending his eight-game goal drought. The South Korean's blistering performance came after being dropped from the starting line-up, and he credited the team's rotation and his own determination for the turnaround. Manager Antonio Conte praised Son's return to form, saying the player is "one of the two best players in my team." The victory lifted Tottenham to 17 points, level with Manchester City and behind leaders Arsenal.

site_title: Rookie Chung scores first HK win
summary: Rookie jockey Angus Chung scored his first Hong Kong win on Sunday, partnering trainer David Hall's Quadruple Double to victory in the Class 4 Bedford Handicap. Chung, 26, used his 10lb claim to maximum effect, fending off Lucky Ruby and Thunderstrike after coming under pressure in the straight. This win follows Pierre Ng's maiden Hong Kong victory just four days prior. Chung, who rode 76 winners from 689 mounts in Australia, credited his success to Hall and trainer Jon O'Connor, who recommended him to Hall.

site_title: Tennis: Alcaraz fires Spain into Davis Cup quarters, Italy down Sweden
summary: Carlos Alcaraz led Spain to the Davis Cup quarterfinals with a win over South Korea's Soon-woo Kwon. Alcaraz, now world number one, secured his first victory in the top spot with a 6-4 7-6(1) win. Spain will face Croatia in the semifinals. Meanwhile, Italy secured top spot in their group with victories over Sweden and Croatia, while Germany topped Group C and will face Canada in the quarterfinals. The knockout rounds will be played in Malaga from November 22-27.

site_title: Powerlifting: 'Record is not mine alone', says Farhanna Farid as she rewrites world record
summary: Singapore powerlifter Farhanna Farid set a new deadlift world record in the women's Under-52kg Open category with a lift of 201kg at the South-east Asian (SEA) Cup 2022. This achievement comes just three months after she set her first world record. Farhanna attributed her success to her training and the motivation to push herself under pressure. Her record-breaking lift eclipses her previous record of 200.5kg, and she is now the best female lifter at the event.

site_title: Time for I Like It Hot to 'roast' her nine rivals
summary: South African horses are set to compete in various races at the Greyville track. I Like It Hot is favored to win the 1,000M Race 1, followed by Guest Getorixx and Mandalay. Malcolm's Dream is expected to make a strong showing in the 1,700M Race 2, while American Style and Lady Is A Champ are likely to finish ahead of Whispering Green. In the 1,800M Race 3, Arumugam and Monarchy are expected to compete, with Sea Master favored to win. The 1,400M Race 4 is expected to be won by Magical Flight, with Chanty Lane and Sashay Away also in contention. In the 1,600M Race 5, A Whole New World is favored to win, while Fever and Living Waters are expected to compete. The 1,000M Race 6 is likely to be won by Magicallee, with Will O Me and Her Royal Majesty also in contention. The 1,200M Race 7 is expected to be won by Mount Greylock, while We All Chomies and Esquevelle are also likely to compete.

site_title: Pogba's brother charged, detained
summary: French football star Paul Pogba's brother, Mathias, has been charged and detained over alleged extortion. Mathias, 32, admitted to publishing a video promising "great revelations" about Pogba. Four others, close to the Pogba brothers, have also been charged and detained. The alleged blackmail plot demands €13 million from Pogba to avoid the release of compromising videos. Pogba denies claims he asked a holy man to cast a spell on teammate Kylian Mbappe. The investigation is ongoing, and Pogba's World Cup hopes remain uncertain due to a recent knee injury.

site_title: Furue stays bogey-free to share Portland lead
summary: Japan's Ayaka Furue fired a bogey-free 67 to match Americans Lilia Vu and Andrea Lee for the lead at the LPGA Portland Classic. Furue, 22, is on 13-under 203, one stroke ahead of Vu, Lee, and several other players. Furue, who claimed her first LPGA Tour title in July, credits playing bogey-free for her success, saying it's more important than getting birdies. The top contenders are Furue, Vu, Lee, and several others, with the tournament set to conclude on Sunday.

site_title: All excess deaths during S'pore pandemic related to Covid-19
summary: Singapore's excess deaths during the COVID-19 pandemic, totaling 1,087, were largely caused by Covid-19 exacerbating underlying illnesses, rather than direct deaths from the virus. This accounted for 40% of the 2,490 excess deaths in the country between January 2020 and June this year. Vaccinations also played a role, with 28% of excess deaths occurring among unvaccinated individuals. The Ministry of Health attributes the low number of deaths to Singapore's effective pandemic response and high vaccine coverage, which has allowed the country to avoid a large number of COVID-19-related deaths.

site_title: Painful win for Alvarez
summary: Saul "Canelo" Alvarez retained the undisputed super middleweight world title with a unanimous decision victory over Gennady Golovkin in their trilogy fight. Despite a "really bad" injury to his wrist that requires surgery, Alvarez outclassed Golovkin, winning the fight 116-112, 115-113, and 115-113. The 32-year-old champion acknowledged the pain and damage to his wrist, saying he needs surgery to recover. Alvarez's win marked a significant bounce-back after losing to Dmitry Bivol earlier this year, but he admitted he wasn't back to his show-stopping best.

site_title: Football: Brighton name Italian De Zerbi as their new manager
summary: Brighton & Hove Albion has appointed Italian manager Roberto De Zerbi as their new head coach on a four-year contract. De Zerbi, 43, succeeds Graham Potter, who left for Chelsea earlier this month. De Zerbi previously managed Sassuolo to successive eighth-placed finishes in Serie A and led Shakhtar Donetsk to the Ukrainian Super Cup. Brighton chairman Tony Bloom expressed confidence in De Zerbi's style and tactical approach, which will suit the existing squad. De Zerbi will be officially unveiled on Tuesday.

site_title: Why two well-off dementia patients with private homes have been abandoned by relatives
summary: Two Singaporean dementia patients, both well-off retirees with private homes, have been abandoned by their relatives despite having sufficient financial means to ensure a comfortable old age. Nursing homes have been referring cases to the Singapore National Trust Company (SNTC) for assistance, highlighting the need for planning and support for individuals with assets. The incident underscores the importance of making arrangements for elderly care, even for those who appear financially secure.

site_title: Football: Udinese go top of Serie A after beating Inter to secure fifth successive win
summary: Udinese secured a 3-1 home win over Inter Milan on September 18, 2022, moving to the top of Serie A standings with their fifth successive league victory. Goals from Jaka Bijol and Tolgay Arslan sealed the win after Inter's Milan Skriniar scored an own goal in the 22nd minute. Udinese will hold the top spot as long as Napoli and AC Milan draw and Atalanta fails to beat AS Roma, with Inter hosting Roma on October 1 and Udinese traveling to Hellas Verona on October 3.

site_title: GuocoLand's Lentor Modern condo 84% sold over launch weekend
summary: GuocoLand's Lentor Modern condo achieved 84% sales over its launch weekend, with 508 units sold out of 605 units. Launch prices ranged from $1.07 million to $3.33 million, with all one- and two-bedroom units and most three-room units sold. Analysts attribute the strong sales to underlying demand from HDB upgraders and new families, despite higher home loan rates, and the project's pull factors and tight supply of new private residential launches.

site_title: Football: Arsenal beat Brentford 3-0 to regain Premier League top spot
summary: Arsenal regained the top spot in the Premier League with a 3-0 win over Brentford, thanks to goals from William Saliba, Gabriel Jesus, and Fabio Vieira. The victory moved Arsenal one point above Manchester City and Tottenham, as injuries to key players did not hinder the team's performance. The match was played in a minute's silence to honor Queen Elizabeth II, and Arsenal's 15-year-old debutant Ethan Nwaneri became the youngest player in Premier League history. The win solidified Arsenal's position as title contenders, with manager Mikel Arteta praising the team's "different mentality" and "class" in the victory.

site_title: Ethnic self-help groups still vital as they customise support for beneficiaries: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's ethnic self-help groups, such as the Chinese Development Assistance Council (CDAC), remain vital in providing customized support to low-income families, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said. These groups, funded by the government and community donations, offer additional aid beyond what the government provides, addressing issues without raising racial or religious sensitivities. With over 18,000 households benefiting from CDAC's programs, the groups will continue to support social mobility as Singapore's economy develops.

site_title: Chasing speed demons all in a day's work for female officer in Traffic Police's elite unit
summary: Sergeant Joey Png, a 34-year-old female officer in Singapore's Traffic Police Special Operations Team, performs covert operations and VIP escorts. She operates stealthily on a black BMW RT 1250 bike, intimidating motorists with her height and weight despite riding a vehicle nearly seven times heavier than her when fully loaded. In the last two months, the Traffic Police dealt with 22,447 speeding-related violations and 231 accidents related to speeding. Sgt Png's unique approach, lifting her helmet visor to show her friendly face, helps calm violators, making her a rare but effective female outrider.

site_title: Football: Paul Pogba's brother charged in extortion case
summary: Mathias Pogba, the brother of French football star Paul Pogba, has been charged and detained over alleged extortion, with four others also held in custody. Mathias admitted to a bizarre video promising "great revelations" about Paul, who had filed a €13 million blackmail plot complaint. The blackmailers demanded large sums of money to avoid compromising videos. The investigation, launched on Sept 2, is being handled jointly by French police units. Paul's World Cup hopes are uncertain due to a knee injury, with surgery described as "successful."

site_title: Arc Children's Centre raises $273,000 at gala lunch after two-year Covid-19 hiatus
summary: The Arc Children's Centre, a charity daycare centre for children with cancer and critical illnesses, raised $273,534 at its first gala lunch since a two-year Covid-19 hiatus. The event, held at Shangri-La Hotel, was attended by 500 guests, including Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat and Mrs Goh Chok Tong. The funds will support various programs providing physical and emotional care to beneficiaries. The centre, which relies on public donations, had seen a 60% decline in donations during the pandemic but continued to provide services, earning praise from Heng Swee Keat for its resilience.

site_title: Boxing: Alvarez cruises to victory over Golovkin in trilogy clash
summary: Saul "Canelo" Alvarez retained his undisputed super middleweight world title with a unanimous decision victory over Gennadiy Golovkin in their trilogy bout. Alvarez controlled the center of the ring, dominating with his faster hand speed, and won 116-112, 115-113, and 115-113 on the judges' scorecards. Golovkin struggled to match Alvarez's energy and work rate, but showed signs of life in the ninth round. The win marks Alvarez's return to form after a loss in his previous fight and solidifies his legacy as a top boxer.

site_title: More than 650 cyclists ride through heavy rain to raise funds for cancer patients
summary: More than 650 cyclists participated in a 38,902km virtual ride in Singapore, raising $88,902 for cancer patients through the "Let's Ride! Singapore" event. Organized by Mirxes, the ride aimed to promote an active lifestyle and disease prevention. The funds will be donated to the National University Cancer Institute, Singapore, supporting patients' treatments and research. The event's success was highlighted by Minister of State for Culture, Community and Youth, Ms Low Yen Ling, who praised the cyclists for their support and dedication to helping those in need.

site_title: Credit Suisse Trust in Singapore trial admits it failed to flag rogue transfers
summary: Credit Suisse Trust in Singapore admitted it failed to flag unauthorised transfers from billionaire client Bidzina Ivanishvili's accounts, breaching its trustee duties. The admission comes as a shift in strategy in the ongoing trial, where Ivanishvili is suing for US$800 million in damages. The trust had previously argued its responsibility was limited to asset administration, but the admission may limit potential fallout from damaging testimony. The move could impact the outcome of the trial, which is tied to Ivanishvili's losses due to rogue banker Patrice Lescaudron's fraud.

site_title: Staying ahead of scammers an opportunity for S'pore to boost its financial reputation: Experts
summary: Singapore lost $346.5 million to scams in the first half of the year, with 14,349 scam cases reported, nearly double the previous year. Experts say the country needs to stay ahead of scammers by coordinating efforts with the government, police, telcos, and financial institutions, and harnessing technology to prevent scams. While the increasing amount lost to scams may tarnish Singapore's reputation, experts believe the authorities can turn this into a win by effectively managing the situation and setting an example for other countries.

site_title: Tennis: Murray eyes chance to partner retiring Federer at Laver Cup
summary: Andy Murray expressed hope to team up with retiring tennis great Roger Federer at the Laver Cup in London. Federer announced his retirement due to injury issues, and Murray sees it as a "special" opportunity to share the court with him. The two will join Rafael Nadal and Novak Djokovic on the same team for the first time. Murray, who last played Federer in 2015, is uncertain about Federer's availability, but the chance to compete with him in doubles would be "really special."

site_title: Chess: High-tech methods like smart glasses make cheating hard to detect
summary: The methods of cheating in chess are becoming increasingly difficult to detect due to high-tech advancements. The game has seen various forms of cheating, from secret meetings to bone conduction spectacles, over the decades. The recent Sinquefield Cup match between Magnus Carlsen and Hans Niemann has brought the issue to the forefront, sparking concerns about the integrity of the game. With technology making it harder to detect cheating, the chess community is struggling to stay one step ahead of those who seek to exploit the game.

site_title: Cycling: Foss in disbelief after dethroning two-time defending champion Ganna
summary: Norway's Tobias Foss stunned the cycling world by dethroning two-time defending champion Filippo Ganna in the men's time-trial event at the road world championships in Australia. Foss won the 34.2km circuit in 40min 2.78sec, edging Swiss rider Stefan Kung by 2.95sec. The 25-year-old Foss, who was not a favorite, described the victory as a "dream" and a surprise. He will wear the rainbow jersey, a first for him.

site_title: Almost $1 million raised by more than 3,000 runners to support cancer fight
summary: More than 3,000 runners participated in the 14th Singtel-Singapore Cancer Society Race Against Cancer, raising almost $1 million to support cancer research and treatment. The event, which resumed physically after two years, aims to raise $1.25 million. The funds will be used to expand the Singapore Cancer Society's programs, including rehabilitation facilities and cancer treatment subsidies, and will help provide hope and strength to the cancer community. The event is part of the society's annual fundraising efforts, which typically raise $20 million to support various cancer-related initiatives.

site_title: As US IPO market languishes, listings head east to booming China
summary: The US IPO market has stagnated due to volatility and slumping stock markets, prompting Chinese companies to shift their listings to Asia. In 2022, 68% of global IPO volume came from Asia, with Chinese IPOs accounting for the majority. The US market, which traditionally accounted for the largest share, has seen only 14% of global volume this year, with many highly anticipated listings pushed back or scrapped. Meanwhile, European exchanges, particularly the newly expanded stock link between China and Europe, are becoming more appealing for Chinese firms, with Porsche set to launch a massive IPO.

site_title: Football: Maupay strikes to help Everton earn first victory of the season
summary: Everton secured their first Premier League win of the season with a 1-0 victory over West Ham United on September 18, 2022. Neal Maupay scored the only goal from a 53rd-minute volley after an excellent touch from Alex Iwobi's pass. The win lifts Everton to 13th in the standings, while West Ham remain in the bottom three with one victory from their seven games. Manager Frank Lampard expressed relief and optimism, stating that the team has room for improvement and is building momentum after a goalless Merseyside Derby on Maupay's debut.

site_title: Tennis: Auger-Aliassime helps Canada seal Davis Cup quarter-final spot
summary: Canada secured its spot in the Davis Cup quarter-finals after Felix Auger-Aliassime defeated Miomir Kecmanovic 6-3, 6-4, helping the team level the group stage tie against Serbia. The win came a day after Auger-Aliassime's 6-3, 6-4 victory over world No. 1 Carlos Alcaraz. Canada will advance to the knockout stages alongside Serbia, which also secured a spot, while Spain is in the running for the second spot. The quarter-finals will be held in Malaga from November 22-27.

site_title: Golf: Smith outshoots Johnson to seize LIV Golf Chicago lead
summary: Australian golfer Cam Smith seized a three-stroke lead at the LIV Golf Chicago Invitational after firing a 68 in the second round, finishing 10-under par after 36 holes. Smith closed with back-to-back birdies to surpass Dustin Johnson, who shot a 74, and fellow American Peter Uihlein. The tournament marks a significant shift in the golf world, with several top players defecting from the PGA Tour to LIV Golf, prompting the PGA to issue indefinite bans on former members.

site_title: Football: Nagelsmann blames 'laissez-faire' attitude as Bayern lose, Dortmund go top
summary: Bayern Munich suffered their first defeat of the season, losing 1-0 to Augsburg in the Bundesliga. Coach Julian Nagelsmann attributed the loss to a "laissez-faire" attitude and lack of teamwork. Borussia Dortmund, meanwhile, moved to the top of the league with a 1-0 win over Schalke, thanks to a goal from teenage substitute Youssoufa Moukoko. Dortmund captain Marco Reus suffered a potentially serious ankle injury in the match.

site_title: Football: Monza shock Juventus 1-0 to clinch first Serie A win of the season
summary: Monza secured their first Serie A win of the season with a 1-0 home victory over Juventus. Juventus was reduced to 10 men after Angel di Maria's red card, and Monza capitalized on the opportunity, with substitute Christian Gytkjaer scoring the winning goal in the 74th minute. The win lifted Monza to 18th place, while Juventus remains eighth but six points behind leaders Udinese. Juventus coach Massimiliano Allegri was also sent off in the match, further complicating their struggles.

site_title: Rugby: Late Marx try earns Boks bonus-point win in Buenos Aires
summary: South Africa secured a 36-20 bonus-point victory over Argentina in Buenos Aires, thanks to a late try by hooker Malcolm Marx. The win lifts the Springboks to 14 points in the Rugby Championship title hunt, level with New Zealand. South Africa dominated the first half with a 22-6 lead, but Argentina staged a comeback in the second half before the Boks pulled away, earning a bonus point in the process. The win marks a crucial step for the Springboks ahead of their final clash with Argentina next weekend.

site_title: Support group on dwarfism hopes to make big difference
summary: A support group called Little Mighty Warriors in Singapore aims to assist parents of children with achondroplasia, a genetic disorder causing dwarfism. Founded by Joshua Khoo, who has the condition, the group provides advice on daily life, health concerns, and insurance issues. With 19 members, the group hopes to become formally registered to better support those with the condition. The group's founder faces challenges in accessing the breakthrough drug Voxzogo, which can increase height, due to its unavailability in Singapore and lack of subsidies.

site_title: Savvy professional didn't plan ahead to manage his own assets, then got dementia
summary: A high-income professional in Singapore, who had prepared complex documents for clients, failed to plan his own retirement and assets, despite entering a comfortable retirement 20 years ago. He procrastinated, living day by day, and left important life decisions undone. This case highlights the importance of planning ahead for one's own affairs, regardless of income level or professional acumen.

site_title: UOB staff stop elderly man from losing $150,000 to 'girlfriend from Netherlands' in love scam
summary: Bank staff foil $150,000 love scam at UOB, saving elderly man from losing life savings. A 70-year-old man was stopped from sending $150,000 to an overseas account by UOB staff, who suspected a love scam. The incident occurred in September at the bank's Raffles Place branch, where staff flagged the suspicious transaction after the man's inconsistencies in his story. The man was convinced not to proceed with the transfer, and he later made a police report. This case is part of a larger trend, with over $20 million lost to Internet love scams in Singapore in the first half of 2022.

site_title: 'Every second critical' in a traffic accident or car fire
summary: A recent Automobile Association (AA) seminar in Singapore highlighted the importance of knowing what to do in critical situations like traffic accidents and vehicle fires. Every second counts, and knowing life-saving skills can mean the difference between life and death. According to SCDF data, there were 155 vehicle fires last year, with 82 being car fires, resulting in fatalities in some cases. The seminar emphasized the need for motorists to know how to react to emergencies, including CPR and using automated external defibrillators, and praised a driver who provided first aid to an injured motorcyclist.

site_title: Island reboot
summary: Sentosa Island in Singapore is shifting its strategy to maintain its appeal to local visitors, who flocked to the island during the pandemic. The island saw a record 9.4 million local visitors from April last year to March this year, a 11.9% year-on-year jump. This surge comes as the island welcomes back overseas visitors, aiming to remain a popular destination for Singaporeans.

site_title: Mum with colorectal cancer gets new lease of life with son's liver
summary: A 61-year-old Singaporean woman, Madam Lim Gek Meng, received a groundbreaking liver transplant from her 22-year-old son, Mr. Goh Jun Le, in July 2022. The transplant, which involved removing 60-70% of Mr. Goh's liver, was the first of its kind in South-east Asia. The procedure, which was initially deemed unlikely due to the risks of cancer relapse, was made possible by a team of international experts who developed a set of stringent criteria for patient selection. The transplant has significantly improved Madam Lim's chances of survival, with a 60% chance of living more than five years, and has offered new hope for stage 4 colorectal cancer patients in the region.

site_title: Nudging children to help dad and mum: Why adult children cut ties and refuse to support parents
summary: The Maintenance of Parents Act in Singapore requires seniors seeking maintenance to undergo conciliation with their children first. A father, in his 80s, sought support from his other two children after his children stopped providing him with $500 monthly due to disapproval of his remarriage following his wife's death. This case highlights the challenges of adult children cutting ties with their parents and refusing to support them financially. The act aims to resolve disputes before resorting to maintenance claims.

site_title: Financial institutions must stay ahead of scammers: Experts
summary: Financial experts in Singapore stress the need for financial institutions and companies to stay ahead of scammers to maintain the country's reputation as a key financial hub. With 14,349 scam cases reported in the first half of this year, resulting in $346.5 million lost, experts urge coordination among government, police, telcos, and financial institutions to tackle scams quickly. Implementing technology and sharing information are key to protecting vulnerable individuals, and experts believe that Singapore can set an example for other countries by successfully curbing scams.

site_title: Sections of Ulu Pandan Park Connector briefly closed after flash flood warning
summary: Sections of the Ulu Pandan Park Connector in Singapore were briefly closed on Sunday morning due to flash flood warnings. The water level in the Ulu Pandan Canal reached 90% capacity, prompting NParks to close the park connector from Clementi Road to Commonwealth Avenue West. The closure was lifted after the rain eased. The canal, which was carved out after a landslide, is expected to help mitigate flood risks upstream. Construction efforts to repair the damage are estimated to take a few months, with some sections remaining closed to the public.

site_title: Savvy professional who helped clients failed to plan for self
summary: A high-income professional, who prepared complex documents for clients, failed to plan for his own retirement, living day by day and leaving important life decisions undone. Despite entering a comfortable retirement 20 years ago, he lacked professional acumen in making plans, mirroring the procrastination habits of many individuals.

site_title: S'pore and India discuss energy, food security at new forum
summary: Singapore and India held a high-level ministerial roundtable, discussing energy, food security, and green technology. Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong described the event as a chance to take bilateral ties to a new phase, citing 57 years of diplomatic relations and strong economic ties. The forum, attended by leaders from both countries, aimed to explore beneficial opportunities amidst post-Covid-19 recovery and supply chain disruptions. The two nations have strong economic ties, with bilateral trade reaching $26.8 billion in 2021 and a stock of direct investment abroad of $66.6 billion.

site_title: Well-off dementia patients 'abandoned' by relatives
summary: Two wealthy retirees, both living alone, are being abandoned by their relatives despite having sufficient means to live comfortably. The women are unable to access their private assets, leaving them reliant on welfare homes. This highlights the need for individuals to make plans for their own financial security, as having wealth alone is not a guarantee against financial setbacks in old age.

site_title: Timeline of Maintenance of Parents Act
summary: The Maintenance of Parents Act was first introduced in Parliament by Walter Woon in May 1994. The bill aimed to provide financial support for adult children who care for their elderly parents. After years of amendments, the bill was passed into law in 2001, allowing adult children to claim maintenance from their parents. The law has undergone revisions since then, with the most recent changes made in 2013. The Act has helped many adult children care for their parents, but also raised concerns about the potential for abuse and dependency.

site_title: New record set for longest line of hand-painted lanterns
summary: A record-breaking 1,688 hand-painted lanterns, stretching 600m, were unveiled at Vista Park in Admiralty, Singapore, setting a new Guinness World Record for the longest line of hand-painted lanterns. The record-breaking display was part of a Mid-Autumn Festival celebration organized by local grassroots organizations, involving over 1,000 participants. The lanterns were strung together with fairy lights and decorated by Admiralty residents, volunteers, and community partners, including Republic Polytechnic and the Singapore Sports School.

site_title: Lifeline for forgotten battery site on Sentosa
summary: A largely forgotten heritage site on Sentosa's Serapong Golf Course, featuring anti-motor torpedo boat battery structures, is set to receive stabilisation work. The site, which has fallen into ruin, is expected to be given a new lease on life. The project aims to slow the site's decline and preserve its historical significance, allowing future generations to appreciate its importance. The stabilisation work is a crucial step in conserving the site's integrity.

site_title: 3 seniors who sought maintenance after unresolved issues drove wedge between them and their kids
summary: A Singapore work group is proposing to introduce non-monetary orders to address the root cause of acrimony between parents and their children in maintenance cases. Three senior cases were cited, where parents sought maintenance due to unresolved issues, leading to a wedge between them and their kids. The Commissioner for the Maintenance of Parents has helped resolve such issues, highlighting the need for alternative solutions beyond monetary orders.

site_title: Woman, 90, reconnects with daughter she gave up for adoption 58 years ago
summary: A 90-year-old Singaporean woman, Madam Teng Ek Kiew, has reconnected with her 58-year-old daughter, Madam Hamsiah Mohamad, whom she gave up for adoption 58 years ago. The reunion was made possible through a video call, allowing the two to reconnect and share a moment of joy after decades of separation. The emotional reunion was a result of Teng's enduring love for her child, despite the difficult circumstances of the adoption. The two women were finally able to bridge the gap of time and reconnect.

site_title: Motor racing: Singapore GP will be tough, says recovering Albon
summary: Williams Formula One driver Alex Albon is recovering from appendicitis and hopes to race in the Singapore Grand Prix on October 2. Albon was replaced at the Italian Grand Prix with Nyck de Vries, who finished ninth. Released from hospital on Tuesday, Albon is now recovering at home in Monaco, where he plans to walk around and aims to be ready for Singapore. He considers the Singapore Grand Prix one of the toughest races, but is determined to participate.

site_title: Sentosa ex-military site that has fallen into ruin to be given lifeline
summary: A forgotten and inaccessible heritage site on Sentosa's Serapong Golf Course, Berhala Reping, is set to receive a lifeline. The site, which dates back to at least 1892, features an anti-motor torpedo boat battery. After falling into ruin, it is expected to be preserved and protected, slowing down its decline. The exact details of the preservation plan have not been released, but the site's restoration is seen as a significant step in preserving Singapore's history and heritage.

site_title: S'pore firm's intricate coins bring glint to collectors' eyes
summary: A Singapore firm, Precious Metal Collectors, has created limited-edition coins that are highly sought after by serious collectors worldwide. The 10kg silver "Nine Sons Of The Dragon King" coin is one example, and its value is driving interest in collectible coins as a store of value. This shift is seen as a response to the volatility of traditional assets. Mr. Billy Neo, founder of Precious Metal Collectors, started accumulating bullion pieces and collectible coins in 2017, anticipating a need for a stable store of value as he retired.

site_title: Cyber threats, energy security among areas discussed during SM Teo's France visit
summary: Senior Minister Teo Chee Hean discussed areas of cooperation with French officials, including cyber threats and energy security, during a visit from Tuesday to Saturday. Teo met with Minister Gerald Darmanin, Minister Agnes Pannier-Runacher, and Secretary-General Stephane Bouillon to reaffirm strong ties between Singapore and France. They also discussed the Russia-Ukraine crisis and its impact on geopolitics. Teo attended meetings with researchers and Electricite de France, and will be the guest of honour at a National Day reception hosted by the Singapore Embassy in Paris.

site_title: Global economy clings to Taiwan's 'silicon shield'
summary: Taiwan, known as the "silicon shield" for its dominance in the semiconductor industry, has become a vital component of the global economy. Despite China's recent military exercises, Taiwan continues to produce most of the world's highest-tech silicon chips. This vulnerability highlights the interconnectedness of the global economy and the importance of Taiwan's role in it. The island's semiconductor industry has been a key factor in the global economy's resilience, but its exposure to China's military actions underscores the need for increased stability in the region.

site_title: Most elderly parents in Singapore get less than $500 in maintenance a month
summary: Most elderly parents in Singapore receive less than $500 in monthly maintenance from their children. According to the Tribunal for the Maintenance of Parents, 82% of parents receive less than $500, while 13% receive between $500-$999. This indicates that many seniors rely heavily on financial support from their children, with a significant majority receiving insufficient aid.

site_title: New job ruse lures victims with fake Halloween Horror Nights tickets
summary: Scammers are using fake Halloween Horror Nights tickets to lure victims into a job con, promising them commission for booking hotel rooms through a fake platform called sunshine.co.uk. Victims are asked to book hotels and earn 3-12% commission, with the promise of withdrawing funds after 40 bookings a day. The Singapore Tourism Board and Resorts World Sentosa have warned consumers to be vigilant and to buy tickets directly from authorized sources. The police have confirmed a report has been lodged, and the scammers remain unresponsive to inquiries.

site_title: New type of job scam lures victims with fake Halloween Horror Nights tickets
summary: A new job scam in Singapore is targeting victims with fake Halloween Horror Nights tickets, luring them into booking hotel rooms to earn commission. Scammers contact victims via Telegram, promising free tickets, then send fake tickets and introduce themselves as marketers for a fictional booking platform. Victims are told to create an account, complete daily bookings, and earn between 3-12% commission. The scammers then ask victims to top up their accounts to continue booking. Authorities have lodged a police report, and the Singapore Tourism Board warns consumers to remain vigilant and report suspicious cases to the anti-scam hotline.

site_title: When childhood hurt, estranged ties lead to children not supporting elderly parents
summary: A work group is proposing non-monetary orders to address the root cause of acrimony in maintenance disputes between elderly parents and their adult children. Research suggests that deep-seated childhood wounds, such as disapproval of a parent's marriage or loss of contact after divorce, can lead to financial refusal. Most elderly parents (82%) receive less than $500 in monthly maintenance, with many relying on a single child for support. Ignoring their elderly parents can lead to financial strain and unresolved family issues, highlighting the need for alternative solutions to address these complex issues.

site_title: Ex-Aetos officer who robbed Jurong shop with gun gets 16½ years' jail, 18 strokes
summary: A former Aetos auxiliary police officer, Mahadi Muhamad Mukhtar, was sentenced to 16½ years' jail and 18 strokes of the cane for robbing a licensed moneylending company in Jurong using a loaded gun. Mukhtar, 39, had researched the robbery tactic from a Canadian who robbed a bank in 2016 and was motivated by debt. He was found guilty of two charges, including robbery and unlawful possession of a firearm, and had $5,200 of the stolen money recovered by investigators.

site_title: Campaign to help S'poreans plan finances, retirement
summary: A new MoneySense campaign in Singapore aims to equip residents with financial knowledge and planning tools to secure their finances and retirement. The campaign, running until November, includes mass media education programs, complimentary services, and tools. Guided by a 2021 survey that found 4 in 10 respondents lacked financial understanding, the campaign encourages sign-ups for retirement planning workshops and one-to-one financial health clinics, offering personalized recommendations and digital financial planning services.

site_title: 6 civil cases filed to recover $6.7m paid for Rolex watches, other items
summary: Six civil cases have been filed by customers of Tradenation and Tradeluxury to recover $6.7 million paid for luxury goods, mostly Rolex watches, that were never delivered. The cases were filed in various courts, with three in the High Court, two in the State Courts, and one in the Small Claims Tribunals. The customers are seeking to recover the total amount paid, with each case likely to be settled separately. The cases are part of a broader investigation into luxury goods scams.

site_title: Singapore invited to attend next year's G-20 summit in India
summary: Singapore has been invited by India to attend the next year's G-20 summit in New Delhi, marking the first time the city-state will participate in the international grouping. India will assume the G-20 presidency from December 1 to November 30 next year, focusing on promoting inclusive, equitable, and sustainable growth. Singapore looks forward to working with India and other G-20 members to realize India's priorities, and will also convey the perspectives of the Global Governance Group, an informal UN grouping of 30 small and medium-sized members.

site_title: Cases of victims injured in group assaults
summary: Two previous cases of group assault have involved severe abuse of victims. In 1999-2000, seven teenagers held a 14-year-old girl captive for 17 days, torturing her with boiling water, forcing her to perform a sex act on a dog, and violating her with a doll's leg. In another case (2016-2018), a family abused an intellectually disabled friend, causing her teeth to fall out, making her perform chores without pay, and subjecting her to physical and emotional abuse. Both cases resulted in long prison sentences for the perpetrators.

site_title: Family stuck overnight in Turkey because flight was overbooked
summary: A freelance designer and her family were stuck overnight in Turkey after their flight from Istanbul was overbooked, leaving them without a seat on the 1.45am flight they were supposed to take. The family, including a 4-year-old son, were offered €600 compensation each and a free change to a flight the next day, but were tired and inconvenienced by the experience. The incident highlights concerns over overbooking, with the Consumers Association of Singapore calling for regulation of the practice.

site_title: New complex houses facilities for both seniors and pre-schoolers
summary: A new complex, St John's-St Margaret's Village (SJSM Village), has opened in Singapore, integrating a nursing home, senior care centre, and pre-school. The facility, built at $60 million, aims to promote inter-generational interactions, allowing seniors and pre-schoolers to participate in activities together. Minister Masagos Zulkifli emphasized the benefits of "active ageing" and Ministerial support for the facility, which will help seniors age in place and lead active lives. The village is the first purpose-built facility of its kind in Singapore, with plans for weekly inter-generational activities and sessions.

site_title: Lawyer who fled S'pore after $33m of client's money went missing struck off the roll
summary: A Singaporean lawyer, Jeffrey Ong, who fled the country after $33 million of his client's money went missing, has been struck off the roll by the Court of Three Judges. Ong, 45, faces 76 charges, including criminal breach of trust, forgery, and cheating. He was found to have acted dishonestly, misrepresenting the account balance and forging a cheque. The court agreed with the Law Society of Singapore's submissions that striking Ong off the roll was the only appropriate sanction. His criminal case remains pending.

site_title: Woman who abused teen with low IQ gets reformative training
summary: A 20-year-old woman, Putri Nuramira Aishah Rosli, has been sentenced to at least 12 months of reformative training for her role in abusing a 19-year-old man with a low IQ. The victim, who had intellectual disability, was held in a hotel room for nine days, where he was beaten, forced to drink urine, and subjected to physical and emotional abuse. The group, which included a 21-year-old and two 16-year-old girls, used various methods to inflict harm on the victim, who suffered critical injuries, including amnesia and chemical burns.

site_title: US inflation fears trigger declines across regional markets
summary: Regional markets declined after US inflation numbers for August came in higher than expected, sparking concerns of aggressive interest rate hikes. The Straits Times Index fell 0.97% while Japan's Nikkei 225 tumbled 2.8%, Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index dropped 2.5%, and South Korea's Kospi fell 1.6%. Australian stocks plummeted 2.58%, wiping $53 billion off market value. Jardine Cycle & Carriage was the lone blue-chip winner, rising 0.3%. Interest rate hike expectations have been fully priced in, with markets anticipating a 75-basis-point hike next week.
