site_title: Football: Liverpool's Van Dijk vows to do 'much better' after dip in form
summary: Liverpool defender Virgil van Dijk has vowed to do "much better" after a dip in form this season. Despite struggling in the first eight games, Van Dijk helped Liverpool win 2-1 against Ajax in the Champions League. He acknowledged his mistakes in losses to Napoli and Manchester United, but remains determined to improve. Van Dijk believes the team can turn their season around and perform as well as they normally do, saying "we are good if we perform as a team." He is focusing on learning from mistakes and working with his teammates to achieve better results.

site_title: Fish farms to get free advice on disease management and testing support
summary: Singapore's Aquatic Animal Health Services (AAHS) will offer free consultations and testing support to fish farmers starting early next year. The service, launched by the Singapore Food Agency, aims to help farmers develop biosecurity and management plans, including advice on disease management, preventive medicine, and staff mentoring. The agency will fund two consultations and two disease investigations per year for the first two years, with costs for medication, chemicals, and transport covered by the farmers. The initiative is expected to boost productivity and reduce costs for the country's 27 land-based seafood farms.

site_title: 21-year-old carrying truncheon and hiding knuckle-duster in his underwear nabbed in Bugis
summary: A 21-year-old man was arrested in Bugis, Singapore, after trying to evade police and running from them. He was found carrying a 50cm retractable truncheon and a knuckle-duster concealed in his underwear. The man resisted arrest, prompting police to use force to subdue him. He was arrested for possession of a scheduled weapon, carrying a truncheon, and suspected drug-related offences. No one was injured during the incident. The man faces potential jail time and caning for the offences, with the maximum sentence for possession of a scheduled weapon being up to five years.

site_title: Improving public transport has helped Jakarta tackle climate change: Governor Anies Baswedan
summary: Jakarta Governor Anies Baswedan credits improving public transport as a key factor in addressing climate change, with coverage doubling from 40% in 2016 to nearly 90% under his watch. The city has also seen a 26% reduction in carbon emissions, just shy of its 2030 target. Baswedan emphasized the importance of equal access to public transport, saying it bridges socio-economic gaps and reduces greenhouse gas emissions. His administration's efforts have earned Jakarta the Sustainable Transport Award, and he is seen as a front-runner for Indonesia's next presidential election.

site_title: Football: Man United's Rashford to miss Sheriff trip due to muscle injury
summary: Manchester United forward Marcus Rashford will miss Thursday's Europa League match against Sheriff Tiraspol due to a muscle injury. Rashford picked up the injury after scoring twice in the team's win over Arsenal on September 4. Manager Erik ten Hag believes the injury is not severe and expects Rashford to return soon. Rashford is an injury doubt for England's Nations League games this month but is likely to make Gareth Southgate's World Cup squad for November and December.

site_title: Driver who rammed into pedestrian during Toa Payoh high-speed police chase pleads guilty
summary: A Singaporean driver, Vaswani Richard Prakash, 36, pleaded guilty to charges including dangerous driving causing grievous hurt and driving while under disqualification. He was involved in a high-speed police chase in 2021 after speeding and evading authorities, resulting in a five-minute chase down the Pan-Island Expressway. Prakash rammed into a pedestrian, causing multiple injuries, and continued driving before losing control and colliding with a police car. He was arrested three days later and faces up to five years in jail and a fine.

site_title: New exec duo join Singapore Turf Club
summary: The Singapore Turf Club has appointed two new executives to its racing division. Dayle Brown, 58, will be the chief racing officer, while Soo Lai Kwok, 49, will serve as assistant vice-president for Malayan Racing Association and racing support for STC. Brown, a seasoned racing veteran and lawyer, will oversee the new normal of horse racing during the Covid-19 pandemic, while Soo, a regulatory expert, will ensure high standards for Singapore race meetings and support operational efficiencies. They will start their new roles on September 19 and 21 respectively.

site_title: Celebrating Merlion’s golden jubilee | The Straits Times
summary: The Merlion statue, unveiled on September 15, 1972, by then Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew, stands 8.6m tall and was relocated to its current spot at One Fullerton in 2002. The statue has witnessed numerous events, including the first couple's wedding in 2002, the Formula 1 Singapore Grand Prix in 2008, and the National Day Parade in 2015. After a decline in tourism during the Covid-19 pandemic, the Merlion is expected to recover, with plans to celebrate its 50th birthday with a golden lighting display.

site_title: Football: Bayern right-back Hernandez's injury adds to France's World Cup worries
summary: Bayern Munich right-back Lucas Hernandez will be out for several weeks due to a muscle tear in his left adductor, adding to French World Cup concerns. Hernandez's injury affects France's defensive options, particularly with Presnel Kimpembe also sidelined for six weeks with a hamstring problem. The French team faces Austria and Denmark in the Nations League, key warm-ups for the World Cup, which starts on November 20. With several key players, including Paul Pogba and N'Golo Kante, also sidelined, France's chances are diminished, raising worries for the title holders.

site_title: Tennis: Berrettini secures Italy opening Davis Cup win
summary: Italy secured its opening Davis Cup win over Croatia with victories from Lorenzo Musetti and Matteo Berrettini. Musetti defeated Borna Gojo 6-4, 6-2, while Berrettini fought back from a set down to beat Borna Coric 6-7, 6-2, 6-1. Italy's top-ranked player Jannik Sinner is expected to join the team on Friday. The win marks Italy's first Davis Cup title since 1976 and sets up a promising campaign for the team.

site_title: Football: French star Pogba's brother detained in extortion case, sources say
summary: French authorities have detained Mathias Pogba, the brother of footballer Paul Pogba, in an investigation into extortion allegations. Paul Pogba claims he is being blackmailed by gangsters, including his brother, over large sums of money to avoid the release of compromising videos. Mathias Pogba's lawyer denies any involvement, stating he knows nothing about the extortion attempt. The investigation, led by two magistrates, is also looking into allegations of blackmail, kidnapping, and a criminal conspiracy. The case's outcome may impact Pogba's chances of playing for France at the upcoming World Cup.

site_title: PUB bags 4 prizes for project innovation at International Water Association Awards
summary: The Keppel Marina East Desalination Plant, one of three PUB projects, won four gold awards at the International Water Association Awards. The plant, which treats both freshwater and seawater, received the IWA Grand Innovation Award and gold awards in Exceptional Project Execution, Market-changing Water Technology, and Performance Improvement. PUB's other projects, the upgraded Choa Chu Kang Waterworks and the Changi Water Reclamation Plan Digital Twin, also won gold awards. The awards recognize PUB's innovation and research efforts in advancing water resilience and environmental sustainability.

site_title: 3-year-old Singaporean girl dies from Covid-19 infection
summary: A 3-year-old Singaporean girl died from a Covid-19 infection on Tuesday, the third child under 12 to die from the virus in the country. The girl had a history of multiple medical conditions and was admitted to hospital on August 13. She died from anoxic brain injury due to cardiac arrest and Covid-19. Singapore has recorded 1,604 Covid-19 deaths since 2020, with 56,953 new cases reported over the last 28 days. The country has seen a high vaccination rate, with 96% of eligible individuals fully vaccinated and 80% of the population receiving booster shots.

site_title: New islandwide campaign to boost financial literacy among Singaporeans
summary: A new islandwide campaign, MoneySense, was launched in Singapore to boost financial literacy among Singaporeans. The campaign, running until November, aims to equip citizens with knowledge and concrete steps to plan their finances and retirement. The initiative, led by the MoneySense Council, includes in-person and mass media education programs, complimentary services, and tools to aid in financial planning. The campaign is guided by findings from the 2021 MoneySense National Financial Capability Survey, which highlighted areas for improvement in financial knowledge and retirement planning.

site_title: Spate of delistings from SGX due to low liquidity and poor valuations, stakeholders say
summary: A spate of companies in Singapore are opting to delist from the SGX due to low liquidity and poor valuations. Several companies have cited poor market conditions and high costs of staying listed as reasons for delisting. This trend comes amid recession fears and rising interest rates, which have led to a decline in trading volumes on the SGX. Experts predict more delistings are likely, as the exchange faces a liquidity crisis. The delistings mark a significant shift for the local bourse, which is struggling to maintain its relevance in the face of changing market conditions.

site_title: Singapore family stuck overnight in Turkey after getting bumped off overbooked flight
summary: A Singaporean family was left stranded in Turkey for 24 hours after being bumped off an overbooked flight from Istanbul to Singapore. The family, consisting of a mother, father, and 4-year-old son, were offered €600 in compensation each. They were also given a free change to a flight the next day and a hotel stay for the night. The incident highlights the issue of overbooking, which has been in the spotlight, with the Consumers Association of Singapore calling for regulation of the practice.

site_title: Police reports lodged against fitness studios that allegedly closed down overnight
summary: Several police reports have been lodged against Kyklos Studio and X Fitness in Singapore, alleging the fitness studios closed down overnight without warning, leaving customers worried about getting their money back. The studios, run by Mr. Atlas Ang, were reportedly locked or taken down, and he has become uncontactable. The police are investigating the matter, and the Consumers Association of Singapore has advised consumers to seek recourse through the Small Claims Tribunals and to check the credibility of the companies before making large upfront payments.

site_title: Crypto nurses losses as clock ticks to Ethereum upgrade
summary: Cryptocurrency markets experienced sharp losses due to restrictive US monetary policy expectations, with Bitcoin near US$20,000 and Ether struggling to hold above US$1,600. The Ethereum blockchain's upgrade, known as the Merge, is set to slash energy use and is expected to be smooth, according to co-founder Joseph Lubin. However, the upgrade's potential impact on digital assets is still uncertain, and some Ethereum-based services may require further work. The Merge is expected to occur late this week, potentially bringing attention back to the Ethereum upgrade and its potential effects on cryptocurrency markets.

site_title: Golf: World rankings risk being 'laughing stock' if LIV excluded, warns Norman
summary: LIV Golf chief Greg Norman warned that the Official World Golf Ranking (OWGR) could become a "laughing stock" if it doesn't award points to players from the Saudi-backed breakaway circuit. Norman urged the custodians of major tournaments to let LIV players participate, despite the PGA Tour's zero-tolerance stance. If LIV players can earn OWGR points, it would make the system obsolete and allow them to qualify for majors more easily. Norman said the OWGR has two options: include LIV or fold, with everyone being happy if they choose the former.

site_title: Asia currency pushback grows as Fed fears ripple across the region
summary: Asian policymakers push back against a surging US dollar, seeking to stem losses in regional currencies that teetered near key levels that may trigger more selling. Japan and South Korea ramped up rhetoric, while China set the yuan's daily reference rate at its strongest bias on record. The decline was sparked by a strong US inflation print, with traders betting on further dollar strength. However, a depleting foreign reserve stock may limit central banks' ability to fight the dollar surge, with some experts suggesting verbal interventions have had limited results.

site_title: Ex-GM of construction firm jailed for cheating offences leading to loss of $755k
summary: Thang Cheong Nam, 56, a former general manager of Golden Nugget construction firm, was sentenced to 4 years and 6 months in jail for cheating two financial institutions out of $755,000. He made 7 fraudulent applications between 2013 and 2014, submitting forged invoices to obtain advance financing. The court heard that Nam had a misguided intent to help the firm, but instead duped the institutions into disbursing funds to three Hong Kong-based suppliers. Nam showed remorse and surrendered himself to the police in 2015, with his lawyers citing his genuine intentions as mitigating factors.

site_title: F1 festivities back after two-year break
summary: The Formula 1 Singapore Grand Prix is set to see its biggest turnout since 2008, with parties to be held from Sept 23 to Oct 2 at four locations: Sentosa, Orchard Road, Clarke Quay, and Kampong Glam. The events, curated by the Singapore Tourism Board, offer a range of activities, including racing simulators, live music, and exhibitions, catering to both F1 fans and the general public. With a surge in flight bookings, the country is expecting a record-breaking influx of visitors, mainly from Oceania.

site_title: Absconding lawyer Charles Yeo remains at large, court told in review of warrant of arrest
summary: Lawyer Charles Yeo Yao Hui, 32, remains at large after absconding, with a warrant of arrest issued against him. He was charged with harassment and wounding the religious feeling of Christians. Yeo forfeited his $15,000 full bail amount and another review is scheduled for March 29. He initially left Singapore to meet a witness but later stated he intended to seek asylum in the UK, prompting his lawyers to be discharged. Efforts are underway to trace his whereabouts with assistance from foreign counterparts.

site_title: Football: Deputy president Bernard Tan to lead FAS in the interim after Lim Kia Tong's death
summary: Deputy president Bernard Tan will lead the Football Association of Singapore (FAS) in the interim after sitting president Lim Kia Tong's death due to a heart attack. Tan, who has been FAS deputy president since 2017, is likely to be interim FAS president until next year's Congress, when a new leader will be elected. The next FAS elections are scheduled for 2025, and there is insufficient time for the election process to take place.

site_title: Metallic foreign matter found in goat cheese from France sold in S'pore, product recalled
summary: The Singapore Food Agency (SFA) has ordered the recall of French goat cheese "President Sainte Maure Cheese" due to the presence of metallic foreign matter. The affected products, manufactured in France and sold in Singapore, have been identified by lot numbers 227DD0539, 234AC0565, and 241DD0540, with expiration dates between Nov 1 and Nov 15. Consumers are advised not to consume the product and to contact retailers for more information, while those who have consumed it should seek medical advice if they have concerns about their health. The recall is ongoing.

site_title: Evening Update: Today's headlines from The Straits Times on Sept 14
summary: Singapore's total employment reached 99.5% of pre-pandemic levels in Q2. The country approved Moderna's first bivalent Covid-19 booster jab for individuals 18 and above. Meanwhile, condo and HDB rentals continued their growth trend, with 20 consecutive months of expansion. However, a lawyer was struck off the rolls for embezzling $33 million, and police lodged reports against fitness studios that allegedly closed down overnight. Other notable news includes the passing of FAS president Lim Kia Tong and Singaporean swimmer Li Ling Yung-Hryniewiecki's successful English Channel swim, as well as a family's overnight stay in Turkey after a flight mix-up.

site_title: Overbooking by cruise operators and airlines: Consumer watchdog to engage STB, CAAS
summary: Singapore's consumer watchdog, the Consumers Association of Singapore, plans to engage the Singapore Tourism Board and Civil Aviation Authority to address concerns about overbooking by cruise operators and airlines. Following a recent incident where over 100 customers were unable to board the Genting Dream cruise ship, the watchdog is reviewing the practice of overbooking and considering regulation to ensure fair compensation for affected customers. Experts caution that regulation may pose additional costs to operators and that alternative arrangements, such as setting guidelines for travel service associations, may be a more practical solution.

site_title: Li Ling Yung-Hryniewiecki swims across English Channel in 12h 54m, first S'pore woman to do so
summary: Li Ling Yung-Hryniewiecki, a 37-year-old Singaporean woman, became the first Singaporean woman to swim across the English Channel in 12 hours and 54 minutes. The swim, which started from Samphire Hoe near Dover and ended at Cap Gris-Nez in northern France, was part of her fundraising efforts for the Splash Foundation, a non-profit organization in Hong Kong. Yung-Hryniewiecki had spent two years planning the swim and trained extensively to prepare her body for the cold water.

site_title: What to know about Singapore’s new national symbols - lion head, public seal, pledge and flower
summary: Singapore has formally recognized four new national symbols: the lion head, public seal, national pledge, and national flower Vanda Miss Joaquim. The lion head, designed by Michael Lee in 1986, represents democracy, peace, and progress. The public seal, created in 1959, features the National Coat of Arms of Singapore and is used on official documents. The national pledge, written in 1966, promotes national pride and unity. The Vanda Miss Joaquim, a hybrid orchid, was chosen as the national flower due to its resilience and year-round blooming quality.

site_title: Employers ramp up hiring while retaining workers in tourism-related sectors
summary: Employers in Singapore's tourism and aviation sectors are ramping up hiring while retaining workers, with the overall monthly recruitment rate for air transport and its supporting services averaging 3.6% in Q2. The hiring rate for production and transport operators, cleaners, and labourers in the sector was particularly strong at 11.6%, while the overall vacancy rate for the sector remains high at 11.1%. Despite this, resignation rates for all sectors held steady, indicating that employers are able to both attract and retain workers, providing relief to manpower shortages.

site_title: Motor racing: Williams driver Albon out of hospital after respiratory failure
summary: Alex Albon, Williams driver, has been released from hospital after suffering respiratory failure following complications from appendix surgery. The 26-year-old underwent surgery but was transferred to intensive care and required breathing assistance. He was removed from a ventilator and allowed to leave hospital to travel home to Monaco on Tuesday. Albon will hope to return to racing in the next event in Singapore on October 2, after impressing with his performances for Williams this season, including his first point at the Australian Grand Prix.

site_title: Football: Chelsea owner Boehly wants Premier League all-star game
summary: New Chelsea chairman Todd Boehly has proposed an American-style all-star Premier League game between a north and south team, suggesting the funds raised could be used to redistribute money from the top of the game down the football pyramid. Boehly, who also owns shares in the Los Angeles Dodgers and Lakers, cited the success of MLB and NBA all-star games as inspiration. The idea comes as Boehly hints at a breakdown in his relationship with former Chelsea manager Thomas Tuchel, who was sacked after a defeat to Dinamo Zagreb, and confirms the club's plans to adopt a multi-club model.

site_title: Luxury goods scam: 6 civil cases filed to recover money paid for Rolex watches, other items
summary: Six civil cases have been filed in Singapore to recover over $6.7 million paid for luxury items, mostly Rolex watches, from Tradenation and Tradeluxury. Pi Jiapeng and his wife allegedly collected payments for items worth at least $32 million, but failed to deliver. The cases, filed in High Court, State Courts, and Small Claims Tribunals, seek to recover the money paid by three customers.

site_title: Football: Italian Serie A to introduce semi-automated offside before World Cup
summary: Serie A will introduce semi-automated offside technology before the World Cup, following VAR controversy at the weekend. The technology, developed by FIFA, uses optical tracking to provide precise information to match officials. It will be tested at Juventus' Champions League match against Benfica and is set to be used in the Italian league "within a few weeks." The system was trialed at the FIFA Club World Cup and Arab Cup, and is being used in the Champions League group stage. The introduction of the technology aims to improve accuracy and speed of offside calls.

site_title: China sets renminbi fix at strongest bias on record to lift currency
summary: China set the renminbi fix at 6.9116 per US dollar, the strongest bias on record, to support the currency amid offshore renminbi weakening towards 7, its lowest since 2020. The move aims to stabilize the market and counter US inflation data fueling bets on Federal Reserve hikes. Analysts believe the policy intention is to anchor spot prices, but may not be enough to turn around dollar-renminbi. China's economy is under pressure from Covid-19 lockdowns and property sector turmoil, with some analysts predicting no long-term renminbi depreciation.

site_title: Tycoon Richard Li's insurer FWD refiles for Hong Kong IPO
summary: FWD Group Holdings, backed by billionaire Richard Li, has refiled an application for a Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO) amid market volatility. The insurer aims to raise around US$1 billion, with Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs, and others serving as joint sponsors. Despite an adjusted loss of US$333 million in the first half of 2022, FWD's operating profit before tax jumped 111% to US$200 million. The company initially planned to list in the US, but switched to Hong Kong due to regulatory concerns. A Hong Kong IPO could take place as early as the first quarter of next year.

site_title: Porsche IPO draws commitment from Norwegian wealth fund: Sources
summary: Volkswagen's Porsche unit is set to list through an IPO, with anchor investors including the Norwegian sovereign wealth fund Norges Bank Investment Management. The company is discussing a valuation of €70 billion to €85 billion and aims to finalize a price range over the weekend. Other investors, such as T. Rowe Price Group and Qatar Investment Authority, have also expressed interest. The IPO is seen as a way to raise funds for Porsche's electrification and software development costs. A listing is expected to reopen European markets, which have been largely shut due to the energy crisis and economic uncertainty.

site_title: Football: FAS president Lim Kia Tong dies aged 70
summary: Lim Kia Tong, the 70-year-old president of the Football Association of Singapore (FAS), died on Wednesday after suffering a heart attack. He was first elected FAS president in 2017 and re-elected unopposed four years later. Described as generous, passionate, and straight-talking, Lim was a dedicated servant of football and left a lasting impact on the sport. He was praised by former players, footballers, and world governing bodies, including FIFA, for his dedication and commitment to developing football in Singapore. A space will be set up at the Jalan Besar Stadium for people to pay their respects.

site_title: Tencent Music plans Hong Kong debut as soon as next week: Sources
summary: Tencent Music Entertainment Group plans to list on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange as soon as next week, according to sources. The Shenzhen-based company, which already trades in New York, aims to pursue a secondary listing by introducing its existing shares, rather than raising new capital. This move comes as part of a trend of Chinese firms seeking alternative listings due to escalating Sino-US tensions, which have raised delisting risks. The listing is expected to be completed by way of introduction, without selling new shares.

site_title: Private home sales slowed in first half of 2022 as cooling measures tamped down demand
summary: Singapore's private home sales slowed in the first half of 2022 due to cooling measures, with 13,311 units sold between January and June, a third of the 37,433 units sold in 2021. The introduction of higher additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) rates for foreigners and citizens buying second and subsequent properties contributed to the decline. Despite this, overall sales are on track to exceed 2020's transactions, but are unlikely to surpass last year's numbers. The market is expected to moderate further in the second half of 2022 due to rising interest rates and cautious buyer sentiment.

site_title: Starbucks projects profit growth from tech, new stores, workers spending
summary: Starbucks projects 15-20% profit growth per share over the next three years, driven by tech investments and new store openings. The company expects to return $20 billion to investors through share buybacks and dividends. To address employee burnout and capacity issues, Starbucks is introducing "load balancing" technology and exploring new store designs and equipment, such as faster ice machines and paperless brewing systems. The company plans to reach 45,000 stores by 2025, including 2,000 new US stores, and nearly double its Chinese store count to 9,000.

site_title: US dollar pushes towards fresh 24-year peak versus yen after inflation shock
summary: The US dollar surged to a 24-year peak against the yen, reaching 144.965 yen, amid a jump in US yields following hotter-than-expected inflation. This move reflects increased bets for aggressive monetary tightening by the Federal Reserve next week, with some economists predicting a 100 basis point rate hike. The dollar's rise pushed the yen to a 25-year low, while the euro and sterling also edged up. The dollar index rose 1.44% overnight, its biggest one-day gain since March 2020.

site_title: Traders start to consider even bigger Fed rate hikes after hot inflation data
summary: US traders are now betting on the Federal Reserve to raise its benchmark rate by at least 3/4 of a percentage point next week, with some expecting a full percentage point increase, amid hotter-than-expected inflation data. The overnight index swap contract suggests a minimum 75 basis points of tightening, and some analysts expect a 100 basis point move this month. If confirmed, this would push the benchmark rate towards 4.3% by the end of 2022, potentially forcing the Fed to reconsider its policy before the end of the year.

site_title: Lawyer Jeffrey Ong, who fled S'pore after $33m of client's money went missing, struck off the roll
summary: Lawyer Jeffrey Ong, who fled Singapore after $33 million of his client's money went missing, has been struck off the rolls by the Court of Three Judges. Ong, 45, had acted dishonestly and breached several Legal Profession (Professional Conduct) Rules. He was found to have misappropriated funds, forged a cheque, and misrepresented to Allied Technologies about releasing the funds. Ong currently faces 76 charges, including for criminal breach of trust, forgery, and cheating. He was denied bail last year and is currently in remand since June 2019.

site_title: Vacancies shrink as more jobs filled; total employment in Q2 near pre-pandemic level
summary: Singapore's labour market remains tight, with 126,100 job vacancies in June, slightly lower than March. Total employment surpassed pre-pandemic levels, growing 66,500 in the second quarter to 99.5% of the 2019 level. Non-resident employment, especially in construction and manufacturing, drove the increase. The unemployment rate declined to 2.1% in July, while retrenchments fell to record lows. The recruitment rate rose to 2.6%, last seen in 2014, with accommodation and air transport sectors seeing the largest increase in recruitment rates.

site_title: US to discuss new chips law with Taiwan next month
summary: The US will discuss its new "Chips and Science Act" with Taiwan next month, with the top US diplomat in Taipei, Sandra Oudkirk, set to lead the talks from October 12-14. The law, signed by President Joe Biden last month, provides $52 billion in government subsidies and $24 billion in investment tax credits for US semiconductor production. The US aims to boost its domestic chip industry, with Taiwan's TSMC and GlobalWafers already investing in US facilities. The talks will focus on implementing the law and strengthening economic ties between the two countries.

site_title: No significant disruption to rice supply in S'pore, but some may raise prices due to India's export tax
summary: Singapore's rice supply remains unaffected, with no significant disruption reported. The country's Rice Stockpile Scheme has helped mitigate any potential impact. India's recent 20% export tax on key rice varieties and ban on broken rice exports may lead to price increases, with some businesses like Mustafa Centre and Chennai Trading and Supermarket planning to raise prices by 20%. However, others, such as Supermarket chain Sheng Siong and Catering Solutions, will not increase prices immediately, citing stable supplies and gradual price adjustments.

site_title: 4 people assaulted low-IQ teen and made him drink urine; 1 person given reformative training  ​
summary: Four individuals in Singapore assaulted a 19-year-old teenager with special needs, forcing him to drink urine, over a nine-day period. The victim was found in a hotel room with severe injuries, including slash wounds, chemical burns, and fractures. One of the attackers, Putri Nuramira Aishah Rosli, 20, was sentenced to a minimum of 12 months of reformative training. The incident highlights concerns about group abuse and the need for rehabilitation programs to address the perpetrators' actions.

site_title: Football: Borussia Dortmund to play Lion City Sailors in friendly in late November
summary: Borussia Dortmund, an eight-time German champion, will play a friendly match with Lion City Sailors in Singapore in late November. This match will be part of Dortmund's mid-season World Cup break, during which they will also play in Indonesia and Vietnam. The German squad may be missing several key players, including Marco Reus and Jude Bellingham, who are set to participate in the World Cup in Qatar. This friendly match is a rare opportunity for fans in Southeast Asia to see up-and-coming players like Salih Ozcan and Youssoufa Moukoko.

site_title: Debt collection practices being regulated, but a few areas need careful consideration
summary: Singapore's Debt Collection Bill, passed on Tuesday, will regulate debt collection activities and curb problematic practices. The bill aims to create a licensing regime for debt collectors, protecting consumers from harassment and abuse. The measure follows a personal experience of the author, who faced threatening phone calls from an unlicensed moneylender. The bill's passage brings relief to many who have suffered from debt collection issues, and it is expected to improve the industry's practices. The licensing regime is expected to be implemented in the near future.

site_title: Football: Geylang coach Noor Ali warded following heart palpitations
summary: Geylang International coach Noor Ali, 47, was hospitalized at Changi General Hospital after experiencing heart palpitations. He was in the dugout on Sunday when the team lost 4-2 to Hougang United, but his health took priority. The club wishes for his speedy recovery, and assistant coach Syed Azmir is leading the team's training sessions. This is the second health scare for an SPL coach in two years, following Young Lions coach Nazri Nasir's mild stroke in 2020.

site_title: Condo and HDB rentals in August continue growth trend, more units leased
summary: Rentals for Housing Board (HDB) flats and private apartments in Singapore continued their growth trend in August, with HDB rents rising 2.4% and condominium rents increasing 3.2%. This marks the 20th straight month of expansion for condo rents and 26th for HDB rents. Year-on-year, condo rents have surged 27.5%, while HDB rents are 21.6% higher. Analysts attribute the rise to the relaxed Covid-19 restrictions and increased demand from foreign students and expatriates, with rental volumes stabilizing despite a decline in units leased.

site_title: Moya Holdings Asia seeks delisting through voluntary cash offer at 9.2 cents per share
summary: Moya Holdings Asia, an Indonesian water treatment operator, announced plans to take the company private through a voluntary cash offer from Tamaris Infrastructure, its majority shareholder, at 9.2 cents per share. The offer represents a 41.5% premium over the last traded price. To delist, the company must gain approval from 75% of shareholders. The offer provides shareholders with an opportunity to realize their investments, allow for greater management flexibility, and save costs on maintaining listed status. The offerer plans to make Moya its wholly owned subsidiary if 90% of shares are accepted.

site_title: Post-pandemic health challenges set to be more complex: Panel
summary: Future health challenges are expected to become more complex, requiring a multi-faceted approach beyond technical solutions. Experts, including Singapore's director of medical services Kenneth Mak and physics laureate George Smoot, discussed the need to address social, cultural, and economic issues alongside technological advancements. Technology will play a key role in tackling these challenges, including precision health, care substitution, and data analysis to identify risk groups and improve healthcare delivery. The panel emphasized the importance of a holistic approach to address the evolving health landscape post-pandemic.

site_title: First job support hub for people with disabilities to open next year in the west
summary: Singapore is set to launch its first Enabling Business Hub, a job support centre for people with disabilities, in the west region next year. The hub aims to contribute to the government's aspirational target of 40% employment among people with disabilities by 2030. Each hub will provide customized work support and hire staff with disabilities, with training provided to staff to better interact with people with disabilities. The initiative is part of the Enabling Masterplan 2030, which also aims to increase the number of people with disabilities in employment from 30.1% to 40% by 2030.

site_title: Crypto traders flee Indian exchanges for Binance to escape taxes
summary: Binance's downloads surged to 429,000 in India in August, triple that of runner-up CoinDCX, as foreign exchanges like Binance and FTX avoid deducting the 1% tax on crypto transactions. Indian-origin platforms have started deducting the levy, prompting traders to switch to foreign exchanges. The tax change has led to a 90% decline in daily volumes at Indian-based platforms. Binance is monitoring the situation and may make further announcements, while its rival WazirX's monthly downloads plummeted to 92,000 in August.

site_title: Football: Bayern beat Barca 2-0 in Champions League on Lewandowski return
summary: Bayern Munich defeated Barcelona 2-0 in their Champions League Group C match, with goals from Lucas Hernandez and Leroy Sane in a span of four minutes. The win moves Bayern to the top of the group on six points, while Barcelona trails on three points. Robert Lewandowski, who left Bayern in the summer, had several chances but was unable to score against his former team, with coach Julian Nagelsmann expressing relief after a win that follows three consecutive draws in the Bundesliga.

site_title: Football: Sporting subs grab late 2-0 Champions League win over stunned Spurs
summary: Tottenham Hotspur suffered their first defeat of the season, losing 2-0 to Sporting in the Champions League. Paulinho scored the opening goal in the 90th minute and Arthur Gomes sealed the victory in added time with a superb strike. The win gives Sporting a 6-point lead in Group D, with Tottenham trailing on 3 points. Tottenham coach Antonio Conte was frustrated with the collapse at the end of the game, while Sporting's Marcus Edwards praised his team's performance, saying they deserved the win.

site_title: Football: Late Matip header earns Liverpool Champions League win over Ajax
summary: Liverpool secured a 2-1 win over Ajax in their Champions League Group A match at Anfield. Joel Matip headed in a late winner in the 89th minute after a corner was initially cleared off the line. Mohamed Salah had given Liverpool the lead in the 17th minute, but Ajax equalized 10 minutes later with a stunning strike from Mohammed Kudus. Liverpool dominated the second half but were relieved to secure the three points, ending a difficult start to the season.

site_title: More divisive world could impact action on climate change: Vivian
summary: A more divisive world could hinder global efforts to address climate change, according to Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan. Geostrategic rivalry and the resulting impact on scientific collaboration could lead to reduced efficiency in global supply chains, contributing to inflation and making it more challenging to achieve the Paris Agreement's goal of limiting global warming to 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels. Balakrishnan emphasized the importance of global collaboration to build a better future, citing Nobel laureates as role models who can bring valuable knowledge and values to the table.

site_title: From Belgian beer to German tomato, Europe's energy crisis is spilling over
summary: Europe's energy crisis is causing a ripple effect on food and drink supplies, forcing businesses and consumers to make tough decisions. Belgium's Brewery Huyghe is at risk of halting production due to a surge in liquid carbon dioxide prices, while German grower Wittenberg Gemuese was stranded when ammonia production halted. The European Union is proposing measures to cut power use and funnel energy company profits to struggling consumers. The crisis is also affecting industries such as fertilization and baking, with at least half of the region's capacity offline, and threatens to disrupt food supply chains.

site_title: Businesses remain profitable despite rising costs: Low Yen Ling
summary: Singapore businesses remain profitable despite rising costs, with gross profits increasing by 9.8% year-on-year in the second quarter. The increase in profits is largely due to higher business costs in the manufacturing and service sectors, driven by rising global energy prices and supply chain disruptions. The Government will continue to monitor business costs and provide support when needed. Relief schemes, such as the Progressive Wage Credit Scheme, have been rolled out to help businesses cope with rising costs. Both the retail and hospitality sectors have seen strong recoveries, with total retail sales exceeding 2019 levels.

site_title: Refusing to give DNA an offence for crime suspects
summary: Singapore's police can now collect DNA samples from suspects involved in non-serious crimes, such as stalking, drink driving, and voluntarily causing hurt, in addition to serious crimes like murder and robbery. The move aims to bolster the police's ability to solve crimes, with about 60% of crime scene samples collected between 2017 and last year being unmatched against the current DNA database. Refusing to provide DNA can result in fines, imprisonment, or both, and police may use reasonable force to collect non-invasive samples like cheek swabs.

site_title: US stocks end with steep declines after hot inflation data
summary: US stocks plummeted on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 3.9% and the S&P 500 dropping 4.3%, as disappointing inflation data raised concerns about the Federal Reserve's ability to ease its anti-inflation measures. Despite a slight slowdown in the annual consumer price index, core CPI accelerated sharply, and economists predict a third consecutive three-quarter point hike. The Nasdaq Composite Index also suffered its worst point loss since May 5.

site_title: Allow singles to apply for BTO flat from age 28: WP's Louis Chua
summary: Singaporean Workers' Party MP Louis Chua has proposed lowering the age threshold for singles to apply for Build-To-Order (BTO) flats from 35 to 28. He argued that current policy deprives singles of home ownership due to affordability issues. Chua cited data showing that singles do not compete with young couples and families for the same flat types. Senior Minister of State Tan Kiat How responded that the government has expanded housing options for singles, but will continue to engage with Singaporeans on their needs and aspirations.

site_title: Usually not offence to unknowingly consume drugs overseas: Minister
summary: Home Affairs and Law Minister K. Shanmugam stated that unknowingly consuming drugs overseas is usually not an offence. He cited the case of Singaporean travellers accidentally buying cannabis-infused products in Thailand, which has become common since Thailand's decriminalization of cannabis in June. The Central Narcotics Bureau (CNB) will investigate, but Shanmugam advised travellers to be cautious and check product labels to avoid unintentional consumption. The CNB is partnering with stakeholders to raise awareness about cannabis dangers through preventive education programs and will engage travellers at checkpoints to caution them against purchasing such products.

site_title: S'pore spent $72.3b in fight against Covid-19 over last 2 financial years
summary: Singapore spent $72.3 billion over the last two financial years to combat COVID-19, with $50.6 billion used to protect jobs through support for workers and businesses. The actual expenditure was lower than the initial $100 billion commitment due to loan capital being released and under-utilization of public health spending. The government will review its financial practices and strengthen controls on procurement and expenditure during emergencies.

site_title: SMEs plan to digitalise to overcome manpower constraints: Survey
summary: Singaporean SMEs see digitalisation as a way to overcome manpower constraints, with 54% planning to transform, automate, and/or digitalise their businesses. Despite 72% forecasting profits this year, rising business costs, availability of suitable manpower, and inflationary pressures are the top three challenges. 68% have applied for government assistance schemes, particularly in digitalisation and technology adoption. The government aims to build enterprise resilience and foster trust in the digital economy, with initiatives such as the Cyber Trust mark and Data Protection Essentials Programme.

site_title: New centre offers help for girls and women facing online attacks
summary: A new resource centre, SheCares@SCWO, launched in Singapore to provide support for girls and women facing online harassment and attacks. The centre, initiated by non-profit organisation SG Her Empowerment (SHE), offers a helpline, counselling, and free legal services by the end of the year. SHE aims to simplify the reporting process for online content and has raised $1 million for operations. The charity, led by veteran lawyer Stefanie Yuen Thio, is working with social media platforms and law societies to address online harm and promote awareness.

site_title: More ships call to refuel at S'pore port in August amid drop in oil prices
summary: Singapore's marine fuel sales rose 1.1% to 4.12 million tonnes in August, driven by lower oil prices that drew more ships to refuel. This is the highest number of ships since November, with 3,212 vessels calling to bunker. Prices for low-sulphur shipping fuel fell from US$875 to US$742 a tonne, making Singapore an attractive refueling option for ship owners. The drop in prices has led to increased refueling activity, with operators citing lower operational downtime compared to other regions.

site_title: Must-reads
summary: A new law in the debt collection industry will regulate conduct that includes threatening physical harm or revealing debtor information. The Debt Collection Bill, passed in Parliament, aims to prevent problematic debt collection practices. In Russia, over 40 elected officials signed a petition demanding President Vladimir Putin's resignation. Thousands paid respects to Queen Elizabeth II in Edinburgh before her state funeral. DBS Bank has set decarbonization targets for seven sectors it finances, while a global recession is unlikely, with regional economic strains more likely, according to JP Morgan.

site_title: 2 jailed for cheating that led to $12m loss for 3 banks, firm
summary: Two men, Ho Yik Fuh and Yeo Kee Siah, have been convicted of cheating and sentenced to jail for duping three banks and a wholesale trading firm into handing over over $12 million in loans. Ho, a car dealer and director of several firms, used a consignment-like arrangement to get financing illegitimately, with Yeo helping to issue false documents. Ho was sentenced to 15 years in jail, while Yeo received three years and four months. Both men intend to appeal against their convictions and sentences.

site_title: MOE working with Sped schools on pay, prospects for teachers
summary: The Ministry of Education (MOE) is working with Special Education (Sped) schools to improve teacher training, pay, and career prospects. MOE will partner with social service agencies to set up five new Sped schools by 2030, and two new early intervention centres by mid-2023. To attract and retain talent, MOE will explore new models, focusing on better outcomes for children, professional development for Sped teachers, and community engagement. The ministry funds all Sped teachers' diplomas in special education and will raise key positions for career advancement.

site_title: Global energy crisis could speed up green transition: Bank chief
summary: DBS Bank CEO Piyush Gupta says the global energy crisis will likely speed up the transition to greener energy sources as reliance on fossil fuels becomes increasingly challenging. However, in the short term, major economies may rush to secure coal and gas supplies due to Ukraine disruptions. Gupta notes that nations prioritize energy resilience and do not want to be held hostage to a single energy source. While some backsliding is expected, he believes the crisis will accelerate the green transition over a 5-10 year period, but warns of short-term market distortions.

site_title: SAF scheme allows drug abusers to confess once without punishment
summary: Singapore's SAF Amnesty Scheme allows servicemen to confess to drug abuse without punishment, receiving counseling and rehabilitation instead. Those who test positive will be charged and face court-martial sentences of 8-9 months detention. The scheme, introduced in 1976, allows one-time avoidance of punishment, with normal penalties applying thereafter. Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen emphasized the need for prevention and enforcement through testing, punishment, and rehabilitation, with measures including regular urine tests and briefings before overseas exercises. Confessed or suspected abusers will be put on a urine test regime and attend counseling sessions.

site_title: Greater flexibility in use of state symbols; stop order for abuse
summary: Singapore's Parliament passed changes to the law on national symbols, allowing for more flexibility in their use while raising penalties for abuse. The new regulations recognize the national pledge, Vanda Miss Joaquim, lion head, and public seal as national symbols alongside the state flag, state crest, and National Anthem. Penalties for misuse, such as burning or desecrating the flag, will be higher, with fines up to $30,000 or imprisonment for up to six months. The government aims to strike a balance between creative use and respect for the symbols, with guidelines to be published next year.

site_title: New law to rein in bad debt collection practices
summary: A new law in Singapore aims to regulate debt collection practices, targeting entities that collect debt from debtors on behalf of others or acquire debt themselves. Those who threaten physical harm or put up personal information of debtors will face jail or fines of up to $10,000. The Debt Collection Bill establishes a licensing regime for debt collection agencies, with penalties for those who engage in problematic conduct. The regulations are expected to take effect next year and will also include public education and awareness campaigns.

site_title: Greenback's unrelenting strength, renminbi weakness may test Singdollar's resilience
summary: The Singapore dollar has outperformed most Asian and global peers this year, but its resilience is tied to the currencies of the US and China. A rising US dollar would tighten global financial conditions, stifling demand for Asian exports, while a weaker renminbi would exacerbate the struggles of trade-driven economies like Singapore's. The Singapore dollar's fate remains uncertain, vulnerable to the fluctuations of its major trading partners' currencies.

site_title: Man jailed for breaching Covid-19 isolation order
summary: A 22-year-old man, Verner Chua Jun Jie, was jailed for one month and one week for breaching a Covid-19 isolation order. Chua, who had a history of theft and drug abuse, was ordered to isolate after developing a cough in December 2020 but instead met a friend for supper and asked for money to pay a fine. He failed to report to a supervision scheme and cut off his monitoring tag. Chua pleaded guilty to two charges, including putting others at risk of disease.

site_title: Divorcing parents of minors to take course, undergo counselling
summary: Singapore's Minister of State for Social and Family Development, Sun Xueling, announced that parents of minors filing for divorce must take an e-learning course and undergo counselling starting this month. The new requirement aims to help parents understand their marital situation, co-parenting relationship, and children's needs. The course will be followed by counselling from a Strengthening Families Programme or Divorce Support Specialist Agency to assess and support parents' needs. This change is part of a broader effort to reduce acrimony in divorce and promote co-parenting.

site_title: No plans to include Covid-19 jabs in kids' vaccination schedule
summary: Singapore's Health Minister Ong Ye Kung stated that there are no plans to include Covid-19 jabs in kids' vaccination schedule, citing a dynamic pandemic situation that will be reviewed with new data. Since vaccination, about 5.7 per 100,000 young people under 18 developed a rare inflammatory syndrome, compared to 38 per 100,000 without vaccination. The Health Sciences Authority is evaluating the Novavax vaccine for those under 18, and bivalent vaccines targeting both ancestral and Omicron strains are also being brought to the country.

site_title: Rise in public transport costs not matched by revenue growth: Iswaran
summary: Singapore's public transport costs have risen by an average 7% annually between 2012 and 2021, but revenue growth has not kept pace. The government provides over $2 billion in subsidies yearly. Transport Minister S. Iswaran announced that the Public Transport Council will review the fare formula by mid-2023 to account for changes in commuting patterns, inflation, and energy costs. The review aims to balance affordability with financial sustainability and ensure the vulnerable segments of society pay a fair share.

site_title: Flood devastation in Pakistan 'just the beginning' of climate crisis
summary: Pakistan's recent floods, affecting a third of the country, are a harbinger of the climate crisis, which is expected to displace 1.2 billion people by 2050. Climate consultant Pok Wei Heng attributed the floods to global emissions, despite Pakistan's minimal contribution. Developed countries are urged to reduce emissions, while individuals and governments can make high-impact changes, such as adopting low-carbon diets and implementing policies like labelling and taxing unhealthy food. The challenge lies in balancing high-impact changes with high costs, as noted by experts.

site_title: Half of Singapore employers plan to hire in Q4: Survey
summary: Half of Singapore employers plan to increase headcount in Q4, with sectors like banking, finance, and real estate showing particularly bullish sentiments. Despite economic headwinds, hiring intentions improved 38% compared to last year. The strongest demand is for IT, finance, and customer service roles, while education, health, and government sectors face the weakest demand. A majority of Singapore employers struggle to find suitable candidates due to a tight labour market and shortage of skilled workers. Hiring is expected to remain high for the rest of the year, driven by year-end festivities and the recovery of MICE events.

site_title: Company Briefs: Frasers Hospitality Trust
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust shares plummeted after a proposal to take the trust private fell through, with 74.88% of shareholder votes in favor but narrowly missing the 75% needed. Bank of America formed a new wealth management banking and lending group, led by April Schneider, comprising 3,500 employees. HSBC's CFO Ewen Stevenson warned of significant salary hikes due to rising inflation, which could put the bank $500 million short of its cost target next year.

site_title: Debt collection practices set to be regulated, but some areas need careful consideration
summary: Singapore is set to regulate debt collection practices with the introduction of the Debt Collection Bill. The bill aims to protect consumers from harassment and abuse by unlicensed moneylenders. However, some areas, such as the regulation of debt counseling services and the impact on unlicensed moneylenders, require careful consideration. The bill's passage brings relief to individuals who have suffered from excessive phone calls and threats from moneylenders, as seen in the author's personal experience with an unlicensed moneylender. The regulation is expected to improve consumer protection and promote a more transparent debt collection industry.

site_title: Sing$ remains Asia's best performer against greenback's relentless surge
summary: The Singapore dollar has become Asia's best performer against the US dollar's surge, with traders seeking refuge in the region's safest haven. This is due to the country's recovering economy and a hawkish central bank, which has tightened monetary policy four times since October last year. As a result, the Sing dollar has outperformed regional peers, including China and Japan.

site_title: Singapore stocks lifted by US bear market bounce
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.5% to 3,290.08 points, tracking US equities' fourth consecutive day of gains. Regional markets were mixed, with South Korea's Kospi Composite Index jumping 2.7% and Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rising 0.7%. CapitaLand Investment was the top performer, gaining 2.7%. US CPI data release ahead of the Fed meeting on September 21 is expected to impact the market.

site_title: Condo resale volume falls for 4th month as prices hold firm
summary: Condo resale volume fell for the fourth consecutive month in September, with 1,135 units changing hands, a 14.5% decrease from July. Despite the decline, resale prices held firm, increasing 1.2% for the 25th straight month. Experts attribute the steady prices to buyers and sellers adjusting to rising mortgage rates and anticipating higher prices for new condo launches. The market is expected to continue its downward trend, with analysts predicting a widening price gap between buyers and sellers.

site_title: Analysts cut oil outlook on recession fears, China virus curbs
summary: Analysts at Morgan Stanley and UBS have cut their near-term oil price forecasts due to recession fears and China's ongoing coronavirus restrictions. Morgan Stanley reduced its Brent crude price outlook by $12 a barrel to $98 for the third quarter and $5 to $95 for the fourth quarter. UBS slashed its year-end forecast by $15 a barrel to $110, citing elevated Russian exports and China lockdowns. Despite these cuts, analysts expect Brent crude to recover to $125 a barrel by the end of 2023 as demand recovers and Russian supply declines.

site_title: Changi's Terminal 4 handles 1,000 passengers on first day of reopening
summary: Changi Airport's Terminal 4 reopened on September 13, 2022, after over two years of closure, handling approximately 1,000 passengers on its first day. Cathay Pacific and Korean Air were the first airlines to operate, with 14 others scheduled to follow in stages until October. The terminal, which has a capacity of 16 million passengers a year, will add to Changi Airport's capacity and help meet increasing demand for air travel. The airport conducted operational readiness trials with airlines and partners before the reopening.

site_title: Hong Kong HQ of Evergrande taken over by receiver
summary: China Evergrande Group's Hong Kong headquarters building, worth over $1 billion, has been taken over by receiver Alvarez & Marsal Asia, according to a document from the Companies Registry. The move follows the developer's failure to deliver a preliminary restructuring plan for its offshore debt, and comes as Evergrande faces a credit crisis affecting China's real estate sector. The 26-storey office building was pledged as security for $1.4 billion in loans made by Chinese lenders in 2020. Evergrande has vowed to announce a specific restructuring proposal before the end of the year.

site_title: Brent, spot and Opec: Making sense of energy market terms
summary: The global energy market has been impacted by rising prices and sanctions on Russia's oil and gas exports. The Brent crude benchmark, used to buy and sell over three-quarters of the world's traded oil, is preferred by physical oil traders for its accuracy in reflecting global supply and demand balances. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) and its allies, OPEC+, have agreed to a 100,000 barrel per day cut to prevent oil prices from sliding further. The G-7 nations and European Union are also working to introduce a price cap on Russian oil to limit Moscow's ability to fund its invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: SGX makes push for full disclosure of CEO pay
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is planning to introduce changes to its corporate disclosure rules, including requiring companies to reveal the full amount of CEO pay. The regulatory arm, SGX RegCo, will consult the market on the proposal, which also includes imposing a nine-year cap on the tenure of independent directors. This move aims to increase transparency on executive pay and address low board renewal, with only 5% of companies currently fully disclosing remuneration details. The changes are part of SGX's efforts to promote environmental, social, and governance issues, and mandatory climate-related and board diversity disclosures.

site_title: Son's goal drought doesn't worry S. Korea coach Bento
summary: South Korea coach Paulo Bento has no concerns about Tottenham forward Son Heung-min's goal drought in the Premier League, saying he will focus on upcoming friendlies against Costa Rica and Cameroon instead of discussing the issue with Son. Bento believes Son's confidence remains high, and the team will focus on the friendlies. Spurs manager Antonio Conte has hinted at potentially dropping Son due to competition from other forwards, but Bento is not considering the issue. The friendlies will give Bento a chance to assess his main squad before the World Cup.

site_title: Real have 'no limits', says coach Ancelotti
summary: Real Madrid, under coach Carlo Ancelotti, are seeking their eighth consecutive win in all competitions as they face RB Leipzig in the Champions League. The team, led by Ancelotti, has won seven matches in three competitions, including a 3-0 win at Celtic. Leipzig, led by new coach Marco Rose, has made a perfect start to the season, winning their last game against Borussia Dortmund. Real Madrid will be without key players Karim Benzema and Eder Militao, while Leipzig will miss Konrad Laimer and Dani Olmo.

site_title: We can knock over anyone: Rennie
summary: Australia coach Dave Rennie is confident his team can win the Bledisloe Cup by defeating New Zealand in Melbourne on Thursday. Rennie has made eight changes to his starting side, focusing on dominating the collision area and countering the All Blacks pack. He believes his team can "knock over anyone" but must perform at their best to have a chance against New Zealand. The match marks a crucial test for both teams, with Australia needing to win at home and New Zealand needing to win in Auckland nine days later to claim the trophy.

site_title: Ejaz, Renzo tune up nicely for thriller
summary: Rising stars Renzo and Ejaz are set to face off in a thrilling Class 4 Division 1 sprint at Kranji on Saturday. Renzo, riding grey Malibu Beach, completed a 600m gallop in 37.6 seconds, while Ejaz's mount, Muraahib, clocked 36.2 seconds for the same distance. Ejaz, trained by Michael Clements, has shown promise with a win from two starts and has twice won trials on the Polytrack. Renzo, on the other hand, has thrice collected the chocolates and is in rattling form. The two horses are expected to give each other a run for the money.

site_title: Garcia could be fined for BMW event pullout
summary: Sergio Garcia may face a fine from the DP World Tour for withdrawing from the BMW PGA Championship without a valid reason. Garcia, a former Masters champion, was seen attending an American football game in Texas, sparking speculation about his true reason for pulling out. He has yet to provide a valid explanation, with the tour giving him three weeks to do so. Failure to comply may result in a fine, with some speculating that Garcia's withdrawal was a gesture of disrespect towards the tour.

site_title: Red Lion's hard landing at NDP: Change in wind conditions a factor
summary: Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen revealed that a sudden change in wind conditions contributed to Red Lions parachutist Jeffrey Heng's hard landing at the National Day Parade (NDP) on August 9. Despite the incident, Heng did not suffer severe injuries. A review committee found that wind speeds during rehearsals and NDP 2022 were within acceptable ranges, but the committee is studying measures to increase safety, including increasing distance between parachutists and space out landings. The Red Lions will continue to participate in NDP if safety can be ensured, with a good safety record of 0.12% injuries per 3,400 jumps.

site_title: DBS sets decarbonisation targets for 7 sectors it finances
summary: DBS Bank, the largest lender in South-east Asia, has set decarbonisation targets for seven sectors, including power, oil and gas, automotive, and aviation, aiming to reduce absolute emissions by 28% by 2030. The targets, aligned with the International Energy Agency's net-zero emissions by 2050 scenario, cover emissions in categories Scope 1, 2, and 3. The bank will review and update its progress annually through its sustainability report, with CEO Piyush Gupta emphasizing the targets as a "north star" for its financing activities.

summary:

site_title: 3 sites in Lentor, Bukit Batok draw tepid bids
summary: Tenders for three state-owned plots in Lentor and Bukit Batok drew fewer bids than expected, with Lentor Central and Lentor Hills Road (Parcel B) receiving just three and two bids, respectively. Top bid prices held up, with Lentor Central selling for $1,108 psf ppr and Lentor Hills Road (Parcel B) for $1,130 psf ppr. Analysts attribute lukewarm interest to rising interest rates, construction costs, and new home supply in the Lentor area, as well as upcoming executive condominiums.

site_title: I want humble team who fight: Potter
summary: New Chelsea manager Graham Potter faces a daunting task in his first Champions League match, a home clash against RB Salzburg. Potter, who has no European elite club competition experience, aims to turn around Chelsea's fortunes after a £250 million summer splurge. He emphasizes the importance of adapting to the step up in class and building a "humble team that fights." Chelsea will be without injured goalkeeper Edouard Mendy and midfielder N'Golo Kante, while Salzburg face their own injury issues, including a depleted defense.

site_title: Joshua takes 40% deal for Fury fight
summary: Britain's Anthony Joshua has accepted a 40% offer for a December 3 fight with Tyson Fury, awaiting the WBC heavyweight champion's response. Joshua's management accepted terms presented by Fury's team last Friday but halted communication due to Queen Elizabeth II's death. Fury, 34, challenged Joshua after losing to Oleksandr Usyk in August and offered a 60-40 purse split, 40% of which would go to Joshua. A confirmation of the fight is set to be announced in the near future, pending Fury's response.

site_title: Non-binary field for Boston Marathon
summary: The Boston Athletic Association (BAA) has announced that non-binary athletes will have the option to register for the 2023 Boston Marathon without having to register in the men's or women's divisions. The new category will follow the women's qualification criteria, with non-binary athletes between 18-34 years old required to have completed a marathon in under 3 hours 30 minutes. Registration opened on September 12, and the BAA expects a field of around 30,000 runners. The move aims to promote inclusion at BAA events, following similar initiatives at other major races.

site_title: De Vries deserves F1 place: Russell
summary: Formula One driver George Russell praises Nyck de Vries for his "excellent job" on his debut with Williams at the Italian Grand Prix, saying he deserves a full-time F1 seat. De Vries stepped in as a replacement after Alex Albon's appendicitis surgery and finished ninth, outperforming teammate Nicholas Latifi. The 27-year-old Dutch driver had previously competed with Russell in junior racing and won the electric Formula E title in 2021. Verstappen also gave de Vries a pep talk before the race, congratulating him on a great job and saying he handled everything well.

site_title: Control game, Lions told
summary: Singapore national football team head coach Takayuki Nishigaya has announced a 24-man squad for two international friendlies in Vietnam and India. The team will face Vietnam on September 21 and India three days later. Nishigaya emphasizes the need for versatility and aggression in his players, with the ability to play different positions crucial for flexibility and tactical advantage. site_title: High interest rates, economic risks, draw tepid bids for 3 state-owned sites in Lentor and Bukit Batok
summary: Singapore's state-owned plots in Lentor and Bukit Batok drew fewer bids than expected, with only three and two bids respectively for Lentor Central and Lentor Hills Road (Parcel B). Top bid prices held up, but analysts attribute tepid interest to high interest rates, rising construction costs, and a build-up of new home supply in the Lentor area. The lukewarm bids may also be due to the proximity of other EC projects and rising prices near the top-end of the price envelope.

site_title: Pledge, lion head, Vanda Miss Joaquim join state flag, crest, anthem as Singapore's national symbols
summary: Singapore's national symbols, including the lion head, Vanda Miss Joaquim, national pledge, and state flag, will be formally recognized alongside the state crest and national anthem. The changes, passed by Parliament, provide more flexibility in using these symbols, while raising penalties for abuse. Those found misusing the symbols can face fines of up to $30,000 or jail terms of up to six months. The government aims to balance creative use with respect for the symbols, and plans to develop specific guidelines and raise public awareness.

site_title: Back with an even bigger smash
summary: The World Table Tennis (WTT) Grand Smash is set to return with an expanded format, including more mixed doubles pairs and a doubling of singles seeds. The Singapore Smash 2023 will feature over 200 players, with a US$2 million prize purse, and is expected to attract 50,000 spectators. The event will also include live entertainment and a revamped precinct. The WTT aims to build on its successful 2022 debut, which reached 160 million unique viewers and a cumulative reach of over 400 million across 196 markets.

site_title: Haaland could haunt old club Dortmund on return
summary: Borussia Dortmund, Haaland's former club, will face Manchester City, where he has already scored 12 goals in 8 games, including 2 against Sevilla. Erling Haaland's incredible goal-scoring record in the Champions League, with 24 goals in 20 games, may haunt Dortmund, who are struggling with injuries and doubts in their defense.
