site_title: Sports World: Newcastle snap up goalie Karius
summary: Newcastle United has signed goalkeeper Loris Karius on a short-term contract until January, with an option to extend the deal until the end of the season. The 29-year-old replaces Karl Darlow, who is sidelined with an ankle injury. Meanwhile, Rob Page has signed a four-year contract as Wales manager through the 2026 World Cup qualifying campaign. Tennis world No. 2 Casper Ruud will start his 2023 season at the Auckland Classic in January, while French cyclist Julian Alaphilippe will defend his road race title at the World Championships in Australia.

site_title: Black players' legacy alive in Gauff, Tiafoe
summary: The US Open marked an "inflection point" in the sport, with Serena Williams' farewell party transitioning into proof of her legacy for black athletes. Frances Tiafoe became the first black American man to reach the semi-finals since Arthur Ashe in 1972, while 18-year-old Coco Gauff continued the progress made by Williams and Venus. The tournament saw a record 776,120 fans, with Blackman citing the performances of Gauff and Tiafoe as evidence of progress made in the sport, inspired by trailblazers like Ashe and Gibson. Williams' legacy continues to inspire a new generation of black athletes.

site_title: Halep out for a few weeks after nose surgery
summary: Romanian tennis star Simona Halep has undergone nose surgery and will need a few weeks of rest before returning to physical activity. The former world No. 1, 30, struggled with breathing issues during the summer, prompting her to undergo the surgery. Halep's absence from the sport comes after she was knocked out of the US Open in the first round. Meanwhile, Iga Swiatek extended her lead at the top of the rankings, while Ons Jabeur moved up to second after beating finalist Caroline Garcia in the US Open semi-finals.

site_title: Costa 'scared to death' of wolves
summary: Diego Costa, a former Chelsea striker, has signed a one-year deal with Wolverhampton Wanderers after losing his previous team's strikers to injuries. In an announcement video, Costa was seen holding chains with three snarling wolves, stating he was "scared to death." Despite the intimidating experience, Costa expressed his enthusiasm for returning to the Premier League, acknowledging he needs two to three weeks to get back into shape. He believes he can bring value to the team and is committed to helping his family. Costa's signing has been met with excitement and anticipation from Wolves fans.

site_title: SMG's top executives seek to privatise company at 37 cents per share
summary: Singapore Medical Group (SMG) top executives are seeking to privatize the company at 37 cents per share in cash or one new share, offering a 18% premium over the past year's volume-weighted average price. The offer, made by an investment vehicle owned by the executives, aims to provide greater flexibility for long-term investments and enhance shareholder value. The move comes as SMG faces operational challenges, including cost increases and a shortage of skilled labor. The offer is conditional on the executives holding 90% of the company and is seen as a way to boost the company's growth prospects.

site_title: Value of Ether, other cryptocurrencies could rise if Ethereum merge goes well, experts say
summary: Ethereum's upcoming "Merge" upgrade, set to take place, is expected to increase the value of Ether and other cryptocurrencies. The transition from proof-of-work to proof-of-stake validation method will reduce energy costs and make the blockchain more sustainable. This change is anticipated to enable more applications to run on Ethereum, attracting developers and potentially driving up the cryptocurrency's value.

site_title: Battling lymphoma: Getting the right treatment and support
summary: Lymphoma, a type of blood cancer affecting the lymphatic system, is more common in those aged 50 and above. Symptoms include fatigue, night sweats, unexplained weight loss, and painless lumps due to swollen lymph nodes. Treatment options include chemotherapy, targeted therapy, and immunotherapy, with advancements leading to positive outcomes. Despite advanced stage disease, lymphoma can still be cured. Patients and caregivers require medical support, dietary guidance, and self-care to maintain mental well-being during treatment.

site_title: Football: Allegri urges Juve to exercise patience when things go awry
summary: Juventus coach Massimiliano Allegri urged his players to exercise patience when matches don't go their way, following a 2-2 home draw with Salernitana. Allegri, who received a red card in the match, emphasized the importance of teamwork and balance, even in difficult situations. Juventus will look to bounce back from their loss to Paris Saint-Germain with a Champions League match against Benfica on Wednesday, who are on a 11-match winning streak. Allegri noted that Juventus must play as a team and be compact to overcome the Portuguese side.

site_title: Post-Covid-19 health challenges set to be more complex: Nobel Prize Dialogue panel
summary: Future health challenges post-Covid-19 will be more complex, requiring solutions beyond new drugs and therapeutics. Social problems, cultural and behavioral issues, economic pressures, and political challenges will need to be addressed. Technology will play a significant role in tackling these challenges, particularly in precision health, data analysis, and care substitution. Experts emphasize the importance of leveraging technology to identify risk groups, develop new screening and diagnosis strategies, and improve healthcare delivery. The panel suggests a multi-faceted approach is necessary to address the evolving health landscape.

site_title: S'pore supports Egypt's COP27 presidency, ready to work together on sustainability: SM Teo
summary: Singaporean Senior Minister Teo Chee Hean reaffirmed the country's support for Egypt's presidency at COP27, a UN climate conference. During a working visit to Cairo, Teo met with Egyptian officials to discuss cooperation on sustainable finance, carbon markets, and food resilience. The two nations also exchanged views on regional security and countering terrorism. Teo expressed appreciation for Egyptian support of Singaporean students at Al Azhar University and agreed on the importance of promoting peaceful coexistence among faith communities.

site_title: Football: Mendy found not guilty of one count of rape as trial continues
summary: Manchester City defender Benjamin Mendy has been found not guilty of one count of rape, with co-accused Louis Saha Matturie also cleared of two counts of rape and one of sexual assault. The verdicts were reached after prosecutors dropped charges related to the alleged rape of a 19-year-old woman, citing a lack of evidence. Mendy still faces seven counts of rape and one of sexual assault against six young women, while Matturie denies six counts of rape and three of sexual assault. The trial continues.

site_title: Changi's T4 handles 1,000 passengers on first day of reopening since the pandemic
summary: Changi Airport Terminal 4 (T4) reopened on September 13, 2022, after a nearly two-year closure due to the pandemic, handling approximately 1,000 passengers on five flights. Cathay Pacific and Korean Air were among the first airlines to operate from T4, with more airlines to follow in the coming weeks. The airport's staff conducted operational readiness trials with airlines and partners, ensuring a smooth restart. The terminal's reopening adds to Changi Airport's capacity, aiming to meet increasing air travel demand, with a total capacity of 16 million passengers per year.

site_title: Asean leaders will have to assess progress of Myanmar peace plans: Vivian Balakrishnan
summary: Asean foreign ministers expressed disappointment over Myanmar's lack of progress in implementing a five-point peace plan agreed upon in April 2021. The plan aims to bring an end to chaos following the military coup, which has killed over 2,000 people. Asean leaders will assess progress in November and make difficult decisions to guide the bloc's next steps. The situation remains dire, with the military primarily responsible for the ongoing crisis. Asean has proposed targeted sanctions, including an arms embargo, to support a negotiated political solution.

site_title: Tennis: Spain skipper Bruguera hopes Alcaraz ready for Davis Cup duty
summary: Spanish tennis captain Sergi Bruguera expressed hope that US Open winner Carlos Alcaraz will be ready to play in the Davis Cup Finals group-stage ties in Valencia, starting Wednesday. Alcaraz, the new world No. 1, was set to join the team on Tuesday, but his availability is uncertain. Bruguera praised Alcaraz's impressive win at the US Open, calling it an "incredible effort mentally and physically." The Spanish team, also featuring Roberto Bautista Agut and Alejandro Davidovich, faces Serbia, South Korea, and Canada in Group B, with the top two teams advancing to the November showdown in Malaga.

site_title: Football: Haaland can be X-factor for Man City in Europe, says Gundogan
summary: Manchester City midfielder Ilkay Gundogan believes striker Erling Haaland can be the X-factor for the team in European competitions. Haaland has made a brilliant start to his career in England, scoring 12 goals in eight games, and Gundogan thinks his skills can translate to success in the Champions League. The duo is set to face former club Borussia Dortmund, and Gundogan is looking forward to the game, saying Haaland's character, determination, and attitude have been impressive. Gundogan's comments come as Manchester City aims to finally win the Champions League title.

site_title: Employers, staff urged to be open to flexible work arrangements, including 4-day work week
summary: Singapore's Minister of State for Manpower Gan Siow Huang urged employers and employees to consider flexible work arrangements, including four-day work weeks. Reports of four-day work-week pilots exist in countries like Ireland, Japan, and Spain, but results are mixed, with concerns over productivity, business costs, and employee well-being. While some sectors have reported productivity improvements, others have seen increased labor costs and employee stress. The Ministry of Manpower encourages employers and workers to explore flexible arrangements that suit their unique needs, with no plans for a public sector trial or formula.

site_title: Golf: Garcia faces fine for pulling out of BMW PGA Championship
summary: Sergio Garcia faces a fine by the DP World Tour for withdrawing from the BMW PGA Championship without a valid reason. Garcia, 42, was spotted attending a football game in Austin, Texas, the day after withdrawing, sparking speculation about the true reason for his exit. Garcia must provide a valid reason within three weeks, or he will be fined. Meanwhile, college golfer David Puig is joining LIV Golf, having previously played in two tournaments as an amateur.

site_title: Allow singles to apply for BTO flats from age 28 instead of 35: WP's Louis Chua
summary: Workers' Party MP Louis Chua has proposed lowering the age limit for singles to apply for Build-To-Order (BTO) flats from 35 to 28. Currently, singles can only apply for two-room flexi flats at age 35. Chua argued that this policy has "serious implications" on singles under 35 who cannot afford private property or rent a flat in the open market. He cited data showing that singles do not compete with young couples and families for the same flat types in non-mature estates.

site_title: Football: Vinicius is a great player, not antagonistic, says Ancelotti
summary: Real Madrid coach Carlo Ancelotti defended forward Vinicius Jr., saying he's a great player who shouldn't be told to tone down his style of play. Vinicius was involved in confrontations during a 4-1 win over Real Mallorca, but Ancelotti dismissed the issue, stating he's not deaf and can hear the criticism. Ancelotti praised Vinicius' talent and the rules of the game protecting all players, not just him. Vinicius is in form, scoring in his last five matches, as Real Madrid head into their Champions League match against RB Leipzig.

site_title: Public transport operating costs up, not matched by revenue growth: Iswaran
summary: Singapore's Transport Minister S. Iswaran stated that public transport operating costs rose 7% annually from 2012 to 2021, outpacing revenue growth. The government will continue to fund public transport infrastructure expansion, with over $60 billion set aside for the next decade. To manage costs, the government aims to keep costs low through efficient procurement and optimizing services. The Public Transport Council is reviewing the fare formula, which will consider changes in commuting patterns and balance affordability with financial sustainability, with the review expected to be completed by mid-2023.

site_title: Divorcing parents of minors to undergo e-learning course and counselling
summary: Singapore's Minister of State for Social and Family Development Sun Xueling announced that parents of minors filing for divorce must take an e-learning course and counselling from this month. The new course aims to help parents understand their marital situation, co-parenting relationship, and children's needs. Currently, only couples contesting the divorce must attend the Mandatory Parenting Programme, but the new amendment requires all parents with minor children to attend the programme before filing for divorce. The programme aims to facilitate co-parenting and educate parents on the divorce's effects on their future and children.

site_title: Floods devastating a third of Pakistan 'just the beginning' of climate crisis: Panellist
summary: Climate change and floods in Pakistan are expected to displace over 1.2 billion people by 2050, according to a climate change consultant. The recent floods, which devastated a third of Pakistan, are linked to climate change despite the country's low emissions. Developed countries are urged to take responsibility for reducing emissions, while individuals can make changes such as transitioning to electric vehicles and reducing meat consumption. Governments can help by implementing policies like labelling and taxing unhealthy food. The climate crisis is seen as just the beginning, with low-cost changes needed to address high-impact changes.

site_title: 15 years' jail for man whose offences caused 3 banks, firm to suffer more than $12m in losses
summary: A Singapore court has sentenced two men to jail for duping three banks and a wholesale trading firm of over $12 million. Ho Yik Fuh, 57, was given 15 years in jail for his role in the scheme, while Yeo Kee Siah, 61, received three years and four months. The pair were convicted of multiple counts of cheating, using a "double financing" method to obtain loans from the banks. The losses were caused by a consignment-like arrangement where Yeo would sell cars to Frankel Motor without paying for them, with Ho then selling the cars to buyers.

site_title: Red Lions parachutist used landing fall technique at NDP and avoided severe injuries: Ng Eng Hen
summary: Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen reported that Red Lions parachutist 3WO Jeffrey Heng executed a landing fall technique during the National Day Parade (NDP) in August, avoiding severe injuries. A review committee found that wind conditions were within acceptable limits, and Heng's actions mitigated the impact of the hard landing. The incident was the third near-miss for the Red Lions, with four injuries recorded in 3,400 jumps, a rate of 0.12%. The review committee will study possible measures to improve safety, including increasing distance between parachutists and examining the impact of eddy currents caused by the floating platform design.

site_title: New law to rein in bad debt collection practices
summary: Singapore has passed the Debt Collection Bill, regulating the debt collection industry to prevent problematic conduct. Debt collectors who use aggressive tactics, such as physical harm threats or public notices with personal info, may face jail and fines. The bill aims to reduce police reports against debt collection businesses and debt collectors, which averaged 367 annually from 2018 to 2022. The regulations, set to take effect next year, will screen debt collection businesses and their key personnel to ensure they are "fit and proper," with penalties for repeat offenders.

site_title: Football: PSG coach Galtier praises brilliant Neymar's work ethic
summary: Paris Saint-Germain coach Christophe Galtier praised Neymar's exceptional work ethic, citing his improved performance after a realisation last season. The 30-year-old forward has scored eight goals and set up six in seven Ligue 1 games, including an assist in PSG's Champions League opener. Neymar's defensive efforts have been crucial to Galtier's high-press system, and his fitness will be crucial for Wednesday's game against Maccabi Haifa, where PSG face a weakened defense due to Presnel Kimpembe's injury.

site_title: DNA collection allowed for less serious crimes: What if a suspect refuses?
summary: Singapore's police will expand DNA collection to eligible crimes, not just serious offenses, following the passage of the Registration of Criminals (Amendment) Bill. The database, currently 60% unmatched, will be bolstered to help solve crimes. DNA can be collected from suspects involved in imprisonable and non-compoundable crimes, such as unlawful stalking and drink driving, but not minor offenses like littering. Refusing to provide DNA is an offense, with fines and jail time possible. The DNA database will be secured with legislative safeguards, audit trails, and a framework for data breaches.

site_title: Boxing: Joshua accepts terms for Dec 3 title fight with Fury
summary: Britain's Anthony Joshua has accepted the terms for a Dec 3 fight with Tyson Fury, the WBC world heavyweight champion. Joshua's management, 258 Management, halted communication due to the death of Queen Elizabeth but resumed after receiving confirmation from Fury's promoter Frank Warren that a contract would be sent soon. The "Battle of Britain" title fight is Fury's second challenge to Joshua, following a challenge made in April. Joshua, 32, is looking to rebound from a second straight loss to Oleksandr Usyk in a title rematch in August.

site_title: MOE working with Sped schools to raise teachers' salaries, improve career progression: Chan Chun Sing
summary: MOE is partnering with social service agencies to set up five new special education (Sped) schools by 2030, as part of the Enabling Masterplan 2030. The ministry is also working with Sped schools to adopt human resource practices and improve teacher salaries and career progression. Education Minister Chan Chun Sing acknowledged the sector's reliance on foreign manpower and plans to increase the number of local Sped school teachers and caregivers. The biggest gap in Sped education is in supporting students after they leave the education system, with parents often worried about their children's future care.

site_title: SAF scheme allows drug users to confess once without being punished: Ng Eng Hen
summary: Singapore's SAF Amnesty Scheme allows servicemen who consume illegal drugs to confess once without punishment, receiving counselling and rehabilitation instead. Those who test positive will face regular testing, counselling, and potential court-martial if they test positive again. The scheme, introduced in 1976, aims to prevent and enforce a drug-free culture within the SAF. Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen emphasized the need for deterrence and rehabilitation to help servicemen overcome their addiction.

site_title: $72.3 billion spent on fight against Covid-19 over FY2020 and FY2021: Indranee
summary: Singapore spent $72.3 billion on the fight against Covid-19 over FY2020 and FY2021, with $13.4 billion for public health measures, $50.6 billion for job support, and $8.3 billion for direct household and social support. The amount was lower than the initial $100 billion commitment due to loan capital being repurposed and under-utilization of public health spending. The Government is reviewing its financial practices during emergencies, including using data analytics to detect potential irregularities and ensuring proper documentation of key decisions.

site_title: Boy, 12, hit by car in Choa Chu Kang stable and responsive, says mother
summary: A 12-year-old boy, Nabil Elrizky Putra, was hit by a car in Choa Chu Kang, Singapore, and is in stable condition. He underwent surgery on his knee but remains conscious and responsive. Nabil suffered a head injury but has no internal injuries. Police investigations are ongoing. His mother, Madam Nora, is monitoring his condition and has alerted his school about the accident, with plans to have him sit the Primary School Leaving Examinations if he recovers. The family is seeking witnesses to the incident.

site_title: More ships call at Singapore port in August to refuel due to steep drop in oil prices
summary: Singapore's marine fuel sales rose 1.1% in August to 4.12 million tonnes, driven by lower oil prices. The port saw 3,212 ships refuel, the highest since November, due to cheaper prices, which fell to around US$742 a tonne. Sales of low-sulphur fuel increased, while higher-sulphur fuel sales dipped slightly. Industry experts predict a potentially healthier fourth-quarter fuel oil market in Singapore, driven by increased imports from Russia to Asia and the Middle East.

site_title: Football: Tottenham players have to accept rotation, says manager Conte
summary: Tottenham Hotspur manager Antonio Conte emphasized the need for squad rotation this season, affecting even top scorers like Son Heung-min. Despite scoring 23 league goals last season, Son has yet to find the net in the current campaign due to competition from Harry Kane, Richarlison, and Dejan Kulusevski. Conte believes rotation is necessary to build ambition and balance, and all players, especially those up front, must accept the change. This approach may impact the team's win-loss record, with Conte acknowledging the difficulty in rescheduling matches due to the World Cup and Queen Elizabeth's passing.

site_title: ERP rates at five locations to increase by $1 from Sept 19
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) announced that Electronic Road Pricing (ERP) rates at five locations in Singapore will increase by $1, starting from September 19. The rate hikes aim to manage congestion on expressways. The increases will apply during specific time periods: $1 from 8:30am to 9am at AYE before Alexandra, $3 from 5:30pm to 6pm at AYE after Jurong Town Hall, $4 from 8:30am to 9am at CTE southbound after Braddell Road, and $1 from 7:30pm to 8pm at CTE northbound after PIE. The rates were last adjusted in August.

site_title: No plans to include Covid-19 jabs in national childhood immunisation schedule for now: Ong Ye Kung
summary: Health Minister Ong Ye Kung stated that there are no plans to include COVID-19 jabs in Singapore's national childhood immunization schedule for now. This decision comes after a rare and severe inflammatory syndrome was reported in 5.7 out of 100,000 fully vaccinated young people under 18. Ong emphasized that the pandemic situation is dynamic and recommendations will be reviewed as new data emerges. The Ministry of Health (MOH) is evaluating the Novavax vaccine for those under 18, and bivalent vaccines targeting both the ancestral and Omicron variants will be introduced.

site_title: Girls and women facing online attacks and harassment can get help at new centre
summary: A new non-profit organisation, SG Her Empowerment (SHE), has launched a support centre for girls and women facing online harassment and attacks. The centre, SheCares@SCWO, will offer a helpline, counselling, and legal services by the end of the year. With $1 million raised for operations, the centre will also simplify the reporting process for online content and work with social media platforms to identify new trends in online harm. SHE aims to provide greater support for women and girls, including research into issues such as objectification, stereotyping, and self-perception.

site_title: SG Extra Podcast: Robust debate in Parliament over new scheme to woo top foreign talent
summary: The Singapore government has introduced a new scheme to attract top foreign talent, the Overseas Networks and Expertise (One) Pass. The Ministry of Manpower will vet applications to prevent abuse and fraudulent applications. Manpower Minister Dr Tan See Leng made the announcement in Parliament, sparking a robust debate over the new work visa. The move aims to boost the country's workforce and combat labor shortages.

site_title: The majestic Singapore orchid named in honour of Queen Elizabeth
summary: Singapore has loaned a Dendrobium Elizabeth orchid, named after Queen Elizabeth II, to the British high commissioner's residence. The orchid, with twisted yellow petals and a green lip, was bred from Singaporean and Papua New Guinean orchids and is known for its majestic and resilient nature. The orchid was named in honor of Queen Elizabeth's 1972 visit to Singapore, where the color yellow-green was popular, and is a nod to the city-state's diplomatic charm offensive. The orchid is part of Singapore's over 200 orchid hybrids named after visiting leaders and celebrities.

site_title: Football: Lions have 'room to grow', says Nishigaya ahead of friendlies with Vietnam, India
summary: Singapore national football team head coach Takayuki Nishigaya believes his team has "room to grow" ahead of two international friendlies against Vietnam and India. The games, set to take place in Ho Chi Minh City, will be crucial for the team's preparations for the Asean Football Federation Championship. Nishigaya wants to see high-pressing and aggressive play from his players, but also emphasizes the need to control the game. The team's squad includes new faces such as goalkeeper Mukundan Maran and defender Joshua Pereira, while notable omissions include Shawal Anuar and Safuwan Baharudin due to personal reasons and injury.

site_title: Table tennis: Singapore Smash returns with top players from March 7-19
summary: The World Table Tennis (WTT) Grand Smash is set to return with its second edition, the Singapore Smash, from March 7-19, 2023. The competition will feature over 200 players, with increased prize money, expanded mixed doubles draw, and improved spectator experience. The event aims to reach 50,000 attendees, up from 11,000 in 2022, and has already gained significant popularity, with the first edition reaching 160 million unique viewers. Top players, including Fan Zhendong and Chen Meng, are expected to return, with more destinations planned for 2023 and 2024.

site_title: Tennis: Zverev's comeback delayed by new injury, could be out for months
summary: German tennis player Alexander Zverev's return to the court may be delayed by months due to a bone edema issue. He had not played since June after undergoing surgery to fix damaged ankle ligaments. Zverev withdrew from the Davis Cup Finals group stage and expressed disappointment, stating the issue causes significant pain. A bone edema diagnosis indicates a longer recovery period, potentially lasting weeks or months. Zverev reached a career-high ranking of world No. 2 in June.

site_title: A more divisive world could impact collaborations in science: Vivian Balakrishnan
summary: Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan warns that a more divisive world could hinder global scientific collaboration, posing challenges to tackling climate change and managing science and technology. Geostrategic rivalries, such as the war in Ukraine, and a shift in global supply chains to "just in case" scenarios will lead to increased costs and inflation. Balakrishnan emphasizes the need for global collaboration to achieve the Paris Agreement's goal of limiting global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels, as individual sacrifices are crucial to collective success.

site_title: Singdollar emerges as Asia's best performer: Will it continue to stay strong amid USD rise?
summary: The Singdollar has emerged as Asia's best performer, holding relatively well against the rising US dollar. Despite the greenback's gains this year, the Singdollar has outperformed regional peers, including China and Japan, due to Singapore's recovering economy and a hawkish central bank that has tightened monetary policy four times since October 2021. This trend suggests the Singdollar may continue to stay strong, providing a refuge for foreign exchange traders amid the US dollar's rise.

site_title: Greenback's unrelenting strength, renminbi weakness may test Singdollar's resilience
summary: The Singapore dollar has outperformed most peers this year, but its resilience is tied to the US and Chinese currencies. A rising US dollar would tighten global financial conditions, stifling Asian exports, while a weaker renminbi, reflecting China's slowing economy, would exacerbate regional trade woes, potentially threatening Singapore's trade-driven economy.

site_title: Morgan Stanley, UBS analysts cut oil outlooks on recession fears
summary: Oil analysts at Morgan Stanley and UBS have cut their price forecasts for the rest of 2022 due to recession fears and Russian oil exports continuing to flow to Asia. Morgan Stanley reduced its Brent crude price outlook by $12 a barrel to $98 for the third quarter and $5 to $95 for the fourth quarter. UBS slashed its year-end forecast by $15 a barrel to $110, citing China lockdowns and elevated Russian exports. Analysts expect Brent crude to recover to $125 a barrel by the end of 2023 as the market tightens.

site_title: Tennis: US Open finalist Ruud to begin 2023 campaign in Auckland
summary: Norwegian tennis player Casper Ruud, who rose to a career-high second in the world, announced he will start his 2023 season at the Auckland Classic in January. Ruud, a US Open finalist, will headline the men's tournament and prepare for the Australian Open, where he lost to Carlos Alcaraz in the final. Ruud's participation is considered a "coup" for the tournament, marking his first appearance in Auckland since 2020.

site_title: Football: Real Madrid closed financial year with €13 million profit
summary: Real Madrid closed its 2021-22 financial year with a €13 million profit, marking the third consecutive year the club remained in profit despite the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic. The club's operating income reached €722 million, a 10% increase from the previous year, with a cash balance of €425 million and net debt of €263 million. This financial success comes after Real Madrid won a record-extending 14th European Cup and domestic titles in the 2021-22 season.

site_title: UBS to raise dividend, exceed buyback after deal collapsed
summary: UBS Group will propose a 10% increase in its annual dividend to 55 US cents per share at its annual meeting, exceeding its target of 50 cents. The move comes after the cancellation of its US$1.4 billion acquisition of Wealthfront, a US robo-adviser. UBS expects to exceed its share buyback target of US$5 billion for 2022, having already purchased US$4.1 billion worth of shares. The decision reflects the bank's focus on returning excess capital to investors and expanding its wealth-management offerings beyond traditional customers.

site_title: Businesses in Singapore seeing rising costs but are still profitable: Low Yen Ling
summary: Businesses in Singapore are experiencing rising costs, including utilities, fuel, and labor costs, but remain profitable. Gross profits increased by 9.8% year-on-year in the second quarter, driven by higher costs in the manufacturing and services sectors. The Government will continue to monitor costs and provide support when needed. External factors, such as global energy prices and supply chain disruptions, have contributed to the cost increases, while the tight labor market also exerts upward pressure on labor costs. Relief schemes, including the Progressive Wage Credit Scheme, have been introduced to help businesses cope with rising costs.

site_title: Ex-Aetos officer who robbed Jurong shop while armed with loaded gun gets 16½ years' jail, caning
summary: A 39-year-old former Aetos auxiliary police officer, Mahadi Muhamad Mukhtar, was sentenced to 16½ years' jail and 18 strokes of the cane for robbing a licensed moneylending company in Jurong, Singapore, while armed with a loaded gun. Mahadi, who was struggling with debt, copied a Canadian robbery tactic and handed a note to a loan officer, demanding cash. He was fired from his job after the robbery and was arrested just five hours later. The court heard that Mahadi had researched robbery and was motivated by financial woes.

site_title: S'pore business sentiment moderates further for Q4
summary: Singapore's business sentiment continued to decline for the third consecutive quarter, with the Business Optimism Index falling to 4.98 percentage points in Q4 2022. Despite three indicators showing quarter-on-quarter improvements, the outlook for services and wholesale sectors deteriorated. The SCCB attributed the decline to weakening external demand, escalating geopolitical tensions, and slower global growth. Sentiments in transportation and construction sectors remained relatively upbeat, while the wholesale sector saw all indicators in negative territory.

site_title: Global energy crisis could lead to faster shift away from fossil fuels, says DBS chief Piyush Gupta
summary: DBS Bank's CEO Piyush Gupta says the global energy crisis could accelerate the shift away from fossil fuels, but in the short term, major economies are rushing to secure coal and gas supplies to mitigate disruptions. Gupta notes that nations want to boost energy resilience and avoid being reliant on a single source. The bank has set decarbonization targets and halted finance for coal projects, but faces challenges in managing general financing to coal companies. Over the 5-10 year period, Gupta believes the crisis will ultimately speed up the green transition, but short-term backsliding is likely due to efforts to secure fossil fuel supplies.

site_title: There’s a new cop on the US banking beat - chief climate risk officer
summary: The US Office of the Comptroller of the Currency has hired Dr Yue Chen as its first chief climate risk officer, focusing on assessing and managing climate-driven risks to banks. Climate change poses a threat to the financial system by making it harder for banks to lend and price loans. The new role expands on the OCC's existing climate risk officer position, which was introduced last year. Dr. Chen, a climate expert with a background in finance, will oversee the regulator's climate risk office and report directly to the OCC's leader, Michael Hsu.

site_title: S'pore-listed Frasers Hospitality Trust tumbles 24% after privatisation deal fails
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust's shares plummeted 24% after a proposed $1.35 billion privatisation deal fell through, despite 74.88% of shareholder votes in favour. The trust, listed on the Singapore Exchange, owns 14 assets globally, including hotels and serviced residences. The deal's failure leaves the trust's stake at 70 cents per share, above book value. The outcome narrowly missed the required 75% vote for the resolution to pass.

site_title: Man jailed for breaching Covid-19 isolation order to have supper with friend
summary: A 22-year-old Singaporean man, Verner Chua Jun Jie, was jailed for one month and one week for breaching Covid-19 isolation orders. Chua, who had a history of theft and drug abuse, visited a doctor with a cough and was diagnosed with an acute upper respiratory infection. Despite being issued a medical leave and isolation order, he met a friend and went for supper at various locations, putting others at risk of disease. Chua had also previously flouted Covid-19 rules and failed to report to a supervising officer.

site_title: Evergrande's Hong Kong headquarters taken over by a receiver
summary: China Evergrande Group's Hong Kong headquarters building, valued over $1 billion, has been taken over by receiver Alvarez & Marsal Asia. The 26-storey office building was used as security for $1.4 billion in loans from lenders, including China Citic Bank International. The move comes as the developer struggles with a credit crisis affecting China's real estate sector. Evergrande has failed to deliver a restructuring plan and will try to announce a proposal by the end of the year. The building was previously seized by a lender, following previous failed attempts by the developer to sell it.

site_title: Understanding global energy markets: What are futures contracts and spot market trades?
summary: Global energy markets are experiencing rising prices due to sanctions on Russia's oil and gas exports following its invasion of Ukraine. The Brent benchmark, which accounts for over three-quarters of the world's traded oil, is widely used for its accuracy in reflecting global supply and demand balances. Futures contracts, a legally binding agreement to buy or sell an asset at a predetermined price, are traded on exchanges such as the New York Mercantile Exchange and Intercontinental Exchange. The spot market, which trades assets for immediate delivery, is often linked to futures contracts for pricing. Opec, a cartel of 13 oil-rich countries, aims to maintain stability in oil markets by coordinating production and managing production quotas. A price cap on Russian oil is being discussed by the G-7 nations to limit Moscow's ability to fund its invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: Micron breaks ground on $21b US chip plant, says more to come soon
summary: Micron Technology broke ground on a $15 billion US chip plant in Boise, Idaho, and plans to build another high-volume manufacturing site in the coming weeks. The Boise factory, set to be operational in 2025, will produce Dram chips for data centers and personal computers, accounting for 40% of global production. This investment, part of the $52 billion Chips and Science Act, will create 2,000 Micron jobs and solidify the US as a major player in semiconductor manufacturing.

site_title: Two Peloton founders leaving company
summary: Peloton founders John Foley and Hisao Kushi are leaving the company, with Foley departing immediately and Kushi departing on October 3. Foley, former CEO and chair, will be replaced by Karen Boone, while Tammy Albarran will take over as chief legal officer and corporate secretary. The move comes after Peloton reported a US$1.2 billion quarterly loss and six consecutive quarters of losses. CEO Barry McCarthy has been working to turn the company around, targeting "value-minded consumers." Foley expressed pride in Peloton's achievements before starting a new professional chapter.

site_title: DBS sets decarbonisation targets for 7 sectors it finances, including oil and aviation
summary: DBS Bank has set decarbonisation targets for 7 sectors it finances, including oil and aviation, aiming to reduce Scope 1, 2, and 3 emissions by 2030. The targets cover sectors such as power, oil and gas, automotive, aviation, shipping, steel, and real estate, with specific reductions in absolute emissions and emissions intensity. The bank's net-zero pledge, made in October 2021, will be guided by these targets, with progress reported annually through its sustainability report.

site_title: Shipowners rush for tankers to move Russian oil this winter
summary: Oil tanker owners are rapidly acquiring ice-class tankers to facilitate Russian oil exports this winter, amid EU sanctions that will restrict European imports of seaborne cargoes. Approximately $1 billion was spent on second-hand ice-class tankers in May to August, a five-fold increase from the previous year. European Union sanctions will force Russian crude and fuel exports to be shipped to destinations further from the Baltic Sea, stretching the ice-class fleet and potentially leading to a shortage of tankers. This shortage may lead to higher rates for hauling refined fuels and a new trade involving ship-to-ship transfers.

site_title: SGX makes push for full disclosure of CEO pay
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is planning to introduce changes to its corporate disclosure rules, including requiring companies to disclose the exact pay of their CEOs and independent directors. The SGX RegCo aims to increase transparency on executive pay, following a global push, and proposes a nine-year cap on the tenure of independent directors. Currently, only 5% of companies provide detailed remuneration information, with companies citing competition as the reason. The SGX RegCo CEO expressed disappointment with the lack of transparency, emphasizing the need for companies to address environmental, social, and governance issues.

site_title: Condo resale volume falls for 4th straight month in August, prices continue to rise
summary: Condominium resale prices in Singapore rose 1.2% for the 25th consecutive month in August, with prices up 10.5% compared to the same period last year. However, resale volume declined for the fourth consecutive month, down 14.5% from the previous month. Analysts attribute the strong prices to sellers anticipating higher prices for new condo launches and factoring them into their asking prices.

site_title: House delves into longstanding issue of wooing talent
summary: The Singaporean government has long been debating the issue of importing talent to supplement the workforce. The concept gained public attention in 1988 when Minister S. Jayakumar announced plans to bring in "foreign talents" to support the local workforce. Since then, the definition, scope, and number of foreign talents have evolved, with various schemes introduced to attract professionals.

site_title: Attracting foreign talent with S'pore's new One Pass is not a zero-sum game
summary: Singapore's new One Pass aims to attract foreign talent without harming local employment. Manpower Minister Tan See Leng emphasized that the country cannot play a defensive game in securing talent. The concept of importing talent dates back to 1988, with the Eminent Entrepreneurs/Professionals Scheme, which granted permanent resident status to 81 Hong Kong professionals. The new One Pass is intended to strike a balance between attracting foreign talent and supporting local employment, rather than a zero-sum game.

site_title: US stocks close higher ahead of key inflation data
summary: US stocks closed higher on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 0.7% to 32,381.34, marking the fourth consecutive gain. The S&P 500 rose 1.1% and the Nasdaq Composite Index increased 1.3%. Investors await critical inflation data and retail sales reports, which may influence the Federal Reserve's interest rate move next week. Despite easing gasoline prices, inflation is expected to remain a concern, potentially leading to a third consecutive three-quarter point rate hike.

site_title: Half of Singapore employers plan to hire in Q4: Survey
summary: Half of Singapore employers plan to increase headcount in the fourth quarter, despite economic headwinds, with high demand for IT, finance, customer service, and relationship manager roles. The survey by ManpowerGroup found that hiring sentiments have improved by 38 percentage points compared to last year, with sectors like banking and finance showing sustained strong hiring environments. However, the weakest demand is seen in education, health, and government sectors, with three-quarters of global companies struggling to fill roles amid the highest labor shortage in 16 years.

site_title: S'pore SMEs overcome manpower constraints with digitalisation, survey finds
summary: Most Singapore SMEs expect to be profitable this year, despite rising costs and manpower constraints. A survey of over 1,000 SMEs found 90% were small and medium-sized enterprises, with 38% projecting revenue increases and 72% forecasting profits. To overcome manpower constraints, 54% plan to digitalize their businesses, while 68% have applied for government assistance schemes. Digitalization is seen as a key strategy to overcome challenges, with the government providing resources and support through platforms like the Chief Technology Officer-as-a-Service.

site_title: Judges, admin officers to get pay hike
summary: Judges and administrative service officers in Singapore will receive a salary hike, with adjustments ranging from 5% to 12% effective October 1. Approximately 300 administrative service officers and 30 judicial and statutory appointment holders will benefit from the increase, including the Chief Justice and judges of the Court of Appeal and High Court. This change marks the first pay adjustment for these groups in nearly 15 years.

site_title: New WSQ scheme to grow talent pool in hospitality sector
summary: Singapore's Shatec and the Singapore Hotel Association launched the Hotel Apprenticeship Diploma Programme, offering three WSQ diplomas in hotel services, food services, and tourism. The 18-month programme provides customized training, mentorship, and an allowance of $1,300 a month during apprenticeships. The initiative aims to attract and retain local talent in the hospitality industry, offering an alternative pathway for job seekers to upgrade their skills. The first courses, in hotel services and culinary arts, are set to begin in April and January next year, respectively.

site_title: One Pass part of suite of measures to remain competitive
summary: Singapore's Manpower Minister Tan See Leng introduced the Overseas Networks and Expertise (One) Pass to attract top foreign talent, allowing holders to hold multiple jobs and start businesses concurrently. The One Pass is part of a broader framework to ensure the country's workforce stays competitive. Additionally, employers will be exempted from job advertising requirements when hiring the top 10% of Employment Pass holders, mainly senior professionals or management staff. This exemption aims to boost global companies' confidence in operating in Singapore, with the goal of providing fairer employment opportunities for Singaporeans.

site_title: Investment bank Goldman to cut several hundred jobs starting this month
summary: Goldman Sachs Group is set to cut several hundred jobs, its largest round of layoffs since the pandemic began, as the bank faces a challenging operating environment amid a slump in revenue. The move follows Goldman's decision to slow hiring and reinstate annual performance reviews, intended to weed out underperforming staff and reduce expenses. The bank's earnings are expected to drop by over 40% this year, according to analysts. The job cuts are part of Goldman's effort to adapt to a slowdown in investment banking and trading, with the company's shares down over 10% this year.

site_title: Parliament pays tribute to Britain's Queen Elizabeth II
summary: Singapore's Parliament observed a minute's silence in tribute to Queen Elizabeth II, who died aged 96, with British High Commissioner Kara Owen in attendance. Leader of the House Indranee Rajah described the Queen's death as "the end of an era," highlighting her unique role in Singapore's history, particularly during the country's transition from a British crown colony to an independent state in the 1960s.

site_title: Use of AR to resolve worksite woes bags construction firm LTA award
summary: Singapore construction firm Hwa Seng Builder has won the Land Transport Authority (LTA) award for its innovative use of augmented reality technology to train workers on safety, health, and environmental issues at worksites. The company's mobile app simulates real-world problems, reducing training hours by 70% and increasing construction productivity. Hwa Seng received the LTA Contractors Challenge Shield and six other awards for its work on the Tampines Expressway-Pan-Island Expressway-Changi Viaduct project, which aims to promote sustainable development and reduce carbon emissions in the construction industry.

site_title: S'pore crypto firms take safety steps ahead of Ethereum upgrade
summary: Singaporean cryptocurrency firms have taken safety measures ahead of an upcoming Ethereum software upgrade. The upgrade aims to increase the blockchain's usability and appeal to investors. To protect investors, firms have temporarily halted crypto transactions, including deposits, withdrawals, and payments, to mitigate potential risks and price volatility resulting from the upgrade.

site_title: 5-12% pay hike for admin officers, judicial and statutory appointment holders
summary: The Public Service Division has announced a salary hike of 5-12% for administrative service officers and judicial/statal appointment holders, effective October 1. Approximately 330 officers will benefit, including the Chief Justice and key judicial figures. The adjustment is aimed at attracting and retaining talent, as well as keeping pace with market benchmarks. The move follows a record 538 lawyers leaving the profession last year and a 10-year peak in public service management executive scheme turnover. The salary increase is seen as long overdue to mitigate inflationary pressures and counter private sector competition.

site_title: HSBC may have to raise staff pay in 2023 due to rising inflation
summary: HSBC may need to raise staff pay in 2023 due to rising inflation, with the bank potentially short US$500 million (S$697.8 million) of its cost target. CFO Ewen Stevenson stated that half of the bank's cost base is fixed pay, which he believes will need to be significantly increased. Despite aiming for a 2% cost growth limit, underlying costs are expected to rise 6-7%. The bank's CEO, Noel Quinn, has a bias for cost control over revenue growth, and Stevenson's confidence in Quinn's commitment to the 2% target is crucial for implementing necessary staff pay increases.

site_title: IT outages at public healthcare institutions due to hardware device failure: Janil
summary: Two recent IT system outages at public healthcare institutions in Singapore were caused by hardware device failures in data centers, specifically nodes that failed due to firmware bugs. The failures occurred in August and September, affecting 17 and 8 institutions, respectively, and causing disruptions to services such as electronic medical records and laboratory systems. Investigations have found no security compromise, and measures are being taken to increase resilience and detect potential vulnerabilities. The Government is working with agencies to share information and improve the public healthcare IT infrastructure.

site_title: Applicants to be vetted, engaged to prevent abuse of One Pass
summary: Singapore's Overseas Networks and Expertise (One) Pass, aimed at attracting top international talent, will have two levels of safeguards to prevent abuse. Applicants will undergo thorough vetting of salary declarations and be engaged during their stay to monitor their income and professional activities. Those who meet the criteria, including fixed monthly salaries of $30,000 or more, or outstanding achievements in various fields, will be granted the pass. The move aims to give top talent time to make a big impact and contribute to the country's economic growth, with benefits extending to local small and medium-sized enterprises.

site_title: STB to take over regulation of cruise terminal operators
summary: The Singapore Tourism Board (STB) will take over the regulation of cruise terminal operators, starting from an undetermined date, to ensure high service standards and prevent excessive pricing. This change comes as the demand for cruise holidays rebounds worldwide and Singapore's cruise capacity is set to more than double in the next five years. The STB will have increased powers to manage cruise terminals, conduct surveys, and obtain financial data, allowing for effective economic regulation and business continuity. The move aims to solidify Singapore's position as the region's leading cruise hub.

site_title: Overbooking allows airlines to offer cheaper fares: Iata
summary: Overbooking by airlines and cruises allows them to offer cheaper fares and maximize capacity, according to the International Air Transport Association (Iata). When flights or cruises are overbooked, passengers are often informed at the last minute, leading to disruptions and potential compensation disputes. Currently, there is no law regulating overbooking in Singapore, and affected consumers rely on conditions of carriage or insurance coverage. In contrast, the European Union has established rules providing compensation for passengers denied a seat on overbooked flights, with varying amounts depending on distance and flight type.

site_title: Parliament observes minute of silence in tribute to Britain's late Queen
summary: MPs held a minute of silence in the House of Parliament to pay tribute to Queen Elizabeth II, who died aged 96. Leader of the House Indranee Rajah praised the Queen's "reciprocal relationship of warmth and affection" with Singapore, citing her symbolic rule over the country until the 1960s and her notable state visits. The Queen was remembered for her duty, stability, and graciousness, as well as her personal touch and warmth towards Singaporeans. Condolences were extended to King Charles III and the people of Britain.

site_title: Teachers need more support to handle student discipline, workload: MPs
summary: Singapore's teachers face significant challenges, with over 1,000 grievances annually, including student misbehavior, parent abuse, and workload issues. MPs call for increased support for managing student discipline, work-life balance, and reducing teachers' workload. The government has introduced retention measures, including a pay bump and new pay grade for senior teachers, but MPs say more needs to be done. Suggestions include sabbaticals, group-level exam setting, and improved work conditions for all educators, including those in polytechnics and Institutes of Technical Education.

site_title: GST hike to go ahead as planned with support measures in place
summary: Singapore's goods and services tax (GST) will increase by 2 percentage points to 9% in two stages, starting from January 1, 2024, despite a 22.4% increase in tax revenue in the 2021 financial year. Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong said the government is committed to offsetting the GST increase, with most households not feeling the impact for at least five years. Lower-income households will not feel the impact for 10 years, and the government will enhance its aid package if necessary.

site_title: 'Buy' call on Keppel as infrastructure assets set to drive future growth
summary: Keppel Corporation has announced a series of initiatives and acquisitions to drive future growth. Analysts at UOB Kay Hian have maintained a "buy" call on the company, upgrading its target price to $10.11. This is due to Keppel's significant investment in infrastructure assets, totaling over $3.2 billion, as part of its restructuring and preparation for growth post the planned divestment of its offshore and marine unit.

site_title: S'pore, Vietnam pledge to deepen ties in digital, green economy areas
summary: Singaporean Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat and Vietnamese Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh reaffirmed their countries' commitment to deepen cooperation in digital and green economies, as well as innovation. They discussed regional and international issues, including upholding Asean centrality and rules-based multilateralism. The leaders agreed to step up economic cooperation in areas like renewable energy, digitalization, and infrastructure, and to strengthen party-to-party ties. Heng's visit aims to further strengthen bilateral relations, which will mark its 10th anniversary next year, with a focus on growing the partnership in the coming 50 years.

site_title: Must-reads
summary: Singapore to implement stringent checks for the Overseas Networks and Expertise (One) Pass to prevent abuse. The pass will be vetted for false salary declarations, and holders will be monitored for income and professional activities. Meanwhile, Russia's oil exports continue to defy Western sanctions as Asia remains a key market. Crypto firms prepare for an upcoming software upgrade on Ethereum, taking precautions to protect investors. Britain marks a historic moment of transformation with the new king and prime minister, while Singapore Airlines offers a road trip to the Canadian Rockies.

site_title: New law allows collection of DNA samples for wider range of crimes
summary: A new law in Singapore allows police to collect DNA samples from individuals involved in a wider range of crimes, including mischief and drink driving, to aid in identifying repeat offenders. The law, which was passed after statistics showed that about one in three individuals convicted of a serious crime had also been convicted of a less serious one, will provide authorities with a larger DNA database to compare samples from crime scenes. The move aims to improve public safety and follows international practices, where some countries collect DNA information for a broader scope of offenses.

site_title: 'Badge Lady' withdraws request to travel to Hong Kong, China
summary: The "Badge Lady", Phoon Chiu Yoke, withdrew her request to travel to Hong Kong and China after the prosecution objected to her application in court. The prosecution cited a risk of Phoon not returning to Singapore, gaps in her itinerary, and concerns about her employment and property status. Phoon, who was previously jailed for 16 weeks for failing to wear a mask, claimed she had made all necessary checks and was not a flight risk. She will file another application when her itinerary is in order and intends to plead guilty to the new charges.

site_title: Enforcement on cluttered corridors to be stepped up
summary: Singapore's government will step up enforcement on cluttered corridors as part of efforts to tackle hoarding issues. Senior Minister of State Sim Ann announced the move in response to recent fires in Housing Board flats. A multi-agency group has reduced the severity of 210 hoarding cases since 2014, with 260 active cases currently being monitored. Enforcement will focus on public health and safety risks, with the assistance of social workers and mental health professionals when necessary. The government will also assess the risk posed by worst hoarding cases and intervene firmly if necessary.

site_title: An insight into the merge, or Ethereum's major upgrade
summary: Ethereum, the world's second-largest crypto token, is set to undergo a major software upgrade, known as the "merge", which promises to slash energy consumption by 99.9%. The upgrade, scheduled for Sept 10-20, will transition from "proof-of-work" to "proof-of-stake", a new system that reduces energy consumption and facilitates cheaper transactions. The change is expected to make Ethereum more favorable compared to Bitcoin, potentially boosting its price and adoption. However, experts warn of potential risks, including hacking and technical glitches.

site_title: Respect from parents also key to teachers' well-being: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Education Minister Chan Chun Sing emphasized the importance of parents' respect for teachers' personal time and boundaries. By doing so, parents can help set realistic expectations for teachers' responsibilities and alleviate their workloads. The Ministry of Education has implemented measures to reduce teachers' workloads, including streamlined administrative processes and flexible work arrangements. However, some parents fail to abide by these guidelines, leading to excessive communication and work-related issues. Chan urged parents to work with schools to follow the Ministry's code of conduct and respect teachers' boundaries to create a healthy and supportive environment for both teachers and students.

site_title: Logistics, student housing assets a boon for Mapletree amid turmoil
summary: Mapletree Investments, a Temasek-linked property developer and manager, reported a 6.2% jump in net profit to $1.96 billion for the financial year ended March 31. The increase was driven by a record year of recurring earnings and higher revenue. The group's total assets under management (AUM) rose 18.7% to $78.7 billion, with 74% of assets managed through its Singapore-listed Reits and seven private funds. This diversification into resilient asset classes such as logistics and student accommodation has benefited the company amid rising inflation and interest rates.

site_title: Fire extinguishers to be placed at lift lobbies of 1 in 2 HDB blocks
summary: The Singapore Civil Defence Force (SCDF) and Housing Board (HDB) will place fire extinguishers at the lift lobbies of one in two HDB blocks, starting a trial program. The initiative aims to improve fire safety for residents. The move follows two recent fires in flats that involved hoarding, resulting in one fatality. The SCDF also educates residents on fire extinguisher use through various programs, and the HDB installs fire alarms in 75% of public rental flats, with plans to expand the scheme in the future.

site_title: Euro-Asia Park condo up for collective sale at $500m
summary: The freehold condominium Euro-Asia Park in Woodleigh Close is up for collective sale via public tender with a guide price of $500 million. The 163-unit, 129,793 sq ft development has a maximum allowable gross floor area of 338,860 sq ft, allowing for up to 397 new units upon redevelopment. The site is zoned for residential use and benefits from excellent transport connectivity and easy access to amenities. The sale is expected to attract developers looking to replenish their land stock in the limited central region, with a pre-application feasibility study underway.

site_title: More S'porean workers need stints abroad to prepare for leadership roles, says minister
summary: Singaporean workers need overseas experience to prepare for leadership roles, according to Minister Tan See Leng. He cited examples of Singaporeans who gained experience abroad, such as Tan Wern-Yuen, who rose to CEO positions at McDonald's, Walmart China, and PepsiCo Apac. The government aims to attract global talent and support local workers through policies like the Complementarity Assessment Framework and Industry Transformation Maps. Skills transfer programs are also encouraged to build a pipeline of local talent, with the goal of creating opportunities for Singaporeans to take on regional or global leadership posts.

site_title: Russia now China's top crude oil supplier
summary: Russia's oil exports continue to thrive despite Western sanctions, with China emerging as the country's top crude oil supplier. The demand from Asia, particularly China and India, is limiting the impact of sanctions, as these countries are willing to purchase discounted Russian oil. Industry sources indicate that Russia is working to maintain shipments despite efforts by Western countries to cap the price of Russian crude to reduce Moscow's revenue.

site_title: Company Briefs: Epicentre Holdings Frasers Hospitality Trust AstraZeneca
summary: Epicentre Holdings has received approval from the Singapore Exchange to delist from the Catalist board due to insufficient assets to meet liabilities. Frasers Hospitality Trust's proposed $1.35 billion take-private deal fell through after failing to secure enough shareholder votes. AstraZeneca aims to double its portfolio of new cancer drugs by the end of the decade, following a successful pipeline revamp under CEO Pascal Soriot.

site_title: Aussie dollar hit by global slowdown, as central bank unable to halt its slide
summary: The Australian dollar has fallen to a multi-year low, losing about 3% since May, due to a global slowdown and a stronger US greenback. Despite the Reserve Bank of Australia's interest rate hikes, the currency remains sensitive to global sentiment and appears powerless to stop its decline. The Australian dollar is expected to test support levels, potentially falling to 62 US cents by early next year. Job data and China's growth prospects may further impact the currency's value.

site_title: Jail for 2 ex-directors in gold investment Ponzi scheme
summary: Two former directors of The Gold Label (TGL) in Singapore, Iseli Rudolf James Maitland and How Soo Feng, were sentenced to 3 years and 10 months in jail for their roles in a $1.2 million Ponzi scheme. The pair, who pocketed the funds between 2009 and 2010, were convicted of carrying on a fraudulent business. The scheme relied on new gold sales to pay earlier customers, with customers promised guaranteed returns of up to 24% per annum. A third former director, Wong Kwan Sing, was previously sentenced to 2 years and 10 months in jail for his role in the scheme.

site_title: Signs of bottom emerge in second-hand market for luxury watches
summary: The second-hand luxury watch market is showing signs of stabilization, with prices slowing their decline. The WatchCharts Rolex index fell 1.84% in early September, a decrease from the summer slump of 3.5-5.9% in June and July. Meanwhile, the Subdial50 index, tracking 50 luxury watch references, rose 1.2% in the 30 days prior to September 7. This suggests a potential bottoming out of prices, with consumer demand remaining resilient despite the market's recent fluctuations.

site_title: UOB Kay Hian maintains 'buy' call on Keppel, citing its restructuring
summary: UOB Kay Hian maintains a "buy" call on Keppel Corporation with an upgraded target price of $10.11, citing the conglomerate's restructuring efforts. Keppel spent over $3.2 billion on global infrastructure assets, positioning itself for growth after the planned divestment of its offshore and marine unit, expected in Q4 2022. This restructuring laid the groundwork for Keppel's next stage of growth, according to analyst Adrian Loh.

site_title: SGX, MAS launch ESG reporting portal for corporates
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) and the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) have launched ESGenome, an online sustainability reporting portal for corporates. The platform, offered free to listed companies, allows investors and financial institutions to access, compare, and benchmark ESG data of companies. It streamlines disclosure and improves data quality, addressing challenges caused by multiple reporting frameworks and inconsistent data collection. The platform aims to support the financing of sustainable companies and projects, with plans to extend its use to non-listed corporations, including small and medium-sized enterprises.

site_title: S'pore stocks close higher as Asia rallies on US, Europe momentum
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.4% to close at 3,274.72, driven by gains in the US and Europe. Trading was muted due to a quiet economic calendar, with Yangzijiang Shipbuilding being the biggest winner, up 3.7%. Jardine Matheson Holdings was the biggest loser, down 1.1%. Key events include the release of US inflation data on Tuesday, which may influence investor sentiment, and China's one-year medium-term lending facility rate.

site_title: Euro climbs to three-week high on Ukraine gains and rates outlook
summary: The euro rose to a three-week high against the US dollar, reaching $1.0063, following reports of Ukraine retaking territory from Russia. This boost in sentiment was driven by hopes that the war may turn in Ukraine's favor, despite the energy crisis and inflation concerns. Bundesbank president Joachim Nagel stated that further interest rate hikes will be needed to curb inflation, while analysts predict the euro will still weaken to $0.95 by year-end. The euro has advanced 2% from its September low, but remains down 11% this year due to the ongoing energy crisis.

site_title: China's consumer stock rout seen as grim signal for economy
summary: China's consumer market is experiencing a downturn due to Covid-19 restrictions and a deteriorating economic backdrop. Consumer discretionary stocks in the MSCI China Index have underperformed the broader gauge, with some retailers and automakers falling over 50% in value. The nation's retail sales have contracted from a year earlier, and consumer confidence remains low. Investors are cautiously optimistic about companies catering to a "consumption downgrade" trend, such as Pinduoduo and Vipshop, which offer cheaper products. Despite China's growing middle class, the market's potential is limited by the government's zero-Covid-19 strategy and policies promoting equality and thriftiness.

site_title: US likely to hit China with broader curbs on chip, tool exports
summary: The US is set to broaden curbs on chip and tool exports to China, with the Commerce Department planning to publish new regulations that require licenses for exporting AI chips and chipmaking equipment to the country. The move aims to thwart China's advances in advanced semiconductors and artificial intelligence. The regulations, which are expected to be published next month, will codify restrictions already in place for several US companies, including Nvidia and AMD. The actions are part of the Biden administration's efforts to protect US national security and foreign policy interests.

site_title: 'His game follows the same path as Rafa'
summary: Carlos Alcaraz, 19, won the US Open, becoming the youngest men's Grand Slam champion since Rafael Nadal in 2005. He defeated Casper Ruud in a 4-set match, earning over $10 million in prize money. Alcaraz is now the youngest world No. 1 and the youngest champion in New York since 1990. His coach, Juan Carlos Ferrero, says Alcaraz has a path similar to Nadal's, known for his intensity and defense. Nadal has urged fans not to put pressure on Alcaraz, focusing on enjoying his career and potential future achievements.

site_title: Three EPL games are off owing to funeral
summary: The Premier League has postponed three matches due to policing pressures ahead of Queen Elizabeth II's funeral. Chelsea's home game against Liverpool, Manchester United's home game against Leeds United, and Brighton's match against Crystal Palace have been called off. The English Football League has resumed matches from Tuesday. Meanwhile, Chelsea manager Thomas Tuchel has been sacked after a poor start to the season, and the club has appointed Graham Potter as their new manager.

site_title: Lowry calls win 'one for the good guys'
summary: Ireland's Shane Lowry wins the BMW PGA Championship, beating Jon Rahm and Rory McIlroy by a stroke. Lowry's victory came after a dramatic final round, where he pipped Rahm's clubhouse target and finished with 17-under 199. The win was seen as a victory for the DP World Tour, with Lowry stating it was "one for the good guys". The tournament featured 18 LIV rebels, but tensions were reportedly lower than expected, with Patrick Reed expressing respect for the DP Tour players.

site_title: Hawk Circle can be third-time lucky
summary: South Africa's racing scene is analyzed with a focus on upcoming races. In Race 1, newcomers Hawk Circle and Coastal Blues are considered potential winners, while well-bred fillies like Red Sash and Helen's Legacy are also contenders. In subsequent races, notable winners include CIAO BELLA, KINGOFTHEWAVES, and Le Morne, with promising horses like GAUDIS MASTERPIECE and PATH OF CHOICE also on the rise.

site_title: Saturday's Singapore Stipendiary Stewards' report highlights
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The Singapore Stipendiary Stewards' report highlights several incidents from recent racing events. In Race 1, Olympia overraced after jumping from a wide barrier, while in Race 2, Supreme One was agitated behind the barrier and weakened in the straight. In Race 5, Whiz Fizz suffered minor interference and failed to run on, and in Race 8, First Chief was given no specific instruction to race forward. Several horses, including Lord Of Cloud and Jupiter Gold, were injured or died after racing. The stewards will monitor the performances of Heng Xing and Lord Of Cloud.

site_title: Richard is treble king for a day
summary: Former jockey turned trainer Richard Lim achieved his best day as a trainer with a treble at the Singapore racing meet, just nine months into his rookie year. Lim's three winners, including maiden victories for Heng Xing and Knight's Gambit, followed a surprise win by First Chief, a horse he had previously trained under a different trainer. The success was a fitting tribute to Lim's past, as he recalled his first career treble 16 years ago, which was celebrated with an award presented by Queen Elizabeth II.

site_title: Monza finish sparks more debate on safety car rules
summary: The FIA's handling of safety car rules at the 2021 Abu Dhabi Grand Prix has reignited debate. In December 2021, FIA race director Michael Masi was criticized for allowing lapped cars to overtake under safety car procedures, potentially altering the outcome of the race. This incident has sparked renewed discussion on safety car rules, with some calling for clearer guidelines to prevent similar controversies. The Monza finish has reignited this debate, as drivers and teams continue to express concerns about the FIA's handling of safety car situations.

site_title: Defensive nous helps Fiji win 7s World Cup
summary: Fiji won the Rugby World Cup Sevens final, defeating New Zealand 29-12. The Fijians, led by coach Ben Gollings, relied on strong defensive performances, including two early tries from Joseva Talacolo and Kaminieli Rasaku. Australia won the women's competition for the first time since 2009, defeating New Zealand 24-22. New Zealand Rugby has been penalized for failing to meet a 40% representation of women on the board, losing NZ$280,000 in funding.

site_title: Things fall into place for Ewing in Cincinnati
summary: US golfer Ally Ewing won the Queen City Championship in Cincinnati, Ohio, with a six-under 66, finishing 22-under 266. Ewing held off China's Lin Xiyu by one stroke, securing her third career LPGA Tour title. The 29-year-old American birdied five consecutive holes on the back nine, overcoming nerves to claim her victory. Lin, the world No. 34, shot a 65 and finished second, with Mexico's Maria Fassi third and South Korea's Lee Jeong-eun fourth.

site_title: Welcome to tennis the Alcaraz  way: Fast, ferocious and fun
summary: Tennis star Carlos Alcaraz dominated the US Open men's final, showcasing his signature playing style of speed and ferocity. The ground staff at Arthur Ashe Stadium found evidence of his intense performance, including burnt shoe rubber and peeled paint on the lines. This suggests Alcaraz's aggressive playing style, which has become a hallmark of his game. His impressive performance solidified his reputation as a formidable force in tennis.

site_title: Back to basics for Klopp and Liverpool
summary: Jurgen Klopp has urged Liverpool to focus on defending and finding consistency ahead of their match against Ajax, following a 4-1 loss to Napoli. The Reds have struggled to start the season, sitting seventh in the Premier League, and Klopp blames the team's lack of consistency, not just the sale of Sadio Mane or lengthy injury list. He emphasizes that winning 50-50 challenges and competing for the ball are key to getting back to basics and improving their performances. Liverpool will face a rebuilding Ajax side, who have won all their league games this season despite a massive rebuilding effort.
