With the help of local tech firm NCS, the CPF Board is currently piloting a feature that can identify callers who are less tech-savvy and prioritises them to reach a call agent faster.

site_title: Diaz goes out in blaze of glory
summary: Nate Diaz ended his UFC career on a high note, defeating Tony Ferguson via submission in the fourth round at UFC 279. Diaz's 21-13 record is a testament to his determination and popularity, which stems from his unapologetic gangster persona. Following his exit, Diaz hinted at a potential boxing match against Jake Paul, while Conor McGregor expressed interest in a trilogy fight. The victory caps off an extraordinary week for the UFC, which was marred by a backstage brawl and weight issues for Khamzat Chimaev.

site_title: Freshmen do S'pore proud with US collegiate triumphs
summary: Singaporean freshmen golfers Shayne Lim and Hiroshi Tai made history by winning collegiate events in the US. Lim, 18, won The Players Club Invitational at Yorktown, Indiana, with a two-under 214 score. Hiroshi Tai, 20, edged out Michael Mjaaseth in a play-off at the Maui Jim Invitational in Arizona, finishing 14-under 202. Both golfers' victories marked a significant achievement for the Singapore Golf Association and showcased their skills in their first college events.

site_title: Amid market uncertainty, best strategy would be to shift to stocks with greater price stability
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates by 75 basis points, citing a need to control inflation. Most economists predict a global economic softening in early 2023. The Dow Jones rose 2.66% for the week, reaching 32,151.71 points. Fed Chair Jerome Powell emphasized the Fed's commitment to reducing inflation, indicating a potential shift towards more conservative monetary policies. This move is seen as a response to market uncertainty and a broader economic slowdown.

site_title: Doohan on shortlist to replace Alonso at Alpine
summary: Australian Jack Doohan, son of motorcycle world champion Mick, is a contender to replace Fernando Alonso at Alpine Formula One team. According to chief executive Laurent Rossi, Doohan is a consideration due to his potential and performance in the Formula Two championship season. However, Alpine may prefer a more experienced driver to immediately score big points. French driver Pierre Gasly is still seen as the team's first choice to replace Alonso, but his move depends on AlphaTauri's ability to sign American IndyCar driver Colton Herta.

site_title: Firms behind fall-detection tech, AI-facilitated education among start-ups entering Vietnam
summary: Singaporean start-ups SoundEye, Acktec Technologies, and Rescale Lab are expanding into Vietnam through the Global Innovation Alliance (GIA) acceleration programme. SoundEye's fall-detection technology, Lasso, is being deployed at hospitals and nursing homes, while Acktec Technologies aims to provide AI-facilitated education through virtual reality. Rescale Lab offers entrepreneurship training and mentorship to aspiring entrepreneurs. The start-ups see Vietnam as a large market with a growing demand for innovative technologies and education solutions, with plans to establish a presence in Vietnam and Japan.

site_title: De Sousa signals return to HK on Lucky Sweynesse
summary: Silvestre de Sousa rode Lucky Sweynesse to a convincing Class 1 HKSAR Chief Executive's Cup Handicap victory at Sha Tin, extending the horse's impressive career trajectory. The New Zealand-bred, who started at a 52 rating, won by 31 1/4 lengths and clocked 1:08.58 seconds for the 1,200m race. Trainer Manfred Man has hinted at a possible tilt at the Longines Hong Kong International Races, citing the horse's impressive form and maturity.

site_title: Potter thanks fans and hopes Brighton do well
summary: New Chelsea manager Graham Potter has penned a farewell letter to Brighton & Hove Albion fans, thanking them for their support and asking for forgiveness for his abrupt departure. Potter, 47, cited a desire to seize a new opportunity at Chelsea, where he'll be under pressure to deliver immediate results after the club's record-breaking £255 million summer spending spree. Despite Brighton's strong start to the season, Potter hopes the club can still thrive without his guidance, leaving fans worried about the club's stability.

site_title: Real rally to big win to maintain perfect start
summary: Real Madrid came from behind to beat Mallorca 4-1 at the Santiago Bernabeu, maintaining their perfect start to the season. The visitors took the lead with Vedat Muqiri's goal, but Federico Valverde equalized at halftime. Vinicius Junior, Rodrygo, and Antonio Rudiger scored in the second half to seal the win. Real Madrid remain two points ahead of Barcelona, while a match between Cadiz and Barcelona was suspended due to a fan's cardiac arrest, with the resuscitation successful and the fan hospitalized.

site_title: McIlroy pays respects to queen, moves to third
summary: Rory McIlroy paid respects to Queen Elizabeth II before resuming play at the BMW PGA Championship. McIlroy, the world No. 3, joined fellow players and caddies in a two-minute silence before the tournament resumed. He expressed his admiration for the queen, who was a steady figure for the country, and stated that continuing play was the right decision. McIlroy shot a 65 to move into contention, one stroke behind leader Viktor Hovland and Soren Kjeldsen. The tournament, shortened to 54 holes, continues with McIlroy in strong position.

site_title: Football gets flak for delaying ties
summary: English football faced criticism for postponing weekend fixtures following Queen Elizabeth II's death, with some fans questioning the decision in contrast to other sports bodies. The Premier League, English Football League, and Scottish football all postponed games as a mark of respect. However, the decision caused fixture chaos and missed an opportunity for fans to pay their respects. Other sports, such as rugby and cricket, opted to resume play as scheduled, with golf's BMW Championship and the British Horseracing Authority also resuming events.

site_title: Sports World: Down 2-0, Hougang still beat in-form Geylang
summary: Hougang United stunned Geylang International 4-2 despite being down 2-0, with Umar Ramle and Faizal Roslan scoring early goals. Geylang International rallied back with four goals but lost the match. In other sports news, West Newton, a horse bred by Queen Elizabeth II, won a Baltimore horse racing event two days after her death. Albert Pujols hit his 696th home run, tying Alex Rodriguez in fourth place on the all-time MLB list. Ally Ewing took a one-shot lead at the LPGA Kroger Queen City Championship after a 67 in the third round.

site_title: 'Dominant' Scheffler gets players' vote
summary: Scottie Scheffler, the world No. 1 American golfer, was named PGA Tour Player of the Year for the 2021-2022 season, receiving 89% of the vote from fellow players. Scheffler won four PGA titles, including his first Major at the Masters, and held the top ranking for 24 weeks. He also earned the most prize money in a single season with $14.1 million and broke the previous record held by Jordan Spieth. Scheffler's dominant and consistent season earned him the endorsement of his peers and PGA Tour Commissioner Jay Monahan.

site_title: Higa's 65 bags him third win of season
summary: Kazuki Higa won the Asian Tour's Shinhan Donghae Open with a flawless final-round six-under 65, taking his season total to 20-under 264. Higa's victory gave him his third win of the season and earned him multi-year exemptions on both the Asian and Korea tours. He edged out Tirawat Kaewsiribandit by two strokes, who struggled for consistency in his final round despite a rare albatross two earlier. Higa's win marked the first time the US$1.4 million tournament was held in Japan.

site_title: Sky's the limit for prolific Swiatek
summary: Iga Swiatek won the US Open women's singles title, defeating Ons Jabeur 6-2, 7-6 (7-5). At 21, Swiatek is now the world No. 1 with 10-1 in WTA Tour-level singles finals, outperforming Serena Williams' record of seven titles in a season. Swiatek has won titles in seven cities in 2022, solidifying her position as a top player. She will hold a significant lead in the rankings over Jabeur and is closing in on Naomi Osaka as the most accomplished Slam champion of their generation.

site_title: Owner Buss wants to see James 'retire as a Laker'
summary: Lakers owner Jeanie Buss expressed her desire for LeBron James to retire as a Laker, citing their strong communication and appreciation for each other. The four-time NBA champion is nearing the end of his two-year contract extension, which will expire when James' oldest son, Bronny, becomes eligible for the NBA draft. Buss wants to see James break Kareem Abdul-Jabbar's all-time scoring record, currently 1,325 points behind, while wearing a Lakers uniform, which holds significant meaning to the organization and personally for Buss.

site_title: Football: Tuchel devastated to leave Chelsea
summary: Thomas Tuchel, 49-year-old German manager, was sacked by Chelsea on Wednesday, following a poor start to the season. His departure comes after a 19-month tenure, where he led the team to the Champions League final and the Club World Cup. Tuchel expressed his devastation on Twitter, stating that Chelsea was a club where he felt at home. The team has since appointed Graham Potter as their new manager.

site_title: Verstappen could retain title in S'pore
summary: Max Verstappen is in line to retain his Formula One title with a 116-point lead over Charles Leclerc, as long as he extends his lead by 22 points at the Singapore Grand Prix on Oct 2. Verstappen won the Italian Grand Prix for his 11th victory of the season, breaking the season-record 13 wins set by Michael Schumacher and Sebastian Vettel. Leclerc, who started in pole position, finished second, while Verstappen's win solidified his position as the overwhelming favorite to secure his sixth win in a row and potentially claim his second drivers' championship.

site_title: Jabeur vows to learn from loss, return stronger in 2023
summary: Tunisian tennis player Ons Jabeur lost her second consecutive Grand Slam final to Iga Swiatek at the US Open. Despite the defeat, Jabeur vowed to learn from her loss and return stronger in 2023. The 28-year-old, who will regain the No. 2 ranking, has had a successful season, winning titles in Madrid and Berlin. Jabeur, who became the first Arab woman to reach a Slam final and the first African woman to reach the US Open championship match, is determined to continue chasing her career goals and is looking forward to competing in the WTA Finals.

site_title: Joy to the max for Faiz
summary: Singaporean apprentice jockey Faiz Khair won his first race on September 10, 2022, aboard CT Kuah-trained Maximilian in a $30,000 Class 5 race. The 28-year-old, who joined the racing world in 2016, had previously been riding for Desmond Koh, but this victory marked his first win. Faiz, who has no racing background, credited his father for supporting his decision to pursue a career in racing and expressed relief and confidence in his abilities.

site_title: Idol Rafa spurs Filipina to junior title
summary: Alexandra Eala, a 17-year-old Filipino tennis player, became the country's first Grand Slam junior champion at the US Open, defeating Lucie Havlickova 6-2, 6-4. Eala credited her idol, Rafael Nadal, for inspiration, citing his determination and clear thinking as key to her success. This win follows her previous achievements, including becoming the first Filipina to win a WTA Tour main-draw match. Eala, now 297th on the tour, plans to transition to the WTA Tour in the coming months, aiming to inspire younger players with her platform.

site_title: From ice cream to sparkling water and dog chews: How cannabis goes 'under cover'
summary: Cannabis-infused products have infiltrated everyday items, disguising themselves as "wholesome" and "wellness" products. These products can contain psychoactive substances, despite claims of containing only cannabidiol (CBD). The harms of cannabis use include increased risk of mental health issues, addiction, and physical health problems. Experts warn that the industry's marketing tactics are deceptive, and the risks of cannabis use outweigh its potential benefits. Singapore's strict laws and regulations aim to protect citizens from the dangers of cannabis, with those found to have consumed the substance abroad facing severe penalties.

site_title: Netball: Near miss for Singapore as they fall 63-53 to Sri Lanka at Asian C'ship final
summary: Singapore's netball team fell short of winning their first Asian Championship title, losing 63-53 to Sri Lanka in the final. The hosts led 30-27 at halftime, but Sri Lanka rallied to win their sixth Asian title. Despite the loss, Singapore head coach Annette Bishop praised the team's effort and progress throughout the tournament. The team will now move on to the Nations Cup in December, with many young players gaining valuable experience.

site_title: Immeasurable can be counted on in Race 5
summary: South Africa's Greyville racing analysis focuses on upcoming events, with key contenders identified in each race. In Race 5, Immeasurable is favored to win after a strong performance in three starts on the Poly track. Other notable contenders include Master to Be and Straight Up. Meanwhile, in Race 7, Bingin Beach is expected to win against Dawn of Fane, with both horses having good form on the Poly track.

site_title: Football: Cadiz 'keeper Ledesma lauded for helping save fan's life during loss to Barca
summary: Cadiz goalkeeper Jeremias Ledesma was praised for his quick thinking after helping medical staff resuscitate a fan who suffered a cardiac arrest during a La Liga game against Barcelona on September 10. Ledesma retrieved a medical kit with a defibrillator and threw it to medical staff, who used it to resuscitate the fan. The fan was transferred to the intensive care unit and remains hospitalized. The match was suspended and restarted after the incident, with Barcelona ultimately winning 4-0. Coach Xavi Hernandez prioritized the fan's condition, saying the game's continuation depended on the fan's recovery.

site_title: Pods set up in void decks to cater to requests for conducive work, study spaces
summary: Singapore is introducing portable work-study pods in void decks to provide a private and conducive environment for residents to work near their homes. The pilot, launched in Boon Lay, features nine air-conditioned pods with Wi-Fi and soundproofing, offering flexibility for students and working adults. The initiative aims to address the need for quiet spaces amidst the ongoing hybrid work arrangements. With 5,000 residents expected to benefit, the pods are available for booking through a mobile app, with prices set to rise after a launch promotion period.

site_title: Ethereum blockchain set for 'monumental' overhaul
summary: Developers are set to upgrade the Ethereum blockchain, reducing its environmentally unfriendly energy consumption by over 99% in a monumental overhaul dubbed "the merge". The changeover, expected to take place between Tuesday and Thursday, will replace the current "proof of work" system with a more energy-efficient "proof of stake" system. The upgrade aims to spur wider adoption of Ethereum, particularly among banks, and could provide a boost to traditional financial institutions. However, the process is risky, and critics question whether it will pass off without incident and overcome major hurdles before widespread adoption.

site_title: Formula One: Verstappen wins in Monza for first time, stretches c'ship lead
summary: Max Verstappen won the Italian Grand Prix, his fifth straight victory, to move potentially a race away from his second Formula One world championship. Verstappen, now 335 points ahead, defeated Charles Leclerc, who finished second, to stretch his lead. A win in the next race in Singapore would seal the title, but the championship will go to Japan if Leclerc wins. Verstappen's victory was his 31st career win, and Red Bull boss Christian Horner praised his driver's performance.

site_title: They 'fought till the end'
summary: Singapore's netball team, led by coach Annette Bishop, lost to defending champions Sri Lanka 63-53 at the Asian Netball Championship, ending their eight-year title drought. The hosts took an early lead, but Sri Lanka rallied to win, with veteran Tharjini Sivalingam scoring a game-high 19 goals. Despite the loss, Bishop was proud of the young team's effort and progress throughout the tournament. Both teams have qualified for the 2023 World Cup in Cape Town, South Africa, and Singapore's next tournament is the Nations Cup in December.

site_title: China consumer stock rout signals darkening economic outlook
summary: China's consumer stock market has experienced a significant downturn, with consumer discretionary stocks in the MSCI China Index underperforming the broader gauge this quarter. The outpouring of pent-up demand has been absent due to Covid-19 restrictions and a record high youth jobless rate, causing companies like Pop Mart International Group and Zhongsheng Group to fall over 50% and a third, respectively. Investors are shifting focus to companies that cater to the "consumption downgrade" trend, such as Pinduoduo and Vipshop, which have seen gains.

site_title: Reserve drivers are always 'ready to step in'
summary: Reserve drivers in Formula One play a crucial, yet often unheralded role, as they provide support to full-time drivers and can step in at a moment's notice. Typically, reserve drivers are veterans without a full-time ride, youngsters looking to break into the sport, or ousted racers seeking a return. They typically spend their time testing, practicing, and performing media and marketing duties, with the potential to replace a full-time driver if needed. Several reserve drivers, including Alexander Albon, Pietro Fittipaldi, Robert Kubica, and Nico Hulkenberg, have spoken about the importance of being ready to step in and the opportunities it can bring.

site_title: ST Explains: Understanding Ethereum's major upgrade
summary: Ethereum is set to undergo a major software upgrade, known as "The Merge", which promises to slash energy consumption by 99.9% by transitioning from "proof-of-work" to "proof-of-stake". The upgrade, scheduled for completion between September 10-20, will radically change transaction processing and new ether token creation. Ethereum backers believe this will make the network more favourable compared to Bitcoin, potentially increasing its price and usability, and could lead to wider adoption of Ethereum applications.

site_title: MMA: Diaz submits Ferguson to end UFC tenure with a win
summary: Nate Diaz won his final UFC fight with a fourth-round submission victory over Tony Ferguson at UFC 279. The 37-year-old Diaz dominated the bout, using his pinpoint boxing to open a cut above Ferguson's eye before submitting him with a guillotine choke. The win caps off an event marred by a backstage brawl and weight issues with Khamzat Chimaev. Diaz's victory statement hinted at a potential move to another sport, while Chimaev vowed to dominate his opponents and become the most feared fighter in the UFC.

site_title: Genting Dream customers denied boarding: Case president calls for review of overbooking practices
summary: More than 100 Genting Dream customers were denied boarding on September 4 due to overbooking. Consumers Association of Singapore (CASE) president Melvin Yong called for a review of the practice, citing the lack of regulation and compensation for affected consumers. In response, Resorts World Cruises offered full refunds and a complimentary cruise, but Yong noted that this may not address concerns of consumers who had taken leave for vacation. Yong suggested reviewing back-end algorithms and implementing a buffer for peak holiday seasons to protect consumers in Singapore's tourism industry.

site_title: Me & My Money: Keep an open mind when investing, says tech exec
summary: Tech executive Christanto Suryadarma advises keeping an open mind when investing, emphasizing the importance of learning from others and staying independent in decision-making. As Zebra Technologies' South-east Asia sales vice-president, Suryadarma encourages investors to be open to new insights and perspectives, while maintaining a research-based approach to making informed decisions.

site_title: DPM Heng Swee Keat to meet Vietnam's PM, visit industrial park during official visit
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat is set to visit Vietnam from Sunday to Thursday, meeting Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh and visiting the Vietnam-Singapore Industrial Park (VSIP). The visit reaffirms bilateral commitment to deepening economic cooperation between Singapore and Vietnam. Established in 1996, the VSIP has attracted US$14 billion in investments and created over 270,000 jobs. Heng's visit highlights the excellent relations between the two countries and is accompanied by officials from various Singaporean ministries.

site_title: Golf: Flawless Higa's closing 65 propels him to Asian Tour win
summary: Japan's Kazuki Higa won the Asian Tour's Shinhan Donghae Open with a flawless final round six-under 65, securing a two-stroke victory over Tirawat Kaewsiribandit of Thailand. Higa's 20-under 264 total marked his third win of the season, earning him multi-year exemptions on the Asian and Korea tours. The 27-year-old credited patience as key to his success, with five birdies and no dropped shots in the final round.

site_title: 6 taken to hospital after traffic accident at junction of Keppel Road and Cantonment Link
summary: A traffic accident occurred at the Keppel Road and Cantonment Link junction in Singapore on Saturday night, involving a ComfortDelGro taxi and a car. Six people, including a 50-year-old taxi driver, were taken to hospital with injuries. The taxi driver suffered leg and chest injuries, while four taxi passengers had minor injuries. The cabby has been warded, and ComfortDelGro is providing assistance. No pedestrians were injured. Police investigations are ongoing.

site_title: Golf: Shayne Lim, Hiroshi Tai do S'pore proud with US college triumphs
summary: Singaporean golfers Shayne Lim and Hiroshi Tai won at The Players Club Invitational in Indiana and the Maui Jim Invitational in Arizona, respectively. Lim, 18, finished two-under 214 to claim her second-best 54-hole score in program history, while Tai, 20, edged out Michael Mjaaseth in a play-off to win the Maui Jim Invitational. Both golfers represented their respective US colleges, Taylor University and Georgia Tech, and expressed excitement about their wins and future performances.

site_title: Golf: Inspired Lowry edges Rahm and McIlroy to win BMW PGA Championship title
summary: Ireland's Shane Lowry won the BMW PGA Championship, edging out Jon Rahm and Rory McIlroy to claim his first title since the 2019 Open. Lowry's 18-under-par 65 in the final round, including a birdie on the 18th, secured the $1.36 million prize. The tournament, reduced to three rounds due to the death of Queen Elizabeth, saw Lowry overcome the presence of LIV Tour players, including Rahm and McIlroy, to secure victory.

site_title: Lunch with Sumiko: 'It's been a roller coaster,' says Edwin Tong on his journey from lawyer to lawmaker
summary: Minister Edwin Tong, who holds roles in Culture, Community and Youth, and Law, described his time in office as a "roller-coaster ride." Tong made the career switch from lawyer in 2018. He is known for being non-conformist and playful, despite his official roles. Tong initially requested an interview in December 2021 but faced delays due to a tight schedule. The interview, "Lunch with Edwin Tong," was finally set up eight months later, marking a significant milestone in the making.

site_title: Driver, 28, dies in PIE accident after van believed to have skidded on slip road
summary: A 28-year-old van driver died in a traffic accident on the Pan-Island Expressway (PIE) in Singapore on Sunday. The driver, who was behind the wheel of a van that was believed to have skidded on a slip road, was pronounced dead at the scene by an SCDF paramedic. The van sustained significant damage, with a smashed windscreen and crumpled bonnet. Police investigations are ongoing, with the van being towed away and the body removed from the scene.

site_title: PCF to add 2,500 pre-school places by end-2023, expand eldercare centres
summary: The People's Action Party's social and charitable arm, PCF, plans to add 2,500 pre-school places and expand its eldercare services by the end of 2023. The expansion will be concentrated in areas with high demand, such as Bidadari and Tampines North, and will benefit around 50,000 children. PCF also aims to set up more senior care centres over the next five years, with plans to open its eighth eldercare facility in 2024 or 2025. The expansion plans do not impact fees for pre-school and eldercare services.

site_title: 4 things to note about joint accounts
summary: In Singapore, joint bank accounts follow the survivorship rule, where the account is owned by the two parties until one of them dies, at which point the remaining owner gains full control of the account and all its funds. The contributor to the account may claim a larger share of the asset, but the law prioritizes the survivor's claim. It's essential for individuals to understand the implications of joint account ownership and the laws governing it to avoid potential disputes and financial consequences.

site_title: What you need to consider as an angel investor
summary: As an angel investor, consider evaluating your friend's business by assessing its potential, market demand, and financial projections. Research the company's team, industry trends, and competitive landscape. Set clear expectations and agreements, including the amount invested, equity stake, and exit strategy. Establish a valuation framework to determine the investment's worth in case the business fails. Consider diversifying your investments to minimize risk. A well-informed decision can help protect your investment and potentially lead to a successful partnership.

site_title: If my kids don't want to run the bank, so be it: UOB's Wee Ee Cheong
summary: UOB Vice-Chairman and CEO Wee Ee Cheong is preparing to break with tradition by picking a successor from outside his family, unlike his father who took over eight banks. Cheong is grappling with the first big acquisition he has directly supervised, the retail portfolio bought from Citi in Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, and Vietnam, which has helped expand UOB's footprint in these markets. The acquisition was hailed as a significant move that solidifies UOB as a dominant regional player, but comes with headaches due to internal cultures and systems. Cheong believes the Citi portfolio will give UOB a five-year advantage in the customer base acquired.

site_title: S'poreans must stay united
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the importance of unity among Singaporeans, urging them to keep the trust in one another as he opened the renovated Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry building.

site_title: Singapore's new work pass: One pass, many options to help woo global talent
summary: Singapore has introduced the Overseas Networks and Expertise (One) Pass, a new work pass aimed at attracting global talent. Announced by Minister for Manpower Tan See Leng, the pass offers various options to help woo top professionals in different fields. The move is seen as part of Singapore's efforts to boost its competitiveness and attract top talent in the global job market.

site_title: How to prepare your house for climate change
summary: Subscribers can prepare their houses for climate change by making proactive upgrades to save money and reduce emissions. Four ways to climate-proof a home include: electrifying with solar energy to eliminate fossil fuel costs and greenhouse gas emissions. This can be achieved by installing solar panels, which not only save money but also reduce the home's carbon footprint. By taking proactive steps, homeowners can avoid unnecessary headaches and emissions, ultimately protecting their homes from the threats exacerbated by climate change.

site_title: Man jailed after trying to bribe co-worker over use of TraceTogether token
summary: A 27-year-old Chinese national, Yang Fei, was sentenced to four weeks' jail for trying to bribe his co-worker, Wan Meng, to flee to Malaysia after using Wan's TraceTogether token to gain access to malls in Singapore. Yang, who had been vaccinated against Covid-19 in China but did not update his records, attempted to bribe Wan with $100 and cigarettes to hamper investigations. Wan, however, refused and reported the incident to the police, leading to Yang's guilty plea and sentence.

site_title: NUS offers meteorology, climate science minor to build up local expertise
summary: The National University of Singapore (NUS) is launching a new minor in meteorology and climate science to build local expertise in the field. The course, open to all students in the NUS College of Humanities and Sciences, will provide an introduction to weather and climate science and is expected to prepare students for careers in sustainability consulting, renewable energy, and coastal protection engineering. The minor aims to address Singapore's reliance on international experts in climate science and is part of a larger effort to develop local talent in the field.

site_title: S'pore woman had to share $5m with ex-husband
summary: A Singaporean woman, inheriting $2 million in shares from her late father, was forced to share the funds with her ex-husband in their divorce settlement due to joint investment accounts. Contrary to common perceptions, the couple's joint account holders have unilateral rights to withdraw money, as they are presumed to own the funds in equal shares, regardless of actual ownership. The woman was required to split the $5 million total value of the shares, resulting in a costly lesson about asset ownership in marriage.

site_title: Pandemic lessons will help nation tackle future challenges: Vivian
summary: Singapore Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan emphasized that the pandemic experience and networks built will help the nation tackle future challenges such as climate change, natural disasters, and geopolitical crises. He noted that the world is in a "more dangerous and volatile place" and that the accumulated knowledge and resources are essential to address these issues. Balakrishnan stressed the need for multilateral cooperation and urgent reorientation of institutions to meet future challenges, citing the importance of being "nimble, networked, and effective" in responding to global crises.

site_title: NBA: Argentina's four-time champion Ginobili enters Hall of Fame
summary: Manu Ginobili, Argentina's four-time NBA champion, has been inducted into the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame. The 45-year-old won four titles in 16 seasons with the San Antonio Spurs, playing alongside Tim Duncan and Tony Parker under coach Gregg Popovich. Ginobili attributed his induction to his role on the Spurs, saying he was part of "two of the most important teams of the 2000s." He also praised his international career with Argentina, winning Olympic gold in 2004.

summary: Singapore has introduced the Overseas Networks and Expertise (One) Pass to attract top global talent, with a monthly salary criterion of $30,000 or more. The pass aims to tap the networks and expertise of foreign professionals, accelerating the development of the local talent pool. Key job roles expected to meet the salary criterion include those in the top 10-20% of organizations, such as managing directors, top executives, and highly skilled professionals. This move is part of Singapore's efforts to compete with other countries in attracting game-changing talent, despite home-grown talent making a splash abroad.

site_title: Istana Park to be 3 times larger
summary: A 500m stretch of Orchard Road will be pedestrianized from 2025, transforming it into an expanded Istana Park, three times its current size. The area will be divided from vehicular traffic, which will be redirected to Penang Road, now set to become a two-way road. The Istana Park will provide a larger public space, offering improved amenities and accessibility. The project is expected to commence in 2025, enhancing the area's recreational and cultural significance.

site_title: Istana Park expansion, pedestrianisation of Orchard Road stretch to be completed from 2025
summary: Singapore's Dhoby Ghaut area is set to undergo a major transformation, with a 500m stretch of Orchard Road to be pedestrianized and the 1.3ha Istana Park expanded to about three times its current size. The project, expected to be completed by 2025, aims to create a car-free environment and recreational options. The expansion will incorporate existing green spaces and include new features such as an orchid-themed garden and nature play area. Experts note that the project's success will depend on designing for transport mode shift and minimizing disruptions to commuters.

site_title: Tennis: Swiatek defeats Jabeur to clinch US Open crown
summary: World number one Iga Swiatek defeated Tunisia's Ons Jabeur 6-2, 7-6 (7/5) to win her second Grand Slam title of the year at the US Open. The 21-year-old Polish star has now won 10 career titles, including her first Grand Slam title in 2022. Jabeur, the fifth seed, was bidding to become the first woman from Africa to win a Grand Slam, but ultimately fell short. Swiatek's victory marked her second Grand Slam win in a single season, a feat not achieved by a woman since 2016.

site_title: Tech equipment reseller narrowly avoids losing more than $100k in business e-mail scam
summary: A tech equipment reseller narrowly avoided losing over $100,000 in a business email scam (BEC) when a fake order from Nanyang Technological University (NTU) was revealed to be a scam. The company received an email from a supposed NTU procurement official ordering 50 laptops, but after investigating, the company realized the email was fake. The scammer had posed as an NTU employee and had instructed the reseller to deliver the laptops to a freight forwarder, who was in on the scam. The reseller has since found legitimate buyers for the equipment and plans to implement new security measures to prevent future scams.

site_title: Appealing to matters of the heart
summary: Minister Edwin Tong, a lawyer-turned-politician, has spoken about the challenges of his role in building national identity and cohesion. His interview, "Lunch With Sumiko," was eight months in the making due to a tight schedule. Tong described being in office as a "roller-coaster ride," suggesting the complexities and difficulties he faces in his ministry. The interview, now available, offers insight into his experiences and perspectives on his work.

site_title: Rental, shared housing more appealing to young S'poreans, though most still want to own homes: Study
summary: A recent study by PropertyGuru found that more young Singaporeans (22-29 years old) are considering renting and shared housing due to high property prices, with one-fifth feeling that current prices are too high. Despite this, most respondents still intend to buy a home within the next two years, with personal space being the top reason. The study highlights the growing need for rental options and flexible housing solutions, with some experts suggesting that housing policy should accommodate the growing rental needs of citizens.

site_title: Academics to artists, S'pore's new talent pass covers wide range of sectors
summary: Singapore has introduced the Overseas Networks and Expertise (One) Pass, a new talent pass that aims to attract top professionals across various sectors, including sports, arts, and academia, beyond the traditional science and technology fields. Workers already in Singapore can apply for the One Pass before their existing work pass expires. The pass does not have a minimum monthly salary requirement, allowing for a broader range of individuals to be considered, including those who may not meet the $30,000 threshold. This move is part of Singapore's efforts to attract global talent.

site_title: Niche work passes such as Singapore's One Pass are evolving
summary: Singapore has introduced the Overseas Networks and Expertise (One) Pass, a new work pass aimed at attracting top talent in various fields. This move follows the launch of the Tech.Pass in January last year, designed to draw tech industry professionals. The One Pass is part of Singapore's efforts to boost its economy and become a hub for skilled workers. The initiative is seen as a key strategy to attract the world's best talent to the city-state.

site_title: C-suite officers, those with rare tech skills can draw $30,000 a month
summary: C-suite officers with rare tech skills can qualify for the Overseas Networks and Expertise (One) Pass, a new pass for top foreign professionals, by having a fixed monthly salary of $30,000. This pass aims to attract high-skilled workers to the country. The exact jobs that pay this amount are not specified in the article, but it implies that tech-related positions with high salaries are eligible for the pass.

site_title: Singapore's new work pass: Visa schemes elsewhere pose challenge to S'pore
summary: Singapore has introduced the Overseas Networks and Expertise (One) Pass to attract top foreign talent, a move that poses a challenge to existing visa schemes in other countries. The new pass aims to foster innovative projects and put Singapore on the global map. Dr. Leonard Ng, a Singaporean materials scientist, holds the UK's Global Talent Visa and hopes the new pass will facilitate his work abroad. The pass is seen as a strategic move to reel in top foreign talent and drive economic growth, but its impact on existing visa schemes remains to be seen.

site_title: Singapore's new work pass to attract talent: What are the jobs that pay $30,000 or more a month?
summary: Singapore has introduced the Overseas Networks and Expertise (One) Pass, a new work pass aimed at attracting top foreign talent. To qualify, applicants must have a fixed monthly salary of $30,000 or more. The pass is part of initiatives to strengthen Singapore's position as a global talent hub. The One Pass is one of several new measures to attract high-skilled workers, including the new Work Holiday Pass and the Global Investor Programme. These initiatives are expected to boost the country's economic growth and competitiveness.

site_title: 'If my kids don't want to run the bank, so be it'
summary: UOB vice-chairman Wee Ee Cheong defies family tradition by considering non-traditional successors for the bank's top position. Unlike his father, Wee Cho Yaw, who ordered him back home after graduation, Wee Ee Cheong is open to selecting a successor from outside the family. This move is a departure from the expected family succession plan, reflecting a shift in leadership style.

site_title: Better-equipped Tampines CPF service centre reopens after revamp
summary: The Tampines CPF service centre in Singapore reopened after a 50% expansion and renovation, offering improved accessibility and services. The centre features 24/7 self-help kiosks, a consultation room for wheelchair users, and a room for public workshops. Digital ambassadors will be available to teach residents digital skills, such as using PayNow and accessing government services online. The centre aims to cater to the growing number of elderly residents who are digitally savvy, allowing customer service executives to focus on human assistance. The renovation is part of the CPF Board's efforts to enhance online services and user experience.

site_title: Keep an open mind when investing, says tech exec
summary: Tech industry executive Christanto Suryadarma, Zebra Technologies' South-east Asia sales vice-president, advises investors to maintain an open mind and be willing to learn from others, while also thinking independently and making informed decisions based on research.

site_title: Trust among S'poreans vital amid US-China tensions: DPM Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the importance of trust among Singaporeans amid rising US-China tensions and economic challenges. He urged Singaporeans to stand up for one another and maintain a consistent, principled stance on vital interests. The Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SCCI) was praised for its role in shaping Singapore's response to the Covid-19 pandemic and its contributions to the nation's multicultural character. Wong encouraged SCCCI to champion the needs of Singaporean enterprises and support the Government's public engagement exercise Forward Singapore.

site_title: One pass, many options to help woo global talent
summary: Singapore's Overseas Networks and Expertise (One) Pass has been announced to attract top talent, with the goal of competing with other countries for game-changing talent. The pass, unveiled by Minister for Manpower Tan See Leng, offers multiple options for businesses to woo global talent. To qualify, job roles must meet a $30,000 monthly criterion, with the aim of supporting businesses in attracting top players in various fields. The pass is part of Singapore's efforts to boost its workforce and remain competitive in the global talent market.

site_title: Makeover of Dhoby Ghaut area to be completed from 2025 onwards
summary: The Dhoby Ghaut area in Singapore is set to undergo a major makeover starting from 2025, with plans to expand Istana Park and pedestrianize a 500m stretch of Orchard Road. The works will include diverting traffic from the pedestrianized stretch to Penang Road, which may require a portion to be made two-way. The expanded park will incorporate existing green spaces and provide more recreational options, with the aim of transforming Orchard Road into a "lush green corridor". Experts say the project will promote public transport use and improve road layouts, but a study is needed to assess the expansion of Penang Road.

site_title: 'What's mine is yours' can be costly sentiment
summary: A woman inherited $2 million in shares from her late father and was required to share the wealth with her ex-husband in their divorce settlement due to transferring the stocks into joint investment accounts. This decision highlights the importance of asset ownership in marriage and the potential consequences of a 'what's-mine-is-yours' approach.

site_title: Visa schemes elsewhere pose challenge to S'pore
summary: Singapore's efforts to attract top foreign talent with the Overseas Networks and Expertise (One) Pass are being challenged by the success of its own home-grown talent abroad. Dr. Leonard Ng, a Singaporean materials scientist, holds the UK's Global Talent Visa, demonstrating the country's ability to produce skilled individuals who can compete with foreign talent. This trend may hinder Singapore's goal of reeling in top foreign talent with its new visa scheme.

site_title: More complaints filed in first half against businesses in beauty sector
summary: Subscribers, a growing number of complaints have been filed against businesses in the beauty sector in Singapore, with many reporting instances of hard selling. A case cited by the Consumers Association of Singapore (CASE) involved a woman who was given a voucher for a free manicure and pedicure but was instead sold an overpriced package worth more than $3,000. This is not an isolated incident, highlighting concerns over the practices of some beauty businesses in the country.

site_title: Call for more volunteers to support organisations that help caregivers
summary: Singapore Minister for Communications and Information Josephine Teo is urging citizens to volunteer with organizations that support caregivers, citing a dipping trend in volunteerism since the pandemic. The People's Action Party (PAP) annual Women's Wing conference featured a public exhibition highlighting 23 groups and initiatives, with some struggling to recruit and retain volunteers. Teo emphasized the need for more volunteers to help charities scale up services, particularly for seniors and individuals with disabilities, and encouraged a shift towards more progressive family norms and shared caregiving responsibilities.

site_title: Teammates her pillar as Lim completes injury comeback
summary: Netball player Laura Lim made a successful comeback from injury, completing a three-year recovery. The first sign of her progress was returning to the OCBC Arena, where she experienced a setback three years prior, resulting in an Achilles tendon injury. Lim's comeback was marked by a visit two weeks prior to the Asian Netball Championship, where she felt her legs wobble, indicating a step closer to full recovery.

site_title: How to prepare your house for climate change
summary: Subscribers can prepare their homes for climate change by implementing defensive solutions, including solar panels, smart meters, and greywater harvesting. Proactive upgrades can help homeowners save money and reduce emissions. Four key ways to climate-proof a home include anticipating extreme weather, and making upgrades such as installing solar panels and smart meters, which can help reduce energy consumption and costs. These measures can also aid in avoiding unnecessary emissions, ultimately providing a more resilient and sustainable living space.

site_title: Niche work passes are evolving
summary: Singapore has introduced a new Overseas Networks and Expertise (One) Pass to attract top talent, following the launch of the Tech.Pass last year. The One Pass aims to bring in experts from various fields, including technology, to contribute to the country's growth. The move is part of Singapore's efforts to attract the world's best talent, as described by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. The launch of the new pass marks the latest in a series of specialized work passes designed to draw in skilled individuals.

site_title: Final and World Cup spot booked
summary: Singapore secured a spot in the Asian Netball Championship final and the 2023 World Cup after defeating Malaysia 54-41 in a hard-fought semi-final match. The team, comprised of mostly young players, overcame a 10-goal deficit in the third quarter to win. They will face Sri Lanka, the reigning champions, in the final. The victory marked a significant milestone for the young Singaporean team, led by shooter Lee Pei Shan, who scored 35 of her 39 attempts.

site_title: Entrepreneur almost lost $100k to business e-mail scam
summary: A tech equipment reseller company narrowly avoided losing over $100,000 to a business email compromise (BEC) scam. The scammer posed as an employee from Nanyang Technological University, ordering 50 laptops to be delivered to a freight forwarder. The company's co-founder initially fell for the scam but alerted the freight forwarder, who informed him it was fake. The police are investigating, and the company plans to implement a new system requiring multiple approvals for orders to prevent similar incidents in the future.

The pass is not limited to those earning above $30,000 per month, making it a more inclusive approach to talent acquisition.

site_title: 4 things to note about joint accounts
summary: A joint bank account comes under the survivorship rule, where the surviving account holder owns the entire account balance upon the death of the other account holder. This means that even if the account is opened with multiple people, only the surviving account holder is considered the owner of the account. It's essential to understand this law before opening a joint account, especially with family members or live-in companions, to avoid any potential disputes or financial implications.

site_title: What you need to consider as an angel investor
summary: As an angel investor, consider evaluating your friend's business by assessing its potential for growth, market demand, and financial projections. Research the industry, competition, and team to determine the business's viability. Set clear expectations and define your investment terms, including the amount, equity stake, and exit strategy. Establish a valuation framework to determine the business's worth in case of a potential sale or liquidation. It's also essential to have a clear understanding of your friend's business plan and their ability to manage the business, as this can impact the success of your investment.

site_title: Irish beef, lamb may soon be on supermarket shelves here
summary: Ireland is planning to promote its beef and lamb products in Singapore through a new campaign, following a successful trade mission to the country. The move aims to increase exports of Irish food and drink, with a target of €800 million by 2025. Irish beef and lamb are already available at top-tier restaurants and online platforms, and will soon be sold in supermarkets. Minister Charlie McConalogue sees opportunities for Ireland to build relationships with Singaporean partners and tap into the country's discerning consumer market, which values sustainability and high-quality food.

site_title: Rental, shared housing appeal more to young S'poreans: Study
summary: Young Singaporeans, particularly those aged 22-29, are opting for rental and shared housing due to high property prices. Despite this, most intend to buy a home within two years, citing the need for personal space as the top reason. One-fifth of respondents in this age group feel current property prices are too high, while two-thirds have chosen to rent over buying due to lack of savings. Experts suggest that housing policy should accommodate growing rental needs, with some advocating for subsidized rent models to bridge the gap between home ownership aspirations and affordability.

site_title: IOC fully confident Paris 2024 can proceed safely
summary: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) expressed full confidence in France's ability to ensure security at the 2024 Paris Olympics, following a series of safety concerns and incidents, including the chaotic Champions League final in May. IOC President Thomas Bach praised the French authorities for drawing the right conclusions from the incidents and having a plan in place for the opening ceremony, which will take place on the River Seine. The number of attendees is being capped, and World Athletics president Sebastian Coe is pushing for certain events to be moved into street locations to increase exposure despite potential security costs.

site_title: Leclerc on pole, eyeing repeat of Italian GP win
summary: Ferrari's Charles Leclerc secured pole position for Sunday's Italian Grand Prix, 0.145 seconds ahead of Mercedes' George Russell. Leclerc's teammate Carlos Sainz, Red Bull's Max Verstappen, and Lewis Hamilton will face grid penalties due to various infractions. Verstappen, the championship leader, will drop to 7th place, while Leclerc hopes to claim his second win at Monza after a 2019 victory.

site_title: 'Fixing swing' gives Lee6 confidence
summary: South Korean golfer Lee6 Jeong-eun fired a 9-under 63 to take a one-stroke lead after the second round of the LPGA Queen City Championship. Lee6, the world No. 43, is seeking her first title since 2019 and credits swing work as a major part of her preparation. She is currently at 13-under 131 after 36 holes, with China's Lin Xiyu second and American Ally Ewing third. Lee6 plans to focus on her game over the next two rounds, saying she feels confident after a bogey-free round.

site_title: Pressure on Albirex now, says Lalic after Sailors falter
summary: Albirex Niigata has taken a three-point lead in the Singapore Premier League title race with 54 points from 24 matches. The Japanese side's wins against Tampines Rovers and Young Lions have shifted momentum in their favor. Meanwhile, Lion City Sailors coach Luka Lalic has expressed concern over his team's recent performance, citing "easy, silly mistakes" and pressure on his team to chase Albirex. With key players injured, the Sailors face a tough challenge to regain the initiative before their next match against Albirex on October 7.

site_title: Formula One: Alex Albon out of Italian GP with appendicitis
summary: Alex Albon, a 26-year-old Formula One driver for Williams Racing, will miss the Italian Grand Prix due to appendicitis. He underwent treatment and is expected to undergo surgery with a full recovery anticipated. Reserve driver Nyck de Vries will replace Albon for the remainder of the weekend, making his Formula One debut.

site_title: World cup teaser at 'exceptional' Lusail
summary: The Lusail Stadium in Qatar hosted a thrilling teaser match for the World Cup, featuring Egyptian champions Zamalek and Saudi champions Al Hilal. The 77,575-seat stadium, set to host 10 World Cup games, including the final, showed its readiness to host large crowds and facilitate international visitors. The match, which ended in a penalty shootout, was praised for its exceptional venue, solar-powered cooling technology, and readiness for the World Cup. Key performers, including Lionel Messi and Neymar, will soon arrive in Qatar for the tournament, which is expected to draw up to 1.2 million visitors.

site_title: SportsWorld: UFC 279 forced into late change of bouts
summary: The Ultimate Fighting Championship (UFC) was forced to make late changes to the lineup of UFC 279, with Khamzat Chimaev weighing 3.4kg over the welterweight limit, forcing him to face Kevin Holland instead of Nate Diaz. Diaz will now fight Tony Ferguson. Meanwhile, the Bosnia and Herzegovina Football Federation's decision to play a friendly with Russia in November sparked criticism, with Sarajevo Mayor Benjamina Karic vowing to halt cooperation if the game is not cancelled. Two Juventus fans were charged with racism after making Nazi salutes during a Champions League match.

site_title: Putting the Great back into HongKong
summary: Hong Kong-bred seven-year-old Hongkong Great won a $85,000 Class 2 race on the Polytrack at Kranji, Singapore, with a 58.5kg topweight. Trainer Ricardo Le Grange, who had initially considered the Polytrack a "grass is greener" option, is now considering the turf for future races. Despite the win, Le Grange plans to run Hongkong Great in the Queen Elizabeth II Cup and Singapore Gold Cup, both on turf. The victory marks a successful Polytrack debut for the horse, who had previously won on the synthetic track in Hong Kong.

site_title: Low-profile Potter in a high-stakes job
summary: Graham Potter, a low-profile manager, was unexpectedly unveiled as Chelsea's new manager. His appointment coincided with the death of Queen Elizabeth II, leading to the cancellation of Premier League fixtures, and a subsequent low-key press conference. The news overshadowed the announcement, with Potter's introduction to the media taking a backseat to the royal news. Despite the unusual circumstances, Potter's appointment marked a significant change for Chelsea.

site_title: Graham Potter a low-profile man in a high-stakes job
summary: Chelsea appointed Graham Potter as their new manager in a low-key fashion, following his unveiling press conference, which coincided with the cancellation of Premier League fixtures due to Queen Elizabeth II's death. Potter, a former Brighton & Hove Albion manager, is known for his adaptable tactical mind and ability to polish talent. His appointment was largely overshadowed by the royal news, but he is now tasked with leading the high-stakes job at Chelsea.

site_title: Tokyo graft scandal seen hurting Sapporo's 2030 bid
summary: A bribery scandal surrounding former Tokyo 2020 executive Haruyuki Takahashi has cast a shadow over Sapporo's 2030 Winter Olympics bid, raising concerns about corruption and potentially hurting Japan's hosting prospects. Takahashi and several business executives have been arrested on suspicion of bribery, with some questioning Sapporo's commitment to a "clean" bid. Despite this, experts believe the scandal may not significantly impact Sapporo's chances, citing the city's strong technical bid and the IOC's desire for a stable host.

site_title: Netball: Singapore beat Malaysia 54-41 to reach Asian Netball Championship final
summary: Singapore's netball team defeated Malaysia 54-41 in the Asian Netball Championship semi-finals, securing a spot in the final and a World Cup qualification. The young team, with over half players under 25, celebrated their second win over Malaysia in three days. In the final, they will face defending champions Sri Lanka, who also qualified for the World Cup. Singapore's Lee Pei Shan was a key player, converting 35 of her 39 attempts, while coach Annette Bishop's pep talk before the fourth quarter helped the team regain momentum.

site_title: Keep discretionary spending in check: Experts advise as prices rise
summary: Financial experts warn Singaporeans to curb discretionary spending amid rising prices and slower income growth. A study by DBS found that discretionary spending increased by 56.7% in entertainment and travel and 38.7% in food over the past year. As core inflation reaches a 13-year high of 4.8%, experts advise reviewing budgets, reducing discretionary spending, and setting aside emergency cash to maintain quality of life. Using tools to earn rebates and rewards can also help stretch dollars, but it's essential to manage spending and avoid credit card debt.

site_title: Celebrations put on ice
summary: The Lion City Sailors won the Deloitte Women's Premier League (WPL) title with a 4-0 victory over Still Aerion Women's FC. The team clinched 28 points from 10 games, surpassing nearest challengers Tanjong Pagar United. Despite celebrating their win, the Sailors will focus on their last two games before presenting the trophy on Oct 2. The team, led by coach Yeong Sheau Shyan, has been undefeated this season with nine wins and a draw, and will take home a $25,000 cheque.

site_title: Golf: Scottie Scheffler named 2022 PGA Tour Player of the Year
summary: Scottie Scheffler was named the 2022 PGA Tour Player of the Year, receiving 89% of the votes from PGA Tour members. He led the tour with four victories, including the US Masters, and won $14.05 million, breaking Jordan Spieth's record. Scheffler's dominant season included 11 finishes in the Top 10 in 25 tournament appearances, and he has maintained the No. 1 spot in the Official World Golf Rankings for 24 consecutive weeks.

site_title: Bare-knuckle duels show tennis is in safe hands
summary: Tennis is in good hands, according to recent standout performances by players from diverse backgrounds. Carlos Alcaraz, Jannik Sinner, Ons Jabeur, Frances Tiafoe, Iga Swiatek, and Casper Ruud have showcased exceptional skills, despite their unique backgrounds. Alcaraz, son of a chef, won the US Open, while Jabeur, from Tunisia, and Tiafoe, from Sierra Leone, have consistently impressed. Swiatek, daughter of an Olympic rower, and Ruud, a golf enthusiast, have also made significant strides. These players demonstrate the sport's inclusivity and potential for talented individuals from various backgrounds.

site_title: It's about time for period research
summary: World Athletics president Sebastian Coe plans to study the impact of menstrual cycles on female athletes' performance. Coe was prompted by comments from female athletes, including Dina Asher-Smith and Lydia Ko, who highlighted the lack of research on the topic. Asher-Smith experienced calf cramps during the 100m final due to her period, while Ko spoke about the effect on her performance during LPGA Tour tournaments. Coe has asked World Athletics' health and science teams to investigate and assess whether current research is being disseminated properly.

site_title: Golf: Kjeldsen, Hovland share lead at BMW PGA Championship
summary: Denmark's Soren Kjeldsen and Norway's Viktor Hovland share the lead at the BMW PGA Championship, each at 12-under par after two rounds. Rory McIlroy is one shot behind, tied for third at 11-under. The tournament, reduced to 54 holes due to a cancelled round following the death of Queen Elizabeth, will resume on Sunday. Kjeldsen overcame a dismal start to post an 8-under 64, while Hovland's steady play was undone by a costly bogey on the 15th. McIlroy praised his putting, saying it was the key to his strong round.

site_title: Much at stake for young guns
summary: Carlos Alcaraz, 19, will face Casper Ruud in the US Open men's singles final on Sunday, with the winner becoming the world No. 1 for the first time. Alcaraz, who defeated Frances Tiafoe in the semi-finals, is on the cusp of history as the youngest man to reach the top spot at 19 years old. The Spaniard will look to claim his maiden Grand Slam title and surpass Ruud, who has also had a standout year, to win the championship and secure the world No. 1 ranking.

site_title: New design thinking programme gets young students to tackle food waste, climate change
summary: A design thinking programme by Tata Consultancy Services (TCS) and the People's Association (PA) in Singapore has engaged 27 students from low-income families to tackle local community issues, including food waste and climate change. The students presented innovative solutions, such as a composting machine, a water-saving shower system, and an app to reduce plastic usage. The programme aims to foster digital literacy among underprivileged youth, families, and the elderly, and will roll out at other community clubs later this year, funded by $70,000 collected by TCS employees.

site_title: Protecting minority sensitivities part of S'pore's playbook for social cohesion, says former top civil servant
summary: Singapore's government plays a role in protecting minority sensitivities, setting clear boundaries to maintain social cohesion, said former top civil servant Yeoh Chee Yan. The country's approach is exemplified by its stance against publishing insulting cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad. Singapore's institutions, such as the Islamic Religious Council of Singapore, were established to safeguard the rights of its Muslim minority community after independence in 1965. This approach has allowed the country to navigate its multi-religious society effectively, according to Minister-in-charge of Muslim Affairs Masagos Zulkifli.

site_title: Formula One: Ferrari's Charles Leclerc claims pole for Italian Grand Prix
summary: Ferrari's Charles Leclerc secured pole position for the Italian Grand Prix, finishing 0.145 seconds ahead of championship leader Max Verstappen. Leclerc's eighth pole of the season was a result of his fastest lap on his final attempt. Verstappen, who faces a five-place grid penalty, will attempt to win his first Monza Grand Prix and extend his lead over Leclerc and teammate Sergio Perez. George Russell and Nyck de Vries will start alongside Leclerc on the front row, while several drivers have been penalized and will start from the back of the grid.

site_title: Thousands join 4km charity fun walk to promote inclusiveness, raise funds
summary: Thousands of participants joined a 4km charity fun walk along Marina Bay Waterfront Promenade to promote inclusiveness and raise funds for social service agencies. The inaugural event, part of the Community Chest Heartstrings Walk 2022, raised approximately $2 million, benefiting over 100 agencies and 200 programmes. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat and Minister Sun Xueling attended the event, which aims to unite Singaporeans to support communities in need, including children with special needs and people with disabilities.

site_title: More volunteers needed for organisations supporting caregivers, say PAP's women leaders
summary: Minister for Communications and Information Josephine Teo and Nee Soon GRC MP Carrie Tan have called for more Singaporeans to volunteer with organizations supporting caregivers, who are often women. The call comes as some groups struggle to recruit and retain volunteers after the Covid-19 pandemic. Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the need to break down stereotypes and encourage shared parental responsibilities, including men taking on caregiving roles. The issue was highlighted at the PAP Women's Wing conference, where representatives from social service agencies and ground-up groups connected with PAP activists, expressing interest in volunteering.

site_title: Motor racing: Ferrari president backs Binotto, expects titles by 2026
summary: Ferrari president John Elkann expressed confidence in team boss Mattia Binotto, stating the team has "great faith" in him despite recent mistakes. The team, which has not won a title since 2008, is currently second in the standings but expects to win the constructors' and drivers' titles by 2026. Elkann acknowledged that Ferrari needs to improve reliability and make progress in various areas, but is optimistic about their future, particularly with Charles Leclerc in pole position.

site_title: Formula One: Hamilton jokes about watching his iPad during Italian GP
summary: Lewis Hamilton joked about taking his iPad into the cockpit during the Italian Grand Prix, saying he'd watch "Game Of Thrones" while stuck in a DRS train. The seven-time champion will start 19th due to engine penalties, but believes a one-stop strategy might not be necessary. Hamilton has won five times at Monza but has yet to stand on top of the podium this season. The Mercedes driver hopes for safety cars to alter the strategy, and the team is looking forward to the next race in Singapore, a tight street circuit where overtaking is difficult.

site_title: Football: Barca hit four at Cadiz and move top of La Liga
summary: Barcelona secured a 4-0 victory at Cadiz, moving to the top of La Liga with 13 points from five games. Goals from Frenkie de Jong, Robert Lewandowski, Ansu Fati, and Ousmane Dembele sealed the win, with a lengthy stoppage in play due to a medical emergency in the crowd. The win keeps Barcelona ahead of Real Madrid, who host Mallorca on Sunday, and coach Xavi Hernandez expressed satisfaction with the result, citing the team's ability to adapt and maintain their position at the top of the league.

site_title: Football: Lion City Sailors seal Women's Premier League title with 4-0 win over Still Aerion
summary: The Lion City Sailors secured the Deloitte Women's Premier League title with a 4-0 win over Still Aerion, amassing 28 points from 10 games and moving out of reach of nearest challengers Tanjong Pagar United. The victory marks the Sailors' undefeated season with nine wins and a draw, and they will receive a $25,000 winners' cheque. The team's focus now shifts to their remaining two games, with coach Yeong Sheau Shyan and captain Ernie Sulastri Sontaril emphasizing the importance of maintaining their team's standard and executing their game plan.

site_title: Netball: Kimberly Lim earns 100th cap at Asian C'ship after long road back from injury
summary: Singapore netball player Kimberly Lim has achieved a milestone by earning her 100th cap at the Asian Netball Championship. Lim, who had a long road back from a severe Achilles tendon injury, overcame her physical limitations to reach this milestone, becoming the eighth netballer to achieve this feat for Singapore.

site_title: Football: Neymar, Mbappe have 'very good' relationship, Galtier says amid rift claims
summary: Paris Saint-Germain manager Christophe Galtier has denied reports of a rift between forwards Neymar and Kylian Mbappe, saying their relationship is "very good." The claim comes after an incident in their Champions League game, where Mbappe chose to take a shot rather than pass the ball to Neymar for a tap-in. Galtier discussed the issue with Mbappe, who he believes will make more decisive passes to Neymar in the future. Despite the apparent tension, Neymar and Mbappe have been training and warming up together, according to Galtier.

site_title: Motor racing: Binotto apologises for comparing Tsunoda to a tsunami
summary: Ferrari team boss Mattia Binotto apologized for comparing Japanese Formula One driver Yuki Tsunoda to a tsunami, which caused offense in Japan. Tsunoda has had five reprimands and eight penalty points on his super-licence in the last 12 months. Binotto stated that his intention was not to offend, and that Tsunoda is a "fantastic driver" and "great man". The incident occurred at the Italian Grand Prix, where Tsunoda's AlphaTauri team was involved in a controversy with Red Bull's Max Verstappen.

site_title: Bigger, better-equipped Tampines CPF service centre reopens after revamp
summary: Singapore's Tampines CPF service centre has reopened after a 50% expansion and renovation, featuring 24/7 self-help kiosks and a consultation room for wheelchair users. The centre offers digital skills workshops and digital ambassadors to help residents learn online services. The move aims to cater to the elderly and digitally savvy population, freeing up customer service executives to focus on human assistance. The centre's new features are part of a larger effort by the CPF Board to encourage online transactions and improve public engagement.

site_title: Singaporeans must stand up for its people and not take sides amid global tensions: DPM Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the importance of trust among Singaporeans amid economic challenges and global tensions, warning that the country could face pressure to take sides in the geopolitical contest between major powers. He urged Singaporeans to stand up for their people and not be swayed by misinformation, instead advocating for a consistent and principled approach to dealing with external issues. Wong highlighted the role of the Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry in championing the needs of the nation's enterprises and fostering unity among Singaporeans.

site_title: Football: Sailors beaten 2-1 at Tampines as Albirex seize SPL title-race initiative
summary: Lion City Sailors suffered a 2-1 loss to Tampines Rovers, allowing Albirex Niigata to seize the Singapore Premier League (SPL) title-race initiative. Albirex now leads with 54 points from 24 matches, a three-point gap ahead of the Sailors. The Sailors' coach Luka Lalic attributed the loss to "easy, silly mistakes" and urged his players to reflect on themselves after losing their last two matches.

site_title: Golf: South Korea's Lee6 fires bogey-free 63 to seize LPGA Queen City C'ship lead
summary: South Korean golfer Lee6 Jeong-eun fired a bogey-free 63 to take a one-stroke lead after 36 holes at the LPGA Queen City Championship, standing at 13-under 131. She birdied six of the first 10 holes and is seeking her first title since the 2019 US Women's Open. China's Lin Xiyu and American Ally Ewing trail behind, with Lin seeking her first tour title on her 188th start.
