site_title: Activist opts for jail in lieu of fine over assembly outside State Courts
summary: Activist Jolovan Wham chose to serve a 15-day jail term instead of paying a $3,000 fine for holding a one-person assembly outside the former State Courts building. The assembly, which involved holding up a sign with a protest message, occurred on December 13, 2018. Wham's lawyer argued that the action did not constitute an assembly under the Public Order Act, but the High Court dismissed his appeal. This is Wham's second instance of choosing jail over a fine, following a similar decision last year.

site_title: SMRT, polys join hands to strengthen local talent pipeline
summary: SMRT and five Singapore polytechnics have signed a memorandum of understanding to strengthen the local talent pipeline, focusing on engineers, programmers, and specialists to support the company's complex MRT system. The tie-up aims to cultivate talent, with plans to double the number of interns and offer full-time jobs to 40% of interns. The collaboration also includes part-time engineering courses and attachments for lecturers, aiming to accelerate the production of skilled graduates and promote lifelong learning. The move is seen as crucial to meet the growing need for talent to support the expanding MRT system.

site_title: Tennis: Ruud into US Open final against teen Alcaraz with both on the brink of world top ranking
summary: Casper Ruud of Norway reached the US Open final, defeating Karen Khachanov 7-6 (7-5), 6-2, 5-7, 6-2 in the semi-finals. Ruud will face 19-year-old Carlos Alcaraz in Sunday's championship match, with Alcaraz aiming to become the youngest world No. 1 at 20. The win solidifies Ruud's position as world No. 7 and sets up a high-stakes final with the stakes of the world No. 1 ranking on the line.

site_title: Bare-knuckle duels show tennis is in safe hands
summary: Tennis players from diverse backgrounds, including Frances Tiafoe, Ons Jabeur, Jannik Sinner, Iga Swiatek, and Casper Ruud, showcased exceptional skills in recent matches, suggesting the sport is in good hands. These players' unique stories, including their parents' professions and ancestral origins, highlight the sport's inclusivity and global appeal. Their impressive performances indicate that tennis is in a stable position, with talented players from various backgrounds contributing to the sport's growth and diversity.

site_title: Non-dialysis care may be preferable for some older kidney patients: Docs
summary: A growing number of older patients in Singapore are opting for non-dialysis care, with at least 5,000 patients aged 75 and above choosing conservative care over dialysis. This decision is driven by the desire to maintain a better quality of life and lower treatment costs. According to kidney doctors, more older and frailer patients can consider conservative care, which can be a more cost-effective option, especially for those with low life expectancy. A new drug, finerenone, has also been rolled out to combat diabetic kidney disease, further supporting the shift towards conservative care.

site_title: World Cup: 'Exceptional' Lusail Stadium hosts frenetic match in sneak peek of football's showpiece event
summary: The Lusail Stadium in Qatar hosted a high-energy match between Zamalek and Al Hilal for the Lusail Super Cup, a preview of the World Cup. The 80,000-seat stadium, set to host 10 World Cup games, including the final, successfully accommodated a crowd of 77,575, with temperatures moderated by solar-powered cooling technology. The match, which ended in a penalty shootout, was described as an "exceptional" venue by Al Hilal coach Ramon Diaz. The stadium's metro network, which will be the main mode of transport during the tournament, also underwent a trial.

site_title: US stocks rise again, finishing good week on upbeat note
summary: US stocks rose on Friday, ending a three-week losing streak, as investors became more optimistic about inflation. The S&P 500 gained 1.5% for the day and 3.6% for the week, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.2% and the Nasdaq Composite Index jumped 2.1%. Despite Federal Reserve Chairman Christopher Waller's warning of more interest rate hikes, economists are lowering their inflation forecasts, potentially leading to a more moderate rate increase. The positive sentiment was fueled by a strong earnings report from Zscaler, which saw a 61% increase in quarterly revenue.

site_title: Golf: BMW PGA Championship cut to 54 holes after queen's death
summary: The BMW PGA Championship resumed as a 54-hole event after being halted on Thursday in respect of Queen Elizabeth II's death. Play will continue on Saturday with those who finished their first rounds playing the second round. Flags will fly at half-mast, and a two-minute silence will be observed. The event aims to honor the queen's life while allowing players to pay their condolences and compete. Notable players, including Tommy Fleetwood and Rory McIlroy, had completed their opening rounds before the suspension.

site_title: Seniors displayed resilience during pandemic: Study
summary: A new study by the National University Health System (NUHS) found that older adults displayed resilience during the pandemic, thanks to support from family and community service providers. The study, which interviewed 62 seniors aged 65-84, revealed that these individuals showed strong independence, awareness, and initiative in managing their physical and mental well-being despite being forced to retreat into their homes due to fear of Covid-19. The study highlights the value of community service providers' efforts, which included phone calls and digital tools, and emphasizes the need to not take this social fabric for granted.

site_title: Compromise, expanding common space key to keeping society united: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of trust and respect among Singaporeans of different faiths and backgrounds in maintaining a united society. He noted that minority communities have played a crucial role in building this trust, while the majority Chinese community recognizes and respects the interests of minority groups. Lee stressed the need for compromise and accommodation, and encouraged institutions and religious scholars to work together to build a multiracial and multi-religious nation where every Singaporean can develop their unique identity.

site_title: More fresh grads from SIT found full-time jobs, with pay exceeding pre-pandemic levels
summary: Singapore Institute of Technology (SIT) reported a 16.2% increase in fresh graduates securing full-time jobs, with 86% of the 2021 cohort finding employment, including part-time work, within six months of graduation. Starting salaries exceeded pre-pandemic levels, with median gross monthly salaries ranging from $3,550 for SIT graduates to $4,500 for Nanyang Technological University graduates. The survey also showed recovery in graduates from the tourism and built environment sectors, with increased job offers from Integrated Work Study Programme companies before graduation.

site_title: Queen Elizabeth's death a profound loss: President Halimah
summary: Queen Elizabeth II, who reigned for 70 years, has passed away, leaving a profound loss for Singapore and the British royal family. President Halimah, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, and Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong have paid tribute to the monarch, describing her as a symbol of unity, greatly loved and trusted. The Singapore government will observe one minute of silence and fly flags at half-mast on the day of her funeral. The British High Commission is opening a condolence book for the public to pay respects to the late queen.

site_title: 'Her warmth and kindness won the hearts of Singaporeans'
summary: Singaporean leaders, including President Halimah Yacob and Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, have paid tribute to Queen Elizabeth II, describing her as a symbol of strength, inspiration, and hope. The Queen's warmth and kindness won the hearts of Singaporeans, who fondly remember her visits to the country in 1972, 1989, and 2006. Her Majesty's dedication to service and her contributions to the Commonwealth and world affairs will be remembered fondly, with her passing leaving a significant mark on Singapore's history and bilateral relations with the UK.

site_title: Ex-Eu Yan Sang chairman, a man who valued relationships, dies at 99
summary: Dr. Richard Eu Keng Mun, former chairman of Eu Yan Sang Holdings, has passed away at 99 due to old age. He was remembered for valuing relationships, being a generous leader, and contributing to charities and education. Dr. Eu served as vice-chairman of UOB, chairman of the Community Chest, and founding chairman of the Singapore Institute of Management. He was also a foodie who loved Japanese cuisine and was active in giving back to society, leaving behind four children, 11 grandchildren, and 12 great-grandchildren.

site_title: Foundation to help minority Muslim societies learn from one another
summary: A foundation established by the Muslim community in Singapore, the Rahmatan Lil Alamin Foundation, will host study visits for minority Muslim societies worldwide to share best practices and exchange ideas. The visits aim to promote mutual understanding and cooperation in developing successful minority Muslim communities globally. The study visits will be organized under the Singapore Cooperation Programme, which focuses on human capital development. The initiative is crucial for minority Muslim communities, particularly in open, secular societies, to learn from Singapore's experiences and adapt to changing circumstances, guided by principles and values.

site_title: Euro slides as US Fed chief steals thunder of ECB's rate increase
summary: The euro slid against the US dollar despite the European Central Bank's (ECB) record 0.75% interest rate hike, as Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell signaled a tough approach to inflation. The euro briefly dipped to US$0.9934 before recovering to US$1.011. Meanwhile, the pound remained near a 37-year low against the dollar, influenced by new British Prime Minister Liz Truss's fuel bill freeze. The ECB warned of potential recession if Russia cuts off gas, while Powell emphasized the Fed's commitment to higher rates to combat inflation.

site_title: Jail for ex-HDB director who filmed naked men in places like locker rooms
summary: A former Housing Board director, Leo Norman Chee Wei Kiong, was sentenced to 2 weeks' jail and a fine of $31,600 for unlawfully recording videos of naked men in public places, including locker rooms. Chee, 61, pleaded guilty to 6 charges, including filming obscene footage and possession of obscene films. He used his mobile phone to record over 140 videos of men in various settings, including gyms and changing rooms, between 2012 and 2020. Chee's actions were described as a "habit" of filming men he found attractive in public places.

site_title: SIA jet diverted to Azerbaijan after engine oil leak detected
summary: A Singapore Airlines flight from Paris to Singapore was diverted to Azerbaijan after an engine oil leak was detected, forcing all 229 passengers and 18 crew to disembark safely. The Boeing 777 aircraft landed at Baku airport on Friday morning. The safety of customers and crew was the top priority, and the airline is providing assistance, including meals and hotel accommodation. A relief flight is planned to ferry the affected passengers and crew back to Singapore.

site_title: Experience, networks from Covid-19 essential in tackling future challenges: Vivian Balakrishnan
summary: Singapore's Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan emphasized the importance of learning from the Covid-19 pandemic in tackling future challenges, including climate change and natural disasters. He highlighted the need to build networks, mobilize resources, and collaborate with each other to address global issues. Balakrishnan noted that the world is in a more volatile place, with interconnected crises making each one worse. He urged multilateral efforts to be more nimble and networked to address these challenges effectively.

site_title: What it should have been
summary: WeWork has clarified occupancy rates for its Singapore co-working office at 21 Collyer Quay, stating 60% commitment, down from an initial 90% reported in a previous article. Occupancy growth for its 14 locations in Singapore in the second quarter of this year actually grew 25 percentage points, not 25% over last year as initially stated. WeWork is a 12-year-old company, not 22 years old.

site_title: Some OCBC-NTUC cardholders ineligible for credit card from new digital bank
summary: OCBC-NTUC cardholders are facing ineligibility for a new digital bank's credit card. However, eligible cardholders can apply for a debit card, which also offers Linkpoints rebates. The decision aims to modernize banking services for underserved individuals, but some, like retired banker Mike Tay, are concerned about losing benefits like Linkpoints rebates at FairPrice.

site_title: Second ex-prison officer jailed for leaking inmates' info to prisoner
summary: A former Singapore prison officer, Muhammad Zul Helmy Abdul Latip, was sentenced to 7 weeks' jail for leaking classified information, including an inmate's contact number and age, to a rival gang headman. Zul accessed the Prison Operations Rehabilitation System II (Ports II) and shared the information with Abdul Karim Mohamed Kuppai Khan, who was a secret society headman. This is the second case of a former prison officer being jailed for leaking inmate information, following a colleague who was sentenced to 10 weeks' jail in August.

site_title: Queen made three visits to Singapore
summary: Queen Elizabeth II made three visits to Singapore, in 1972, 1989, and 2006, during her symbolic rule over the island state as a British crown colony and later as an independent nation. Her 1972 visit included a tour of Toa Payoh Housing Board estate, where she stayed in a flat that is now preserved for posterity. In 2006, she revisited Toa Payoh and met with then President S R Nathan and Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, marking a full circle of her royal visits to Singapore.

site_title: EY plans to split off audit, consulting units to ease regulatory concerns
summary: Ernst & Young (EY) plans to split its audit and consulting units into two separate companies to address regulatory concerns over potential conflicts of interest. The move is expected to be finalized early next year if partners approve the plan. The split is aimed at providing more choice in the market and better career opportunities for employees, with recruitment plans continuing as usual. The Big Four accounting firms, including EY, Deloitte, KPMG, and PricewaterhouseCoopers, have faced increased pressure to separate their audit and consulting practices following corporate failures and regulatory scrutiny.

site_title: New book seeks to demystify Nominated MP scheme
summary: A new book on Singapore's Nominated Member of Parliament (NMP) scheme has been launched, aiming to demystify the system. The book, written by 20 current and former NMPs, features personal reflections, anecdotes, and little-known facts about their stints. Former Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew and current Speaker Tan Chuan-Jin praised the NMPs for adding color and depth to parliamentary debates, and for representing various sectors. The book hopes to inspire conversations among Singaporeans about their political future and promote deeper civic education.

site_title: China's inflation slowdown fuels calls for more policy stimulus
summary: China's inflation slowed in August, with the consumer price index rising 2.5% and factory-gate inflation slowing to 2.3%, according to the National Bureau of Statistics. This gives policymakers room to support the economy if needed, with some economists calling for further policy stimulus. The slowdown is attributed to sporadic Covid-19 lockdowns and falling commodity prices. Despite this, a weaker renminbi complicates the picture, and most economists expect the People's Bank of China to wait before cutting interest rates again.

site_title: Shopee shuts some operations in Latin America
summary: Shopee, a Singapore-based e-commerce arm of Sea, has shut local operations in Chile, Colombia, and Mexico, and will leave Argentina entirely. The company will maintain cross-border operations in the three countries but cut most teams, affecting dozens of employees. This move comes amid "macro uncertainty" and a focus on core operations. Shopee's revenue in Brazil, its core Latin American market, rose 270% in the second quarter, but the company is under pressure to cut costs after slowing growth.

site_title: India curbs rice exports, adds pressure to food crisis
summary: India, the world's largest rice shipper, has imposed a 20% duty on exports of white and brown rice, banning the sale of broken rice abroad. This move affects about 60% of India's rice exports, mainly going to Asia and Africa, and is expected to boost global rice prices, potentially exacerbating food inflation and hunger. The restrictions are the third major agricultural commodity curbed by India this year, following wheat and sugar exports. The move is seen as a response to India's own food crisis, with rice planting down 5.6% this season due to rainfall issues.

site_title: Foreign student lost bulk of parents' life savings to scammers
summary: A 24-year-old Chinese foreign student lost his parents' life savings of $200,000 to scammers impersonating China officials, just two days after arriving in Singapore. The scammers claimed he was involved in money-laundering activities and demanded $70,000, which he transferred. After receiving more demands, he transferred another $130,000. The victim, who wishes to remain anonymous, said he felt pressured and believed the scammers, fearing arrest. Authorities have received 287 reports of similar scams this year, with a total of $34.6 million lost by victims.

site_title: Pandemic galvanised people to support one another: President
summary: Singaporean President Halimah Yacob stated that the COVID-19 pandemic has galvanized people to support one another, increasing interest in volunteering and charitable causes. Despite the pandemic's impact on businesses and individuals, support for those in need has increased. The President's Challenge Volunteer Drive, launched in 2012, has seen 82,000 volunteers contribute their time and talent over the past decade, with initiatives such as skills training workshops and community gardening projects. The drive aims to rally Singaporeans to help the disadvantaged.

site_title: Keeping net-zero pledges can save Indonesia $98b
summary: Indonesia can potentially save $98 billion by 2050 by sticking to its net-zero pledges and transitioning out of fossil fuels into cleaner energy sources, according to an International Energy Agency (IEA) report. The report notes that if Indonesia achieves its clean energy targets, its fuel import bill could drop from $100 billion to $30 billion, resulting in significant cost savings. This can be achieved by switching to cleaner energy sources and renewables by 2050.

site_title: Twitter paid whistle-blower $9.8m for silence: Elon Musk's lawyer
summary: Twitter paid whistle-blower Peiter Zatko $7 million to secure his silence, according to Elon Musk's lawyer Alex Spiro. The payment was made as part of a settlement related to Zatko's lost compensation after leaving Twitter. The whistle-blower had raised concerns about operational problems within the platform, including spam and bot accounts, before being fired. Zatko will still testify before Congress and regulators, and the trial to force Elon Musk to consummate the Twitter deal is set for October.

site_title: Suit by Ong Teng Cheong's elder son came 'after much deliberation'
summary: Former Singapore president Ong Teng Cheong's elder son, Mr Ong Tze Guan, has filed applications in the High Court to wind up two family companies, O&O Capital and Wang Investment. The move comes after years of disagreements with his former sister-in-law, Madam Wang Yi Yi, over the companies' management. Mr Ong's lawyer stated that the decision was made after "much deliberation" and was not a surprise to Madam Wang. The court has been asked to monitor the timelines for filing the case.

site_title: Crypto dreams dealt blow as Thailand tightens rules
summary: Thailand's efforts to become a leading digital asset trading hub have been dealt a significant blow as regulators tighten rules following trading irregularities and market collapses. The country's cryptocurrency trading slumped to 64 billion baht ($2.5 billion) in September, the lowest since 2020. The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has fined executives and plans a working group to enhance supervision, citing investor protection concerns. The stricter oversight has further dented investor confidence, with the number of active trading accounts falling to 246,000 in September.

site_title: Whampoa Group to invest $140m via VC fund for digital assets
summary: Whampoa Group, a Singapore-based multi-family office, plans to invest $140 million through a venture capital fund in digital assets, primarily in start-ups in the Web3 segment. The fund, expected to be launched next quarter, will focus on mass adoption of Web3 products and services. Whampoa Digital, the group's digital assets arm, will invest in and incubate early-stage start-ups, initially deploying $100 million, with plans to scale up. The investment aims to capitalize on the growing demand for Web3 solutions in Southeast Asia, where demographics and high Internet penetration create a fertile ground for mass adoption.

site_title: Hudspeth to build on podium finish
summary: Singapore driver Sean Hudspeth achieved a podium finish at the Barcelona leg of the European Le Mans Series, exactly a year after breaking his ankle and tearing a ligament. Hudspeth, who had to undergo two operations, returned to racing with his JMW Motorsport teammates, coming in third in the LMGTE class. The achievement marked a significant comeback for the 28-year-old, who is now hungry for more with two races left, with his ultimate goal of competing in the 24 Hours of Le Mans.

site_title: Company Briefs : Toyota Ninja Van Oxley
summary: Toyota has reached a potential $150 million settlement to resolve US class-action litigation over recalls of 3.36 million vehicles due to defective fuel pumps. The settlement covers owners of Toyota and Lexus models from 2013-2020. Meanwhile, Ninja Van is investing $50 million in automation systems for parcel processing, aiming for a 50% productivity improvement in South-east Asia by 2024. Oxley Holdings is proposing a dividend in specie of Aspen shares, with shareholders receiving 23 shares for every 1,000 held, representing about 9.4% of Aspen's total issued shares.

site_title: S'pore shares end 0.9% higher as investors price in rate hikes
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.9% to 3,262.95, driven by regional bourses' gains after Wall Street's 0.6% increase. Despite hawkish US Federal Reserve sentiments, investors priced in rate hikes, with Japan's Nikkei 225 and Australia's stocks also rising. Hong Kong's Hang Seng advanced 2.7% after a week of decline. Top performer Yangzijiang Shipbuilding gained 3.9%, while Sembcorp Industries and Sats were the only two STI constituents in the negative zone.

site_title: Red Bull looking forward to spoil Ferrari's homecoming
summary: Red Bull's Max Verstappen is set to spoil Ferrari's homecoming at the 100th anniversary Monza circuit, despite being hit with a five-place grid penalty for exceeding his engine allocation. Verstappen aims for his fifth consecutive win to take his tally to 11 victories from 16 races, but the penalty may hinder his chances. Ferrari's Charles Leclerc and teammate Carlos Sainz will also face stiff competition from Verstappen, who believes Red Bull's car is efficient at medium downforce levels, making Monza a favorable circuit for them.

site_title: DBS enters metaverse in tie-up with The Sandbox
summary: DBS Bank is launching a metaverse virtual world called DBS BetterWorld, in partnership with The Sandbox. The platform will be accessible to the public for free and will feature immersive elements, including buildings, plants, and animals. The bank aims to showcase its commitment to sustainability and social responsibility, and will use the platform to profile social entrepreneurs and promote eco-conscious living. DBS is the first Singapore company to partner The Sandbox, and the first local bank to enter the metaverse. The platform is expected to launch next year, when The Sandbox fully launches its metaverse.

site_title: Citigroup wins appeal over mistaken $704m transfer to Revlon
summary: A US appeals court ruled in favor of Citigroup, rejecting a decision that Revlon creditors could keep $504 million mistakenly transferred by the bank in 2020. The court overturned a trial court's decision, stating that lenders were not entitled to the funds. Citigroup had described the mistake as a "massive unforced error" and had taken steps to automate manual processes. The ruling provides stability and upholds the concept of cooperation in the syndicated lending market, resolving a bitter battle between Revlon and its creditors.

site_title: A run for everyone
summary: The Great Singapore Run is a 107km footrace spanning from Jurong Lake Gardens to Mount Faber, offering various routes for ultramarathoners and beginners. Four mini routes are available: nature trail, city run, coastal run, and beachside run. The event allows participants to explore Singapore's biodiversity, cityscape, and coastline while keeping fit. Registration is available, and the run is suitable for runners of all levels.

site_title: Lin on a roll after the rain with 'lots of putts'
summary: Lin Xiyu of China took the lead at the inaugural Kroger Queen City Championship with an eight-under 64 after one round at Kenwood Country Club in Cincinnati. She birdied six of her first nine holes, including all four par-three holes, and made "lots of putts" despite playing only nine practice holes due to rain. Lin leads Japan's Nasa Hataoka by one shot and Australia's Sarah Kemp and South Korea's Kim A-lim by two. The event continues on Friday.

site_title: Porsche's return to Formula One fails
summary: Porsche's negotiations with Red Bull for a Formula One partnership have failed, with both companies concluding that a deal cannot be reached. The talks involved Porsche buying a 50% stake in Red Bull's F1 team and becoming engine suppliers. Porsche remains interested in a future entry into F1, but will continue to observe the motor racing field, which it considers an attractive environment. The failure may be due to Red Bull's desire to maintain independence, a key strength of the team. Porsche's alternatives are limited, with McLaren and Williams ruling out a takeover.

site_title: Sky Field has the class edge
summary: In Sunday's Hong Kong (Sha Tin) racing, Sky Field is expected to have a significant class edge as a Group 1 winner, with a significant impost. He faces stiff competition in Race 4, with Trillion Win and Lucky Sweynesse also in contention. Meanwhile, in other races, Sparkling Dolphin is set to fire first-up in Race 5, and Circuit Stellar is a strong contender in Race 10. The Hong Kong Jockey Club notes that several horses have improved between terms, including Brilliant Life and Wide Blue Yonder.

site_title: Sports World
summary: The Jacksonville Jaguars secured their first win in seven games with a 3-1 victory over Balestier Khalsa in the Singapore Premier League. The Dallas Cowboys were named the world's most valuable sports team for a seventh consecutive year, valued at $8 billion. A backstage scuffle broke out at the UFC 279 press conference in Las Vegas, with Ultimate Fighting Championship president Dana White left fuming.

site_title: Singapore to host study visits for minority Muslim communities to exchange ideas
summary: Singapore will host study visits for minority Muslim communities from countries where Muslims are a minority, under the Singapore Cooperation Programme. The Rahmatan Lil Alamin Foundation, set up in 2009, will organize the visits to promote mutual exchange of ideas and practices. The goal is to develop successful minority Muslim communities globally and boost cooperation. Minister-in-charge of Muslim Affairs Masagos Zulkifli emphasized the importance of empowering minority Muslim communities to make their own decisions, citing Singapore's experience during the Covid-19 pandemic in reconciling science and faith.

site_title: After Celavi, life goes on
summary: Singapore trainer Michael Clements reflected on his team's disappointing performance in the Korea Sprint, citing the track's pure sand surface and timing issues as the main causes. Clements admitted that he may have made a mistake by sending his horse Celavi to Korea, but noted that the experience was valuable in planning for future races. Celavi will now take a four-to-five-week break before returning to training for the Merlion Trophy on February 4. Clements has set his sights on the Group 1 Queen Elizabeth II Cup and Singapore Gold Cup, targeting his top horses Spirit Of Big Bang and Tangible for these prestigious events.

site_title: Trio of stars shine brightest in Zurich
summary: Armand Duplantis, Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce, and Noah Lyles dominated the Diamond League final in Zurich, setting meet records in their respective events. Duplantis won the pole vault with a 6.07m jump, Fraser-Pryce set a 10.65-second record in the women's 100m, and Lyles broke the 200m meet record with a 19.52-second victory. The event featured 19 Olympic champions, 21 world champions, and 20 European champions, with top athletes competing for the Diamond Trophy and $30,000 in prize money.

site_title: Next 24 hours
summary: The next 24 hours feature various sports events and activities. Cycling fans can watch Stage 20 of La Vuelta on Singtel TV Ch116 at 6:15pm. The English Premier League has been postponed as a mark of respect for Queen Elizabeth II's passing. In Singapore, Tampines will face Lion City Sailors and Albirex will face Young Lions in the Singapore Premier League. The Spanish Primera Liga will also continue with matches starting at 7:55pm. Additionally, golfers can watch the Asian Tour's Shinhan Donghae Open on StarHub Ch204, while Formula One fans will watch the Italian Grand Prix practice and qualifying.

site_title: Record 8th world title for surfer Gilmore
summary: Stephanie Gilmore won her eighth world surfing title, becoming the most successful woman surfer in history, defeating Carissa Moore in the California finals. Gilmore, 34, finished fifth in the regular season but won heats against top competitors to reach the title match. She described the win as "freaking cool" and credited the pressure of the format for her success. On the men's side, Filipe Toledo won his maiden world title, beating Italo Ferreira to cement his reputation as the world's best small-wave surfer.

site_title: Safe sport panel named
summary: Singapore's Safe Sport Commission has named its first 18-member disciplinary panel to handle moderate to severe cases of misconduct under the Safe Sport Programme. The panel, led by senior counsel Molly Lim, comprises athletes, officials, coaches, and lawyers, and will assess allegations of breaches of the unified code and determine sanctions. The commission aims to provide a safe and fair environment for sports participants, with the goal of preventing abuse and harassment. The panel will consider factors such as culpability, harm caused, and aggravating and mitigating factors before deciding on measures or sanctions.

site_title: A 'very tough' final for both
summary: Tunisian Ons Jabeur advanced to the US Open women's singles final after defeating Caroline Garcia 6-1, 6-3 in a 66-minute match. Jabeur, the world No. 5, is seeking her first Major title victory and is also making history as the first Arab and African woman to reach a US Open singles final. She will face Iga Swiatek, the world No. 1, in the final, with Jabeur seeking revenge after Swiatek's win over her in the Rome final earlier this year.

site_title: Sinclair suspended over controversial tweet
summary: Former Manchester City and West Ham footballer Trevor Sinclair was suspended after a tweet sparked outrage over his comments on Queen Elizabeth II's death. Sinclair claimed there was no reason for black and Asian people in Britain to pay tribute to the 96-year-old monarch, sparking a backlash from sporting figures. Sinclair's management agency condemned his views, and TalkSport suspended him until further notice. This is not Sinclair's first controversy, as he was previously fired from his pundit role by the BBC for racially abusing a police officer in 2018.

site_title: Olympics: Full faith in French police for Paris 2024, says IOC
summary: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) expressed full faith in French police for securing the Paris 2024 Summer Olympics, citing lessons learned from the delayed Champions League final in May. The chaotic event, marred by tear gas and delayed entry, led to French authorities acknowledging police were caught off-guard by local troublemakers. IOC President Thomas Bach praised the French security authorities, stating they had drawn the right conclusions from the incidents and enjoy the IOC's full confidence. The Paris Olympics are expected to attract 600,000 spectators in the opening ceremony, a major security operation in itself.

site_title: Football: Barcelona transform finances despite spree, Liga figures show
summary: Barcelona has transformed its finances after a summer transfer spree, lifting its salary cap from minus €144.3 million to €656.4 million. The club spent €153 million on transfer fees, but generated more revenue by selling 25% of domestic TV rights for €400 million and 50% of Barca Studios for €200 million. Real Madrid remains at the top with a cap of €683.4 million, while Atletico Madrid and Sevilla follow closely. The significant gap between the richest clubs and the rest highlights the disparity in the Spanish league's financial landscape.

site_title: Mile may well be what Willow's Wish wants
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Sunday's South Africa (Scottsville) racing analysis focuses on key form trends and potential winners. Race 1's debutants ASIYE PHAMBILI and MISSION ROCKS are worth following, while ISN'T SHE BONNY and ROY'S CAVIAR are expected to perform well in Race 2. In Race 3, SHANTA'S PRIDE and KITTYBOYS GIRL are contenders, and FASHIONIGMA is a strong pick in Race 4. Other notable performances are expected from WILLOW'S WISH, MASTER OF DESTINY, and HEY BILL in their respective races. The article provides insights into the best bets and potential winners for each event.

site_title: Compromise, expanding common space key to keeping society united: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of compromise and expanding common space to keep society united. He noted that minority communities have maintained trust with the majority Chinese community and that everyone understands the need to respect each other's interests. Lee highlighted Singapore's efforts to uphold equality and safeguard minority rights, and encouraged institutions and religious scholars to work together to build a multiracial and multi-religious nation. He also stressed the need for majority groups to adopt an attitude of compromise and accommodation, and for minority groups to participate fully in the economic and social life of the country.

site_title: Formula One: Verstappen handed five-place grid penalty at Italian GP
summary: Max Verstappen has been handed a five-place grid penalty for the Italian Grand Prix after exceeding his engine allocation. The penalty affects championship leader Verstappen, as well as teammate Sergio Perez, Lewis Hamilton, Carlos Sainz, Valtteri Bottas, and Yuki Tsunoda. Verstappen, 109 points ahead in the standings, is still favored to win his second straight world title. The grid penalties will impact the starting positions for the Italian Grand Prix.

site_title: Lewy aims to capitalise on Benzema's absence
summary: Real Madrid will face Barcelona without injured Karim Benzema, who is expected to be out for at least a month. This absence could allow Robert Lewandowski to solidify his position at the top of La Liga's scoring charts, as he already leads the league with five goals. Barcelona, who have scored 16 times in four games, are set to face struggling Cadiz on Saturday, providing Lewandowski with opportunities to extend his hot form. Barcelona boss Xavi Hernandez praises Lewandowski for his maturity and scoring ability, saying he makes the team better.

site_title: Motor sports: Singapore's Sean Hudspeth wants to build on European Le Mans Series podium finish
summary: Singaporean motor sports driver Sean Hudspeth achieved a significant milestone by finishing third at the European Le Mans Series' Barcelona leg, exactly a year after breaking his ankle and tearing a ligament. The 28-year-old's determination and hard work paid off after a tough year of recovery. Despite still being 5% fit, Hudspeth expressed his satisfaction and emotional response to the podium finish, which he attributes to his team's efforts and his own perseverance. He now sets his sights on the next two races, aiming to improve himself and potentially compete in the 24 Hours of Le Mans.

site_title: LIV golfers under a cloud in London
summary: The BMW PGA Championship at Wentworth was marred by the presence of 17 LIV Golf players, including Rory McIlroy, who criticized his former Ryder Cup colleagues for joining the Saudi-backed series. England's Tommy Fleetwood led the field with an 8-under 64, while McIlroy shot a 68. The tournament was suspended early due to the death of Queen Elizabeth and will restart as a 54-hole event on Saturday. The LIV Golf players, including Bernd Wiesberger and Abraham Ancer, were met with tension and criticism from the DP World Tour players and officials, who have not followed the PGA Tour's stance on suspending players who joined LIV Golf.

site_title: Formula One: Sainz ensures Ferrari top times again in Italian GP practice
summary: Carlos Sainz secured Ferrari's top times in both practice sessions at the Italian Grand Prix, finishing 0.143 seconds ahead of Max Verstappen. Verstappen, seeking his first win at Monza, faces a five-place grid penalty for his fifth engine of the season. Sainz's teammate Charles Leclerc finished third, while Verstappen's teammate Sergio Perez and Lewis Hamilton also received penalties. The session was preceded by a minute's silence for Queen Elizabeth II's passing, with a further minute's silence scheduled for Sunday's race.

site_title: Returning Red Devils provide little spark
summary: Manchester United lost 1-0 to Real Sociedad in their Europa League opener, with Lisandro Martinez being penalized for handball in the 59th minute. The Red Devils struggled to create scoring opportunities, despite fielding a strong side. Meanwhile, Arsenal bounced back from their first defeat of the season with a 2-1 win over FC Zurich, with Brazilian teenager Marquinhos scoring on his debut.
