site_title: Football: PSG considering legal action against troublemakers after Nice v Cologne violence
summary: Paris Saint-Germain (PSG) is considering legal action against its supporters who were involved in violent crowd trouble in Nice ahead of a Europa Conference League match. One of the PSG supporters, identified as a former member of the dissolved Supras Auteuil group, was in critical condition after falling off a stand. The club condemned the violence and stated that it would take action against those responsible, as the Supras Auteuil group is banned from entering the Parc des Princes.

site_title: EPL games postponed to honour queen
summary: The English Premier League has postponed all matches this weekend as a mark of respect following the death of Queen Elizabeth II, despite official guidance stating there was no obligation to do so. The decision was made by the 20 Premier League clubs to pay tribute to the 96-year-old monarch and to honor her extraordinary life and contribution to the nation. The postponements will create fixture congestion later in the season, but are seen as a necessary gesture of respect during the 10-day national mourning period.

site_title: SMRT ties up with S'pore's five polytechnics to boost home-grown talent pipeline
summary: SMRT, Singapore's public transport operator, has tied up with five polytechnics to boost the pipeline of home-grown engineers, programmers, and specialists. The partnership aims to cultivate talent to support the growing MRT system, which is expected to reach 360km by the early 2030s. The agreement includes opportunities for polytechnic lecturers to work with SMRT, internships, and full-time job offers to 40% of interns from polytechnics. The move is part of efforts to recruit and develop workers to meet industry needs, with 1,500 jobs expected to be created from the Thomson-East Coast Line by 2025.

site_title: The Great Singapore Run | The Straits Times
summary: The Great Singapore Run is a 107km footrace spanning from Jurong Lake Gardens to Mount Faber, offering four mini routes for varying levels of experience. The routes include a nature trail, coastal run, beachside run, and city run, featuring scenic views of Singapore's parks, reservoirs, and cityscape. Safety tips for runners include taking precautions for health, hydration, and visibility, especially at night or in unfamiliar areas. The event aims to promote a fun and safe running experience for participants of all levels.

site_title: Football: Mathias Pogba denies involvement in extortion of brother Paul
summary: Mathias Pogba denies involvement in the extortion of his brother Paul, a World Cup-winning footballer, according to his lawyer. Paul claims gangsters are blackmailing him, demanding large sums of money to avoid the release of compromising videos. Mathias published a video promising "great revelations" about Paul, fueling speculation, but denies any involvement in the alleged extortion. Two investigating magistrates are leading the probe, examining allegations of blackmail, kidnapping, and membership in a criminal conspiracy.

site_title: Football: English Premier League fixtures postponed after Queen Elizabeth's death
summary: The English Premier League and English Football League postponed all fixtures from September 9-11 as a mark of respect following the death of Queen Elizabeth II. However, cricket and rugby matches were allowed to proceed as planned this weekend. The decision was made by the Football Association, with Premier League chief executive officer Richard Masters paying tribute to the queen's long service to the country. Other sports, including golf, cricket, and rugby, also observed a minute's silence or cancelled events in respect.

site_title: Ex-Eu Yan Sang chairman Richard Eu Keng Mun dies at 99, hailed for service to society
summary: Dr. Richard Eu Keng Mun, the 99-year-old former chairman of Eu Yan Sang Holdings, has died of old age. He was remembered by his family and friends for his values of relationships, generosity, and service to society. Eu was a philanthropist, founding chairman of the Singapore Institute of Management, and vice-chairman of United Overseas Bank. He was also a foodie who enjoyed trying various cuisines, and was known for his kindness and humility. The Eu Yan Sang legacy will continue, with donations made in his name supporting education and charitable causes.

site_title: Football: Former United midfielder Mata joins Galatasaray on two-year deal
summary: Former Manchester United midfielder Juan Mata has joined Turkish football powerhouse Galatasaray on a two-year contract worth €1.9 million. The deal includes an optional second year. Mata, 34, made 285 appearances for United, winning several titles, but struggled to maintain his form after moving from Chelsea in 2014. Galatasaray also announced signing Argentinian striker Mauro Icardi on loan for the 2022-23 season, following the signing of Uruguay midfielder Lucas Torreira last month.

site_title: Surfing: Australia's Gilmore wins record eighth world title
summary: Stephanie Gilmore won her record eighth world surfing title, becoming the most successful woman surfer in history, after defeating 2019 and 2021 champion Carissa Moore in a one-day winner-takes-all finals at Lower Trestles in San Clemente, California. Gilmore, 34, finished fifth in the regular season and won heats against top surfers to secure the title. She credited the finals format for the pressure and excitement, saying it was "freaking cool" to beat Moore. Gilmore's win cements her place as the most successful female surfer, surpassing Layne Beachley's seven titles.

site_title: S'pore seniors showed resilience in managing Covid-19 pandemic stressors: NUHS study
summary: A new study by the National University Health System (NUHS) in Singapore found that older adults showed resilience in managing the emotional and physical impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite initial fears, seniors demonstrated a strong sense of independence and initiative in maintaining their well-being, thanks to support from family and community service providers. The study, which interviewed 62 seniors aged 65-84, highlighted the importance of social and emotional support, as well as practical resources, in helping seniors cope with the pandemic.

site_title: 'A baptism of fire': NMPs share their experiences in new book
summary: Former Singaporean Nominated Members of Parliament (NMPs) share their experiences in a new book, detailing their stints in Parliament and the impact they had on debates. The book, edited by Ms Anthea Ong, features 20 NMPs who recount personal reflections, analyses, and anecdotes about their time in office. Launched by Emeritus Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong, the book highlights the NMP scheme's role in strengthening democracy and increasing parliamentary inclusivity, with NMPs able to raise issues without worrying about winning votes. The book aims to educate Singaporeans about the NMP scheme and inspire conversations about the country's political future.

site_title: Some NTUC-OCBC cardholders not eligible to switch to new digital bank's credit card
summary: Some NTUC-OCBC cardholders in Singapore are not eligible to switch to the new digital bank's credit card due to the phasing out of co-branded cards and accounts by January 31, 2023. The move aims to transition users to the new digital bank, but some cardholders, like retired banker Mike Tay, may be affected. The affected cardholders will lose access to benefits like earning and redeeming Linkpoints at FairPrice. The change is part of the digital bank's efforts to modernize the financial system and cater to underserved populations.

site_title: 4 weeks' jail for man who used co-worker's TraceTogether token, tried to bribe him to flee Singapore
summary: A 27-year-old Chinese national, Yang Fei, was sentenced to 4 weeks' jail for using his co-worker's TraceTogether token to gain access to malls and trying to bribe his co-worker to flee Singapore to Malaysia. Yang, who was vaccinated against Covid-19 in China but had not updated his vaccination records in Singapore, was found guilty of committing an act with a tendency to obstruct the course of justice. The court heard that Yang attempted to bribe his co-worker with $100 and cigarettes to escape, but was thwarted when his co-worker recorded their conversation and reported him to the police.

site_title: Table tennis: World team championships at 'full steam' in locked-down Chinese city
summary: Table tennis world team championships are set to take place in Chengdu, China, despite the city being under lockdown due to Covid-19 cases. The tournament, starting Sept 30 and ending Oct 9, will be held in a "closed-loop" bubble with around 1,000 people, including 300 players. This is the first international sports event in China since the Beijing Winter Olympics and Paralympics in February and March. The ITTF is confident in their plans and has successfully implemented a closed-loop management system in the past. The event aims to deliver a great experience for participants.

site_title: Athletes, coaches and lawyers for Safe Sport Commission's first disciplinary panel
summary: Singapore's Safe Sport Commission has announced its first disciplinary panel to handle moderate to severe cases of misconduct in member organizations under the Safe Sport Programme. The 18-member panel, led by senior counsel Molly Lim, includes athletes, coaches, and sports officials. The panel will assess allegations of breaches of the Unified Code, which was launched in November 2022, and determine the severity of misconduct based on culpability and harm caused. The panel will also consider aggravating and mitigating factors before deciding on measures or sanctions. The creation of the panel aims to provide a fair and independent channel for resolution to ensure cases are handled fairly and provide a safe sporting environment.

images.alt_text: SMEs will receive a higher level of support, while larger companies will be eligible for a smaller quantum.
Recycling air conditioners is crucial because they contain refrigerants such as hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), which can have a significant environmental impact if not properly recovered.
CMG20250710-LooHH01 / 特约摄影骆辉煌 / KTPH trials new “smart diapers” to improve patient care Ward B76, Khoo Teck Puat Hospital [Ward B76, Khoo Teck Puat Hospital]
Those found guilty of trafficking more than 500g of cannabis, or more than 1kg of cannabis mixture, may face the death penalty.
Singapore's artistic swimmers with Ollie the Otter and Dewey the Dugong, mascots for the World Aquatics Championships Singapore 2025.
US President Donald Trump’s nominee for ambassador to Singapore, Dr Anjani Sinha (left), was grilled by Senator for Illinois Tammy Duckworth during a Senate confirmation hearing.
With the help of local tech firm NCS, the CPF Board is currently piloting a feature that can identify callers who are less tech-savvy and prioritises them to reach a call agent faster.

site_title: HDB ex-director jailed after taking videos of naked men at places including locker rooms
summary: A former Housing Board (HDB) director, Leo Norman Chee Wei Kiong, was sentenced to two weeks' jail and a fine of $31,600 for unlawfully recording videos of naked men in public places, including locker rooms. Chee, 61, pleaded guilty to six charges and had 146 obscene films on his phone. He used his mobile phone to film men in gyms and changing rooms, including a man who caught him and reported him to the police. Chee resigned from HDB to avoid embarrassment.

site_title: Activist Jolovan Wham chooses to serve 15-day jail term in lieu of fine over assembly outside State Courts
summary: Activist Jolovan Wham, 42, served a 15-day jail term in lieu of a $3,000 fine after being found guilty of holding a one-person assembly outside the former State Courts building in December 2018. Wham's lawyer argued that his actions did not fall under the definition of an assembly under the Public Order Act, citing the law's over-inclusiveness. However, the High Court dismissed his appeal, with the deputy attorney-general arguing that the permit scheme aimed to prevent public disorder and that Wham's actions were not serious.

site_title: 7 weeks' jail for 2nd ex-prison officer who shared inmates' information with prisoner
summary: A Singapore prison officer, Muhammad Zul Helmy Abdul Latip, was sentenced to 7 weeks' jail for sharing classified inmate information with a fellow prisoner, Abdul Karim Mohamed Kuppai Khan. Zul, a former Sergeant 2, accessed the Prison Operations Rehabilitation System II (Ports II) and shared information including an inmate's age and a prisoner's girlfriend's contact number. This is the second case involving a former prison officer, following Muhammad Fattahullah Mohd Nordin's 10-week sentence for similar offenses.

site_title: Covid-19 galvanised people to step up, help one another: President Halimah
summary: President Halimah Yacob said Covid-19 galvanized people to step up and help one another, despite the pandemic's negative impact on businesses and individuals. Support for those in need and charitable causes increased, with over 82,000 volunteers contributing to the President's Challenge Volunteer Drive over the past decade. The drive, launched in 2012, aims to support low-income families, and its focus this year is on providing essential skills training and services. Halimah praised volunteers for their efforts in helping seniors, people with disabilities, and low-income families, calling it a key factor in building a cohesive society.

site_title: Stepping up engagements and having a tarik-fic time: What politicians are up to this week
summary: Singaporean politicians have been stepping up their engagement with the public, with many attending community events and selling party newsletters. The Workers' Party (WP) and Progress Singapore Party (PSP) distributed mooncakes and newsletters, while People's Action Party (PAP) MPs resumed activities halted during the pandemic. Meanwhile, Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong and Minister Baey Yam Keng showcased their love for "teh tarik" tea, a Malaysian drink. The tea diplomacy was met with positivity, with Wong and Malaysian Finance Minister Tengku Zafrul Aziz bonding over the drink and even playing guitars together. However, some politicians, like former Ang Mo Kio GRC MP Ang Hin Kee, expressed concerns about the growing use of cannabis, with Singapore's laws on the subject remaining unchanged.

site_title: Irish beef, lamb to hit shelves in S'pore as Ireland looks to become strong food trade partner
summary: Ireland is expanding its food trade presence in Singapore, with Irish beef and lamb now available in retail stores, following the successful introduction of Irish ducks. The move comes after a trade mission to South-east Asia and Japan led by Ireland's Minister for Agriculture, Food and Marine. Ireland aims to increase its food exports to Singapore to €800 million by 2025, driven by the dairy and meat sectors. The country's sustainable food production and low reliance on grain and feed prices are seen as key advantages in the market.

site_title: Formula One: Porsche says talks with Red Bull to enter the sport have failed
summary: Porsche announced that talks with Red Bull to form a partnership involving a 50% stake purchase and engine supply have failed. The deal, which would have allowed Porsche to re-enter Formula One, was seen as imminent after Audi's announcement as an engine supplier for the 2026 season. Porsche cited the inability to achieve an equal partnership as the reason for the failure, but stated the company will continue to observe the racing field, which remains an attractive environment. Porsche previously competed in F1 from 1957-62 and 1983-91, winning two constructors championships.

site_title: SIA flight from Paris to S'pore diverted to Azerbaijan after oil leak detected in engine
summary: A Singapore Airlines flight from Paris to Singapore was diverted to Azerbaijan on Friday morning after an oil leak was detected in one of its engines. The Boeing 777 aircraft, carrying 229 passengers and 18 crew, left Paris at 11:20pm on Thursday and was due to arrive in Singapore at 5:30pm. The plane landed safely at Baku airport at 6:35am, and all passengers disembarked normally. The airline provided meals, hotel accommodation, and a relief flight to ferry the affected customers and crew back to Singapore, prioritizing safety and customer confidentiality.

site_title: Sea's Shopee shuts operations in Argentina, Chile, Colombia, Mexico: Sources
summary: Sea's e-commerce arm Shopee is shutting local operations in Chile, Colombia, and Mexico, while maintaining a cross-border model in these countries. This decision comes as the company faces growing pressure to cut costs and achieve profitability, amid slowing e-commerce growth and rising interest rates. Shopee will also close its operations in Argentina entirely, affecting dozens of employees. The move is part of a broader effort to focus on core operations and concentrate resources in its most profitable markets, including Brazil.

site_title: As crises mount, Europe turns once again to big spending, throws vast sums at energy crunch
summary: European governments are increasing spending to address the energy crisis, with over $350 billion earmarked to subsidize consumers, industry, and utility companies. This is in addition to a nearly trillion-dollar stimulus package adopted over the past year. The move is a significant shift from the EU's previous neoliberal stance, with leaders opting for interventionist policies to mitigate the impact of reduced Russian gas supplies. The goal is to contain the crisis, build public support, and prevent social unrest and economic meltdown.

site_title: India's top conglomerate Tata in talks to join club of iPhone makers
summary: Tata Group, India's top conglomerate, is in talks with Taiwanese supplier Wistron Corp to establish an electronics manufacturing joint venture in India, aiming to assemble iPhones. If successful, it would be the first Indian company to build iPhones, boosting the country's effort to challenge China's dominance in electronics manufacturing. The deal could also persuade other global brands to consider assembly in India, reducing reliance on China amidst increasing geopolitical risks. Talks are ongoing, with the structure and details yet to be finalized.

site_title: Russian man jailed four months for forging document to delay repaying $1.7m loan
summary: A 54-year-old Russian permanent resident, Dmitriy Shport, was sentenced to four months in jail for forging a document to delay repaying a $1.7 million loan to his friend, Irina Sergeva. Shport created a fake option to purchase (OTP) document to convince Sergeva that he had sold his condominium unit and had the funds to pay her. However, the sale actually occurred in 2017, and Shport used the funds to pay off other debts. Shport pleaded guilty and accepted responsibility for his actions, saying it was a "foolish act."

site_title: 717 complaints against businesses in beauty industry in first six months of 2022: Case
summary: The Consumers Association of Singapore (CASE) reported 717 complaints against businesses in the beauty industry in the first six months of 2022. Most complaints centered on misleading or false claims, undue pressure, and non-utilization of packages due to sudden insolvency. One case, involving a free manicure and pedicure voucher, resulted in the customer paying over $3,000 after being subjected to aggressive sales tactics by staff.

site_title: Ex-president Ong Teng Cheong's son took former sister-in-law to court after much deliberation, heartache: Lawyer
summary: Former Singapore president Ong Teng Cheong's son, Ong Tze Guan, has filed court applications to wind up two family companies, O&O Capital and Wang Investment, which his former sister-in-law Madam Wang Yi Yi was a co-shareholder and co-director in. This move comes after years of disagreements over company management. The applications were filed on August 17. The outcome of the court cases is uncertain, but the goal is to part ways with Madam Wang Yi Yi.

site_title: More fresh graduates from SIT find full-time work, receive higher pay than before pandemic
summary: Singapore Institute of Technology (SIT) graduates achieved a 95.6% employment rate within six months of graduation, exceeding pre-pandemic levels. 86% of the 2021 cohort secured full-time permanent jobs, with median gross monthly salaries surpassing pre-pandemic levels. ICT graduates earned the highest median monthly salaries, with software engineering graduates earning $5,000. The employment outcomes show significant recovery for graduates in tourism and built environment sectors impacted by Covid-19, with more securing full-time work.

site_title: Citigroup's $708m blunder ends in victory for the bank
summary: A US appeals court rejected a ruling allowing Revlon creditors to keep over half a billion US dollars mistakenly wired by Citigroup in 2020. The court overturned a trial court's decision, citing a "massive unforced error" by the bank. Citigroup CEO Jane Fraser called it a mistake that needed to be automated, and the bank's main banking unit welcomed the decision as a victory. The ruling may require lenders who received the mistaken funds to return them, resolving the issue and allowing Revlon's bankruptcy to move forward.

site_title: Golf: China's Lin Xiyu leads inaugural Kroger Queen City Championship
summary: China's Lin Xiyu leads the inaugural Kroger Queen City Championship after shooting an 8-under 64 in the first round. Lin birdied six of her first nine holes and got away with just one bogey. She leads Japan's Nasa Hataoka by one shot, with Australia's Sarah Kemp and South Korea's Kim A Lim two shots back. The 26-year-old attributed her success to the course's rolling greens, saying "the green was actually rolling like really, really, really good".

site_title: DBS enters metaverse in tie-up with The Sandbox to create virtual BetterWorld
summary: DBS Bank has partnered with The Sandbox to create a metaverse virtual world called DBS BetterWorld, a sustainable and immersive environment where users can build a better world. DBS will acquire a 3x3 plot of virtual land, which will be developed with interactive elements like buildings, plants, and animals. The platform will be accessible to the public, including non-DBS customers, and will focus on environmental, social, and governance (ESG) issues, with the goal of promoting positive impact and community engagement.

site_title: Queen Elizabeth's kindness won the hearts of S'poreans: President Halimah, PM Lee send condolences
summary: President Halimah Yacob and Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong of Singapore have sent condolences to King Charles III and British Prime Minister Elizabeth Truss following the death of Queen Elizabeth II. The Queen, who reigned for 70 years, was greatly loved by Singaporeans, who remembered her kindness and warmth during her three visits to the country in 1972, 1989, and 2006. The Singaporean leaders praised the Queen's dedication to service, her role as a symbol of hope and stability, and her contributions to the Commonwealth and world affairs.

site_title: China’s inflation slowdown fuels calls for more policy stimulus
summary: China's consumer price index rose 2.5% in August, down from 2.7% in July, as sporadic Covid-19 lockdowns and falling commodity prices suppressed spending. The producer price index slowed to 2.3% from 4.2% in July. The slowdown gives policymakers room to support the economy if needed, with some economists calling for further easing of monetary policy to stabilize growth. However, a weaker renminbi complicates the picture, and most economists expect no interest rate cut next week, with other policy options, including a cut to the reserve requirement ratio, remaining on the table.

site_title: India curbs rice exports to calm local prices, but move could fuel global food inflation
summary: India has imposed a 20% duty on exports of white and brown rice and banned the sale of broken rice abroad, affecting around 60% of its rice shipments. The move is expected to boost global rice prices, potentially exacerbating food inflation and hunger in countries already struggling with these issues. This is the third major agricultural commodity in India to face export restrictions this year, following wheat and sugar. The restrictions are likely to benefit rival suppliers Thailand and Vietnam, which are cooperating to increase rice prices.

site_title: EY plans to spin off audit, consulting units to ease regulatory concerns
summary: EY plans to split its audit and consulting units into two companies to address regulatory concerns over potential conflicts of interest. The move is expected to conclude in early 2023 if ratified by 13,000 partners. The split will allow for more choice in the market and result in better opportunities for employees. EY's record revenue for the most recent financial year is US$45.4 billion, up 13.5% from the previous year. The move follows pressure from regulators, including the UK's Financial Reporting Council, and comes as the Big Four firms face scrutiny over their advisory services.

site_title: Twitter paid whistle-blower $9.8m for silence, says lawyer for Elon Musk
summary: Elon Musk's lawyer revealed that Twitter paid whistle-blower Peiter Zatko $7 million to secure his silence, according to a Sept 6 hearing in the lawsuit over Musk's attempt to cancel a $44 billion Twitter purchase. Zatko had raised concerns about operational problems, including the number of bots embedded in Twitter's customer base. The payment was part of a settlement related to Zatko's lost compensation after leaving Twitter, allowing him to act as a government whistle-blower. The case is set to go to trial in October.

site_title: Highlights of Queen Elizabeth's 3 visits to Singapore
summary: Queen Elizabeth II visited Singapore three times: in 1972, 1989, and 2006. During her first visit in 1972, she toured the National Orchid Garden and visited Toa Payoh, where she spent time in a resident's kitchen. In 1989, she attended a state banquet and visited the Kranji War Memorial. Her final visit in 2006 included a visit to the Toa Payoh HDB estate, where she met residents and was served a drink from the same glass she had used 34 years earlier.

site_title: Wall Street shares close higher despite tough Fed talk
summary: US shares closed higher on Thursday, rebounding from early losses after the European Central Bank's largest rate hike and the US Federal Reserve's hawkish comments. The ECB raised interest rates by 75 basis points, while Fed chairman Jerome Powell reaffirmed the need for strong action to combat inflation. Despite tough talk, the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.6%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.7% and 0.6%, respectively. McCormick & Company fell 6.7% after lowering its 2022 earnings forecast.

site_title: IHH Healthcare's $1.8b offer for Ramsay-Sime Darby JV falls through
summary: IHH Healthcare's $1.8 billion offer for its 50-50 joint venture Ramsay-Sime Darby JV has fallen through. The Malaysian healthcare provider had submitted a proposal in March but discussions concluded without a binding agreement. The joint venture operates hospitals in Indonesia and Malaysia, and was planning an initial public offering. IHH's shares rose 0.5% to $1.94 following the news. The decision marks the end of IHH's discussions to fully acquire the joint venture, which had been seen as a strategic opportunity to expand its portfolio.

site_title: Motorists face roadblocks in getting refunds for deactivated Malaysian Touch 'n Go cards
summary: Malaysian Touch 'n Go card holders who have not used their cards in 12 months are facing difficulties in obtaining refunds for their unused balances. Despite the land borders reopening in April, some motorists have been trying to get refunds for five months, highlighting the complexity of the process. The issue has raised concerns among drivers who need to use their cards to enter Malaysia, with some resorting to alternative methods to avoid the hassle of refund applications.

site_title: Pound recovers after fall against US dollar on news of  death of Queen Elizabeth
summary: The pound recovered from a 0.6% fall against the US dollar after Queen Elizabeth II's death, trading up 0.6% at US$1.1578. However, an expert said the Queen's death has "no significant impact" on the pound, as she had little political significance. The euro rose 0.16% against the pound, while the US dollar index fell 0.25% to 109.25. New UK Prime Minister Liz Truss's energy cost reduction measures were seen as the main factor in the pound's recovery.

site_title: Crypto dreams dashed in Thailand as regulators tighten rules
summary: Thailand's efforts to become a leading trading center for digital assets have been derailed due to regulatory tightening following trading irregularities and market collapses. Trading of cryptocurrencies on licensed exchanges plummeted to $2.5 billion in August, the lowest since 2020. The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) plans a working group to enhance supervision, citing investor protection concerns. The market has been hit by global crypto routs, meltdowns of crypto lenders, and a decline in active trading accounts, with some companies experiencing significant losses, including a 80% drop in shares of a cryptocurrency mining company.

site_title: S’pore, UK share 200 years of history, Queen’s death a profound loss: President Halimah
summary: Singapore and the UK share a 200-year history, with Queen Elizabeth II's death marking a profound loss, according to President Halimah Yacob. The Queen, who visited Singapore in 1972 and 1989, was a symbol of unity and dedicated her life to service, leaving a significant mark on Singapore's history and ties with the UK. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong extended condolences to the royal family and British people, describing the Queen as the "heart and soul" of the UK.

site_title: S'pore's Whampoa Group to invest $140.5m via fund for digital assets
summary: Whampoa Group, a Singapore-based multi-family office, plans to invest $140.3 million (S$140.5m) in a venture capital fund focused on digital assets. The fund, led by co-founders Amy Lee and Lee Han Shih, aims to invest in start-ups in the Web3 segment, a utopian vision of the Internet where users own online services. The investment group also plans to raise $50 million for a crypto-related hedge fund, market-neutral to cryptocurrencies' volatility, and has received strong interest from Chinese tech firms and Asian business groups.

site_title: Football: Man Utd lose in Europa League after leading tributes to Britain's Queen
summary: Manchester United lost 1-0 to Real Sociedad in the Europa League after leading tributes to Queen Elizabeth II, who died aged 96. The Premier League teams wore black armbands in respect, with a minute's silence held before kick-off. United's Cristiano Ronaldo and Bruno Fernandes were visibly emotional, while former manager Jose Mourinho paid a sombre tribute to the Queen. The match marked a subdued atmosphere at Old Trafford, with the team acknowledging the Queen's "immense contribution" to public life.

site_title: Highway toll cards hard to purchase since full reopening of land borders
summary: Motorists driving into Malaysia are facing difficulties purchasing highway toll cards, known as Touch 'n Go cards, since the full reopening of land borders. Previously, these cards were available at 7-Eleven convenience stores in Singapore. The issue has affected travelers attempting to cross into Malaysia for leisure or business purposes, highlighting the need for alternative purchasing options or more efficient border reopening processes.

site_title: Why do landslides occur and will there be more in future?
summary: A landslide occurred at the Clementi NorthArc Build-To-Order site in Singapore last Friday. Engineering experts attribute the incident to heavy rain, which is expected to increase in frequency due to projected intense rainfall. As a result, experts warn that more landslides may occur in the future. The factors contributing to the incident are still being investigated.

site_title: Euro slides as Fed chief steals ECB's rate hike thunder
summary: The euro slid to a fresh 20-year dollar low on Thursday, despite the European Central Bank's (ECB) record 0.75 percentage point interest rate hike. ECB chief Christine Lagarde warned of a prolonged period of high inflation, while Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell signaled a tough approach to inflation, seen as more hawkish than Lagarde's comments. The pound also remained close to a 37-year low, with the British currency rising slightly after the death of Queen Elizabeth II.

site_title: Call to continue growing community of young leaders for social cohesion
summary: The S. Rajaratnam School of International Studies (RSIS) launched the Young Leaders Programme, a platform for young leaders to collaborate on initiatives to strengthen social cohesion in Southeast Asia. The 3-day conference highlighted various youth-led initiatives, including immersive virtual tours and interfaith festivals, and emphasized the importance of youth leadership in building a better society. Minister Edwin Tong called for continued support and the regular conduct of the South-east Asian Social Cohesion Radar study to track social cohesion trends in the region.

site_title: S'pore continually looking into multi-faceted issue of disadvantages facing those less well off
summary: Singapore is continually exploring ways to address the multi-faceted disadvantages faced by those less well off, including financial issues, family problems, and incarceration and drug addiction. Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasizes that solutions go beyond financial assistance, requiring a comprehensive approach that involves understanding individual needs and providing wraparound solutions. A family-centric approach is being adopted, with a focus on coordination among government agencies, community groups, and volunteers to provide holistic support. Wong stresses the importance of engaging young people and respecting seniors, encouraging intergenerational connections and learning from shared experiences.

site_title: Sporting events cancelled after Britain's Queen Elizabeth dies
summary: Queen Elizabeth II, Britain's longest-reigning monarch, died peacefully at 96. The death led to cancellations of sporting events, including the second day of the England-South Africa cricket test, the BMW PGA golf championship, and Premiership Rugby Cup game. Other sports, such as soccer, tennis, and motor racing, observed a minute's silence. The British Horseracing Authority suspended all events for two days. Tributes poured in from the sports world, with World Athletics president Sebastian Coe hailing the queen's exceptional leadership and commitment to the 2012 London Olympics.

site_title: Maid-abuse charges against teacher, husband withdrawn
summary: A primary school teacher and her husband, accused of abusing their domestic helper, had their maid-abuse charges withdrawn after 12 days of trial. The charges, filed in 2020, were dismissed due to new evidence that emerged during the trial. The couple, who cannot be charged again with the same offenses, were given a discharge amounting to an acquittal. The teacher, Ms Nachammai Selva Nachiappan, and her husband, Mr Arunachalam Muthiah, expressed relief and gratitude for the support they received.

site_title: McDonald's Pikachu carrier a hot seller
summary: McDonald's released a limited edition Pikachu carrier, a hit with fans, with short queues forming at some restaurants before its 11am launch. The item, priced at $12.90, sold out at multiple outlets by 6pm, with over 300 sets available at most stores. Online listings of the carrier and accompanying Pokémon trading card on Carousell ranged from $30 to $50. The item drew comparisons to McDonald's 2000 Hello Kitty toy promotion, which also sparked collectors' frenzy and long lines.

site_title: Clementi landslide: More parts of park connector to reopen
summary: More parts of the Ulu Pandan park connector in Singapore will reopen on Saturday after a landslide at a Clementi Build-To-Order site. The segments downstream from the incident site will reopen, with flood risks remaining due to the canal's repair. Immediate measures include a 3.5m-wide channel and pumps to improve water flow. Sheet piling works will start this weekend to reinforce the slope, with the stretch upstream from the incident site remaining closed for safety reasons. Monitoring of rain forecasts and water levels will continue to ensure temporary closures of the park connector if necessary.

site_title: New book shows how small states punch above their weight
summary: A new book, "Small States In A Big World: Size Is Not Destiny," edited by Ambassador-at-large Tommy Koh, highlights the success of small countries despite their limited size. The book features 40 essays by 46 authors from 29 small countries, showcasing their achievements in areas such as environmental protection, education, and economy. Small countries have punched above their weight, with many dominating top spots in global rankings, and have formed the Forum of Small States (FOSS) to amplify their collective voice, with 108 members representing a majority of UN membership.

site_title: MinLaw, MHA rebut NGOs' claims about death penalty in Singapore
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Law (MinLaw) and Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) have rebutted NGOs' claims about the death penalty, stating there is no international consensus against capital punishment when imposed according to due process and judicial safeguards. The ministries said Singapore has the right to determine its own criminal justice system, and that the imposition of capital punishment for drug offenses is not a breach of international law. They also refuted claims that cost orders against lawyers obstruct access to justice for death-row inmates, citing examples of successful legal representation and dismissals of frivolous lawsuits.

site_title: Must-reads
summary: A contractor, Le Fong Building Services, has been barred from hiring foreign workers for three months after a worker fell over 8m through a roof due to a broken skylight panel. The US Department of Defense has also halted F-35 jet deliveries due to an alloy made in China. In Singapore, parts of a park connector will reopen after a construction site collapse, and maid-abuse charges against a couple have been withdrawn. Businesses must adopt sustainability to stay relevant, according to Singapore's Minister for Sustainability and the Environment. Insurers face challenges in covering new cancer treatments.

site_title: Tennis: It's Jabeur versus Swiatek in US Open final
summary: Tunisia's Ons Jabeur dominated Caroline Garcia in the US Open semi-finals, becoming the first African woman in history to reach the final. Jabeur won in straight sets, 6-1, 6-3, after breaking Garcia in the opening game. She will face world No. 1 Iga Swiatek in the final, after Swiatek rallied from a set down to beat Aryna Sabalenka. Jabeur, known as Tunisia's "Minister of Happiness," expressed relief and joy at making it to the final, while Swiatek said she will need to be careful against Jabeur's strong hands and baseline game.

site_title: S'pore offers lessons in cyber security, urban design: Nobel laureate
summary: Singapore is being studied by Nobel laureate Professor Paul Romer for its successful approach to cyber security and urban design, with Romer citing the country as a model for effective protection from cyber threats and urban development. Romer, who won the Nobel Prize in economics in 2018, has found Singapore's approach to wage policy and urbanization to be valuable for the world, and he aims to discuss these topics during the upcoming Nobel Prize Dialogue in Singapore.

site_title: Dilemma for insurers following changes to Cancer Drug List
summary: Insurers face a challenge in providing coverage for cancer treatments and drugs not on the Cancer Drug List (CDL) while keeping premiums reasonable. They must develop riders to offer additional options, with proposals expected to be announced by the end of the year, just before the CDL treatment regime changes in April 2023. This will require insurers to balance coverage with affordability.

site_title: HDB resale prices up for 26th month; 33 flats sold for at least $1m
summary: HDB resale flat prices rose for the 26th consecutive month in August, with 33 flats sold for at least $1 million each, according to flash data from real estate portals. The prices increased 10.8% year-on-year and 0.4% month-on-month. The most expensive resale flat sold for $1.35 million. Analysts attribute the rise to a strong economy, increasing household incomes, and HDB upgraders, with more million-dollar resale transactions expected in the coming months.

site_title: S'pore's first cardinal urges unity, harmony in thanksgiving mass
summary: Singapore's first cardinal, Cardinal William Goh, urged unity and harmony in a Thanksgiving Mass, emphasizing the importance of promoting love and unity through inter-religious dialogue and building a more inclusive society. He called on Catholics to join him in these tasks and encouraged the use of their position to influence the world for the better. Cardinal Goh also highlighted the need for cohesion and inclusivity, particularly for marginalized groups, and encouraged Catholics to engage with humanists and secularists to achieve this goal.

site_title: Charities will not need permit to raise funds from 2023
summary: Charities in Singapore will no longer need a police permit to raise funds in public from 2023, reducing administrative burdens. Registered charities and exempt charities, such as universities and hospitals, will need to disclose details of their campaigns on the Charity Portal. The move aims to balance requirements and ensure donors can make informed decisions. Enforcement action may be taken against improper appeals or failure to comply with new disclosure requirements. The change is expected to benefit small charities, but also raises concerns about potential scams.

site_title: What you need to know about travelling to Japan now
summary: Japan has eased travel restrictions, allowing foreign tourists to travel on non-guided tour packages. Travellers must book flights and accommodation in advance with recognized agents, stay in designated accommodations, and remain contactable throughout their stay. Visas remain mandatory, with processing taking at least 5 working days. Covid-19 test requirements have been relaxed, but mask-wearing is advised. The daily arrival limit has been increased to 50,000.

site_title: Man who made girlfriend take nude photo of her mother gets 20 weeks' jail
summary: A 25-year-old Singaporean man was sentenced to 20 weeks' jail for threatening to distribute intimate photos of his ex-girlfriend without her consent and instigating her to commit voyeurism. The man demanded his girlfriend take nude photos of herself and her mother, and when she refused, he threatened to post the photos online and harm her if she didn't comply. The victim made a police report, and the couple has since broken up. The man's lawyer attributed his behavior to a lapse in judgment and a fear of consequences.

site_title: Fewer road deaths in first half of year but elderly cases up
summary: In the first half of 2022, 45 people were killed in 44 fatal road accidents in Singapore, a decrease of 13 fatalities from the same period in 2021. However, elderly pedestrian deaths increased from 5 to 9, accounting for 81.8% of pedestrian deaths. The easing of Covid-19 safe management measures led to an increase in traffic volume, resulting in more accidents involving injuries or fatalities. Drink-driving arrests rose, but accidents caused by drink-driving decreased. Speeding-related accidents and violations also increased, while running red lights decreased.

site_title: World can learn from S'pore in urban design and cyber security: Nobel laureate
summary: Singapore is a model for effective urban design and cyber security, according to Nobel laureate Professor Paul Romer. Romer, who won the Nobel Prize in economics for his theory on technological change and economic growth, is seeking to understand Singapore's strategies for protecting citizens from cyber threats. He also hopes to learn from Singapore's wage policy and urbanization efforts, which he believes could be transferable to other countries. Romer will participate in the Nobel Prize Dialogue Singapore on September 13, where he will discuss topics such as building trust and the role of government in facilitating cooperation.

site_title: Building a cohesive society requires deliberate, consistent effort: DPM Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the importance of deliberate effort in building a cohesive society. He cited the COVID-19 pandemic as a test of social cohesion, where high-trust countries had lower death rates. Wong proposed fostering contact and interaction between people from different backgrounds, promoting inclusive growth, and encouraging dialogue among community, religious, and government leaders. He also highlighted the need for balance and compromise in resolving fundamental disagreements and avoiding zero-sum battles, as seen in Singapore's approach to resolving racial riots through negotiation and accommodation.

site_title: Firm barred from hiring foreign workers after safety lapse
summary: A waterproofing company, Le Fong Building Services, has been barred from hiring foreign workers for three months after a worker fell through a roof and suffered multiple injuries. The incident occurred under new heightened safety measures announced by the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) following a spate of workplace fatalities this year, with 37 deaths recorded so far. The company's managing director, William Lim, was ordered to personally account for lapses and rectify safety issues, including a lack of proper safety systems for working at height.

site_title: Watches.com details value of 500 timepieces seized in HK
summary: The Hong Kong Customs and Excise Department seized 500 watches valued at approximately HK$600,000 (S$107,400) from an indirect subsidiary of Singapore-listed Watches.com, CKLY Trading Limited (CTL). The watches were reportedly fake and seized under the Trade Descriptions Ordinance. Both Incredible Holdings and Watches.com maintain the watches are genuine, with CTL providing invoices to support their claim. Two individuals, a director and a shopkeeper, were arrested and are out on bail. The companies plan to work with the Hong Kong legal team to retrieve the watches and dismiss the investigation.

site_title: Collective sale angst for older Orchard Rd leasehold condos
summary: Aging luxury leasehold condos in Orchard Road are facing collective sale angst. Horizon Towers in Leonie Hill launched its third attempt at a collective sale at $1.1 billion, while Orchard Bel Air's $587.5 million tender closed without bids, indicating little interest from buyers.

site_title: Japan beats Q2 growth forecast on business spending
summary: Japan's economy grew at a 3.5% annualized rate in the second quarter, exceeding initial forecasts of 2.9% and beating pre-pandemic levels. Robust business spending and private consumption contributed to the growth, while net exports also played a role. Despite this, economists warn that the economy is expected to slow in the third quarter due to a record virus wave and supply chain issues. The Bank of Japan is expected to maintain its monetary stimulus program to ensure inflation becomes more sustainable.

site_title: Sugar and salt shortages leave bitter taste in Filipinos' mouths
summary: The Philippines is facing severe shortages of sugar, salt, onions, and garlic due to dependence on food imports and global produce price surges. The country's inflation rate is near its highest level since 2018, partly due to elevated food costs. The government is proposing a 44% hike in the agriculture department's budget to prioritize farming, while President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. is also taking on the role of agriculture secretary. Food shortages are expected to worsen, with the beverage industry and Burger King Philippines already feeling the effects, and the government is accused of hoarding supplies.

site_title: Sunseap to almost double its workforce here by 2030
summary: EDPR Sunseap, a clean energy provider and arm of Portuguese utility giant Energias de Portugal, plans to almost double its workforce in Singapore by 2030, creating 300-400 new jobs. The company aims to use Singapore as a regional hub to drive projects across Asia, leveraging the city-state's talent pool and procurement capabilities. EDPR Sunseap already employs 450 people in Singapore and plans to grow its renewable projects in Asia to over 2 gigawatts by 2025, narrowing the gap with other regions.

site_title: Apple offers safety upgrades, adventure watch, steady prices
summary: Apple has maintained the same prices for its high-end iPhone 14 models as last year's iPhone 13, despite inflationary pressure. The company focused on safety upgrades, including a satellite SOS feature and emergency response capabilities, and a new adventure-focused watch. The iPhone lineup received tweaks to cameras and battery life, but only the Pro lineup received a new processor chip. Prices for the iPhone 14 start at $799, while the Pro models will be available starting September 16, with the Pro Max costing $1,099 in Singapore.

site_title: Company Briefs: GE
summary: A federal judge blocked General Electric from making or selling its Haliade-X offshore wind turbines in the US due to patent infringement. Siemens Gamesa Renewable Energy obtained an injunction after a jury found GE's design infringed on a patent held by the Spanish manufacturer. However, two US wind projects can continue using GE's turbines. Meanwhile, Tesla's China operations rebounded after a factory upgrade, delivering 76,965 vehicles in August, while Apple's data centre in Guiyang, China, was forced to shut down due to a Covid-19 lockdown.

site_title: Jokowi signs order to ratify airspace pact with Singapore
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo signed a presidential regulation to ratify the flight information region (FIR) agreement with Singapore, realigning the boundary between the two countries' FIRs to align with Indonesia's territorial boundaries. The agreement aims to increase aviation safety and non-tax state revenues, and is part of a set of bilateral agreements signed in January 2022. The agreements also include defence cooperation and extradition, which were previously signed in 2007 but not ratified. Singapore welcomes the ratification, and both countries are expected to implement the agreements simultaneously.

site_title: Inflation and tech sell-off hit wealth of S'pore tycoons
summary: Singapore's billionaires saw their combined wealth drop 20% to $230.6 billion this year, hit by inflation and the global tech sell-off. The Forbes 2022 list shows the top 5 remain unchanged, with Li Xiting at No. 1 and the Ng brothers at No. 2. However, other tycoons like Goh Cheng Liang and Facebook co-founder Eduardo Saverin experienced significant losses, with their net worth falling 30% and 50% respectively. Grab co-founder Anthony Tan dropped out of the list after his company's stocks nearly halved in value.

site_title: KL hikes key rate but is not on pre-set tightening path
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, raised its overnight policy rate by 25 basis points to 2.5% to combat price pressures, but signaled that future tightening is not guaranteed. The move, the third this year, aims to support growth while taming inflation. The bank expects inflation to peak in the third quarter and moderate, and will adjust monetary policy in a measured and gradual manner. The decision comes after Malaysia lifted its mask mandate, boosting the economy, but also amid rising consumer prices.

site_title: DeFi projects try to replenish treasuries after crypto's bust
summary: Decentralized finance (DeFi) projects are seeking to replenish their treasuries after the crypto market collapse. Aave Companies, a major DeFi lending project, is seeking $16.28 million from its DAO to cover development costs. Lido DAO, another prominent project, has approved a proposal to sell 10 million native tokens to venture capital firm Dragonfly Capital to cover expenses. The collapse has led to significant declines in the value of DeFi treasuries, with Aave's liquid assets dropping from $800 million to $378 million. Industry experts attribute the struggles to a lack of experience in managing finances among technical founders.

site_title: 75 per cent of Sky Eden@Bedok condo units sold on first day of launch
summary: Three-quarters of Sky Eden@Bedok's 158 units were sold on the first day of its launch, with all two-bedroom units sold at an average price of $2,100 per sq ft. The 99-year leasehold mixed-use development, located in Bedok Town Centre, attracted buyers due to its accessible location and proximity to thriving economic hubs. Units range from $1,937 psf to $1.31 million, with schools such as Red Swastika School nearby. The strong sales performance is attributed to pent-up demand, driven by limited unsold stock in the mass market.

site_title: Companies must go green to stay relevant, Grace Fu says at SBA event
summary: Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu emphasized the importance of businesses adopting sustainability to stay relevant amid climate change's impact on supply chains and consumer demand. She cited 68 carbon pricing initiatives globally, warning that those unable to adapt may struggle to compete. Fu highlighted examples of businesses integrating sustainability, such as PUB's solar energy use, and encouraged proactive integration into business decisions. The Singapore Business Awards recognized business leaders who have made a positive impact, with winners including United Overseas Bank's CEO and AIA Group's CEO, amidst a ceremony held after two years of hybrid format due to the pandemic.

site_title: S'pore shares end higher, buoyed by strong Wall Street showing
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.7% on Thursday, driven by a strong Wall Street showing, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,233.61. Regional markets were mixed, with Japan's Nikkei 225 jumping 2.3% and Australia's shares surging 1.8%. However, China's markets declined, with the Shanghai Composite Index falling 0.3% and the Shenzhen Composite Index losing 0.9%. Analysts attribute the China slowdown to its zero-Covid-19 strategy, citing the recent lockdown extension in Chengdu. Sembcorp Industries was the top loser, while Jardine C&C was the top performer.

site_title: Lewandowski's treble a birthday gift for his wife
summary: Robert Lewandowski scored a hat-trick in Barcelona's 5-1 win over Viktoria Plzen, marking his first Champions League game for the team. Lewandowski has now scored eight goals in five appearances and moved ahead of Karim Benzema in the Champions League's all-time top scorers list. The victory came on his wife's birthday, whom Lewandowski credited with the goals. Lewandowski's reunion with former Bayern Munich coach Julian Nagelsmann is set for next week's match at the Allianz Arena, with Nagelsmann expressing excitement for the game.

site_title: SNOC president Tan gets third term
summary: Singapore National Olympic Council (SNOC) president Tan Chuan-Jin has been unanimously re-elected for his third term, serving from 2022 to 2026. Lawrence Leow was elected as one of the SNOC's vice-presidents, replacing Milan Kwee, who passed away in 2021. Leow, SBA president, and former sailing chief Benedict Tan were re-elected, along with Jessie Phua and Juliana Seow as vice-presidents. Lee Wung Yew was elected treasurer for a one-year term. National bowler Shayna Ng was appointed chair of the SNOC Athletes' Commission for 2022-2025.

site_title: Chelsea set for Potter magic in revival plan
summary: Graham Potter has been appointed Chelsea's new manager on a five-year deal after Thomas Tuchel's firing. Potter, 47, is expected to bring three of his staff members to Stamford Bridge. He was chosen by owner Todd Boehly, who praised Potter's "proven coach and innovator" status. Potter's arrival has drawn mixed reactions, with some hailing his attractive playing style and others warning that Chelsea's ruthless culture may hinder his success. He will take charge of the team on Saturday's Premier League trip to Fulham.

site_title: Klopp wants Reds to 'reinvent ourselves'
summary: Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp has called for a "team reset" after the team's poor start to the season was compounded by a 4-1 loss to Napoli in their Champions League opener. The loss exposed Liverpool's early-season problems, with the team conceding their worst result in the Champions League era. Klopp believes the team must reinvent themselves to compete in both the Premier League and Champions League, with key players returning from injury but still struggling to find form.

site_title: Energy majors exaggerating green efforts: Industry watchdog
summary: Energy majors BP, Chevron, ExxonMobil, Shell, and TotalEnergies are exaggerating their green credentials in public messaging, despite allocating most new investment to oil and gas projects. Industry watchdog InfluenceMap analyzed over 3,400 public communications, finding 60% of messages contained green claims, but only 12% of new investments went to low-carbon activities. The disparity allows companies to delay decarbonization, potentially overshooting the International Energy Agency's net-zero pathway.

site_title: 'Unfair' criticism levelled at Qatar 2022: Organisers
summary: Qatar 2022 World Cup organisers claim criticism of the host nation has been "unfair" and "not based on factual reality". CEO Nasser Al Khater said Qatar has made changes in response to criticism, including those related to human rights and alcohol consumption. The organisers have announced a "reimagined" Fan Festival, a 40,000-capacity event featuring live broadcasts, concerts, and interactive gaming stations, with alcohol available for sale after 6:30pm. FIFA president Gianni Infantino praised the festival, calling it an opportunity for fans to experience football in new ways.

site_title: Richarlison in tears after dream European debut
summary: Brazilian forward Richarlison broke down in tears after scoring his first two goals for Tottenham Hotspur in a 2-0 win over 10-man Marseille in the Champions League. Richarlison, who completed his £60 million move to Spurs in the summer, had previously spoken about playing in the Champions League as his dream. The 25-year-old's emotional response was triggered by the Champions League anthem, with his father in attendance, and marked a successful European debut. The win sees Spurs unbeaten in their first seven games in all competitions this season.

site_title: Still our title to lose, says Sailors' Lalic
summary: Interim Lion City Sailors coach Luka Lalic remains optimistic about the team's chances of retaining their title despite a 3-1 loss to Geylang International. The team is still in first place with a superior goal difference, and Lalic believes they can win their remaining five SPL games. Key players, including Pedro Henrique and Hariss Harun, are dealing with injuries, but Lalic is confident in his team's attacking style and defensive capabilities. The Sailors face a tough match against Tampines Rovers, led by striker Boris Kopitovic, who is seeking to break the club record for most league goals.

site_title: Swiatek stays on course for Grand Slam No. 3
summary: World No. 1 Iga Swiatek beat American Jessica Pegula 6-3, 7-6 (7-4) to reach the semi-finals of the US Open for the first time. Despite a shaky serving display, Swiatek remained focused and handled the tough match. She will now face Aryna Sabalenka in the semi-finals after Sabalenka beat Karolina Pliskova 6-1, 7-6 (7-4). Swiatek remains the top women's player, having secured her position with the win.

site_title: From hearing loss to knee injuries – doctors share advice on preventing and treating medical conditions before they become more serious
summary: Medical experts from Gleneagles Hospital share advice on preventing and treating various health conditions, including hearing loss, knee injuries, and digestive issues. Doctors discuss warning signs, treatments, and non-surgical options for conditions like endometriosis, knee injuries, IBS and IBD, seizures, metabolic surgery, heart failure, and hearing loss. The podcast series aims to provide listeners with useful information on common and not-so-common health topics.

site_title: Maggie Smith set to go one better, even at new track
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The S.A. Turffontein form analysis provides insights into the chances of various horses in nine upcoming races. Maggie Smith is favored to go one better in her second outing, with ONCE IN A LIFE TIME also being a strong contender in the 1200m R2. STEPPING OUT and PROMONTORY are expected to perform well in the 1600m R3, while HOMELY GIRL and SUPREME QUEST have chances in the 1450m R4. WILLIAM ROBERTSON and SIR MICHAEL are likely to compete in the 1450m R5, with TUSCAN WINTER poised to complete a hat-trick in the 1450m R6.

site_title: Not so pitch perfect
summary: Singapore's Women's Premier League (WPL) has faced setbacks four months into its season. Poor conditions at Yishun Stadium, one of the venues, have been a major issue. The league, launched in May after a two-year hiatus, had initially received significant fanfare. However, teething issues have surfaced, including the poor stadium conditions, which may impact the game's growth. The WPL's first title sponsor, Deloitte, has a three-year deal worth over $300,000. The league's future remains uncertain due to these issues.

site_title: S'pore draw first blood
summary: Singapore netballers defeated Malaysia 56-43 in a thrilling match at the Asian Netball Championship, securing a spot in the semi-finals. The hosts, led by co-captain Toh Kai Wei, improved their performance compared to their loss to Sri Lanka, citing better composure and teamwork. Malaysia coach Lisa Beehag praised Singapore's speed and agility, while Singapore's Yew Shu Ning credited the crowd for boosting their morale. The teams will meet again in the semi-finals on Saturday, with the winners earning a spot at the 2023 Netball World Cup.

site_title: Great Eastern Women's Run back on Nov 20
summary: The Great Eastern Women's Run (GEWR) will return on November 20, featuring a physical all-women race for the first time since 2019. The event, which was cancelled in 2020 due to the pandemic, will have a competitive 21.1km race for invited elite athletes and a virtual component for the public in various categories. Organisers are excited to welcome back runners and encourage them to break personal milestones, with a focus on charity and community. Registration is now open for the 10km, 5km, and 2km Mummy + Me categories.

site_title: Netball: Singapore beat Malaysia, but face real test in rematch at Asian C'ship s-finals
summary: Singapore beat Malaysia 56-43 in the Asian Netball Championship, finishing second in Group E. The hosts, led by co-captain Toh Kai Wei, started stronger in the rematch, using speed and agility to gain a 30-22 lead in the first half. Singapore will face Malaysia again in the semi-finals on Saturday, while defending champions Sri Lanka play Hong Kong. The winners of the semi-finals will earn a spot at the 2023 Netball World Cup.

site_title: Star Jack looks the part
summary: Star Jack, an 8-year-old Japanese-bred gelding, is poised for his eighth victory after a strong final gallop in his last start. With a win rate of two from five starts in the last four months, trainer Hideyuki Takaoka's horse is considered a strong contender in Saturday's $50,000 Class 4 event over the Polytrack 1,800m. Star Jack's stablemate, Poroshiri, could also inject speed into the race, while French jockey Marc Lerner, who has ridden the horse to two victories, is set to ride him again.

site_title: Tan Chuan-Jin re-elected SNOC president; badminton chief Lawrence Leow one of four V-Ps
summary: Tan Chuan-Jin was unanimously re-elected as president of the Singapore National Olympic Council (SNOC) for a third term from 2022 to 2026. Lawrence Leow, president of the Singapore Badminton Association, was elected as one of the SNOC's vice-presidents. Other re-elected vice-presidents include Benedict Tan and Jessie Phua. Former national shooter Lee Wung Yew was elected treasurer for a one-year term, replacing Milan Kwee. National bowler Shayna Ng was appointed chair of the SNOC Athletes' Commission, and Paralympian Theresa Goh was elected as one of its 10 members.

site_title: Formula One: Hamilton to take grid penalty at Monza
summary: Formula One driver Lewis Hamilton will start the Italian Grand Prix from the back of the grid due to exceeding his power unit allocation for the season. Hamilton damaged a power unit at the Belgian Grand Prix and will use his fourth for the race, resulting in a grid penalty. With seven races remaining, Hamilton is sixth in the championship, 152 points behind leader Max Verstappen.

site_title: Super Salute issues an early warning
summary: Singaporean trainer Jason Lim's newcomer Super Salute impressed in a barrier trial, winning by eight lengths in 59.23 seconds. The horse, a son of I Am Invincible, was previously owned by China Horse Club and Newgate, but Lim has high hopes for his potential in the Singaporean racing scene. A Class 4 race over 1,200m is now being considered as a possible debut, with a Novice race offering $75,000 in prize money, compared to $50,000 for a Class 4 race. Lim believes Super Salute is a sound horse and professional, and the A$110,000 purchase price was a good investment.

site_title: S'pore students top geography Olympiad, place well in other international competitions
summary: Singaporean students have topped the International Geography Olympiad, winning three gold medals and one silver medal. The team, consisting of four students, including 17-year-old Wong Kang Zheng, who competed despite contracting Covid-19, emerged first out of 54 countries and 209 participants. This victory marks Singapore's return to the top of the competition since 2014. The students also performed well in other international competitions, including the International Olympiad in Informatics and the International Biology Olympiad.

site_title: 65-year-old man convicted over trying to deposit 3 fake $10,000 notes
summary: A 65-year-old Singaporean man, Young Tat Ong, has been convicted of trying to deposit three fake $10,000 notes into his bank account. Ong agreed to help a Vietnamese man, Dinh Dai Quang, exchange genuine notes for smaller denominations for a commission. Despite suspicions, Ong attempted to deposit the notes, which were later found to be counterfeit. The court heard that Ong had doubts about the notes' authenticity but proceeded anyway. Ong faces up to 20 years in prison and a fine for the offense.

site_title: Sports World: Valieva drug probe to be concluded soon
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

The Russian Anti-Doping Agency's (Rusada) investigation into Olympic figure skater Kamila Valieva's positive test for trimetazidine is nearing its conclusion. Seven months after the test result was published, Rusada stated the probe is in its final stage. The results for the team event in Beijing remain provisional, pending the decision on medals for the runners-up and third-placed teams. Meanwhile, England midfielder Keira Walsh has joined Barcelona for a world-record fee of around £350,000, and Chechnya-born Swede Khamzat Chimaev is set to face Nate Diaz at UFC 279, aiming to keep his name in the welterweight title picture.

site_title: Belief helps Alcaraz win marathon match
summary: Carlos Alcaraz defeated Jannik Sinner in a 5-hour, 15-minute match to reach the US Open semi-finals. The match, which finished at 2:50am, marked the latest finish in the tournament's 141-year history. Alcaraz, the world No. 4, won 6-3, 6-7, 6-7, 7-5, 6-3, describing the win as his best performance. Sinner, the 11th seed, called the defeat the hardest of his career, while Alcaraz will face Frances Tiafoe in the semi-finals, who aims to inspire more people of color to play tennis.

site_title: 'Great security plan' for World Cup
summary: World Rugby chief executive Alan Gilpin is confident about fan safety for the Rugby World Cup in France, despite security issues at the Champions League final in Paris. The French government and Uefa are conducting inquests into the chaotic scenes, but Gilpin believes lessons can be learned and a "great security plan" is in place. The tournament, which opens with a match against New Zealand, has seen a shake-up in the rankings, with Ireland and Wales emerging as contenders to clinch the Webb Ellis trophy.

site_title: Golf: Fleetwood, Hovland share lead as storm clouds loom at BMW PGA Championship
summary: Tommy Fleetwood and Viktor Hovland shared the lead at the BMW PGA Championship, with Fleetwood topping the leaderboard with an 8-under 64. Rory McIlroy, a critic of LIV Tour players, shot a 4-under 68, while Matt Fitzpatrick and Billy Horschel also finished strong. The tournament was suspended due to bad weather and the death of Queen Elizabeth. The LIV Tour's presence has sparked controversy, with former European Ryder Cup captain Paul McGinley stating that players who joined the breakaway tour should not be allowed to play on the DP World Tour.

site_title: Kyrgios gets fine again for his racket
summary: Nick Kyrgios was fined US$14,000 for unsportsmanlike conduct after demolishing two rackets after his US Open quarter-final loss to Karen Khachanov. The fine brings his total to US$32,500 for five offences in New York. Kyrgios expressed frustration after the loss, feeling that his efforts counted for nothing. Tennis analyst John McEnroe criticized Kyrgios' on-court meltdown, saying it was unbecoming. Kyrgios will now head home to Australia to face alleged assault charges in October, unrelated to the tennis incident.

site_title: Football: Qatar criticism 'not based on reality'; organisers promise 'amazing World Cup'
summary: Qatar's World Cup organisers have dismissed criticism of the host nation as "unfair" and "not based on factual reality". CEO Nasser Al Khater stated that criticism from Western media has been "misconceived" and that Qatar has made significant changes in response to concerns. The World Cup will feature a "reimagined" Fan Festival with live broadcasts, concerts, and interactive gaming stations, and alcohol will be available for sale in select areas of the stadium. Organisers aim to provide a memorable experience for fans and ensure a smooth experience for visitors.

site_title: Clean energy provider EDPR Sunseap to almost double its workforce here by 2030
summary: EDPR Sunseap, a clean energy provider, plans to almost double its workforce in Singapore by 2030. The company, which already employs 450 staff in the city-state, aims to create 300-400 new jobs in functions such as energy assessment, engineering, and project management. EDPR Sunseap hopes to leverage Singapore's talent pool and hub status to drive its regional projects, including government tenders and procurements for Europe and the US. The company also plans to grow its renewable projects in Asia to over 2 gigawatts by 2025.

site_title: Vital for companies to go green to stay relevant, says Grace Fu at S'pore Business Awards event
summary: Singapore Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu emphasized the importance of companies adopting sustainability to remain relevant and competitive in the face of climate change. She cited the World Bank's 68 carbon pricing initiatives globally and warned that businesses unable to adapt may struggle to compete. Fu highlighted examples of businesses integrating sustainability, such as PUB's solar energy use, and encouraged others to follow suit. The Singapore Business Awards recognized business leaders who made a positive impact, with winners including United Overseas Bank's CEO Wee Ee Cheong and gaming chair company Secretlab's CEO Ian Ang.

site_title: As kidney failure rises in ageing S'pore, some senior patients opt for non-dialysis care
summary: At least 5,000 Singaporean seniors aged 75 and above have opted for non-dialysis care, choosing conservative management of chronic kidney disease over dialysis. This decision is driven by the rising number of end-stage kidney disease patients, increasing by 30% from 2011 to 2019, and the associated high costs of dialysis. Conservative care, which includes medication and palliative care, is estimated to cost $100 per month with subsidies and insurance, significantly lower than dialysis costs. Experts recommend this option for patients with low life expectancy, and a new drug, finerenone, has been rolled out to combat diabetic kidney disease, which is the top contributor to chronic kidney disease.

site_title: Athletics: Great Eastern Women's Run returns with in-person race on Nov 20
summary: The Great Eastern Women's Run (GEWR) is set to return on November 20 with an in-person all-women's race for the first time since 2019. The event was cancelled in 2020 due to the pandemic and featured an elite-only half-marathon in 2021. This year's event will include a 10km, 5km, and 2km Mummy + Me categories, as well as a competitive 21.1km race for local elite athletes. The event aims to inspire women to break new ground, achieve personal milestones, and raise funds for local charities.

site_title: Singapore's first cardinal urges unity, harmony in thanksgiving mass
summary: Singapore's first cardinal, William Goh, urged unity and harmony in a thanksgiving mass at St Joseph's Church, calling on the Catholic Church to promote love and unity through inter-religious dialogue and building a more inclusive society. Goh emphasized the importance of working with people of different faiths, orientations, and backgrounds to create a cohesive society. He also highlighted the need to engage humanists and secularists to achieve this goal. The event was attended by 3,500 people, including Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, and was seen as a historic moment for Singapore and the Catholic Church.

site_title: Jobs in built environment should be redesigned to attract young talent, study finds
summary: A joint study by the Building and Construction Authority (BCA) and Ernst & Young recommends redesigning jobs in the built environment sector to attract young talent. The study aims to improve career progression, working conditions, and work-life balance, as well as achieve greater productivity to meet industry demands. Senior Minister of State for National Development Tan Kiat How emphasizes the need for better recognition, salaries, and career progression to change the sector's perception.

Recycling air conditioners is crucial because they contain refrigerants such as hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), which can have a significant environmental impact if not properly recovered.
