site_title: New longevity clinic to provide patients 'customised' health plan to slow ageing
summary: A new longevity clinic is set to open at Alexandra Hospital in Singapore, offering customized health plans to slow ageing. The clinic, staffed by internal medicine specialists, will diagnose patients' biological age through blood tests and other assessments. Based on this, doctors will provide personalized plans that include exercise, diet, and lifestyle interventions. The goal is to reverse the ageing trajectory and potentially stop or slow the onset of age-related diseases. The clinic is expected to open early next year and will be the first publicly funded outpatient clinic in longevity medicine in Singapore.

site_title: Interpol red notice issued against former Wirecard director
summary: Interpol has issued a red notice against Edo Kurniawan, a former Wirecard Asia director, for allegedly conspiring to misappropriate funds between $41,200 to $100,000. Kurniawan, whose whereabouts are unknown, is accused of working with three former employees to commit fraud and forgery. The case is linked to the Wirecard scandal, where $2.1 billion went missing. Kurniawan is wanted for charges including criminal breach of trust, falsifying invoices, and acquiring benefits from criminal conduct. A warrant of arrest has been issued, and anyone with information can contact the police hotline.

site_title: Football: Leipzig sack Tedesco after Champions League home debacle
summary: RB Leipzig sacked coach Domenico Tedesco after a 4-1 loss to Shakhtar Donetsk and a 4-0 loss to Eintracht Frankfurt, marking a poor start to the Bundesliga season. Tedesco led the team to a Champions League spot and the German Cup, but failed to replicate success. The club cited a mediocre start to the Bundesliga season as reason for the change, with CEO Oliver Mintzlaff stating a new management change is necessary to turn things around quickly.

site_title: Man admits involvement in forged invoices scheme that cheated Iras of $772k
summary: A 42-year-old former taxi driver, Lee Chong Hoong, pleaded guilty to his role in a forged invoices scheme that cheated the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (Iras) of around $772,200 in GST claims. Lee, who was recruited as the nominee director of a shell company, forged over 183 invoices worth $56.5 million between 2015 and 2016, making a personal profit of at least $80,000. He was convicted of one count of carrying on the business of a company for a fraudulent purpose and will be sentenced on October 6.

site_title: $8m boost for tourism and lifestyle businesses to help market S'pore as a destination
summary: The Singapore Tourism Board (STB) has launched the SingapoReimagine Marketing Programme, providing $8 million in funding to support tourism and lifestyle businesses in promoting Singapore as a destination. The programme, which includes a $20 million Marketing Partnership Programme, aims to help businesses recover from the pandemic by cementing Singapore's position as a must-visit destination. Successful applicants will receive up to $500,000 in funding, with a focus on creative and innovative marketing campaigns that emotionally connect with target audiences. Applications are now open until October 28, with successful applicants announced in January 2023.

site_title: Football: Lionesses wrap up World Cup qualifiers with 80 goals scored, 0 conceded
summary: England's women's national football team completed their World Cup qualifiers with a perfect record, scoring 80 goals without conceding any. They thrashed Luxembourg 10-0 in their final match, with Georgia Stanway and Beth England scoring doubles. The team's flawless campaign saw them win all 10 games, and they have already qualified for the 2023 women's World Cup in Australia and New Zealand. England's next test will be against the US, the world champions, on October 7 in a friendly match.

site_title: Retail workers taking home higher pay as sector's progressive wage model kicks in
summary: Retail workers in Singapore will receive a 8.4-8.5% annual pay rise over three years under the Progressive Wage Model (PWM), with about 19,000 employees eligible. The move aims to narrow the gap between low-wage workers and the median salary. Firms have until February to comply, with penalties including suspended work pass privileges. The government will support companies through the Progressive Wage Credit Scheme, co-funding up to 75% of the salary increase for workers earning below $2,500.

site_title: Wearable robot detects and prevents falls especially in the elderly, reducing reliance on caregivers
summary: A wearable robot, the Mobile Robotic Balance Assistant, was developed by researchers at Nanyang Technological University and Tan Tock Seng Hospital to detect and prevent falls among the elderly. The robot, about 1m tall and 70cm wide, has in-built sensors that can detect loss of balance and stabilise users with a harness. In clinical trials, the robot was successful in aiding participants with sitting, standing, and walking, and no falls were recorded. The robot aims to reduce reliance on caregivers and promote independent living among the elderly, with plans to commercialize it within the next two years.

site_title: New longevity centre looks at how to reverse ageing and prolong disease-free years
summary: The National University Health System Centre for Healthy Longevity in Singapore has opened to test ways to slow ageing and prolong disease-free years. The centre aims to translate laboratory findings into human clinical trials and develop biomarkers to measure ageing. With Singapore's population expected to be one in four elderly by 2030, the centre seeks to enhance healthspan by three to five years in the Singapore population by slowing biological ageing. The centre is conducting various studies, including Project Abios, to measure biomarkers and test novel supplements and repurposed drugs to slow ageing.

site_title: How can you drive into Malaysia if Touch 'n Go cards are sold out?
summary: Touch 'n Go cards, required for road tolls when driving into Malaysia, have been out of stock since April 1. Previously available at 7-Eleven convenience stores in Singapore, they are now sold out due to increased demand following the reopening of land borders.

site_title: Inter-faith collaboration needed to achieve shared objectives: Panel
summary: A panel discussion at the International Conference on Cohesive Societies emphasized the need for inter-faith collaboration to address shared objectives such as climate change, social justice, and cohesion. Experts, including UN Environment Programme director Iyad Abumoghli, noted that despite religious diversity, all faiths uphold high values and moral principles. Collaboration between faiths, scientific institutions, and policymakers is crucial for building ethical behavior and resolving conflicts, and can lead to a more cohesive and sustainable world. The discussion highlighted the importance of education and avoiding polarization.

site_title: Richard Li's insurer FWD eyeing Hong Kong IPO in 2023: Sources
summary: FWD Group Holdings, backed by billionaire Richard Li, is targeting a 2023 Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO) to raise approximately US$1 billion. The company had initially planned to list in 2022 but postponed due to a weak market. FWD plans to refile its listing documents, showcasing earnings growth despite industry headwinds, and is working towards a potential share sale as early as the first quarter of 2023. The final size and timing of the IPO are still subject to change.

site_title: Oakwood serviced apartments up for sale at $170m
summary: Oakwood Studios, a 98-unit serviced apartment complex in Singapore's Orchard enclave, has been put up for sale via an Expression of Interest (EOI) exercise with a guide price of $170 million. The property, last refurbished in 2017, spans 18,000 sq ft and features on-site amenities such as a fitness centre and rooftop swimming pool. With a guide price of $1.7 million per unit, the sale is expected to attract demand from expatriates and long-stay corporate and leisure travellers, driven by Singapore's elevated residential rental demand and travel surge. The EOI closes on October 7.

site_title: COE premium for large cars hits new high again, prices rise in all categories except small cars
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) prices rose across all categories except for smaller cars, with the premium for larger and more powerful cars reaching a new record high of $113,299, a 1.2% increase from the previous record. The only decrease was in the COE price for smaller cars, which fell by 2.1%. Industry watchers attribute the price rise to the limited availability of COEs, with some dealers preparing for the upcoming Cars@Expo event and anticipating changes to rebates for cleaner commercial vehicles.

site_title: Motorists face roadblocks in getting refunds for expired Malaysian Touch 'n Go toll cards
summary: Motorists driving to Malaysia are facing difficulties in obtaining refunds for their expired Touch 'n Go toll cards, which were deactivated after 12 months of disuse due to the pandemic closure. The issue has affected Singapore drivers, who have been trying for five months to get their unused balances refunded since land borders reopened in April 2022.

site_title: DJ Tenashar charged over forged document using Attorney-General's name
summary: Club DJ Tenashar, 37, appeared in a Singapore district court on September 7, charged with using a forged document as a genuine one, specifically a letter purportedly filed with the Attorney-General's consent to institute contempt of court proceedings. The document contained a forged signature with the Attorney-General's name. She was remanded for psychiatric observation and her case was adjourned to September 21. If convicted, she faces up to 10 years in jail and a fine.

site_title: Research engineer develops rehab tools to help father's stroke recovery, wins James Dyson Award
summary: Research engineer Mr John Tay, 27, developed Rehabit, a set of four products for upper-limb rehabilitation, to help his father recover from a stroke. Rehabit won the national winner of the James Dyson Award, a $9,000 cash award, and will progress to the international stage. The award recognizes innovative designs that can change lives. Tay plans to reinvest the award into upgrading Rehabit and exploring its application in other rehabilitative physical therapy sectors.

site_title: More people going maskless in S'pore but most customer-facing staff still donning masks
summary: Singapore has made masks optional in most settings, but many customer-facing staff continue to wear them, despite not being mandated by law. Employees at businesses such as hair salons, childcare centers, and supermarkets have chosen to keep their masks on, citing customer comfort and personal protection. Some businesses, like hair salons, have implemented policies to encourage mask-wearing, while others, like the Timezone gaming arcade, have adopted a more relaxed approach, following government policy and customer comfort.

site_title: Where Asia's rich are putting their cash as global risks grow
summary: Asia's wealthy individuals, with over $1 million in investable funds, are repositioning towards private markets to shield assets from market volatility amid rising inflation and market volatility. They are shunning stocks and bonds, focusing on safer assets like gold and cash, and largely avoiding crypto. A survey by Lombard Odier found that 77% of respondents are concerned about inflation, and 56% are diversifying to reduce market risk. The trend is particularly pronounced among Singapore and Australian high net-worth individuals, with 60% planning to increase allocations to private markets.

site_title: China sets renminbi fix at strongest bias on record as losses mount
summary: China's central bank set the renminbi's reference rate at 6.9160 per US dollar, its strongest bias on record, as the currency faces pressure due to the COVID-19 lockdowns and property sector stress. The move aims to dampen depreciation pressure and maintain stability ahead of a key party reshuffle. Despite a drop against the US dollar, the renminbi remained steady versus a basket of peers, with analysts suggesting the currency's focus may shift away from the 7 per dollar level.

site_title: 'Badge Lady' returns to court to face fresh charges linked to Covid-19 pandemic
summary: "Badge Lady" Phoon Chiu Yoke, 55, returned to court to face fresh charges linked to the Covid-19 pandemic. She is accused of two Covid-19 Act and one Infectious Diseases Act offence for not wearing a mask in public places, including walking without a mask in Orchard Road on March 6. Her previous 16-week jail sentence was served, and she is now set to face new charges, with her pre-trial conference scheduled for October 14.

site_title: Oil tumbles to lowest since January over global demand concerns
summary: Oil prices have fallen to their lowest level since January, driven by concerns over a global slowdown and the impact of China's zero-Covid-19 strategy on consumption. West Texas Intermediate dropped below $86 a barrel, following OPEC's decision to pare output and Saudi Arabia's price cuts for Asian and European customers. The US dollar's surge to an all-time high also makes oil more expensive for international buyers. Crude has made three monthly losses, the worst streak in over two years, as investors worry about recession and economic slowdowns.

site_title: More than 3,700 cartons of duty-unpaid cigarettes seized; 2 men arrested in Jurong
summary: Singapore Customs seized 3,744 cartons of duty-unpaid cigarettes, worth approximately $319,730 in duty and $25,440 in GST, from an industrial building unit. Two men, a 38-year-old Bangladeshi and a 24-year-old Singaporean, were arrested in connection with the operation. The men allegedly used black trash bags and empty green baskets to conceal the cigarettes. Investigations are ongoing, and offenders can face fines up to 40 times the evaded amount and jail terms of up to six years.

site_title: Football: Real win at Celtic in Champions League, but suffer Benzema blow
summary: Real Madrid secured a 3-0 victory over Celtic in their Champions League Group F opener, but suffered a significant blow as Karim Benzema was forced off the field with a knee injury in the first half. Benzema was replaced by Eden Hazard and will undergo tests to determine the severity of the injury. Despite riding their luck, Real dominated the second half, scoring three goals through Vinicius Jr, Luka Modric, and Eden Hazard. The win marks a strong start for Real, but Benzema's injury raises concerns about the team's depth.

site_title: Sugar and salt shortage worsens Philippines' food supply woes
summary: The Philippines is experiencing a severe shortage of sugar, salt, onion, and garlic, exacerbating food supply woes and inflation. The country relies heavily on imports, with 90% of salt and over 50% of other essential commodities coming from abroad. Food policy is a pressing concern, with President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. proposing a 44% budget increase to prioritize farming. The sugar shortage has led to halted operations at four Coca-Cola plants and Burger King offering extra lettuce and tomato in exchange for onion, while the government investigates hoarding and confiscates suspected stockpiles.

site_title: Biden administration releases plan for US$50 billion investment in chips
summary: The US Department of Commerce has released a plan to invest $50 billion in the domestic semiconductor industry, dubbed the CHIPS for America Fund. The fund aims to build up the industry, counter China's influence, and reduce dependence on foreign supply chains. The $28 billion grant and loan program will support chip manufacturing facilities, while $10 billion will expand manufacturing for older technologies and $11 billion will fund research and development initiatives. The program is expected to begin soliciting applications by February next year and disburse funds by spring.

site_title: Worst bond market ever pushes Asian firms into short-term loans
summary: Global bonds have entered a bear market, marking the first in a generation, due to central banks tightening policy to combat inflation. Asian companies, particularly in China, are turning to short-term loans as they face debt maturities and difficulties selling new bonds. The number of companies seeking short-term loan facilities has increased 30-40% this year, with some seeking loans of up to 12 months. This shift is driven by the need for liquidity and the desire to avoid the lengthy approval process for longer-term loans.

site_title: Hottest auto stock in Asia Mitsubishi Motors surges 81%, thanks to its focus on Asean
summary: Mitsubishi Motors shares have surged 81% this year, outperforming Asian peers, driven by demand for small cars and pickups in Southeast Asia. The Japanese car exporter's product mix, suited to emerging markets, has helped it thrive as economies reopen post-pandemic. Unlike peers Toyota, Honda, Nissan, Subaru, and Mazda, Mitsubishi Motors is less vulnerable to the US economy's slowdown due to its strong presence in Asean markets, where commodity prices and tourism are expected to boost growth.

site_title: Food delivery firm foodpanda lays off staff in Singapore, retrenchment reportedly affects about 60
summary: Food delivery firm foodpanda has laid off about 60 employees, or 5% of its 1,200 staff in Singapore, as part of efforts to become profitable and remain competitive. The job cuts are part of a larger restructuring effort by its German parent company, Delivery Hero, which reported a US$888.8 million loss in 2021. Foodpanda launched its regional headquarters in Singapore in July and has 37% market share in the local food delivery sector. The company is also cutting jobs in the Philippines and Thailand.

site_title: Yen set for worst year as traders eye intervention; US dollar continues to climb
summary: The yen has slumped over 19% this year, its worst annual drawdown since 1979, as traders anticipate further verbal intervention from Japanese officials. The currency has hit a 24-year low against the dollar, pushing it past the 143 level for the first time since 1998. The US dollar continues to climb, driven by the US Federal Reserve's aggressive tightening cycle, which is also affecting developed economies and driving up the cost of imported goods and inflation.

site_title: US stocks fall as Fed worries offset good services data
summary: US stocks fell on Tuesday as worries about the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes offset positive economic data. The American services sector expanded in August, defying expectations for a slowdown, but concerns about Europe's energy woes and rising interest rates kept investors nervous. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.6%, while the S&P 500 fell 0.4% and the Nasdaq Composite Index slid 0.7%. A deal to acquire Signify Health by CVS Health boosted some stocks, but Bed Bath & Beyond plummeted 18.4% after the death of its CFO.

site_title: Dubai office rents are rising faster than in New York and London
summary: Dubai's office rents are rising, increasing by 7% in the year through June, faster than in New York and London. The emirate's strong demand for office space is driven by its nimble response to the pandemic and relatively easy access to visas. Skyscrapers like ICD Brookfield Place are fully leased, with a long wait list for the rest. Companies are expanding in Dubai, including UBS Group, Rapyd, and Pernod Ricard, and workers are returning to offices at a high rate, with 80% of workers in Dubai back in the office compared to less than 40% in London.

site_title: National servicemen can now buy military gear on Lazada
summary: Singaporean national servicemen can now purchase military gear from online marketplace Lazada through the SAF's eMart. The platform, launched in collaboration with Lazada Singapore and the Combat Service Support Command, allows servicemen to save on delivery costs. Currently, 20 military products are available, including a backpack and camouflage cream, with more items to be added. Servicemen can use their eMart credits, but must pay with debit or credit cards. The partnership aims to provide greater convenience and allow the SAF to learn from commercial industry partners.

site_title: Tennis: Jabeur defeats Tomljanovic, to face Garcia in US Open semi-finals
summary: Tunisia's Ons Jabeur defeated Australian Ajla Tomljanovic 6-4, 7-6 (7/4) to reach the US Open semi-finals, becoming the first African woman to do so. Jabeur, 28, will face French 17th seed Caroline Garcia in Thursday's semi-finals after Tomljanovic's run was ended by the Tunisian's clever play and attacking style. Jabeur drew confidence from her Wimbledon final appearance and hopes to inspire future generations of African female tennis players, saying it means a lot to her to reach the semi-finals.

site_title: Football: Haaland double fires Man City in Champions League rout of Sevilla
summary: Manchester City routed Sevilla 4-0 in the Champions League opener, with Erling Haaland scoring a double to inspire the win. Haaland's 12th goal in seven games solidified his position as a key player for the team, and his 25th Champions League goal in 20 games. The win sets City up well for their Group G campaign, with Pep Guardiola praising Haaland's predatory instincts and suggesting the team will adapt to his playing style. City's victory was a welcome start to their Champions League campaign, which they hope will end in their first European triumph since 2011.

site_title: S'pore and the Philippines boost digital, healthcare, counterterrorism cooperation
summary: Singapore and the Philippines have strengthened their cooperation in digital connectivity, healthcare, and counterterrorism through several memoranda of understanding (MOUs) signed during Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr's two-day state visit. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Marcos witnessed the signings, which include agreements on digital cooperation, healthcare professional deployment, and counterterrorism information sharing. The countries also exchanged agreements on water management, personal data protection, and urban development, with a focus on expanding their partnership in emerging issues like sustainability and food security.

site_title: Staff of six banks deployed at police's Anti-Scam Command
summary: Singapore's Anti-Scam Command has deployed staff from six banks to help tackle scam incidents efficiently. The bank employees assist in tracing funds and freezing accounts involved in scams, speeding up interventions. Since their deployment, over $1.5 million was recovered in more than 40 scam cases, making up 60% of the lost funds. The move is seen as a major step in the police's scam-fighting efforts, with coordinated operations resulting in the arrest of over 3,900 scammers and money mules.

site_title: Check out pre-1900 maps of S'pore for free on website
summary: A new online platform, developed by Yale-NUS, offers 1,500 pre-1900 maps of Singapore and South-east Asia for free. The digitized maps, compiled from four libraries, provide a unique insight into the region's history and development. Users can search by date, location, features, and publishers, with maps overlaid on present-day maps to show changes over time. The platform aims to make historical maps accessible to geography, history, and scholars, as well as amateur enthusiasts. It can be accessed at historicalmaps.yale-nus.edu.sg.

site_title: Football: Lethal Mbappe gets PSG off to flying start in Champions League
summary: Paris Saint-Germain (PSG) started their Champions League campaign with a 2-1 win over Juventus at the Parc des Princes. Kylian Mbappe scored two stunning goals, including a volley from Neymar's return pass, to give PSG a 2-0 lead before Weston McKennie reduced the deficit in the 53rd minute. PSG's win leaves them level with Benfica in Group H, and Mbappe's performance suggests he is committed to leading his hometown team to a Champions League title.

site_title: Cohesive societies born of choice and conviction: President Halimah
summary: President Halimah Yacob stated that cohesive societies are born of choice and conviction, emphasizing the need for collective action and cooperation to recover from the pandemic. She highlighted the importance of social cohesion in maintaining collective security and noted that the pandemic has deepened fault lines in societies worldwide. The International Conference on Cohesive Societies, now in its third year, aims to foster harmony in diverse societies through dialogue among religious leaders, policymakers, academics, and civil society activists.

site_title: Ex-ITE lecturer took upskirt videos on campus
summary: A former lecturer at the Institute of Technical Education (ITE) College East in Singapore was sentenced to four months' jail for taking upskirt videos and photographs of at least five students over four to five months. Darren Quek, 48, admitted to committing the offences after his arrest, which included 133 upskirt photos and videos found on his mobile phone. Quek targeted students wearing short skirts or "sitting improperly" and was caught by a student who alerted the police. He abused his trust and authority as a lecturer, and the court considered a sentence between four and six months.

site_title: Sentosa marks golden jubilee with time capsule
summary: Sentosa Island marked its 50th anniversary with a time capsule containing items representing its colonial past, establishment, golden jubilee, and future. The capsule was sealed on September 2 with a book featuring 50 personalities and stakeholders. A charity golf event raised $3,908,888.88 for the President's Challenge and Community Chest, benefiting over 100 agencies and 200 programs. President Halimah Yacob expressed her support for Sentosa's growth and community giving, wishing the Sentosa Development Corporation continued success in creating unique experiences for Singaporeans.

site_title: Man expected to plead guilty to dumping Felicia Teo's body
summary: A 37-year-old man, Ahmad Danial Mohamed Rafa'ee, is expected to plead guilty to dumping Felicia Teo's body in a public place, among other charges, on October 14. Ahmad was initially accused of killing 19-year-old Felicia in 2007 but was given a discharge not amounting to an acquittal for the murder charge in June. He is accused of committing these crimes with an 18-year-old Indonesian man, Ragil Putra Setia Sukmarahjana, who has not been charged. Details of Felicia's death and who was responsible remain undisclosed.

site_title: Cyclist sues PUB for at least $578k after accident involving drain grating
summary: A 42-year-old cyclist, Maung Maung Aung Soe Thu, is suing PUB for at least $578,000 after he fell off his bike and suffered injuries due to a drain grating in Changi Point Coastal Walk. PUB denies negligence, arguing that it did not owe a duty of care and the probability of injury from an accident involving the grating is extremely low. The court will determine liability and, if found liable, assess the damages. PUB's lawyers claim the costs of inspecting and replacing more than a million gratings would be astronomical, and the cyclist was contributorily negligent by choosing to cycle on the road.

site_title: Vital for S'pore, Malaysia to stand united amid headwinds: DPM Wong
summary: Singapore and Malaysia must continue to work closely together amid a more uncertain global landscape, Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong said. The bilateral relationship will be crucial as both countries face issues like energy, food, and economic slowdowns. Wong emphasized the importance of standing united and strengthening cooperation to navigate a new global order characterized by geopolitical contestation and fragmentation. He encouraged personal relationships and collaboration to address differences and advance bilateral ties, which have been strengthened through decades of friendship and close ties.

site_title: S'pore, Saudi Arabia can foster closer ties in areas like green economy
summary: Singapore and Saudi Arabia have reaffirmed their strong ties, with a focus on fostering cooperation in the green economy and other dynamic growth areas. During a visit by Singapore's Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan, the two countries agreed to enhance collaboration in renewable energy, logistics, and technology. They also reaffirmed the 45th anniversary of their diplomatic relations and welcomed closer cooperation through the Saudi-Arabia Singapore Joint Committee. A letter of invitation was extended to Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman for an official visit to Singapore, further solidifying bilateral ties.

site_title: Blueprint for shaping built environment sector gets a revamp
summary: Singapore's National Development Minister Desmond Lee has unveiled a refreshed blueprint to transform the built environment sector, aiming to build a more sustainable environment through the adoption of prefab and digital technologies. The blueprint includes the use of prefabricated prefinished volumetric construction (PPVC) methods, which improved manpower productivity by 40% and reduced pollution and noise issues. The sector also plans to adopt smart facility management technologies, with 80% of public buildings and 40% of private buildings targeted to adopt these technologies by 2030. The blueprint guides the development of the sector for years to come.

site_title: EDB reviewing Tech.Pass after MOM launches pass for top talent in all sectors
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) is considering merging the Tech.Pass with the new Overseas Networks and Expertise Pass, which offers flexibility in employment and starting a business to top foreign professionals in all sectors, not just technology. This move aims to attract top talent to Singapore. The Tech.Pass, launched in 2019, has been reviewed by the Economic Development Board (EDB) and its review is ongoing. The new pass, unveiled last month, provides similar benefits to the Tech.Pass but is more inclusive of top talent from all sectors.

site_title: Social cohesion is more than about race or religion: SMU president
summary: Singapore's President of the Singapore Management University, Professor Lily Kong, emphasizes that social cohesion is not solely dependent on racial or religious harmony. Key factors include migration, multiculturalism, social and economic inequality, the digital divide, and inter-generational relationships. Kong calls for a multi-dimensional approach to address these challenges, including building diverse networks and promoting upward mobility. The government and youth leaders are also working to foster a sense of community and solidarity, with initiatives like the Young Leaders Programme. Experts stress the need for a collective effort to build resilience and address social cohesion.

site_title: All-women halfway house to help offenders reintegrate into society
summary: A new all-women halfway house, Rise Above, will open in Singapore by the end of the month, providing help to female offenders before reintegration into society. The facility, run by the Singapore Muslim Women's Association, will have 9 initial residents and can accommodate 30 women a year. The halfway house offers family-centric programs, including journalling and reflection circles, to aid in rehabilitation and skills development. Minister of State Muhammad Faishal Ibrahim emphasized the importance of a secular facility, allowing all female offenders to receive help regardless of background.

site_title: Community care staff get award to help them upgrade skills
summary: Community care staff in Singapore received the Community Care Manpower Development Award to upgrade their skills. The award, given by the Agency for Integrated Care, provides training support and opportunities to advance careers. Notable recipients include Ms Jenny Ang, a centre manager at St Luke's ElderCare, and Sathish Kumar Lakshmanan, a principal physiotherapist at Bright Hill Evergreen Home. The award aims to equip the sector with the right skills to meet the needs of an ageing population, with recipients pursuing studies in areas like palliative care and gerontology.

site_title: WeWork launches S'pore's largest co-working office in Collyer Quay
summary: WeWork has launched its largest co-working office in Singapore, 21 Collyer Quay, at 220,000 sq ft, exceeding the average floor size of its typical facilities. The facility is 60% committed and marks the company's 14th addition to its portfolio in Singapore, where it has seen 87% tenancy and 30% annual revenue growth. WeWork's investment is seen as a boost to the city's flexible work arrangements and co-working facilities, with the government backing the concept. The launch is also a milestone for the 12-year-old company, which is projecting to turn profitable by the end of this year.

site_title: Developer to launch Perfect Ten's second tower in Bukit Timah
summary: Perfect Ten, a luxury freehold project in Bukit Timah, will launch 55 units of its second 115-unit tower on Saturday. Prices start from $2.1 million for two-bedroom units and $3.5 million for three-bedroom units. The project has achieved 83% sales of its first tower, with a total sales volume of $285 million. The second tower features high ceilings, open-floor plans, and European brands' fittings and appliances. The project is popular among locals and families due to its proximity to reputable schools and amenities.

site_title: Canadian warship docks here as part of visit to Asia-Pacific
summary: The Canadian warship HMCS Winnipeg arrived in Singapore as part of a six-month deployment to the Asia-Pacific region, marking the seventh Canadian ship to visit the country in five years. The frigate will dock at Changi Naval Base for maintenance and to provide rest to the 240 sailors on board. During its visit, HMCS Winnipeg will engage in training exercises with regional militaries and international partners, strengthening Canada's presence in the region and security ties with Singapore. The ship will also visit ports in Malaysia, Cambodia, Thailand, and Japan before departing for its next destinations.

site_title: Programming to cyber security: what it takes to be a banker today
summary: The finance industry is becoming increasingly complex, requiring bankers to possess a wide range of skill sets, including computer programming and cyber security. Experts at a forum organized by The Straits Times and UBS emphasized the need for students to develop skills such as data analytics, stakeholder engagement, and communication. Successful bankers must also be informed about current events and cultivate a habit of reading widely. Additionally, curiosity, teamwork, and collaboration are key attributes that can help job seekers stand out in the industry.

site_title: Police investigating attack on two women at Marquee nightclub
summary: Two women, Leeanne O'Donnell, 23, and Julia Wong, 25, were attacked at Marquee nightclub in Marina Bay Sands on Saturday. The incident occurred when a man with chin-length hair approached Ms. Wong, punched and pushed her off a podium, and later punched Ms. O'Donnell when she tried to defend her. The attackers fled after the bouncers arrived, and both women were hospitalized with injuries. The police confirmed a report was lodged and investigations are ongoing. The women are recovering and plan to return to the club after they recover, although the incident has left them scarred.

site_title: Broad support for expanded law, but dorm operators seek greater clarity
summary: Singapore's expansion of the Foreign Employee Dormitories Act (Feda) to regulate 1,600 migrant worker dormitories has drawn broad support from industry associations and NGOs. The law, set to take effect in April 2023, will apply to dorms with 7 beds or more, introducing four licence classes and tiered requirements. However, dorm operators, particularly smaller ones, are seeking greater clarity on new licensing conditions and enforcement, citing concerns over added administrative costs and infrastructural upgrades, such as en-suite toilets for every six residents. The Ministry of Manpower is in talks with operators to develop a transition plan.

site_title: Single law for 1,600 worker dorms to help curb disease outbreaks
summary: Singapore will regulate approximately 1,600 worker dorms, housing around 440,000 migrant workers, under a single law starting April 1 next year. The Foreign Employee Dormitories Act (Feda) will be expanded to cover smaller dorms with 7 beds or more, improving living standards and disease outbreak containment. The law will have four licence classes, with stricter requirements for larger dorms, and existing smaller dorms will need to meet some new requirements starting next April.

site_title: Pogba a doubt for World Cup after operation on right knee
summary: France midfielder Paul Pogba's World Cup hopes are uncertain after undergoing knee surgery. The 29-year-old injured his right knee in July and initially opted against surgery, but changed his mind after returning to training. Coach Massimiliano Allegri believes Pogba may not play for Juventus until January. Pogba's relationship with teammate Kylian Mbappe appears unaffected, with Mbappe dismissing claims of a rift following a blackmail affair involving Pogba's family.

site_title: E-commerce sales in Singapore seen to reach $19.7b by 2027
summary: E-commerce sales in Singapore are expected to reach $19.7 billion by 2027, despite slower growth this year, according to a report by Meta and Bain & Company. The forecast reflects optimism over South-east Asia's long-term growth, driven by the growing digital consumer population. Digital consumers in the region are expected to account for 88% of the population by 2027, with e-commerce gross merchandise value reaching $280 billion. Consumers in Singapore spent more per transaction this year, with online basket sizes increasing to $131.

site_title: Company briefs: Lufthansa
summary: Lufthansa prepares an improved offer to pilots threatening to strike, aiming to avert disruptions at its main airports. The VC pilots' union has threatened to go on strike starting Sept 8, adding to 8,000 already cancelled flights. The airline will hold talks with the union on Tuesday, warning of a "massive" impact if a strike occurs. Meanwhile, Binance announces the conversion of existing USD Coin and new deposits into its own stablecoin, starting on Sept 29.

site_title: Tuesday's fast work by horses engaged at Kranji on Saturday
summary: Horse racing results from Kranji on Saturday and Monday showed several fast performances. Hongkong Great set a new track record in Class 2 with a time of 36.2 seconds. Other notable winners included King Louis, Wan Legacy, and Spirit Of Big Bang. In the Restricted Maiden, Two Million and Golden Brown secured victories with times of 39.5 and 41.4 seconds, respectively. The results suggest a strong competition in the racing events.

site_title: S'pore stocks end with slight gain amid quiet trading across region
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.3% to 3,224.18, with 1.85 billion shares traded worth $957.2 million. The Straits Times Index (STI) had more decliners (247) than gainers (240). Jardine Cycle & Carriage and Sembcorp Industries were the top gainers, with share price increases of 6.3% and 4.5% respectively. China's economy saw a boost with Shanghai and Shenzhen indexes rising 1.4% and 1.2% respectively, following fresh stimulus measures.

site_title: Crypto funding in S'pore falls in first half of year after record 2021
summary: Funding to cryptocurrency companies in Singapore declined to US$539.1 million in the first half of 2022, down from US$1.3 billion in the second half of last year, amid a market rout. Despite this, the sector saw more deals involving significant start-up investments, with two-thirds coming from seed and early-stage venture capital funding. The industry also saw seven exit or merger deals, according to a KPMG report. Investment is expected to return to a long-term growth trajectory, with focus on infrastructure for decentralised finance and governance risk.

site_title: Suppliers quit Macau's beleaguered casino scene for S'pore, Philippines
summary: Macau's casino industry continues to decline due to China's Covid-19-zero policy, with suppliers relocating to more welcoming markets. Suppliers such as Light & Wonder and a Japanese equipment maker are moving expatriate staff to the Philippines and Singapore, citing supply chain challenges and waning demand. Macau's gaming revenue has fallen to 9% of pre-pandemic levels, while Singapore and the Philippines have seen revenue growth. The trend is expected to accelerate, with Macau's government imposing a cap of 12,000 gaming machines in 2023, further exacerbating the decline of the once-bustling casino scene.

site_title: Sembcorp Industries sells India coal-fired power plants for $2.1b
summary: Sembcorp Industries sold its stake in Sembcorp Energy India (SEIL), India's largest independent power producer, to Tanweer Infrastructure for $2.1 billion. This sale will reduce Sembcorp's greenhouse gas emissions by over 37% and enable it to meet its 2025 emissions target six months ahead of schedule. The move will also increase the share of renewable energy in Sembcorp's portfolio to over 50%, up from 43%. The sale's proceeds will be used to decarbonize the company, improve debt servicing, and invest in green assets, ultimately benefiting shareholders with higher dividends.

site_title: Sembmarine expects its order book to grow further this year
summary: Sembcorp Marine expects its order book to grow further this year, driven by an improving outlook for oil, gas, and renewable energy. The company's president and CEO, Wong Weng Sun, attributed the firmer outlook to the energy crisis and the growing demand for immediate action to overcome the existing energy shortage. Despite four consecutive years of losses, Sembmarine is starting to see business recover, with its net order book reaching $2.5 billion. The company's merger with Keppel Offshore & Marine is expected to result in a combined order book of over $10 billion, paving the way for the new entity to become profitable.

site_title: Sports World: Vinicius now Spanish, frees up non-EU spot
summary: Brazilian footballer Vinicius Junior has acquired Spanish nationality, allowing Real Madrid to register a non-EU player. This move frees up a spot for another non-EU player under Spanish La Liga rules. Meanwhile, Carlos Queiroz is set to return as Iran's coach ahead of the World Cup, and the Australian Football League has secured a record $4.3 billion broadcast rights deal. Dutch track star Sifan Hassan is considering a move to the marathon, citing her need for a "very big challenge" after her Tokyo Olympics campaign.

site_title: Joshua ready to accept Fury bout
summary: Anthony Joshua has accepted a public challenge from Tyson Fury to a "Battle of Britain" fight for the WBC heavyweight championship in December, despite recent losses. Joshua, 32, is match fit after a 12-round fight against Oleksandr Usyk in August and is willing to fight Fury, 34, if he sticks to his word. Joshua's management team has been contacted by Fury, who has announced plans to fight in the next few months. A unification bout between Fury and Usyk is also being discussed for 2023.

site_title: Billionaire client says Credit Suisse Trust failed to prevent his loss of $1.78b
summary: Former Georgian prime minister Bidzina Ivanishvili alleges that a Credit Suisse Trust unit failed to prevent him from losing US$1.27 billion due to the fraudulent actions of its former banker, Patrice Lescaudron. Ivanishvili claims the trust unit did not safeguard his investments and take steps to prevent losses linked to Lescaudron's misconduct. The case comes as Credit Suisse faces a string of scandals and aims to cut costs to recover from setbacks. Ivanishvili's lawyers argue that the trust unit should be held liable for the losses, while Credit Suisse Trust claims the proceedings are "overreaching" and the bank did not have actual knowledge of the misconduct.

site_title: Swiatek breaks new ground in New York, faces Pegula in q-finals
summary: Iga Swiatek became the first Polish woman to reach the US Open quarter-finals, defeating Jule Niemeier 2-6, 6-4, 6-0. The French Open champion will face US eighth seed Jessica Pegula in the quarter-finals. The match was marred by 15 double faults and 76 unforced errors. Swiatek credited her success to her walk-on playlist, which she has stuck to throughout the year. Pegula, a Wimbledon quarter-finalist, defeated Petra Kvitova in straight sets to set up a quarter-final clash against Swiatek.

site_title: Next 24 hours
summary: Key events and sports schedules are listed for the next 24 hours. The Diamond League Zurich athletics event is set to begin, while cycling's La Vuelta Stage 17 will take place. Football matches in the UEFA Champions League will be played, including Napoli vs Liverpool and Tottenham vs Marseille. Tennis fans can catch the US Open on the final day, with multiple channels airing the event. Viewers can access schedules and updates on the Singtel and StarHub websites or check the on-screen TV guide.

site_title: Incredibly proud as not even Tiger has won FedExCup thrice
summary: Rory McIlroy has won the FedExCup for the third time, a record achievement even surpassing Tiger Woods. The win comes after a strong performance at the tournament, where McIlroy clawed his way back from a 10-shot deficit to take the lead. McIlroy expressed pride in his resilience and dedication to the sport, crediting his caddie for saying he deserved the win. He also praised Scottie Scheffler, the current world No. 1, who had a remarkable season but was edged out by McIlroy. The win marks a satisfying end to a challenging year for McIlroy, who believes the PGA Tour is the best place to play elite golf.

site_title: Conte wants Champions League glory as manager
summary: Tottenham Hotspur manager Antonio Conte has expressed his ambition to win the Champions League, his first major European trophy as a manager. Conte, whose team faces French side Marseille in their Group D opener, believes his players are in their element when competing in the Champions League. Tottenham, who finished fourth in the Premier League last season, have a strong early season form and are expected to go far in the competition, with Harry Kane spearheading the attack. Marseille, under coach Igor Tudor, are underdogs but have recent European success, having reached the semi-finals of the Europa Conference League last season.

site_title: Defector Smith among PGA best-player nominees
summary: Cameron Smith, a LIV Golf Invitational Series member, is one of three nominees for the 2021-22 PGA Tour Player of the Year award, alongside Rory McIlroy and Scottie Scheffler. Despite winning The Players Championship and the British Open, Smith is unlikely to win due to his recent switch to LIV Golf, which has led to him being suspended from the PGA Tour. Scheffler, who had a standout season with multiple victories, is the likely favorite to win, according to Rory McIlroy. Voting runs until Friday.

site_title: Alcaraz, Sinner set up next-generation clash
summary: Carlos Alcaraz, 19, reached the US Open semi-finals by defeating Marin Cilic 6-4, 3-6, 6-4, 4-6, 6-3. The match lasted 3 hours and 53 minutes, with Alcaraz sealing the win on his first match point. He will face 21-year-old Jannik Sinner, who also won his match, in the semi-finals. The victory sets up a potential showdown between the two young players, with Alcaraz looking to become the youngest world No. 1 when the ATP rankings are updated.

site_title: Nadal no more in the moment
summary: Rafael Nadal suffered his earliest defeat at a Slam in over five years, losing to Frances Tiafoe 6-4, 4-6, 6-4, 6-3 at the US Open. Nadal, 36, was unable to regain his momentum after a strong start, and his game lacked spark and depth. The defeat marked a significant setback in his quest for Grand Slam titles, as he trailed Roger Federer and Novak Djokovic in the chase for the most singles titles. Nadal, who is expecting his first child, hinted that his family will take precedence over his tennis career.

site_title: Fitzsimmons reveals three aces
summary: Leading trainer Tim Fitzsimmons has three promising horses for the upcoming Kranji race on Saturday. Dancing Light, a four-year-old son of Street Boss, has won two trials and is set to compete in a Class 4 sprint. Golden Brown, a three-year-old, has also shown impressive form at trials and is expected to make his racing debut. Mr Black Back, a three-year-old sired by Snitzel, has a promising family line and may also make a mark in the Class 4 sprint over 1,200m.

site_title: Fighter Laporte 'confident' for trial
summary: Former French rugby coach Bernard Laporte, 58, goes on trial on corruption and influence peddling charges related to awarding a shirt sponsor contract to a close friend, Mohed Altrad, in a case that could impact France's hosting of the Rugby World Cup in 2023. Laporte's lawyer claims the accusations are "completely trumped up," while France's financial crimes unit disagrees, citing evidence of illegal influence peddling and passive corruption. The trial runs until September 22, and Laporte's reputation has already been impacted despite being re-elected as FFR boss in 2020.

site_title: Sikh cricketer trolled for dropped catch
summary: Indian cricketer Arshdeep Singh faced online abuse after dropping a crucial catch in a match against Pakistan, with many targeting him due to his Sikh minority status. His Wikipedia entry was briefly altered to link him to the Khalistan Sikh separatist movement, prompting the government to intervene. Star player Virat Kohli backed Singh, stating that anyone can make a mistake, while fellow Muslim player Mohammed Shami also showed support. The incident highlights the ongoing issue of hate messages targeting India's religious minorities, with Kohli previously defending Shami against similar abuse in 2021.

site_title: Cape return will see Warrior keen to do battle
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The article provides form analysis for various horse racing events in South Africa. The top contenders for each event are identified, including favorites like Light Speed and Kingdom of Heaven, as well as horses with potential for improvement, such as I'll Slip Away and Allende. The article also highlights horses with strong track experience, like Warrior and HYDE PARK, and those with good form, like Enchanted Creek and Beneath The Moon. The analysis provides insights into the strengths and weaknesses of each horse, helping readers make informed decisions about their betting strategies.

site_title: 2024 Champs League format 'already a success'
summary: Paris Saint-Germain president Nasser Al-Khelaifi claims the revamped 2024 Champions League format is already a success, citing a 150% increase in TV rights sales in the US and significant gains in the UK and France. The format change, which expands the group stage to 36 clubs, is expected to shake up the competition and increase TV revenue, with global deals worth €15 billion (S$20.9 billion) for the next three seasons. Al-Khelaifi also highlighted the need for football investment to grow and criticized clubs with "disastrous debt" that can be passed on to successors.

site_title: Crypto funding in S'pore falls in first half of 2022 from last year's record: KPMG report
summary: Funding to cryptocurrency companies in Singapore decreased to US$539.1 million in the first half of 2022, down from US$1.3 billion in the same period last year, amid a market rout. Despite this, the sector saw seven exit or merger deals and attracted smaller funding amounts, with two-thirds coming from seed and early-stage venture capital funding. The industry is expected to experience growth in infrastructure funding for decentralized finance, governance risk, and compliance.

site_title: Sacred Gift serves notice of good things
summary: Sacred Gift, a six-time winner, demonstrated his prowess on the Polytrack, finishing a strong winner in his 1,000m trial. Despite being slow out of the barriers, the seven-year-old horse showed impressive form, fanning out for a run to the line and holding off challengers to win by a neck and a head. Trainer Jerome Tan will now plot a course for a potential seventh win, and fans are encouraged to support Sacred Gift in his next outing on the Polytrack.

site_title: Foul play claims rejected
summary: AlphaTauri has condemned online abuse and accusations of foul play against the team and Red Bull's head of strategy, Hannah Schmitz, following Yuki Tsunoda's retirement in the Dutch Grand Prix. Tsunoda initially stopped on the track due to a suspected wheel issue, triggering a virtual safety car that helped Red Bull's Max Verstappen win. Mercedes' Lewis Hamilton questioned the incident, suggesting it may have affected the outcome. AlphaTauri denies foul play, stating that Tsunoda had a car failure that the team didn't immediately detect, and that Schmitz was unfairly targeted.

site_title: Football: Dinamo shock Chelsea in Champions League, ruin Aubameyang's debut
summary: Chelsea suffered a 1-0 defeat to Dinamo Zagreb in their Champions League match, ruining Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang's debut. Mislav Orsic scored the only goal in the 13th minute, exploiting Chelsea's soft centre. The defeat marks Chelsea's third successive away loss in all competitions, despite spending £250 million on new signings since the end of last season. Aubameyang, who joined Chelsea for £10.3 million, struggled to make an impact and was replaced by Armando Broja in the 61st minute.

site_title: Football: Nagelsmann hopes Bayern 'wake up' ahead of Inter clash
summary: Bayern Munich coach Julian Nagelsmann attributed his team's stuttering form to a lack of energy, despite having a strong goal difference of plus 14. Nagelsmann hopes his side will "wake up" ahead of their Champions League clash with Inter Milan, where they face a strong opponent with a similar defensive tactic to Borussia Monchengladbach and Union Berlin. Bayern remain favorites to win their 11th consecutive Bundesliga title, but Nagelsmann is concerned that his team needs to regain their energy to break down Inter's defense.

site_title: Nunez tipped to take off shortly
summary: Liverpool striker Darwin Nunez is expected to start scoring regularly for the Reds despite a slow start to the domestic campaign. Pundit Darren Bent believes Nunez's ban and slower start won't hinder his performance, citing his sharp skills and ability to create chances. Nunez faces a new challenge in the Champions League opener against Napoli, where he'll be up against prolific scorer Khvicha Kvaratskhelia, and will look to build on his previous European performances.

site_title: Football: Barcelona will 'dream big' in Champions League says Xavi
summary: Barcelona coach Xavi Hernandez expressed confidence in his team's ability to challenge for the Champions League title this season. Despite being knocked out of the competition in the group stage last year, Xavi welcomed the pressure to win, saying "We will compete and dream big." The team has made significant signings, including Robert Lewandowski, and has a strong squad with players like Raphinha, Ousmane Dembele, and Ansu Fati performing well. Xavi aims to advance to the knockout stages and ultimately win the title, starting with Wednesday's opener against Viktoria Plzen.

site_title: Mixed views on huge wins
summary: The Asian Netball Championship has sparked mixed opinions on the impact of its one-sided games. The dominant performances of top teams, such as Singapore's 103-3 win over Japan and Sri Lanka's 102-14 victory over India, have raised concerns that the tournament is not showcasing the sport's full potential. However, others argue that these lopsided matches are necessary to separate the top teams from the rest and ensure a competitive tournament. The contrasting views highlight the need for a balanced approach in assessing the championship's success.

site_title: All-women halfway house to help offenders reintegrate into society
summary: A new all-women halfway house, The Rise Above Halfway House, will open in Singapore by the end of September, enabling 30 women offenders to reintegrate into society. The facility, run by the Singapore Muslim Women's Association, will provide programmes such as journalling and reflection circles to help residents cope with feelings of guilt, shame, and regret. Minister of State Muhammad Faishal Ibrahim emphasized the importance of a secular halfway house, allowing women offenders from diverse backgrounds to receive help, and Associate Professor Faishal noted that the facility's family-centric approach will aid women in re-establishing their multiple roles.

site_title: Broad support for expanded dormitories law, but operators worried about transition costs
summary: Singapore's expanded Dormitories Act, which will regulate 1,600 migrant worker dormitories from April 1, 2023, has garnered broad support from industry associations and NGOs. The law, which was initially introduced in 2016, will now apply to smaller dorms with seven beds or more. However, operators are concerned about transition costs, licensing conditions, and enforcement. They are seeking clarity on non-infrastructure-related requirements and assurance that the Ministry of Manpower will ensure enforcement. The expanded law aims to improve living standards for migrant workers, but its effectiveness will depend on its implementation and enforcement.

site_title: Tennis: Terrific Ruud beats Berrettini to reach US Open semi-final
summary: Norway's Casper Ruud defeated 13th seed Matteo Berrettini 6-1 6-4 7-6(4) to reach the US Open semi-final. Ruud, the French Open runner-up, controlled the match, especially in the first set. Berrettini, sidelined multiple times this season, found his form in the third set but Ruud made a terrific comeback, breaking Berrettini in the ninth and never trailing in the tiebreak. The win sets up a potential showdown for the world number one ranking against third seed Carlos Alcaraz.

site_title: Drunk woman who punched SCDF paramedic jailed one week
summary: A 32-year-old intoxicated woman, Retana Rose Gracielle De Gracia, was sentenced to one-week jail for punching and slapping a Singapore Civil Defence Force (SCDF) paramedic, Muhammad Danial Rennie, after he told her not to touch ambulance equipment. The incident occurred on November 18 last year, when De Gracia was found passed out in front of a taxi. She pleaded guilty to using criminal force on a public servant and was given a short jail term to deter others from committing similar offenses.

site_title: Football: Tottenham have been penalised, fumes Conte over fixture pile-up
summary: Tottenham Hotspur manager Antonio Conte expressed frustration over the team's congested schedule, penalized with more games in a shorter period than other teams. Conte called for the Premier League to ease the burden, stating that one extra day between games can "completely change your life" and lead to dropped points. Tottenham face three matches in a week, starting with a Champions League opener, and are currently without injured Brazilian forward Lucas Moura. Conte praised his former teammate Igor Tudor, now Marseille manager, and expressed his team's desire to avoid the hectic schedule.

site_title: Super Wealthy looks capable of Cup double
summary: Trainer David Hayes is confident Super Wealthy can capture consecutive wins in the Class 1 HKSAR Chief Executive's Cup Handicap at Sha Tin on Sunday. Super Wealthy, a Group 3-winning horse, returns after a pair of trials and minor surgery, and Hayes believes he has a good chance against Sky Field, Lucky Sweynesse, and others. Rated 114, Super Wealthy has a history of competing well at the top level, including a 2021 Group 3 National Day Cup Handicap win.

site_title: Video of 2 cleaners jamming with a discarded piano goes viral on TikTok
summary: Two cleaners in Singapore, Shintaro Tay, and his colleague, posted a video on TikTok of themselves playing a discarded piano in the bin centre, where they were waiting out the rain. The impromptu jam session went viral, surprising the duo with its widespread popularity. The unexpected success of their video highlights the power of creativity and spontaneity in unexpected places.

site_title: Football: Forget Old Firm thrashing, Rangers are a threat - says Ajax coach
summary: Ajax Amsterdam coach Alfred Schreuder warns his team not to underestimate Rangers ahead of their Champions League Group A clash. Despite Rangers' heavy 4-0 loss to Celtic, Schreuder believes they will try to apply similar pressure on Ajax. Ajax have won five out of five in the Eredivisie and are two points clear at the top, but Schreuder notes his side is not yet at top form. A winning start is crucial for Ajax, and Schreuder emphasizes the importance of playing for the win while showing respect for the opponent.

site_title: Ukraine’s Zelensky ‘rings’ NYSE bell, seeks US$400b in foreign investment
summary: Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky remotely rang the NYSE opening bell, seeking $400 billion in foreign investment to rebuild the country's economy, which was severely damaged by Russia's invasion. Zelensky's government has launched a platform of over 500 projects in 10 key sectors, including military-industrial complex, energy, and pharmaceuticals. The appeal comes as Ukraine seeks $5 billion in international aid each month to keep its economy running, and amid ongoing humanitarian and security efforts from the US and its allies.

site_title: S'pore co-sharing spaces set to grow as WeWork launches largest such facility here
summary: WeWork has launched its largest co-working facility in Singapore, occupying the former HSBC building at 21 Collyer Quay. The 220,000 sq ft space is three times larger than the average floor size of its typical facilities, with 700 spaces in 150 cities worldwide. The facility is 60% committed, amid continued demand for hybrid work, and is expected to increase Singapore's total flexible space stock by 6% this year. WeWork's presence in Singapore is set to expand, with the company employing 170 staff and making the city-state its regional headquarters.

site_title: Sembmarine order book expected to grow further this year on bullish sector outlook
summary: Sembmarine, a marine and offshore engineering group, expects its order book to grow further this year due to a bullish sector outlook. The company's president and CEO, Wong Weng Sun, stated that the energy crisis has contributed to the firmer outlook, and order visibility is clearer. Sembmarine posted a net loss of $142.9 million for the half year ended June 30, but its net order book has crossed $2.5 billion after securing $1.9 billion worth of new orders. The proposed merger with Keppel Offshore & Marine will result in a combined order book of over $10 billion.

site_title: Cyclist injured after bike wheel caught in drain grating sues PUB for at least $578k
summary: A cyclist, Maung Maung Aung Soe Thu, is suing PUB for at least $578,000 after his front wheel got caught in a drain grating on Changi Point Coastal Walk in 2021, causing him severe injuries. PUB denies negligence, citing low probability of accidents and astronomical costs of inspecting and replacing gratings. The case argues that PUB breached its duty of care by failing to ensure safe road conditions. A three-day hearing has opened in the High Court to determine liability, with a separate hearing to assess damages if PUB is found liable.

site_title: Marcos gets grand welcome from Filipinos in Singapore
summary: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. received a grand welcome from Filipinos in Singapore on the first day of his two-day state visit, with an estimated 2,000 supporters attending a gathering at the National University of Singapore. Marcos, who won 36,000 votes in Singapore in the May presidential elections, expressed gratitude to his supporters and promised to work on job creation and improving the Philippines. He also vowed to provide scholarships, healthcare benefits, and housing programs for families of migrant workers, aiming to bring in more job-generating investments to the country.

site_title: Push for prefab, digital tech use as blueprint is refreshed for built environment sector
summary: Singapore's built environment sector has adopted the prefabricated prefinished volumetric construction (PPVC) method, which improved manpower productivity by 40% and reduced pollution and noise issues. The method involves precasting 3D modules off-site, then stacking and installing them on-site. The sector has also set targets for 80% of public sector buildings and 40% of private sector buildings to adopt smart facility management technologies by 2030. The refreshed industry transformation map aims to build a productive, resilient sector that contributes to a sustainable environment and combats climate change.

site_title: Getting it right for net zero by 2050
summary: Singapore has set a target to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050, aligning with climate scientists' recommendations. The decision comes after a detailed action plan was developed to reduce emissions, unlike the trend of setting targets without a plan. This move follows other countries' pledges to reach net-zero emissions, made before the COP26 climate summit in Glasgow. Climate action advocates have welcomed the move, recognizing the significance of Singapore's commitment to reducing its carbon footprint by 2050.

site_title: Data, tech literacy, communication skills, reading habit key for career in banking, students told
summary: A forum organised by The Straits Times and UBS discussed the skills, habits, and attributes needed for a career in banking and finance. Experts emphasized the importance of data literacy, communication skills, and reading habits in the industry. Key skills in demand include programming, cyber security, and data analytics, as well as stakeholder engagement and stakeholder management. Attendees also learned about the need for curiosity, collaboration, and a willingness to learn. The event aimed to prepare students for a career in the financial sector, with UBS sponsoring digital subscriptions for participants.

site_title: Boxing: Joshua ready to take up Fury's 'Battle of Britain' challenge
summary: Anthony Joshua has accepted a public challenge from Tyson Fury to a "Battle of Britain" for the WBC heavyweight championship, with a possible fight set for December. Joshua, who lost to Oleksandr Usyk in August, wants to return to the ring before the end of the year. Fury, who has previously announced his retirement, now intends to fight Joshua instead. Joshua's management team has been contacted, and a fight date will be announced if Joshua is interested. The bout could be a unification fight between the WBC and other heavyweight champions.

site_title: Watches.com subsidiary has goods seized in Hong Kong; director and staff out on bail
summary: A subsidiary of Watches.com, CKLY Trading Limited (CTL), in Hong Kong has had about 500 watches worth $30,000 seized by Customs officers due to alleged false trade descriptions and forged trademarks. CTL's director, Christian Heilesen, and a sales employee were released on bail after assisting with the investigation. Shares of Watches.com fell 12.5% following the news. Both companies claim they are not liable and will contest the allegations vigorously.

site_title: Football: PSG face backlash for 'inappropriate' mockery of train plea
summary: Paris Saint-Germain coach Christophe Galtier and star player Kylian Mbappe faced backlash after mocking a suggestion to take the train instead of private planes for short-haul travel. Galtier joked about traveling by "sand-yacht" and Mbappe laughed uncontrollably during a press conference. The team, which is owned by Qatar, has been criticized for its carbon footprint, with some calling for restrictions on private jet travel to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. PSG has defended its travel choices, citing security concerns and night travel difficulties.

site_title: Staff from 6 banks deployed at police's Anti-Scam Command office for faster response to cases
summary: Singapore's Anti-Scam Command office has deployed staff from six banks to aid in scam investigations, resulting in the recovery of over $1.5 million from more than 40 scam cases. The collaboration has increased the speed of interventions, with the police able to quickly freeze bank accounts and trace funds. Since the deployment, the Anti-Scam Command has also issued warnings to over 95,000 individuals and coordinated 12 operations, leading to the arrest of over 3,900 scammers and money mules. This move is seen as a significant step forward in the police's scam-fighting efforts.

site_title: Canadian warship docks at Changi Naval Base in deployment to Asia-Pacific
summary: A Canadian warship, HMCS Winnipeg, docked at Changi Naval Base in Singapore as part of a six-month deployment to the Asia-Pacific region. This is the seventh Canadian ship to visit Singapore in five years, showcasing strengthened bilateral defence and security ties. The frigate will engage in regional security and stability efforts, including training exercises with regional militaries, before visiting ports in Malaysia, Cambodia, Thailand, and Japan. The deployment is part of Operation Projection, which aims to increase Canada's presence in the region and enhance relationships with allies and partners.

site_title: Golf: LIV recruit Smith among nominees for PGA Tour Player of the Year
summary: Australian golfer Cameron Smith has been nominated for PGA Tour Player of the Year, alongside Scottie Scheffler and Rory McIlroy. Smith, who won his first Major at the British Open and joined LIV Golf, is one of the highest-ranked players to make the switch. The winner will be determined by PGA Tour members who played in at least 15 FedEx Cup events. Despite the PGA Tour previously suspending members who compete on LIV Golf, Smith's nomination highlights the ongoing tension between the two tours. Voting will close on Friday.

site_title: Wafers, two sauces being recalled after SFA finds undeclared allergens in them
summary: The Singapore Food Agency (SFA) has recalled three products due to undeclared allergens. Sinhua Hock Kee Trading's Fukutoku Seika Soft Cream Wafers contained egg white and wheat flour, while New Intention Trading Co's ABC Sweet Soy Sauce and Arklife Distributors' ABC Sambal Ayam Goreng Sauce contained sulphur dioxide and benzoic acid, respectively. The recalls are ongoing, with consumers advised to contact their point of purchase for enquiries if they are allergic to the allergens. The products were imported from Indonesia and Japan, with the allergens not posing a food safety issue to consumers in general.

site_title: Netball: Big scorelines at the Asian Netball C'ship draw mixed reactions
summary: The Asian Netball Championship has seen significant scoreline differences, with games such as Singapore 103, Japan 3 and Sri Lanka 102, India 14 drawing mixed reactions. Critics argue that large score gaps may hinder the growth of the sport, as they can be discouraging for participating countries. However, supporters believe the victories for host Singapore and Sri Lanka can boost the sport's popularity and national pride. The outcome highlights the challenges of promoting netball globally.

site_title: 1,600 worker dorms to come under single law next year in move to contain disease outbreaks quickly
summary: Singapore plans to regulate about 1,600 dormitories with 7 beds or more under a single law, the Foreign Employee Dormitories Act (Feda), from April 1 next year. The law will cover smaller dorms, which currently fall under different regulations, and impose essential living standards such as minimum space per resident and maximum room occupancy. The move aims to contain disease outbreaks and improve living standards for migrant workers, with existing smaller dorms required to meet some new requirements from next April.

site_title: Developer backed by tycoon Li Ka Shing to launch Perfect Ten's second tower in Bukit Timah
summary: Developer CK Asset Holdings, backed by tycoon Li Ka Shing, is launching 55 units of its second tower in Perfect Ten's Bukit Timah project on September 10. The units feature high ceilings and open-floor plans, with prices starting from $2.1 million to $4.1 million. The first tower achieved $285 million in sales volume, with 96 units sold at an average price of $3,000 per sq ft. The new tower offers panoramic views and a 50m-long infinity pool, and is designed by CK Asset's in-house design team.

site_title: EDB reviewing Tech.Pass after MOM launches pass for top talent in all sectors
summary: Singapore's Tech.Pass may be merged with the new Overseas Networks and Expertise Pass, which offers similar flexibility to top foreign professionals in all sectors, not just technology. The new pass allows pass holders to start a business and hold multiple employment roles simultaneously. Unveiled by Manpower Minister Tan See Leng, the pass aims to attract top talent to Singapore.

site_title: Tennis: Alcaraz, 19, wins late-night thriller to set up 'next-gen' clash with Sinner, 21
summary: Carlos Alcaraz, 19, defeated Marin Cilic 6-4, 3-6, 6-4, 4-6, 6-3 at the US Open on September 5, advancing to a quarter-final clash against Jannik Sinner. The match lasted 3 hours and 53 minutes, finishing at 2:24 am due to rain. Alcaraz's victory sets up a "next-gen" matchup against Sinner, with the Spaniard in contention to become the youngest world No. 1 after the final.

site_title: 4 months' jail for ex-ITE lecturer who took students' upskirt videos, photos on campus
summary: A Singaporean former lecturer, Darren Quek Sze-Wen, was sentenced to four months' jail for taking upskirt videos and photos of multiple students on campus. Quek, 48, admitted to committing the offences over four to five months, targeting at least five victims. His mobile phone was found to contain 133 upskirt images and videos. He was charged with insulting a woman's modesty and attempting to commit the offence, with three other charges considered during sentencing.

site_title: More to social cohesion than just racial and religious harmony, says SMU president
summary: Singapore's President Lily Kong emphasizes that social cohesion requires more than just racial and religious harmony, citing factors such as migration, multiculturalism, social and economic inequality, and inter-generational relationships as potential fault lines. Kong calls for a focus on building resilience and addressing these dimensions to foster a cohesive society. The International Conference on Cohesive Societies aims to engage over 800 delegates from 40 countries in conversations around faith, identity, and cohesion, highlighting the importance of solidarity, community, and inclusivity in building a cohesive society.

site_title: E-commerce sales in S'pore expected to reach $19.6b by 2027, despite slower growth this year
summary: E-commerce sales in Singapore are projected to reach US$19.6 billion by 2027, despite slower growth this year, with sales expected to grow to US$9 billion in 2022. The region's digital consumer population is expected to account for 88% of the population by 2027, driving growth in e-commerce gross merchandise value to US$280 billion. Consumers in Singapore spent more per transaction in 2022, with online basket sizes increasing to US$131, and are using more online platforms and switching brands for better value and quality products.

site_title: The Life List: Lee Jong-suk and Yoona’s friendship makes them a convincing couple in Big Mouth
summary: K-drama "Big Mouth" starring Lee Jong-suk and Girls' Generation's Yoona is a crime noir series that follows the story of an incompetent lawyer wrongly accused of being a notorious con man. Director Oh Choong-hwan praises the chemistry between the two leads, citing their long friendship as a key factor in their convincing on-screen relationship. The series, available on Disney+, marks Oh's first foray into the noir genre and showcases his secret to creating good TV: his personal passion and enthusiasm for the project.
