site_title: Binance to convert users' USDC into its own stablecoin
summary: Binance, the largest crypto exchange, will convert existing user balances and new deposits of USDC, USDP, and TUSD into its own stablecoin, BUSD, starting on September 29. This move effectively bans USDC from trading on the platform, citing the goal of enhancing liquidity and capital-efficiency for users. USDC, valued at nearly $52 billion, will be automatically converted to BUSD, but users can withdraw the other stablecoins when withdrawing funds from Binance.

site_title: Cricket: Sikh Indian player Arshdeep Singh trolled for dropped catch in Pakistan clash
summary: Indian cricketer Arshdeep Singh faced online abuse after dropping a crucial catch against Pakistan in the Asia Cup match. The abuse targeted Singh's Sikh faith, with some users falsely linking him to the Khalistan Sikh separatist movement. However, star player Virat Kohli defended Singh, stating that "anyone can make a mistake." This incident highlights the growing issue of online hate and bias targeting cricketers from India's religious minorities, similar to the 2021 abuse of Muslim player Mohammed Shami. The hashtag #IndiaWithArshdeep trended on Twitter in support of Singh.

site_title: Singapore hunts for global rainmakers with new One Pass expat visa: Tan See Leng
summary: Singapore introduces the Overseas Networks and Expertise (One) Pass, a 5-year visa allowing holders and partners to work, in an effort to attract global talent, particularly "rainmakers" in fields like science, tech, and finance. The move aims to boost innovation and increase productivity, with the goal of raising manufacturing value-add by 50% and annual exports to $1 trillion by 2030. Manpower Minister Tan See Leng emphasized that the government is not limiting the number of applicants and is targeting high-quality talent, rather than quantity.

site_title: Bed Bath & Beyond CFO's death ruled a suicide
summary: Bed Bath & Beyond's CFO, Gustavo Arnal, 52, has been ruled a suicide after falling from a New York skyscraper. The death came days after the retailer announced store closures and layoffs, and amid a lawsuit accusing the company of artificially inflating its stock price. Arnal joined Bed Bath & Beyond in 2020 and previously worked at Procter & Gamble and Avon. The company is evaluating the lawsuit, but claims the allegations are without merit. The retailer's fortunes have been declining since an attempt to sell more of its own brand goods.

site_title: NSmen and NSFs can now buy army gear on Lazada as SAF starts eMart on the platform
summary: Singapore's Singapore Armed Forces (SAF) has launched eMart on online marketplace Lazada, allowing NSmen and NSFs to purchase military gear online. The eMart, Lifestylemart, offers 20 military products, including essential items, with delivery fees starting at $1.49. However, eMart credits cannot be used on Lazada, and customers must pay with debit or credit cards. The partnership aims to provide greater convenience for servicemen with busy lives, while also allowing the SAF to reach more consumers. More collaborations with e-commerce partners are planned.

site_title: Runaway rise in global housing prices coming to an end: Surveys
summary: Global housing prices are expected to slow more than initially predicted over the next two years, with nearly all nine major housing markets forecast to decline. Interest rates and rising living costs are contributing to the slowdown, with prices needing to fall by double digits in several key markets to become affordable. Analysts predict modest price declines, with Canada, Australia, and New Zealand needing to fall 17.5-20% to reach affordability, while British prices need to fall 8.5%.

site_title: Supermodel Adriana Lima welcomes her third child
summary: Brazilian supermodel Adriana Lima has welcomed her third child, a baby boy named Cyan, born on August 29. The 41-year-old model, who was a Victoria's Secret model for two decades, shared the news on Instagram with a photo of the newborn's eye. This is her first child with boyfriend Andre Lemmers, a movie producer. Lima has two daughters with her ex-husband, Serbian basketball player Marko Jaric. The couple announced her pregnancy in February with a viral TikTok video.

images.alt_text: Brazilian model Adriana Lima walks the runway at the 2018 Victoria's Secret Fashion Show on November 8, 2018.

site_title: Club DJ Alan Walker will miss F1 Singapore Grand Prix, but is revved up for upcoming gig
summary: DJ Alan Walker will miss this year's Formula One Singapore Grand Prix due to his WalkerVerse global tour, but will perform in Singapore on September 9 at Marina Bay Sands Expo. Walker's upcoming show will feature his record Walkerverse Pt. 1, an experimental album released during the pandemic. The concert will deliver an immersive theatrical experience with stage design, lighting, and visuals. Walker, known for his hit song "Faded," aims to create catchy melodies and a unique "Alan Walker experience" for his fans.

site_title: Oil prices inch lower on symbolic Opec+ output cut
summary: Oil prices declined on Tuesday as Opec+ agreed to cut output by 100,000 barrels per day in October, a move seen as symbolic to bolster prices after a recent market slide. Brent crude futures fell 0.5% to $95.25, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 2.4% to $88.94. Analysts consider the cut to be largely symbolic, with limited impact on actual supply, and see it as a signal that Opec+ is closely watching demand to manage supply and keep oil prices afloat.

site_title: Man accused of dumping Felicia Teo's corpse in Punggol expected to plead guilty next month
summary: A 37-year-old man, Ahmad Danial Mohamed Rafa'ee, is expected to plead guilty to four charges related to the 2007 death of 19-year-old Felicia Teo. He will plead guilty to unlawfully depositing her corpse, misappropriating her belongings, giving false evidence, and fabricating false evidence. Ahmad was previously given a discharge not amounting to an acquittal for the murder charge, but the prosecution will still pursue the case as relevant information or evidence may emerge. The case involves Ahmad and an Indonesian man, Ragil Putra Setia Sukmarahjana, who is still at large.

site_title: Covid-19 showed that cohesive societies are born of choice and conviction: President Halimah
summary: President Halimah Yacob emphasized that cohesive societies are born of choice and conviction, citing the Covid-19 pandemic as a test of social cohesion. The pandemic highlighted the need for collective action and cooperation, but also deepened fault lines in societies, leading to bigotry, xenophobia, and hate crimes. The International Conference on Cohesive Societies in Singapore brought together over 800 participants to discuss how to foster harmony in diverse societies and promote social cohesion. Halimah called for safeguarding and promoting social cohesion, bridging divides, and harnessing diversity for the common good.

site_title: Tennis: Pliskova downs Azarenka to reach US Open's last eight
summary: Karolina Pliskova defeated Victoria Azarenka in three sets, 7-5, 6-7 (5-7), 6-2, to reach the quarter-finals of the US Open. The 30-year-old Czech player will face Aryna Sabalenka in the quarter-finals. Sabalenka overcame a leg injury to defeat Danielle Collins in a three-set match. The Belarusian player is looking forward to the match against Pliskova, citing maintaining composure as key to victory, as the two players share a 2-2 head-to-head record.

site_title: Hot Bods: I cannot do without snacks
summary: Influencer Rachel Yim, 26, and head of marketing Benjamin Tan, 29, share their fitness regimens and diets. Rachel prioritizes calisthenics, golf, and yoga, while Benjamin focuses on rock climbing and calisthenics. Both have busy schedules, with Rachel doing personal training once a week and Benjamin bouldering 2-4 times a week. Their diets consist of protein-rich foods, with Rachel favoring black coffee, salads, and snacks, and Benjamin eating oats, noodles, and protein-rich foods like egg whites and salmon. Both emphasize the importance of discipline in fitness and lifestyle.

images.alt_text: Influencer Rachel Yim and head of marketing Benjamin Tan.

site_title: China takes more visible measures to slow its currency’s descent
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China, has taken steps to slow its currency's descent by cutting the foreign exchange reserve requirement ratio to 6% starting September 15. The move also allows banks to hold less foreign currencies in reserve, increasing the supply of dollars and other currencies onshore. The renminbi's reference rate was set at 6.9096 per US dollar, marking the strongest-than-expected fixing for a 10th day. The measures aim to stabilize the weakening currency, but experts say more action may be needed if the renminbi approaches the psychological 7-per-dollar level.

site_title: PGA Tour player blog: Pretty cool to do something that not even Tiger has done in this game, says Rory McIlroy
summary: Rory McIlroy has become the first player in PGA Tour history to win the FedExCup three times, following his victory at the East Lake Golf Club. The 33-year-old golfer expressed pride and satisfaction with his achievement, noting that it's a unique accomplishment even for a legendary player like Tiger Woods. McIlroy attributed his success to his resilience and determination, and praised Scottie Scheffler for an outstanding season. The win marks a fitting conclusion to a challenging year for golf, and McIlroy hopes it will reinforce the PGA Tour's position as the premier golf tour in the world.

site_title: Wooing new blood to Singapore's interfaith networks
summary: Singapore's interfaith networks aim to build racial and religious ties through grassroots efforts. In 2002, former leader of a Malay youth organisation, Abdullah Shafiie, was tasked with developing these networks. With the help of ESM Goh Chok Tong and Minister Edwin Tong, various harmony circles were established, led by chairmen from different backgrounds. The initiative seeks to foster a sense of community and understanding among Singapore's diverse populations.

site_title: Singapore eyes 2050 for net-zero emissions
summary: Singapore is considering setting 2050 as the year its greenhouse gas emissions reach net zero, according to a consultation exercise launched by the National Climate Change Secretariat. The country is also reviewing its 2030 climate target, which currently allows for 65 million tonnes of emissions. The public can provide feedback on the proposed timeline and target until September 26. Achieving net-zero emissions would involve significantly reducing greenhouse gas emissions by switching to renewable energy sources and minimizing fossil fuel use.

site_title: Tennis: 'I am not in that moment anymore,' says Nadal as he falls to a younger man
summary: Rafael Nadal lost to Frances Tiafoe in the US Open last-16, his earliest Grand Slam loss in six years. Nadal, 36, fell to the 26th-ranked American 6-4, 4-6, 6-4, 6-3. The defeat marked Nadal's first Grand Slam loss of 2022 after an abdominal strain and a stress fracture. Nadal hinted at his retirement plans, saying "I am not in that moment anymore" and that he needs to focus on his personal life, including becoming a father for the first time.

site_title: 47% jump in cyber extortion cases in first half of year
summary: Cyber extortion cases surged 47% in the first half of this year, with 203 reported cases and over $754,000 lost by victims. Most cases involve tricking victims into appearing nude or performing sexual acts on webcam, with Instagram being the most common platform used to approach victims. Experts warn that the pandemic's increase in online activity has made people more vulnerable to exploitation, and perpetrators are using new tactics to target young people.

site_title: Dance review: Glitch by Raw Moves is more about ideas than dance
summary: A multidisciplinary performance, "Glitch" by RAW Moves, was held at the Goodman Arts Centre on September 1, combining dance, visual arts, and experimental music. The work, created by Wu Jun Han, Ricky Sim, and Nidya Shanthini Manokara, explores the relationship between humans and machines. The performance engages trained dancers to unravel this concept, with the entire event serving as an immersive experience. "Glitch" is more focused on ideas than traditional dance, presenting a unique blend of art forms.

images.alt_text: Glitch is a multidisciplinary work with visual arts and dance set to experimental music.

site_title: Catch 3rd episode of Our Better Nature video series on making S'pore a cool city
summary: Singapore's temperatures have risen by 1.8 degrees Celsius since 1948 due to the urban heat island effect, exceeding the global average increase of 1.1 degrees Celsius from pre-industrial times. Efforts to address this issue include innovations like heat-reflective paint and a locally developed air-conditioning system. The Straits Times' video series "Our Better Nature" highlights these solutions, which will be showcased in the third episode, airing on Tuesday, and will explore the country's sustainability efforts under the Singapore Green Plan 2030.

site_title: Tennis: Swiatek, Pegula into US Open quarter-finals
summary: World number one Iga Swiatek became the first Polish woman to reach the US Open quarter-finals, defeating Jule Niemeier 2-6, 6-4, 6-0. Swiatek, French Open champion, will face US eighth seed Jessica Pegula in the semi-finals. In another US Open quarter-final match, Pegula defeated Petra Kvitova 6-3, 6-2. Swiatek credited her pre-match playlist for her success, saying she's "pretty bored" with it but won't change it.

site_title: Football: Pogba undergoes 'successful' knee surgery but is a doubt for World Cup
summary: Paul Pogba underwent successful knee surgery on Monday, but his World Cup availability is uncertain. The France midfielder initially opted against surgery but changed his mind after returning to training. Pogba could be out for up to two months, potentially missing the tournament. Juventus coach Massimiliano Allegri has also expressed doubt about Pogba's availability, stating he may not play for the team until January. Meanwhile, teammate Kylian Mbappe downplayed concerns about their relationship, saying he trusts Pogba's version of events and prioritizes the national team ahead of the upcoming tournament.

site_title: Ex-Georgia PM blames Credit Suisse unit for $1.78b losses in Singapore case
summary: Former Georgian Prime Minister Bidzina Ivanishvili has accused a Credit Suisse unit in Singapore of failing to safeguard his $1.27 billion investments, resulting in losses of $1.78 billion. Ivanishvili claims Credit Suisse Trust failed to take steps to prevent losses linked to fraud committed by its former banker Patrice Lescaudron, who was convicted of forging signatures and mismanaging investments. The case comes as Credit Suisse aims to recover from scandals and losses, with new CEO Ulrich Koerner tasked with paring costs and restoring the bank's reputation.

site_title: Casino suppliers quit Macau for resurgent Singapore, Philippines
summary: Macau's casino industry is experiencing a significant decline due to China's Covid-19-zero policy, with suppliers relocating to more welcoming markets such as Singapore and the Philippines. Suppliers like Light & Wonder and a Japanese company are moving employees and inventory out of Macau, citing supply chain challenges and a 90% revenue plunge. Macau's casinos are not buying new equipment until licenses are secured by the end of the year, and the market is expected to continue to dwindle, with gaming revenue in August at 9% of pre-pandemic levels. The industry's decline is seen as a major blow to Macau's ambitions to develop a Vegas-style entertainment market.

site_title: Rugby: French federation chief Bernard Laporte's graft trial opens
summary: French rugby federation chief Bernard Laporte is going on trial on charges of corruption and influence peddling, accused of favouring close friend and billionaire owner Mohed Altrad in awarding a shirt sponsor contract to his company. Laporte is also accused of intervening with the federal disciplinary commission to reduce a fine against Altrad's company. The trial, which will run until September 22, has shaken the French rugby world and hurt Laporte's reputation, despite his re-election as FFR boss in 2020. Laporte's lawyer denies the accusations, claiming they are "trumped up" and in the best interest of the federation.

site_title: Inflatable flood bags, portable barriers distributed to homes as a precaution
summary: A landslide in Clementi, Singapore, has prompted the National water agency PUB to distribute inflatable flood bags and portable barriers to nearby homes as a precautionary measure. The devices can be set up quickly to prevent flood waters from entering homes. Works to widen the Ulu Pandan Canal have also begun, aiming to improve water flow and mitigate flood risks. With rainy weather expected, PUB has increased its deployment of quick response team vehicles and is closely monitoring rain forecasts and water levels. The area remains under caution, with residents advised to stay away from the affected site.

site_title: What it should have been
summary: Singapore's aviation firms are ramping up hiring amid a surge in air travel. However, Transport Minister S. Iswaran's statement that passenger traffic at Changi Airport is expected to reach 80% of pre-pandemic levels from October was incorrect. Instead, he stated that the number of flights should reach 80% of 2019 volumes from October.

site_title: New off-peak car numbers drop as COE prices climb
summary: The number of off-peak car (OPC) registrations in Singapore dropped to 140 between January and July, down from 468 in the same period last year. This represents 0.74% of total car registrations, largely due to rising COE prices undercutting the OPC rebates, making the option less attractive.

site_title: Former actress Jacelyn Tay shows off figure in bikini to recommend breast pumps
summary: Former actress Jacelyn Tay, 47, posted a photo of herself in a bikini to recommend breast pumps, sparking both praise and criticism for her message and image. Tay, a health coach and nutrition consultant, emphasized the benefits of hands-free breast pumps for breastfeeding mums. However, most comments focused on her figure, with some criticizing her use of the photo. Tay replied diplomatically, acknowledging the need for more creative suggestions.

site_title: Republic Poly students hope for less rigid views of success
summary: Republic Polytechnic students in Singapore participated in a dialogue on the country's future, hoping for a more inclusive society and a modern definition of success. The session, part of the Forward Singapore exercise, aimed to build consensus and listen to the aspirations of young people. Students expressed their desire for more space to pursue their passions, a more modern concept of success, and a more inclusive society. The dialogue's findings will be consolidated into an "evolving document" that will guide future policy decisions.

site_title: Virtual reality tours of places of worship help build understanding
summary: Virtual reality tours of places of worship have been launched to promote understanding and harmony among different racial and religious groups. The initiative, a collaboration between Being Bridges and 13 Racial and Religious Harmony Circles, allows participants to take a 360-degree look around various places of worship while standing in the same location. This immersive experience aims to foster greater empathy and appreciation for diverse faiths, helping to build a more harmonious community. The program is part of efforts to promote interfaith understanding and social cohesion.

site_title: Man mistaken for Bentley driver recalls harrowing experience
summary: A Bentley driver, identified as Mr. Neo Tiam Ting, was mistakenly identified as the person who threatened to run down a security guard outside Red Swastika School in January. The incident was captured on video and sparked widespread concern. Following the video's release, Mr. Ting's phone was flooded with messages from acquaintances questioning his actions.

site_title: Volkswagen triggers landmark Porsche IPO plan, defying market doubts
summary: Volkswagen has announced its intention to float Porsche, triggering a potential €60-€85 billion IPO, the largest in German history and European since 1999. The move is seen as a significant step in Volkswagen's transformation into a leading software-based mobility provider. Porsche SE, controlled by the Porsche and Piech families, will hold a 25% plus one share stake, bolstering their push for greater control under new CEO Oliver Blume. The IPO will be open to retail investors in European countries, including France, Spain, and Italy.

site_title: Organisers expect 47,000 visitors at international F&B trade show here
summary: Singapore's international F&B trade show, FHA-Food & Beverage, is attracting 47,000 visitors, similar to pre-pandemic numbers, with over 2,000 exhibitors from 56 countries. The event, now held annually, features a halal zone, food tech zone, and wine fair, with a focus on sustainability and alternative protein sources. Minister of State for Trade and Industry Alvin Tan notes the strong participation rate as a sign of Singapore's recovering Mice industry, with the EU promoting organic and GI products, and the Government planning to partner with food manufacturers to grow the industry.

site_title: Singapore eyes 2050 target for net-zero emissions
summary: Singapore is considering setting a 2050 target for net-zero emissions, giving clarity to a timeline announced earlier this year. The country is also deciding whether to raise its 2030 climate target to support the longer-term goal. The public can provide feedback on the 2050 timeline and the possibility of an updated 2030 target via a government feedback portal until September 26. Achieving net-zero emissions requires efforts from all segments of society, including companies, workers, and individuals, to cut greenhouse gas emissions and restore forests and mangroves.

site_title: Ang Mo Kio, Tampines BTO projects most popular in Aug launch
summary: In Singapore's August Build-to-Order (BTO) sales exercise, larger flats in mature estates of Ang Mo Kio and Tampines were the most popular, with 17.2 first-time applicants vying for each of the 117 five-room flats in Tampines. In contrast, three-room flats in Bukit Merah had lower first-timer application rates, with only 1.9 applicants per flat. The Housing Board attributed this to the longer minimum occupation period and selling criteria of the prime location public housing model, which may deter first-time buyers.

site_title: Catch episode of Our Better Nature on making S'pore a cool city
summary: Singapore's temperatures have risen 1.8°C higher than in 1948 due to the urban heat island effect, surpassing the global average increase of 1.1°C from pre-industrial times. The city-state is testing innovative solutions to mitigate this, such as heat-reflective paint and an air-conditioning system harnessing ambient heat for cooling. The Straits Times' six-part series "Our Better Nature" highlights these efforts, airing on the ST's website and social media channels every fortnight, as part of the Singapore Green Plan 2030's sustainable future initiatives.

site_title: Wooing new blood to interfaith networks
summary: Singapore's Harmony Circle, a network of inter-racial and inter-religious groups, faces a challenge in attracting new members, particularly youth. The average age of members is about 60, making it difficult to expand the network. In 2002, former leader Abdullah Shafiie was tasked with developing the concept, which he sees as a meaningful challenge. Despite the hurdle, Shafiie remains committed to building inter-racial and religious ties through the Harmony Circle network.

site_title: A walk down the same path brings different races and faiths together
summary: A community event, Harmony Walk, was organized by Limbang and Yew Tee Racial and Religious Harmony Circles in July 2022. The walk, which passed by places of worship, brought together over 400 residents from different races and faiths, fostering connection and understanding among them. The event aimed to promote harmony and unity in the community, highlighting the importance of interfaith dialogue and community engagement.

site_title: SIA to move S-E Asia departures to T2 as revamped terminal expands services
summary: Changi Airport's Terminal 2 will reopen on October 11 for Singapore Airlines flights to South-east Asian destinations, marking the first phase of the terminal's expansion. The terminal, which was revamped to handle up to 5 million more passengers annually, will initially operate at half capacity. The full list of airlines using the terminal will be announced later. The airport's passenger handling capacity will be restored to pre-pandemic levels of 70 million passengers per year.

site_title: Dealing with doxxing
summary: A woman sought revenge on her husband's mistress by doxxing her online, sending emails to her colleagues and threatening messages. This act of online vigilantism highlights the rise of doxxing despite efforts to deter it. Lawyers acknowledge the ubiquity of the internet as the main reason for this phenomenon. While some deterrents have been effective, the ease of online information sharing makes it unavoidable, and authorities must adapt to tackle this growing issue.

site_title: What AI still cannot do: Reason and  truly empathise
summary: Meta's BlenderBot 2.0, touted as a groundbreaking AI chatbot, was found to perform poorly, producing illogical and biased responses. The chatbot's inability to reason, make sense of multiple sources, and reconcile opposing viewpoints highlights the current limitations of AI. Despite being trained on vast amounts of data, AI programs like BlenderBot and GPT-3 can reproduce societal biases and lack empathy, demonstrating the need for human intervention to develop more advanced artificial general intelligence.

site_title: DPM Wong meets Malaysian PM, other leaders during official visit
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong's first official visit to Malaysia saw him meet with Malaysian Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob, reaffirming cooperation in green and digital economies, and discussing the Johor Bahru-Singapore Rapid Transit System Link Project. Wong also discussed the Singapore-Kuala Lumpur high-speed rail project, with Malaysia expressing interest in reviving talks. The visit included meetings with other politicians and government officials, including the Central Bank of Malaysia governor, and a dinner reception with Kuala Lumpur Business Club leaders.

site_title: Workplace fatalities hit 37 - the figure for whole of last year
summary: Workplace fatalities in Singapore have reached 37 for the year, surpassing the total for the entire previous year. A 45-year-old Grab delivery rider died after a collision with a lorry in Hougang. The incident has sparked a six-month heightened safety period, during which companies cannot hire new foreign workers if unsafe conditions are found. The 54-year-old lorry driver was arrested for drink driving. The government has announced stricter measures to address rising work-related deaths and injuries, with CEOs held personally accountable for lapses.

site_title: Managing health insurance costs after retirement
summary: A survey by Etiqa Insurance Singapore found that 44% of Singaporeans who plan to retire by 65 are uncertain if they can retire comfortably and happily. Despite this, 9 in 10 Singaporeans aim to retire by 65, highlighting the need for planning ahead to manage health insurance costs as premiums rise with age.

site_title: Breakthrough event at Marymount
summary: This year's Racial Harmony Day event at Marymount saw a breakthrough, with a higher turnout of participants from schools, religious organizations, and residents. The event, held at An-Nahdhah Mosque, marked a change from the usual community club setting. This shift highlighted the importance of interfaith dialogue and community engagement in promoting racial harmony. The success of the event suggests a growing commitment to fostering greater understanding and inclusivity among Marymount's diverse population.

site_title: Flag post led to threats, months of harassing messages
summary: A Singaporean man, Avijit das Patnaik, received threatening messages on social media for six months after posting a flag in his yard. The messages included threats to harm him and criticism for being an Indian national taking jobs away from locals. The harassment began after Patnaik's flag post, which sparked controversy in the country. Authorities have not commented on the matter, but the incident highlights the issue of online harassment and racism in Singapore.

site_title: High demand for larger AMK, Tampines units
summary: Larger Build-To-Order (BTO) flats in mature estates like Ang Mo Kio and Tampines saw high demand last month. At Central Weave @ AMK, 398 four-room and 372 five-room flats were in high competition, with 7-17 first-time applicants vying for each unit. Prices range from $535,000 to $877,000. In contrast, two projects under the prime location public housing model in Bukit Merah had extremely low first-time application rates, indicating a high chance of selection for first-timers.

site_title: ST Explains: Should I downgrade my private IP plan if I can't afford the insurance premium as I age?
summary: In a survey by Etiqa Insurance Singapore, 9 out of 10 Singaporeans are confident of retiring by 65, but 44% of these individuals doubt their ability to retire comfortably and happily due to concerns over failing health and running out of money.

site_title: Company Briefs: Volkswagen
summary: Volkswagen's finance chief Arno Antlitz stated that the planned listing of Porsche sports car brand could provide the company with more flexibility to accelerate transformation. The listing is set to be one of Europe's biggest initial public offerings. Meanwhile, HSBC is trimming its China debt issuance team, while JP Morgan plans to hire retail bankers in Germany to expand its international consumer business.

site_title: Bed Bath & Beyond's CFO falls to death at New York's Jenga tower
summary: Bed Bath & Beyond's CFO, Gustavo Arnal, 52, fell to his death from the "Jenga" tower in New York's Tribeca skyscraper on Friday, days after the company announced store closures and layoffs. Arnal joined Bed Bath & Beyond in 2020 and previously worked at Procter & Gamble and Avon. The cause of death is pending investigation by the New York City Medical Examiner's Office. The company has faced financial struggles, including a 26% slump in same-store sales and a class-action lawsuit alleging insider trading and artificially inflating the stock price.

site_title: Corporate misconduct: Regulators could use a bigger stick
summary: Regulators in Singapore have imposed the largest fine on a company, $12.6 million, on Noble Group for improper accounting and misleading financial statements. However, the fine is relatively small compared to the company's market value of $10 billion and annual income of over $1 billion. This has raised questions about whether regulators have enough resources to effectively punish corporate misconduct, sparking debate about whether fines are too lenient.

site_title: Markets scream warning over new UK PM's mammoth task
summary: The UK's new Prime Minister, Liz Truss, faces a daunting economic landscape with the pound near its lowest in decades, high borrowing costs, and record underperformance in domestic stocks. The pound has dropped 15% this year, and borrowing costs have surged after six rate hikes by the Bank of England, with expectations of further increases. Investors are concerned that Truss may borrow heavily to fund tax cuts, exacerbating the country's balance sheet issues. Analysts predict a challenging time for the economy, with a possible recession looming due to rising energy costs and a cost-of-living crisis.

site_title: Grab rival Be Group gets $84m loan for Vietnam expansion
summary: Vietnamese ride-hailing start-up Be Group has secured a loan facility of at least US$60 million (S$84 million) from Deutsche Bank to expand and enhance its services. The loan will be used to boost its primary services, including ride-hailing, food delivery, and digital banking. Be Group aims to surpass 10 million active users next year and double that figure by 2026, challenging market leader Grab Holdings in Vietnam. The company's market share in Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City is around 30-40% and 25-35%, respectively.

site_title: Inflation slows S'pore's July retail sales growth to 13.7%
summary: Singapore's retail sales grew 13.7% year-over-year in July, slowing from 14.9% in June. Despite this, analysts expect double-digit gains to persist due to major events and the holiday season. Core inflation rose 4.8% year-over-year, driven by higher prices for food, electricity, and gas, while overall inflation reached 7%, the highest in 14 years. Retail sales growth was driven by categories such as watches, jewelry, clothing, and food, but was impacted by lower sales at supermarkets and minimarts.

site_title: 7 Sim Lim Square units licensed for nightlife venues up for sale at $17m
summary: Seven retail units at Sim Lim Square, a 1987 electronics and information technology mall, have been put up for sale with a guide price of $17 million. The units, with a total strata floor area of 5,156 sq ft, come with Class 1 entertainment licences and a balance master tenancy of over five years. The sale is seen as a response to recent collective sales and the loss of nightlife entertainment licences, potentially driving strong demand for retail units with necessary infrastructure and approvals. Foreigners are eligible to purchase the units.

site_title: SIA, Genting S'pore, Suntec Reit top picks as investors turn to service sector: DBS
summary: DBS Bank recommends investors shift from manufacturing to the service sector, citing weak Purchasing Managers' Index and slowing growth expectations from China. To hedge against changing consumer sentiments, investors can consider buying into meetings, incentives, conferences and exhibitions (Mice) stocks, particularly Singapore Airlines (SIA), Genting Singapore, and Suntec Reit, with "buy" recommendations and target prices of $6.60, $1, and $1.90 respectively. These companies are poised for growth on the back of tourism recovery and office workers' return.

site_title: S'pore stocks climb 0.3% as regional markets finish mixed
summary: The Singapore stock market closed 0.3% higher on Monday, following other Asia-Pacific indexes such as Shanghai and Australia. Despite regional markets ending mixed, mining firm Golden Energy and Resources was a major gainer, rising 15.7% to 77.5 cents. The Straits Times Index reached 3,215.48, with 1.51 billion units traded locally. However, key gauges in Japan, Hong Kong, and South Korea finished lower, driven by concerns over an energy crisis in Europe, Chinese Covid-19 lockdowns, and geopolitical tensions.

site_title: Corapi is a sound proposition on last two starts
summary: Key South African horse racing analysis for Tuesday's Vaal form analysis includes: Corapi, a sound proposition after two close starts, and potential winners in various races. Trainer Paul Peter dominates the opener with I'M IN LOVE and CENTRAL CITY, while Second Breath and Back to the Future show improvement. Other notable contenders include Corapi, Queen Theodora, and Brazilian Storm.

site_title: Koh suspended one race day
summary: Jockey Koh Teck Huat has been suspended from September 11 to 17 for careless riding, affecting one Singapore race day. The incident occurred when Koh's mount, Fight To Victory, shifted in near the 700m mark, causing Fiddlestick to be carried in across the running of Retallica, resulting in a check. Koh's suspension will be served after the completion of his penalty period on September 17.

site_title: Credit Suisse court battle with tycoon kicks off in Singapore
summary: Credit Suisse's Singapore-based subsidiary, CS Trust, is on trial accused by billionaire client Bidzina Ivanishvili of negligence that cost him up to $1.12 billion. Ivanishvili, a former Georgian prime minister, claims Credit Suisse failed to protect his assets, while the bank argues it was unaware of a fraud scheme perpetrated by convicted banker Patrice Lescaudron. The trial comes as Credit Suisse faces reputational hits and restructuring challenges amid a strategic review that could see the investment bank drastically reduced. Ivanishvili is seeking $800 million in damages, which could be offset by a similar award in a related case in Bermuda.

site_title: 230,000 kids aged up to six years to receive $200 in their Child Development Accounts
summary: About 230,000 Singaporean children aged 6 and under will receive a $200 top-up in their Child Development Accounts (CDAs) starting Thursday. The top-up is part of the Household Support Package announced during Budget 2022 to support families with child-raising expenses. Funds in the CDAs can be used for education and healthcare at approved institutions. Parents must have a CDA by June 30 next year to receive the top-up, and recipients will receive a notification via SMS, email, or letter after the top-up is credited.

site_title: Dressel breaks silence on World C'ships exit
summary: Caeleb Dressel, a seven-gold Olympic champion, broke his silence on his sudden withdrawal from the 2022 World Aquatics Championships in Budapest. He stated on Instagram that he had been happy without swimming and had pursued other activities, such as a honeymoon and hiking, to find a balance between swimming and his personal life. Dressel's pullout was reportedly due to mental health reasons, a theme echoed by fellow swimmer Adam Peaty, who also took a break for similar reasons. Dressel expressed his intention to return to swimming.

site_title: From jaded to co-captain
summary: National netball player Khor Ting Fang has overcome injury woes and self-doubt to take on a leadership role at the Asian Netball Championship. In 2019, she faced extreme highs and lows, including an injury, which made her question her abilities. However, she persevered and has now become the co-captain of the team, standing out for her determination and resilience.

site_title: HK judge adjourns winding-up suit against Evergrande to Nov 7
summary: A Hong Kong High Court judge has approved China Evergrande Group's request to adjourn a winding-up petition against the company until November 7. The petition, filed by an investor in Evergrande's unit, sought to liquidate the company due to a US$110 million unpaid agreement. The judge rejected the immediate liquidation request, citing the need for Evergrande to formulate a restructuring plan for offshore creditors, which could be impacted by the petition's success. Evergrande aims to announce a concrete resolution plan by November 7, respecting the rights of all stakeholders.

site_title: In the Nick of time, is Kyrgios growing up?
summary: Nick Kyrgios, the Australian tennis player, has shown improvement in his game, as evidenced by his victory over world No. 1 Daniil Medvedev at the US Open. Kyrgios attributes his success to hard work and dedication, stating that he is "trying to work hard every day" and making every practice session count. This maturity and focus may indicate that Kyrgios is maturing as a player, but whether this transformation is desirable is a matter of debate.

site_title: Jump in exports to US keeps India in race to become next China
summary: India's exports to the US have surged, reaching $20 million in Christmas decorative items and T-shirts in the latest month, almost triple the value from the previous year. This marks a significant shift away from China, with India gaining a lead over the Philippines. Indian exporters, such as Mr. Amit Malhotra, have seen a 20% increase in orders and production capacity has been bumped up. The trend is expected to continue, with India projected to contribute over $500 billion to the global economy by 2030, driven by its abundant labor force and growing manufacturing sector.

site_title: Premier League talking points
summary: Tottenham Hotspur secured a 2-1 win over Fulham, with Richarlison impressing in his first three-way attack start. The Brazil forward linked well with Harry Kane and Son Heung-min, and his performance could be crucial for the team's success. Meanwhile, several Premier League managers expressed frustration with VAR decisions, with David Moyes and Eddie Howe criticizing officials for their calls. Leicester City manager Brendan Rodgers faces significant concerns after a 5-2 loss to Brighton, with the Foxes struggling to find consistency.

site_title: Euro hits 20-year low as Russia keeps gas supply off
summary: The euro hit a 20-year low of US$0.988 due to Russia's halt on gas supply through the Nord Stream pipeline, sparking concerns over energy prices and growth. The pound also fell to a 2½-year low at US$1.14445, while the US dollar index surged to a two-decade high of 110.25. Experts attribute the decline to heightened geopolitical risk and adverse global demand shocks, with the European currencies expected to be the worst hit. Markets anticipate outsized rate increases, including a near 80% chance of a 75-basis point rise in Europe.

site_title: First it was the car, now it's his team
summary: Lewis Hamilton finally cracked under pressure in the Netherlands, where his Mercedes team opted for an aggressive one-stop strategy despite the dominant Red Bull of Max Verstappen. The strategy, which favored Hamilton, ultimately backfired, and he failed to capitalize on the opportunity. This marked a rare instance of Hamilton having a legitimate chance of victory this season, highlighting the strain of racing an uncompetitive car. The loss was a setback for Hamilton, who has been struggling with his Mercedes team this season.

site_title: Ferrari's 'mess' at Zandvoort
summary: Ferrari suffered a disastrous Dutch Grand Prix, with team boss Mattia Binotto and driver Carlos Sainz describing the event as a "mess". The team's strategy and pit stops were marred by errors, including a 12-second delay and an unsafe release that resulted in a five-second penalty. Charles Leclerc salvaged a podium spot, but Ferrari's prospects for the championship are dwindling, with Leclerc trailing Max Verstappen by 109 points. The team will face a tough challenge at their home track, Monza, for the Italian Grand Prix.

site_title: Johnson wins his first LIV event
summary: Dustin Johnson won his first LIV Golf Invitational Boston event with a clutch eagle putt at the first play-off hole, defeating Chile's Joaquin Niemann and India's Anirban Lahiri. Johnson finished 54 holes at 15 under, tying with Niemann and Lahiri. The victory marked his sixth birdie of the day and earned him the $4 million first prize, along with $750,000 for the team first prize. Johnson's win highlighted the increasing competitiveness and financial stakes in the breakaway circuit.

site_title: Lim's Ibex flexes his muscles
summary: Trainer Jason Lim's patience paid off with Ibex's first win at his eighth Kranji start on Saturday. The 5-year-old Dream Ahead gelding, purchased from ex-Kranji trainer Cliff Brown, had previously run underwhelmingly in his first four starts due to immaturity. However, after a year-long rest, Ibex has matured and shown significant improvement. Ridden by Krisna Thangamani, Ibex dominated the field in a $20,000 Maiden race, covering 1,200m in 1min 12.24sec. Lim attributes the win to Ibex's age and maturity, with Krisna citing his previous experience on the horse as key to the success.

site_title: Harassment law may deter doxxing, but victims face challenges in making their case: Lawyers
summary: A Singaporean woman was charged with harassment after sending threatening messages to her husband's mistress and her colleagues on LinkedIn. A dedicated Protection from Harassment Court was established in June 2022, but lawyers note that victims of doxxing face challenges in making their case. The court aims to provide a specialized platform for harassment cases, but its effectiveness in deterring doxxing remains to be seen.

site_title: Sports World: Women's doubles silver for Zeng, Zhou
summary: Singapore's Zeng Jian and Zhou Jingyi secured a silver medal in the table tennis women's doubles at the WTT Feeder Panagyurishte in Bulgaria, falling to France's Prithika Pavade and Camille Lutz 3-1. Zeng attributed their success to their on-court partnership and communication, aiming to continue growing and achieving more success. Meanwhile, British distance runner Mo Farah won his third Big Half London half-marathon, boosting his confidence ahead of the London Marathon in October.

site_title: Chelsea still have striking problem
summary: Thomas Tuchel is unsure when Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang, Chelsea's new striker, can make his debut due to a broken jaw sustained in a home invasion robbery. Aubameyang has been training with a mask, and Tuchel says it's too early to predict his availability for the Champions League opener against Dinamo Zagreb. Meanwhile, new signing Wesley Fofana is set to start, and Reece James has signed a new five-year contract with Chelsea.

site_title: Football: Italian FA probing anti-semitic chants from Juve, Inter fans
summary: The Italian Football Federation is investigating anti-Semitic chants from Juventus and Inter Milan fans during the Milan Derby. Videos showed Inter fans chanting "the champions of Italy are Jews" and Juventus fans making similar chants against Fiorentina. The incidents occurred during a match between the two teams, also marred by sporadic acts of violence between supporters. The federation's probe aims to address the disturbing behavior, which is considered unacceptable in Italian football.

site_title: Football: Haaland alone will not help Man City win Champions League, says Guardiola
summary: Pep Guardiola stated that Manchester City cannot rely solely on Erling Haaland to win the Champions League, despite the Norwegian striker's impressive start to his career, scoring 10 goals in six games. Guardiola emphasized the need for his team to create chances for Haaland to score, rather than relying on him to carry the load. The team's defense is also a concern, with John Stones and Kyle Walker both injured, but Guardiola is optimistic about the team's chances with the addition of new signing Manuel Akanji.

summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The article lists upcoming sports events for the next 48 hours. Cycling events include La Vuelta Stage 16 and Stage 17, while football matches include Uefa Champions League Group E matches and Uefa Champions League Group A matches. Tennis events include US Open Day 9 and Day 10. The article also mentions athletics events, including Diamond League Zurich Day 1. Viewers can check the on-screen TV guide or visit singtel.com and starhubtvplus.com for updates. The sports events are scheduled to take place on September 6 and 7.

site_title: Tennis: Rublev downs Norrie to reach third US Open quarter-final
summary: Andrey Rublev defeated seventh-seeded Cameron Norrie 6-4, 6-4, 6-4 in the US Open fourth round, advancing to his third quarter-final appearance. The match was delayed by 30 minutes due to rain, but Rublev remained focused, winning 11 aces and 30 winners. He will face Rafael Nadal or Frances Tiafoe in the semi-finals, marking his sixth quarter-final at the majors.

site_title: Galtier feels rotation key in PSG's chase for Euro glory
summary: Paris Saint-Germain coach Christophe Galtier believes rotation is key to the team's success in their pursuit of European glory. Since the Qatari takeover in 2011, PSG have struggled with managing star egos, but Galtier's approach, which prioritizes the team over individual players, may be the solution. With a record 24 goals scored in six league matches, Galtier has already shown his ability to manage the team's star players, including Lionel Messi, Kylian Mbappe, and Neymar. The team's success will depend on their ability to work together and make sacrifices for the greater good.

site_title: Nunes Gears up for comeback
summary: Champion jockey Manoel Nunes is set to return to Kranji races on September 24 after nearly three months on the sidelines following a neck fracture sustained in a June 18 fall. Nunes, 46, had made good progress in his rehabilitation, including regular physio and running, and is feeling "as good as gold." He will resume riding trackwork on September 17 and plans to start with a few rides to avoid re-injury. Nunes currently leads the jockeys' log with 58 winners, with Wong Chin Chuen 22 behind. Nunes aims to claim his fourth Singapore champion jockey title.

site_title: United 'still far away' from winning trophies
summary: Manchester United manager Erik ten Hag expressed his satisfaction with the team's fourth straight Premier League win, a 3-1 victory over Arsenal. However, he emphasized that the team is still far from competing for honors, stating they are "still far away" from winning trophies. Ten Hag praised his team's improved mentality and spirit in dealing with setbacks, but highlighted the need for sustained control of games and high standards in training. The team's next step will be to increase the intensity of their play and pressure on opponents, with promising player Antony showing his potential.

site_title: Bentley incident in school: Man wrongly targeted as driver feared for his family and business
summary: A Bentley driver, later identified as Mr Neo Tiam Ting, was falsely accused of threatening to run down a security guard at Red Swastika School in Singapore in January. Online vigilantes targeted him, with many acquaintances sending him messages asking why he allegedly made the threat. The incident highlights the dangers of online vigilantism and the importance of verifying information before jumping to conclusions. Mr Neo Tiam Ting was wrongly identified and feared for his family and business due to the online backlash. An investigation is needed to clear his name and address the issue of online misinformation.

site_title: Renewable energy, green economy areas where Singapore, Saudi Arabia can forge closer cooperation
summary: Singapore and Saudi Arabia have agreed to foster closer cooperation in areas such as renewable energy and the green economy. During a meeting with Minister of Transport and Logistic Services Saleh Nasser Al Jasser, both countries welcomed closer cooperation in logistics services and renewable energy. The Saudi-Arabia Singapore Joint Committee (SSJC) was reaffirmed as a useful platform for bilateral cooperation. The agreement was introduced in 2013 and aims to encourage greater exchanges between the GCC and Singapore in areas of mutual interest. The two countries also discussed global and regional developments, including energy markets and climate change.

site_title: From offering holiday perks to letting parents match their children's school schedules: How workplaces are being built with empathy
summary: Companies are introducing family-friendly initiatives to boost employee welfare, productivity, and business outcomes. Examples include staggered work hours, flexible schedules, and work-from-home arrangements. Employers like Klook, Kim Choo Kueh Chang, and Greenpac Singapore report improved employee motivation and productivity levels. Challenges were overcome by understanding individual needs, exercising empathy, and striking a balance between business and personal commitments. SMEs are well-positioned to introduce such initiatives, and government grants can support bold steps. Hybrid work arrangements are also being adopted, allowing employees to balance work and family commitments.

site_title: Gauff, 18, is youngest US Open q-finalist since 2009
summary: Coco Gauff, 18, has become the youngest US Open quarter-finalist since 2009, defeating 33-year-old Zhang Shuai in a thrilling 7-5, 7-5 match. Gauff's victory sets up a showdown with 17th seed Caroline Garcia, who has momentum on her side after winning a WTA 1000 event in Cincinnati. Gauff has not dropped a set en route to the quarter-finals, while Garcia is riding a 12-match win streak and is considered a title favourite. The match is expected to be a closely contested battle between youth and experience.

site_title: Motor racing: MotoGP signs agreement to race in Saudi Arabia
summary: MotoGP has signed a memorandum of understanding to hold an annual Saudi Arabian Grand Prix on a newly constructed, multi-purpose circuit. The partnership aims to expand the sport into the Middle East, producing a new talent development program for young Saudi riders. This move follows Saudi Arabia's recent expansion into Formula One and other motorsport events, with 80% of Saudi fans expressing interest in more events in the country.

site_title: LIV Golf continues to try new ways to be noticed
summary: The LIV Golf tour, backed by Saudi Arabia, has continued to make headlines with its unconventional approach to men's golf. The circuit's latest event in Massachusetts featured a dramatic entrance by frontman Greg Norman, who parachuted onto the first tee, and allowed players to wear shorts, a move seen as an anti-PGA Tour gesture. Despite sparse attendance, LIV Golf is attracting a younger, more boisterous crowd and has successfully recruited prominent golfers. The tour's success has forced the PGA Tour to take notice, and neither circuit is backing down. With more tournaments scheduled, LIV Golf is determined to establish itself as a viable alternative to the established PGA Tour.

site_title: Football: Uefa chief Ceferin certain 2030 World Cup will be in Spain and Portugal
summary: Uefa president Aleksander Ceferin expressed certainty that Spain and Portugal will host the 2030 World Cup, citing the two countries' passion for football and good infrastructure. Spain and Portugal signed a joint bid agreement in 2020, and Ceferin assured they would receive full support. Fifteen stadiums in Spain and three in Portugal are among the 11 venues expected to host matches if the bid is successful. The bid faces competition from other countries, including Argentina, Uruguay, and Morocco, which have also announced World Cup hosting intentions.

site_title: Football: Rotation key in chasing European glory, Galtier tells star-studded PSG side
summary: PSG coach Christophe Galtier has implemented a rotation system to manage the egos of his star-studded squad, aiming to turn the team into a cohesive unit. Galtier, who has a reputation in French football, has been successful in pre-season with PSG scoring 24 goals in their first six league matches. He has also benched star players like Neymar, which has led to a more harmonious team environment. Ahead of the Champions League opener against Juventus, Galtier emphasized the importance of squad rotation, citing the team's busy schedule and the need for players to be ready to play.

site_title: Forward Singapore: RP students hope they can pursue their passions, want a more inclusive society
summary: Republic Polytechnic students participated in a dialogue session as part of Singapore's Forward Singapore exercise, aiming to build a more inclusive society and define success on their own terms. The session, led by Education Minister Chan Chun Sing and Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong, focused on education and lifelong learning, gathering feedback from students on desired outcomes and their roles in shaping policies. Students expressed a desire for a more modern definition of success, prioritizing personal fulfillment over traditional measures, and called for a collaborative approach to nation-building.

site_title: Passengers from S'pore and Malaysia unable to board after cruise is overbooked
summary: Over 100 passengers from Singapore and Malaysia were unable to board the Genting Dream cruise ship due to overbooking. The ship, which can accommodate 3,352 passengers, was overbooked for its September 4 departure from Singapore. Affected passengers will receive a full refund and a complimentary cruise on the Genting Dream before April 28, 2023. Passengers were informed of the overbooking two days before departure, causing disappointment and inconvenience, especially for those who had planned to take their families on the cruise.

site_title: Tennis: Australian tennis great Court says admiration of Williams not reciprocated
summary: Margaret Court, a 24-time Grand Slam singles champion, expressed disappointment that her admiration for Serena Williams is not reciprocated. Despite Williams' impressive career, Court feels underappreciated in the sport, citing her own stellar record in the 1960s and early 1970s. Court, who holds the record for most Grand Slam singles titles, also criticized the current tennis landscape for not honoring its past, saying players today don't appreciate the challenges faced by players like her, who had to play every week without money or support.

site_title: DPM Wong calls on Malaysia PM Ismail Sabri Yaakob
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong visited Malaysia, marking his first official trip across the Causeway since being appointed in June. He met with Malaysian Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob, reaffirming cooperation in green and digital economies, as well as the Johor Bahru-Singapore Rapid Transit System Link Project. The two sides discussed reviving talks on the Singapore-Kuala Lumpur high-speed rail project, which was terminated in 2021. Wong also met with various Malaysian officials to enhance cooperation in areas such as finance and defense, and discussed global economic challenges.

site_title: 'Just like Nadal, Djokovic'
summary: Daniil Medvedev praises Nick Kyrgios' performance, comparing his game to that of tennis greats Novak Djokovic and Rafael Nadal. After their match at the US Open, Medvedev believes Kyrgios is on the cusp of fulfilling his potential, having already won a Grand Slam doubles title and reached his first Major singles final. Kyrgios' next opponent will be Karen Khachanov, and Medvedev thinks he has the tools to win the US Open if he plays at his level. Kyrgios' projected rise to at least 18th in the rankings is also a result of the match.

site_title: 50 items for 50 years: Sentosa commemorates Golden Jubilee with time capsule
summary: Singapore's Sentosa island commemorated its 50th anniversary, or Golden Jubilee, by sealing a time capsule containing 50 items representing its history, including old admission tickets, souvenirs, and used ammunition rounds. The items span four periods, from colonial past to the present. The time capsule will be placed at the Sentosa Development Corporation office. A charity golf event raised $3,908,888.88, which will benefit agencies supported by the President's Challenge and Community Chest. President Halimah Yacob praised Sentosa's growth alongside Singaporeans and expressed hope for continued success in creating unique experiences.

site_title: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr to make state visit to Singapore from Sept 6 to 7
summary: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr will make a two-day state visit to Singapore from Sept 6-7, marking his first visit as president. The visit reaffirms the strong ties between the two countries, with cooperation in trade, investment, defense, security, healthcare, education, and culture. Marcos will meet with Singapore's President Halimah Yacob, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, and other officials, with bilateral agreements expected to be signed on counter-terrorism and data privacy. The visit highlights the Philippines' emphasis on relations with its ASEAN neighbors, with Singapore being its top trading partner in the region.

site_title: Green Pulse Podcast: Can natural gas, a fossil fuel, really be green?
summary: The Straits Times' Green Pulse Podcast explores whether natural gas can be considered a greener fuel as countries transition away from fossil fuels. Natural gas is cleaner than coal and oil but still a fossil fuel, with methane having a more powerful warming effect. Experts discuss the viability of natural gas as an alternative, the need for renewable energy to reduce gas demand, and potential uses for gas infrastructure in emerging green fuels like hydrogen.

site_title: Tennis: Djokovic to skip Serbia's Davis Cup group-stage ties for personal reasons
summary: Novak Djokovic, the former world No. 1, will miss Serbia's Davis Cup group-stage matches in Valencia due to personal reasons. Djokovic's official website lists the Laver Cup at London's O2 Arena as his next tournament, indicating he will not participate in the Davis Cup. Serbia is drawn in Group B alongside Spain, South Korea, and Canada, with two teams advancing to the quarter-finals. The knockout stages will be held in November in Malaga.

site_title: Singapore aiming to have emissions reach net zero by 2050; public feedback sought
summary: Singapore aims to reach net-zero emissions by 2050, aligning with other developed nations, including Japan, Canada, and the European Union. The country is considering raising its 2030 climate target to support the longer-term goal. The public is invited to provide feedback on the 2050 timeline and potential updated 2030 target through a government feedback portal until September 26. Achieving net-zero emissions will require efforts from all segments of society, including companies, workers, and individuals.

site_title: New guide to help junior lawyers gauge progress in oral advocacy skills
summary: A new guide was launched to help junior lawyers gauge their progress in oral advocacy skills. Developed by the Singapore Academy of Law, the guide sets out milestones for junior lawyers to achieve in their first seven years of career, including gaining experience as lead counsel at procedural hearings. The guide aims to address the lack of opportunities for junior lawyers in oral advocacy, with Chief Justice Sundaresh Menon stating that it's essential for junior lawyers to develop their skills through practice and hands-on experience.

site_title: Sembcorp Industries sells its India coal-fired power plants for $2.1 billion
summary: Sembcorp Industries sold its stake in Sembcorp Energy India (SEIL) for $2.1 billion, relinquishing ownership of India's largest independent power producer. The sale of two coal-fired plants with 2.6GW capacity will reduce Sembcorp's greenhouse gas emissions by 37% and enable it to meet its 2025 emissions target ahead of schedule. The move will also increase renewable energy sources in its portfolio to over 50% and potentially boost earnings from sustainable solutions.

site_title: Sporting Life: In the Nick of time, is Kyrgios growing up?
summary: Nick Kyrgios, a 25-year-old tennis player, has shown improvement in his game, particularly in his recent match against Daniil Medvedev at the US Open. Kyrgios has been described as "cool, cheeky, and controversial" but is now "getting a little conventional" in his approach. He attributes his growth to hard work and making the most of practice sessions. The article raises questions about whether Kyrgios is truly growing up, but his recent performance suggests a more mature and disciplined approach to the sport.

site_title: Netball: After roller-coaster journey, Khor Ting Fang gears up for Asian C'ship dream
summary: Khor Ting Fang, Singapore's national netball co-captain, is gearing up for the Asian Netball Championship. In 2019, she experienced a roller-coaster journey, including highs and lows as an athlete. Fang was named co-captain for the Asian Netball Championship, marking a significant milestone in her netball career.

site_title: Two women punched, kicked by strangers at Marquee nightclub; police probing attack
summary: Two women, Leeanne O'Donnell and Julia Wong, were attacked by at least two men at Marquee nightclub in Singapore on Saturday. The incident occurred when a man punched and pushed Wong off a podium, prompting O'Donnell to intervene, resulting in both women being punched and kicked. They received medical treatment and are recovering from their injuries. Police are investigating the incident, and Marquee nightclub is also looking into the matter. The women plan to return to the club after recovering, but acknowledge being "scarred" by the attack.

site_title: Man sentenced to 7 weeks in jail, could not account for monies banked into his account
summary: A 26-year-old man, Kanda Amandeep Singh, was sentenced to 7 weeks in jail for receiving US$26,500 in suspicious funds from foreign victims of remittance fraud. He had withdrawn the funds via cash and transfers after being tricked into helping a third party receive the money from his relatives. Kanda was unaware of the funds' source and felt suspicious, but continued the withdrawals. He pleaded guilty to two offences under the Corruption, Drug Trafficking and Other Serious Crimes Act.

site_title: Drunk man who drove ambulance before crashing it on SLE gets 2 years' jail, 10-year driving ban
summary: A 27-year-old Singaporean man, G. Mohanavarooman Gopal Oyyappan, was sentenced to 2 years' jail and a $4,000 fine for drink driving, causing grievous hurt, and driving without a valid license. He took a joyride in his employer's ambulance, crashing it on the Seletar Expressway in 2020, and his passenger suffered fractured ribs. Mohan lied to police about being the driver, and his blood-alcohol level was more than double the legal limit. He will also face a 10-year driving ban.

site_title: Ang Mo Kio, Tampines BTO projects most popular in August launch; demand for PLH flats dampens
summary: In Singapore's August Build-to-Order (BTO) sales exercise, larger flats in mature estates like Ang Mo Kio and Tampines were the most popular, with 8-17 first-time applicants vying for each flat. Demand for three-room flats in mature estates was low, while five-room flats were in high demand due to limited supply. The Housing Board allocated flats through balloting, with prices ranging from $194,000 to $877,000.

site_title: BT Money Hacks Podcast: Investing in cars - worth it or lemons from the start?
summary: Rare and collectible cars are experiencing a surge in value, with indices in an all-time high territory. However, investing in cars can be a double-edged sword, as they can depreciate quickly and are not always a reliable hedge against inflation. To maintain value, investors should focus on purchasing mint condition vehicles and avoid driving them. Modern classics are also gaining popularity, making them a potential investment opportunity. Experts advise consulting professional advisors for independent advice, as the podcast provides general information only.

site_title: NUS student admits riding e-scooter on road during accident that injured pillion rider
summary: A National University of Singapore (NUS) student, Chuang Fu Yuan, 25, pleaded guilty to riding an e-scooter on the road, causing a serious accident that injured a pillion rider, Dai Yi Ting. Chuang had gathered with friends for a party and rode an e-scooter, despite university policies and laws prohibiting it. The incident occurred on February 27, 2019, and resulted in Dai suffering head and lung injuries. Chuang will be sentenced in October, and disciplinary action has been taken by the university.

site_title: Workplace fatality toll so far this year rises to 2021 figure with death of delivery rider
summary: A 45-year-old Grab delivery rider died in a hospital after colliding with a lorry in Singapore, bringing the workplace fatality toll to 37 this year, matching the total for 2021. The rider, who was unconscious when taken to hospital, died from his injuries. A 54-year-old lorry driver was arrested for drink driving and is assisting police investigations. The incident occurred during a six-month heightened safety period announced in September, which aims to address rising work-related deaths and injuries.

site_title: 5 foam-rolling exercises for sceptics
summary: Foam rolling, a practice that involves rolling a muscle over a cylindrical piece of foam, may provide similar benefits to massage in reducing muscle tension and improving range of motion. Research suggests that foam rolling can reduce muscle stiffness, increase flexibility, and alleviate post-workout soreness. However, the effectiveness of foam rolling is still debated among experts, with some citing the lack of large, well-designed studies to confirm its benefits. When done correctly, foam rolling can be a safe and effective tool for improving muscle function and reducing pain, but individuals with certain medical conditions or mobility issues should use caution or consult with a physical therapist before starting.

images.alt_text: In theory, rolling a muscle over a stiff, cylindrical piece of foam does something similar to massage.

site_title: Motor racing: Ricciardo would consider reserve seat to stay in Formula One
summary: Daniel Ricciardo, a former McLaren driver, said he would consider a reserve seat in Formula One to stay in the series. The 33-year-old Australian has been looking at all options, including taking a sabbatical for the 2023 season if a suitable position doesn't come up. Ricciardo expressed his desire to stay active in the sport, even if it means taking a role like a reserve driver. He has been tested over the past few years and is proud to say he hasn't been broken, maintaining his love for the sport.

site_title: Do S'pore regulators need bigger stick to deter corporate misconduct following Noble Group's case?
summary: Singapore regulators have fined Noble Group $12.6 million for improper accounting and misleading financial statements, the largest penalty on a company in Singapore's history. However, the fine is a relatively small fraction of the company's $10 billion market value. The case has sparked debate about whether the penalty is sufficient to deter corporate misconduct, raising questions about whether regulators have let offenders off too easily.

site_title: F&B trade show expects visitor numbers to return to pre-pandemic levels
summary: Singapore's Food & Beverage (F&B) trade show, FHA-Food & Beverage, is expecting 47,000 visitors, similar to pre-pandemic numbers. The event features over 2,000 exhibitors from 56 countries and a dedicated Alternative Protein Asia zone. Demand has been strong, leading to an annual event schedule starting this year. The European Union has a significant presence, promoting organic and GI products. The Singapore government plans to partner with food manufacturers to grow the industry through trade agreements and digital partnerships. The event is free, but registration is required.

site_title: Man sexually assaulted 11-year-old he met on Instagram and gave her drugs
summary: A 34-year-old man in Singapore, Muhammad Hisham Abdul Karim, was sentenced to 20 years' jail and 24 strokes of the cane for sexually assaulting an 11-year-old girl he met on Instagram. He befriended her in 2017, offered her methamphetamine, and engaged in sexual acts with her at the back of a lorry. He also contacted six other girls, aged 10 to 12, with similar intentions. The court described the offences as "premeditated and deviously planned" and noted that his previous sentence did not deter him from continuing his predatory behavior.

site_title: Clementi landslide: PUB distributing flood bags and flood barriers as precautionary measure
summary: National water agency PUB is distributing inflatable flood bags and portable flood barriers to homes in Sunset Way and Sunset Drive in Singapore as a precautionary measure after a landslide last week blocked the Ulu Pandan Canal, increasing flood risk. The devices can be set up quickly during heavy rain to prevent floodwaters from entering homes. Works to widen the canal have started, and PUB is also increasing its deployment of quick response team vehicles to respond to potential flash floods.

site_title: Football: Mourinho's Roma suffer humiliating 4-0 loss at Udinese
summary: AS Roma suffered a humiliating 4-0 loss to Udinese on September 4, handing Jose Mourinho his worst defeat as a Serie A team manager. Udinese took an early lead through Destiny Udogie's 5-minute goal, with Lazar Samardzic doubling the score in the 56th minute. Roberto Pereyra and Sandi Lovric sealed the win for Udinese, as Roma remain fifth in the league with 10 points. Mourinho attributed the defeat to individual mistakes, but acknowledged they were collective errors, with the loss leaving Roma one point behind leaders Napoli and AC Milan.

site_title: SPL Team of the Week: Matchweek 23
summary: Geylang International secured their second win over Lion City Sailors this season, thanks to six saves from goalkeeper Zaiful Nizam. The Eagles' comeback was led by Ilhan Noor, who equalized with a deflected cross, and Vincent Bezecourt, who scored a clinical double to stun the league leaders. Meanwhile, Albirex Niigata and Tampines Rovers also secured victories, with Kodai Tanaka scoring four goals to keep his team on track for the league title. The match highlights the strong performances of various players in the Singapore Premier League.

site_title: All SIA flights to South-east Asia cities to depart from Changi Airport's Terminal 2 in October
summary: Changi Airport's Terminal 2 will reopen for departing flights on October 11, with Singapore Airlines (SIA) flights to South-east Asian destinations being the first to move to the terminal. SIA's flights will initially depart from the southern wing, with all flights expected to be completed by October 13. The terminal's arrival halls had previously reopened in stages, with the northern wing expected to be fully completed by 2024. The move aims to increase passenger capacity and prepare for the busier year-end holiday peak, with Changi Airport's passenger handling capacity to be restored to pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: Former maths teacher at international school jailed for sex acts with student, 14
summary: A 29-year-old former maths teacher in Singapore has been jailed for 5 years for engaging in sex acts with a 14-year-old student. The teacher, who cannot be named, pleaded guilty to 3 charges of sexual penetration of a minor and was instructed to consume contraceptive pills after two instances of sex. The victim, now 17, was manipulated into keeping the relationship secret and reported the abuse to her mother, leading to a police report. The court found the teacher had abused his position of trust as a teacher and put the victim's health at risk.

site_title: Evergrande winding-up lawsuit in Hong Kong adjourned to Nov 7
summary: Hong Kong's High Court has adjourned a winding-up petition against China Evergrande Group to November 7, following an application by the company and its major offshore credit group. The petition, filed by an investor over a US$110 million repurchase agreement, could impact Evergrande's debt restructuring plan if successful. The court acknowledged the complexity of the firm's debt, but expects meaningful progress in restructuring by the next hearing. Evergrande aims to announce a concrete resolution plan respecting all stakeholders' rights as soon as possible, despite missing a self-imposed deadline for a detailed proposal.

site_title: Theatre review: The death of Singapore theatre and the revenge of an aggrieved playwright
summary: Singaporean playwright and poet Alfian Sa'at delivers a performance lecture, "The Death Of Singapore Theatre As Scripted By The Infocomm Media Development Authority Of Singapore," at The Substation. The play is a response to the Infocomm Media Development Authority's (IMDA) perceived stifling of the local theatre scene. Through this work, Sa'at seeks revenge on the agency that has been a long-standing critic of his work, allowing him to express his frustrations and grievances. The event marks a significant moment for Sa'at, giving him a platform to address the government agency that has been a thorn in his side.

images.alt_text: Actress Farah Ong in Alfian Sa'at's performance lecture, The Death of Singapore Theatre as scripted by the Infocomm Media Development Authority of Singapore at T:>Works for The Substation SeptFest2022

site_title: ITE students to open Western food stall under Food Republic tie-up to nurture young hawkers
summary: ITE College West students, including 19-year-old Wayne Tee, will operate a Western food stall at Food Republic in Shaw Centre under a tie-up with the Young Hawker Entrepreneurship Incubator Programme. The 7-student team will offer dishes priced under $15, with Asian-Western fusion fare, and will be supported by ITE lecturers. The 6-month internship aims to provide a stepping stone for students to test ideas and skills in a real work environment, and will serve as a capstone of their learning, with income dependent on sales.

site_title: 121 community care staff receive awards to upgrade their skills
summary: Singapore community care staff, including Ms Jenny Ang and Sathish Kumar Lakshmanan, received the Community Care Manpower Development Award for upgrading their skills. 121 staff members, including 46-year-old physiotherapist Sathish Kumar Lakshmanan, received the award, which provides training support and opportunities to advance their careers. The Agency for Integrated Care has given out almost 700 awards since 2017. The award aims to equip the sector with the right skills to meet the needs of an ageing population, with 25% of the population expected to be 65 and above by 2030.

site_title: Actress Park Eun-bin overwhelmed with gifts on 30th birthday
summary: K-drama actress Park Eun-bin celebrated her 30th birthday surrounded by gifts, expressing gratitude to fans for their love and support. Her series "The Extraordinary Attorney Woo" has seen a surge in popularity, becoming the seventh highest rated drama in South Korean cable television history and topping Netflix charts in the region. The show's portrayal of an autistic lawyer resonated with audiences, cementing Park Eun-bin's status as a rising star in the K-drama scene.

images.alt_text: The Extraordinary Attorney Woo star has seen her popularity skyrocket.

site_title: The Weeknd cancels concert in California mid-performance, says he lost his voice
summary: The Weeknd abruptly canceled a concert in California mid-performance on Saturday, citing that he lost his voice. He stopped the show after performing three songs at SoFi stadium, promising the audience that they would receive a full refund and apologizing for the inconvenience. The 32-year-old singer explained the situation on social media, stating that his voice went out during the first song and that he was devastated. His next concert is scheduled for September 22 at Rogers Centre in Toronto.

images.alt_text: The Weeknd performed during his After Hours Til Dawn tour at SoFi Stadium in Inglewood, California, on Sept 2, 2022.
