site_title: Blackpink becomes the first music act to top 80m YouTube subscribers
summary: K-pop girl group Blackpink has achieved a milestone by becoming the first music act to surpass 80 million subscribers on YouTube. They also broke the record for the first music act to reach 70 million subscribers in November 2021. The group's second album, Born Pink, is set to release on September 16, and they will embark on a world tour later this year. Their single "Pink Venom" has broken multiple records, including 90.4 million views within 24 hours, and is currently trending on YouTube.

images.alt_text: Blackpink performs at the 2022 MTV Video Music Awards at the Prudential Center in Newark, New Jersey, U.S., August 28, 2022. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: In The Driver's Seat: Hamilton finally has a Mercedes that can win, but his team might now be the problem
summary: Lewis Hamilton suffered a setback in the Dutch Grand Prix, his first chance to win with a competitive Mercedes this season. Despite a strong car, Hamilton's team made a one-stop strategy that favored teammate Max Verstappen over him, echoing Ferrari's strategy at Silverstone that favored Charles Leclerc. This decision came after a season marred by Hamilton's emotional struggles and an uncompetitive Mercedes. The result marked a turning point for Hamilton, who finally acknowledged his team might be the problem, rather than the car.

site_title: Crypto sceptics look to bend the ear of regulators at inaugural event this week
summary: Crypto critics, including economists and researchers, will attend the inaugural Crypto Policy Symposium in London and online, aiming to prompt critical discourse about the volatile sector. The event comes as Bitcoin's price has plummeted to around US$20,000, highlighting the risks for retail investors. Critics will emphasize the need for a clear legislative framework, better regulation, and informed users, following the collapse of Celsius Network and other crypto-related failures. The event seeks to balance the benefits of cryptocurrency technology with its real risks.

site_title: The Life List: Thai star Mario Maurer sports man bun for Bad Romeo
summary: Thai actor Mario Maurer has agreed to play the lead role in the hit Thai romance series Bad Romeo, despite only reading two episodes of the script. Maurer will portray Kaokla, a car mechanic with a signature man bun, opposite Urassaya Sperbund. The series, which explores a dramatic and high-stakes love story, will follow Kaokla and Sperbund's romance that transcends social class and overcomes a seven-year separation.

images.alt_text: Mario Maurer plays a man-bun sporting car mechanic in Thai romance series Bad Romeo.

site_title: Concert review: Assured playing of technically demanding pieces by Sir Stephen Hough
summary: Sir Stephen Hough delivered assured performances of technically demanding pieces at Victoria Concert Hall, part of a solo recital and a concert supported by the Re:Sound collective. The concerts took place on August 31 and September 4, with Hough showcasing his skill and artistry. His playing was praised, and the events were well-received by the audience.

site_title: Weekly MoneyFM Podcasts: How AI is fuelling more secure digital identity solutions
summary: Singapore's Weekly Money FM Podcasts discuss various topics, including the use of AI in securing digital identity solutions. Experts share insights on the benefits of zero-trust identity, a solo trip inspiring a career change, and innovative solutions to tackle climate change. Additionally, the podcast touches on local news, such as a new grant for companies, the launch of "smart diapers" for adult patients, and a Singaporean fugitive being charged with drug trafficking. The podcast is available on Money FM's website and on Spotify.

site_title: We ditched our corporate life to travel slow in Sulawesi
summary: A couple ditched their corporate lives to travel slow in Sulawesi, Indonesia. They spent time hiking around active volcanoes Mount Lokon and Mount Mahawu in Tomohon, popular with hikers. On a fishing boat, they encountered a crocodile fish, highlighting the unique experiences they had while exploring the region.

images.alt_text: Mount Lokon and Mount Mahawu are two active volcanoes popular with hikers in Tomohon.
Buffaloes are signs of wealth in Toraja and are gifted and sacrificed at Torajan funeral ceremonies.

site_title: Squid Game grabs early Emmy awards, setting up drama battle
summary: Squid Game won its first Emmy awards, including Outstanding Guest Actress in a Drama Series for Lee Yoo-mi, at the Creative Arts Emmys on Sept 4, 2022. The South Korean drama took home an acting honor and three other trophies, setting up a battle for the top drama prize. Lee Yoo-mi accepted the award on stage, speaking in Korean and English. The show will compete for the top drama honor against Stranger Things and Succession at the televised red-carpet event on Sept 12.

images.alt_text: Lee Yoo-mi won Outstanding Guest Actress in a Drama Series award at the Creative Arts Emmys on Sept 04, 2022.

site_title: S'pore retail sales up 13.7% in July as growth slows amid higher inflation
summary: Singapore's retail sales rose 13.7% year-on-year in July, slower than the 14.9% growth in June, due to higher inflation. Excluding motor vehicles, sales grew 18.1% year-on-year. Despite the slowdown, analysts expect retail sales to remain strong due to upcoming events like the Formula 1 Singapore Grand Prix and the year-end holiday season.

site_title: 7 Sim Lim Square units for nightlife venue use go on sale for $17m
summary: Seven retail units at Sim Lim Square, a six-storey electronics and IT mall in Singapore, have been put up for sale via private treaty with a guide price of $17 million. The units come with Class 1 entertainment licences, allowing 3am operating hours, and an estimated 4% rental yield. The sale comes amid a surge in demand for retail units zoned for nightlife entertainment purposes, following recent collective sales and licence renewals. The properties are eligible for foreigners and offer no seller's stamp duty or buyer's stamp duty.

site_title: Tennis: No shame for Medvedev as he loses to in-form Kyrgios at US Open
summary: Nick Kyrgios defeated Daniil Medvedev 7-6 (13-11), 3-6, 6-3, 6-2 in the fourth round of the US Open. Medvedev praised Kyrgios' performance, comparing it to that of Rafael Nadal and Novak Djokovic. The loss marks Medvedev's worst showing at a New York hard-court Grand Slam since 2018, and he will lose his world No. 1 ranking. Medvedev attributed his discomfort to the extreme air conditioning in the US, but acknowledged Kyrgios played a high-level match.

site_title: Number of off-peak cars continues to dip as COE premiums climb
summary: Singapore's off-peak car (OPC) scheme saw just 140 cars registered between January and July, representing 0.74% of total car registrations. This decline comes amid rising COE premiums, making the OPC option less attractive. The number of OPC cars on the road decreased to 10,293 in July, down from 45,173 in 2012. The drop in OPC registrations is attributed to the increasing cost of COE premiums, which is undercutting the rebates offered by the scheme.

site_title: Spider-Man: No Way Home tops dismal box office after nine months away
summary: Spider-Man: No Way Home returned to the No. 1 spot in North America over the Labour Day weekend, grossing US$6 million from 3,935 theatres with 11 minutes of extra footage. The film, which debuted in December 2021, is expected to finish the extended holiday weekend with US$7.6 million. Top Gun: Maverick trailed closely with US$5.5 million between Friday and Sunday, and an estimated US$7 million through Monday. Despite being widely available on home entertainment, both films highlight the bleak landscape at the box office.

images.alt_text: Sony’s Spider-Man: No Way Home managed to return to the No. 1 spot in North America over Labour Day weekend.

site_title: Euro hits 20-year low as Russia turns off gas supply
summary: The euro hit a 20-year low of US$0.988 as Russia halted gas supply to Europe, sparking concerns over energy prices and growth. The US dollar index surged to a two-decade high, while sterling hit a 2½-year low. Markets anticipate outsized rate hikes this week, with a near 80% chance of a 75 basis point hike in Europe and a 70% chance in Australia. The euro's decline is attributed to the heightened geopolitical risk and adverse global demand shocks, with European currencies expected to be the worst hit.

site_title: US cinemas had a great summer but there's a plot twist
summary: US cinema ticket sales lagged significantly behind pre-pandemic levels, with summer sales still below expectations. Despite blockbuster hits like Top Gun: Maverick and Doctor Strange In The Multiverse Of Madness, the industry faces debt, a severe shortage of big movies, and rising costs. Analysts suggest closing underperforming screens and restructuring the business to stay afloat, with Cineworld preparing to file for bankruptcy and AMC Entertainment struggling with $5 billion in debt. Attendance is expected to fall below 800 million this year, a far cry from the 1.6 billion tickets sold in 2002.

site_title: SIA, Genting S'pore and Suntec likely winners as consumers switch from products to services: DBS
summary: DBS Bank recommends investors consider switching from manufacturing to service sector stocks due to weak consumer demand and slowing growth expectations. Key picks include Singapore Airlines ($6.60), Genting Singapore ($1), and Suntec Reit ($1.90), which are poised for growth from tourism recovery and office workers returning to the office, respectively.

site_title: Markets scream warning over new UK prime minister's mammoth task
summary: The UK's next prime minister faces a daunting task, with the pound posting its worst monthly performance since 2016, a surge in government borrowing costs, and record underperformance in domestic stocks. The pound is trading near its lowest in decades, and borrowing costs for businesses have jumped after six rate hikes by the Bank of England. Investors will be watching closely to see if the new prime minister's policies can mitigate the economic crisis, with speculation that they may exacerbate it.

site_title: Children up to 6 years old to receive $200 in Child Development Account top-ups
summary: About 230,000 Singaporean children under 6 years old will receive a $200 top-up into their Child Development Account (CDA) from September 8. Parents must open a CDA by June 30 next year to receive the top-up. The funds can be used for education, healthcare, and childcare expenses at approved institutions. This is part of the Household Support Package announced during Budget 2022, providing additional support for families with child-raising expenses.

site_title: Football: Premier League talking points
summary: Manchester United has turned the corner after winning four consecutive games, including a 2-0 win over Arsenal, to boost their Premier League season. The team's recent signings, such as Lisandro Martinez and Tyrell Malacia, have provided solidity to their defense, while Christian Eriksen's clever play has brought out the best in Bruno Fernandes. Manager Erik ten Hag remains cautious, stating that United are still far from their best, but the team's confidence has been boosted with Cristiano Ronaldo's future now settled until January.

site_title: Barack Obama: US president, Nobel laureate and now an Emmy winner
summary: Former US President Barack Obama has been awarded an Emmy for narrating the Netflix documentary series "Our Great National Parks." This marks his first Emmy win, bringing him one step closer to achieving EGOT status, which requires winning an Oscar, Tony, and Grammy in addition to the Emmy. Obama's production company, which has a deal with Netflix, previously won an Oscar for "American Factory" and an Emmy for directing, although the awards went to the filmmakers. The award is the latest in Obama's distinguished career, following his Nobel Peace Prize win in 2008.

images.alt_text: Mr Barack Obama (with Mrs Michelle Obama) was awarded an Emmy for narrating his Netflix documentary series Our Great National Parks.

site_title: Jump in exports to US keeps India in race to become next China
summary: India has gained a clear lead in exports to the US, with seaborne shipments of festival goods and accessories reaching $20 million in August, nearly tripling the value from the previous year. This is driven by diversification of supply sources in the face of rising labor costs and disruptions from China's COVID-19-zero policy. India's exports to the US have increased by 54% for Christmas decorations and 32% for handicrafts in the year ended March. The trend is expected to continue, with India projected to contribute over $500 billion annually to the global economy by 2030.

site_title: China's love affair with property not over despite downturn
summary: China's economy has grown increasingly reliant on the property sector, with housing assets accounting for 70% of urban family wealth in 2019. Despite a downturn, China's love affair with property is not over, with the sector remaining a key driver of growth. The reliance on property ownership for wealth accumulation is deeply ingrained in Chinese culture, with limited alternatives for investment onshore.

site_title: Grab rival Be Group gets $84m loan for Vietnam expansion
summary: Vietnamese ride-hailing start-up Be Group has secured a loan facility of at least US$60 million (S$84 million) from Deutsche Bank to expand and enhance its services, including ride-hailing, food delivery, and digital banking. The funds will be used to challenge Grab Holdings in the country, with Be Group aiming to surpass 10 million active users next year and double that figure by 2026. The company, which operates in 28 provinces and cities, has a 30-40% share of the ride-hailing market in Hanoi and 25-35% in Ho Chi Minh City.

site_title: K-pop, K-drama...K-art. Frieze fair lands in Seoul
summary: The inaugural Frieze Seoul art fair took place in Seoul, marking the city's emergence as a cultural powerhouse in the art world. The fair, which featured major Western galleries, confirmed Seoul's position as a vibrant and exciting market in Asia, following a surge in the local art market since the COVID-19 pandemic. Industry experts praise the city's rich art scene, world-class museums, and a balanced demographic of collectors, including younger, tech-savvy buyers. The fair's arrival is seen as a natural fit for Seoul, which is now positioning itself as a key player in the global art market.

images.alt_text: Visitors walk past artwork, Day Into Night Lips, 2022, by artist Gina Beavers during the Frieze Seoul 2022 art fair in Seoul on Sept 2, 2022.

site_title: NDP: Goodbye, floating platform, hello, National Stadium?
summary: The Marina Bay floating platform, which hosted its last National Day Parade (NDP) this year, is set to be transformed into the permanent NS Square by 2026. The platform's unique venue may be replaced by the National Stadium, which could host future NDPs, but some elements such as aerial displays and fireworks may not work as well. Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen and former NDP creative director Beatrice Chia-Richmond suggest the National Stadium offers a more intimate setting, while veteran musician and director Dick Lee notes the unique character and significance of each venue.

site_title: Film legend Paul Schrader is seriously ill but on a roll
summary: Film legend Paul Schrader, 76, is struggling with a mysterious illness that has left him breathless and uncertain about his future. Despite this, his latest film, Master Gardener, starring Sigourney Weaver and Joel Edgerton, received praise at the Venice Film Festival. The film follows a gardener with a dark past and explores themes of forgiveness and rebirth. Schrader, known for his Oscar-nominated films like First Reformed and Raging Bull, credits new technology for allowing him to work more freely, but notes that the film industry is still facing challenges, with many struggling to make a living.

images.alt_text: US filmmaker Paul Schrader receives the Golden Lion at the  Venice Film Festival on Sept 3, 2022.

site_title: Brendan Fraser makes Whale-sized comeback in Venice
summary: Actor Brendan Fraser made a significant comeback in the Venice Film Festival with his portrayal of Charlie, a morbidly obese English professor in Darren Aronofsky's film "The Whale." Fraser, 53, transformed his body to play the role, drawing instant acclaim and praise from critics. The film, which explores themes of trauma, love, and redemption, has been praised for its optimistic tone and Fraser's powerful performance. Fraser's return to acting marks a notable comeback after his career declined in the late 2000s, and he is now considered a frontrunner for an Oscar.

images.alt_text: US director Darren Aronofsky (left) and US-Canadian actor Brendan Fraser at the premiere of The Whale during the 79th annual Venice International Film Festival on Sept 4, 2022.

site_title: Work Talk Podcast: Oh, how we suck at work appraisals
summary: Singapore workers are often dissatisfied with their annual performance reviews, with many considering them to be unhelpful and unfair. Experts argue that managers should adopt a different approach to appraisals, focusing on development and growth rather than just grades. In a tight labour market, managers can reduce attrition by conducting better appraisals, but the current system can lead to workers feeling undervalued and unfulfilled. The conversation highlights the need for managers to adapt their approach to the changing workforce and prioritize employee development and well-being.

site_title: After 2½ years of fighting Covid-19, most NCID staff can finally take a breather
summary: The National Centre for Infectious Diseases (NCID) staff in Singapore are finally able to take a break after 2½ years of fighting Covid-19. According to NCID executive director Leo Yee Sin, nurses have been particularly exhausted, but most staff can now take a breather. This comes after a long period of battling the pandemic on the front lines.

site_title: Tennis: Berrettini, Ruud into US Open quarter-finals
summary: Italy's Matteo Berrettini advanced to the US Open quarter-finals, defeating Alejandro Davidovich Fokina 3-6, 7-6 (7/2), 6-3, 4-6, 6-2. Berrettini, the 13th seed, will face Norway's Casper Ruud, the fifth seed, in the quarter-finals on Tuesday. Ruud also reached the quarter-finals, defeating French lucky loser Corentin Moutet 6-1, 6-2, 6-7 (4/7), 6-2. The two will compete for a semi-final spot.

site_title: Golf: Dustin Johnson wins LIV event in Boston, takes home US$4 million first prize
summary: Dustin Johnson won the LIV Golf Invitational Boston, defeating Chile's Joaquin Niemann and India's Anirban Lahiri in a three-way playoff. Johnson carded a 65 on Sunday to finish 15-under par, securing the US$4 million first prize and becoming the first American to win the individual trophy in the series. Johnson's victory marked his sixth win in the LIV Golf Invitational series, following his previous wins in London, Portland, and Bedminster.

site_title: Tennis: Garcia storms into maiden US Open quarter-final
summary: France's Caroline Garcia advanced to the US Open quarter-finals with a 6-4, 6-1 victory over Alison Riske-Amritraj. Garcia, the world number 17, has now won 12 consecutive matches and reached the quarter-finals at the US Open for the first time. She will face Coco Gauff or Zhang Shuai in the semi-finals, having previously lost to Riske-Amritraj in all three of their meetings. Garcia attributed her success to managing her emotions and playing her shots, expressing excitement about her tournament run.

site_title: New study questions carbon capture projects' ability to cut global CO2 emissions
summary: A new study by the Institute for Energy Economics and Financial Analysis questions the effectiveness of carbon capture projects in reducing global CO2 emissions. The report found that many projects underperformed or failed, and that CO2 captured is often used to extract more oil, contributing to increased emissions. The study calls for developers to take responsibility for CO2 leakage and stresses that captured CO2 should not be used in oil extraction. The report's author, Mr. Bruce Robertson, recommends that carbon capture projects not be used as a climate solution to justify fossil fuel use, citing the need for alternative solutions to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050.

site_title: Content creator Annette Lee on her 7 must-have travel items
summary: Content creator Annette Lee shares her 7 must-have travel items to pack in a hand-carry for a stress-free trip. With baggage issues common in airports, especially in Europe and the US, having essential items readily available is crucial. Annette and travel correspondent Clara Lock agree that a well-stocked hand-carry can make a big difference in navigating unfamiliar environments and dealing with travel disruptions. Their shared tips focus on practicality and versatility to ensure a smooth journey.

site_title: NCID on alert against future disease outbreaks, with current ones under control
summary: The National Centre for Infectious Diseases (NCID) in Singapore is on high alert against future disease outbreaks, with the current Covid-19 cases under control. Despite a recent surge in hospital admissions, with over 60 cases at NCID, the situation is being closely monitored. Meanwhile, the NCID is also dealing with a dengue outbreak, with over 25,500 cases recorded since the start of the year, a significant increase from the previous year.

site_title: Engineer who led construction of floating platform 15 years ago recalls the challenges
summary: A 15-year-old floating platform in Singapore, built for the National Day Parade (NDP), has been a successful and enduring venue, hosting 11 NDPs and becoming a popular spot for waterfront events. Designed by a team led by Tan Hian Nam, the platform was constructed in 13 months, exceeding its initial two-year timeline by three years. The platform will soon be demolished to make way for the NS Square, a new development that will serve as a venue for future NDPs and a community space with educational areas, aiming to share the country's defence story and create shared experiences for Singaporeans.

site_title: Credit Suisse court battle with billionaire kicks off in Singapore
summary: Credit Suisse is on trial in Singapore for alleged negligence by a billionaire client, Bidzina Ivanishvili, which he claims cost him up to $800 million. Ivanishvili, a former Georgian prime minister, will testify via video link. The trial comes after Ivanishvili won a related case against Credit Suisse's Bermuda unit, which was also accused of negligence. The case is part of a series of disputes that have weighed on the bank's costs and reputation, amid a strategic review that could see significant restructuring.

site_title: askST Jobs: I've secured a job with a rival firm. What can I do so I don't burn bridges?
summary: A former employee who joined a rival firm can minimize the risk of burning bridges by honoring their employment contract, including non-competition clauses and garden leave. It's essential to be transparent with their previous employer, avoid bad-mouthing them, and respect intellectual property. Taking steps to make the handover process smoother for their replacement and expressing gratitude to colleagues can also help preserve a professional relationship.

site_title: Learning to let go on home-based learning days
summary: Debra Ann Francisco shares her experience of juggling work and homeschooling her son on Fridays during the pandemic. She recalls the initial dread of supervising her children's lessons at home while working, a common challenge faced by many parents island-wide. Francisco reflects on learning to adapt and find balance in this new normal, highlighting the need for flexibility and time management skills to manage work and childcare responsibilities effectively.

site_title: Less time at school, more time for learning
summary: Singapore's secondary schools and junior colleges have introduced a home-based learning (HBL) day once a fortnight, allowing students to pursue their interests and interests outside of the classroom. This change has been beneficial for students, such as Madhumaya Anandan Kumaran, who can now save time on commuting and dedicate an hour to personal activities, like learning oil painting. The HBL day is seen as a positive development, giving students more flexibility and autonomy in their learning.

site_title: LTA, NParks plant a cool idea at bus stops islandwide
summary: The National Parks Board (NParks) and Land Transport Authority (LTA) have launched a nationwide initiative to install green-roofed bus stops to cool the city. This plan aims to reduce the urban heat island effect and improve air quality. The green-roofed bus stops, which feature local shrubs and plants, have been rolled out islandwide, providing a natural cooling solution for commuters. This initiative is part of Singapore's efforts to mitigate the impact of climate change and improve the city's livability.

site_title: 'Emerging infections are not fiction any more': NCID head Leo Yee Sin on preparing for Disease X
summary: The National Centre for Infectious Diseases (NCID) in Singapore is strengthening its capabilities to prepare for "Disease X", the next potential pandemic threat. As the centre turns three in September, its executive director Leo Yee Sin emphasized the need to bolster clinical, public health, and research arms to combat future outbreaks. This move comes after the centre's successful battle against Covid-19. The enhanced NCID will help Singapore stay safe and respond effectively to emerging infectious diseases.

site_title: Ready for a night out? Hire a disco nanny
summary: In party hot spots like Mykonos and Ibiza, overnight childcare services, known as "disco nannies," have become increasingly popular among tourists. These agencies provide caregivers who specialize in late-night care for children, often with graduate degrees in education and multiple language skills. The services allow parents to enjoy a night out, with some nannies staying with children until the parents' hangovers subside the next day. Demand is high, with some clients booking nannies up to a year in advance, and costs range from €20 to €30 per hour.

site_title: Shrines destroyed in Kusu Island fire 70% reconstructed: Caretaker
summary: Three Malay shrines on Kusu Island, destroyed in a fire on April 17, 2022, are nearly 70% reconstructed, according to caretaker Ishak Samsudin. The reconstruction, funded by donations, will follow the original structure and will be ready for the upcoming pilgrimage season. The second phase, rebuilding the metal roof, is not expected to be completed in time, and a temporary shelter will be set up. The reconstruction is a significant undertaking, with materials being carried up 152 steps by hand, and costs estimated at $5,000 to $6,000 a week.

site_title: Singapore aviation firms ramp up hiring to meet increase in flights
summary: Singapore Airlines and other local aviation firms are ramping up hiring to meet the increase in flights, with cabin crew trainees and airport workers in strong demand. The airline has hired 1,200 people so far and aims to recruit the remaining 800 trainees by December. Changi Airport's handling capacity has largely stayed ahead of growing passenger traffic, with the airport needing an additional 3,500 to 4,000 workers to reach 95% of pre-pandemic levels. Airlines are offering higher salaries to attract workers, with some roles seeing a 30% increase.

site_title: Start-up's novel energy storage system to power parts of Pulau Ubin
summary: Singapore start-up VFlowTech has built a container-like energy storage system using vanadium metal, which can store energy from the sun or wind. The system, developed by two NTU scientists, will power parts of Pulau Ubin, aiming to reduce the island's reliance on fossil fuels. The 40-foot-long batteries can store 1 megawatt-hour of energy, equivalent to powering nearly three Housing Board flats for a month. VFlowTech's technology is safer and longer-lasting than lithium-ion batteries, with a lifespan of 25 years.

site_title: Made in Germany: On the trail of Leica, Mercedes-Benz and other super-brands
summary: The "Made in Germany" stamp originated from the British "Merchandise Marks Act" in 1887, which required foreign goods to be stamped with their country of origin. This concept was later adopted by Germany and has since become synonymous with the country's high-quality products, including Mercedes-Benz, Bosch appliances, and Adidas sportswear. German brands are now among the most admired globally, reflecting the country's reputation for engineering excellence and attention to detail.

images.alt_text: Mercedes-Benz World

site_title: LTA, NParks planting a cool idea at bus stops across S'pore
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) and National Parks Board (NParks) are planting green roofs on 150 bus stops across Singapore over the next two years to reduce ambient heat. This initiative aims to provide shade and mitigate the urban heat island effect, making the city a cooler place to live. The green roofs will feature shrubs, which will not only provide aesthetic appeal but also help to reduce the temperature at bus stops.

site_title: Study questions carbon capture projects' ability to cut CO2 emissions
summary: A new study questioned the effectiveness of carbon capture projects in reducing global CO2 emissions, finding that 10 out of 13 facilities did not meet their goals. The study highlights the need for careful consideration in upcoming projects, including ensuring that captured CO2 is not used in oil extraction.

site_title: Better pay, work-life balance and recognition needed to draw new engineers: Experts
summary: Singapore's engineering industry faces a shortage due to low pay, poor work-life balance, and lack of recognition, according to experts. The Professional Engineers Board Symposium highlighted the need for higher remuneration, work-life balance, and recognition to attract new talent. The Government has initiated initiatives such as the Skills Framework for Built Environment and the Corenet X platform to support engineers. However, young engineers like Ryan Tan are exploring alternative fields due to unattractive pay and long working hours, raising concerns about the industry's ability to retain talent.

site_title: Make sure you do the right things after securing a job with rival firm
summary: Securing a job with a rival firm can be a natural career progression, but it's essential to maintain a professional relationship with the current employer. Before joining a competitor, review confidentiality agreements and non-competition clauses in the employment contract. Honouring these commitments can help preserve your good name and avoid future entanglements. Experts advise being transparent, respecting intellectual property, and making the transition as smooth as possible for the replacement. Taking time to thank colleagues on the last day also shows appreciation and can maintain a positive relationship.

site_title: Nervousness as markets turn volatile on softer US jobs data
summary: US job data showed "Goldilocks" numbers, but markets tanked last Friday due to concerns over the Federal Reserve's next rate hikes, sparking fears of "over-tightening." The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 3% and lost 4.81% since June, with a 13.81% decline since the start of the year. Investors are nervous about the Fed's aggressive hikes, leading to market volatility.

site_title: Recovery works may take a few months
summary: A landslide occurred at a Clementi Build-To-Order (BTO) site on September 2, damaging a section of the Ulu Pandan park connector and displacing soil into the Ulu Pandan Canal. Recovery works, led by the Building and Construction Authority (BCA), Housing Board, and National Parks Board, are ongoing, with a focus on mitigating the impact and ensuring public safety. Minister Desmond Lee said the works may take a few months to complete, with a temporary closure of a section of the park connector in place due to potential flood risks.

site_title: DPM Wong to meet Malaysian King and PM during 4-day visit
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong is set to visit Malaysia from Sunday to Wednesday, where he will meet with the King, Sultan Abdullah Sultan Ahmad Shah, and Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob. This is Wong's first official visit to Malaysia since his appointment as Deputy Prime Minister in June. During his 4-day trip, Wong will also meet with key government officials and business personalities, including the Minister of Defence and Finance. The visit aims to strengthen bilateral ties between Singapore and Malaysia.

site_title: Enjoying HBL days with my teens
summary: A mother shares her positive experience with her children's home-based learning (HBL) days, where she gets to spend quality time with them and they learn to manage technology and self-learning. Her 16-year-old son and 13-year-old daughter have different learning styles, but both are independent and responsible for their work. The mother trusts them to complete their assignments and only offers moral support, allowing them to bond with her during HBL days. She believes HBL has been a valuable adaptation to the pandemic and provides a refreshing change from traditional school days.

site_title: WP panel to look into Daniel Goh's Facebook posts on Raeesah Khan
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) has convened a disciplinary committee to investigate Facebook posts by cadre member Daniel Goh regarding former WP MP Raeesah Khan. Goh's posts questioned the party's handling of Khan's resignation, alleging the leadership failed to address "inconvenient questions." He claimed his posts were based on public information and expressed concerns about public accountability and integrity. Goh has stated he has no intention of resigning from the party, but urged the leaders to make public the grounds for the disciplinary committee and explain any sanctions they may impose.

site_title: Fun With Kids
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Family-friendly activities are available in Singapore, including a walking tour game "Otah & Friends: Go Gai Gai" in Joo Chiat, which costs $17 per person and takes 2.4km. The game is suitable for kids aged 6 and up. The Esplanade is hosting the 18th annual Moonfest from Sept 10-12, featuring family workshops and free Chinese arts performances. Meanwhile, the Singapore Botanic Gardens has a Think! Contemporary Preschool Exhibition showcasing artworks created from recycled materials by pre-schoolers until Sept 18. These activities aim to make family time more special and engaging.

site_title: S'pore aviation firms ramp up hiring amid surge in air travel
summary: Singapore Airlines and other local aviation firms are ramping up hiring amid a surge in air travel, with nearly all types of airport workers in strong demand due to a tight labor market. The airline aims to hire 800 more cabin crew trainees by December, while Changi Airport's handling capacity has largely stayed ahead of growing passenger traffic. Experts note that major Asian markets remain restricted, limiting the recovery in Asia, and that labor shortages are a key hurdle for airlines in the region.

site_title: Repair work may take months
summary: A landslide at a Clementi Build-To-Order site in Singapore damaged the Ulu Pandan park connector and displaced soil into the Ulu Pandan Canal. Repair work, led by the Housing Board, National Parks Board, and PUB, is ongoing but may take several months to complete. A section of the park connector has been reopened, while another section remains closed for public safety. National Development Minister Desmond Lee visited the site on Sunday and assured that the repair efforts are underway, prioritizing public safety and safety of the site.

site_title: Motor insurers hit by rising costs and intense competition
summary: Motor insurers face rising costs and intense competition, but a battle for market share has kept premium increases in check. Industry experts attribute this to the competition sparked by AXA Singapore's exit from the motor insurance business earlier this year, which has led to insurers vying for new customers and maintaining price stability.

site_title: Traceability key to lifting ban on cats in HDB flats
summary: The Singapore government is considering lifting the ban on keeping cats as pets in Housing Board (HDB) flats after a public consultation exercise. The ban, in place since 1960, was initially implemented due to concerns over cat waste and noise. However, the Animal and Veterinary Service (AVS) now proposes a framework that includes microchipping and licensing, as well as a Trap-Neuter-Return-Manage (TNRM) program for community cats. Traceability of cats through microchipping is seen as key to lifting the ban, allowing owners to be held accountable and reunite lost pets with their owners.

site_title: Motor insurers hit by rising costs, rivalry for business keeps higher premiums in check
summary: The motor insurance sector in Singapore reported a total underwriting loss of $15.4 million from April to June, largely due to rising inflation costs. However, a fierce rivalry among insurers has kept premium increases in check, preventing a significant rise. The exit of AXA Singapore from the market has intensified the competition, prompting insurers to focus on attracting new customers and maintaining market share.

site_title: China's love affair with property not over despite downturn
summary: China's love affair with property remains strong despite a downturn. Real estate ownership is seen as a key way to grow generational wealth globally, and this is particularly true in China, where housing assets account for 70% of urban family wealth as of 2019. This trend is largely driven by a lack of investment alternatives onshore, making property a primary means of wealth accumulation.

site_title: Straits Trading targets new areas after ARA stake sale
summary: Straits Trading Company has sold its stake in ARA Asset Management to ESR Group for US$5.2 billion, yielding $142.5 million in cash and 214.7 million ESR shares. This deal allows Straits Trading shareholders to choose between receiving additional shares in the company or opting for shares in ESR, a leading property manager in the Asia-Pacific. Straits Trading plans to allocate the capital to industrial properties over the next 3-5 years, marking a shift in the company's investment strategy.

site_title: Markets turn volatile on softer US jobs data, speculation of further rate hikes
summary: US jobs data for August was met with a volatile market reaction, as investors worried about further interest rate hikes by the US Federal Reserve. Despite "Goldilocks" jobs numbers, the Dow Jones Industrials Index plummeted 3% last Friday, resulting in a 4.81% loss since June and a 13.81% decline since the start of the year. The market is caught between high inflation and rising interest rates, leading to uncertainty and a decline in stock prices.

site_title: After Ara divestment, property manager Straits Trading targets growth in new areas
summary: The Straits Trading Company, a Hong Kong-listed firm, has gained more than $1 billion after selling its 22% stake in ARA Asset Management (Ara) to ESR Group for US$5.2 billion. As part of the deal, Straits Trading received 214.7 million ESR shares. The acquisition marks a significant growth opportunity for Straits Trading, allowing shareholders to opt for additional shares in the company or shares in ESR, one of the largest property managers in the Asia Pacific region.

site_title: Verstappen hails 'special' home win
summary: Max Verstappen won his fourth consecutive Formula One race at the Dutch Grand Prix, claiming a "special" victory at his home track. The Red Bull driver now holds a 109-point lead over nearest challenger Charles Leclerc with seven races remaining, bolstering his chances of a second consecutive world championship. Verstappen credited his team's strategy and his own timing for the win, while Leclerc expressed frustration over Ferrari's struggling performance.

site_title: S'pore crush Maldives to enter netball s-finals
summary: Singapore has advanced to the semi-finals of the Asian Netball Championship after a 96-10 victory over Maldives. Despite losing veteran shooter Charmaine Soh to a knee injury, the team rallied behind Goh Wei Ping, who scored 30 goals in her international debut. Singapore will face Hong Kong, the top team in Group D, in the second round on Tuesday. The team's head coach, Annette Bishop, praised Goh's performance, saying it was "excellent" in a game that showcased the team's strength and ability to adapt to challenges.

site_title: Crowds throng JB as school holidays begin
summary: Large crowds flocked to Johor Bahru, Malaysia, as school holidays began on both sides of the Causeway, causing traffic congestion in the city. Over 313,000 people passed through the Woodlands and Tuas checkpoints on August 26-28, surpassing pre-Covid-19 levels. Many hotels, including one with 80% occupancy, reported busy periods due to the holidays. Travelers advised to adjust their plans to avoid heavy traffic, with some using mobile apps to track traffic patterns. Delays are expected, with immigration clearing times potentially taking 3-4 hours.

site_title: Swiatek 'finds solutions' despite imperfect display
summary: Poland's Iga Swiatek reached the fourth round of the US Open for the second successive year, overcoming a second-set deficit to defeat American Lauren Davis 6-3, 6-4. Despite an imperfect display, Swiatek, the world No. 1, remains the title favourite. She will face unseeded German Jule Niemeier in the last 16. American Danielle Collins also advanced to the fourth round, while Chinese players Zhang Shuai, Zheng Qinwen, Yuan Yue, and Wang Xiyu all made history by reaching the third round.

site_title: Kusu Island shrines set to be ready for pilgrimage season
summary: Kusu Island's three Malay shrines, destroyed in a fire in April, are nearly 70% reconstructed and expected to be ready for the upcoming pilgrimage season, which begins in September. The shrines, built in the 1920s, were funded by caretaker Ishak Samsudin with donations from friends and companies. The reconstruction process has been challenging due to the site's accessibility, requiring workers to carry materials by hand up 152 steps. The first phase of reconstruction will follow the original structure, but the metal roof is unlikely to be ready in time, with a temporary shelter planned.

site_title: Seagulls soar high to continue good start
summary: Brighton extended their Premier League lead with a 5-2 victory over Leicester, their fourth win from six games. Leicester's struggles continued as they lost for the fifth time in a row, taking just one point from their first six games. Manager Brendan Rodgers expressed frustration at the team's lack of improvement, citing a lack of support from owners in the transfer market. Leicester's bottom-of-the-table position has left Rodgers under severe pressure, with the club's worst start to a season since 1983.

site_title: Sports World: Sailors’ title charge halted by Geylang
summary: The Singapore Premier League title chase was disrupted as Geylang International defeated Lion City Sailors 3-1, halting the Sailors' title charge. The Sailors remain top with 51 points, but Geylang's win moves them to fourth place. Meanwhile, Barcelona secured a 3-0 win over Sevilla, moving to second place in La Liga with 10 points behind leaders Real Madrid. In mixed martial arts, Ciryl Gane defeated Tai Tuivasa by technical knockout in the third round of their heavyweight bout at UFC Fight Night in Paris.

site_title: Why the Lakers are willing to pay LeBron US$100m
summary: The Los Angeles Lakers are willing to pay LeBron James a two-year, $97.1 million contract extension with a player option for a third year, despite trends suggesting that James' performance may decline with age. The deal is seen as a signal to other teams that the Lakers are committed to keeping their stars, and has a branding benefit for the team. James has defied human limits in his career, but his contract may pay off for the Lakers in ways beyond wins, including merchandise sales and TV ratings, as his retirement date approaches.

site_title: No respite likely from bond losses as Fed looks set to keep raising rates
summary: The US bond market is likely to continue losing value as the Federal Reserve is expected to keep raising interest rates to combat inflation. Despite a slight easing of wage pressures, the economy's momentum suggests the Fed will maintain its aggressive monetary policy until inflation subsides. Treasury yields have risen, with the 10-year yield reaching 3.19%, and investors are pricing in a 3.8% peak rate. The Treasury market has lost over 10% this year, setting the stage for its deepest annual loss in decades.

site_title: Fury won't wait for Usyk, will reveal new opponent
summary: Tyson Fury has announced he will reveal his next opponent in the coming days, despite initial plans for a unification fight with Oleksandr Usyk this year. Fury has been active in wrestling, making a guest appearance at WWE's show in Cardiff, and has expressed interest in joining the company full-time. Usyk has stated he won't fight Fury this year due to old traumas that need to be treated, and has set a target of next year for a potential rematch. Fury has been open about his desire to continue fighting, saying he won't wait around for others.

site_title: Celavi fades once she gets the sand kickback in Seoul
summary: Celavi, a Singapore raider, was favored to win the 1 billion won Group 3 Korea Sprint, but was instead outpaced by South Korea's Eoma Eoma in a 2-horse duel. The mare dropped back quickly after facing the "sand kickback" in the 1,200m race at Seoul Racecourse, finishing second to Japan's Raptus. Celavi's jockey attributed the loss to the mare's sudden loss of motivation after encountering the kickback, and the horse will return to Singapore on Tuesday.

site_title: Nigerian sprinter gets ban for doping
summary: Nigerian sprinter Nzubechi Grace Nwokocha has been provisionally suspended for using banned substances Ostarine and Ligandrol, according to the Athletics Integrity Unit. The 21-year-old gold medalist in the 4x100m relay at the Commonwealth Games in Birmingham awaits a hearing before a final decision is made. If the suspension is upheld, Nigeria may risk losing their gold medal. This is a setback for the country, which had a successful campaign, earning 12 gold medals and finishing seventh overall. A hearing is scheduled to determine Nwokocha's fate.

site_title: No 'overthinking' does it
summary: Singaporean figure skater Pagiel Sng won the gold medal in the senior men's category at the inaugural SEA Open Figure Skating Trophy, scoring 172.12 points. His victory also meets the minimum total elements score required for the International Skating Union Four Continents Figure Skating Championships. Sng credited his coach for keeping him focused and the home crowd's support for his win, saying it was a "dream come true" and a testament to his hard work.

site_title: Nadal improves but needs more
summary: Rafael Nadal dominated Richard Gasquet 6-0, 6-1, 7-5 to advance to the US Open fourth round, improving his record against his childhood rival to 18-0. Nadal, the world No. 3, acknowledged he needs more improvement to challenge for a fifth US Open title, which would tie him with other Open era greats. Up next for Nadal is Frances Tiafoe, while Wimbledon finalist Cameron Norrie reached the fourth round with a win over Holger Rune.

site_title: City not precise enough: Guardiola
summary: Pep Guardiola criticized Manchester City for being "not precise enough" in their 1-1 Premier League draw against Aston Villa, despite Erling Haaland's 10th goal in six games. The Norway striker scored in the second half, but City failed to build on the lead, with Villa's Leon Bailey scoring an equalizer. The draw marked City's first time this season failing to score more than once in a game. Despite the loss, City remain in second place above Tottenham on goal difference.

site_title: NCID staff set for a breather after 21/2 years of fighting Covid-19
summary: Staff at the National Centre for Infectious Diseases (NCID) in Singapore are set to take a 2.5-year break after fighting Covid-19 on the front lines. NCID's executive director, Leo Yee Sin, hopes that most people can now take a breather, indicating an improvement in the situation.

site_title: Azarenka raises fears of sexual abuse
summary: Victoria Azarenka expressed concern over the exploitation of women tennis players, citing the recent rape charges against former coach Pierre Bouteyre, who coached French player Fiona Ferro. Azarenka, a member of the WTA Tour's Players' Council, emphasized the need for better safeguarding practices to protect vulnerable players. She praised Ferro for coming forward and expressed her own hesitation about encouraging her daughter to pursue a career in professional tennis if she were a parent. Azarenka urged the tennis community to do more to support and protect players.

site_title: Focus shifts to preparing for future disease outbreaks, with current ones under control
summary: The National Centre for Infectious Diseases (NCID) is shifting focus from combating Covid-19 to preparing for future disease outbreaks. Currently, the dengue outbreak has seen over 25,500 cases since the start of the year, surpassing the 5,258 cases reported for the entire previous year, highlighting the need for NCID to adapt to emerging health threats.

site_title: Joy for hosts as Yamaguchi, Nishimoto win
summary: Japanese shuttlers Akane Yamaguchi and Kenta Nishimoto won the women's and men's singles titles at the Japan Open, respectively. Yamaguchi defeated An Se-young 21-9, 21-15, while Nishimoto stunned Chou Tien-chen 21-19, 21-23, 21-17. This marks Yamaguchi's third title of the year, including the All England Open, and Nishimoto's first international title. The victory brings double joy to the Japanese crowd, following a loss by fellow countryman Kento Momota in the first round earlier in the tournament.

site_title: Another Imposing victory looks on the cards
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The article analyzes the form of horses at Greyville in South Africa. In the 5 races, several horses are considered contenders for victory, including Imposing, Bonne Bouche, Wylie Riley, High Moon, and Imposing. Each horse's strengths and weaknesses are discussed, with some having an advantage due to the Polytrack surface. The article concludes that some horses, such as Imposing and Bonne Bouche, have a strong chance of winning, while others, like Wylie Riley and High Moon, are dark horses in their respective races.

site_title: Next 48 hours
summary: Singapore to launch a new grant for companies amid US tariff uncertainties, with up to 90% of air-con units potentially recyclable. The country is also exploring 'smart diapers' for adult patients and has arrested a Singaporean fugitive charged with drug trafficking, who may face the death penalty. Meanwhile, the World Aquatics Championships Singapore 2025 has been declared open by President Tharman Shanmugaratnam.

site_title: Dutch GP sees bright future ahead
summary: Dutch Grand Prix organisers expressed confidence in the event's future as a part of Formula One's calendar, citing its unique value in terms of sustainability, smart mobility, and entertainment. The massive popularity of world champion Max Verstappen helped secure funds to modernize the tracks, and the event's popularity, with over 300,000 tickets sold out months in advance, suggests a strong future. A decision to continue the deal will depend on local corporate sponsors and the willingness to maintain the event without government support.

site_title: Taking a huge step towards 2023 Cambodia SEA Games
summary: National triathletes Luke Chua and Bryce Chong took part in the TriFactor National Sprint Championship, with Chua emerging as the national sprint champion after a neck-and-neck finish with his teammate. Chua attributed his win to training with his teammates and preparing for the 2023 SEA Games in Cambodia. Filipina Raven Alcoseba won the women's title, while Cedric Chua finished third. The event was part of the team's training for the SEA Games, with the trio aiming to qualify and compete against Southeast Asian athletes.

site_title: Help for sports lovers to stay active despite history of knee injuries
summary: A sports enthusiast shares their personal story of struggling with knee injuries, starting at age 21 after a backflip went wrong, resulting in an ACL rupture. The author has since been on a quest to find a remedy for their knees, highlighting the challenges of maintaining an active lifestyle despite repeated injuries.

site_title: Consistency a challenge for All Blacks and Boks
summary: New Zealand's All Blacks suffered a 53-3 thrashing of Argentina, but forwards coach Jason Ryan called for consistency, not a response to setbacks. The team's hot-cold form has been a challenge, despite impressive wins after losses. Ryan and new assistant coach Joe Schmidt are credited with improving the team's performance. New Zealand leads the Rugby Championship with two Tests remaining, while South Africa captain Siya Kolisi targets a consistent run of results for the Springboks. Consistency is key for all teams, with the competition reaching its climax.

site_title: Start-up's novel energy storage system to power parts of Pulau Ubin
summary: Singapore's start-up VFlowTech has developed a novel energy storage system using vanadium metal, which can store energy from the sun or wind. The system, consisting of two tanks filled with vanadium ions, can last 25 years and be cheaper over its life cycle compared to lithium-ion batteries. Two of VFlowTech's 40-foot-long batteries will power parts of Pulau Ubin, including National Parks Board facilities and some houses, starting from early next year. The move aims to support Singapore's energy transition and increase the island's reliance on solar energy.

site_title: NCID boosting capabilities to deal with next pandemic
summary: Singapore's National Centre for Infectious Diseases (NCID) is strengthening its capabilities to combat the next pandemic, dubbed "Disease X." Following the COVID-19 outbreak, NCID's executive director Leo Yee Sin announced enhancements to its clinical, public health, and research arms to prepare the nation for future disease threats. This move aims to bolster Singapore's pandemic-fighting capabilities, despite ongoing outbreaks.

site_title: Wong makes hay while sun shines
summary: Malaysian jockey Wong Chin Chuen scored a treble in two weeks, narrowing the premiership lead of trainer Manoel Nunes to 22 wins in 21/2 months. Wong rode Buuraq, Ace Sovereign, and Cash Cove to victories, with the latter helping trainer Alwin Tan's prospects for next year's Three-Year-Old races. Wong's performances were aided by Nunes' trainer Tim Fitzsimmons, who has been a staunch supporter. Wong's suspension for careless riding looms, but he will return to racing on September 24, coinciding with Nunes' comeback.

site_title: Shorts are in as LIV heats up rivalry
summary: LIV Golf, a Saudi-backed golf circuit, has become the first professional golf circuit to allow men to wear shorts in competitive rounds, a move that may lure more golfers away from the established PGA Tour and DP World Tour. The decision, made by LIV's tournament director, Davie Williams, aims to address the discomfort of playing in hot temperatures. Six-time Major champion Phil Mickelson was seen wearing shorts during his second round at the competition's fourth tournament, citing the move as "a long time coming" in the game of golf.

site_title: Giving condo shop owner seat on council ruled as wrong
summary: A condominium in Choa Chu Kang, Singapore, had a shop owner automatically appointed to its management council without nomination, sparking a dispute. The Strata Titles Board ruled that the property is not a mixed-use development, as it only serves residents and not the public. The board agreed with six home owners that the shop owner should not have a reserved seat, and ordered the management corporation to pay $1,600 in costs. The decision is now on appeal to the High Court.

site_title: Goodbye, floating platform, hello, National Stadium?
summary: The National Day Parade (NDP) floating platform, which hosted 11 NDPs since 2007, is set to be transformed into the National Stadium NS Square by 2026. The platform's directors and performers weigh in on its advantages and shortcomings, with actress Beatrice Chia-Richmond praising its unique waterfront views and illuminated stage, but noting its distance from the audience limits the aerial displays. Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen suggests the platform could host future NDPs, while veteran musician Dick Lee praises the Padang for its historical significance and formal elegance. The NDP will return to the Padang next year, with the National Stadium potentially hosting future events.

site_title: Stem cell treatment offers hope to patients with damaged knee cartilage
summary: Researchers at the National University Hospital (NUH) have found an 80% success rate in regenerating damaged cartilage in knees using stem cells derived from bone marrow. A study of 440 knees and 392 patients showed a 72% continued success rate over 10 years, with no additional procedures needed. This treatment offers new hope for younger, active patients suffering from cartilage degeneration, providing a promising alternative to traditional treatments.

site_title: A sustainable garment hub in Vietnam designed to reduce the carbon footprint of making a T-shirt
summary: Vietnam's Aurora Textile Industrial Park, a sustainable garment hub, has been completed in Nam Dinh province, producing 1 billion meters of fabric annually and reducing the country's dependence on imports. The park, developed by Cat Tuong Real Estate Group, features green infrastructure, energy-efficient solutions, and a focus on supply-chain sustainability. With 40,000 jobs created and local suppliers connected, the park aims to support Vietnam's textile and garment industry, which accounts for 16% of the country's GDP.

site_title: Residents learn to manage finances, guard against scams
summary: A financial literacy programme by CGS-CIMB Securities launched in Sembawang GRC, teaching residents how to invest, manage finances, and guard against scams. The three-month programme aims to educate over 500 young people, lower-income families, and senior citizens on navigating the high cost of living amid inflation. The event follows a survey showing that over 50% of Singaporeans feel financially illiterate, with the programme's goal also to prevent residents from falling victim to scams, with over 14,300 reported cases in the first half of this year.

site_title: Bed Bath & Beyond CFO plunges to death at New York's 'Jenga' tower
summary: Bed Bath & Beyond's CFO, Gustavo Arnal, 52, fell to his death from New York's Tribeca skyscraper, also known as the "Jenga" tower, last Friday. The news comes after the struggling retailer announced store closures and layoffs. Arnal joined Bed Bath & Beyond in 2020 and previously worked for Procter & Gamble and Avon. The cause of death has not been determined, and the company has confirmed his passing but provided no further details. The incident occurs amid Bed Bath & Beyond's financial struggles, including a 26% slump in same-store sales and a lawsuit alleging insider trading.

site_title: Facebook page to get Pofma correction order over HDB post
summary: A Facebook page, The Alternative View, will receive a correction direction under the Protection from Online Falsehoods and Manipulation Act (Pofma) for a post implying HDB profits from Build-To-Order flats in Ang Mo Kio. The post featured a misleading headline and image, sparking a correction from the Ministry of National Development (MND). HDB will not profit from the sale, but may incur a loss due to subsidies and CPF housing grants. The page will display a correction notice with a link to the Government's clarification, without removing or editing the original post.

site_title: Netball: S'pore through to Asian C'ship s-finals after beating Maldives 96-10
summary: Singapore advances to the semi-finals of the Asian Netball Championship after defeating Maldives 96-10. Despite losing veteran shooter Charmaine Soh to a knee injury, the team rallied behind her replacement Goh Wei Ping, who contributed 30 goals. Singapore will face Hong Kong in the semi-finals on Tuesday, with the second round results determining the fixtures. The team's head coach, Annette Bishop, praised Goh's performance, saying it was "excellent" and a key factor in their semi-final spot.

site_title: Football: Ten Hag salutes Antony and Rashford as Man United sink Arsenal
summary: Manchester United manager Erik ten Hag praised the partnership between new signing Antony and Marcus Rashford, who both played key roles in a 3-1 win over Arsenal. Antony scored on his debut, while Rashford scored a brace. Ten Hag noted that the duo formed an instant connection, providing a threat with their speed and creativity. The win lifted United to fifth place, but ten Hag warned the team not to get carried away, citing room for improvement in pressing, organisation, and possession control.

site_title: Football: Minor-league side's custodian dismissed for urinating in hedge during FA Cup tie
summary: A goalkeeper for ninth-tier Blackfield & Langley was dismissed from an FA Cup match for urinating in a hedge. Connor Maseko, 76th minute, was shown a red card during the goal-less draw with Shepton Mallet. The incident occurred when Maseko needed to use the toilet after the ball went out for a goal kick. The referee deemed it an offense, and the match was replayed at Shepton Mallet's home ground, where the team is now seeking match sponsors and reminding fans to bring their own toilet roll.

site_title: Badminton: Nishimoto, Yamaguchi take honours at Japan Open
summary: Kenta Nishimoto and Akane Yamaguchi won the men's and women's singles titles at the Japan Open, respectively. Nishimoto defeated Chinese Taipei's No. 4 seed Chou Tien-chen in the final, while Yamaguchi beat South Korea's An Se-young. The victories marked Japan's first international titles in badminton since 2016. Nishimoto's win was his first international title, having lost in his previous six final appearances, while Yamaguchi retained her world title and won her third tournament of the year.

site_title: Figure skating: Singapore's Pagiel Sng wins gold in SEA Open Trophy in home debut
summary: Singapore's Pagiel Sng wins gold in the inaugural SEA Open Figure Skating Trophy with a total score of 172.12, claiming the senior men's gold in his home debut. Sng edged out New Zealand's Douglas Gerber for silver and Hong Kong's Adonis Wong for bronze. The victory also meets the minimum total elements score required for the ISU Four Continents Figure Skating Championships. Sng credits his coach and the electric atmosphere for his success, aiming to qualify for the World Junior Figure Skating Championships in February 2023.

site_title: WP disciplinary panel to look into Daniel Goh's Facebook posts on Raeesah Khan
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) has convened a disciplinary committee to investigate cadre member Daniel Goh's Facebook posts regarding former WP MP Raeesah Khan's resignation. Goh's posts questioned the WP leadership's handling of the situation and raised concerns about accountability and integrity. He has declined to be interviewed by the committee and urged the party leaders to explain their decision to convene the committee and any disciplinary sanctions they may impose on him. Goh has stated he has no intention of resigning from the party.

site_title: Golf: US teen sensation Li leads by one from Thompson and Masson at LPGA Dana Open
summary: US teenager Lucy Li leads the LPGA Dana Open after 54 holes, standing at 14-under 199. Li birdied six of the last 11 holes to secure a one-stroke lead over compatriot Lexi Thompson and Germany's Caroline Masson. The 19-year-old has already secured a 2023 LPGA Tour berth and hopes to secure her first LPGA victory. Li's victory would be her third on the US women's developmental tour this year.

site_title: Motor racing: Verstappen wins fourth race in a row at Dutch GP to take stranglehold on title fight
summary: Max Verstappen won the Dutch Grand Prix for the second year in a row, taking his 10th victory of the season and extending his lead in the championship to 109 points over Charles Leclerc. Verstappen's fourth consecutive win solidified his position for a second successive world title, with seven races remaining. The Red Bull driver praised his team's strategy, saying they "made the right calls" to secure the win.

site_title: Triathlon return sets pulses racing
summary: Over 1,200 people participated in the TriFactor Triathlon Singapore on Sunday, marking its return after a two-year hiatus due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Competitors raced in four categories, while children aged 6-12 participated in a separate kids' distance event. National triathletes Luke Chua and Raven Alcoseba won the men's and women's national sprint championships, respectively, with times of 1hr 26sec and 1hr 6min 46sec.

site_title: The Alternative View to get correction order after implying HDB will profit from Ang Mo Kio BTO flats
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) in Singapore will issue a correction direction to Facebook page The Alternative View for implying that HDB profits from Ang Mo Kio BTO flats. The Ministry of National Development (MND) stated that HDB incurs a loss from the project, with estimated collection costs lower than development costs. HDB also incurs a deficit annually due to significant subsidies and CPF housing grants, with most first-time buyers using less than a quarter of their income for housing loans.

site_title: First Zika patient reported in S'pore since March 2020 has recovered
summary: Singapore's first Zika patient reported since March 2020 has recovered, according to the Ministry of Health. The imported case was confirmed on August 22 and was treated with measures to eliminate mosquito breeding habitats and fog to kill adult mosquitoes. Zika, like dengue, is transmitted by the Aedes mosquito and is generally a mild illness. The public is advised to stay vigilant and take precautions to prevent mosquito breeding at home. This case comes amid a surge in dengue infections, with 25,591 cases recorded so far this year.

site_title: Football: Rodgers takes blame for Leicester slump after fifth straight loss
summary: Leicester City manager Brendan Rodgers blamed himself for the team's poor results, including their fifth straight loss, after a 5-2 defeat at Brighton & Hove Albion. The Foxes' defensive struggles and inability to retain possession are attributed to Rodgers, who said the team needs to work harder and build confidence to achieve a win. Despite the loss, Rodgers remains optimistic, focusing on the upcoming home match against Aston Villa and the need to sustain the game for longer periods.

site_title: Clementi landslide: Recovery, construction work may take months, says Desmond Lee
summary: A landslide at a Clementi Build-To-Order (BTO) site in Singapore damaged the Ulu Pandan Park Connector and displaced soil into the Ulu Pandan Canal. Recovery and construction efforts are underway, with Minister Desmond Lee stating that they may take a few months to complete. The area has been closed, with a section of the park connector remaining shut for public safety. Investigations are ongoing to determine the cause of the slope failure, and temporary measures are in place to mitigate flood risks.

site_title: Crowds throng Johor Bahru amid S'pore and Malaysian schools' week-long break
summary: Large crowds flocked to Johor Bahru, Malaysia, over the weekend as Singapore and Malaysian schools observed a week-long break. Traffic congestion was reported in several areas, with over 313,000 people passing through the Woodlands and Tuas checkpoints each day. The Immigration and Checkpoints Authority (ICA) warned of heavy traffic and advised travellers to adjust their plans to avoid congestion. Hotel bookings were also high, with 80% of rooms occupied at one hotel. The school holidays coincide with Malaysia's week-long break, which ends on Sept 10 or 11.

site_title: ST Explains: Why cats are banned from HDB flats, and what lifting the ban would take
summary: Singapore's Housing and Development Board (HDB) may lift the ban on keeping cats as pets in flats after a public consultation exercise, which aims to improve cat welfare and management. The ban, in place since 1960, restricts cats due to concerns over shedding, defecation, and noise. The Animal and Veterinary Service (AVS) will explore a microchipping scheme and licensing system to ensure responsible ownership and animal welfare. A six-month consultation period will run from September 2022 to March 2023, with feedback used to refine a recommended framework for cat ownership in HDB flats.

site_title: Get free access to 1,500 pre-1900 maps of S'pore and S-E Asia on new Yale-NUS website
summary: Yale-NUS College has launched a new website offering free access to 1,500 pre-1900 maps of Singapore and Southeast Asia. The digital platform, compiled by a research team led by Jane Jacobs, features maps from four libraries, including the University of Oxford's Bodleian Libraries. The maps, digitized and made easily searchable, provide historical insights into the region's development and can be accessed by geography, history, and amateur history enthusiasts.

site_title: JC students in Raffles Institution have four-day week
summary: Raffles Institution has implemented a four-day week for its junior college students, starting from Wednesday. The decision is reportedly in line with the school's efforts to reduce its environmental footprint and promote student well-being. Students will attend classes from Monday to Friday, with Wednesdays off. The move is seen as a significant change for students like Damien Ooi, who have been accustomed to a traditional five-day school week since childhood.

site_title: Enjoying HBL days with my teenagers
summary: A Singaporean mother shares her positive experience with her teenagers' fortnightly home-based learning (HBL) days, which she also looks forward to. She appreciates the independence her children have developed to manage their work, allowing her to have one-on-one time with each teenager. During HBL days, her children typically work on assignments, and she provides moral support while giving them space to complete their tasks. She believes HBL has been beneficial in allowing their education to continue during the pandemic, and she cherishes the extra time spent with her children at home.

site_title: No escape from biggest bond loss in decades as Fed keeps hiking
summary: The US bond market is expected to remain under pressure due to the Federal Reserve's efforts to combat inflation, with interest rates likely to continue rising. The latest employment report showed a slight easing of wage pressures and an uptick in the jobless rate, but the overall picture reinforced speculation that the Fed will keep raising interest rates until inflation recedes. The 10-year Treasury yield has topped out at or above the Fed's peak rate during previous monetary-policy tightening cycles, leading to a potential downside for bond prices.

site_title: Financial literacy programme to help Sembawang GRC residents tackle rising cost of living and scams
summary: A financial literacy programme by CGS-CIMB Securities has launched in Sembawang GRC to educate residents on managing the cost of living, investing, and preventing scams. The 3-month programme aims to help 500 young people, lower-income families, and senior citizens learn about financial literacy and investment. The initiative follows a surge in reported scams, with over 14,300 cases in the first half of the year, and aims to provide basic information and education on financial literacy and scams through workshops and online resources.

site_title: Rugby: Kolisi wants Springboks to regain top form for Championship climax
summary: South Africa captain Siya Kolisi is targeting consistency for his team in the Rugby Championship's final two rounds. The Springboks secured their second win of the campaign against Australia, moving to third place and one point behind leaders New Zealand. Kolisi emphasized the importance of consistency, saying it's what all nations are looking for, and that it's brilliant for rugby as any team can win on any given day. With two victories and two defeats each, any of the four nations can still claim the title, and the Springboks will face Argentina in their last two games.

site_title: Section of park connector near Clementi BTO site to remain closed: NParks
summary: A section of a park connector in Singapore remains closed due to ongoing recovery and repair works and potential flood risks after a landslide at a nearby Build-To-Order (BTO) construction site in Clementi. The landslide damaged the park connector and displaced soil into the Ulu Pandan Canal, prompting authorities to close the affected section for public safety. A channel has been carved out to prevent flooding, and the park connector beyond the closed section will remain open. The BTO project has been delayed due to the Covid-19 pandemic, with the estimated completion date now in the second half of this year.

site_title: Traders find haven from global stock gloom in South-east Asia
summary: South-east Asia's growth outlook is attracting investors as the region's economies are expected to grow at least 5% this year. Despite global equities struggling, the region's benchmark MSCI Asean Index has outperformed the broader MSCI Asia Pacific Index for a third straight quarter. The reopening of the region, driven by booming domestic demand and tourism, is expected to shield it from a global slump, with commodity exports and foreign direct investment also contributing to the region's promising earnings outlook.
