site_title: Electronics sector shrinks after 2 years of expansion
summary: The Singapore electronics sector experienced a slowdown in August, with its purchasing managers' index (PMI) falling to 49.6, indicating contraction. The sector's decline was driven by fewer new orders and lower output. Despite this, overall factory activity remained in expansion mode, but at a slower pace. Experts attribute the slowdown to global headwinds, including high inflation, energy prices, and geopolitical uncertainties. The sector's performance is closely watched, with potential implications for Singapore's manufacturing growth and GDP expectations.

site_title: Brokers' call stays at 'buy' on ridership, dividend payouts
summary: Analysts have reaffirmed their "buy" calls on ComfortDelGro, citing rising ridership of public transport and decent dividend payouts despite the company being dropped from Singapore's Straits Times Index. ComfortDelGro's market capitalization fell below the threshold, but analysts expect further earnings recovery in the coming quarters driven by improved monetization of its Singapore taxi business and higher rail ridership. The company declared an interim dividend of 2.85 cents per share and a special dividend of 1.41 cents per share, offering an attractive dividend yield of 5.9%.

site_title: Fraser-Pryce eyes school sports day
summary: Jamaican track star Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce, a two-time Olympic 100m champion, is set to balance motherhood with her athletic career. With her 5-year-old son Zyon starting primary school, Fraser-Pryce plans to participate in school sports day, warning that she'll be a tough competitor. Despite her recent World Athletics Championships title, Fraser-Pryce downplays talk of retirement, aiming to compete in the 2024 Paris Olympics. The World Athletics Indoor Championships, initially postponed three times due to Covid-19, will now be held in March 2025 in Nanjing.

site_title: Klopp gives Nunez a 'slap' as punishment
summary: Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp has welcomed back striker Darwin Nunez after a three-game ban, stating he's "learnt his lesson" and is now "really settled." Nunez's return comes ahead of the Merseyside derby against Everton, but Klopp may not slot him back into the first team, as Roberto Firmino has been clinical with three goals in the Reds' past two games. Klopp also praises new signing Arthur Melo, who will provide cover for injured players, and is delighted with the competition he will bring.

site_title: Adani's flagship firm enters key India index in new boost
summary: Adani Enterprises, the flagship firm of Asia's richest man Gautam Adani, has been included in the NSE Nifty 50 Index, replacing Shree Cement, starting from September 30. The inclusion is based on factors like free float market capitalization and is expected to bring in a net inflow of $213 million for Adani Enterprises. This marks a boost for Adani, whose firms have surged ahead with acquisitions, despite concerns about leverage. Shares of Adani Enterprises have risen 89% this year, with Adani Power experiencing a 310% surge.

site_title: Sea cuts jobs in gaming arm Garena in second downsizing wave
summary: Sea Limited, a South-east Asia tech giant, is cutting jobs in its gaming arm Garena and research and development unit for the second time this year. Approximately 40 jobs will be lost from its game live stream app Booyah!, and about a dozen employees will be let go from Sea Labs. The company is shifting focus towards profitability, citing rising competition and slowing growth in its e-commerce business. This move follows a string of setbacks, including a decline in bookings for Garena and withdrawal of its 2022 e-commerce forecast.

site_title: Next 48 hours
summary: Key events and sports schedules are outlined for the next 48 hours, including cycling's La Vuelta Stage 14, English Premier League matches, the Singapore Premier League, Spanish Primera Liga, golf tournaments, mixed martial arts events, and more.

site_title: Second trial victory for Mr Black Back
summary: Australian trainer Tim Fitzsimmons secured his second trial victory with Mr. Black Back, a well-bred son of Snitzel and Oaks winner Faint Perfume. The five-year-old won the 1,000m trial by 1/2 length, improving on his previous 11/2-length win in 61.32 seconds. Fitzsimmons' yard boasts other talented horses, including Wan Legacy, In All His Glory, and Golden Monkey. The trainer's consistency in Australia, with two wins and three seconds from six starts, suggests he may be building towards a successful racing season.

site_title: Sports World
summary: Chinese teenager Yin Ruoning leads the LPGA Dana Open with a six-under 65, tied with South Korean Choi Hye-jin and Spain's Carlota Ciganda. Donovan Mitchell was traded from the Utah Jazz to the Cleveland Cavaliers for three players and three NBA draft picks. Nairo Quintana has appealed his Tour de France disqualification for taking a banned pain medication. Australia has decided not to bid for the 2023 Asian Cup but will submit a bid for the 2026 women's tournament.

site_title: Tough battles in store
summary: Sri Lanka, the reigning Asian Netball Championship (ANC) title holders, face a tough challenge in defending their title due to limited international preparation. They have not played an international tournament since 2019, while rivals Singapore and Malaysia have undergone overseas training tours. Despite this, Sri Lanka's captain Gayanjali Amarawansa is confident in their team's preparation, citing a solid practice period and a well-planned strategy. The top two teams will earn spots at next year's Netball World Cup, with Singapore seeking to qualify for the tournament despite a young and inexperienced squad.

site_title: Ferrari expect to get back on track in the Netherlands
summary: Ferrari is optimistic about their chances in the upcoming Dutch Grand Prix, with Carlos Sainz expressing confidence that they can close the gap to Red Bull leader Max Verstappen. Sainz believes their car should be more competitive at Zandvoort, a shorter track with fewer turns, compared to Spa-Francorchamps, where Red Bull had an aerodynamic advantage. Ferrari is also hopeful of sneaking back into the title race with eight grands prix remaining, with Charles Leclerc agreeing that the gap will be closer.

site_title: Broadway Girl can make amends
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

Sunday's South Africa form analysis highlights promising contenders for various races. Broadway Girl is expected to make amends in Race 3 after a disappointing run last time, while Swiss Paradise and A Time to Dance look promising in their debut. In other races, Arividicio, Lazy Guy, and Imperial Order have good chances, and Imperial Order, Imperial Order, and Lady Catherine are top picks in their respective races. The article also provides analysis of other runners, including favorites and dark horses, with a focus on their past performances and potential for improvement.

site_title: Speedy Akanji a perfect fit for City: Guardiola
summary: Pep Guardiola believes Manchester City's new signing Manuel Akanji is the "perfect" fit for the team, providing valuable cover for Aymeric Laporte and Nathan Ake. The 27-year-old Switzerland defender was signed on a five-year contract for £15.1 million after Guardiola expressed concerns about City's centre-backs' fitness. Akanji's arrival is seen as a response to recent injuries to Laporte and Ake, and he will compete with Erling Haaland for starting spots in the team. Haaland, who has netted nine times in his first five league appearances, is expected to continue breaking records.

site_title: Chinese quartet stamp their mark
summary: A Chinese quartet has made history at the US Open, becoming the first four women from China to reach the third round of a single Grand Slam event. Zheng Qinwen and Yuan Yue, along with Wang Xiyu and Zhang Shuai, advanced through the tournament, with Zheng defeating Anastasia Potapova and Yuan defeating Irina-Camelia Begu. The achievement marks a significant milestone for Chinese women's tennis, with 19-year-old Zheng rising to 39th in the world rankings. The success is attributed to the energy and competition among the Chinese players, with Zheng crediting her hard work and determination for her performances.

site_title: Window shopping: Normal service resumes
summary: The post-pandemic transfer window in European football saw a significant increase in spending, with the "Big Five" leagues' total transfer value reaching almost £4 billion. Despite concerns over the sustainability of such large expenditures, the English Premier League set a record for transfer spending, highlighting the industry's focus on short-term financial gains rather than long-term viability. This trend suggests that football's business model remains driven by a short memory, prioritizing immediate financial gains over sustainable practices.

site_title: Ten Hag wants United to be 'ruthless'
summary: Manchester United secured a 1-0 win over Leicester City, with Jadon Sancho scoring in the first half. The victory marked United's third consecutive Premier League win, moving them up to fifth place. Despite the signing of Brazil winger Antony, Sancho's goal reminded manager Erik ten Hag of his qualities, and ten Hag expressed satisfaction with his team's display. The win comes after two losses, and ten Hag believes United still have improvements to make, stating that they need to be "more ruthless."

site_title: Close call for worker who was cycling home in the area
summary: A landslide occurred in the Ulu Pandan Park Connector in Clementi, Singapore, just minutes before a cyclist, Lim Thiam Chye, was supposed to reach his home. The incident uprooted trees, street lamps, and a section of a construction site, causing concern for park connector users. Authorities have stated that nearby buildings remain structurally sound, but the site is being monitored. An excavator has been used to pour concrete onto the landslide site to prevent further collapse, and repair works are underway.

site_title: No change to IP premiums for next two years
summary: Singapore's Integrated Shield Plans (IPs) will maintain unchanged premiums for the next two years. The Cancer Drug List, introduced on September 1, sets out cost-effective cancer treatments covered by MediShield Life insurance. From April next year, IP riders will be redesigned to offer coverage for treatments not on the list, with insurers using a framework to decide which treatments to cover. Cancer patients undergoing treatment will receive transitional support from insurers until September 2024. The insurance sector aims to ensure continued access to cancer drugs in Singapore.

site_title: Chelsea break transfer record
summary: Chelsea has broken the English Premier League transfer record with a spending spree of over £255 million in a single window, surpassing the previous record held by Manchester City. The club signed Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang from Barcelona for £10.3 million and secured a season-long loan for Denis Zakaria from Juventus. This move marks Chelsea's highest spending in a single window, with Aubameyang's return to the Premier League seen as a significant addition to the team. Aubameyang suffered a broken jaw in a robbery and is expected to be out for several weeks.

site_title: School discipline master took upskirt videos
summary: A 49-year-old school discipline master pleaded guilty to three counts of insulting a woman's modesty for taking upskirt videos of at least 47 victims, including 38 colleagues and seven students, over three years. The man, who was already suspended from service since 2018, used his mobile phone to record videos without consent, often targeting vulnerable students. He was suffering from major depressive disorder at the time of the offences and is expected to be sentenced on November 3, with a report to assess his suitability for a mandatory treatment order.

site_title: First Zika case reported in S'pore since 2020 amid dengue surge
summary: A new Zika case has been reported in Singapore, marking the first case since March 2020, amid a surge in dengue infections. The case was recorded during the week of Aug 21-27, with 666 dengue cases also reported for the same period. The Ministry of Health confirmed the case, which is the first since 2020, and is investigating further details. Zika is transmitted by the Aedes mosquito, also carrying dengue and chikungunya viruses, and symptoms include fever, rash, and body aches.

site_title: Trials of battery swopping systems for electric m-cycles
summary: Singapore is testing battery swapping systems for electric motorcycles, with trials by Gogoro and MO Batteries starting this month. The 12-month trials will examine the potential of swopping battery technology for motorcycles, with each company partnering with fleet firms to deploy their vehicles. The trials follow the revision of technical standards for EV charging, which addresses battery swapping for motorcycles. The Land Transport Authority aims to support the move towards cleaner vehicles with new training and certification courses.

site_title: Pandas Kai Kai and Jia Jia to remain here on extended loan till 2027
summary: Singapore's River Wonders has secured a 5-year extension for giant pandas Kai Kai and Jia Jia, allowing them to stay until 2027. The 10-year loan deal was signed with China's National Forestry and Grassland Administration. The pandas, who arrived in Singapore in 2012, recently welcomed a cub named Le Le. The extension agreement is a testament to the strong Singapore-China friendship and will enable further giant panda conservation efforts.

site_title: Singapore intervenes early to tackle inequality: Shanmugam
summary: Singapore Minister for Home Affairs and Law K. Shanmugam discussed internal and external challenges facing the nation, including rising income inequality. He warned that attracting top talent from abroad could lead to fewer mid-level jobs for Singaporeans. To combat inequality, the government intervenes upstream by providing education and support for vulnerable groups, such as pre-school education. Shanmugam also emphasized the need to remain vigilant against external threats, including changes in global trade routes and the rise of remote work. He stressed the importance of meritocracy and the effectiveness of the death penalty as a deterrent.

site_title: Czech duo 'sorry' as they eliminate Williams sisters
summary: The US Open doubles match between the Czech duo Lucie Hradecka and Linda Noskova and the Williams sisters, Venus and Serena, ended with a 7-6 (7-5), 6-4 victory for the Czech pair. The highly anticipated match, which marked the first time the Williams sisters played together since 2014, drew a capacity crowd to Arthur Ashe Stadium. Despite the loss, the Williams sisters showed respect, embracing briefly and packing their bags after the match. Hradecka apologized to the crowd, saying "I'm so sorry for you that we beat them, but we are so happy that we did it."

site_title: Azarenka not surprised by Kostyuk snub
summary: Victoria Azarenka beat Marta Kostyuk 6-2, 6-3 in the US Open second round, amidst tensions between players from Russia and Ukraine. Kostyuk, who has called for players from Russia and Belarus to be barred from tennis due to their country's invasion of Ukraine, refused to shake Azarenka's hand after the match, citing the Belarusian president's public appearances with Russian President Alexander Lukashenko. Azarenka defended her stance, saying she prioritizes empathy and trying to help, while Kostyuk criticized Azarenka's perceived silence on the war.

site_title: Travel agencies see surge in inquiries about trips to Japan
summary: Travel agencies in the EU are experiencing a 50% surge in inquiries about trips to Japan following the country's easing of restrictions for tourists. Starting September 7, foreigners can visit via package tours without a chaperone. The move is expected to boost demand for vacations in Japan, particularly among families, seniors, and those who prefer hassle-free holiday planning. The daily cap for arrivals will increase to 50,000, and tourists will need to apply for a visa through authorized travel agents by signing up for a "non-guided package tour".

site_title: Fadaboy looks good against the novices
summary: Fadaboy, a 4-year-old Australian-bred thoroughbred, is poised to win his second consecutive race in the Novice event at Kranji on Saturday. Trained by Donna Logan and ridden by Australian jockey Blake Shinn, Fadaboy's impressive debut win and subsequent narrow loss in his second start demonstrate his vast potential. With a strong field, including stablemates Rocky and Ejaz, and newcomer Raffie, Fadaboy's chances are bolstered by the riding change to four-time Singapore champion jockey Vlad Duric.

site_title: Hand Flower Brand Soy Sauce recalled due to undeclared food additive exceeding regulatory limit
summary: The Singapore Food Agency (SFA) has recalled Hand Flower Brand Soy Sauce due to the presence of an undeclared food additive, benzoic acid, which exceeded the regulatory limit. The recall is for batches with the code KSS0 125 and expires on July 26, 2023. While one-off consumption is unlikely to be a concern, long-term consumption of high levels of benzoic acid may lead to health issues, including central nervous system disorders. Consumers are advised to seek medical advice if they have concerns and contact their point of purchase for inquiries.

site_title: Multi-nation air combat drill in Australia a good chance for NSmen to hone skills
summary: A multinational air combat drill, Exercise Pitch Black, is taking place in Australia, providing a unique opportunity for Singaporean national servicemen (NSmen) to hone their skills. The drill, which involves air forces from multiple countries, offers a realistic and challenging environment for NSmen to train and test their abilities. Major (NS) Robin Chew, a 43-year-old operationally ready NSman, has volunteered for the exercise three times, citing the adrenaline rush of piloting a fighter jet as a major draw. The drill aims to enhance regional air power and cooperation among participating nations.

site_title: Help for patients on cancer drugs outside new list
summary: Singapore's government has committed to supporting patients on cancer drugs not on the Cancer Drug List, which was introduced to reduce soaring costs. The list, which covers 90% of approved cancer drugs, was implemented to limit insurance coverage and encourage price reductions. The government has increased subsidies from $12 million to $80 million annually and will provide support to patients starting treatment on or before Wednesday. The move aims to minimize the impact on patients and stem the growth of cancer treatment costs, which have more than doubled in the past five years.

site_title: Landslide at Clementi BTO site causes major damage
summary: A landslide at a Clementi Build-To-Order (BTO) site in Singapore caused major damage, affecting a retaining wall and park connector, but the nearby residential blocks will not be affected. Work on the site will resume next week, with key collection for the units scheduled for December, despite the incident. Engineers confirmed the nearby buildings are structurally sound, and water quality was not affected. The landslide has raised flood concerns, prompting the creation of a channel to improve water flow through Sungei Ulu Pandan canal.

site_title: 3 allegedly sold bank account details to scammers
summary: Three men, Muhamad Hakim Fugi, Tan Yong Kwang, and Zhang Demin, have been charged in a district court for allegedly selling their bank account details to scammers. The trio are accused of laundering at least $370,000 from various scams involving eight victims. Hakim faces two conspiracy charges and two counts under the Computer Misuse Act, while Tan is charged under the Computer Misuse Act for providing his bank account details in exchange for $500 a month. Zhang faces one count of helping another person control benefits of criminal conduct.

site_title: Formula One: Ferrari one-two in second Dutch GP practice
summary: Ferrari secured the top two spots in the second Dutch GP practice, with Charles Leclerc setting the fastest lap time of 1:12.345 seconds. Mercedes' Lewis Hamilton took third place, 0.072 seconds behind. Red Bull's Max Verstappen, the championship leader, was eighth due to a gearbox problem in the first session. Verstappen will look to regain his form for the upcoming race, which will be his 10th win of the season. Ferrari's Carlos Sainz was just 0.004 seconds behind Leclerc in the second session.

site_title: SIA is most recommended brand in S'pore for second straight year: Poll
summary: Singapore Airlines has retained its title as the top brand in Singapore that consumers would recommend to others for the second straight year, according to a YouGov study. The airline received an approval rating of 86.6% from its customers, who were asked to recommend the brand to friends and colleagues. This marks the second consecutive year Singapore Airlines has topped the list, solidifying its reputation as a highly recommended brand in the country.

site_title: Formula One: Red Bull boss rules out any Porsche takeover of the team
summary: Red Bull team principal Christian Horner ruled out a Porsche takeover, stating that any partnership would need to fit with the team's terms. Horner emphasized Red Bull's independence as a strength, which is part of its DNA and allows for quick decision-making. The team has set up its own powertrain company, Red Bull Powertrains, and is ready to continue on its own, with plans to launch its 2026 engine. Horner dismissed speculation about a potential partnership with Porsche, saying the team's train has left the station and is focused on its own development.

site_title: Football: Tanaka scores four against Balestier again as Albirex clinch 5-3 comeback win
summary: Albirex Niigata secured a 5-3 comeback win over Balestier Khalsa in the Singapore Premier League, with Kodai Tanaka scoring four goals, including a hat-trick and a penalty. The Japanese team trailed 3-1 at halftime but rallied behind Tanaka's determination and goal-scoring prowess. The win moves Albirex level on points with league leaders Lion City Sailors and sets up a potential title showdown on October 7. Tanaka now leads the scorers' chart with 28 goals, and his team's morale has been boosted ahead of their crucial match against Sailors.

site_title: Electronics sector shrinks after two years of expansion
summary: The Singapore electronics sector experienced a contraction in August, with its purchasing managers' index (PMI) falling to 49.6, down 0.9 points from July. The sector's slowdown was attributed to fewer new orders and lower output. Despite this, the overall manufacturing sector expanded for the 26th consecutive month. Economists expect a potential recovery in the China market to bolster the electronics sector, but global headwinds, including high inflation and energy prices, pose concerns. A manufacturing downturn could impact Singapore's gross domestic product expectations for the rest of the year.

site_title: NSmen fighter pilot, engineer hone skills at 17-nation air combat drill in Australia
summary: Singaporean NSmen fighter pilot Major (NS) Robin Chew and Military Expert 1-2 (NS) Isaac Ee participated in Exercise Pitch Black in Australia, a 17-nation air combat drill from Aug 19 to Sept 8. Chew, who flies an F-15SG, praised the exercise for offering better training opportunities due to Australia's airspace, while Ee highlighted the challenges of working in the dry climate. Both NSmen emphasized the importance of constant training to maintain proficiency, with Chew completing 40 days of in-camp training each year.

site_title: Football: Spurs on right path to improve squad but rivals ahead, says Conte
summary: Tottenham Hotspur manager Antonio Conte believes the team has made progress in improving their squad, with key signings like Richarlison and Yves Bissouma. However, Conte notes that there is still a significant gap between Spurs and their Premier League rivals. Despite a quiet transfer deadline day, Conte is optimistic about the team's future, stating that they have just started the process of improving the squad. Conte also highlighted areas where players, such as Bissouma and Oliver Skipp, need to work to catch up with their teammates.

site_title: Tennis: Jabeur pushes past Rogers to reach US Open fourth round
summary: Tunisian tennis player Ons Jabeur defeated US player Shelby Rogers 4-6 6-4 6-3 at the US Open, reaching the fourth round for the first time. Jabeur struggled in the first set but regained control in the second, while Rogers fought back to hold serve and break Jabeur in the seventh game. Jabeur ultimately won on her sixth match point, praising her determination to "keep fighting and go until the end" after a "crazy match."

site_title: Football: Akanji 'perfect' for Man City, says Guardiola
summary: Manchester City manager Pep Guardiola has welcomed the signing of defender Manuel Akanji, calling him the "perfect" fit to provide cover for injured central defenders Aymeric Laporte and Nathan Ake. The 27-year-old Swiss defender was signed on a five-year contract from Borussia Dortmund for £15 million. Guardiola cited Ake's recent injuries and Laporte's knee issue as reasons for the transfer. Akanji is expected to be involved in Saturday's match against Aston Villa, while Laporte is unlikely to return until October. Erling Haaland's impressive form has also caught Guardiola's attention.

site_title: Motor racing: Piastri to race for McLaren after contract dispute
summary: Australian Oscar Piastri will join McLaren for the 2023 and 2024 seasons after the Contract Recognition Board ruled in favor of McLaren's contract with Piastri, dismissing Alpine's claim. Piastri, a 21-year-old Formula Three and Formula Two champion, had been Alpine's reserve driver. The decision comes after Piastri rejected Alpine's offer to replace Fernando Alonso. Piastri will partner Lando Norris and replace Daniel Ricciardo, with McLaren principal Andreas Seidl calling Piastri a "perfect fit" for the team.

site_title: US job growth solid in August; unemployment rate rises to 3.7%
summary: US employers added 315,000 jobs in August, beating expectations, and the unemployment rate rose to 3.7% from 3.5%. This marks the 20th consecutive month of job growth, despite a contraction in GDP in the first half of the year. The Federal Reserve is expected to deliver a third 75 basis point interest rate hike this month, citing a painful period of slow economic growth and rising unemployment. The labor market remains resilient, with 11.2 million job openings and low unemployment benefit applications.

site_title: Football: Tuchel urges Aubameyang to prove Arsenal wrong
summary: Thomas Tuchel has challenged new Chelsea striker Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang to prove Arsenal wrong after signing him for £10.3 million. Aubameyang, who scored 79 goals in 95 appearances under Tuchel at Borussia Dortmund, was stripped of his Arsenal captaincy and sold to Barcelona. Tuchel believes Aubameyang is focused and happy to prove himself, and that his speed and work ethic will be key to his success. Aubameyang will miss Chelsea's next Premier League match due to a minor jaw injury but could return to training next week.

site_title: Are the recent digital bank offerings in the interest of consumers?
summary: Singapore's digital banking space has launched with Trust Bank, GXS Bank, and MariBank competing for market share. While consumers may be interested in better interest rates, the true focus appears to be on banks trying to outdo each other. The early days of the competition are still underway, with MariBank yet to launch. The outcome of this digital banking race is yet to be determined.

site_title: No change for Integrated Shield Plans premiums for next 2 years
summary: Singapore's Integrated Shield Plans (IPs) will maintain unchanged premiums for the next two years, until August 31, 2024. This move aims to ensure affordability of cancer treatments following the introduction of the Cancer Drug List. From April 2024, IP riders will be redesigned to offer coverage for treatments not on the list, with varying premium rates. Insurers will monitor claims and adjust premiums if necessary, while providing transitional support to policyholders undergoing treatment. The goal is to ensure continued access to cost-effective cancer treatments in Singapore.

site_title: SIA remains most recommended brand in Singapore: YouGov study
summary: Singapore Airlines has retained its top spot as the most recommended brand in Singapore, according to a YouGov study. The airline garnered an impressive 86.6% of customer recommendations, solidifying its position as the go-to choice for consumers in the country. This marks the airline's continued success in building strong brand loyalty among its customers.

site_title: Clementi landslide: Close call for warehouse worker who passes area when cycling home
summary: A landslide in Singapore's Ulu Pandan Park Connector path, near Clementi, narrowly spared the life of a 56-year-old warehouse worker who was cycling home from work on Friday morning. The landslide, which blocked the path and uprooted trees and street lamps, occurred just minutes before the worker passed by. Authorities have confirmed that buildings in the vicinity remain structurally sound, but the area has been closed off for repairs. Residents and users of the park connector expressed shock and concern for safety, with some vowing to exercise extra caution when using the path.

site_title: Cancer patients affected by insurance coverage changes to get help for treatment: Ong Ye Kung
summary: Singapore has made significant changes to cancer insurance coverage, aiming to stem the soaring cost of cancer treatment. The government has increased the annual subsidy from $12 million to $80 million and raised the per capita household income threshold from $2,800 to $6,500. Cancer patients on drugs not on the Cancer Drug List will receive government support to complete their treatment, and insurance companies providing Integrated Shield Plans will be required to pay for non-subsidized treatments. The move is expected to bring down prices of cancer drugs by 30-65% on average.

site_title: Early intervention needed to level playing field and address inequality: Shanmugam
summary: Singapore Minister for Home Affairs and Law K. Shanmugam emphasizes the need for early intervention to address income inequality, as the country attracts top talent and multinational companies. He notes that without such talent, mid-level jobs for Singaporeans will dwindle. To combat inequality, the Government intervenes upstream through programs like pre-school education and support for vulnerable mothers. Shanmugam also cautions against complacency in the face of international competition, citing examples like the decline of the Silk Route. He stresses the importance of meritocracy and the need for Singapore to remain competitive.

site_title: Work to repair damage caused by landslide at Clementi BTO site to start next week
summary: A landslide at a Clementi Build-To-Order (BTO) site in Singapore caused extensive damage, including a retaining wall and a basketball court, and affected nearby water flow. Repairs are set to begin next week, with no delay expected for new flat buyers. Nearby residents and park connector users have expressed concern, but authorities have assured that nearby buildings remain structurally sound. The damage has raised flood concerns, prompting the creation of a channel to improve water flow through Sungei Ulu Pandan.

site_title: Football: Klopp relieved to sign Arthur as Henderson awaits scan results
summary: Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp expressed relief over the signing of Brazilian midfielder Arthur Melo on loan from Juventus, aiming to ease the team's injury crisis. However, Arthur won't feature in Saturday's Merseyside derby against Everton due to waiting for international clearance. Meanwhile, Jordan Henderson's hamstring injury status remains uncertain after a scan, and Klopp is hopeful for the rest of the season. Klopp praises Arthur's skills, calling him a "really good footballer" who will bring rhythm and passing ability to the team. Uruguay striker Darwin Nunez returns to the squad after completing a three-match suspension.

site_title: First Zika case reported in S'pore since 2020 amid surge in dengue cases
summary: Singapore has reported its first Zika case since March 2020, amidst a surge in dengue infections this year. The case was confirmed for the week of Aug 21-27, with 666 dengue cases recorded during the same period. The Zika virus is transmitted by the Aedes mosquito, which also carries dengue and chikungunya viruses. The Ministry of Health has confirmed the new case, but no further details are available. This marks the first local Zika case since 2020, when the World Health Organisation declared the Zika outbreak a public health emergency in Singapore.

site_title: S'pore needs to build new growth engines to remain competitive and continue investing in its people: Gan Kim Yong
summary: Singapore needs to identify new growth engines to remain competitive amid global economic headwinds, according to Trade and Industry Minister Gan Kim Yong. The government will continue to invest in its people's training and upgrading to ensure the workforce remains relevant, while workers must take ownership of their own development through lifelong learning and training. Efforts to transform the economy are underway, driven by the Singapore Economy 2030 plan, which outlines strategies across four key pillars.

site_title: Swimming: Fina approves competition use of caps designed for afro hair
summary: Fina, the world governing body of swimming, has approved the use of caps designed for afro and big hairstyles in its competitions at every level. The decision follows a review and partnership between Fina and Soul Cap, a company that created the cap to fit over dreadlocks, braids, and afros. The move aims to promote diversity and inclusivity in the sport, particularly for black swimmers, who are underrepresented in elite swimming. The approval took effect on September 1, and Soul Cap expressed gratitude to the swim community for their support in raising awareness about accessibility and inclusion.

site_title: Football: Australia out of 2023 Asian Cup race, wants to host 2026 women's event
summary: Australia has decided not to bid for the 2023 Asian Cup, citing a lack of government support and uncertain AFC timing. However, Football Australia will submit a formal bid for the 2026 women's tournament, which will be co-hosted with New Zealand. The decision comes as China relinquishes its hosting rights for the 2023 tournament due to its zero-Covid policy. Australia will now join Saudi Arabia, Jordan, and Uzbekistan in bidding for the 2026 women's Asian Cup.

site_title: Delivery rider dies in Hougang accident; lorry driver arrested for drink driving
summary: A 45-year-old food delivery rider died in a fatal accident with a lorry in Buangkok Green, Hougang, on Thursday. The 54-year-old lorry driver was arrested for drink driving after police were alerted to the incident at around 8pm. The delivery rider was taken to Tan Tock Seng Hospital, where he died. Police investigations are ongoing, with traffic blocked on Buangkok Green. This incident marks the second recent fatality involving a food delivery rider in Singapore, following the death of Jason Tan in April and another rider who died in June.

site_title: Stricter workplace safety requirements necessary, say construction firms
summary: Singapore's construction firms call for stricter workplace safety requirements due to the rising number of workplace injuries and deaths, with 36 fatalities as of Sept 1 this year. The Ministry of Manpower's new measures include a six-month heightened safety period and mandatory safety timeouts for companies in high-risk sectors. Failure to comply can result in penalties, including suspension of operations and restrictions on hiring new foreign workers. Experts emphasize the need for companies to take ownership of safety protocols and for migrant workers to feel empowered to report unsafe conditions without fear of job loss.

site_title: HSBC starts to lay off AXA Singapore staff; over 20 given notice on Thursday
summary: HSBC has laid off over 20 AXA Singapore staff, with the last day of employment being November 30. The affected employees were given three business days to consider a severance payment. The redundancies mark a significant change in HSBC's operations in Singapore, with no further details provided on the reasons behind the layoffs.

site_title: Travel firms see surge in inquiries for Japan after restrictions are eased
summary: Travel agencies in Singapore have seen a 50% surge in customer inquiries for Japan after the country eased restrictions for tourists. Foreigners will be allowed to visit Japan via package tours without a chaperone starting from September 7, 2022. This change is expected to lead to higher demand for vacations in Japan in the coming months.

site_title: Football: Newcastle owners in 'scary' incident at Liverpool
summary: Newcastle co-owners Mehrdad Ghodoussi and Amanda Staveley narrowly escaped injury when a motorbike driven by two men in balaclavas was driven towards pedestrians outside Anfield before their Premier League match against Liverpool. The bike was involved in a chase with an electric bike, and the riders were arrested on suspicion of various offenses, including drug driving and theft. Thankfully, no serious injuries were reported, but the incident was described as "scary." The match ended with Liverpool winning 2-1.

site_title: BCA issues stop-work order on Clementi BTO site after landslide; key collection delay unlikely
summary: A landslide occurred at the Ulu Pandan Park Connector near the Clementi NorthArc Build-To-Order (BTO) construction site in Singapore, causing damage and injuring one person. The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) issued a stop-work order, but confirmed the nearby buildings are structurally sound. Key collection for the units is unlikely to be delayed, with the first batch planned for December. Repair works are ongoing, and nearby train operations remain unaffected.

site_title: 325 suspects being probed for allegedly scamming victims of over $9 million
summary: Singapore police have arrested 325 suspects in a two-week operation, believed to be involved in over 695 cases of scams that resulted in losses of over $9 million for victims. The suspects, aged 16-86, are facing charges of cheating, money laundering, or providing payment services without a license. The operation, conducted by the Commercial Affairs Department and police land divisions, aims to combat various types of scams, including business e-mail compromise, e-commerce, and phishing. Those found guilty can face up to 10 years in jail and significant fines.

site_title: Who did the best business in the transfer window?
summary: Manchester City tops the transfer window with a £1.7 billion net spend on over 140 players, showcasing the Premier League's dominance. The big move, Erling Haaland's £51 million signing, was a guaranteed headline deal. His arrival led to two more significant transfers: Manchester City selling Gabriel Jesus to Arsenal and Raheem Sterling to Chelsea.

site_title: Singapore hotels charge highest average room rate in 10 years as visitors return
summary: Singapore hotels reported a near-decade high average room rate of $259 in July, driven by a 69.2% year-on-year increase. Hotel revenues reached $318.5 million, more than 4½ times the level recorded in the same period last year. Visitor arrivals surged to 726,601 in July, and revenue per available room rose 140.3% from the previous year, hitting a new post-Covid-19 high of $204.99. Average occupancy rates reached a multi-year high of 79%, just 4 percentage points shy of the pre-pandemic rate.

site_title: Netball: Defending champions Sri Lanka seek sixth Asian title in Singapore
summary: Sri Lanka, the defending champions of the Asian Netball Championship, are set to begin their title defense in Singapore on September 3. Despite not having played an international tournament since 2019 due to the pandemic and economic situation, the team remains confident in their abilities. Captain Gayanjali Amarawansa attributes their stability physically and mentally to their practice sessions since January, and believes the team is ready for the competition. Meanwhile, top contenders Malaysia and Singapore are also gearing up for the tournament, with Malaysia's coach Lisa Beehag praising her team's progress and Singapore's coach Annette Bishop confident in her young team's abilities.

site_title: Transfer window shopping - normal service resumes
summary: Barcelona resumed normal transfer window shopping despite its debt, defying predictions that the pandemic would lead to a more rational approach to football business. The transfer market in the "Big Five" European leagues reached £4 billion, with the English Premier League setting a new transfer spend record. This outcome contradicts initial concerns that the pandemic would bring an end to excessive spending, instead showcasing football's focus on short-term financial gains.

site_title: Football: Juventus loan Swiss international Zakaria to Chelsea
summary: Juventus has loaned Swiss midfielder Denis Zakaria to Chelsea until the end of the season for €3 million plus bonuses. Zakaria's contract with Juventus expires in 2026, but he has fallen out of coach Massimiliano Allegri's plans due to the arrival of Paul Pogba and Leandro Paredes. The loan also gives Chelsea the option to buy Zakaria for €28 million with additional add-ons. This move comes after Juventus sent Brazilian Arthur Melo to Liverpool on loan earlier in the week.

site_title: Secondary school discipline master took upskirt videos of colleagues, students
summary: A 49-year-old secondary school discipline master took upskirt videos of at least 47 women, including 7 students, over a 3-year period. He used his mobile phone to secretly record the videos, targeting women who wore skirts or dresses, and even his mother-in-law. The man pleaded guilty to 3 counts of insulting a woman's modesty and has been suspended from service since 2018. He is expected to be sentenced on November 3, with potential jail time and fines of up to a year for each count.

site_title: Brokers maintain 'buy' call on ComfortDelGro despite STI exit
summary: Analysts at CGS-CIMB and Maybank maintain their "buy" calls on ComfortDelGro, citing expected earnings growth of 27% year-over-year, driven by improved public transport ridership and tourism recovery. Despite being dropped from the Straits Times Index, the company's decent dividend payouts and attractive yield of 5.9% remain attractive. ComfortDelGro's net profit rose 30.4% in the first half, boosted by rising ridership in countries except China, and it declared interim and special dividends.

site_title: Tennis: Nadal overcomes freak racket injury and Fognini to reach 3rd round at US Open
summary: Rafael Nadal overcame a freak injury when he accidentally hit himself with his racket to defeat Italy's Fabio Fognini 2-6, 6-4, 6-2, 6-1 at the US Open. Nadal, the four-time champion, required a medical timeout after the injury to his nose and went on to face France's Richard Gasquet, with whom he has a 17-0 career record. The match featured 15 breaks of serve and 97 unforced errors, with Nadal eventually regaining his composure to win.

site_title: Trials start for new system to allow electric motorcycles to replace depleted batteries at stations
summary: Trials for a battery swapping system for electric motorcycles began in Singapore, with two companies, Gogoro and MO Batteries, testing the technology over 12 months. The system allows users to swap depleted batteries for fully charged ones, reducing wait times. The trials involve 26 electric motorcycles and two stations, with the goal of certifying the technology under revised standards for electric vehicle charging. The move aims to support Singapore's push towards environmentally friendly land transport.

site_title: Football: Forest break English record for most signings in one transfer window
summary: Nottingham Forest has broken the English record for most signings in one transfer window with 21 players, spending nearly £150 million. The newly promoted Premier League side has also taken four points from their opening five games, sitting 15th in the league standings. Manager Steve Cooper's high-profile signings include England international Jesse Lingard, midfielder Morgan Gibbs-White, and strikers Taiwo Awoniyi and Neco Williams. Forest's aggressive transfer strategy aims to secure their stay in the top flight after a 23-year absence.

site_title: SMU student sentenced to 12 weeks' jail for filming 19 upskirt videos
summary: A Singapore Management University (SMU) student, Tien Kiat Chong, 26, was sentenced to 12 weeks in jail for filming 19 upskirt videos of women, mostly on escalators. He pleaded guilty to a single charge of insulting women's modesty and had another charge of possessing obscene films taken into consideration during sentencing. Chong will also face a two-year suspension from SMU and community service. The court heard that Chong intended to appeal the sentence and was offered bail of $8,000.

site_title: Bankrupt Celsius seeks to return $70 million of locked crypto
summary: Celsius Network, a bankrupt cryptocurrency lender, is seeking permission from a US bankruptcy judge to release approximately $50 million worth of cryptocurrency from custody accounts. The move aims to return funds to users locked out of their accounts, who deposited coins with the goal of earning interest. This is a fraction of the over $200 million trapped in custody accounts and a small portion of the $4.2 billion in earn accounts. A hearing on the request is set for October 6.

site_title: Football: Man United cult hero Park Ji-sung gets job at top Korean club
summary: Former Manchester United midfielder Park Ji-sung has been named technical director at South Korea's reigning champions Jeonbuk Motors. In his new role, Park will oversee youth teams and handle transfers, expanding his managerial capacity. The 41-year-old aims to bring European football culture to South Korean players and has already implemented changes, such as eliminating dormitory life for players. Park, a cult hero in his homeland, played for Manchester United and the South Korean national team, winning several titles before retiring in 2014 due to knee injuries.

site_title: Tennis: Williams sisters crash out of US Open doubles competition
summary: The Williams sisters, Serena and Venus, lost their US Open doubles match to the Czech duo of Lucie Hradecka and Linda Noskova with a score of 7-6 (7-5), 6-4. The match, which marked their first doubles appearance in over four years, ended with the sisters exiting the court to a standing ovation. Serena had hinted at her potential retirement in a Vogue article earlier this month, but will continue competing in the singles tournament, facing Ajla Tomljanovic in the third round on Friday.

site_title: Trio charged after they allegedly sold their bank account details to scammers
summary: Three men, Muhamad Hakim Fugi, Tan Yong Kwang, and Zhang Demin, have been charged in a Singapore district court for allegedly selling their bank account details to scammers. The accounts were used to launder at least $370,000 from various scams involving eight victims. Hakim, the sole Singaporean, faces two counts of conspiracy to cheat banks and charges under the Computer Misuse Act. Tan, a Malaysian, has been charged under the Computer Misuse Act and is expected to plead guilty on October 10. Zhang, a Chinese national, is accused of helping another person control the benefits of criminal conduct.

site_title: River Wonders' giant pandas Jia Jia and Kai Kai to extend their stay in Singapore till 2027
summary: Singapore's River Wonders has signed a deal with China to extend the loan of giant pandas Jia Jia and Kai Kai until 2027. The 10-year loan, which was initially set to expire in 2022, will now continue for five more years. The pandas, who arrived in Singapore in 2012, gave birth to a cub, Le Le, last year and will return to China when he turns two. The extension agreement is a testament to the growing friendship between Singapore and China, with the two countries continuing to cooperate on giant panda conservation efforts.

site_title: Improving services, hiring plans and a possible expansion on the cards for Lazada: Group CEO
summary: Lazada Group CEO James Dong is exploring improvements to services, hiring plans, and possible expansion amid a tougher e-commerce landscape. The sector is facing a challenging economic climate with shoppers returning to physical stores after the lifting of Covid-19 restrictions. This shift is expected to slow down online demand, posing a threat to online businesses. Dong's efforts aim to adapt Lazada to the changing market, but the exact nature of these plans remains unclear.

site_title: Philippine peso slides to record low, boosting case for rate hikes
summary: The Philippine peso dropped to a record low of 56.90 per US dollar, weakening 0.9% and extending its decline to 10% this year. The currency's slide is attributed to widening trade deficits and the divergence between the US Federal Reserve's hawkish stance and the Philippine central bank's potential slowdown in interest rate hikes. The peso may fall to 57 per dollar by year-end, according to a senior economist. The Philippine central bank may slow the pace of rate hikes after inflation has been contained, with potential 25-basis point increases for the rest of the year.

site_title: Global bonds tumble into their first bear market in a generation
summary: Global bonds have entered their first bear market in a generation, with the Bloomberg Global Aggregate Total Return Index falling over 20% below its 2021 peak. The decline is attributed to soaring inflation and steep interest-rate hikes by central bankers to quash inflation, even if it means a recession. This marks the end of a four-decade bull market in bonds, and the 60/40 portfolio is on track for its worst annual loss since 2008.

site_title: Luxury goods scam: Duo accused of helping couple flee maintain they intend to plead guilty
summary: Two Malaysian men, Mohamed Alias and Mohamad Fazli Abdul Rahman, are accused of helping a Singaporean couple, Pi Jiapeng and Pansuk Siriwipa, allegedly involved in a $32 million luxury goods scam, flee the country. The men claim to intend to plead guilty to their charges of assisting the escape of the couple. They face two charges each and are currently in remand, with their cases adjourned to September 16.

site_title: US sought records on Binance CEO in late 2020 for crypto money laundering probe
summary: US federal prosecutors requested Binance, the world's largest cryptocurrency exchange, to provide internal records and communications involving its CEO Zhao Changpeng in a 2020 money laundering probe. The investigation, part of a broader Justice Department inquiry, seeks to determine if Binance violated the Bank Secrecy Act, which requires crypto exchanges to register with the Treasury Department and comply with anti-money laundering requirements. Binance has cooperated with regulators and claims to have an industry-leading security and compliance team, but the company has faced scrutiny and fines from financial regulators worldwide over anti-money laundering concerns.

site_title: Football: 'Unfinished business': Aubameyang returns to Premier League with Chelsea transfer
summary: Chelsea has signed Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang from Barcelona on a two-year contract, ending the Gabon striker's brief stint with the Spanish club. Aubameyang, who was the Premier League's joint top scorer in the 2018-19 season, returns to the league after a four-year absence. The transfer was announced after the deadline, but Chelsea submitted the paperwork to the Premier League in time. Aubameyang's signing is a move to address Chelsea's front line, which has been playing without a striker since Romelu Lukaku's loan move to Inter Milan.

site_title: Part of park connector near Clementi BTO site closed after landslide
summary: A section of the Ulu Pandan Park Connector near a completed Housing Board Build-To-Order project in Clementi was closed after a landslide caused soil to spill into the nearby Ulu Pandan Canal on Friday morning. One passer-by sustained minor injuries and was treated at the scene. Authorities, including the HDB, NParks, PUB, and BCA, are conducting an investigation and carrying out recovery actions to ensure public safety. The area has been cordoned off, and residents are advised to stay clear until further notice.

site_title: Football: Belts tightened, but PSG bring quiet transfer deadline day to life in Europe
summary: Paris Saint-Germain (PSG) has brought quiet to the European transfer deadline day despite committing huge sums to persuade Kylian Mbappe to sign a new contract. The Qatar-owned club spent over €100 million on new signings, including Fabian Ruiz and Hugo Ekitike, but failed to sign Slovakia defender Milan Skriniar from Inter Milan. In contrast, other top European clubs, such as Barcelona, Bayern Munich, and Manchester City, have made significant spending, with Barcelona spending around €150 million on transfers and Manchester City acquiring Erling Haaland from Borussia Dortmund.

site_title: First public housing site in Dover Forest to be launched in November
summary: The first public housing site in Dover Forest will launch in November with 1,330 BTO flats available, including 3-room and 4-room units. The site is within walking distance of Dover MRT station on the East-West Line, while the western half of the forest is preserved for biodiversity.

site_title: Sea cuts jobs in gaming arm Garena in second downsizing wave
summary: Sea Limited, a Singapore-based e-commerce giant, is cutting 40 jobs in its gaming arm Garena and 12 employees in its research and development unit, Sea Labs, as part of its second round of job cuts this year. The company aims to improve efficiency and focus on profitability amid rising competition and slowing e-commerce growth. Sea had previously made job cuts at Shopee in June, and the company's market value has lost nearly US$170 billion since an October high due to concerns about its money-making prospects.

site_title: Warship USS Tripoli docks in Singapore
summary: The USS Tripoli, the US Navy's newest America-class amphibious assault ship, has docked in Singapore as part of its maiden deployment. The ship, carrying 2,400 military personnel, including 1,200 marines, arrived in Singapore after a months-long journey from San Diego, California. The vessel is operating in the 7th Fleet area of operations to enhance inter-operability with allies and partners, and serve as a ready response force in the Indo-Pacific region. USS Tripoli's unique design allows it to project air assets, adding to the power and flexibility of US forces.

site_title: ComfortDelGro dropped from STI, replaced by liquor giant Emperador
summary: ComfortDelGro, a Singaporean transport company, has been dropped from the Straits Times Index (STI) and replaced by Emperador, a Philippine liquor giant. The change will take effect on September 19. Emperador's shares jumped 4% after the news, while ComfortDelGro's shares fell 2.1%. ComfortDelGro's removal is due to its small market capitalization of around $3 billion, while Emperador's market capitalization is around $8 billion. The STI reserve list, which includes five non-constituents, will replace ComfortDelGro in the index.

site_title: askST: What is a digital bank and how do their offerings differentiate them from traditional ones?
summary: Two new digital banks, GXS Bank and Trust Bank, have opened in Singapore, amid heightened competition in the local and foreign lender market. Despite slowing economic growth, policymakers see room for more digital bank entrants, indicating a growing interest in the sector. The arrival of these two new banks is seen as a positive development, offering consumers more choices and driving innovation in the financial services industry.

site_title: Yen at risk of further declines after breaching key 140 level
summary: The Japanese yen fell below the key 140 per US dollar level for the first time in nearly a quarter century, weakening by 0.9% against the dollar. The currency's decline reflects the widening yield gap between the US and Japan, driven by the Federal Reserve's hawkish monetary policy. Traders are betting on further declines, with options markets showing a bias towards contracts that would pay off if the dollar-yen continues to rise. The Bank of Japan's dovish stance has hindered efforts to halt the yen's decline, with officials showing little inclination to intervene in the currency markets.

site_title: Football: Liverpool reinforce midfield with Arthur loan from Juventus
summary: Liverpool has signed Brazilian midfielder Arthur Melo from Juventus on a season-long loan. The move comes amid an injury crisis for the team, with midfielders Thiago Alcantara, Jordan Henderson, Naby Keita, and Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain sidelined. Arthur, 26, has made 63 appearances for Juventus since joining from Barcelona in 2020 and can play in central midfield. The loan deal does not include an option to buy, and Liverpool face Merseyside rivals Everton on Saturday.

site_title: Nurse-turned-lecturer among 8 teachers to get President's Award
summary: Nurse-turned-lecturer Ms Pauline Hu, 50, received the President's Award for Teachers for her dedication to educating students, particularly seniors. She guides her students to develop devices such as the Sensistove, a gadget to detect gas stove misuse. Hu is one of eight teachers to receive the top honour, chosen from 17 finalists across various institutions. The award highlights the impact of teachers on society, going beyond academics to focus on socio-emotional and mental resilience foundations.

site_title: Billionaire Adani's flagship firm enters key India index in new boost
summary: Adani Enterprises, the flagship firm of Asia's richest man Gautam Adani, will join the NSE Nifty 50 Index, replacing Shree Cement, as of September 30. This move is expected to bring in a net inflow of around $213 million for Adani Enterprises' stocks. The inclusion is part of the group's expansion, with shares rising 89% this year, driven by a 310% surge in Adani Power. However, analysts have raised concerns about the conglomerate's leverage and credit metrics. The move is seen as a boost for Adani Enterprises.

site_title: Dow, S&P 500 snap losing streak ahead of jobs data
summary: The Dow and S&P 500 snapped a four-day losing streak on Thursday, ahead of jobs data expected to support the Federal Reserve's monetary tightening. Stocks fell early but rallied in the final hour, driven by bargain hunting. Analysts expect a 300,000 jobs gain in August with a 3.5% unemployment rate. The Dow Jones ended 0.5% higher at 31,656.42, while the S&P 500 gained 0.3% to 3,966.85. Nvidia and Twitter fell due to export restrictions and an edit button test, respectively.

site_title: How new digital banks can add value to industry
summary: Two new digital banks, GXS Bank and Trust Bank, have opened for business in Singapore amidst heightened competition in the financial industry. Despite slowing economic growth, policymakers believe there is still room for new digital bank entrants, citing the need for innovation and increased financial inclusion. The arrival of these digital banks is seen as a positive development, potentially adding value to the industry through improved efficiency and customer convenience.

site_title: Tennis: China's 'fab four' make history at US Open
summary: China's women's tennis team has made history at the US Open, becoming the first four-woman team from the country to reach the third round of a single Grand Slam event. Zheng Qinwen, Yuan Yue, Wang Xiyu, and Zhang Shuai achieved this milestone, with Zheng and Yuan advancing to the next round. The achievement marks a significant increase in success for Chinese women's tennis, following notable performances by Li Na in the past decade. China's men's team also celebrated a US Open first, with Wu Yibing advancing to the third round.

site_title: Football: Ten Hag urges Man United to 'be more ruthless' despite win
summary: Manchester United secured a 1-0 win over Leicester City with Jadon Sancho scoring in the 23rd minute, his second goal of the season. The victory marked United's third consecutive Premier League win under manager Erik ten Hag, who praised the team's spirit and determination. Despite the big-money signing of Brazil winger Antony, Sancho's performance reaffirmed his role in the team. Ten Hag expressed his desire for United to be "more ruthless" in their attacking play, and Cristiano Ronaldo's future remains uncertain as he starts on the bench for a third consecutive game.

site_title: 2 dead, 8 hurt after car crashes into Tower Transit bus in Woodlands
summary: A car crashed into a Tower Transit bus in Woodlands, Singapore, killing the car's driver and a 53-year-old bus passenger. The driver died at the scene, while the passenger died in hospital. Seven other bus passengers were injured and taken to hospital. The bus was traveling on service 858 when the accident occurred. The bus operator, Tower Transit, has offered condolences to the families involved and will assist with medical claims. Residents are concerned about traffic safety at the junction, citing the lack of red-amber-green turning signals.

site_title: Boutique hotel opens at Gardens by the Bay
summary: Garden Pod, a boutique hotel at Gardens by the Bay, officially opened on Thursday. Designed by Laud Architects, the hotel features four duplex suites with 70 sq m of space over two levels, each accommodating up to four guests. The suites come with amenities such as a living room, kitchen, and private outdoor patio, and are constructed from repurposed shipping containers with photovoltaic panels. The hotel is a sustainable concept, meeting 80% of its energy needs through solar energy. Rates start from $450 per night, making it a unique retreat in the heart of the bay.

site_title: Tennis: Alcaraz tames Coria to reach US Open third round
summary: Carlos Alcaraz defeated Federico Coria 6-2 6-1 7-5 to reach the US Open third round, advancing to a match against American Jenson Brooksby. Alcaraz, the third seed, used his all-court speed and forehand to win the match, saving 14 of 15 break points. Brooksby, who beat Borna Coric earlier in the day, will look to capitalize on Alcaraz's emotional outburst, saying he used Coric's frustration to his advantage.

site_title: Tuas Port will be critical engine of Singapore's economy: PM
summary: Singapore's Tuas Port, a $20 billion mega port, officially opened its first phase with 500 workers operating three berths. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong hailed the facility as a critical engine driving the country's economy, reinforcing its status as an international maritime center. The port's use of artificial intelligence and machine learning will assure international partners of its ability to handle complex operations. With a handling capacity of 65 million TEUs, Tuas Port is expected to create thousands of jobs and solidify Singapore's position as a major hub for global trade.

site_title: Python swallows 6kg pet cat in Tanah Merah condo
summary: A reticulated python in Tanah Merah, Singapore, swallowed a 6kg pet cat, Ben, on Monday night. The cat's owner, Angel Low, reported Ben missing after seeing a video of the snake with a bulging belly. The python regurgitated the cat while being transported to the Singapore Zoo, but it was too late to retrieve the body. The carcass was disposed of according to zoo protocols, and the incident highlights the need for pet owners to keep a close eye on their pets when outdoors.

site_title: Indian court ruling shows risks of legal challenge to definition of marriage: Minister
summary: Singapore's Home Affairs and Law Minister K. Shanmugam warns that the Indian Supreme Court's recent ruling on expanding the definition of family to include atypical households may pose risks to Singapore's current definition of marriage. The ruling, which recognized same-sex couples and blended families, highlights the need for Parliament to decide on the definition of marriage, rather than the courts. The government plans to amend the Constitution to safeguard the definition of marriage and ensure it is defined as between a man and a woman.

site_title: Over 2m can get alerts as employers credit money to CPF
summary: Singapore's Central Provident Fund (CPF) has launched a new service allowing over 2 million members to receive email and push notification alerts when their monthly contributions are credited by employers. Members can easily verify declared wages and contributions, and receive alerts if discrepancies are found. The service received positive feedback from 16,000 members, with an average rating of 4.6 out of 5 points. The alerts encourage members to check their contributions and help prevent arrears from accumulating, allowing for early recovery and rectification of errors.

site_title: ST Engineering unit bags $1.4b rail project in southern Taiwan
summary: ST Engineering unit Urban Solutions won a $1.4 billion contract to provide turnkey rail services for Kaohsiung MRT Yellow Line in southern Taiwan. The 10-year project includes rail electronics solutions, depot design and construction, and systems integration. Works are expected to start late this year, with ridership estimated at 1.2 million, or 42% of the city's population. The contract is expected to have minimal impact on ST Engineering's net tangible assets and earnings per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Aussie home prices suffer sharpest fall in 40 years on rising rates, inflation
summary: Australian home prices plummeted 1.6% in August, marking the largest monthly drop in 40 years, as rising interest rates and inflation pressures eroded demand. The national annual price growth fell to 4.7%, with major cities such as Sydney, Melbourne, and Brisbane also experiencing significant declines. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to hike interest rates again next week, with forecasts suggesting the cash rate could reach 4% by mid-2023, further squeezing household wealth and confidence.

site_title: Ngee Ann City eatery fined $3,000 for flouting rules during CNY reunion
summary: A Singapore court fined East Ocean Teochew Restaurant $3,000 for violating Covid-19 regulations during a Chinese New Year reunion gathering in January. The restaurant allowed 11 guests from different households to dine together, despite a limit of five people per group. This was the third time the establishment had flouted pandemic measures, with previous fines in 2021. Operations manager Lai Yoong Chong and manager Ho Yan Min were found guilty of not checking the customers' household status before allowing them into the premises.

site_title: Ong Teng Cheong's elder son sues sis-in-law over GCB
summary: Former President Ong Teng Cheong's elder son is suing his sister-in-law over an award-winning Art Deco bungalow in Dalvey Estate. The dispute arises from the bungalow, which was once the private residence of the late Mr Ong Teng Cheong. The elder son had previously settled a dispute with his brother over their parents' architectural business. The lawsuit is nearly a year after the earlier settlement. Details of the case are not disclosed, and the outcome is yet to be determined.

site_title: US, S'pore reaffirm importance of rules-based world order
summary: US and Singapore reaffirmed the importance of a rules-based world order during a lunch hosted by Singapore's Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan for a US congressional delegation. The delegation, comprising representatives from both parties, exchanged views on regional and international developments. Both sides also affirmed the deep and multifaceted partnership between Singapore and the US, with a focus on deepening US engagement in the region, including the Indo-Pacific Economic Framework. The meeting highlighted sustained US engagement in the region and its commitment to a rules-based world order.

site_title: Chinese stock's 13,000% surge creates another US IPO mystery
summary: A Chinese firm, Addentax Group, made its US IPO debut with a 13,031% surge, making it a US$20 billion company and surpassing a third of S&P 500 Index members. The company's market capitalization ballooned despite modest revenues of US$12.7 million for the year ended in March, which allowed for relaxed disclosure requirements under US laws. This marks the eighth firm from Hong Kong or China to experience similar surprising moves following US IPOs this year, with similar firms AMTD Digital and Magic Empire experiencing similar surges before declines.

site_title: Euro zone inflation hits record as ECB hawks push rate rise
summary: Euro area inflation reached a record 9.1% in August, exceeding the 9% median estimate. Underlying inflation, excluding energy and food, rose to 4.3%, highlighting broad-based price pressures. The European Central Bank (ECB) is considering a 75-basis point interest rate hike, with policymakers seeking a balance between controlling inflation and avoiding economic momentum. Economists predict a recession in the euro area, and governments have spent €280 billion on measures to offset the energy price shock.

site_title: Economists cut S'pore forecast on inflation, global slowdown woes
summary: Singapore's private-sector economists have cut their 2022 growth forecast to 3.5% due to a sharper-than-expected surge in inflation and global economic slowdown. The forecast is lower than the previous 3.8% growth estimate. Economists also expect higher inflation, with overall inflation forecast to hit 5.7% and core inflation at 3.8%. Despite this, they predict the unemployment rate will reach 2% by year-end, and inflation is expected to ease in 2023. The biggest risk to the domestic economy is spillovers from an external growth slowdown among major trading partners.

site_title: MAS imposes penalty of $375,000 on UOB Kay Hian
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has imposed a composition penalty of $375,000 on brokerage firm UOB Kay Hian for failing to comply with business conduct requirements, including anti-money laundering and countering the financing of terrorism regulations. The firm breached MAS's Securities and Futures (Licensing and Conduct of Business) Regulations by accepting third-party receipts without adequate due diligence and failing to verify customers' source of wealth. UOBKH has paid the penalty and taken remedial measures to enhance its internal policies and controls.

site_title: Company briefs:   Arm
summary: Arm has sued Qualcomm for breach of contract and trademark infringement, alleging Qualcomm's acquisition of chip start-up Nuvia is invalid due to unapproved licence transfers. Snap is laying off 20% of its employees, discontinuing at least six products, and appointing its first COO in seven years. Meanwhile, Deutsche Lufthansa will suspend nearly all flights at two German hubs due to a strike by pilots demanding higher pay, affecting 130,000 passengers.
