site_title: StanChart, NTUC Enterprise launch digital Trust Bank
summary: Standard Chartered Bank and the National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) have launched Trust Bank, a digital bank offering a savings account, credit card, and family personal accident insurance. The bank has no minimum balance, lock-in period, or fees and offers up to 21% rebates on its credit card for NTUC members. Trust Bank aims to cater to older Singaporeans and the less tech-savvy, simplifying banking and launching innovative products. The bank's CEO says the goal is to build deep relationships with customers and encourage loyalty, while Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong urges the bank to protect consumers from bank scams and maintain data security.

site_title: Asia's factory activity slumps on China's Covid-19 curbs, US slowdown
summary: Asia's factory activity slumped in August due to China's zero-Covid-19 curbs, cost pressures, and the US slowdown. China's private PMI contracted for the first time in three months, while Japan's factory activity grew at its slowest rate in nearly a year and South Korea's shrank by the sharpest pace in two years. Taiwan's manufacturing activity also deteriorated sharply. The US Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes are stoking fears of recession, further weakening the business mood. Weakening demand is easing price pressures, but the outlook for the region's economic recovery remains dark.

site_title: Applicants caught off guard after Shopee withdraws job offers
summary: Shopee has withdrawn job offers for several positions at its Singapore headquarters, leaving applicants stunned. A user on Chinese workplace app Maimai claimed to have received a call upon landing in Singapore informing them of the job offer's withdrawal. The move has caught applicants off guard, with one individual having already flown to Singapore to take up the role. The reason behind the withdrawal is not specified, leaving the affected applicants uncertain about their future.

site_title: Kyrgios spitting mad over odour
summary: Australian tennis player Nick Kyrgios sparked controversy during his US Open third-round match, spitting at fans and using expletives towards his entourage. The volatile player claimed a strong cannabis smell was affecting his asthma and led to a code violation and a warning to the crowd. Kyrgios, a heavy asthmatic, emphasized that marijuana is not ideal for athletes with the condition. He has a history of on-court outbursts, including a Wimbledon incident in July where he demanded a fan be ejected.

site_title: K-pop ETF makes NYSE debut, riding on Blackpink, BTS craze
summary: A new K-pop exchange-traded fund (ETF) made its debut on the NYSE Arca exchange, tracking an index of 30 companies in the Korean entertainment industry. The KPOP ETF, launched by Contents Technologies, invests in firms benefiting from K-pop culture, including Hybe (BTS), JYP Entertainment, SM Entertainment, and YG Entertainment. This is the first US or European ETF to focus on the K-pop industry, with a 70-80% weight on entertainment firms. The fund aims to provide global investors with exposure to K-pop companies, despite facing challenges in defining its target market.

site_title: Jo not given special treatment
summary: Singapore national swimmer Joseph Schooling was put on a supervised urine test regime for six months after confessing to taking cannabis while training overseas. His urine test initially returned negative, but the Ministry of Defence took action due to the Misuse of Drugs Act, which treats overseas substance abuse as if it occurred in Singapore. Schooling could have faced a standard nine-month sentence if his test had been positive, but the military justice system instead imposed a six-month regime.

site_title: Elder son takes legal steps to wind up two firms
summary: The elder son of former Singaporean President Ong Teng Cheong, Mr. Ong Tze Guan, has initiated legal proceedings against his sister-in-law, Madam Wang Yi Yi. He has filed applications in the High Court to wind up two firms, O&O Capital and Wang Investment, of which Madam Wang is also a shareholder and director. This move comes after more legal proceedings were initiated against him. The details of the case are yet to be disclosed.

site_title: STI closes with slight gain even as sombre mood hits region
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 2.4 points, or 0.07%, to 3,224.08, defying a sombre mood in the region due to aggressive rate-hike fears in the US and concerns over inflation. Despite 275 losers beating 227 gainers, the index bucked the trend, with Nio being the biggest value gainer for the month. Experts predict a "bear market rally" in Wall Street, but see the current situation as a tactical opportunity to pick up select growth names at inexpensive valuation levels.

site_title: Schooling and Lim to get support, says SSA
summary: Singapore Swimming Association (SSA) has pledged to support national athletes Joseph Schooling and Amanda Lim as they rehabilitate after admitting to consuming drugs. The SSA expressed disappointment but reaffirmed its zero-tolerance stance towards illegal drugs, stating it will continue to work with the athletes to prevent future missteps. Schooling, the country's Olympic gold medallist, was placed on a six-month urine-testing regime, while Lim received a stern warning from the Central Narcotics Bureau. The SSA will review the facts and work with Sport Singapore and the SNOC to determine the next steps.

site_title: Play without fear: Tigers' new coach
summary: New head coach Peter de Roo has urged Balestier Khalsa to play with fearlessness and possession-based football, despite sitting second-last in the Singapore Premier League. De Roo, a Dutchman, aims to break the team's confidence barrier and trigger a winning streak. He will face off against Albirex Niigata on Friday, a title-chasing team that has won 12 of their last 15 matches. De Roo is excited to return to the touchline after 20 years as a technical director and believes his team has the potential to succeed.

site_title: Good day for Chinese players at US Open
summary: Chinese players dominated at the US Open on Wednesday, with Wang Xiyu and Zhang Shuai advancing to the third round of the women's singles. Wang defeated Maria Sakkari 3-6, 7-5, 7-5, while Zhang beat Anna Karolina Schmiedlova 7-5, 6-1. In the men's draw, Wu Yibing made history by becoming the first Chinese man to reach the third round of the US Open, defeating Nuno Borges in a five-set thriller. Both Wu and Wang will face tough opponents in the third round, with Wu set to face defending champion Daniil Medvedev and Wang facing Alison Riske-Amritraj.

site_title: Weed grinder the smoking gun that triggered Schooling's confession
summary: A weed grinder was found in Olympic gold medallist Joseph Schooling's friend Amanda Lim's possession at Changi Airport, sparking a probe that led to Schooling's confession of taking cannabis. The discovery triggered a probe, which ultimately resulted in Schooling's admission.

site_title: Too early to dismiss Jo's mistake as moment of folly
summary: National swimmer Joseph Schooling admitted to using cannabis while training for the SEA Games in Hanoi. His confession sparked a surprising online reaction, with some dismissing it as a "moment of folly" or a non-issue due to cannabis being a "soft" drug. However, the reaction suggests that the issue may be more complex than initially thought.

site_title: I Am Giant could make his rivals look small
summary: South Africa's Turffontein track saw several notable performances on Saturday. I Am Giant, who won his debut, is expected to continue his form and is considered the top selection. Raratonga Rose is predicted to be a penalty kick in the 2,000M event, while The Inkosana is favored to take the 2,000M race. Other notable performances included wins by Lord of Light and Legislate's Dance.

site_title: China to publish detailed steps for new economic measures soon
summary: China plans to publish detailed steps for its newly announced economic policy measures, aiming to revive the sluggish economy amid the resurgence of Covid-19 and a distressed property sector. The 19 new policies include supporting key projects and equipment upgrades, guiding commercial banks to provide medium- and long-term loans, and propelling up the weak property market. The government will also provide special loans for home delivery and give local governments greater autonomy to implement policies, with a focus on "one policy for one city." The measures come as China's economy narrowly escaped contraction in the June quarter.

site_title: 'Crazy' weekend in store for max
summary: Max Verstappen is set for an emotional and "pretty crazy" home race in the Dutch Grand Prix, seeking his 10th win of the season and a 30th career victory. The 24-year-old champion expects a tougher contest, with Ferrari a strong contender, but remains focused on scoring points and enjoying the weekend with fans and family. Verstappen will pay tribute to his father Jos with a new helmet design, aiming to smash Michael Schumacher's record of 13 wins in a season.

site_title: Antony finally joins United, Akanji signs for rivals City
summary: Manchester United signed winger Antony from Ajax Amsterdam for £82 million, with a contract until 2027. The 22-year-old Brazilian international joins former Ajax coach Erik ten Hag's recruits, including Lisandro Martinez and Tyrell Malacia. Meanwhile, Manchester City strengthened their defense by signing Swiss Manuel Akanji on a five-year deal from Borussia Dortmund. The transfer deadline day moves come after Chelsea reached an agreement with Barcelona to sign Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang and Marcos Alonso.

site_title: Klopp proud of 'perfect response'
summary: Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp praised his team's composure in securing a 2-1 win over Newcastle United at Anfield. The Reds trailed 1-0 until substitute Fabio Carvalho scored in the 97th minute, sparking wild celebrations. Klopp attributed the win to the team's ability to keep calm and play the extra pass, which made them "immediately really dangerous." The German manager also praised Carvalho, who has made a great start since joining the club from Fulham. The win marks a significant comeback for Liverpool, who had struggled until the late stages of the game.

site_title: EPL should stop using VAR: Conte
summary: Tottenham Hotspur manager Antonio Conte criticized the use of Video Assistant Referee (VAR) after a penalty was overturned in a 1-1 draw with West Ham United. A header by Harry Kane was initially awarded a penalty but was later reversed after a lengthy VAR check, with the ball striking Kane's arm before his hand. Conte expressed frustration, stating that VAR should be used to support the referee, not overturn decisions. He suggested that VAR should be stopped in England to avoid human mistakes, echoing comments from West Ham boss David Moyes who called the controversy the "turning point" of the game.

site_title: Paving the way for female refs at men's World Cup
summary: Japanese referee Yoshimi Yamashita, 36, is set to make history at the Qatar World Cup as one of six female officials selected for the first time by FIFA to officiate at the men's tournament. Yamashita, who has officiated at the 2019 Women's World Cup and the Tokyo Olympic Games, attributes her success to hard work and a strong passion for football. She emphasizes that physical fitness is not the only factor in refereeing, but rather mental toughness and ability to remain calm under pressure. Yamashita's historic appointment marks a significant step towards women officiating at men's games.

site_title: Arsenal stay perfect but can do better
summary: Arsenal maintained their perfect Premier League record with a 2-1 win over Aston Villa, thanks to goals from Gabriel Jesus and Gabriel Martinelli. Despite dominating possession and scoring chances, manager Mikel Arteta believes the team still has room for improvement. The win advances Arsenal to 15 points from five matches, while Aston Villa's fourth defeat in five games adds to the pressure on manager Steven Gerrard. Arteta praised his team's character and energy, but acknowledged areas for improvement ahead of their next match against Manchester United.

site_title: Sports World : Loh knocked out by Prannoy in Japan
summary: Singapore's Loh Kean Yew lost 22-20, 21-19 to India's H.S. Prannoy in the Japan Open's round of 16, ending the country's badminton event. The Republic's mixed doubles duo of Terry Hee and Jessica Tan also lost to Thailand's Dechapol Puavaranukroh and Sapsiree Taerattanachai. The Hong Kong Open and Macau Open have been cancelled for the third consecutive year due to Covid-19 restrictions.

site_title: I Feel like I've already won, says Williams
summary: Serena Williams credits Tiger Woods as a key motivator for her win over world No. 2 Anett Kontaveit, reaching the third round of the 2022 US Open. Williams, 40, has been wrestling with retirement, but Woods' support helped her gain clarity. The two are chasing history, with Williams seeking her 24th Slam and Woods aiming to break Jack Nicklaus' record of 18 Majors. Williams feels "like I've already won" the US Open, mentally and figuratively, after her dramatic win.

site_title: A city great in the making
summary: Manchester City's Erling Haaland scored a hat-trick in a 6-0 Premier League win over Nottingham Forest, becoming the first player in the Premier League era to net nine goals in his first five appearances. Manager Pep Guardiola praised Haaland's talent, saying he has the quality to become a Manchester City legend, but emphasized the team's focus on winning titles rather than individual records. Haaland, who has already scored 9 goals in 5 games, is now the favorite to finish as the season's top scorer.

site_title: Next 24 hours
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Today's sports schedule includes La Vuelta Stage 13, Balestier vs Albirex in the Singapore Premier League, and Celta vs Cadiz in the Spanish Primera Liga. Golfers will compete in the DP World Tour's Made in HimmerLand and the LPGA Tour's Dana Open. MotoGP and Formula One will hold practice sessions for the San Marino Grand Prix and Dutch Grand Prix, respectively. The US Open tennis tournament continues with Day 5 matches. Viewers can catch these events on various channels, including Singtel TV and StarHub.

site_title: New measures show resolve to stem workplace deaths, but they should be made to stick
summary: Singapore has taken extraordinary measures to curb work-related deaths and injuries, following an alarming rise this year. The steps, announced by Senior Minister of State for Manpower Zaqy Mohamad, include stepped-up pressure and scrutiny on companies. The measures aim to change the safety mindset and culture. The government urges the continued pressure to be maintained until substantial changes are seen, emphasizing the need for lasting changes in workplace safety.

site_title: Celavi is happy in Seoul: Clements
summary: Trainer Michael Clements expressed slight concern over his mare Celavi's barrier draw at Seoul Racecourse for Sunday's 1 billion won Korea Sprint. Normally, a low barrier would be favorable, but Clements believes the Polytrack-loving mare may struggle with the deep sand track. Despite this, Clements is optimistic about Celavi's chances, citing her speed and ability to adapt to the track conditions. With eight international horses, including three from the UK, Hong Kong, and Japan, Clements is preparing for a competitive race, but remains confident in Celavi's form.

site_title: UK judge dismisses jury in Giggs domestic violence case
summary: A British judge has dismissed the jury in the domestic violence case against former Manchester United winger Ryan Giggs, after it failed to reach a verdict after 23 hours of deliberations. The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) has been given a week to consider a possible retrial of the case, which could lead to a five-year jail term if Giggs is found guilty of controlling and coercive behavior, assaulting, and abusing his ex-girlfriend Kate Greville and her sister. Giggs, who denies all allegations, remains out on bail and is not required to attend the next court hearing on September 7.

site_title: Labour MP calls for further measures to prevent safety lapses
summary: Labour MP Melvin Yong calls for further measures to prevent safety lapses, urging companies in high-risk industries to implement a compulsory safety timeout and set up workplace safety committees. The Ministry of Manpower has announced new measures, including a six-month heightened safety period, mandatory safety timeouts, and increased support for small-and medium-sized enterprises. Senior Minister Zaqy Mohamad emphasizes the need for a safety culture shift, with a focus on carrots, not just sticks, to encourage companies and workers to prioritize workplace safety.

site_title: New features help S'pore stay ahead of competitors, say firms
summary: Singapore's Tuas Port, set to officially open, boasts several features that keep it ahead of competitors. The port's dark yard areas utilize automated driverless machines, reducing electricity use and increasing efficiency. Shipping lines and exporters praise the port's higher operational costs as justified by the increased efficiency and smaller carbon footprint. Tuas Port is also prepared for mega container vessels and aims to improve inter-terminal transfer time and domestic emissions. Located strategically, the port serves three main markets: Asia-Europe trade, transshipment, and intra-Asian container trade.

site_title: Stricter measures to curb rise in workplace deaths
summary: The Singapore government has introduced stricter measures to curb workplace deaths, including barring firms with unsafe work conditions from hiring new foreign workers for up to three months. Companies in higher-risk sectors must conduct a safety timeout, a mandatory review of safety procedures, and top management must personally account for lapses. The measures come amid a worrying rise in work-related deaths, with 36 fatalities this year, and will be enforced from September 1 to 15. Failure to comply will result in penalties, including a one-month ban on hiring new foreign workers.

site_title: Must-reads
summary: Stricter workplace safety rules are in place following a rise in workplace deaths and injuries. Companies will not be allowed to hire new foreign workers for up to three months if unsafe conditions are found. Meanwhile, Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. plans to increase the cap on Filipino nurses working overseas, raise their benefits, and introduce scholarship opportunities. In other news, Thailand is offering 10-year visas to top professionals, and Singapore's economic growth forecast has been cut to 3.5% due to inflation and slowing trading partners. The world is also experiencing an age structural change, with older people expected to outnumber the young by 2100.

site_title: Watson prepared for Augusta ban
summary: Bubba Watson, a two-time Masters champion, has expressed his desire to return to Augusta National despite joining LIV Golf. However, he is prepared for a potential ban. Watson, along with other LIV Golf players, has been critical of the PGA Tour's decision not to award world ranking points for LIV events. Watson and LIV Golf players, including Cameron Smith, argue that this decision is unfair and will hinder competition. Watson's future at Augusta National remains uncertain, but he is praying for a decision that allows past champions to continue competing.

site_title: 39 SMEs lauded for giving back to the community
summary: 39 small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore have been commended for giving back to the community, a 77% increase from 2020, according to the National Volunteer and Philanthropy Centre (NVPC). This reflects growing efforts to integrate philanthropy into business practices. The recognized SMEs, including Palo IT, aim to make a positive impact through initiatives such as workplace diversity, education, and vocational training for underprivileged youth. Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong praised the increased corporate giving, citing a higher level of trust and unity in Singapore since the pandemic.

site_title: Coffee shop zi char chain removes service charge after consumer backlash
summary: A Singapore coffee shop zi char chain, FuLee Seafood, has removed its 0.1% service charge from dine-in customers' bills after consumer backlash. The charge was introduced in mid-July but was reversed around mid-August following customer reactions. The decision was made by the chain's owner, Wu Yujiao, who declined to comment further.

site_title: Stepped-up pressure on companies to boost safety should continue
summary: Singapore has taken extraordinary measures to curb the rise in work-related deaths and injuries, with stricter rules aimed at boosting workplace safety. The stepped-up pressure on companies reflects a resolve to address the alarming increase in workplace fatalities. While the new measures are a step in the right direction, further changes are needed to ensure continued progress in reducing worker deaths and injuries.

site_title: Labour MP calls for further measures to curb rise in workplace deaths
summary: Labour MP Melvin Yong calls for further measures to curb workplace deaths in Singapore, citing the recent rise in fatalities. The government has announced measures, including a mandatory safety timeout for high-risk industries, heightened safety periods, and increased support for small-and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). Yong also recommends involving all parties in reviewing safety systems and processes, and setting up workplace safety committees. Senior Minister of State for Manpower Zaqy Mohamad emphasizes the need for a cultural shift towards prioritizing workplace safety, stating that the measures are not just about enforcement, but also about encouraging companies and workers to improve their safety culture.

site_title: Tennis: Ukrainian Kostyuk's handshake refusal latest sign of tension at US Open
summary: Ukrainian tennis player Marta Kostyuk refused a handshake with Belarusian opponent Victoria Azarenka after Azarenka's win, the latest sign of tension at the US Open. Kostyuk has called for the WTA to ban Russian athletes from the tour, while Azarenka expressed her commitment to raising humanitarian aid for Ukraine. The incident highlights the ongoing geopolitical tensions between the countries amidst the conflict in Ukraine.

site_title: Two ex-directors of firm linked to Ponzi scheme convicted
summary: Two former directors, Iseli Rudolf James Maitland and How Soo Feng, were convicted of carrying on a fraudulent business as directors of The Gold Label (TGL), a firm linked to a Ponzi scheme. TGL owed clients over $85 million after its business broke down in 2010. Maitland and How profited from the scheme, with over $1.2 million in directors' fees paid between 2009 and 2010. The pair claimed ignorance, but prosecutors argued they must have known the business model was unsustainable, with evidence showing they were aware of money circulation and the need for investments.

site_title: Formula One: Hamilton admits 'slow' Mercedes car 'hurts'
summary: Lewis Hamilton expressed frustration with his Mercedes car's performance in the Belgian Grand Prix, calling it "slow" and admitting it "hurts." The seven-time world champion, who finished in a collision with Fernando Alonso, aims to bounce back at the Dutch Grand Prix. Hamilton praised Red Bull for their dominant display, saying their performance was "brilliant." He also clarified his past comments about Red Bull, stating they were taken out of context and that he believes in his team's ability to catch up.

site_title: Thailand legalising cannabis poses more challenges to S'pore's anti-drug stance: Shanmugam
summary: Singapore's Minister of Home Affairs and Law K. Shanmugam expressed concerns that Thailand's legalization of cannabis poses challenges to maintaining Singapore's drug-free status, citing the easy availability of the drug in neighboring countries. Shanmugam noted that Thailand's authorities have struggled to control its use, and the flow of people between Singapore and Thailand will increase the challenges. He emphasized the addictive nature of cannabis and its potential to cause irreversible damage, while citing statistics on the lives lost to drug use globally.

site_title: Football: Man United sign Antony, Dubravka on transfer deadline day
summary: Manchester United completed signings of Ajax midfielder Antony and Newcastle United goalkeeper Martin Dubravka on transfer deadline day. Antony, 22, signed a five-year contract worth £80.75 million, having played under manager Erik ten Hag at Ajax. Slovakia international Dubravka joined on loan, with the option to make the transfer permanent. The signings follow recent arrivals of Tyrell Malacia, Christian Eriksen, Lisandro Martinez, and Casemiro, as United aim to improve their Premier League standings.

site_title: Tennis: Azarenka romps past Kostyuk into US Open third round
summary: Victoria Azarenka, a two-time Grand Slam champion, defeated Ukraine's Marta Kostyuk 6-2, 6-3 in the US Open second round, advancing to the third round. The match had raised concerns about a potential politically charged contest due to Azarenka's Belarusian background and Ukraine's involvement in the war. However, tensions were minimal during the match, with Kostyuk offering a perfunctory gesture after the match. Azarenka will face either Paula Badosa or Petra Martic in the third round.

site_title: Tennis: Top-ranked Swiatek cruises past ex-champ Stephens in US Open second round
summary: World number one Iga Swiatek defeated American Sloane Stephens 6-3, 6-2 in the US Open second round, advancing to the third round on Arthur Ashe Stadium. Swiatek outplayed Stephens, sending 14 winners over the net and winning over three-quarters of her first-serve points. The victory marked Swiatek's second win over Stephens this year. Swiatek will face Lauren Davis in the next round, while Serena Williams, a 23-time Grand Slam champion, retired after her loss to Anett Kontaveit in the second round, generating more attention at the tournament.

site_title: Formula One: Alonso apologises to 'legend' Hamilton after Spa spat
summary: Fernando Alonso apologized to Lewis Hamilton after calling him an "idiot" during a heated exchange following a collision at the Belgian Grand Prix. Alonso said his comments were made in the heat of the moment and were blown out of proportion, with no truth to them. He expressed respect for Hamilton, a seven-time world champion, and acknowledged that his comments could have been seen as a reflection on Hamilton's British nationality. Alonso plans to be more guarded in the future, staying quiet on the radio to avoid further controversy.

site_title: 'No clear evidence' Schooling, Lim currently taking drugs: Shanmugam
summary: Home Affairs Minister K. Shanmugam has disputed perceptions that national swimmers Joseph Schooling and Amanda Lim were given lenient treatment for consuming cannabis. Shanmugam emphasized that consumers are treated as persons needing help, with no criminal charges or records, and are sent to the Drug Rehabilitation Centre. Schooling was placed on a six-month urine-testing regimen, while Lim received a warning. Shanmugam stressed that the pair's achievements should not be negated by one mistake and that their apologies and cooperation will help in Singapore's fight against drugs.

site_title: Month-long fire drill campaign in commercial, industrial buildings returns after 2-year halt due to Covid-19
summary: Singapore has resumed a month-long fire drill campaign in commercial and industrial buildings after a two-year hiatus due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The campaign, organized by the National Fire and Emergency Preparedness Council in conjunction with the Singapore Civil Defence Force, aims to promote fire prevention and emergency preparedness. Over 58,000 participants will be involved in the drills, which include horizontal and vertical evacuation exercises at 310 buildings, starting from September. The drills are crucial in maintaining a safe environment for patients and staff in hospitals, as seen in a recent simulation at Khoo Teck Puat Hospital.

site_title: Too early to dismiss Schooling's mistake as moment of folly
summary: National swimmer Joseph Schooling revealed he used cannabis in Hanoi to train and participate in the SEA Games, sparking online reactions. Some defended his decision, viewing cannabis as a soft drug, while others criticized the move. Schooling has not publicly commented on the use of cannabis, fueling further debate. The incident has raised questions about the swimmer's approach to performance enhancement and the cultural attitudes surrounding cannabis use in Singapore.

site_title: Football: Gunfire hits Turkish Football Federation, no one hurt
summary: Assailants opened fire on the Turkish Football Federation's headquarters in Istanbul, Turkey, on Thursday, but no one was injured. Two suspects, described as drunk, were arrested shortly after the incident. Eleven shots were fired, striking the building's office and meeting room, according to Turkish Interior Minister Suleyman Soylu. An investigation is ongoing, with the federation's board meeting taking place at the time of the attack.
