site_title: CNB officer, former colleague tampered with urine sample
summary: Three Central Narcotics Bureau (CNB) officers, Muhammad Zuhairi Zainuri, Abdul Rahman Kadir, and Mohamed Hafiz Lan, were convicted of conspiring to obstruct justice by tampering with a urine sample of a suspected drug abuser, Maung Moe Min Oo. The officers, who had worked together, replaced Maung's urine sample with Hafiz's to make it appear he was clean, allowing him to leave the CNB office. Zuhairi and Abdul Rahman were each sentenced to one count of engaging in a conspiracy to intentionally obstruct the course of justice, while Hafiz was previously sentenced to 18 months' jail for a similar charge.

site_title: Firms play key role in helping those with dementia: President
summary: Singapore's President Halimah Yacob emphasized the importance of collective efforts in supporting those with dementia, as the nation's population ages. A $1 million donation from Keppel Corp's philanthropic arm to Dementia Singapore will help subsidize attendance fees for needy clients at daycare centers. President Halimah shared her personal experience of caring for her mother with dementia, highlighting the strain on caregivers. She urged everyone to play a part in building a dementia-friendly Singapore, normalizing conversations and reducing stigma through simple acts of kindness and empathy.

site_title: Company Briefs: Straits Trading
summary: Straits Trading has decided to proceed with its proposed special dividend despite not needing shareholder approval, after receiving an irrevocable undertaking from a shareholder with sufficient voting rights. H&M reported a 4% decline in sales excluding currency shifts, its first retreat in six quarters, amid a growing cost-of-living crisis in Europe. Google is making cuts to Area 120, its in-house incubator, as the tech giant moves to control spending and focus on artificial intelligence, affecting half of the teams.

site_title: Leadership contest at Athletics' AGM
summary: Singapore Athletics (SA) president Lien Choong Luen is facing a leadership contest at the association's annual general meeting. Lien is seeking a 2nd term, while Govindaraju will lead a slate of candidates to challenge him. The elections will take place at the Black Box Auditorium at the Sports Hub on Friday, with 22 affiliates casting votes to determine the next leadership team.

site_title: EC owners evicted after MCST's forced sale over unpaid fees
summary: A couple was evicted from their three-bedroom apartment at Arc@Tampines after the management corporation's strata title (MCST) force-sold the unit at an auction in April due to unpaid fees. This was a rare and complicated process, with the MCST having run out of options. The couple was affected by the MCST's actions, highlighting the difficulties of forced sales in Singapore.

site_title: New $400m grant to develop local talent in financial services
summary: Singapore has received a $400 million grant to develop local talent in the financial services industry, with the aim of maintaining its position as a global financial hub. The grant will support a new Talent and Leaders in Finance programme, which will invest in skills training for Singaporean finance professionals. The programme will focus on developing local specialists and leaders, with the goal of building a skilled and adaptable workforce. Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the importance of fostering a future-ready workforce to achieve Singapore's goal of being a leading international financial centre in Asia.

site_title: SNOC's decision on duo's money
summary: The Ministry of Culture, Community and Youth (MCCY) denied involvement in withholding Joseph Schooling and Amanda Lim's SEA Games prize money, stating it's a private award scheme managed by the Singapore National Olympic Council (SNOC). SNOC said the duo's prize money is on hold pending a review of their actions, which include a confession to consuming cannabis. The athletes will have to wait to receive their cash bonus, which was initially set at $17,500. A disciplinary committee meeting will be held to look into their cases.

site_title: Hundreds of ESG funds in Europe face reclassification
summary: Hundreds of European ESG funds face reclassification due to failure to meet the EU's strict sustainable investment requirements under the Sustainable Finance Disclosure Regulation (SFDR). Only a small fraction of funds registered as Article 9 live up to the threshold, with Morningstar estimating that 40% have a sustainable investment goal of less than 50%. Many fund managers, including Pacific Investment Management and Goldman Sachs, have already downgraded funds from Article 9 to Article 8. Regulators are struggling to interpret the rules, and the European Commission is seeking further guidance.

site_title: No pay for top management as Sea takes steps to control costs
summary: Sea Limited's top management has decided to forgo salaries until the company reaches self-sufficiency. In an internal memo, CEO Forrest Li outlined cost-cutting measures to shield the company from the economic slowdown, including capping business travel expenses, limiting hotel stays, and reducing meal and entertainment reimbursements. The company has also shut down operations in some markets and trimmed staff, with Shopee closing offices in Chile, Colombia, and Mexico. Sea aims to achieve positive cash flow as soon as possible and is focusing on core operations amidst rising interest rates, inflation, and a volatile market.

site_title: Man gets life term, caning for 'senseless' murder of jogger
summary: A 22-year-old man, Surajsrikan Diwakar Mani Tripathi, was sentenced to life imprisonment and 15 strokes of the cane for the "senseless" murder of a 38-year-old jogger, Mr Tay Rui Hao, on May 10, 2020. The killing occurred on the anniversary of the day Surajsrikan's father abandoned his family and his enlistment. Surajsrikan pleaded guilty to the charge of murder with the intention of causing fatal injury, which carries the death penalty or life imprisonment and caning.

site_title: Tennis: It was an 'honour to share all these years' with Federer, says Nadal
summary: Rafael Nadal expressed his gratitude and admiration for Roger Federer, calling their time together in tennis an "honour" after Federer announced his retirement from the sport. Federer, a 20-time Grand Slam champion, will retire after the Laver Cup in London, citing a knee problem. Nadal, who has won 10 of their 14 Grand Slam matchups, wished Federer happiness with his family and expressed excitement to share more moments together in the future, including the Laver Cup.

site_title: Singapore market edges up, tracking Wall Street's rebound
summary: The Singapore market edged up 0.3% to 3,267.98 points, driven by a rebound in Wall Street's trading, with the S&P500 index up 0.3%. Local banks, including OCBC Bank, DBS Bank, and UOB, rose 1.1%, 0.2%, and 0.1% respectively. Jardine Matheson Holdings was the biggest winner, surging 5.1%. Despite this, South Korea's Kospi lost 0.4% and Malaysian stocks dipped 0.1%.

site_title: 'Malaysian F1 race won't return soon'
summary: Malaysia is unlikely to host a Formula One (F1) race again in the near future, according to Sepang International Circuit CEO Azhan Shafriman Hanif. The government's focus on rebuilding the economy following the coronavirus pandemic has led to the decision. While the possibility of F1 returning in two to three years cannot be ruled out, the circuit officials emphasize the need for a bigger picture, including benefits such as spillover effects, rebranding, and technology transfer. The Sepang track will instead host MotoGP events, including the Malaysian Grand Prix from October 21-23.

site_title: Next 48 hours
summary: Singapore's football games for the next 48 hours are postponed as a mark of respect following the death of Football Association of Singapore president Lim Kia Tong. The postponed matches include English Premier League games between Villa and Southampton, Forest and Fulham, and Spanish Primera Liga matches between Valladolid and Cadiz. Other sports events include the Italian Open golf tournament, the Portland Classic LPGA Tour, and the Davis Cup tennis finals.

site_title: Genting-linked company among seven bidding for Macau casino licences
summary: Seven companies, including Genting-linked GMM, have bid for new Macau casino licences, with contracts set to begin in early 2023. The bidders, including Sands China, Wynn Macau, and MGM China, submitted proposals amid a broader overhaul of Macau's gaming industry legislation. The government will review the bids and announce six winners by the end of November or early December. Macau's new operators will face stricter oversight and control, including formal table caps and minimum income requirements, amid a challenging environment for new entrants.

site_title: Samsung to pump $7b into green projects, lobby Seoul to add clean energy
summary: Samsung Electronics plans to invest $7 billion in green initiatives, aiming to reverse rising emissions and zero out direct pollution by mid-century. The company aims to eliminate Scope 1 and 2 carbon emissions, switch overseas factories to renewable electricity within five years, and boost energy efficiency of its products. Samsung will lobby the South Korean government to support clean energy policies and consider using offsets in voluntary carbon markets. The company's key challenge remains South Korea's grid, with fossil fuels accounting for over 65% of electricity generation.

site_title: Real-use case of tokens remains cryptic for now
summary: The real-world value of tokens remains unclear despite the Ethereum Merge upgrade, which is the world's second-most valuable digital currency. Tokenisation, converting assets into digital assets, offers possibilities for re-engineering the financial industry. However, its true potential remains cryptic, with proponents citing a world of possibilities but no concrete evidence. The upgrade of Ethereum has sparked debate, but the fundamental question of token value remains unanswered.

site_title: S'pore EV operator gains Thai foothold
summary: Singapore-based electric vehicle operator SEV plans to supply at least 1,000 electric cars and 1,000 electric scooters to Planet Communications Asia's unit in Pattaya, Thailand, as part of a pilot program. The move aims to promote sustainable tourism and install EV charging points and battery-swop stations. If successful, SEV may expand its operations in Thailand, leveraging Planet EV's local networks. This partnership marks SEV's entry into the Thai market and follows a surge in EV sales globally, with two million vehicles sold worldwide in the first quarter of this year, up 75% from last year.

site_title: Ethereum's Merge upgrade completed
summary: Ethereum has completed its "Merge" upgrade, a software update that aims to reduce the blockchain's energy consumption by 99%. The upgrade replaces power-hungry computers with energy-efficient staking wallets, making the network more sustainable. The change also alters the properties of Ether, making it more akin to yield-bearing securities, potentially increasing its value. While the upgrade is a key step towards faster and cheaper transactions, it may cause initial hiccups and potential issues with forks and scams. Ethereum's developers have worked on the upgrade for years, with a goal of making the network more secure and efficient.

site_title: Mourners pay respects to late FAS president at wake, Jalan Besar Stadium
summary: Former Football Association of Singapore (FAS) president Lim Kia Tong, 70, died on Wednesday. A wake was held at the Singapore Funeral Parlour in Tampines, attended by dozens of visitors, including former national footballer Lim Tong Hai. Players from Singapore Premier League and Singapore Football League clubs also paid their respects at the Jalan Besar Stadium. The FAS set up a tribute space at its headquarters for people to write their condolences.

site_title: Wear the Lucky Charm in Race 2
summary: Lucky Charm, a three-year-old bay gelding, is expected to repeat his impressive debut performance in the $20,000 Open Maiden race at the Polytrack 1,000m. Trained by Michael Clements and owned by Gandharvi Stable, Lucky Charm has made significant progress, with his track gallops showing plenty of oomph. The addition of blinkers is expected to perk him up further, and he faces a weak field. Lucky Charm's sire, Maurice, is Japan's 2015 Horse of the Year, and he has a good chance of scoring at start No. 2, potentially joining his stablemate Coin Toss in winning.

site_title: Klopp pours scorn on Boehly's EPL All-Star pitch
summary: Jurgen Klopp has criticized Chelsea chairman Todd Boehly's proposal for an American-style All-Star Premier League game, calling it a "lesson from American sports" that may not be suitable for the congested English football calendar. Boehly suggested that the game could raise funds for lower levels of football in England, but Klopp questioned the feasibility of the event, comparing it to the Harlem Globetrotters and suggesting that the players would need a four-month break. Boehly also confirmed Chelsea's plans to adopt a multi-club model similar to the City Football Group.

site_title: A point to start Potter's spell
summary: Chelsea's new manager Graham Potter achieved a positive start to his tenure with a 1-1 draw against RB Salzburg in the Champions League. Despite high passing tempo and impressive performances from Raheem Sterling and Reece James, Chelsea lacked clinical edge to win. Potter praised the team's attitude and application, but acknowledged areas for improvement. The draw leaves Chelsea at the bottom of Group E with one point, with a double-header against AC Milan to come. Potter faces a tough task to avoid a group-stage exit and will lose key players during the international break.

site_title: 'Thank you for the memories'
summary: Roger Federer, a 41-year-old Swiss tennis great, has announced his retirement from competitive tennis after the Laver Cup in London next week. Federer, who won 20 Grand Slam titles and is regarded as one of the best players ever, has struggled with injuries in recent years, including three knee surgeries. He will play his final ATP event at the Laver Cup and plans to continue playing tennis in the future, but not in Grand Slams or on the tour. Federer expressed gratitude to fans, family, and opponents, saying he feels "extremely grateful" for his career and the game of tennis.

site_title: Super start for trainer Pierre Ng
summary: Pierre Ng achieved his first career victory as a trainer with 30-1 outsider Super Commander at Happy Valley on Wednesday night. Ng, who had previously served as an assistant trainer, was thrilled with the horse's performance under Luke Ferraris. The win marked a significant milestone for Ng, who had previously produced creditable results as an assistant trainer. Ng's first win was described as a "very good feeling" and a "totally different" experience from his previous role.

site_title: Amnesty poll shows fans want Fifa to pay workers
summary: A majority of World Cup fans, 73%, support Fifa compensating migrant workers for rights abuses during the 2022 Qatar tournament, according to a poll by Amnesty International. The survey of 17,000 adults from 15 countries found that 84% of fans who planned to watch the tournament backed the proposal. The poll comes amid criticism of Qatar's treatment of migrant workers, with Amnesty and other organizations urging Fifa to set aside $440 million in compensation. Fifa has previously stated it has compensated some workers, but has not publicly responded to the proposal.

site_title: 13-year-old among 9 arrested for rioting with knives in Lengkok Bahru
summary: Nine individuals, including a 13-year-old boy, have been arrested for rioting with knives in Lengkok Bahru, Singapore. The 15-year-old boy was allegedly assaulted over a prior dispute on September 2 and suffered multiple injuries. The suspects, all males aged 13-24, were arrested over the next week and charged with rioting armed with a deadly weapon. The offence carries a prison term of up to 10 years and caning. Investigations are ongoing, with the police vowing to apprehend offenders and deal with them in accordance with the law.

site_title: UOB says physical presence will help it compete in digital age
summary: UOB plans to transform its physical presence to compete in the digital age, focusing on holistic customer service through human expertise, data, and technology. The bank is revamping its physical branches in key markets, including Thailand, Vietnam, and Indonesia, to meet an omnichannel strategy. UOB aims to be the most preferred bank for consumers and businesses by 2035, with a focus on personalisation, connectivity, and sustainability. The bank is investing in digital capabilities, including an all-in-one app with AI-powered personalisation, to stay competitive amidst digital banks.

site_title: Relentless in no mood to let up
summary: Derby runner-up Relentless is set to return to racing with a comeback campaign in Singapore, starting with a Class 1 mile race on September 24. Trainer Tim Fitzsimmons believes Relentless will measure up to better horses, citing the Derby formline as a positive indicator. Relentless will then head towards the Group 1 Queen Elizabeth II Cup on October 15 and the Group 1 Singapore Gold Cup on November 19. Relentless will be ridden by Manoel Nunes in the Class 1 race and Vlad Duric in the QEII Cup.

site_title: James slams NBA's Sarver sanctions
summary: NBA commissioner Adam Silver fined and suspended Phoenix Suns owner Robert Sarver $10 million and one year for reported racist and sexist behavior, but did not ban him. NBA stars LeBron James, Chris Paul, and players' union executive director Tamika Tremaglio criticized the decision, calling it "wrong" and stating that Sarver's behavior was "unacceptable" and "toxic." The investigation found Sarver used the "N-word" at least five times, sexually harassed female employees, and cursed at workers, leading to a toxic work environment for over a decade.

site_title: Moderna's bivalent Covid-19 booster vaccine expected to arrive in Singapore by end-September
summary: Moderna's bivalent Covid-19 booster vaccine, targeting the original Sars-CoV-2 strain and Omicron BA.1 variant, is expected to arrive in Singapore by the end of September. The vaccine has been authorized for use as a booster for people aged 18 and above who have already received their primary series vaccination. Health Minister Ong Ye Kung stated that data from clinical trials show strong protection against both variants, and the risk of severe adverse reactions is comparable to the original vaccine. The safety of the vaccine is also comparable, with mostly mild-to-moderate side effects.

site_title: Three more cases of monkeypox detected in S'pore, bringing total to 19
summary: Singapore reported three new cases of monkeypox, bringing the total to 19, according to the Ministry of Health. The new cases were detected in the week between Sept 4 and Sept 10. This marks a change from the previous update on Sept 8, which reported no new cases for the week of Aug 28 to Sept 3. The outbreak was declared a global health emergency by the World Health Organisation on July 23, and most patients recover within two to four weeks without hospitalization.

site_title: Haaland's goal reminds me of Cruyff's, says Guardiola
summary: Manchester City manager Pep Guardiola compared Erling Haaland's acrobatic goal to Johan Cruyff's, praising the Norwegian striker's flexibility and ability to score despite his size. Haaland's sixth consecutive goal extended his scoring streak, while City's 2-1 win over Borussia Dortmund opened up a three-point lead at the top of Group G. Guardiola also drew comparisons to Zlatan Ibrahimovic, noting Haaland's elastic and flexible nature, which allowed him to score from a cross. The win marked a turnaround for City after a slow start, with Guardiola proud of the team's late resurgence.

site_title: Pogba's brother detained: Reports
summary: French authorities have detained Mathias Pogba, the older brother of football star Paul Pogba, in an investigation into alleged extortion. Mathias presented himself to investigators and was placed in police custody. His lawyer denies any involvement, stating that the Pogba family is being threatened by outside forces. The investigation, led by two magistrates, examines allegations of blackmail, kidnapping, and conspiracy. Paul Pogba claims he's being blackmailed with a €13 million demand if he wants to avoid compromising videos being released. The investigation's findings will be evaluated by French authorities.

images.alt_text: SMEs will receive a higher level of support, while larger companies will be eligible for a smaller quantum.
Recycling air conditioners is crucial because they contain refrigerants such as hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), which can have a significant environmental impact if not properly recovered.
CMG20250710-LooHH01 / 特约摄影骆辉煌 / KTPH trials new “smart diapers” to improve patient care Ward B76, Khoo Teck Puat Hospital [Ward B76, Khoo Teck Puat Hospital]
Those found guilty of trafficking more than 500g of cannabis, or more than 1kg of cannabis mixture, may face the death penalty.
Singapore's artistic swimmers with Ollie the Otter and Dewey the Dugong, mascots for the World Aquatics Championships Singapore 2025.
US President Donald Trump’s nominee for ambassador to Singapore, Dr Anjani Sinha (left), was grilled by Senator for Illinois Tammy Duckworth during a Senate confirmation hearing.
With the help of local tech firm NCS, the CPF Board is currently piloting a feature that can identify callers who are less tech-savvy and prioritises them to reach a call agent faster.

site_title: Jail for man who pestered cop to access police database, cheated him to fund $150,000 scam
summary: A Singaporean man, Lincoln Poh Chong Tee, 26, was sentenced to 12 months' jail for his role in a $150,000 money exchange scam. Poh, who recruited friends to help him, including a police officer, Bryan Tay Wei Chuan, who was forced to access the police database to verify the identity of a scammer. Poh used the information to fund the scam, which involved cheating a woman, Lin Chun Yan, out of $80,600. Four others involved in the scam have been dealt with or are facing charges, while the scammer Raymond remains at large.

site_title: All Blacks pip Wallabies in classic clash
summary: The All Blacks edged out the Wallabies 39-37 in a thrilling Bledisloe Cup match, winning the trans-Tasman series for a 20th consecutive year. The match featured a series of injuries, including both team captains, and ended in controversy when referee Mathieu Raynal took the ball away from Australia's flyhalf Bernard Foley for time-wasting despite the clock being off. Jordie Barrett scored a late try for New Zealand, securing the win and the Bledisloe Cup. The All Blacks remain top of the Rugby Championship table, four points ahead of Australia.

site_title: New attraction Central Beach Bazaar opens at Sentosa, as visitor numbers rise
summary: Sentosa Island in Singapore has opened its fourth new attraction, Central Beach Bazaar, featuring an 80m-tall Sentosa SkyJet fountain, the return of the Sentosa Musical Fountain, and a multi-concept food street. The attraction joins other recent additions, including SkyHelix Sentosa, Southside, and Scentopia Sentosa. Visitor numbers to the island have risen by 48% between April and August compared to the same period in 2021, with Sentosa attracting almost 50% more visitors since the easing of border measures.

site_title: Police report made against retailer over 'mystery' items sold at tech show
summary: A report has been lodged against retailer The Auction House in Singapore over the sale of "mystery" items at a tech show. The items were sold in parcels for $6, sparking a frenzy among bargain hunters. The police confirmed that the activities may be illegal under Singapore law, which prohibits mystery boxes. Experts say that if properly regulated, mystery boxes can be fun for consumers and a useful sales mechanism for retailers, but there is a need for clearer guidelines on what will be allowed. Investigations are ongoing.

site_title: LIV players shouldn't be on Team Europe, says McIlroy
summary: Rory McIlroy reiterated his stance against having LIV Golf players on Team Europe at the 2023 Ryder Cup, stating that he doesn't think they should be on the team. Despite some uncertainty surrounding European players, McIlroy believes a rebuild was needed and that the team can be strengthened with rookies. Matt Fitzpatrick, on the other hand, is more neutral, focusing on winning the Ryder Cup rather than the team's composition. The PGA Tour has made changes to increase competitiveness and competitiveness, but McIlroy remains opposed to LIV Golf players participating.

site_title: Serena hints at retirement U-turn
summary: Serena Williams dropped a hint on ABC's Good Morning America that she might not be done with competitive tennis after seemingly retiring at the US Open. The 23-time Grand Slam champion mentioned NFL star Tom Brady's example of a retirement U-turn, saying "you never know" if she'll return to the sport. Williams, 40, has been "evolving" away from tennis, but indicated a desire to remain involved in the sport in some capacity, citing its positive impact on her life.

site_title: Valverde's rocking feet has Ancelotti purring
summary: Real Madrid coach Carlo Ancelotti praised midfielder Federico Valverde, saying he'll give up his coaching license if Valverde doesn't score at least 10 goals this season. Valverde scored his third goal in eight appearances in a 2-0 win over RB Leipzig. The victory kept Real top of Group F, while Juventus coach Massimiliano Allegri expressed confidence despite a 2-1 loss to Benfica, stating he doesn't feel his job is at risk. PSG also won 3-1 at Maccabi Haifa, with Lionel Messi, Kylian Mbappe, and Neymar scoring.

site_title: Sports World : Non-binary option in London Marathon
summary: The 2023 London Marathon will offer a non-binary gender option for entrants, part of a drive to make the event more diverse and inclusive. The Boston Marathon also announced a similar change. The London Marathon returns to its traditional April slot after a four-year hiatus due to the coronavirus. Meanwhile, Eintracht Frankfurt has been charged with racist behaviour and throwing objects by Uefa after their Champions League win in Marseille. Barcelona midfielder Gavi signed a contract extension with a €1.4 billion release clause, and former coach Alan Pardew has joined Aris Thessaloniki for a one-year contract.

site_title: S'pore EV operator gains Thai foothold in bid to expand
summary: Singapore-based electric vehicle operator SEV plans to supply at least 1,000 electric cars and 1,000 electric scooters to Thai-listed telecom equipment distributor Planet Communications Asia's new EV unit, Planet EV, in Pattaya. The partnership aims to promote sustainable tourism and provide users with online booking and return options. If successful, it could pave the way for SEV to expand its operations in Thailand, leveraging Planet EV's local networks and contacts.

site_title: Owners evicted from Arc@Tampines unit after MCST's forced sale to recover unpaid maintenance fees
summary: A Singapore couple was evicted from their Arc@Tampines apartment after the management corporation's strata title (MCST) forced sold the unit at an auction to recover unpaid maintenance fees of approximately $36,000. The owners had repeatedly failed to pay bills, leading the MCST to take drastic measures. The forced sale is rare and complex, with the MCST having exhausted other options before proceeding with the auction. The couple was subsequently evicted from the unit.

site_title: More businesses can join in efforts to help those with dementia, caregivers: President Halimah
summary: President Halimah Yacob announced that businesses can join efforts to support those with dementia and caregivers in Singapore. Keppel Corporation's philanthropic arm donated $1 million to Dementia Singapore, funding daycare services for needy clients and subsidizing attendance fees. The donation aims to reduce stigma and increase awareness about dementia. Halimah shared her personal experience with her mother's dementia, highlighting the need for collective efforts to build a dementia-friendly Singapore.

site_title: New private home sales slump in August amid Hungry Ghost month, limited unsold stock
summary: New private home sales in Singapore slumped to a 28-month low in August, with 437 residential units sold, a 47.6% drop from July. This marked the lowest monthly sales since April 2020. The slump was attributed to limited unsold stock and a lack of new condominium launches, with 134 units launched in August, a 66.7% decrease from July. However, analysts expect sales to improve with upcoming launches and robust sales by Sky Eden@Bedok and AMO Residence.

site_title: Tennis: Roger Federer to retire after next week's Laver Cup
summary: Roger Federer, widely regarded as the greatest male tennis player, has announced his retirement after the Laver Cup in London next week. The 41-year-old, who won 20 Grand Slam singles titles, cited his age and recent injuries as reasons for his decision. Federer, who has played over 1,500 matches, will continue to play tennis in the future, but not in Grand Slams or on the tour. His retirement is a significant loss to the sport, with many of his peers and fans expressing their gratitude and admiration for his contributions to tennis.

site_title: Travellers flying out of Changi Airport to pay higher charges from Nov 1
summary: Passengers flying out of Changi Airport in Singapore will face higher charges starting November 1, with a total departure fee increasing from $52.30 to $59.20. The fee hike will also apply to airlines, with increased aircraft parking and landing fees. The charges will fund airport operations, terminal upgrades, and future development plans, including the upcoming Changi Airport Terminal 5. The fee increase comes as international air travel recovers from the Covid-19 pandemic, with passengers averaging 58% of 2019 levels and airlines facing rising fuel prices.

site_title: What is the real-use case of tokens in global economies?
summary: Critics argue that tokens lack a real use case beyond speculative returns. Despite the Ethereum merge, the value of tokens remains uncertain. Tokenisation, which converts assets into digital assets, is seen as a potential game-changer, but its benefits are still debated. Proponents claim it can reengineer the traditional financial industry architecture, but the fundamental question of tokens' value remains unanswered. The real-world application of tokens is yet to be proven, leaving their true value uncertain.

site_title: From NEWater to vertical farming: Key milestones in Singapore’s 50-year journey towards sustainability
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Sustainability and Environment (MSE) has marked 50 years of efforts to build a greener and more sustainable nation. The ministry has contributed to significant improvements in public health, food and water security, and environmental sustainability. Key milestones include the transformation of the Singapore River, the relocation of street hawkers, the expansion of the sewerage network, and the introduction of NEWater and desalination plants. The ministry has also invested in initiatives to promote water conservation, reduce waste, and increase local food production. Through its various efforts, MSE has helped to create a cleaner, healthier, and more resilient Singapore, with a strong focus on sustainability and environmental stewardship.

site_title: BT Podcasts: S-Reits - good hedge against inflation?
summary: Singapore real estate investment trusts (Reits) can still perform well despite a rough start to 2022, according to Vijay Natarajan, RHB Singapore's real estate and Reits analyst. Rising interest rates may impact inflation, but Reits can serve as a hedge against inflation. However, S-Reits face growing competition, and a global recession could further affect their performance. Natarajan suggests rebalancing portfolio segments and staying up to date with market trends to navigate the current volatility.

site_title: Samsung to invest $7 billion under plan to tame rising emissions
summary: Samsung Electronics plans to invest $7 billion in green initiatives to eliminate Scope 1 and 2 carbon emissions by mid-century. The company aims to switch overseas factories to renewable electricity within five years and domestic plants to 100% renewables by 2027. Samsung will also lobby South Korea's government for policy support and consider using offsets in voluntary carbon markets. The move comes as the company faces criticism for its slower approach to climate action compared to peers like Apple.

site_title: NHB's latest on-site heritage galleries feature Chinatown businesses
summary: The National Heritage Board's Street Corner Heritage Galleries in Chinatown feature 11 heritage businesses showcasing their past history through "mini-museums". Spring Court Restaurant, established in 1929, and Tong Heng, founded in 1910, are among the featured businesses, highlighting their evolution and traditional practices. The scheme aims to raise public awareness of heritage businesses and provide funding for talks, workshops, and events, with the goal of making these precincts "living showcases" of heritage.

site_title: Firm barred over safety lapse: Worker who fell 8m through roof discharged from hospital
summary: A worker from waterproofing company Le Fong Building Services fell 8m through a roof, resulting in a two-week hospital stay. The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) barred the company from hiring new foreign employees and issued a stop-work order due to its unsafe work practices. An inspection found the company failed to implement a proper safety system, posing an imminent danger to other workers. The company's managing director, William Lim, was held accountable and must rectify the situation before the stop-work order can be lifted.

site_title: No pay for Sea CEO, top management amid deepening cash flow woes
summary: Sea Limited's top management, including CEO Forrest Li, will forgo their salaries until the company reaches self-sufficiency. The leadership team will also implement cost-cutting measures, including capping business travel expenses and limiting hotel stays. The company is facing deepening cash flow woes amid economic slowdown and rising interest rates, with market value losing about $170 billion since October. Sea aims to achieve positive cash flow as soon as possible and is withdrawing from some markets to focus on profitability. The company's gaming arm Garena is expected to post its first decline in bookings this year.

site_title: 22-year-old facilitator charged with causing death of ACS(I) student who fell from Safra rope course
summary: A 22-year-old outdoor activities facilitator, Muhammad Nurul Hakim Mohamed Din, has been charged with causing the death of 15-year-old ACS(I) student Jethro Puah Xin Yang who fell from a rope course at Safra Yishun in 2021. Hakim is accused of failing to properly fit Jethro's safety harness, leading to the teen's death from traumatic asphyxia and multiple organ failure. Hakim faces up to five years' jail and a fine, and was granted bail of $10,000.

site_title: Ethereum completes long-awaited energy-saving 'Merge' upgrade
summary: Ethereum has completed its long-awaited energy-saving "Merge" upgrade, replacing power-hungry computers with a more energy-efficient setup using staked Ether. The upgrade reduces Ethereum's energy consumption by 99%. The Merge does not change the end-user experience but marks a key step towards faster and cheaper upgrades. Staked Ether is expected to generate a 5.2% return, making it more attractive to investors. The upgrade may be followed by hiccups, and the creation of copies of Ethereum on forked chains raises concerns about confusion and potential attacks.

site_title: Tennis: Serena Williams says Brady's NFL retirement U-turn 'really cool trend'
summary: Serena Williams, a 23-time Grand Slam champion, dropped a hint that she might not be done with tennis after making a farewell at the US Open. She cited Tom Brady's NFL retirement U-turn as a "really cool trend" and stated that she feels "evolving" away from tennis. Williams, 40, said she's unsure if she'll continue to compete but wants to keep a "foot" in the sport, possibly through business or motherhood. Her sister, Venus, has been trying to get her to make a comeback, but Serena remains undecided.

site_title: DPM Heng meets Ho Chi Minh City's leaders as he wraps up visit to Vietnam
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat met with Ho Chi Minh City's leaders, including party secretary Nguyen Van Nen and chairman Phan Van Mai, during his visit to Vietnam. The meeting aimed to step up cooperation between the two cities and strengthen their economic ties. Heng also visited the Vietnam-Singapore Industrial Park, where he expressed his appreciation for the growth of the initiative. He met with Vietnam Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh and reaffirmed the bilateral commitment to deepen cooperation in areas like the digital economy, green economy, and innovation.

site_title: Basketball: NBA stars decry league's ruling on Suns owner
summary: NBA Commissioner Adam Silver fined and suspended Phoenix Suns owner Robert Sarver $10 million and one year, respectively, for reported racist and sexist behavior, but not banned. NBA stars LeBron James, Chris Paul, and players' union executive director Tamika Tremaglio criticized the ruling, calling it "wrong" and "short." The investigation found Sarver used the "N-word" at least five times, sexually harassed female employees, and cursed at workers, creating a toxic work environment. The punishment fell short, according to critics, who argue Sarver's behavior should have led to a ban.

site_title: Australia seen dodging recession even as China economy slows
summary: Australia's economy is expected to avoid recession in the coming year despite China's slowing economy and inflationary pressures. The country's strong labor market, low unemployment, and high savings rate are helping households cope with rising borrowing costs. A cash windfall from export prices and a weaker currency are also contributing to a soft landing. Key indicators, such as the yield curve and employment-to-population ratio, support this view, with the chance of recession in Australia next year at 25%, compared to 60% in Britain and 50% in the US.

site_title: ST CloseUp: Our sons - gay Singaporeans grapple with 377A and other challenges
summary: In Singapore, gay men like Kaal Hamid, Muhammad Faliqh, Jerome Chan, and Eugene Tan face challenges due to the country's laws and societal attitudes. The government's plan to repeal Section 377A, which criminalizes sex between men, has brought some relief. However, many believe it will take time for Singaporeans to fully accept gay individuals. The government has announced plans to amend the Constitution to protect the definition of marriage as between a man and woman and has stated policies on public housing, adoption, and education will remain unchanged.

site_title: Future Turn may get his win sooner
summary: South Africa's Durbanville track will host several key horse racing events. Future Turn is a likely winner in the 1,800M Race 4, having finished close in his previous starts over shorter distances. Charlie Malone and Max the Otter are expected to compete well in Race 1, while I'll Slip Away and Strawberry Light are on the shortlist for Race 2. The 1,000M Race 7 features African Rain, who has not been disgraced in recent starts, and Resonate, who has a favorable riding arrangement.

site_title: Man charged over allegedly carrying truncheon, hiding knuckle-duster in his underwear
summary: A 21-year-old man, Mohamed Danish Amsyar Ali Amran, was charged with possession of a truncheon and knuckle-duster in public, as well as violating his electronic monitoring tag. He allegedly evaded police in Bugis, running away when ordered to stop. Caught in Bencoolen Street, he was subdued without injury. Danish faces up to five years in jail and six strokes of the cane for the offenses. He was denied bail and will return to court on September 30.

site_title: Google cuts funding, jobs at its new-project incubator
summary: Google is cutting funding and jobs at its Area 120 incubator, a program that supports new projects. Some teams have had their projects reorganized or canceled, with affected workers needing to find new roles or risk losing their jobs. Area 120 will focus on AI-related projects, and impacted team members will receive support. The move is part of Google's efforts to control spending and prioritize critical roles amid a potential economic recession.

site_title: French aircraft train with RSAF in S'pore as part of operations in region
summary: The Republic of Singapore Air Force (RSAF) and French Air and Space Force (FASF) conducted joint training exercises in Singapore as part of the Pegase mission, a month-long operation to boost France's presence in the Asia-Pacific region. Six aircraft, including two Rafale fighter jets, were deployed, and French Ambassador Marc Abensour flew on one of the planes. The training exercises, which began on Wednesday and will end on Friday, aim to enhance interoperability between the two air forces, following the signing of a mutual logistics support arrangement in June.

site_title: Govt not involved in decision to withhold Schooling, Lim's SEA Games prize money: MCCY
summary: The Ministry of Culture, Community and Youth (MCCY) has denied involvement in withholding prize money from national swimmers Joseph Schooling and Amanda Lim, who were absent from the MAP Awards ceremony due to their cannabis use. The Singapore National Olympic Council (SNOC) confirmed that the prize money is on hold pending a review of the athletes' conduct, which includes a stipulated code of conduct as part of their team membership agreement. Both Schooling and Lim have been issued warnings and apologies for their mistakes, and a disciplinary committee will convene to look into their cases.

site_title: Singapore's greening journey marks milestone with 50 trees planted at Punggol Waterway Park
summary: Singapore's greening journey marked a milestone with the planting of 50 trees at Punggol Waterway Park, 59 years after the first tree planting campaign in 1963. Minister for Sustainability and Environment Grace Fu commemorated the 50th anniversary of her ministry, highlighting the country's commitment to balancing environmental protection with economic growth and social inclusion. The event contributes to the OneMillionTrees movement, aiming to transform Singapore into a City in Nature by planting a million trees by 2030.

site_title: Football: Aris Thessaloniki hire Pardew as coach
summary: Former Premier League coach Alan Pardew has signed a one-year contract with Greek club Aris Thessaloniki, replacing Argentine coach German Burgos. Pardew, 61, has a philosophy and wants to make his own interventions, with the option for an additional season. Aris are sixth in the Greek league after four matches, with traditional powers Panathinaikos, PAOK Thessaloniki, and Olympiakos at the top three spots. Pardew has a history of success, including leading West Ham to the Premier League and the FA Cup final.

site_title: New $400 million grant to develop local workforce for financial services
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong announced a new $400 million grant to support the development of a local workforce for the financial services industry. The grant will be used to enhance skills training and foster a skilled and adaptable workforce, in line with the refreshed Financial Services Industry Transformation Map (ITM) 2025. The ITM aims to maintain Singapore's lead as a global financial hub and includes five pillars: asset class strengths, digitalization, Asia's net-zero transition, financial networks, and workforce development. A new Talent and Leaders in Finance programme will be rolled out, investing in skills training and developing more Singaporean finance specialists and leaders.

site_title: 3 men charged over alleged money-laundering activities linked to $4.5m scam
summary: Three Chinese nationals, Zhuang Qianbao, Liu Xin, and Liu Jiannan, have been charged with money-laundering activities linked to a $4.5 million investment scam. The men allegedly used bank accounts to receive and withdraw ill-gotten gains, with the women facilitating the process by handing over cash. Preliminary investigations revealed the use of automated teller machine cards and cryptocurrencies to launder the funds. The police vowed to take action against those allowing their accounts to be used for illegal purposes, warning the public to reject requests to open or sell bank accounts linked to criminal activities.

site_title: Temasek's CLA Real Estate sets up life sciences investment company
summary: CLA Real Estate Holdings, a subsidiary of Temasek, has established ClavystBio, a life sciences investment company. Led by CEO Christopher Laing, ClavystBio has made US$220 million in investment commitments to six early-stage companies and three venture partners. The company plans to develop a purpose-built innovation district with collaborative life sciences infrastructure, as well as create programs to drive industry expertise and intellectual property translation. ClavystBio aims to support companies in emerging fields such as cell and gene therapy, biomarkers, and digital health, positioning Singapore as an attractive location for life sciences companies to start and grow.

site_title: S'pore's drug policy not determined by external parties, but the interest of its citizens: Shanmugam
summary: Singapore's drug policy and penalties are determined by the country's best interests, according to Home Affairs and Law Minister K. Shanmugam. The evolving stances in regional countries, such as Thailand's legalization of cannabis, do not influence Singapore's stance. Instead, the country faces challenges due to increased availability of controlled drugs, which are deemed bad for society by the majority of Singaporeans. Shanmugam cited negative effects in other countries, like Sweden's bombings by drug-linked gangs and the US opioid crisis, to justify maintaining its current approach.

site_title: Asset managers facing hundreds of ESG fund downgrades
summary: Prominent asset managers in Europe are facing hundreds of ESG fund downgrades following EU guidance, with over 300 Article 9 funds at risk of losing their designation due to failing to meet sustainability thresholds. Only a small fraction of Article 9 funds live up to the EU's strictest ESG category, and regulators are struggling to interpret the rules. Asset managers may reclassify funds from Article 9 to Article 8 or enhance their Article 9 strategies to comply with EU requirements, with the EU Commission expected to provide further clarification.

site_title: CNB officer and his ex-colleague convicted over tampering with drug abuser's urine sample
summary: Two former Central Narcotics Bureau (CNB) officers, Muhammad Zuhairi Zainuri and Abdul Rahman Kadir, have been convicted of conspiring to tamper with a urine sample of a drug abuser, Maung Moe Min Oo, to expedite his departure from the CNB office. The officers tampered with the sample by replacing it with Zuhairi's urine, which tested negative for drugs. Maung was allowed to leave after no trace of drugs was found in the sample. Zuhairi, 34, and Abdul Rahman, 46, were each convicted of one count of engaging in a conspiracy to intentionally obstruct the course of justice and will face disciplinary proceedings.

site_title: HDB, condo rents rise again
summary: HDB flat rents rose 2.4% and condominium rents 3.2% in September, marking the 26th consecutive month of HDB rent growth and 20th for condominium rents. These increases follow previous rises, indicating continued upward pressure on housing costs in Singapore.

site_title: Moderna's Spikevax bivalent Covid-19 vaccine: How safe is it?
summary: Moderna's Spikevax bivalent Covid-19 vaccine, targeting both the ancestral and Omicron variants, has received interim authorisation from Singapore's Health Sciences Authority. The vaccine is expected to arrive in Singapore by the end of September, primarily for booster shots in people aged 18 and above. Safety trials show comparable mild to moderate side effects, and the HSA will monitor its safety. Current vaccines remain highly protective against severe disease, and Singaporeans are advised to receive their vaccinations without delay.

site_title: Football: Valverde strike earns Real narrow Champions League win over Leipzig
summary: Real Madrid secured a 2-0 win over RB Leipzig in the Champions League, maintaining their 100% start to the campaign. Late strikes from Federico Valverde (80th minute) and Marco Asensio (stoppage time) sealed the victory. The win kept Madrid top of Group F with six points, ahead of Shakhtar Donetsk. Real Madrid have now won all eight games this season, with coach Carlo Ancelotti praising Valverde's form and Asensio's late contribution.

site_title: EU green finance advisers walk out in protest
summary: Five non-profit civil society groups, including the World Wide Fund for Nature, have resigned from the European Commission's Platform on Sustainable Finance in protest of the EU's interference in their work. The groups claim their recommendations on excluding gas and nuclear power plants from the EU Taxonomy were ignored. Despite EU law requiring the taxonomy to follow scientific evidence, the groups say their recommendations were overridden by intense lobbying from companies and member states. The resignation comes as the EU prepares to set out the mandate for the next stage of the taxonomy.

site_title: Affiliates head to the polls to decide next leadership of Singapore Athletics
summary: Singapore Athletics president Lien Choong Luen is seeking re-election for a second consecutive term, facing a challenge from former vice-president Govindaraju Sinnappan. The elections, held during the annual general meeting, will see 22 affiliates cast votes to determine the association's next leadership. Govindaraju's team promises to decentralize development, increase pathways for national athletes, and strengthen affiliates. The outcome is seen as crucial, given Singapore's strong performance at the recent SEA Games, where athletes picked up 11 medals.

site_title: Driver who hit pedestrian in police chase pleads guilty
summary: A 36-year-old driver, Vaswani Richard Prakash, pleaded guilty to charges including dangerous driving causing grievous hurt and driving while under disqualification. He was involved in a 5-minute police chase on the Pan-Island Expressway after speeding and evading authorities, resulting in a crash that injured a pedestrian. Prakash, who was out on bail for earlier offences, also pleaded guilty to drug abuse and other traffic offenses. The victim, who suffered multiple leg injuries, underwent surgery and may have permanent knee pain.

site_title: About 80 teachers complete attachment to various industries
summary: About 80 teachers out of 150 who participated in the Teacher Work Attachment Plus programme have completed stints in various industries such as manufacturing and environment. The programme aims to bring fresh perspectives to the classroom by providing teachers with work exposure, potentially every five years. Education Minister Chan Chun Sing emphasized the importance of teachers' personal growth and connecting theory with practice, highlighting the potential to motivate students to keep learning and equip teachers with new skill sets to support students.

site_title: Formula One: F1 unlikely to return to Malaysia anytime soon, says circuit chief
summary: Formula One is unlikely to return to Malaysia anytime soon due to the country's focus on rebuilding its economy after the COVID-19 pandemic. The Sepang International Circuit's CEO, Azhan Shafriman Hanif, stated that the government may reconsider hosting the event in two to three years when the economy stabilizes. To return, the government would need to assess the benefits and costs, including technology transfer, talent development, and environmental sustainability. The circuit is promoting the upcoming MotoGP event at Sepang instead, citing its success as a multi-faceted event.

site_title: Govt unveils transformation plan for financial sector; to add at least 3,000 jobs a year
summary: Singapore's updated financial sector transformation plan, led by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), aims to grow the sector by 4-5% annually from 2021 to 2025 and create 3,000-4,000 net jobs. The plan includes initiatives to digitalize financial infrastructure, support Asia's net-zero transition, and foster a skilled workforce. Key strategies include setting up a digital platform for small businesses, promoting philanthropy, and incentivizing financial technology start-ups to develop capabilities in new technologies. The plan also includes a $100 million grant to support sustainable and transition financing.

site_title: Football: Salzburg hold Chelsea to 1-1 Champions League draw
summary: Chelsea's 2021 Champions League winners suffered a 1-1 draw against Salzburg, severely denting their chances of qualifying from Group E. Raheem Sterling scored in the 48th minute, but Salzburg equalized through Noah Okafor in the 75th minute. The result left Chelsea with one point, bottom of the group, after losing their first game to Dinamo Zagreb last week. The draw was Chelsea's first under new coach Graham Potter, who acknowledged that the team needs to improve in "little details" to achieve success.

site_title: China braces for slowdown that could be worse than 2020
summary: China's economy is bracing for a slowdown, with growth projections down to 3.5% for the year, the second-weakest annual reading in over four decades. The country's strict Covid-19-zero policy, housing market collapse, drought, and weak demand are major contributors to the economic slowdown. Several major banks now predict that a 3% growth rate is unachievable, and economists warn of a difficult period if the policy is gradually eased, with widespread disruptions to business and consumer activity. The housing crisis has also undermined the wealth of Chinese households, and the manufacturing sector is struggling due to weak demand and inventory buildup.

site_title: 3-year-old S'porean girl dies of Covid-19
summary: A 3-year-old Singaporean girl died of a Covid-19 infection on Tuesday, becoming the third death of a patient under 12 due to the virus. The girl, who had multiple medical conditions prior to contracting Covid-19, tested positive on August 9 and died from anoxic brain injury due to cardiac arrest and Covid-19. This is part of Singapore's 1,604 Covid-19 deaths since the pandemic began in 2020.

site_title: Football: Benfica fight back to inflict more Champions League misery on Juventus
summary: Benfica secured a 2-1 win over Juventus in Champions League Group H, maintaining their perfect start in the competition. Juventus took an early lead with a fourth-minute goal from Arkadiusz Milik, but Benfica equalized with a penalty from Joao Mario in the 43rd minute. David Neres sealed the win for Benfica with a goal in the 55th minute, as Juventus slumped to their first two group stage losses in Champions League history. Benfica are now second in the group with six points, level with Paris St Germain.

site_title: US stocks close slightly higher as inflation data weighs
summary: US stocks closed slightly higher on Wednesday, regaining some lost ground from the prior session, despite disappointing inflation data still affecting markets. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.1%, the S&P 500 increased 0.3%, and the Nasdaq Composite climbed 0.7%. Investors remain cautious, bracing for a potential interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve next week. Individual companies saw mixed results, with Starbucks rising 5.5% on upgraded revenue and profit forecasts, while Union Pacific dropped 3.7% due to a looming freight railroad strike.

site_title: Seven companies bid for new casino licences in Macau
summary: Seven companies, including Sands China, Wynn Macau, and Galaxy Entertainment, have submitted bids for new casino licences in Macau, set to start in early 2023. The Macau government will review proposals and negotiate terms before announcing six winners by the end of November. The new licence holders will face a 10-year concession period, with Macau imposing formal table caps and minimum income requirements to tighten oversight and control over casino operators. The move aims to revamp the industry, which generated $36 billion in revenue in 2019 before the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Case to engage STB, CAAS on overbooking in travel sector
summary: Singapore's consumer watchdog will engage the Singapore Tourism Board and the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore to address concerns about overbooking by cruise operators and airlines. Following an incident where over 100 customers couldn't board a cruise ship due to overbooking, the Consumers Association of Singapore has received three complaints about overbooking this year, with two in 2020 and last year combined. Experts caution that regulations may pose a cost burden to operators, while others suggest guidelines for travel services could address the issue.

site_title: Football: Front three all score as PSG fight back to beat Haifa in Champions League
summary: Paris Saint-Germain came from a goal down to beat Maccabi Haifa 3-1 in the Champions League, with Lionel Messi, Kylian Mbappe, and Neymar all scoring for the French team. Messi equalized before the break and PSG finished off their hosts with an improved performance in the last half-hour. The win puts PSG top of Group H on goals scored, ahead of Benfica. The match marked two consecutive wins for PSG in the Champions League group stage.

site_title: Punggol Field murder: Man gets life term, caning for stabbing jogger in 'senseless' killing
summary: A 22-year-old man, Surajsrikan Diwakar Mani Tripathi, was sentenced to life imprisonment and 15 strokes of the cane for stabbing a 38-year-old jogger, Mr Tay Rui Hao, in a "senseless" killing in Punggol Field, Singapore, on May 10, 2020. Surajsrikan, who had a history of anxiety and obsessive-compulsive disorder, tripped during his nightly jog and attacked the victim after feeling frustrated and angry. The court heard that the date of the incident was significant for Surajsrikan, as it marked the anniversary of his father abandoning his family and his enlistment.

site_title: Private home sales hit the brakes as curbs cool demand
summary: Private home sales in Singapore slowed in the first six months of this year, with 13,311 units sold compared to 37,433 in 2021. The decline is attributed to cooling measures introduced in December last year, which raised buyer's stamp duty rates for foreigners and citizens buying multiple properties. Despite this, overall sales are expected to exceed 2020's transactions, but are unlikely to surpass last year's nine-year high. The proportion of permanent residents and foreigners buying property increased, while Singaporeans accounted for 80.2% of transactions.

site_title: No major disruption to Singapore's rice imports from India's levy move
summary: Singapore's rice imports from India remain unaffected by the recent 20% levy on exports of key varieties and ban on broken rice exports. The country's Rice Stockpile Scheme has helped mitigate the impact of any supply disruptions or price fluctuations. Despite this, some businesses, such as Mustafa Centre and Chennai Trading and Supermarket, plan to increase prices by 20% due to the Indian government's export tax, which has further inflated the price of rice. The government will continue to monitor the situation and ensure a sufficient supply of rice.

site_title: Football: Haaland hurts Dortmund with brilliant late strike in Champions League
summary: Manchester City secured a 2-1 win over Borussia Dortmund in the Champions League, thanks to an 84th-minute goal from Erling Haaland. Haaland scored his 13th goal in eight games with a brilliant finish, leaping to guide home a cross with the outside of his boot. City came from behind after Jude Bellingham scored for Dortmund in the 66th minute, but Haaland's goal sealed the win. The match marked City's second consecutive group win, putting them top of the standings with six points.

site_title: Must-reads
summary: The global job market remains tight, with numerous job vacancies unfilled despite resident employment surpassing pre-pandemic levels. Retrenchments have reached record lows, and the unemployment rate has dipped. Bollywood actor Amitabh Bachchan has been recruited to promote the use of coins in India. In Malaysia, Sultanah Nur Diana Petra Abdullah, the new queen consort, held her first public engagement following her secret marriage. In Singapore, concerns have been raised about overbooking practices by cruise operators and airlines, prompting a probe. Several fitness studios have also allegedly closed down without notice.

site_title: S'pore gives interim nod for Moderna's bivalent vaccine
summary: The Health Sciences Authority (HSA) of Singapore has granted interim authorization for the use of Moderna's Spikevax bivalent Covid-19 vaccine, targeting the original Sars-CoV-2 strain and the Omicron BA.1 variant. The vaccine is approved for use as a booster for individuals aged 18 and above who have already received their primary series vaccination. The vaccine's safety profile is comparable to Moderna's original vaccine, with mild to moderate side effects, and it is expected to provide broader immunity against circulating variants while retaining critical protection against severe disease and death.

site_title: How the tide turned on data centres in Europe
summary: European countries' enthusiasm for data centers has turned sour due to their high energy and water consumption. The industry's impact on energy supplies has been exacerbated by the war in Ukraine, leading to energy shortages and rocketing bills. Grassroots campaigns and local opposition have halted projects in several countries, including Ireland, where the government has implemented strict limits on new developments until 2028. The data industry argues that it is working to source green energy, but critics say there is a lack of transparency about data storage and that the industry's carbon footprint will be difficult to assess due to its increasing reliance on emerging technologies like the metaverse.

site_title: Improving public transport helps tackle climate change: Jakarta Governor
summary: Jakarta Governor Anies Baswedan emphasized the importance of improving public transport in addressing climate change, stating that increased use of public transport reduces greenhouse gas emissions. Under his administration, Jakarta's public transport coverage has doubled from 40% to 90%, and the city has reduced carbon emissions by 26%. Baswedan also highlighted that the improved public transport system promotes equal treatment of people from different socio-economic backgrounds, reducing segregation in the city.

site_title: Court told lawyer Charles Yeo who absconded remains at large
summary: Lawyer Charles Yeo, 32, who absconded from Singapore, has not returned despite a warrant of arrest being issued against him. His full bail amount of $15,000 was forfeited. Yeo, former chairman of the Reform Party, had sought asylum in the UK and was working with foreign counterparts to trace his whereabouts. A review on the warrant is scheduled for March 29 next year. Yeo was previously allowed to leave Singapore to meet a witness but failed to return, leading to the issuance of the warrant.

site_title: Total employment hits 99.5% of pre-pandemic level
summary: Singapore's labour market has reached 99.5% of pre-pandemic levels, driven by significant employment growth. Job vacancies fell to record lows, while the unemployment rate dipped further to 2.1% in July. Total employment grew by 66,500 in the second quarter, with non-residents contributing 59,400 of the increase. Retrenchments also fell to 990, a record low. The recruitment rate rose to 2.6% and the resident long-term unemployment rate declined to 0.7%.

site_title: F1 festivities back after two-year break
summary: The Formula 1 Singapore Grand Prix is set to return after a two-year hiatus, with festivities to take place at four locations - Sentosa, Orchard Road, Clarke Quay, and Kampong Glam - from September 23 to October 2. Flight bookings into Singapore have increased by 305% since the start of the year, with Oceania seeing a 17% rise in visitor numbers. The events, including parties and activities, aim to complement the racing experience and showcase Singapore's offerings.

site_title: Police reports lodged against 2 fitness studios allegedly closed overnight
summary: Two fitness studios, Kyklos Studio and X Fitness, run by Mr. Atlas Ang, have allegedly closed down overnight, leaving customers with unfulfilled bookings and unpaid deposits. Several police reports have been lodged against the studios, and customers are seeking refunds for packages ranging from $200 to $600. The studios' websites and social media pages have been taken down, and the owners have not been contactable. Authorities are investigating the matter, and the Consumers Association of Singapore has informed affected customers of available recourse.

site_title: The Merlion turns 50: How would you 'remake' the national icon?
summary: The Merlion, Singapore's national icon, is celebrating its 50th birthday. Created by British zoologist Alec Fraser-Brunner in 1972, the statue was designed by local sculptor Lim Nang Seng and built by him after winning a design competition. Originally located at the mouth of the Singapore River, it was moved to its current site at One Fullerton in 1997. The Merlion has become a popular tourist spot, with replicas found worldwide, and has undergone various transformations, including a 2011 pop-up hotel installation. To commemorate its 50th birthday, visitors are invited to reimagine the Merlion and submit their ideas.
